Title: Activists Prepare for Intense Battle Over Supreme Court Nominee and Abortion Rights

Article:

Washington, D.C. - The confirmation process for the next Supreme Court justice is expected to be a contentious battle, as demonstrated by the early mobilization of abortion rights activists. Two Republican senators, Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) and Susan Collins (R-ME), are being targeted by these activists due to their potential opposition to the nominee and their pro-choice stance.

The National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League (NARAL) has been actively engaging with 10,000 activists this week, discussing the potential threats to abortion rights. NARAL President Ilyse Hogue stated, "We know—and we know for sure—that any of Trump's list of 25 will vote to decimate our rights under Roe v. Wade. Period."

NARAL has made it clear that they will target senators who vote to confirm the nominee. Ilyse Hogue tweeted, "When voting on a #SCOTUS nominee, senators need to examine their values and their moral compasses. And if they do not, then they need to examine their political futures."

Indivisible, a group established in opposition to President Donald Trump, is also rallying its members. The group has set up a hotline to connect people with their senators and created a script for callers to read.

Abortion is not the only driving issue behind the protests. Groups in support of Obamacare are also gearing up for the fight, with Protect Our Care warning that the new justice could be a deciding vote that gets rid of protections for pre-existing conditions.

However, activists face a challenge, as three Democratic senators may also break ranks with their party to join Republicans in voting to confirm the president's nominee. Sens. Joe Manchin (D-WV), Heidi Heitkamp (D-ND), and Joe Donnelly (D-IN) all voted to confirm the president's first Supreme Court pick, Justice Neil Gorsuch, and all three are seeking re-election in states that President Trump won in 2016.

It's also important to note that the nominee's stance on issues may not be as predictable as assumed. Justice Anthony Kennedy, appointed by President Ronald Reagan, was described as a conservative but only held conservative views about half of the time. Similarly, Chief Justice John Roberts, appointed by President George W. Bush, has issued some rulings on the high court that make many conservatives cringe.

Regardless, senators can expect a summer filled with activist-filled lobbies, protests, and threats against their political futures as they weigh their votes for or against the next justice of the Supreme Court.

Title: Maryland Lawmakers Propose Replacing Roger Taney's Bust in U.S. Capitol with Thurgood Marshall

Article:

Maryland lawmakers have introduced legislation to replace a bust of Chief Justice Roger Taney, who authored the Dred Scott decision, in the old Supreme Court chamber of the U.S. Capitol. The proposed replacement is Baltimore native Thurgood Marshall, the first justice of African descent on the Supreme Court.

The debate to install Taney's bust in the Capitol building occurred over a century ago, with controversy surrounding Taney's role in upholding the institution of slavery. George Templeton Strong, a contemporary, wrote upon Taney's passing, "the Hon. old Roger B. Taney has earned the gratitude of his country by dying at last. Better late than never."

Despite the controversy, Taney's bust remained undisturbed in the Capitol for 143 years. Even the Maryland statehouse removed their tribute to Taney. Now, Maryland's senators, with backing from the Democratic members of the Maryland House delegation, are proposing to replace Taney's bust with a bust of Thurgood Marshall.

Thurgood Marshall's legacy as an attorney, Johnson administration official, and Supreme Court justice is significant, and his tribute in the Capitol is warranted. However, replacing Taney's bust with Marshall's would underscore the significance of Marshall's enshrinement, as he was the first justice of African descent, while Taney is known for his role in upholding slavery.

The bill, if successful, would provide a fitting closure to Maryland's place in the old chamber. The replacement of Taney's bust with Marshall's would symbolize the progress made in the fight for civil rights and equality.

The Baltimore Sun reported on the proposed legislation, with Joe Patrice, a senior editor at ███ and co-host of Thinking Like A Lawyer, commenting on the bill. Patrice serves as a Managing Director at RPN Executive Search.

Title: Senate Majority Leader McConnell Urges Roy Moore to Step Aside Amid Allegations

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, has called for Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore to step aside from the upcoming Senate race, following allegations of inappropriate relationships with teenagers. The December election is to replace former Senator Jeff Sessions, who stepped down to become President Trump's attorney general.

Speaking to reporters at a plant in Kentucky, McConnell expressed his belief in the women who have made the allegations against Moore. He also mentioned that he is exploring other Republican options for the seat, including incumbent Luther Strange, who lost a primary to Moore earlier this year. McConnell suggested the possibility of a write-in campaign for an alternative candidate.

Roy Moore, who has vehemently denied the allegations, reported by the Washington Post last week, has stated that he "has not been guilty of sexual misconduct with anyone" and has never purchased alcohol for underage women. The allegations include claims by Leigh Corfman, who was 14 when Moore, then 32, allegedly took her to his home in 1979, undressed her, and, according to the report, "touched her over her bra and underpants... and guided her hand to touch him over his underwear." Another woman, Gloria Deason, claimed she was 18 when Moore took her on a date and bought her wine.

Moore and his GOP allies in Alabama have questioned the timing of the story, suggesting it was planted to derail his political career. In response to McConnell's statement, Moore took to Twitter on Monday, saying the Senate Majority Leader should step aside.

Additional reporting:
- GOP Sen. Pat Toomey says Roy Moore should drop out of Alabama Senate race
- Roy Moore questions timing of allegations, says "revelations about motivations" coming.

Title: Increased Incidents of Political Intimidation and Violence Against Republicans

Article:

In recent times, incidents of violence and intimidation against Republican politicians and their supporters have become more prevalent in a politically charged climate.

On Thursday, a woman in Tennessee was charged with felony reckless endangerment for allegedly attempting to run Republican Congressman David Kustoff off the road following a town hall meeting. The woman, Wendi Wright, was reportedly enraged over Kustoff's support for the American Health Care Act and screamed at the congressman and his aide, striking his car windows and reaching inside the vehicle.

On the same day, police in North Dakota escorted an enraged man from another town hall after he became physical with Republican Rep. Kevin Cramer over his support for the GOP Obamacare replacement. The man, before shoving cash down Cramer's collar, shouted, "Will the rich benefit from [the health care being destroyed], do the rich get a tax break? Yes or no?"

CNN's Poppy Harlow downplayed the incident, stating the man was "showing his disgust" with Cramer.

The day before, a Huffington Post article titled "How to Really Turn Up the Heat on Elected Officials" went viral. The author, Michaelangelo Signorile, called on protesters to harass Republicans at dinner, while shopping, and even at home. Signorile argued that societal norms for the basic levels of decency one should afford political opponents no longer apply to liberals.

"It's time to move beyond polite protests within specified boundaries. It's time to escalate the expression of our outrage and our anger in a massive way," he wrote.

Signorile's article has already been shared more than 29,000 times.

Political violence has become increasingly common as left-wing organizations have incited mobs against Republicans and supporters of the president. A popular parade in Portland, Oregon was cancelled after threats of violence against a local Republican organization. An email warning parade organizers promised 200 or more protesters would rush into the parade and drag the Republican marchers out if necessary. Portland has been a site for organized left-wing protests, which have often turned into violent riots.

The threat was sent from an email address registered with RiseUp.Net, an organization that provides communication and computer resources to allies engaged in struggles against capitalism and other forms of oppression.

Berkeley, California has become a political battlefield on multiple occasions, after far-left groups have resorted to violence to keep Pro-Trump speakers or free speech marchers, who happened to be Trump supporters, from appearing in public.

Pro-Trump speaker Milo Yiannopoulos had his speech at the University of California-Berkeley cancelled after rioters set the campus ablaze to keep him from speaking. Protests against Milo at UC Berkeley resulted in chants of "This is what community looks like."

Political commentator Ann Coulter, who staunchly supported Trump during his presidential campaign, had her speech at UC Berkeley cancelled after the protest groups vowed a repeat performance of the Milo riots.

A North Carolina GOP office was firebombed a month before the election, and a building adjacent to it was spray-painted with graffiti: "Nazi Republicans get out of town or else."

Being a Republican in high school or college is increasingly dangerous—and not just at Berkeley.

Shortly before the election, a female high school student was attacked after declaring her support for Trump. A fellow female student took the girl's glasses off and punched her in the face, saying, "Fuck you, you bitch."

Olivia Corn, president of Cornell University's College Republicans, said she was physically assaulted the night after Trump won the election. "Fuck you, racist bitch, you support a racist party," her attacker reportedly said. Ironically, Corn said she was "not Donald Trump's biggest fan," and added that she "was saddened that I was not afforded the same respect that I offer others."

A Maryland high school student wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat after the election was punched and kicked by students protesting Trump after he started arguing with them.

Similarly, police in Florida arrested a 17-year-old high school student after he punched a classmate for carrying a Trump sign at school.

"It definitely had a political motivation," said Lt. Mike Bandish of the Palm Bay Police Department. "The boy was carrying a Trump sign and walked into the gym. The other boy punched him in the face."

Title: White House Criticizes CNN and MSNBC for Cutting Away from Coronavirus Briefing

Article:

The White House has criticized CNN and MSNBC for cutting away from Monday evening's coronavirus briefing led by President Donald Trump and his administration. White House spokesman Judd Deere described the networks' actions as "disgraceful" for not airing the entire White House briefing during the ongoing pandemic.

In a tweet, Deere stated, "Pretty disgraceful that @ CNN and @ MSNBC have both cut away from this @ WhiteHouse briefing with @ realDonaldTrump and @ Mike_Pence during a global pandemic. Thank you to @FoxNews for keeping Americans informed."

Fox News also cut away from the briefing but only just before it ended. In response to Deere's tweet, a CNN spokesperson issued a statement, "If the White House wants time on the network, they should make an official request. Otherwise, we will make our own editorial decisions."

An MSNBC network spokesperson said the network aired the briefing for more than an hour before cutting away "because the information no longer appeared to be valuable to the important ongoing discussion around public health."

Several individuals have criticized the administration's daily coronavirus briefings for allegedly spreading misinformation, and some have urged news networks not to show them live. Last week, President Trump got into a spat with NBC News reporter Peter Alexander when he asked what the president's message is to Americans who are "scared" about the coronavirus.

In Monday's briefing, Trump indicated that he wants to work with local economies to "cautiously resume" activities after the pandemic has shut down industries.

As of Monday, COVID-19 has infected more than 43,000 people in the U.S., leading to at least 552 deaths, according to data from Johns Hopkins University.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Calls for Gun-Control Debate in Response to Connecticut School Shooting

Article:

In the aftermath of the deadly shooting rampage at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, which left 20 children and six adults dead, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has called for a gun-control debate in Congress. Reid, who has previously voted against gun-control measures, controls whether the Senate will take up any legislation that could be sent to the House of Representatives.

In a statement on Monday, Reid said, "In the coming days and weeks, we will engage in a meaningful conversation and thoughtful debate about how to change laws and culture that allow violence to grow." This was the first time lawmakers convened since the shooting.

The shooting incident involved a semi-automatic rifle and two semi-automatic handguns, as well as hundreds of rounds of ammunition, according to police. The shooter, identified as Adam Lanza, also killed his mother at their home.

In the days since the shooting, calls for action have come from all directions, including lawmakers who previously fought more restrictions. Sen. Joe Manchin III, a West Virginia Democrat, said, "Everything should be on the table."

Sen. Mark R. Warner of Virginia, who has a pro-gun stance, has changed his position on so-called assault weapons following the Newtown incident. Sen. Frank R. Lautenberg plans to reintroduce a bill that bans magazines with the capacity of holding more than 10 rounds of ammunition, while Sen. Dianne Feinstein will introduce a bill to ban assault weapons. Congress passed such a ban in 1994 that lapsed in 2004.

Some, however, doubted more restrictions would work and called for increasing access to guns for teachers to prevent such attacks. Rep. Louie Gohmert of Texas expressed a similar sentiment, wishing Sandy Hook Principal Dawn Hochsprung, who was fatally shot while lunging at the shooter, had access to a firearm.

Reid's vow to hold a gun debate could free up the necessary time to bring a bill to the Senate floor, where the last major gun debate was in 2004. Reid has been a supporter of gun rights, including voting against renewal of the assault-weapons ban during that debate.

Democratic Sen. Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, promised to lead hearings on the status of laws, but said other Senate committees need to step up and look at other issues such as mental health concerns. The White House has pledged to engage citizens in an effort to prevent more tragedies like this, but has yet to specify the legislative measures it will support.

Title: Political Divisions Surround Tara Reade's Allegation Against Joe Biden and Comparisons to Trump's Sexual Assault Allegations

Article:

The political landscape is currently divided over the allegation made by Tara Reade, a former staffer for Joe Biden, that he sexually assaulted her. Some critics have accused liberal feminists of hypocrisy for not championing Reade as fervently as they did Christine Blasey Ford, who accused Brett Kavanaugh of sexual assault during his Supreme Court nomination fight.

The New York Times article attempts to address the inevitable calculus voters will have to make in November by providing a thorough accounting of the "pattern of behavior" laid out by the more than 20 women who have accused Donald Trump of sexual harassment or assault. The article suggests that the allegations against Trump go "far beyond the accusations against Mr. Biden."

It is not wrong to consider how a sexual assault allegation might affect a political candidate's chances. However, the article's comparison of the sexual assault allegations against Biden and Trump is criticized for engaging in an obfuscating exercise of relativity.

Regarding Biden's policy plan, critics note that his response to young people demanding a better health policy is to offer a policy that won't help them for decades. Some argue that Biden's plan, which doesn't lower the Medicare eligibility age significantly, shows that he isn't serious about courting the left.

On the other hand, some argue that young voters' inability to deliver on their preferred candidate's behalf will not go unnoticed in political circles. They suggest that young voters need to show up and be counted like never before to establish themselves as a reliable force in political circles.

In conclusion, the political landscape is divided over Tara Reade's allegation against Joe Biden and the comparisons to Donald Trump's sexual assault allegations. Critics argue that Biden's policy plan does not go far enough to address the concerns of young voters, while others argue that young voters need to show up and be counted to establish themselves as a reliable force in political circles.

Title: Billionaire Tom Steyer's Role in Delaying Keystone XL Pipeline

Article:

Billionaire Tom Steyer, a prominent Democrat and hedge fund manager, has been identified as a key figure in the delay of the Keystone XL pipeline, a proposed oil pipeline extension. Steyer, who is based in California and New York, has been a vocal opponent of the project and has funded a series of television ads to persuade the public that the pipeline is not in the nation's best interest.

According to the New York Times, Steyer spent $11 million during the 2014 elections to support Terry McAuliffe's gubernatorial campaign in Virginia and intervened in a Democratic congressional primary in Massachusetts. Now, he is seeking to build a war chest for his political organization, NextGen Climate Action, which aims to focus on climate change issues. Steyer is reportedly seeking to raise $50 million from other donors to match his own $50 million investment.

Steyer's efforts have attracted the support of other deep-pocketed donors and environmental philanthropists, with the goal of making NextGen Climate Action one of the largest outside groups in the country. In early February, Steyer gathered several leading liberal donors and environmental philanthropists at his ranch in California to discuss his plans.

Steyer's campaign against the Keystone XL pipeline has not been limited to Republicans. In March, NextGen Climate Action asked supporters to choose one congressional candidate from five running this year for the group to target in its next ads. Four of the five candidates were Republicans, including Senator Marco Rubio of Florida. However, the fifth candidate was a vulnerable Democratic incumbent, Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana, who has close ties to the oil and gas industries and has been an outspoken supporter of the Keystone pipeline.

It is unclear whether Steyer's campaign will focus solely on attacking Republicans or also target non-true-believing Democrats. The new fundraising push seeks to tap into the booming fortunes of Silicon Valley, where many donors rank climate change as their top political issue. The shift in donations from philanthropy and education into campaign vehicles designed to win elections is a sign of frustration among donors that neither Democratic nor Republican officials are prioritizing climate change measures.

Title: Democratic-Leaning States Face Significant Tax Cuts in Republican Tax Plan

Article:

Democratic-leaning states are set to bear a substantial portion of the tax cuts unveiled in a Republican tax plan on Thursday, as the plan reduces deductions that are most commonly used by residents of states that voted against Donald Trump in the 2016 elections. The bill, introduced by the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Ways and Means on Thursday, targets state and local tax deductions as part of its plan to offset reductions in taxes elsewhere.

The bill eliminates the most widely-used deduction, income tax, and caps property tax deductions, the second most-used, at $10,000. State and local deductions are used primarily by high-tax states that tend to vote Democratic in presidential elections, and local officials say the tax bill appears to divide its benefits and burdens along partisan lines.

Kevin Sullivan, Connecticut's Commissioner of Revenue Services, stated, "I do think this has been developed in a way that looks at who were the prevailing forces in the presidential election and who were not." Connecticut, along with several other high-tax Democratic states, is expected to see middle-class households paying more taxes under the Republican plan.

Among the states potentially hardest-hit are California and New York, with state income tax rates of 13.3% and 8.82%, respectively, according to a recent report by the Tax Foundation. This group also includes New Jersey, Minnesota, and Oregon - all of which voted for Trump's Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton, in the 2016 election.

By contrast, out of the seven states that levy no income tax, Trump only lost Washington and Nevada, while winning Alaska, Florida, South Dakota, Texas, and Wyoming.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, a Democrat and one of the most outspoken opponents of the bill, wrote in a letter to Trump this week, "By eliminating or rolling back state and local tax deductibility, Washington is sending a death blow to New York's middle class families and our economy."

The legislation would also end a tax exemption for billions of dollars of so-called private activity bonds issued by state and local governments annually to finance affordable housing, non-profit hospitals, colleges, airports, and port facilities - a measure that would affect both Democrat and Republican states alike.

Conservative groups have defended the tax bill, stating it would simplify the tax code, reduce the overall burden on the economy, and spread the costs and burdens more fairly.

Jonathan Williams, chief economist at the American Legislative Exchange Council, an organization of conservative state legislators, said in an email, "The principles outlined in this federal tax reform effort will provide pro-growth tax rate reductions, while adding fairness and simplicity to the tax code."

Nick Samuels, a senior credit officer at Moody's Investors Service, said the proposed bill would hit primarily high-income and high-tax states like California, New York, and New Jersey, making it harder for them to raise revenue from income and property taxes.

Officials in the affected states say millions of residents, not just high-earners, would suffer due to lost tax breaks and less funding available for public services. In New Jersey, 1.8 million households deduct a total of $17 billion in state income or sales taxes, and 1.6 million households deduct a cumulative $14.9 billion in local property taxes from their federal taxes, according to the nonpartisan think-tank New Jersey Policy Perspective.

Jon Whiten, the group's vice president, stated, "This deal is still terrible for New Jersey's working families, with big tax breaks that overwhelmingly go to the wealthiest 1 percent, setting up deep cuts to programs and services that we all rely on."

Minnesota's Democratic Governor Mark Dayton warned on Monday that the legislation would eliminate tax deductions totaling over $12.3 billion annually for 900,000 families in his state.

The states with the highest property tax collections per capita include New Jersey, New Hampshire, Connecticut, and New York, according to the Tax Foundation. For California, approximately one in three residents took a state or local deduction in 2015, totaling roughly $113 billion, according to H.D. Palmer, a spokesman for the state's finance department.

"Congress is trying to rush consideration of a tax proposal that will have profound and widespread impacts on California," Palmer said.

National Conference of State Legislatures President and Republican South Dakota state senator Deb Peters, in a statement, called the legislation "an attack on the sovereignty of states."

Title: Trump Jr. Turns Over Thousands of Documents to Congress in Ongoing Investigations

Article:

Attorney for Donald Trump Jr., Alan Futerfas, has stated that they have cooperated with various committees and voluntarily handed over thousands of documents in response to their requests. The documents were provided as part of Congress' ongoing investigations into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential campaign.

The correspondence, though representing a small portion of the documents, has raised questions due to its connection with the Russian lawyer, Natalia Veselnitskaya, and the White House's response to the Russian meddling. The messages have added a second instance where Trump Jr. appears eager to obtain damaging information about Hillary Clinton, despite its provenance.

It is unclear what investigators will make of the correspondence. The stakes for the Trump family are high, as Trump Jr.'s June 2016 meeting with Veselnitskaya and the White House's defense of him are already reportedly subjects of interest in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation.

Trump Jr. mostly ignored the frequent messages from WikiLeaks, but he at times appears to have acted on its requests. For instance, when WikiLeaks first reached out to Trump Jr. about putintrump.org, Trump Jr. followed up on his promise to "ask around." On the same day that Trump Jr. received the first message from WikiLeaks, he emailed other senior officials with the Trump campaign, including Steve Bannon, Kellyanne Conway, Brad Parscale, and Trump son-in-law Jared Kushner, telling them WikiLeaks had made contact. Kushner then forwarded the email to campaign communications staffer Hope Hicks. At no point during the 10-month correspondence does Trump Jr. rebuff WikiLeaks, which had published stolen documents and was already observed to be releasing information that benefited Russian interests.

WikiLeaks did not respond to requests for comment.

Title: Clinton Faces Challenges in Uniting Democratic Party After Primary Victory

Article:

In the aftermath of her victory in the New York primary, Hillary Clinton faces the challenge of uniting the Democratic Party, particularly the Sanders wing. During her victory speech, Clinton acknowledged the need for unity, stating, "To all the people who supported Senator Sanders, I believe there is much more that unites us than divides us."

Clinton has several options to address this issue. She could offer Sanders a prime-time speaking spot at the Democratic National Convention, select a vice president who shares Sanders' concerns, emulate John F. Kennedy's decision to make his primary rival, Lyndon Baines Johnson, his running mate in 1960, or incorporate Sanders' positions into the Democratic Party platform. If Sanders ends up with a campaign debt, Clinton could also promise to help pay it off, as President Obama did for her in 2008.

However, Clinton's efforts to appeal to Sanders' voters may be complicated by her potential shift back to the political center in preparation for the general election. This move could alienate Sanders' voters, who are already skeptical of Clinton.

A more significant challenge is whether Sanders, who has not always identified as a Democrat and has shown reservations towards Clinton, will wholeheartedly endorse her if she secures the nomination. Howard Dean, who lost the Democratic presidential nomination in 2004 to John Kerry, noted that endorsing a candidate is easier than convincing supporters to follow suit. "It's much easier for the candidate to understand that he or she has to get with the program," said Dean, who supports Clinton. "I had made up my mind that I was going to support John, but bringing supporters along was much tougher."

Title: Majority of Americans View Relationship Between Trump Administration and News Media as Unhealthy, Impeding Access to Political News

Article:

The relationship between the Trump administration and the news media is, according to most U.S. adults, problematic. A new survey conducted by ███ from March 13-27, 2017, among 4,151 adults who are members of ███'s nationally representative American Trends Panel, reveals that 83% of Americans believe the current tensions have made the relationship between the administration and the news media unhealthy, with only 15% saying it is healthy despite current tensions.

Furthermore, 73% of U.S. adults believe these tensions are getting in the way of access to important national political news and information. This concern is shared across nearly all demographic groups, including large majorities of both Democrats and Republicans.

The findings show that 88% of Democrats and 78% of Republicans view the relationship as unhealthy. Additionally, about seven-in-ten members of both parties say access to important political news is impacted. The findings are similarly consistent across other demographic groups such as age, race, income, and education.

Awareness of the current state of the relationship between the Trump administration and the news media is virtually ubiquitous in America, with 94% of U.S. adults saying they have heard about it. Younger Americans are less likely to have heard a lot about the relationship, with 55% of adults ages 18-29 saying they've heard a lot compared with 71% of those 30-49, 77% of those 50-64, and 86% of those 65 and older.

The survey does not provide insight into who Americans blame for these tensions or what actions they want taken. However, it is clear that they currently have high levels of awareness and concern.

Title: New York City Businesses Struggle with Minimum Wage Increase

Article:

New York City businesses, which have been mandated to pay a minimum wage of $15 per hour for over a year, are reportedly experiencing negative impacts and making difficult adjustments, according to The Wall Street Journal. Businesses with 11 or more employees were required to pay the increased wage at the beginning of 2019.

Thomas Green, president of the Queens Chamber of Commerce, has observed an increase in small businesses closing this year due to the wage increase. "They're cutting their staff," Green said. "They're cutting their hours. They're shutting down. It's not just the rent."

The minimum wage increase is particularly challenging for businesses located in boroughs with less disposable income, according to Lisa Sorin, president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce. While Manhattan businesses might be able to handle the increase, places like the Bronx are forced to "keep up or get out."

Even for businesses not forced to close due to the minimum wage increase, it can stifle growth. Susannah Koteen, who owns a restaurant in Harlem, told WSJ that she had to cancel plans to move her business to a larger location because she could not afford the risk of having to hire more staff in an unpredictable industry.

"You would just have no choice but to cut people at the bottom," Koteen said.

These anecdotes illustrate the reality that while most people may believe workers deserve higher wages in theory, the practical implications of a higher minimum wage can be extremely damaging to minimum wage employees who may lose job opportunities and small business owners who are already operating with tight margins.

John Bonizio, who owns four Metro Optics Eyewear locations in the city, said, "As a retailer, I was not opposed to the minimum-wage increase because it puts more money or more disposable income into the pockets of people who are my customers. But, what you have to stop doing, is picking the pockets of small businesses."

Title: Nike's Controversy Over Betsy Ross Flag: Historical Context and Political Implications

Article:

In a recent turn of events, Nike has faced controversy over a sneaker design featuring an early version of the American flag, prompting the company to halt its distribution. The controversy stems from former NFL player Colin Kaepernick's reported objection to the design, which some perceive as tied to slavery. However, the relationship between the Betsy Ross flag and white supremacy is not universally agreed upon among historians.

The 13-star flag, America's first, is often attributed to Philadelphia seamstress Betsy Ross, although historical confirmation of this lore is lacking. Betsy Ross lived during the era of slavery, but the flag's connection to white supremacy is not immediately clear, according to a number of historians contacted by the source. The political leanings of Ross are unknown, as Philadelphia, with its large Quaker population, had neutral leanings during the Revolutionary War.

The Betsy Ross flag is not included in the Anti-Defamation League's (ADL) database of more than 150 so-called hate symbols, such as the Confederate flag, a noose, Pepe the Frog, and Sadistic Souls. Mark Pitcavage, senior research fellow at ADL's Center on Extremism, noted that while the flag has been used by white supremacists "from time to time," he has "never once thought about" adding the Betsy Ross flag to the list.

The Betsy Ross flag has caused controversy before, such as in 2016 when students at a majority white high school in Michigan waved the 13-star flag during a football game, while holding "Make America Great Again" flags in support of President Donald Trump. The NAACP's local chapter at the time stated that Ross's flag had been "co-opted by exclusionary movements."

Nike's decision to pull the sneakers was intended to avoid offense, but it also opened the company up to political rebuke and jeopardized potential financial incentives to add a manufacturing facility in Arizona. Arizona Gov. Doug Ducey criticized Nike's decision on Twitter, stating that the company had "apparently decided that Betsy Ross is unworthy" and had "bowed to the current onslaught of political correctness and historical revisionism."

The Betsy Ross flag was formally commemorated on June 14, 1777, when the U.S. passed a law creating Flag Day. The legislation reads: "Resolved. That the flag of the United States be thirteen stripes, alternate red and white; that the union be thirteen stars, white in a blue field, representing a new Constellation." The flag has evolved since its earliest iteration, adding more stars as more states joined the union.

Scott P. Marler, associate professor of history at the University of Memphis, stated that "since patriot groups, militias, etc., tend to be firmly linked to '100% (white) Americanism,' the rumor has now taken root that the Ross flag constitutes another such symbol (like the Confederate flag)." Marler lamented, "Well, if it wasn't before, it sure will be now, and it's a shame to concede it to them."

Nike shares closed down less than 1% in trading Tuesday afternoon, having risen about 8% over the past 12 months.

Title: Law Professor Pamela Karlan's Testimony Sparks Controversy Over Alleged Personal Attacks

 Article:

 In the ongoing impeachment hearings, law professor Pamela Karlan's testimony has sparked controversy over allegations of personal attacks, particularly towards President Donald Trump's son, Barron Trump. Critics argue that her comments disqualify her as an expert witness due to the demonstration of strong personal animus against Trump.

 During the proceedings, Karlan made a comment about the difference between a president and a king, stating that the U.S. Constitution prohibits titles of nobility, and while the president can name his son Barron, he cannot make him a baron.

 The article suggests that leftist academics, including Karlan, are prone to expressing such insults publicly due to their ideological bubbles and the perceived lack of backlash from their peers. The piece also references several instances of controversial comments made by prominent Democrats, such as Hillary Clinton's "deplorables" remark and former FBI agent Peter Strzok's derogatory texts about Trump supporters.

 The article further discusses the theory of evolutionary psychologist Dr. Nigel Barber, who posits that conservatives have a predisposition to fear and a distaste for complexity and compromise, which may contribute to political polarization. The article argues that this theory is reminiscent of Karlan's comments about conservatives and liberals.

 The article concludes by suggesting that the left's animosity towards Trump and his supporters is driven by an elitist attitude and a pre-ordained decision to impeach President Trump, a sentiment that predates his term in office. The article also criticizes the left for their hypocrisy in advocating for Trump's ouster while pretending to safeguard constitutional liberties. The author, David Limbaugh, is a writer, author, and attorney, and his latest book is "Guilty by Reason of Insanity: Why the Democrats Must Not Win."

Title: California Primary: "Zombie Votes" and Potential Implications for Remaining Candidates

Article:

As California polls close tonight, the first batch of votes to be counted will consist of the more than 3.7 million ballots already mailed in, which may include "zombie votes" for candidates who have ended their presidential campaigns. These votes are not for actual zombies but rather votes cast for candidates who have withdrawn from the race.

According to Paul Mitchell, an electoral researcher from Political Data Inc., between 350,000 to 400,000 Californians have already voted by mail for a candidate who has dropped out, and he suspects that number could grow to over half a million.

Most voters appear to have waited until the last minute to cast their ballots. Although more than 16 million Californians received a mail ballot, less than a quarter of those ballots had been returned by the eve of the election.

Since these ballots only need to be postmarked by tomorrow and arrive by Friday to be counted, officials are preparing for potential problems and delays in determining the final outcome in close races. This is one reason some advocated voting ahead of time, a strategy campaigns also urged to secure early support and a strong showing in the early vote tabulations.

However, many who voted early for candidates like Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar, Andrew Yang, or Tom Steyer may now regret their choices, as these candidates have dropped out of the race. California has no provision for changing one's mind after a vote is cast and mailed in.

The implications of these "zombie votes" could affect the number of delegates remaining candidates will be allotted. Party rules dictate that a candidate must earn 15% of the statewide vote to get any statewide delegates, and also that a candidate must earn 15% of the vote in any of the state's congressional districts to receive any delegates apportioned at the district level.

In a hypothetical scenario, Mitchell suggested that Michael Bloomberg could potentially exceed the 15% threshold due to "zombie votes" from candidates who have dropped out, causing other candidates to miss the 15% threshold.

It is also possible that a candidate who has dropped out will still exceed the threshold enough to win some delegates in certain congressional districts. These delegates would be chosen by the ex-candidate and expected to vote for them on the first ballot at the Democratic National Convention.

As for the anticipated flood of same-day voting, either in person or by mail, it is difficult to say which candidate stands to benefit most. Joe Biden, for instance, has been buoyed by a robust victory in the South Carolina primary and a stream of quitting candidates who have endorsed him. Californians who didn't vote early may be swayed by all that good news for Biden.

Conversely, the former vice president lost that momentum among all the Californians who have already voted by mail at a time when he trailed other contenders.

Heading into the final hours of the California primary, the latest available public polls still indicated Bernie Sanders with a significant lead. For more information on the candidates, check out the ███ voter guide.

Title: Green Party's Jill Stein Criticizes Two Major Parties, Seeks to Break "Stranglehold" in 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

In the 2016 presidential race, Green Party candidate Jill Stein, a 66-year-old Harvard-trained physician from Massachusetts, has expressed her disapproval of both major party candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. Stein, who is currently polling at approximately 2 percent, trails Libertarian Party candidate Gary Johnson, who is projected to take about 4 percent of the popular vote.

During an interview last week, Stein stated, "We have every reason to be terrified of Donald Trump in the White House. But I do not think we should fool ourselves into thinking that we should sleep well at night with Hillary Clinton in the White House either. They're both dangerous and unacceptable in different ways."

Stein believes that this election year presents an historic opportunity for third parties, stating, "This is a realignment election. And you have this marriage of the Democratic and Republican parties now. And it's important, I think, for Greens and Libertarians to be working together right now to just break through this stranglehold and be challenging them right out of the gate."

Stein and Johnson share similar views on topics such as foreign policy, marijuana legalization, and same-sex marriage. However, their economic policies differ significantly. Stein advocates for a single-payer health care system, claiming it would cost taxpayers nothing. She also proposes pouring federal money into the clean energy sector and ending the use of fossil fuels by the year 2030.

Stein has faced criticism regarding her stance on vaccinations, with some claiming the Green Party is anti-vaccine. In response to small amounts of mercury once found in childhood vaccines, Stein has stated, "There were real questions that needed to be addressed. I think some of them at least have been addressed. I do not know if all of them have been addressed." This statement has been met with controversy, as there is a scientific consensus that there is no link between vaccines and autism or any other serious health problems.

Stein characterizes the media coverage of her statements as misleading and compares it to the "birther" issue of the election, claiming she is only calling for reforms to the FDA, which she sees as corrupted by lobbyists.

With the election just days away, both Johnson and Stein's poll numbers are declining. Achieving 5 percent of the popular vote would be a significant milestone for both parties, as it would lead to the Federal Election Commission conferring the classification of "minor party," granting them easier ballot access and eligibility for matching public funds.

Stein expressed her discontent with the current state of the election, stating, "It's outrageous that people should be struggling right now with this question of, 'Do I prefer a fascist or a warmonger?'"

The interview was conducted by Zach Weissmueller, produced and edited by Justin Monticello and Jim Epstein, and filmed by Monticello and Alex Manning. The music was composed by RW Smith.

Title: Iran Tensions and the 2020 Elections: An Analysis of Foreign Policy's Potential Impact

Article:

The recent American-ordered drone strike that resulted in the death of Iran's powerful military leader, Qassem Soleimani, has sparked retaliation from Iran and heightened the alert status of American troops in the Middle East. This event has also brought foreign policy to the forefront of the news cycle, leading to speculation about its potential impact on the 2020 primary and general elections.

While foreign policy typically does not significantly affect people's votes, this Iran episode could be an exception due to its prominence in the national conversation and the contrasting foreign policy positions of the major parties. However, the role international affairs play in primaries is not well-studied, especially in relation to experienced foreign policy candidates.

In the current Democratic primary, former Vice President Joe Biden is such a candidate, and two recent polls suggest that Democratic primary voters trust him the most on foreign policy. According to CNN, nearly half (48%) of Democrats and Democratic leaners said they thought Biden could best handle foreign policy, with Sen. Bernie Sanders coming in second place with 14%. In a poll taken immediately after the strike that killed Soleimani, HuffPost/YouGov found that 62% of Democrats and Democratic leaners trust Biden on Iran, although Sanders and Sen. Elizabeth Warren weren't too far behind, with 47% trusting each of them (respondents were allowed to select multiple candidates they trusted).

The candidates' positions on Iran could also be determinative. A candidate like Sanders, who has been critical of Biden's vote to go to war with Iraq, could gain an advantage if the primary becomes a question of who is the most anti-war. The candidates' statements about Iran during the upcoming debate could be a make-or-break moment for many of the candidates, as foreign policy can serve as a litmus test that all serious candidates must pass.

In the 2016 Republican primaries, for example, Ben Carson may have flunked such a test when he struggled to articulate his plan to combat terrorism after the coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris in November 2015. Although it's impossible to know exactly how much this hurt Carson in voters' eyes, he had been running even with now-President Trump in the polls at the time of the attacks, but he sharply declined thereafter and ceased to be a serious threat for the nomination.

However, Iran's effect on the primary might be fleeting, as news cycles move on, and past events touted as "game changers" have failed to permanently change the state of the race. For Iran to have any real effect on the general election, it would likely have to stay in the news for the next several months.

In theory, the Republican Party might have an advantage in an election focused on national security, as the GOP has long been seen as better at protecting the country from external threats, according to Gallup polling. However, the gap has narrowed during the Trump era, and other polls suggest Trump himself is not very well trusted on foreign policy.

It's possible that Trump could become more popular in the wake of this month's attacks thanks to the "rally-around-the-flag effect," or the idea that major international crises can unite the country around the commander-in-chief. However, this effect is not an ironclad rule, and context plays a major role in whether a rally-around-the-flag polling bump develops at all.

Ultimately, in keeping with our highly polarized times, the most plausible theory is probably that opinion on Iran will break down along partisan lines—and therefore won't do much to change the trajectory of the general election. One of political science's most consistent findings on this issue is that elite cues drive public opinion on foreign policy. In other words, if the president's critics support a conflict and bend the metaphorical knee to the commander-in-chief, the public takes note and does the same. But if elite opinion splits along partisan lines—as it is doing so far on Iran—then so will public opinion.

Title: Iraq War's Legacy Looms Over Obama's Syria Decision

Article:

The ongoing Syrian regime's potential use of chemical weapons presents a political dilemma for President Obama, often referred to as the "slam dunk" issue. This term was used by then-CIA director George Tenet in reference to Iraq's alleged possession of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) during the Bush administration.

In his 2007 book "At the Center of the Storm," Tenet admitted that there was no serious debate within the administration about the imminence of the Iraqi threat, and that there were no in-depth discussions of possible alternatives to military invasion. The Iraq War, which has resulted in 4,486 U.S. military fatalities and at least several hundred U.S. civilian contractor deaths in Iraq, has left a lasting impact on the Syria debate.

The New Yorker's Amy Davidson writes that Iraq has "informed every part of this debate." A Politico article carries the headline "Iraq haunts President Obama's Syria choices." According to Politico, Obama's advisers are cautious about the Syria crisis, fearing a repeat of the Iraq War.

Obama has already had a "slam dunk" moment with his assertion that the Assad regime's use of chemical weapons against Syrian rebels would constitute crossing an unacceptable "red line," implying a potential U.S. military response. However, the White House's statement this week suggests that the red line may not have been fully crossed, with the phrase "small scale" used to describe the chemical agent sarin's use.

Obama's initial use of "red line" regarding Syria left room for maneuver, as he warned last summer that "a red line for us is we start seeing a whole bunch of chemical weapons moving around or being utilized." Critics may view this as waffling, but there is a clear difference between "small scale" and "a whole bunch" of chemical weapons being used.

The Obama administration now faces a lot of soul-searching, including a review of history regarding other controversial intelligence assessments, as some officials consider the Tonkin Gulf Resolution, which gave President Lyndon Johnson the authority to conduct war in Vietnam without formal declaration.

The Obama administration's "red line" stands, along with the "varying degrees of confidence" among U.S. intelligence agencies regarding Syria's use of chemical weapons. Retired Marine Corps General Anthony Zinni told Time magazine, "The trouble with statements like that is you can get drawn into military operations." This is the situation the Obama administration now finds itself in.

Title: Trump Signs Executive Order on Police Reform, Critics Say It Falls Short

Article:

President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Tuesday aimed at improving police training and encouraging departments to meet higher certification standards on use of force. The order comes in response to the killing of George Floyd by police last month, which has led to widespread protests and calls for police reform.

In a Rose Garden ceremony, Trump largely defended police officers, stating that Americans "demand law and order." The order will create a database to track police officers with multiple instances of misconduct, and use federal grants to encourage departments to meet certain standards. It will also call on departments to involve social workers and mental health professionals on calls dealing with homelessness, mental illness, and addiction.

The order also calls for police departments to ban the use of chokeholds except when an officer feels their life is endangered. However, it is unclear what practical effect this may have, given questions about Trump's powers over law enforcement, which is mostly state and local authority.

Republican Rep. Jim Jordan called the order a "tremendous step forward in improving the system and beginning a new era in the relationship between communities and the police officers that keep them safe."

Critics, however, faulted what they called an empty photo op, stating that the order is unlikely to result in practical changes to policing for much of the country. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said the order "falls sadly and seriously short of what is required to combat the epidemic of racial injustice and police brutality that is murdering hundreds of Black Americans."

The order does not address concerns about police treating African Americans and people of color unfairly. Instead, it focuses on breaking down barriers and bringing communities together, and not demonizing the police, according to Trump.

Trump also defended law enforcement, stating that the number of bad officers is "very tiny." He denounced what he termed "radical and dangerous" proposals to defund police departments, asserting that many departments are underfunded and under-supported.

Some activists responding to recent killings by police have rallied behind the slogan "defund the police," which they say would involve taking some money given to departments today and using it for mental health, social work, and other functions apart from patrol-style policing.

Trump and Republicans have seized on what they call extreme ideas about abolishing police departments altogether. Before signing the order on Tuesday, Trump said he met with several families who lost loved ones "in deadly interactions with police."

The precise details of the order were not immediately clear, but according to at least one report, the mother of a Pittsburgh boy who was killed by police said she had traveled to Washington for meetings this week but would not talk with Trump.

Trump touted positive economic news and steps his administration has taken to assist minority communities, such as empowerment zones and aid to historically black colleges and universities. Trump also said "We must build upon our heritage, not tear it down," an apparent reference to the dismantling of Confederate and other statues around the country.

The White House is also in a political confrontation with Congress over the apparent expansion of bipartisan support among lawmakers to rename U.S. military facilities named for Confederate commanders. Meanwhile, the Senate Judiciary Committee has convened a hearing Tuesday afternoon on policing and community relations, and Senate Republicans continue work on a policing bill they are expected to unveil this week. The Democratic-led House of Representatives has introduced a bill that would also ban chokeholds.

Title: The Role of Money in Presidential Elections: A Historical Perspective and the 2020 Scenario

Article:

The historical trend of wealthy individuals attempting to secure presidential victories through substantial financial backing has not guaranteed success, as demonstrated by cases such as Meg Whitman, Carly Fiorina, Linda McMahon, and Ross Perot in the past. The latest addition to this list could be Howard Schultz in the current election cycle. David Koch, a Libertarian Party candidate for vice president in 1980, also falls under this category.

In essence, the significance of the "money primary" lies not in the importance of money itself, but in its role in determining which candidates receive media attention. A minimal amount of funds is necessary to maintain a campaign, travel, and manage essential functions. However, beyond this baseline, money is typically allocated towards consultants and television advertisements.

Candidates continue to spend a significant portion of their funds on television ads, as this medium is popular among the baby boomer demographic, which is more likely to vote. However, TV ads are often ineffective in targeting specific demographics and come at a premium, with many swing-state local TV stations willing to incur losses for the guaranteed revenue from presidential election campaigns.

In 2020, earned (free) media will once again play a crucial role, with social media, particularly Facebook and Instagram, becoming increasingly significant. While some individuals are swayed by television, many more are influenced by their friends and peers.

In light of the current political climate, the electorate's polarization has diminished the effectiveness of television ads in persuading voters. As a result, the 2020 presidential election is expected to see a shift towards earned media on social platforms.

For a comprehensive overview of the 2020 presidential candidates' Q1 fundraising totals, readers are encouraged to delve deeper into the specifics of each candidate's financial support.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Authorizes Subpoena for Full Mueller Report and Associated Evidence

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday authorized Chairman Jerry Nadler to issue a subpoena for special counsel Robert Mueller's full report and all underlying evidence collected by Mueller. This move gives Nadler the discretion to issue a subpoena to Attorney General William Barr at any time, a decision that is likely to initiate a legal confrontation between Congress and the Justice Department.

However, Nadler stated that he does not intend to issue the subpoena immediately. Instead, he plans to give Barr time to reconsider his decision to redact the report before submitting it to Congress. "If that doesn’t work out, in a very short order, we’ll issue the subpoenas," Nadler said.

In addition to authorizing subpoenas for Mueller's report, the committee also authorized subpoenas for five former senior aides to President Donald Trump as part of a broad obstruction of justice and corruption probe. The individuals include former chief of staff Reince Priebus, former adviser Steve Bannon, former White House counsel Don McGahn, McGahn's former deputy Ann Donaldson, and former communications director Hope Hicks.

The authorization for subpoenas puts Congress on an aggressive footing while Barr reviews Mueller's report and redacts several categories of information. Barr has indicated he intends to redact classified information, grand jury testimony, material relevant to ongoing investigations, and "reputational" information that could be harmful to "peripheral third parties."

Democrats have argued that Congress should have access to all of the information, even if it is blacked out of the version of the report Barr makes public. They note that Republicans received material in all four categories when they demanded documents from the Justice Department over the past two years.

In a recent letter to lawmakers, Barr said he intends to provide the redacted version of the report to Congress by "mid-April." He also offered to testify before Congress in early May. House Democrats rejected that offer as insufficient and demanded he testify immediately.

Republicans on the Judiciary Committee criticized the subpoena effort as a partisan push to attack the president. Rep. Doug Collins (R-Ga.), the ranking Republican on the panel, said Democrats are asking Barr to violate laws and regulations to reveal redacted information.

Collins also suggested that some of the Trump aides who Democrats authorized subpoenas for have indicated a willingness to cooperate. He called the effort "political theater" intended to get reporters to write about subpoenas for close aides to the president.

Nadler repeatedly invoked the investigation of President Bill Clinton by former independent counsel Ken Starr as an example of why Mueller’s report should be released. Though Nadler was a harsh critic of Starr at the time, he emphasized Wednesday that Starr provided Congress voluminous material that Barr now proposes to redact.

Some Republicans urged Nadler to go to court and ask a judge to lift the restriction on sharing grand jury material. Nadler indicated he intends to do that but wants the committee to issue a subpoena first.

"These investigations should end. We should move on. We shouldn’t be issuing subpoenas today," Rep. John Ratcliffe (R-Texas) said. But Ratcliffe said if the committee intends to issue subpoenas, "Let’s issue one for Bob Mueller. Let’s ask Bob Mueller whether he thinks the report that he created should be disclosed without considerations of classified national security information or without redactions for grand jury information."

Republicans repeatedly indicated that Mueller’s report found no evidence of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia and made no conclusion on obstruction of justice, prompting sharp rejoinders from Democrats who noted none of them had seen the report yet.

"Why are we here? It seems to me we’re here because the Mueller report wasn’t what the Democrat thought it would be," wondered Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio).

"I’ve seen the principal findings from the attorney general," Jordan said.

Title: Romney Expresses Confidence Following Debate Series, Renews Attacks on Obama's Second-Term Agenda

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, expressed confidence Tuesday during a rally in Henderson, Nevada, stating that the debates with President Barack Obama had "super-charged" his campaign. Romney told a crowd of approximately 6,000 people that there was an increase in enthusiasm and support following the debates.

Romney renewed his criticism of Obama's second-term agenda, stating that the president had been reduced to defending characters on Sesame Street and engaging in word games, while his attacks on Romney were not an agenda in themselves. Romney claimed that the debates had revealed a lack of an agenda from the president, contributing to his campaign's struggles while Romney's campaign was gaining momentum.

The third debate between the two candidates, focused on foreign policy, took place on Monday night. A CNN instant poll showed that debate watchers gave Obama the edge in that meeting, and Democrats quickly pointed to areas where Romney seemed to agree with the president's policies. A senior adviser to Romney acknowledged that there were areas of agreement, but emphasized Romney's stance on China and modernizing the Navy as notable differences.

Romney's running mate, Paul Ryan, echoed the campaign's confident demeanor during a joint rally with Romney on Tuesday, stating that in two weeks, President Obama would become "former President Barack Obama" and Mitt Romney would be the next President of the United States. Both Romney and Ryan urged the Nevada audience to vote early, as polls show a tight race in Nevada with Obama holding a slight edge.

President Obama is scheduled to rally an audience in Las Vegas the following night.

Title: Trump Administration Advocates for Complete Dismantling of the Affordable Care Act

Article:

The Trump administration on Monday announced its support for a federal judge's ruling that the entire Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, should be overturned. This shift in the Justice Department's position has alarmed Democrats who have vowed to oppose the move.

In a filing with the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, three Justice Department lawyers stated, "The Department of Justice has determined that the district court's judgment should be affirmed." They further clarified, "The United States is not urging that any portion of the district court's judgment be reversed."

The consequences could be substantial if the courts ultimately strike down Obamacare, as more than 20 million Americans are covered through the ACA's Medicaid expansion and its insurance exchanges. The ACA, which has been the subject of repeated legal challenges since its 2010 passage, has transformed the nation's health system, creating new patient protections and reshaping payments for doctors and hospitals.

Some of the Trump administration's proposed drug price reforms depend on provisions contained in the ACA. The GOP-led states that initially brought the lawsuit, Texas v. United States, had called for the entire law to be invalidated because Congress eliminated its individual insurance mandate penalty.

House Democrats, who had separately planned to introduce legislation on Tuesday that would fortify Obamacare, denounced the Trump administration's new legal position as "unconscionable." Rep. Frank Pallone (D-N.J.), chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said in a statement, "Millions of Americans will lose their health care immediately if this decision is upheld."

Justice Department spokesperson Kerri Kupec said the department "has determined that the district court's comprehensive opinion came to the correct conclusion and will support it on appeal."

Attorney General Bill Barr pledged to reconsider the Justice Department's stance on the lawsuit during his Senate confirmation hearing. However, legal experts had not expected Barr to take a more aggressive position than his predecessor Jeff Sessions, who told career Justice Department lawyers to drop their defense of the law, leading three lawyers to remove their names from the government's brief and prompting the senior attorney, Joel McElvain, to resign.

Nick Bagley, a University of Michigan law professor who has criticized the ruling, stated, "Barr inherited an indefensible legal position. But instead of backing down, he's embraced a downright crazy one." A group of Democratic-led states led by California is challenging the Texas ruling, arguing that the federal health care law can remain in place even without a tax penalty for Americans who forego health coverage.

Title: Latino Groups Shift Strategy Away from Backlash, Focus on Voter Registration and Political Power

Article:

In the aftermath of President Barack Obama's decision not to take executive action on immigration reform before the midterm elections, Latino leaders and advocacy groups have shifted their strategy from potential protests and political retribution to a focus on voter registration, political power, and ballot initiatives.

Latino groups, unions, and civil rights organizations are concentrating on registering voters, raising funds to help elect more Hispanics to Congress, and highlighting ballot initiatives in states like Oregon that would restrict access to driver's licenses. They also plan to launch direct mail, radio, and TV ads as Election Day approaches.

The decision by leading Washington advocacy groups not to urge their large voting bloc to stay at home in November reflects the political calculation of senior Democrats on Capitol Hill and in the White House. Latino voters are unlikely to abandon the Democratic party, even with a delay on executive action, according to these leaders.

Cristóbal Alex, the Latino Victory Project's executive director, predicted that more than 7 million Latino voters would turn out for the midterm elections. The White House has also played a role in quelling some anger by holding a series of meetings with stakeholders since the announcement that Obama would not move forward before the election.

However, it remains unclear whether Hispanics will respond to the call to vote. Obama's decision to postpone an executive order until the end of the year has made the job of driving up interest among Latino voters, already a challenge in midterm election years, much more difficult, according to activists and political analysts.

Immigration reform is not a widely used topic to turn out the voters in the midterms. Instead, the drive is focused on motivating Latino voters over issues like education, health care, the economy, and the environment.

So far, there are 100 partners in the Hispanic Heritage Month get-out-the-vote movement, which has registered more than 38,000 people online. The effort has more voter registration events planned next week in Texas, Florida, and Utah, and is also engaging through Twitter.

If Latino voters show up on Election Day, they could prove decisive in close Senate, House, and gubernatorial races, according to an analysis from the polling firm Latino Decisions. The Senate contest in Colorado, where 14 percent of eligible registered voters are Hispanic, is a clear example. Latino Decisions has also identified the Michigan, North Carolina, and Georgia Senate races as campaigns where Latino voting rates could swing the election. Even in Kansas, where Latinos make up 5.5 percent of registered voters, Hispanic turnout could swing the election if candidates target them, according to Matt Barreto, co-founder of polling firm Latino Decisions.

The top-tier gubernatorial races for Latino influence include Illinois, Florida, Arizona, Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Texas, according to the firm. If these elections come down to the margins, the growing Hispanic electorate in each state could decide the outcome, Barreto said.

In response to a reporter's question about whether he was advocating that Latinos stay home in November, Gary Segura, a Latino Decisions co-founder, clarified that he was speaking as an analyst. However, his comments prompted a quick retort from Janet Murguía, president and CEO of the National Council of La Raza, who stated that the NCLR is not encouraging anyone to sit on the sidelines.

A June poll conducted by Latino Decisions with the Center for American Progress found that 57 percent of Latinos said Obama's failure to take executive action would leave them less enthusiastic about voting Democratic and 54 percent said they would be less excited to vote at all. Latino outside groups are aware of the need to try to energize their base, so they expect to push ahead.

Next week, several groups, including the National Hispanic Leadership Agenda and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund, will be in Arizona to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the first statewide anti-immigration proposition in California, which spurred Latino and immigrant participation in the election process. The drive to raise cash has also continued, with the Latino Victory PAC and the Congressional Hispanic Caucus BOLD PAC hosting a fundraiser Wednesday evening at Rosa Mexicano.

Title: U.S. Adds 222,000 Jobs in June, Exceeding Expectations

Article:

The U.S. jobs market experienced a significant growth in June, with the addition of 222,000 jobs, according to the Labor Department's report released on Friday. This figure surpassed the 152,000 jobs added in May and economists' expectations of 140,000 to 200,000 jobs. May's numbers were revised up from the initial gain of 138,000 jobs reported last month.

Employment increased by 37,000 jobs in the healthcare sector, 23,000 in the social assistance sector, 17,000 in the financial sector, and 8,000 in the mining sector. The average hourly earnings increased by 4 cents in June, to $26.25. On a year-over-year basis, wages increased by 2.5 percent.

Since the start of the year, the unemployment rate has decreased by 0.4 percent, and the number of people who are unemployed has fallen by 658,000, according to the Labor Department. The number of long-term unemployed people stayed roughly flat, at 1.7 million people, in June. Since the start of the year, the number of long-term unemployed people has decreased by 322,000.

The labor force participation rate in June was 62.8 percent, about the same as last month. Economists were split on what the jobs report means for the chances of future interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve.

American Action Forum President Douglas Holtz-Eakin wrote on his organization's website that the Labor Department's report will allow the Fed to increase rates. Curt Long, chief economist at the National Association of Federally-Insured Credit Unions, suggested that another rate increase may not happen this year because wage growth has stalled, which could lead to concerns about low inflation.

The jobs numbers come after President Trump earlier this week expressed his discontent on Twitter that the media is not spending enough time covering the economic gains that have occurred since he took office in January. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi (Calif.) stated that the June report "shows an economy where American workers still are not getting the bigger paychecks they deserve."

House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady (R-Texas) said that the jobs report showed "positive gains" but that Congress still has "a lot more work to do to make it easier for all Americans to earn higher wages, find good-paying jobs, and get ahead." Jason Furman, who served as chairman of former President Barack Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, called June's job gains "impressive" but the news on wages "disappointing."

Title: President Trump Implements Changes to Federal Employee Compensation and Dismissal Policies

Article:

President Donald Trump has implemented changes to the compensation and dismissal policies for civilian federal workers, freezing their automatic 2.1% pay raise for 2019. The move, according to the President, is a necessary step to address perceived disparities between federal employee salaries and those in the private sector.

The Congressional Budget Office reports that federal workers, on average, earn higher salaries than their private-sector counterparts performing similar jobs and receive benefit packages that are 47% more generous. Federal employees also receive up to 49 paid days off annually, compared to the private sector's average of 10 days.

In his 2018 State of the Union address, Trump promised to "reward good workers" and "remove federal employees who undermine the public trust." In May, Trump issued executive orders aimed at streamlining the process for terminating problematic employees and shortening the performance improvement period from up to 120 days to 30 days. The changes also aim to expedite the appeals process, reducing the average duration from eight months to an unspecified shorter period.

According to Office of Personnel Management data, only a minuscule half of one percent of federal workers are terminated each year, which is one-fifth the firing rate in the private sector. The changes have received support from more than half of federal workers, according to a June poll, with many expressing frustration over the perceived lack of accountability and the impact on their workloads.

Trump's executive orders also limit federal employees from spending more than 25% of their working hours on union business, a move estimated to save taxpayers $100 million annually. The changes have faced legal challenges from public-sector unions, with a federal district court judge ruling in August that the changes must be decided through collective bargaining, not by the President. Trump's Justice Department is appealing the decision.

In addition to these changes, Trump is working to reform the Veterans Administration, where a scandal erupted in 2014 over employees doctoring patient waiting lists. The changes to the VA Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act, enacted in 2017 to address some of the red tape involved in firing and disciplining wrongdoers, are being held up by union-driven litigation.

One such case involves Jeffrey Sayers, the head of pharmacy for the Los Angeles area VA, who was terminated for mishandling prescription drugs. Sayers is suing for back pay and reinstatement, claiming he was fired too quickly.

The success of Trump's efforts to protect veterans and ensure taxpayer value in every government department hinges on restoring merit-based management in the federal bureaucracy, as the original intent of the Pendleton Act of 1883 was to replace the partisan spoils system with merit. However, the current system, referred to as the TIMER system, rewards employees based on their tenure rather than their work quality.

Title: Federal Appeals Court Upholds Trump Administration's Denial of Grant Money to Sanctuary Jurisdictions

Article:

A federal appeals court on Wednesday ruled in favor of the Trump administration in its dispute with "sanctuary" jurisdictions, allowing the administration to withhold grant money from states that refuse to cooperate with federal immigration authorities. The 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals in New York overturned a lower court ruling that had stopped the administration's 2017 move to withhold grant money from the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant Program.

The decision conflicts with rulings from other appeals courts concerning sanctuary policies, indicating a likely Supreme Court review. The Trump administration's fight against sanctuary policies, which limit local law enforcement cooperation with federal immigration authorities, has been a contentious issue.

The appeals court ruled that the federal government can impose conditions on the federal grants at issue, as these conditions help the federal government enforce national immigration laws and policies supported by successive Democratic and Republican administrations. The court also noted that in immigration policy, the Supreme Court has found that the federal government maintains "broad" and "preeminent" power.

The ruling marks a key win for the administration in its efforts to crack down on the use of sanctuary policies. The Justice Department recently announced a series of measures, and President Trump has called on Congress to pass legislation that would allow victims of crimes committed by illegal immigrants to sue sanctuary cities and states.

The administration has been relentless in its pushback against sanctuary policies, highlighting cases in which criminals are released onto the streets only to re-offend. It has also deployed a series of measures to combat the practice, including deploying elite Border Patrol agents to sanctuary cities to help ICE track down and detain illegal immigrants.

The ruling is potentially an important development, as states like New York rely heavily on Department of Justice grant money. Mike Howell, a former member of the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Legal Counsel, told Fox News that the ruling is significant because of the amount of money that flows in via grants and the federal government's power over states and localities. If the federal government is able to condition that grant money, it's a huge deal, he said.

Sanctuary policies generally forbid local law enforcement from honoring detainers, requests from Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) that they be alerted to the release of an illegal immigrant from custody so they can be picked up by ICE and put through deportation proceedings. Proponents of the policies claim it makes cities safer because it encourages illegal immigrants to cooperate with police without fear of deportation. However, the Trump administration has been pushing back by highlighting cases in which criminals are released onto the streets only to re-offend.

Title: Trump Administration's Immigration Order and the Role of the Ninth Circuit Court

Article:

The Trump administration's immigration order, which temporarily restricts entry to the United States by individuals from seven predominantly Muslim countries, has been a subject of intense debate and legal challenges. The order, which is based on the President's authority over foreign policy and immigration under the U.S. Constitution and the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952, has been upheld by some and criticized by others.

The U.S. Constitution vests plenary power in the President regarding foreign policy and immigration. Section 212 (f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 allows the President to suspend the entry of aliens or any class of aliens into the United States if they are deemed detrimental to the interests of the United States. The Trump administration's order is not dissimilar to previous orders issued by past presidents, with examples including Barack Obama's six-month ban on Iraqi entry in 2011 and Jimmy Carter's ban on Iranians during the hostage crisis.
