The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, based in San Francisco, has been criticized for its ruling that temporarily halted the implementation of the Trump administration's order. The court's decision was based on the grounds that the order and the president's rhetoric on immigration were not politically correct. This decision has sparked calls for reform, with some arguing that the court's ruling ignores federal law and is a result of leftist politics.

The Ninth Circuit Court, like other federal courts, is established by Article 3, Section 1 of the U.S. Constitution. The court, and others like it, can be changed through federal statutes. In 2004, a bill was passed by the Republican-led House to break up the Ninth Circuit into three separate entities, but the plan was shot down by Democrats. The idea of reforming or abolishing the court has been suggested by political figures such as Newt Gingrich, who has criticized the court for making "anti-American" rulings.

The Supreme Court, currently in a 4-4 ideological split, is expected to review the Ninth Circuit's ruling. The outcome of this review remains to be seen, but many legal analysts believe the Supreme Court will overturn the Ninth Circuit's decision. The controversy surrounding the Ninth Circuit's ruling has reignited discussions about the need for court reform, with some arguing that the court's decision is a clear example of the need for change.

The Trump administration's immigration order has sparked intense debate and legal challenges, with the Ninth Circuit Court's ruling being a point of contention. The outcome of the Supreme Court's review of the Ninth Circuit's decision will likely have significant implications for the future of immigration policy in the United States.

Title: Donald Trump Jr. Accuses BBC of Anti-Israel Bias in Tweets Over Jerusalem Attacks

Article:

In a series of tweets, Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of former U.S. President Donald Trump, has accused the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) of publishing misleading headlines regarding attacks against Israelis.

On July 14, 2017, Trump Jr. tweeted, "Three Palestinians killed after deadly stabbing in Jerusalem," which he later described as "as close to being misleading as possible." In response, he stated, "Two Israeli cops killed, third injured, in a Muslim terror attack."

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu acknowledged Trump Jr.'s reaction and expressed gratitude for his unwavering support for Israel. The BBC, it seems, did not learn from this incident. A few days later, Trump Jr. again criticized the BBC for omitting key details about an attack in Jerusalem that left two policemen dead.

Other social media users also noticed the BBC's reporting and provided their own accounts of the events. John Cardillo, a media personality, tweeted, "Two Israeli cops killed, third injured, in a Muslim terror attack."

The BBC did provide more information on the victims, naming the two policemen who died of their injuries in the hospital as Advanced Staff Sergeant Major Kamil Shanan, aged 22, and Advanced Staff Sergeant Major Hail Sattawi, who was 30. Both victims were Druze from Israel's northern Galilee region.

This is not the first time Trump Jr. has called out the BBC's alleged anti-Israel bias. Previously, the BBC deleted a tweet that Trump Jr. criticized.

In addition to his criticism of the BBC, Trump Jr. is currently facing a media firestorm following reports that he met with a Russian lawyer last year after learning she may have opposition research on Hillary Clinton. Some lawmakers are calling for him to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee.

Title: North Korea Announces Resumption of Nuclear Reactor at Yongbyon Plant

Article:

North Korea has announced its intention to restart a nuclear reactor at the Yongbyon nuclear plant, escalating tensions on the Korean Peninsula. The move comes after a rare plenary meeting of the central committee of the ruling Workers' Party, which set a new strategic direction for the nation.

In a statement, North Korea said work to restart all facilities at the Yongbyon nuclear plant will begin without delay. The country cited an acute electricity shortage and the need to bolster its nuclear armed forces as reasons for the move. Analysts suggest that Pyongyang views its nuclear arms program as essential for national security and non-negotiable.

The plutonium reactor, which was shut down in 2007 as part of international nuclear disarmament talks that have since stalled, is capable of producing approximately one bomb's worth of plutonium per year. The declaration of a resumption of plutonium production, along with the restart of other facilities at the main Yongbyon nuclear complex, will heighten concerns in Washington and among its allies about North Korea's timetable for building a nuclear-tipped missile capable of reaching the United States, a technology it is not currently believed to possess.

The announcement comes after the Pentagon sent two F-22 Raptor fighter jets to South Korea to participate in U.S.-South Korean military drills. This follows last week's news that nuclear-capable B-2 stealth bombers had conducted a training flight to the Korean Peninsula.

The North, and its young leader Kim Jong Un, have been blaming the U.S.-South Korean military drills (which have been conducted many times in recent decades) for the current tensions. The North has cut hotlines to the South and annulled the 1953 armistice that ended open warfare on the peninsula.

South Korea's new president, Park Geun-hye, described the security situation as "grave." Yonhap News reports that she believes "discouraging North Korea from provocations through strong diplomatic and military deterrence is just as important as punishing the communist nation after provocations."

State Department spokeswoman Victoria Nuland cast doubts on whether Pyongyang would go ahead with its vow. "There's a long way to go between a stated intention and actually being able to pull it off," she said. At the White House, spokesman Jay Carney said the U.S. was paying close attention to the events on the Korean peninsula. "The entire national security team is focused on it," he said.

Title: FBI Director's Email Review Announcement Sparks Controversy Among Political Figures

Article:

WASHINGTON — The announcement by FBI Director James Comey on Friday regarding the bureau's review of newly-discovered emails related to the investigation of Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server has sparked controversy among political figures, with Clinton campaign officials urging Comey to provide more details about the ongoing investigation.

Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta, appearing on CNN's State of the Union with Jake Tapper, described Comey's letter as "long on innuendo, short on facts." Podesta noted that Comey could not even say if the emails contained significant information. He accused Comey of breaking with precedent by disclosing information about an ongoing investigation before determining if the newly-discovered emails provide any new insights.

"If they're not significant, they're not significant," said Podesta, who called Comey's action "inappropriate." He added that Comey "should have read them first" before making a bombshell announcement about the emails just 11 days before the election.

"This is something that has been tossed into the middle of the campaign," Podesta said. "We would have preferred that that not happen, but now that it has happened, we would prefer that Mr. Comey come forward and explain why he took that unprecedented step."

Attorney General Loretta Lynch objected to Comey's decision to announce the probe, according to Justice Department sources, because she felt it violated department policy to not take steps that may interfere with an election.

The FBI obtained a warrant to review emails linked to Huma Abedin, a longtime Clinton aide and adviser. Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook said he does not believe Comey's action will cost Clinton the election.

"I don't think so," Mook said on NBC's Meet the Press, adding that Clinton is gaining an "insurmountable lead" in the swing state of Nevada.

However, Mook urged Comey to put more information about the emails "out there on the table." If Comey does not do that, Mook said, the FBI director will end up fueling conspiracy theories.

"Let's just get all the information out there so that rumors and hypotheticals can be put to rest," Mook said.

Donald Trump tweeted Sunday that Democratic criticism of Comey is hypocritical. Trump's running mate, Mike Pence, praised the FBI's decision to review the emails but sent an ambiguous message about how it might affect the election.

"I don't think it alters the campaign at all," Pence told Fox News Sunday. "What we already know here is troubling to the American people, and it's convincing millions of Americans that Hillary Clinton is just a risky choice in this election."

Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Kaine called Comey's letter "extremely puzzling" and a "distraction" in an interview with ABC News' This Week.

"It is just extremely puzzling," Kaine said. "Why would you release information that is so incomplete when you haven't even seen the material yourself? Eleven days before an election, why would you talk about an ongoing investigation?"

Kaine added that, "As far as we know now, Director Comey knows nothing about the content of these emails."

Podesta said Abedin has been fully cooperating with the FBI. He also said she remains on the campaign staff.

Trump campaign manager Kellyanne Conway praised Comey's decision to announce the review of the newly found emails.

"Hillary Clinton flouted the law and set up a private server so she could hide stuff from the public," Conway said.

Sen. Ron Johnson, R-Wis., chairman of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, said, "I'm not praising James Comey."

"I think this investigation has been bungled from the start," the senator said on Fox News.

Rep. Adam Schiff of California, the senior Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, called it "a terrible error in judgement by (Comey) to release this kind of ambiguous letter."

"If the director can't clean up this mess, and I hope he will try, I think he ought to acknowledge that he made a serious mistake, and underscore once again that there's nothing that alters that core conclusion he reached in July," Schiff said on ABC's This Week. He was referring to Comey's previous announcement that Clinton had been "extremely careless" in using a private server but had committed no crime.

Title: Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard Garners Increased Interest Following Democratic Debate Performance

Article:

In the first Democratic primary debate, several candidates aimed to gain national recognition, with a crowded stage of ten making it challenging. However, a few candidates managed to stand out, including Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard.

During the debate, there was a significant increase in search traffic for Gabbard, as well as Sen. Cory Booker and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio. While Booker's search traffic spike was anticipated, Gabbard's was more surprising.

Comparing the number of views on each candidate's Wikipedia page from the past week, Gabbard generated the second-highest number of views, trailing only Sen. Elizabeth Warren. When examining the past month of page views on Wikipedia, Gabbard's totals are mostly keeping pace with the frontrunners, and when compared to another candidate polling in single digits, like Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar, Gabbard is more than doubling her totals.

Google Trends data suggests that the increased interest in Gabbard may not be entirely unexpected. The past month of search data shows that, aside from her home state of Hawaii, it is individuals from New Hampshire and Iowa—the early primary states—who are searching for information about her.

However, it is essential to note that Gabbard's increased interest does not necessarily indicate that she is a serious contender. Gabbard has clashed with fellow Democrats by being critical of President Obama's foreign policy, stating that his administration "refuses to recognize" that "radical Islam" is responsible for terrorism. She has also been criticized for expressing support for Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad.

In conclusion, the heightened interest in Gabbard following the Democratic debate may not have come out of nowhere, as she has generated significant search traffic and Wikipedia page views. However, her controversial foreign policy stances and past criticisms may limit her chances of becoming a serious contender in the Democratic primary.

Title: Progressives Struggle to Articulate Economic Benefits of Immigration as Critics Highlight Alleged Harm

Article:

A growing reluctance among progressives to articulate the economic benefits of immigration is notable, especially given the clear and concrete arguments made by critics who argue that immigrants increase crime, lower wages, threaten jobs, spread disease, strain government budgets, and abet terrorism. However, it is important to note that these claims are not universally supported, as immigrants have crime rates lower than native-born individuals.

In contrast, progressives often defend immigration with vague, abstract statements such as "our diversity is our strength." Progressives tend to approach the issue through a civil rights lens, focusing on doing justice to the poor and oppressed, rather than meeting America's economic needs or slowing demographic decline.

Andrew Selee, president of the Migration Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research group, notes that progressives have yet to develop a coherent, cogent, and succinct political case for immigration. "People on the left have a hard time arguing why immigration is important to the country," Selee said. "This is still one of the most pro-immigrant societies in the world, but that diffuse feeling hasn't been matched with a coherent, cogent, succinct political case."

The current border crisis has garnered significant attention, often overshadowing the benefits of legal immigration. It is worth noting that three-quarters of immigrants are in the United States legally. With the foreign-born share of the population nearing record highs, and restrictionists seeking cuts in legal admissions, progressives cannot afford to remain merely anti-anti-immigrant. If they want to sustain the longest, most diverse epoch of mass migration in American history, they need to explain why.

To understand the progressives' mindset, it is important to understand their two-decade quest for legalization and its bitter residue. If the right sees the undocumented as invaders, the left sees them as victims of poverty and violence. Moreover, progressives view them as family and friends. The average undocumented person has been in the United States for 15 years, and many have American children. Progressives warn that deportation campaigns destabilize entire communities, harming immigrants and natives alike.

Title: Group of Economists Advocates for Continued Direct Cash Payments to Americans

Article:

A group of 153 economists, many of whom are reportedly of a left-leaning political persuasion, have signed a letter urging U.S. policymakers to continue providing direct cash payments to Americans until the economy strengthens. The economists argue that these payments can improve financial security, boost consumer spending, and speed up the economic recovery.

The letter, organized by the Economic Security Project and The Justice Collaborative, suggests that the initial economic impact payments served as a lifeline for some during the pandemic, and that significant economic fallout and continued demand lag will persist even as businesses reopen and jobs return.

The signatories of the letter include Jason Furman, who chaired the Council of Economic Advisers during the Obama Administration, Claudia Sahm, a former Fed economist, Darrick Hamilton from the Kirwan Institute for the Study of Race and Ethnicity at The Ohio State University, and Indivar Dutta-Gupty, co-executive director at the Georgetown Center on Poverty and Inequality. Some of the signatories are reportedly advising the campaign of presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden, according to Reuters.

The $600 supplement added to weekly unemployment benefits, which has reportedly discouraged millions of Americans from seeking employment, is set to expire at the end of the month. With jobs still scarce, jobless Americans may face a "cash cliff" without continued government support.

Congressional lawmakers are currently on a two-week recess and will face pressure to make decisions when they reconvene in late July. With money being printed and used to plug the record US budget deficit, the article suggests that Congress may promptly approve trillions more in handouts to avoid potential social unrest.

Title: New York and California Face Potential Loss of Congressional Seats Due to Population Decline

Article:

The United States Census Bureau has released population estimates indicating that New York and California, two liberal states, are among 27 states and the District of Columbia that have experienced a decline in residents due to domestic migration over the last two years. The Empire State and the Golden State are poised to lose congressional seats due to this ongoing exodus.

New York, one of only 10 states to suffer a total population decline in 2018-19, experienced its fourth consecutive annual decrease after five years of growth, and the largest population drop of any state, according to the census data. The state's population has been stagnant over the past decade, with a modest 75,459 increase in residents since 2010, a growth rate of just 0.4 percent, ranking 46th-lowest out of 50 states. This stagnation is likely to result in the loss of one or two congressional seats in the coming years.

Staten Island Republican Councilman Joe Borelli attributed the population decline to the high cost of living in New York, including high taxes, regulations, and housing costs. "The cost of living in New York — the high taxes, regulations, and housing costs — are making it untenable to live the American dream here," Borelli told The New York Post, noting how many high school friends have moved out of New York.

California's population growth has also continued to slow, and for the first time in the state's history, it may also lose a congressional seat. The Los Angeles Times reported that the state's economic woes are making it harder for people to make a living, so they're leaving. William Frey, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, told the newspaper that California's population migration could result in the loss of a seat in the US House of Representatives. California currently has 53 seats in the House.

According to Frey's analysis of census data, Texas may gain three seats after the 2020 decennial count, while states such as Arizona, Colorado, and Oregon may gain one seat apiece. The apportionment population count for each of the 50 states includes the state's total resident population—citizens and non-citizens—as well as a count of the overseas federal employees and their dependents who have that state listed as their home state in their employers' administrative records, according to the US Census Bureau.

Title: Trump to Announce Executive Action on 2020 Census Citizenship Question Despite Ongoing Legal Challenges

Article:

President Donald Trump is set to announce an executive action regarding the inclusion of a citizenship question in the 2020 census, despite ongoing court challenges. The announcement is expected to be made during a news conference following a planned meeting on social media this afternoon. The exact timing is estimated to be around 5:00 p.m., either in the Rose Garden or another location at the White House.

The administration's efforts to add the contentious question have been blocked in the courts due to challenges from some U.S. states and civil rights groups. Critics argue that asking about citizenship in the census discriminates against racial minorities and is aimed at giving Republicans an unfair advantage in elections. Trump and his supporters argue that it is important to know how many non-citizens are living in the country.

The administration is still finalizing the details of the action, which is expected to be an executive order, according to one of the officials. The administration's attempts to add a question to the nation's decennial population survey have become embroiled in a legal fight not only due to the opposition of plaintiffs but also due to the Department of Justice's handling of the cases.

The case has already reached the U.S. Supreme Court, which last month ruled against Trump's first attempt to add the question, stating the administration's rationale was "contrived." However, the court left the door open for a possible addition if officials could offer a new explanation. Since then, the Justice Department has sought to replace the lawyers handling the case. On Wednesday, a second federal judge rejected the department's efforts, stating it had to offer detailed reasoning for the change.

Attorneys within the Trump administration have been studying the census issue and intend to keep the president's order within the confines of the Supreme Court decision. However, they are aware that whatever action Trump takes is likely to be challenged in court again. The U.S. Constitution specifically assigns the job of overseeing the census to Congress, which could complicate any effort to add the question via presidential missive.

Trump remains insistent that the question be added to the census despite the legal challenges. The census is used to determine how many seats each state gets in the U.S. House of Representatives and also affects how billions of dollars in federal funds are distributed across the country.

Title: Congressional Republicans Advocate for Medicare and Medicaid Cuts in Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

Article:

Congressional Republicans are advocating for significant reductions in Medicare and Medicaid spending as part of the negotiations to address the fiscal cliff and deficit reduction. This stance is primarily directed against two programs that have been instrumental in public welfare for the past half-century.

Postelection polls indicate that large majorities of voters for both President Obama and Mitt Romney opposed large Medicare cuts as a means to reduce the budget deficit. The Obama administration has already pledged to extract over $1 trillion in savings from these programs over the next decade. With limited room for further cuts without affecting the most vulnerable Americans, the focus may shift towards finding alternative methods to address the fiscal cliff.

The Affordable Care Act includes provisions that will reduce projected Medicare spending by $716 billion over 10 years. These savings are primarily achieved through reducing annual increases in Medicare reimbursements for hospitals, nursing homes, and other healthcare providers, as well as by reducing unjustified subsidies paid to private Medicare Advantage plans. During the campaign, the Romney-Ryan ticket criticized the president for making such large cuts and even promised to restore all of it.

In addition to these savings, President Obama, in his budget for fiscal year 2013, proposed an additional $340 billion in Medicare spending reductions over 10 years. This includes tactics such as requiring drugmakers to pay rebates to Medicare in certain circumstances, reducing payments to some healthcare providers for treating patients just released from the hospital, reducing coverage of bad debts that hospitals and skilled nursing homes have failed to collect from patients, and charging higher premiums to high-income beneficiaries.

These cuts may be acceptable as part of a larger budget deal to avert the fiscal cliff. However, there may be limited options for further reducing Medicare or Medicaid spending beyond these measures, as the fiscal health of healthcare providers should not be jeopardized.

Title: Senate Impeachment Trial Resumes Monday: Final Arguments, Vote on Trump's Conviction or Acquittal Expected

Article:

The Senate impeachment trial of President Donald Trump resumes on Monday at 11 a.m. EST. The trial will continue with closing arguments from both the House impeachment managers and Trump's legal team. The Senate is expected to vote on whether to convict or acquit the president on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress on Wednesday.

The two articles of impeachment were approved by the Democratic-controlled House on Dec. 18 following a two-month inquiry into allegations that Trump held up military aid to pressure Ukraine into announcing investigations for his political benefit, including one involving former Vice President Joe Biden, a Democratic rival in the 2020 election.

Trump has maintained his innocence and claimed he was acting to combat corruption. His defense team has argued that the House failed to prove its case, that the abuse of power charge is too subjective, and that the obstruction of Congress charge infringes on the president's right to claim executive privilege in court. Attorney Alan Dershowitz made the argument, which many legal scholars dispute, that even if the allegations were true, they were not impeachable because they did not constitute a crime.

Last week, the Senate voted 51-49 against issuing subpoenas for additional witnesses and documents, which would have delayed the trial's conclusion. Each side will have two hours to argue the case one final time before senators take to the floor to deliver speeches explaining how they view the charges. With a 53-47 seat Republican majority in the Senate and a two-thirds vote needed for conviction, it is almost certain the president will be acquitted in the final vote on Wednesday.

Senators will vote Wednesday to acquit or convict Trump.

During the impeachment trial and the upcoming Iowa caucuses on Monday, Democratic candidates Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, Amy Klobuchar, and Michael Bennet will have to juggle their campaign activities.

Lead House impeachment manager, Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., said on CBS News' "Face the Nation" on Sunday that Democrats "proved the corrupt scheme that they charged in the articles of impeachment." Schiff stated that the only question now is whether the president should be removed from office because he has been found guilty of these offenses.

Schiff also said that even if the Senate votes to acquit, "the president was impeached" because "by standing up to this president as we have, by making the case to the American people, by exposing his wrongdoing, we are helping to slow the momentum away from our democratic values."

Schiff declined to comment on whether the House would continue to seek testimony from former national security adviser John Bolton, who reportedly states in his upcoming book that Trump told him the aid to Ukraine was tied to the investigations Trump desired. However, Schiff said, "the truth will come out."

The news of John Bolton's book has cast a shadow over the impeachment trial. GOP Sens. Joni Ernst of Iowa and Lamar Alexander of Tennessee stated that while Trump's actions were not impeachable, he should have gone through the Department of Justice if he had concerns about Biden and his son's former position on the board of Burisma, a Ukrainian energy company.

"I think, generally speaking, going after corruption would be the right thing to do," Ernst, who declared she will vote to acquit, said on CNN's "State of the Union." "But I think he could have done it through different channels," she added, referring to Trump's decision to have his personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, handle it.

On NBC News' "Meet the Press," Alexander said he believed Trump "called the president of Ukraine and asked him to become involved in investigating Joe Biden." He also said, "at least in part, he delayed the military and other assistance to Ukraine in order to encourage that investigation."

"I think he should not have done it. I think it was wrong," said Alexander, who plans to vote for acquittal. "If he was upset about Joe Biden and his son and what they were doing in Ukraine, he should have called the attorney general and told him that, and let the attorney general handle it the way they always handle cases that involve public figures," said Alexander, who is not seeking re-election in November's election.

When asked why he thought Trump did not go to the DOJ, Alexander said, "Maybe he did not know to do it."

"I would think he would think twice before he did it again," he added.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., told Fox News on Sunday that "the day of reckoning is coming for congressional and Senate oversight of Joe Biden." Graham stated that he would bring in State Department officials and ask them why they did not do something about the obvious conflict of interests Joe Biden had.

"We're going to get to the bottom of this," he said. "And I can prove beyond any doubt that Joe Biden's effort in the Ukraine to root out corruption was undercut, because he let his son sit on the board of the most corrupt company in the Ukraine, and we're not going to give him a pass on that."

In an interview with Bloomberg News, Ernst said Democrats had lowered the bar for impeachment to the point that if Biden were to become president, there would be voices calling for his removal because of Hunter Biden's connection to Burisma.

"I think this door of impeachable whatever has been opened," Ernst told Bloomberg. "We can have a situation where if it should ever be President Biden, that immediately, people, right the day after he would be elected, would be saying, 'Well, we're going to impeach him.'"

During the impeachment trial, senators asked several questions, some of which are still unclear. The outcome of the trial will determine whether Trump is acquitted or convicted, and the implications for the 2020 election and future impeachments.

Title: Three Reasons for Democratic Opposition to Border Wall Called False: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

In a recent column, conservative commentator Dennis Prager argues that three reasons commonly cited by Democrats for their opposition to building a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border are false. Prager asserts that these reasons are not only unfounded but also constitute lies.

Prager questions whether Democrats genuinely believe these arguments, suggesting that their beliefs are either delusional or intentionally deceptive. He points out that left-wing academics, including his former professors at Columbia University, have historically held controversial views on issues such as the Cold War, gender, and race.

Prager also questions the Democrats' stance on the cost of the wall, stating that the $5.7 billion price tag is a small fraction of U.S. federal spending and that Democrats have consistently advocated for increased government spending. He also cites examples of large-scale projects, such as California's high-speed train, that have been pursued despite significant financial burdens.

Regarding the effectiveness of the wall, Prager points out that many Democrats, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Chuck Schumer, have previously supported border fencing. He questions whether Democrats view fencing as effective but a wall as ineffective.

Lastly, Prager questions the moral argument against the wall, stating that Democrats have not provided a clear rationale for this position. He also questions whether Democrats view physical barriers as immoral in other contexts, such as around homes or communities.

Prager concludes by suggesting that the left's use of lies to achieve their goals is a long-standing practice, and that truth has never been a core value for leftists. He emphasizes that while truth is a value for both liberals and conservatives, it has never been a value for the left, who prioritize other objectives over truth.

Dennis Prager is a nationally syndicated radio talk-show host and columnist. His latest book, "The Rational Bible," was published by Regnery in April 2018. He is the founder of Prager University and can be contacted at dennisprager.com.

Title: The Importance of Feeling Connected to Something Larger: A Key Factor in Living a Fulfilling Life, According to Behavioral Science

Article:

A key factor in living a fulfilling life, according to behavioral science, is feeling connected to something larger than oneself. This concept, which exists at the heart of both ancient religions and modern social-justice movements, is not a new one, but it is often overlooked or difficult to achieve in practice.

In his book "The Happiness Hypothesis," NYU social psychologist Jonathan Haidt identifies this sense of connection as one of three major themes of a fulfilling life. He compares humans to plants, stating that, like plants, people need love, work, and a connection to something larger to thrive.

On his website, Haidt expands on this point, stating that humans are like bees, needing to be part of a larger hive or a larger body to make sense of their lives. In modern society, people have become independent, free to live as they please, which may contribute to feelings of aimlessness or a lack of meaning in life for some individuals.

Haidt suggests that joining a cause or organization with a noble purpose can help individuals find this sense of connection. He recommends joining an organization with a long and noble past, as it can provide a sense of "vital engagement." This term refers to the crucial relationship that exists between a person and their surroundings.

Haidt writes, "It is worth striving to get the right relationships between yourself and others, between yourself and your work, and between yourself and something larger than yourself. If you get these relationships right, a sense of purpose and meaning will emerge."

In conclusion, the pursuit of meaning seems like a fitting theme for 2017, as individuals seek to find a sense of connection and purpose in their lives. Joining a cause or organization with a noble purpose can provide a means to achieve this sense of connection and contribute to a fulfilling life.

Title: Political Observers Predict Mitt Romney Victory in 2012 Presidential Election

Article:

Political observers, including veteran Republican campaign pollster John McLaughlin, are predicting a victory for Mitt Romney in the 2012 Presidential Election. McLaughlin, who is known for his accurate predictions, such as the 2010 wave that powered the GOP to capture more than five dozen seats in the House, believes that Romney has surged in all the target states and will win the election by a margin of 5 percentage points.

His prediction contradicts most polling, which shows a tight national race between Romney and President Obama, and state polls that show Obama leading in most battlegrounds. The only poll that shows Romney clearly winning is the respected Gallup national tracking poll of likely voters, which gives the Republican nominee a 5 percentage-point advantage.

Mark Meckler, co-founder and former national coordinator of the National Tea Party Patriots, also predicts a Romney win by 6 percentage points. He believes that the wave of anti-debt, anti-big-government voters that swept the Democrats in the 2010 congressional elections is readying itself again and will deliver a Romney victory.

Tea party coordinator Toby Marie Walker in Waco, Texas, sees the same momentum, predicting that Romney will receive 54 percent of the national vote. She believes that the shift in voter sentiment, which she has observed through phone calls to independents in other states, will give Romney more Senate seats than pollsters suggest.

However, not all political observers share this view. Republican pollster Whit Ayres sees little evidence of a congressional wave this time, as his polling shows an even split between Democrats and Republicans on the generic ballot. Nevertheless, Ayres believes that independents who had voted for Obama by an 8-point margin in 2008 are now voting against Obama by double digits.

Nate Silver, who writes the FiveThirtyEight blog at The New York Times, believes that the election is moving in Obama's direction. He currently gives Obama a 77 percent chance of winning and predicts that he will receive nearly 300 electoral votes, up 10 from a week ago.

Despite these predictions, some voters, such as Alaska tea partyer David Eastman, are not convinced. Eastman believes that small-government voters do not have much enthusiasm for Romney's campaign.

John McLaughlin attributes the backlash against Obama from Hurricane Sandy as a significant factor in the election's outcome. He believes that voters without power who are cutting down trees in the Northeast and are very upset post-hurricane will not be kind to the incumbent president or his party if they lack power through Election Day.

Title: Congressional Hearings on Benghazi and the Middle East: Expanding the Scope of Inquiry

Article:

Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is testifying before Congress regarding the events in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012. The hearing is expected to focus on the security lapses, the lack of rescue attempts, and the overall response to the attack that resulted in the deaths of four Americans.

However, this article suggests that instead of focusing solely on the Benghazi incident, Congress should broaden the scope of the hearings to discuss the administration's policy towards the Arab world. The author argues that the region has descended into political and economic chaos in the two years since North Africa and the Middle East were relatively calm and stable.

The article poses ten questions for Secretary Clinton, focusing on various aspects of the administration's policy in the region. These questions include inquiries about the administration's relationship with the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt, the handling of Libya's weapons caches, the potential threat of chemical weapons in Syria, accountability for the Benghazi attack, the effectiveness of the 'light footprint' strategy, the safety of American civilians in Iraq and Afghanistan, the administration's relationship with Israel, potential responses to Iran's nuclear program, contingency plans for rescuing Americans in the region, and the expansion of drone wars.

The author contends that Secretary Clinton has much to explain, and that the hearings provide an opportunity to hold the administration accountable for its policies in the Arab world. The article concludes by suggesting that if Congress and the American people do not receive answers during these hearings, they may one day ask, "who lost the Arab world?" The author emphasizes the importance of getting Secretary Clinton on the record now.

Title: Fox News Misrepresents Republican Support for the Sequester in Budget Control Act of 2011

Article:

Two reports on Fox News' Special Report with Bret Baier have been criticized for misrepresenting the Republican Party's support for the across-the-board automatic spending cuts known as the sequester. The reports reinforce a right-wing narrative that President Obama is solely responsible for these cuts, while in reality, a majority of Republicans in both the House and Senate voted for the Budget Control Act of 2011, which included the sequester.

In August 2011, shortly after the Senate passed the Budget Control Act, House Speaker John Boehner celebrated the law as "a positive step forward that begins to rein in federal spending." House Majority Leader Eric Cantor touted the law as "a significant move" and said it "will finally begin to change the way Washington spends taxpayer dollars." House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan declared the law a "victory for those committed to controlling government spending and growing our economy." In total, 174 Republican representatives and 28 Republican senators—a majority of Republicans in both chambers—voted for the Budget Control Act of 2011.

However, in recent weeks, Fox News and other right-wing media outlets have been aggressively pushing myths about the sequester, including the false narrative that President Obama is single-handedly responsible for the looming spending cuts. On Wednesday's edition of Special Report, Fox News' chief White House correspondent Ed Henry framed a report on the sequester around the narrative that it was an Obama initiative and quoted Republican Congressman Randy Forbes blaming Obama for it. Though the report included Democratic Sen. Max Baucus saying that Congress shares the blame for the automatic cuts, Henry did not point out that Republicans not only actively supported the idea but overwhelmingly voted for the law.

In a later segment during the same show, Fox again covered up Republican support for the sequester. Discussing the consequences of the spending cuts, chief political correspondent Carl Cameron said, "President Obama, who first proposed the sequester, and his party, are trying to blame the GOP for dire economic consequences, in particular to the military. But in 2009 he proposed spending $14 billion less than what the military is currently budgeted for should sequester happen." Cameron did not mention the Republican support for the Budget Control Act of 2011.

Title: Lessons from the Wisconsin Recall Election: Insights from the Democratic Side

Article:

In the aftermath of Republican Governor Scott Walker's re-election in Wisconsin, Democratic activists and politicos have been reflecting on the reasons behind their party's loss. NPR's senior Washington editor, Ron Elving, provided insights on some aspects of the election, while this article focuses on the perspectives of Democratic activists in Waukesha, Wisconsin.

The mood among these activists, who were interviewed after the election, was a mix of exhaustion, disappointment, and combative reflection. They expressed concerns about the absence of President Obama during the recall effort, but acknowledged that his paid Wisconsin staff was involved in the recall campaign.

One key takeaway from the discussions was the realization that assumptions about union households should be avoided. Democrats at the table were surprised by the exit poll statistic showing that 38 percent of voters with a labor union member in the family voted for Walker. Kristin Hansen, a volunteer with Organizing for America, Obama's re-election organization, stated, "You can't assume just because a person is a union member, they are also a Democrat."

Another issue raised was the impact of stricter voting registration laws enacted by the GOP-controlled Legislature since 2010. These changes have limited opportunities for registering voters, expanded blackout days for voter registration efforts, and set earlier deadlines for absentee or early voting. The new rules meant that Democrats had only eight days after the primary to register new voters.

The activists also noted the real sentiment among voters against recalls, with fewer than a third of voters thinking recalls were appropriate for any reason. This sentiment was not effectively addressed or combated by the Democrats, according to the activists.

Furthermore, the impact of the Latino community and first-time voters was highlighted. The local Obama campaign lacked bilingual field organizers and visible volunteers from the Latino community, which was a missed opportunity, according to the activists.

In conclusion, the Democratic activists emphasized the importance of avoiding assumptions about union households, addressing stricter voting registration laws, combating anti-recall sentiment, and engaging with the Latino community and first-time voters in future elections.

Title: West African Healthcare Workers Undergo Intense Training to Combat Ebola Outbreak

Article:

In the ongoing battle against the Ebola virus in West Africa, the lack of isolation wards for infected individuals is a significant challenge. In response, President Obama has announced plans to construct 17 new Ebola Treatment Units (ETUs) in Liberia, which will require thousands of trained and willing healthcare workers.

In Monrovia, efforts are underway to train local doctors, nurses, and janitors on how to safely care for Ebola patients. The World Health Organization (WHO) has taken over a two-story concrete hotel and transformed the ground floor into a mock ETU.

During a recent training session, trainees dressed in protective gear were simulating the care of an Ebola patient. The exercise, part of a one-week course, involved several trainees getting "splattered" with fake blood, a reminder of the real-life challenges they will face.

Dr. Srinivas Murthy, an infectious disease specialist from the University of British Columbia, is one of the WHO staff guiding the trainees. He emphasized the importance of maintaining calm and following protocol to minimize the risk of infection.

The trainees are the second group to go through the course. Of the 72 people in the class, 40 are healthcare workers of various types, including doctors, nurses, physicians' assistants, and medical students. The remaining 32 are hygienists who will be responsible for cleaning and disinfecting the ETUs.

During the training, the trainees encountered numerous challenges, such as fogged goggles, torn gloves, and overheating in their protective suits. Despite these difficulties, they were expected to maintain focus and follow protocol.

As more Ebola treatment units are built, Liberia needs to find thousands of other workers who are willing to take on the risks associated with treating Ebola patients. The WHO aims to train several thousand new workers in the coming months.

Title: Dalits in India Call for Acknowledgement of Centuries of Oppression, Citing Parallels with U.S. Protests

Article:

In response to the anti-racism protests in the United States, members of the Dalit community in India, historically referred to as "untouchables," have called for recognition of the centuries of oppression they have endured. Dalits, who are situated outside the Hindu caste hierarchy, have historically faced violence, segregation, and exclusion from various aspects of society, including being barred from having their shadows touch those of people from more privileged castes.

Omprakash Mahato, president of the Birsa Ambedkar Phule Students Association, a Dalit organization at New Delhi's Jawaharlal Nehru University, expressed solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement, stating, "We extend our solidarity because we feel them and we have faced discrimination ourselves."

India outlawed discrimination based on caste in 1955, but ancient biases against Dalits and members of less privileged caste groups persist, making it difficult for them to access education, jobs, and housing. Mahato stated, "In India, people need to admit their role in everyday discrimination faced by Dalits and only then can a dialogue for change be initiated. We hope what they are seeing unfolding globally will lead to soul searching."

Dalits and scheduled tribes, Indigenous peoples who are often isolated or disadvantaged, make up about a quarter of India's population of 1.3 billion. Ruth Manorama, who works for the rights of Dalit women, stated, "Indian Dalits have historically learned a lot from the struggle of the African Americans." She also highlighted the discrimination faced by Dalits during India's strict lockdown, with Dalits often waiting longer for food or financial aid at local distribution points and being turned away.

A Change.org petition, signed by approximately 300 people, emphasizes that "the lives of Dalits and minorities matter too" and urges Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to acknowledge that "caste discrimination is included in racial discrimination." Henri Tiphagne of People's Watch, a charity supporting the petition, stated, "It is a good time for people in India to understand and to point out to the government that racial discrimination is not only what you see in America, but it is the same as how so-called 'untouchables' are treated in India."

Title: Trump and McMaster Disagree on Russian Interference in 2016 Election

Article:

President Donald Trump and his National Security Advisor H.R. McMaster have publicly disagreed over the issue of Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election. On Sunday, Trump tweeted that McMaster "forgot to say that the results of the 2016 election were not impacted or changed by the Russians."

McMaster, in a speech at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday, stated that it is now "incontrovertible" that Russia interfered in the 2016 election. He emphasized that the evidence is now "really incontrovertible and available in the public domain," contrasting previous difficulties in attributing such interference.

McMaster's remarks came after a federal grand jury indicted more than a dozen Russians in connection with the interference. In his speech, McMaster strongly condemned the Russian disinformation campaign, which, according to the indictment, aimed to sway American voters in favor of Trump.

In a separate tweet on Sunday, Trump seemed to deny ever denying Russia's involvement, stating, "I never said Russia did not meddle in the election, I said 'it may be Russia, or China or another country or group, or it may be a 400-pound genius sitting in bed and playing with his computer.' The Russian 'hoax' was that the Trump campaign colluded with Russia - it never did!"

On Saturday, McMaster did not equivocate in his remarks, using forceful language to convey American strength against Russian disinformation campaigns. He emphasized the need for the West to unite in defending against such threats.

In response to a question from a Russian politician about potential U.S.-Russia cooperation on cybersecurity, McMaster seemed to dismiss the notion, stating, "I'm surprised there are any Russian cyber experts available, based on how active most of them have been in undermining our democracies in the West."

Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, who spoke minutes earlier from the same stage, dismissed the indictment, calling it "just blabber." The New York Times reports that Lavrov attempted to bolster his case that Russia has done nothing wrong by citing Vice President Mike Pence's earlier assessment of the FBI investigation.

Pence told Axios on Wednesday that "irrespective of efforts that were made in 2016 by foreign powers, it is the universal conclusion of our intelligence communities that none of those efforts had any effect on the outcome of the 2016 election." However, former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper told NPR that "the intelligence community has neither the authority nor the capability to make such a judgment as to whether there was or was not impact on the election."

On Friday, President Trump conceded in a tweet that Russia did carry out an "anti-US campaign," but he stated that it began well before he launched his presidential run. "The results of the election were not impacted. The Trump campaign did nothing wrong - no collusion!" he wrote.

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who oversees the investigation, stated on Friday that there is "no allegation in this indictment that any American was a knowing participant in this illegal activity" and "no allegation that this activity actually altered the outcome of the 2016 election."

On Sunday, Trump implied in a tweet that the investigation itself plays into Russia's plans. "If it was the GOAL of Russia to create discord, disruption and chaos within the U.S., then, with all of the Committee Hearings, Investigations and Party hatred, they have succeeded beyond their wildest dreams," he wrote. "They are laughing their asses off in Moscow. Get smart America!"

Title: Parkland Student Activists Announce Nationwide Bus Tour for Gun Control Advocacy and Voter Registration

Article:

The student gun control activists from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, who gained prominence following the mass shooting at their school in Parkland, Florida, in March, will embark on an extensive bus tour on Monday. The tour, titled "March for Our Lives: Road to Change," will make 70 stops in 20 states, with the aim of advocating for stricter gun control legislation and voter registration.

The tour will be led by David Hogg and Emma Gonzalez, who have emerged as de facto spokespeople for the youth gun control movement. In an interview with Axios, Hogg, who graduated on Sunday along with Gonzalez and their fellow Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School seniors, stated, "I'm glad I'm getting my diploma and not my death certificate."

Gonzalez, who plans to attend the New College of Florida in the fall, believes the tour will help increase support for the youth gun control movement among lawmakers who are concerned about the political implications of publicly opposing a coalition of young people. Gonzalez stated, "If you don't support this, it'll look like you're going against kids."

The nationwide tour will be accompanied by a separate Florida-specific tour featuring stops in all of the state's congressional districts. As the Parkland students' home state, Florida has been a focal point of their voter registration and gun control awareness campaigns in recent months. However, the results thus far have not been encouraging: in six of Florida's seven largest counties, including Broward county where the shooting occurred, youth voter registration is down relative to 2014.

The student activists experienced a surge of enthusiasm in the wake of the shooting, but public support for gun control as the nation's top political priority has decreased significantly since then. Just 6% of respondents listed gun control as the most important problem facing the U.S. in an April Gallup poll, down from 13% in March.

Title: House Republicans to Move Toward Contempt Charges Against Attorney General Eric Holder

Article:

House Republicans have announced their intention to move forward with contempt charges against Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., escalating a power struggle over the Fast and Furious operation, a botched gun-walking program initiated during the Obama administration. The move, supported by Republican leaders, will see House Oversight and Government Reform Committee Chairman Darrell E. Issa hold a vote next week to recommend contempt proceedings, with a House floor vote potentially following shortly thereafter.

Administration officials have dismissed the move as political, while the Justice Department stated it was close to reaching an agreement to share some of the information the Oversight Committee is seeking. House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, stated that Mr. Holder has had multiple opportunities to comply, and that the Justice Department is "out of excuses."

Trust between both parties has eroded, with Democrats arguing that the GOP is pursuing a political agenda to discredit President Obama, and Republicans citing repeated denials and inaccurate information provided by the administration. Mr. Holder and Mr. Obama have acknowledged flaws in Fast and Furious, a program that allowed guns to be sold to straw purchasers in the U.S., knowing they were being sent to Mexican cartels.

The operation was primarily handled by Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives employees, with minimal oversight from the Justice Department, according to the administration. The department initially denied many details of the operation, including the fact that guns were knowingly "walked" without being tracked, but recanted in December, taking the embarrassing step of officially withdrawing an inaccurate letter sent to Congress.

Mr. Issa is seeking to obtain documents that he believes would show how the Justice Department changed its stance on the operation's details and the level of blame that should be assigned. His committee issued a subpoena for documents in October, and Mr. Issa stated on Monday that the Justice Department is still withholding the information.

The Justice Department has not provided any valid reasons for withholding the information, according to Mr. Issa. Mr. Holder's spokeswoman described the contempt proceedings as "political games" that interrupted what she claimed had been productive talks on turning over information.

Deputy Attorney General James M. Cole stated that he has offered to meet with Mr. Issa to negotiate a compromise on documents, but that Mr. Issa has not responded to this request. In a letter on Monday afternoon, Mr. Cole said, "The conversations between our staffs have been productive, and we believe that an amicable resolution of these matters is achievable. Because of this, the committee's decision to set a hearing on its draft contempt resolution is premature."

During the operation, nearly 2,000 guns were sold to straw purchasers with the expectation that they would be trafficked across the border to the Sinaloa Cartel. ATF agents lost track of the guns, and the guns began to appear at crime scenes, including at least two weapons found at the scene of a shootout that killed U.S. Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry in December 2010.

Mr. Holder stated that he took steps in 2011 to shut down the program and requested an internal audit to hold employees accountable. Last week, Mr. Holder told another House panel that he would be willing to meet with Mr. Boehner to try to work out a solution that would allow the documents to be reviewed without impinging on the executive branch's deliberative process.

This is not the first time the Obama administration has faced contempt of Congress proceedings. In 2008, the House approved a contempt resolution against former White House lawyer Harriet Miers, seeking an interview with her on her role in the firings of U.S. attorneys. She refused an on-the-record sworn interview with congressional investigators. The House voted 223-32 to hold her in contempt, with most Republicans boycotting the vote.

At the same time, former White House political adviser Karl Rove was refusing to be interviewed by the House Judiciary Committee. That matter never reached the House floor. In 2009, after President George W. Bush left office, Democrats and former Bush officials reached an agreement to produce documents and on-the-record testimony.

Title: Philanthropist Patty Quillin Donates $1.5 Million to Support Criminal Justice Reform in Los Angeles County

Article:

Billionaire philanthropist Patty Quillin, wife of Netflix CEO Reed Hastings, has donated at least $1.5 million to support efforts to reform the criminal justice system in Los Angeles County. Quillin, who resides in Santa Cruz, has contributed $1 million to a group aiming to replace incumbent Los Angeles County District Attorney Jackie Lacey with a more progressive prosecutor and $500,000 to support a voter referendum (Measure R) that mandates changes for the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department and reduces the jail population. Both contests will appear on the countywide ballot on March 3, also known as Super Tuesday.

Quillin's $1 million donation went to an independent expenditure (IE) committee backing former San Francisco District Attorney George Gascón, who is running to become L.A. County's top law enforcement official. The "Run, George, Run: George Gascón for LA DA 2020" committee includes national leaders from the criminal justice reform community, such as Black Lives Matter co-founder Patrisse Cullors. The committee has funded polling, billboard space, and produced a series of ads.

During Gascón's eight-year tenure as San Francisco's District Attorney, he had the support of New York billionaire George Soros, who has spent over $20 million to promote like-minded prosecutor candidates throughout the United States. However, Mr. Soros has not been involved in the current race. The pro-Gascón IE's top individual donors, in addition to Quillin, include Liz Simons, the daughter of a retired hedge fund billionaire, who donated $500,000 last month.

Quillin is the director of a fund at the Silicon Valley Community Foundation, a group that has awarded over $6 billion in grants since its formation in 2007. Both she and her husband are reportedly "black label" donors, meaning they have provided tens of millions of dollars or more to the institution. In 2012, Hastings and Quillin pledged to give half of their fortune to philanthropy or charitable causes.

Quillin has also been identified as a financial supporter of a nonprofit publication called "The Appeal," which focuses on local prosecutors and criminal justice policies. The outlet has published several articles critical of D.A. Lacey, and Gascón and his campaign have shared some of these stories on social media.

The Los Angeles Police Protective League, which represents rank-and-file LAPD officers, has directed $1 million into its own political action committee opposing Gascón. The group recently released a 30-second television ad that began airing on Friday, focusing on his performance as San Francisco's District Attorney. The cop union mocked the Gascón campaign for labeling the spot "racist."

Former public defender Rachel Rossi is also in the race. If none of the candidates receive more than 50% of the votes in next month's primary election, the top two vote-getters will compete in a runoff in November.

Title: Forensic Pathologist Suggests Jeffrey Epstein's Death Was Homicide

Article:

Forensic pathologist Dr. Michael Baden, who observed the autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier found dead in his Manhattan jail cell in August, has stated that the evidence points towards homicide rather than suicide. Baden, who was hired by Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, made these remarks on Fox News on Wednesday.

Baden noted several unusual findings during the autopsy, including two fractures on either side of Epstein's larynx and one on the hyoid bone, above the money manager's Adam's apple. He asserted that these fractures are not consistent with hanging and are more indicative of ligature homicidal strangulation.

"Hanging does not cause these broken bones, homicide does," Baden insisted on Fox. "A huge amount of pressure was applied."

Baden also called for federal prosecutors to release the findings from DNA samples taken during the autopsy, including information about whose DNA is on the torn strips of orange sheets used as a makeshift noose. He noted that the DNA from fingernail clippings taken from Epstein has not been released either.

The pathologist also questioned the supposed "total breakdown in security" surrounding Epstein's death, citing the "extremely unlikely" coincidence of two guards falling asleep while video cameras in Epstein's cell and hallway were also not working.

"Occasionally a guard falls asleep—never two guards at the same time," Baden said on Fox. "The issue would be, did somebody come in and cause his death?"

Baden admitted that there would be no shortage of people who might want to harm Epstein, given the numerous allegations of sex crimes against him. However, he stressed that a large number of people would have been involved if Epstein's death was a homicide.

"It's 80 days now and the brother feels he is getting a runaround," Baden said. "He thinks that his brother wasn't the type to commit suicide but he wants to get the information that he hasn't been able to get so far."

Title: Colin Kaepernick Files Grievance Against NFL Team Owners Over Alleged Conspiracy

Article:

Colin Kaepernick, the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback, has filed a grievance against NFL team owners, alleging a conspiracy not to hire him due to his protests against racial injustice. Kaepernick, 29, has been without a team since he opted out of his contract with the San Francisco 49ers in March 2017.

Kaepernick first protested by sitting during the national anthem in August 2016, before opting to kneel instead. His actions inspired other players to follow suit, and criticism from President Donald Trump in September 2017 saw the protests spread.

In a statement released on Sunday, Kaepernick's lawyers wrote: "We can confirm that this morning we filed a grievance under the CBA on behalf of Colin Kaepernick. This was done only after pursuing every possible avenue with all NFL teams and their executives."

The statement continued, "If the NFL (as well as all professional sports leagues) is to remain a meritocracy, then principled and peaceful political protest - which the owners themselves made great theatre imitating weeks ago - should not be punished and athletes should not be denied employment."

The lawyers added, "Such a precedent threatens all patriotic Americans and harkens back to our darkest days as a nation. Protecting all athletes from such collusive conduct is what compelled Mr. Kaepernick to file his grievance."

Kaepernick's goal, according to the statement, is "to simply be treated fairly by the league he performed at the highest level for and to return to the football playing field."

Robert Kraft, owner of the New England Patriots, told BBC Sport last week that he had "never heard anyone talking about excluding" Kaepernick. Some players from the 49ers again knelt during the anthem before their match on Sunday.

Colin Kaepernick started the NFL's "take a knee" protest movement in 2016, but many feel he has paid a high price for his political stance. After opting out of the final year of his contract with the San Francisco 49ers (the team said he would have been dropped regardless), he has not been picked up by another organization.

This is despite injuries to quarterbacks such as Marcus Mariota at the Tennessee Titans. Kaepernick had to watch on as others were given a trial. It seems he has grown tired of this situation and is now taking direct action.

Title: U.S.-China Trade War to Impact Apple Inc. Starting This Weekend

Article:

The ongoing trade war between the U.S. and China will affect Apple Inc., the largest U.S. technology company, starting this weekend. The 15% tariffs, announced by President Donald Trump, will impact hundreds of products entering the U.S. or being withdrawn from warehouses for consumption in the U.S., according to the order.

The tariffs, as per the order, will take effect at 12:01 a.m. local time on Sunday in Washington. One veteran analyst, Gene Munster of Loup Ventures, expressed hope for a last-minute reprieve, stating that adding tariffs to any Apple product without some form of offset could have significant negative effects.

However, any reprieve for Apple looked unlikely as Trump showed little sign of backing down. Apple did not respond to requests for comment.

The following is a list of Apple products that will be hit by 15% tariffs starting this weekend:

1. Nand flash, a key storage component for iPhones
2. Apple wearable gadgets

The iPhone, which contributes more than half of Apple's revenue, will not face this 15% tariff until December 15. However, other hardware products, which made up at least 10% of sales in the company's 2018 fiscal year, will have to absorb the 15% import levy that kicks in on Sunday.

It is unclear if Apple will raise product prices or assume the cost of the tariffs. The company, one of the world's most profitable, maintains higher margins than most other consumer hardware makers.

A 15% tariff on Apple wearable gadgets sold in the U.S. could potentially reduce earnings by 5 cents to 10 cents a share per year, Munster estimated on Friday. Analysts, on average, estimate Apple's adjusted profit will be $11.63 a share in the 2019 fiscal year, according to data compiled by ███.

Apple has been lobbying Trump for more than a year to avoid tariffs. During a recent dinner with the president at his golf club in Bedminster, New Jersey, Chief Executive Officer Tim Cook voiced concerns that Apple's main rival Samsung Electronics Co. will gain an edge because its products won't be subject to the levies.

Just days after that dinner, Trump announced that tariffs on $300 billion of goods from China would be 15%, up from 10%. These tariffs will take effect in two tranches, with the first batch happening on September 1.

Apple spent decades building one of the largest supply chains in the world. The company designs and sells most of its products in the U.S., but imports them from China after assembly. This makes it one of the most exposed companies to tariffs.

Title: Private Industry and Technology as Potential Solutions for Rural America's Depopulation

Article:

During the confirmation hearing for Sonny Perdue, the presumptive Secretary of Agriculture, the former Georgia governor faced questions from both Republicans and Democrats regarding President Trump's budget for rural America. The opposition stemmed from concerns about the impact of the proposed budget on small, struggling rural communities.

While many rural Americans agree with this assessment, it is also clear that these government programs are seen as a temporary solution to a long-standing economic issue. Rural counties, like those in the Midwest, have lost their competitive advantage to urban areas.

To address this challenge, political leaders in South Dakota, among other states, have implemented initiatives such as DakotaRoots.com, a recruitment tool designed to attract young workers. The program has been successful, with more than 4,000 people now calling South Dakota home due to the Dakota Roots program.

However, critics argue that these initiatives, while laudable, are relatively modest in their impact. Rural America needs more than a few thousand people to rebuild its economy; it needs millions.

To achieve this, some propose leveraging the expertise of America's tech firms. These companies have developed algorithms to match people with potential romantic partners, taking into account user preferences and making informed guesses about compatibility.

A similar approach could be applied to matching potential residents with rural communities. By using algorithms to sort cities based on user preferences for factors such as affordable housing, healthcare, schools, transportation, proximity to recreation, and low taxes, a "top 10" list of locations best suited to individual needs could be generated.

States and communities eager for new talent could then dedicate resources towards recruiting these prospective citizens. This approach is seen as a potential solution to the depopulation of rural areas, as young professionals and middle-class families increasingly seek better options due to stagnant wages, student debt, and the dream of homeownership.

In the end, rural communities face a choice: they can wait for more welfare programs to trickle down from Washington D.C., or they can collaborate with private industry to recapture the restless spirit of American workers on the move. The latter approach, with fewer bureaucrats involved, is seen by some as the path to making rural America truly great again.

Title: Warren Apologizes to Cherokee Nation for DNA Test Amidst 2020 Presidential Speculation

Article:

Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat representing Massachusetts, has reportedly apologized to the Cherokee Nation leadership over a DNA test she undertook to prove Native American ancestry. The apology comes as Warren is set to announce her presidential bid for 2020, amidst ongoing discussions about her ancestry that have been a recurring issue in her political career.

Warren, who established an exploratory committee for the presidential run on New Year's Eve, has been touring the nation in preparation for her anticipated announcement to join the growing pool of Democrats vying for the White House. However, the issue of her ancestry has resurfaced, a matter that is likely to persist during her campaign.

Before expressing her presidential aspirations, Warren released the results of a DNA test, aiming to quell questions about her ancestry. The test indicated Native American heritage but faced criticism from tribal leaders and backlash that has marked her initial months of campaigning.

According to The Intercept and the New York Times, Warren privately reached out to Cherokee Nation leadership and apologized for the test and any harm it may have caused. Cherokee Nation spokeswoman Julie Hubbard told The Intercept, "Senator Warren has reached out to us and has apologized to the tribe." She added, "We are encouraged by this dialogue and understanding that being a Cherokee Nation tribal citizen is rooted in centuries of culture and laws, not through DNA tests."

Warren released the results from the DNA test in October, which showed "strong evidence" of Native American ancestry, partly in response to criticism from Republicans, including President Donald Trump, who nicknamed her "Pocahontas."

Conservatives have accused Warren of claiming Cherokee heritage to gain favor for jobs that boosted her career, a claim her former employers have denied. Last month, Warren addressed the test during a question-and-answer session with supporters at a rally in Iowa.

An audience member asked, "Why did you undergo the DNA testing and give Donald Trump more fodder to be a bully?" Warren responded, "I am not a person of color. I am not a citizen of a tribe. Tribal citizenship is very different from ancestry."

Warren explained that when she ran for public office for the first time in 2012, Republicans "honed in on this part of my history" and made "racial slurs." She added, "My decision was, I'm just going to put it all out there."

"I can't stop Donald Trump from what he's going to do. I can't stop him from hurling racial insults," Warren said. "But what I can do is I can be in this fight for all of our families."

Title: Syrian President Assad Questions U.S. Commitment to Defeat ISIS, Labels U.S. Troops in Syria as "Invaders"

Article:

Syrian President Bashar Assad has expressed doubts about the U.S.'s commitment to defeating the Islamic State (ISIS) group, stating that he has not seen any concrete actions from the Trump administration to back up the president's rhetoric. In an interview published on Saturday, Assad expressed hope that the current U.S. administration will follow through on their promises.

Trump's campaign platform included a pledge to eradicate ISIS, and upon taking office in late January, he ordered his top military leaders to present a new plan to dismantle the terror group within 30 days. However, it is unclear whether they have delivered a report to Trump.

Assad also suggested that the U.S.-backed military effort against ISIS in Syria has been limited, describing it as "only a few raids." Despite this, Assad remains optimistic about potential cooperation between his regime and the Trump administration, although he did not elaborate on this point.

The interview, which was approximately 27 minutes long, was conducted by the Chinese TV station Phoenix and was posted on Syria's state-news agency SANA on Saturday.

Critics, particularly among Republicans and military hawks, have been critical of former President Obama's handling of ISIS and his dealings with Assad. They argue that Obama and his administration failed to acknowledge "radical Islamic terrorism" and did not follow through on a 2012 statement that Assad would cross a "red line" in using chemical weapons on civilians after evidence of such attacks became apparent.

ISIS has gained ground in largely northern and remote regions of Syria during the six-year civil war. U.S. military leaders have primarily limited their public comments about the war on ISIS to efforts in Iraq, particularly in west Mosul. However, they announced earlier this week that the U.S. is preparing to send around 400 additional support troops to Syria, in addition to the roughly 500 already in the country, for a multi-national effort to defeat ISIS in their stronghold of Raqqa.

Assad stated in the interview that winning in Raqqa was a priority for his regime, and he considered any foreign troops entering Syria without his permission as "invaders," regardless of their nationality.

Title: Gun Control Ads Cause Concern for Democratic Leadership Over Vulnerable Senator Mark Pryor

Article:

Gun control legislation has become a source of concern for the Democratic leadership, as the party braces for potential backlash from pro-gun control advocates. According to several sources, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's aides recently met with staffers of New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg to discuss the potential impact of targeting vulnerable Democrats, such as Arkansas's Mark Pryor, on gun control issues.

Advertisements from the Bloomberg-funded Mayors Against Illegal Guns are set to air soon in Alaska, Arkansas, and North Dakota – states with Democratic senators who opposed the White House on the recent background checks vote. The group is also planning to deploy up to 60 field organizers in about a dozen states where senators, both Democrats and Republicans, voted against the bill. The goal is to build infrastructure and counter the influence of gun rights groups like the National Rifle Association.

The increased focus on gun control has Democrats worried about maintaining their hold on the Senate, as they face opposition not only from Republicans but also from pro-gun control forces. Gun control legislation has gained momentum since the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, in December 2012, which left 20 children and six adults dead. However, advocates acknowledge that they cannot overcome the power of the NRA on Capitol Hill unless those who oppose them face electoral consequences for their actions.

In Arkansas, the group's radio spots will target the state's African-American community, a demographic that Mark Glaze, director of Mayors Against Illegal Guns, believes is crucial for Mark Pryor's reelection. Four Senate Democrats – Pryor, Max Baucus of Montana, Mark Begich of Alaska, and Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota – joined with Republicans to derail the bill, drawing criticism from the gun control movement and complaints from the White House.

However, it is Pryor's fate that has Democratic leadership most worried. Senate Democrats point to the example of former Arkansas Democratic Senator Blanche Lincoln as a warning. In 2010, labor unions, angered by Lincoln's vote against legislation they supported, helped fund a primary challenger. Lincoln narrowly won the primary, but was then defeated by Republican John Boozman in the general election.

Democratic senators and aides also note that Pryor has supported President Barack Obama and the leadership on other significant issues such as Obamacare, banking reform, and taxes. Reid will need Pryor's support on upcoming immigration votes.

Title: Advertisers Pull Out of Laura Ingraham's Fox News Show Following Controversial Tweets

Article:

At least seven companies have announced they are discontinuing advertisements on Laura Ingraham's Fox News show following her controversial tweets about a survivor of the Florida school massacre. The conservative pundit's comments sparked a call for a boycott from Parkland student David Hogg, who survived the February 14 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida.

Hogg, 17, tweeted a list of a dozen companies that advertise on "The Ingraham Angle" and urged his supporters to demand that they cancel their ads.
