Hogg, who has become a prominent figure in the youth-led movement advocating for tighter firearm restrictions, took aim at Ingraham after she mocked him on Twitter over his college applications.

On Thursday, Ingraham issued an apology "in the spirit of Holy Week," stating that she was sorry for any hurt or upset she may have caused Hogg or the "brave victims" of Parkland. Ingraham also noted that her show was one of the first to feature Hogg after the shooting and praised his poise given the tragedy.

Nutrish, a pet food line created by celebrity chef Rachael Ray, travel website TripAdvisor Inc (TRIP.O), online home furnishings seller Wayfair Inc (W.N), the world's largest packaged food company, Nestle SA (NESN.S), online streaming service Hulu, travel website Expedia Group Inc (EXPE.O), and online personal shopping service Stitch Fix (SFIX.O) all confirmed they were canceling their advertisements.

Wayfair stated in a statement that while they support dialogue and debate, Ingraham's personal criticism of a high school student who had lost classmates in an unspeakable tragedy was not consistent with their values. Nutrish tweeted that they were in the process of removing their ads from Ingraham's program. Nestle stated they had "no plans to buy ads on the show in future." Hulu confirmed they were no longer advertising on Ingraham's show and were monitoring all ad placements carefully.

TripAdvisor, which was not on Hogg's list or another list of sponsors that Hogg retweeted, stated they no longer advertise on this show. Expedia, which was not on Hogg's list, also confirmed they no longer advertise on Ingraham's show.

Hogg wrote on Twitter that an apology to mollify advertisers was insufficient. He stated he would accept an apology only if Ingraham denounced the way Fox News treated him and his friends. "It's time to love thy neighbor, not mudsling at children," Hogg tweeted.

Ingraham's show airs on Fox News, part of Rupert Murdoch's Twenty-First Century Fox Inc (FOXA.O).

Title: Trump Promises to Repeal Johnson Amendment, Courting Social Conservatives

Article:

In a bid to appeal to social conservatives, former President Donald J. Trump, speaking at the 11th Annual Values Voters Summit on Friday, pledged to repeal the Johnson Amendment, a provision that prohibits churches and other tax-exempt organizations from endorsing political candidates.

Since securing the Republican nomination and shifting focus to the general election against Hillary Clinton, Mr. Trump has been reaching out to social conservatives, a significant segment of the Republican coalition. During his speech, he emphasized, "The first thing we have to do is to give our churches their voice back. I will repeal the Johnson Amendment if I am elected your president."

In a jocular tone, Mr. Trump suggested that repealing the 1950s-era provision named after then-Sen. Lyndon B. Johnson might be the only way he could gain entry into heaven.

The 2016 election saw questions about the support of social conservatives, who are traditionally active in political campaigns, for Mr. Trump due to his stance on abortion, his two divorces, and high-profile extramarital affairs in the 1990s. To address these concerns, Mr. Trump has highlighted his children, who have won praise from even skeptical conservatives, and chosen Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, a well-respected social conservative, as his running mate.

On policy matters, Mr. Trump has promised to nominate Supreme Court justices who will uphold the Constitution, defend "religious liberty," repeal and replace Obamacare, and fight to expand school choice for students in failing schools.

"Let me state this upfront: in a Trump administration, our Christian heritage will be protected and defended like you have never seen before," he said.

Mr. Trump has also assembled high-profile figures to his Evangelical Advisory Board, including Tony Perkins, head of the Family Research Council, which hosted the summit, and former Rep. Michele Bachmann. Bachmann praised Mr. Trump's stances on immigration, foreign policy, and taxes.

"On every single level, if you look at the agenda that Donald Trump has put forward, it has been one that I, as a Constitutional conservative, as a believer in Jesus Christ, can not only easily embrace, but readily embrace," Mrs. Bachmann said.

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus urged, "Let's lock arms and do what we can to elect Donald Trump president of the United States."

"The Left is launching an assault on our culture. They want to strip God out of the public square. Our nation's religious heritage has helped make us what we are today. No America with religious convictions will have to bow at the altar of secularism if Donald Trump is president," Mr. Priebus said.

Sandra Seaver of Maine expressed her support, stating, "I used to hold my nose and vote for Trump, but since he has become more presidential, I have been very impressed with him."

Other attendees acknowledged that Mr. Trump might not be the ideal candidate for them, but his resistance to political correctness and his opposition to Hillary Clinton made him an acceptable choice.

"If you don't vote for Trump, it is essentially a vote for Hillary," said Jim Chamberlin, of Ohio.

Title: Obama Defends Susan Rice Amidst Benghazi Criticism, Threatens Political Battle Over Nominations

Article:

In a heated news conference on Wednesday, President Barack Obama defended his handling of the September 11 terrorist attack on the U.S. Consulate in Libya's second-largest city and criticized Republican senators John McCain and Lindsey Graham for attacking his top aide, U.N. Ambassador Susan E. Rice. The two senators have stated that Rice's inaccurate account of the cause of the Benghazi attacks makes her unfit for promotion, and they have threatened to block her if she is nominated to succeed Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

During the conference, Obama defended Rice, stating that she had nothing to do with the Benghazi incident and was merely presenting intelligence she had received. He accused the senators of besmirching her reputation and called their attacks outrageous.

Two hours before the news conference, McCain and Graham announced their intention to block Rice should the president nominate her to succeed Clinton. McCain criticized Rice for her account of the Benghazi attack on five Sunday political talk shows, stating that she said the incident was the result of a mob protest against an anti-Islamic video. Graham also criticized Rice's handling of China and Russia during tough negotiations at the United Nations.

After Obama's response, Graham retorted that he does blame Obama and formally introduced a resolution calling for a special select committee to investigate Benghazi. He stated that he does not want a fight but has a firm resolve to investigate the incident further.

The exchange highlights what could be a bumpy road in the second term for some of Obama's potential nominees, as many departments and agencies that played a role in the Benghazi incident could face vacancies in their top posts. Clinton has stated she will be leaving the State Department, and Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta has not indicated whether he will leave or stay put. The president may also have to fill the Pentagon's top civilian job.

In addition, CIA Director David H. Petraeus left his key national security post open with his surprise resignation and admission last week of an extramarital affair. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who has faced scrutiny over the Justice Department's ill-fated Fast and Furious gunwalking scandal, is also expected to move to the private sector early in Obama's second term.

The Justice Department's supervisory role in the unusual FBI investigation into Petraeus' personal life and the FBI's failure to inform the president of its probe until months after it had begun will complicate the confirmation process of any Holder successor.

Obama defended Rice, stating that she had done "exemplary work" as U.N. ambassador and that the senators now have "a problem with me" for taking her to task. However, he did not announce any more nominations at this point and stated he has not decided whether to nominate Rice.

McCain and Graham earlier stated they would do "whatever is necessary" to stop Rice from becoming the next secretary of state if Obama does pick her. Senator John F. Kerry, Massachusetts Democrat, is also reportedly under consideration for Clinton's job. Graham stated he does not have any concerns about Kerry, but his idea for a select committee to investigate Benghazi is meeting with resistance from top Democrats, who stated there are multiple committees already looking into the run-up to the attack and the slow U.S. military response.

Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, who was one of four Americans killed in the attack, had asked for more security, but his request was denied. There were several warnings of increased terrorist activity, including an attack on the consulate in June, which Graham stated Obama must answer whether he knew about. A Defense Department timeline released last week showed the military took hours to get a security team to the site of the attack.

Obama in his news conference defended his own handling of the attack, stating that his orders to his national security team were to do whatever was necessary to make the Americans safe. When pressed during the news conference to provide more answers to the families of the victims of the Benghazi attacks, Obama stated he would address the families directly, not through the press. However, he also referred to an ongoing investigation, stating he and the administration would "provide all the information that is available about what happened that day."

When it comes to the bloody civil war in Syria, Obama stated that he is encouraged that the Syria opposition has formed a new, more representative leadership council, but that the U.S. is not ready to recognize the group as a "government in exile" or to arm it. The president also pledged to try to engage Iran in negotiations over its disputed nuclear program, stating he would not be "constrained by diplomatic niceties and protocols" even though he believes there is "still a window of time for us to resolve this diplomatically."

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's Allegations Against Mitt Romney's Tax History Sparks Controversy

Article:

The ongoing debate over Mitt Romney's tax history escalated on Sunday, as Republican figures criticized Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid for his claim that Romney, the presumed Republican presidential candidate, has not paid taxes for the past 10 years.

During an appearance on ABC's "This Week," Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus labeled Reid a "dirty liar who hasn't filed a single page of tax returns himself." When asked by show moderator George Stephanopoulos if he stood by his comment, Priebus responded, "I just said it."

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) also criticized Reid on CNN's "State of the Union," stating, "What he did on the Senate floor is so out of bounds. I think he's lying about his statement of knowing something about Romney."

Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell (R) called Reid's comments "reckless and slanderous." On CBS's "Face the Nation," McDonnell said, "We know about [Romney's] tax returns? He's paid his taxes." He added that "people don't care about Mitt Romney's tax returns" and accused Democrats of making an issue of Romney's tax returns to divert attention from President Obama's handling of the economy.

Democrats have persisted in their claim and have raised more questions about Romney's personal fortune, estimated to be as much as $250 million. Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz (D-FL), who heads the Democratic National Committee, said on ABC's "This Week," "There are questions that, when you're running for president of the United States, that the American people deserve answers to."

Romney has refused to release more than one year of personal tax returns, citing concerns that the information could be distorted and used against him. There is no legal requirement that presidential candidates release their taxes, although it has become customary in recent decades.

Reid's initial allegation last week, that he had learned from an investor in Romney's former firm, Bain Capital, that Romney had not paid taxes, has not been substantiated. Reid has not offered proof and has stated that he is unsure whether his claim is true. He repeated the accusation on the Senate floor, a move Republicans characterized as politically motivated and inappropriate. Senators cannot be sued for defamation over statements made on the chamber floor.

Since his initial charge, Reid has doubled down on his insinuation and stated that he does not need to prove it. "I don't think the burden should be on me," he said in a telephone call with Nevada reporters last week. "The burden should be on him. He's the one I've alleged has not paid any taxes. Why didn't he release his tax returns?"

Reid spokesman Adam Jentleson, in an email on Sunday regarding the attacks on Reid, said the unnamed source is "extremely credible" and accused Republicans of trying to "cover up for Mitt Romney's stonewalling."

"This issue is not going away until Romney decides to be straight with the American people and release his tax returns," Mr. Jentleson said.

However, late last week, Romney himself emphatically stated that he would not release the returns and dared Reid "to put up or shut up."

"Harry's going to have to describe who it is he spoke with, because of course that's totally and completely wrong. It's untrue, dishonest, and inaccurate. It's wrong," Romney told Fox News' Sean Hannity on his radio show. "So I'm looking forward to have Harry reveal his sources, and we'll probably find out it's the White House."

No Democrat appearing on Sunday's news talk shows disavowed Reid's comments, which Republicans said last week smacked of McCarthyism in their use of anonymous sources to make insinuations that the accused must then disprove. Rather than disavowing Reid's claims, most Democrats instead tried to turn the conversation away from him and instead on Romney.

David Axelrod, Obama's senior campaign adviser, told "Fox News Sunday" that he didn't know the identity of Reid's source but that "Gov. Romney can resolve this in 10 seconds. They can release the tax returns."

Robert Gibbs, an adviser to Obama and his former press secretary, was asked on CNN's "State of the Union" whether Reid should tamp down his accusations against Romney. "I don't think anybody controls Harry Reid," was his reply.

When pressed again by show moderator Candy Crowley whether Reid should drop the issue, Gibbs said instead that "Harry Reid isn't the one who's made this debate. Mitt Romney has brought this to the fore."

Title: Presidential Authority to Kill: Legal and Ethical Implications of Trump's Actions

Article:

Last week, President Donald Trump ordered the U.S. military to invade Iraq, a previously friendly country, without the knowledge or consent of its government, and assassinated a visiting foreign government official. The victim was the head of Iran's military and intelligence. The killing, which occurred through the use of an unmanned drone, took place as the general and his companions were driving on a public highway in a van. The general was not engaged in an act of violence at the time of his death, nor were any of his companions.

The president's supporters have argued that the general's death was revenge for Americans and others killed by the general's troops and surrogates. Trump has argued that he ordered the general's death because of what evil the general might order his own troops and surrogates to do in the future.

The question arises: Can the president legally kill a person not engaged in an act of violence because of what the person might do in the future? The president has taken an oath to uphold the Constitution, which provides only two means for the federal government to kill a human being. The first is pursuant to a declaration of war, which only Congress can do. The second way that the Constitution permits federal government killings is pursuant to due process. That means that the person to be killed is lawfully in custody, has been properly charged, lawfully tried and fairly convicted of a capital crime, and the conviction has been upheld on appeal.

Can the president kill foreign military personnel and claim the justification of self-defense? The laws of war permit him to do that, but self-defense—actually, defense of the country—only comes into play when the foreign military personnel are physically engaged in killing Americans or are certainly about to do so. That justification only applies when force is imminent and certain. Were imminence and certainty not the requirement, then nothing would prevent a president from slaying any monster he chose simply based on a fear that the monster might someday strike. Such a state of affairs is contrary to two presidential executive orders, one issued by President Gerald R. Ford and the other by President Ronald Reagan, and neither negated by Trump.

Such a territorial invasion and killing also violate the United Nations Charter—a treaty that prohibits unlawful invasions and killings of member nations' territories and officials outside of a lawful and U.N. approved declaration of war. Roaming the world looking for monsters to slay not only violates long-standing principles of American domestic and international law, but also it violates basic Judeo-Christian moral principles, which teach that the end does not justify the means and might does not make right.

The question of whether the American president can kill an Iranian government official in Iraq because of fear of what he might do—without a declaration of war or any legal process—raises concerns about the rule of law, personal liberty, and limited government. It also raises questions about the safety of the people, as laws are in place to prevent wanton killings, lest killers turn on us.

In Robert Bolt's play "A Man for All Seasons," Sir Thomas More argues with his son-in-law, William Roper, about the extent of the law's protections of those universally recognized as evil. Roper says that he would cut down all the laws in England to get rid of the Devil. More counters that even the Devil is entitled to the benefits of the law. Then he hurls this zinger: "And, when the last law was down, and the Devil turned round on you?—where would you hide, Roper, the laws all being flat? This country's planted thick with laws from coast to coast—man's laws, not God's—and, if you cut them down—and you're just the man to do it—d'you really think you could stand upright in the winds that would blow then? Yes, I'd give the Devil benefit of law, for my own safety's sake."

More crystalized the dangers of those who—like Trump—take the law into their own hands for the sake of expedience or to rid the world of a monster. Without law, how does one decide what monsters should go and what monsters may stay?

When President Obama used drones to kill peaceful, uncharged Americans in Yemen, candidate Donald Trump condemned that behavior. He offered that, as president, he would bring the troops home, stop the nation building, quit being the world's police force, and end the endless wars. Instead, his act of state terrorism has succeeded in doing what the general he killed could never do while alive. Trump has united the Iranian people behind their fanatical government, and he caused the Iraqi government to kick out all American troops—troops that had no lawful or moral basis for being there in the first place, and whose numbers have only increased.

Trump cut down the laws to get to the Devil. Whom will he kill next? Judge Andrew P. Napolitano was the youngest life-tenured Superior Court judge in the history of New Jersey. He is Fox News’ senior judicial analyst. He has been published in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and numerous other publications. He is the author of the best-seller, "Lies the Government Told You: Myth, Power, and Deception in American History." For more of Judge Napolitano's reports, Go Here Now.

Title: Orlando Nightclub Shooting: Investigation Ongoing as Political Debate Erupts

Article:

The FBI has identified the perpetrator of the Orlando nightclub shooting as 29-year-old Omar Mateen, a U.S. citizen of Afghan descent. The FBI Director, James Comey, has stated that there is no evidence suggesting the attack was directed from the Middle East, labeling Mateen as a "homegrown extremist."

Mateen, who was once under FBI surveillance for nearly a year, was allowed to purchase firearms despite his past surveillance. Witnesses have reported that Mateen was a regular at the Pulse nightclub and had dated men. Officials also claim Mateen scouted Disney World for a potential attack.

The shooting has significantly impacted the ongoing U.S. presidential campaign. Following President Barack Obama's refusal to mention "Muslim" or "Islamic terrorism" in his statement on the Orlando massacre, presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump expanded his proposed Muslim ban. Trump's proposal now aims to close the U.S. borders to individuals from countries with a history of Islamic terrorism, regardless of their religion.

Trump accused Obama of willful ignorance regarding Islamic terrorism, stating, "There's something going on." Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton initially followed Obama's politically correct line, but later acknowledged the threat of "radical Islamism."

The political debate has focused on gun control and anti-terror legislation, with the Democratic response during a raucous session of Congress focusing on gun control legislation. However, Republican opposition has halted the proposed legislation.

Investigators continue to gather more information about Mateen, the deadliest mass shooter in American history. The investigation is ongoing.

Title: Immigrant Households in the U.S. Use Welfare at Higher Rates Than Native-Born Counterparts, According to New Study

Article:

A new study released by the Center for Immigration Studies (CIS) indicates that 51 percent of immigrant-headed households, both legal and illegal, reported using at least one welfare program in 2012. This is compared to 30 percent of native-headed households that used at least one welfare program.

The report, authored by CIS's Director of Research Steven Camarota, analyzed welfare data from the Census Bureau's Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP). The CIS's definition of welfare includes Medicaid, cash, food, and housing programs.

Camarota stated, "If immigration is supposed to benefit the country, then immigrant welfare use should be much lower than native use. However, two decades after welfare reform tried to curtail immigrant welfare use, immigrant households are using most programs at higher rates than natives."

Camarota noted that the skill and education level of many current immigrants is contributing to their welfare use. He added, "The low-skill level of many immigrants means that although most work, many also access welfare programs. If we continue to allow large numbers of less-educated immigrants to settle in the country, then immigrant welfare use will remain high."

While welfare use among both new and long-time immigrants is high, with 48 percent of immigrants in the U.S. for more than 20 years reporting welfare use, the rates vary based on region of origin. In 2012, 73 percent of immigrant-headed households from Central America and Mexico reported using one or more welfare program. Households from the Caribbean used welfare at a rate of 51 percent, African immigrants were at 48 percent, South America at 41 percent, East Asia 32 percent, Europe 26 percent, and South Asia 17 percent.

The report also highlights that while immigrant-headed households use welfare at a higher rate than natives, they also pay taxes at a lower rate. "On average, immigrant-headed households had tax liability in income and payroll taxes in 2012 that was about 11 percent less than native households, or about 89 cents for every dollar native households pay, based on Census Bureau data. Immigrant households have lower average incomes (from all sources) than native households and are a good deal larger, giving them more tax deductions. As a result, their average income tax liability is less than native households," the report reads.

Title: Florida Voters Approve Measure to Restore Voting Rights for 1.4 Million Felons

Article:

Florida voters approved Amendment 4 on Tuesday, a ballot measure that will restore voting rights to an estimated 1.4 million people with felony records in the state. The amendment, which passed by 64 percent, will re-enfranchise all felons in the state, except those convicted of murder or sex offenses.

The amendment was supported by various groups, including progressive organizations, civil liberty organizations, conservative groups aligned with the Koch brothers, and celebrities. It also received grassroots support from ex-offenders and their families who argue that those who have paid their debt to society should be returned to full citizenship.

Desmond Meade, president of Florida Rights Restoration Coalition, addressed a room of overjoyed supporters at an election night watch party in Orlando, stating, "This was a campaign about inclusion. Those numbers represented what happens when we come together along the lines of humanity and reach each other where we're at. That's what happens when we're able to transcend partisan politics and bickering, when we're able to transcend racial anxieties and discourse, when we're able to come together as God's children."

Florida was one of four states that imposed lifetime bans on voting for people with felony records. The two remaining states are Iowa and Kentucky. Virginia has a similar provision, but the last two governors have used their executive powers to restore voting rights of those affected.

Thirty-three states have various laws disenfranchising felony offenders and those under law enforcement supervision, impacting an estimated 6.1 million potential voters, according to a 2016 Sentencing Project report.

Former offenders in Florida could petition the governor for clemency to have their voting rights restored, but in 2011, then-governor Rick Scott, who is running for the U.S. Senate this year, rewrote the rules, making Florida the toughest state in the U.S. for felons to regain their voting rights.

Bryan Russi, 42, an ex-felon and current real estate agent from Orlando, stated, "Ultimately, we are citizens, we are in the community, we do want to have a say—I know I do—and this is a great way to have that opportunity." Russi added, "It's not Republican or Democrat, it's a human thing. Everyone has people who have been affected."

Kim Lawrance, an activist whose 18-year-old daughter is currently incarcerated, expressed her hope that her child would be able to vote one day. "They should be able to come home and get reintegrated into society," Lawrance said. "When your time is done, it's done."

One estimate suggests that 10 percent of all Floridians who are otherwise eligible to vote have been disenfranchised by the law. Felon disenfranchisement also disproportionately affects black residents. One out of every 13 African-Americans in the U.S. has lost their voting rights due to felony disenfranchisement laws, compared to one in every 56 non-black voters, the Sentencing Project report said.

Florida's felony disenfranchisement laws were, like those in many other states, a vestige of the state's racist 19th-century "Black Codes," which attempted to systematically criminalize freed slaves following the Civil War and then bar them from voting.

In a statement, ACLU of Florida Executive Director Howard Simon celebrated what he called "one of the largest expansions of the franchise in our nation's history" but warned that the fight was not over. Simon stated, "In the days and weeks ahead, we will seek to work with the newly elected governor to ensure that Amendment 4 is implemented as intended by the Floridians who placed it on the ballot and voted to approve it—without delay and without imposing more burdens on the process to register to vote."

Shortly after Amendment 4 passed, Trump-aligned Republican Ron DeSantis narrowly defeated progressive Democrat Andrew Gillum in the race for Florida governor.

Title: Obama and Trump Meet for First Time at White House, Discussing Peaceful Transition of Power

Article:

WASHINGTON — In a historic meeting at the White House, President Barack Obama and President-elect Donald Trump discussed the transition of power on Thursday. The two men, who were intense rivals during the 2016 election, spoke well of each other and shook hands for the cameras.

Just days after a campaign marked by vicious attacks, the two leaders pledged to work together to address the challenges facing the United States. Obama stated that his "number one priority" in the next two months in office is to facilitate the transition to the Trump administration.

The two leaders discussed "organizational issues" and both domestic and foreign policies. Obama emphasized the importance of unity, stating, "I believe that it is important for all of us, regardless of party and regardless of political preferences, to now come together, work together, to deal with the many challenges that we face."

Trump, who famously challenged Obama's birthplace, called his predecessor "a very good man" following their Oval Office meeting. The New York businessman also said, "We had never met each other. I have great respect."

The two shook hands for the cameras, but did not take questions from reporters. After the meeting, White House press secretary Josh Earnest said the two leaders did not resolve all of their differences, but did not try to either; their focus was a smooth transition.

Trump later met with Republican House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky. Trump and Ryan spoke of a "fantastic, productive meeting about getting to work."

In his campaign, Trump pledged to reverse and tear down many of Obama's policies, including his health care law, the Iran nuclear deal, and business and environmental regulations. However, in his victory speech, Trump called for unity, stating, "It's time for America to bind the wounds of division."

The Trump team is also putting together possible picks for the Cabinet and White House staff. While Obama and Trump spoke in the Oval Office, first lady Michelle Obama gave a tour of the residence to Melania Trump. During the campaign, Mrs. Obama criticized Trump over his lewd comments about women, while Mrs. Trump, during her address to the Republican national convention, used lines cribbed from a speech the first lady had once given.

Obama and Trump's rivalry, intrinsic to the 2016 election, goes back years. During Obama's first term, Trump made a name for himself by becoming the de facto leader of the so-called "birther" movement, pushing the false idea that the president was not born in the United States. In this past campaign year, Clinton described the birther movement as a racist attack on the nation's first African-American president. In 2011, Obama responded by producing a long-form birth certificate and mocking Trump at a high-profile press dinner as the New York businessman sat in the audience. At the White House on Wednesday, Obama said he wants to make sure the presidential succession is "well executed because ultimately we're all on the same team."

Title: Republicans Lead in Competitive 2014 Midterm Races Due to Low Obama Approval, Discontent with Obamacare

Article:

According to a poll conducted by Politico between May 2-13, Republicans are leading in the most competitive House and Senate races for the 2014 midterm elections. The poll surveyed 867 likely voters, with 41 percent indicating they would choose a Republican candidate, compared to 34 percent who would choose a Democrat. Approximately 25 percent of respondents were undecided.

The poll results reflect President Barack Obama's low job approval rating and public disenchantment with the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). Politico stated that both the president's job approval and the partisan ballot matchup are more negative for Democrats in this poll than in other national surveys, indicating a challenging political landscape for the Democratic Party.

However, the poll also showed that in a number of conservative states and races that could be a toss-up, voters lean in the liberal direction on several issues on the Democratic Party agenda, including immigration reform, pay equity, and background checks for gun sales. Healthcare, however, is a higher priority for voters, with nearly 9 out of 10 people stating their view on healthcare would be an important determinant of their vote.

Among those surveyed who had an opinion of the Affordable Care Act, the electorate was almost evenly split between those who want to repeal the law entirely (48 percent) and those who favor either leaving it alone (16 percent) or keeping it in place with modifications (35 percent). The poll suggests that fully repealing the ACA may not be a straightforward political proposition for the Republican Party, and could be a more complex issue for a GOP presidential ticket to navigate in 2016.

The survey also found that majorities of white voters (54 percent) and men (51 percent) support repealing Obamacare, but a majority of most subgroups do not support repeal, including independents, moderates, African-Americans, and Hispanics. The midterm electorate is expected to be whiter and more conservative than the country as a whole, and many of the year's highest-stakes Senate races are in Southern states, such as Arkansas, North Carolina, and Louisiana. Therefore, even if the law has gained some legitimacy with the broader public, it remains ominous for Democrats that repeal is the plurality position of likely voters.

Title: President Trump Visits Puerto Rico Amidst Ongoing Hurricane Maria Recovery Efforts

Article:

President Donald Trump is currently on a trip to the Puerto Rican capital, San Juan, following criticism from local politicians regarding the administration's response to Hurricane Maria. During a press conference last week, President Trump described the hurricane's aftermath as "wiped out" and "never seen anything like it."

The president is expected to spend at least five hours in Puerto Rico, during which he will meet with first responders, local politicians, some residents, and Marine Corps and Navy personnel, accompanied by First Lady Melania Trump. The itinerary includes meetings with Governor Ricardo Rossell, a visit to a local church, and attending briefings.

This visit marks Trump's fourth trip to a region affected by natural disasters, including Texas, Florida, Louisiana, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. However, some Puerto Rican politicians have criticized the administration's response to the disaster, with San Juan Mayor Carmen Yulin Cruz stating during a press conference last Friday that the administration's inefficiency is contributing to a "genocide" if the crisis is not handled.

Trump has responded to the criticism by tweeting that the Mayor of San Juan and other Puerto Rican politicians lack leadership ability and are not helping their workers. He also claimed that 10,000 federal workers are on the island providing vital recovery support, a figure reported by FEMA. Nearly 50 percent of people now have access to drinking water, according to FEMA.

Hurricane Maria has exacerbated Puerto Rico's already dire economic situation, as the territory has been in economic recession for about a decade and undergoing a debt crisis. The economic woes have left the country's infrastructure in a poor state, making the recovery process more challenging.

As of now, more than 90 percent of residents are still without power, and some hospitals reportedly have no power as well. Rural areas continue to struggle to access essential needs such as food, fresh water, or medicine.

The purpose of Trump's visit is believed to be addressing the perception that the administration has neglected the response to the crisis. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stated on Monday that the trip is about the recovery, to which the administration is "fully committed."

"The top priority for the federal government is certainly to protect the lives and the safety of those in affected areas and provide life-sustaining services as we work together to rebuild their lives," Sanders said.

Title: Protesters Demand Town Hall Meetings with Sen. Dianne Feinstein During Recess

Article:

Demonstrators protested Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) on Friday outside the Public Policy Institute of California in San Francisco, expressing their disapproval of her decision not to hold town hall meetings during the current congressional recess.

According to the San Francisco Chronicle, Sen. Feinstein, who has not held town hall meetings during her last two U.S. Senate campaigns, has no plans for any town halls during the current recess. People attending Feinstein's ticketed event were invited to send questions via email to the event moderator in advance, with free tickets available. There were reportedly only 240 chairs in the room, although many more were standing.

During the event, Feinstein reportedly enjoyed the outbursts from the protesters, as reported by The Sacramento Bee. The protesters were from the San Francisco chapter of Indivisible, a liberal group that has disrupted talks in recent weeks to push their "anti-Donald Trump" agenda. They held up signs reading, "Hold a real town hall," and others held up a green "agree" and a red "disagree" sign.

At another point during the event, Feinstein reportedly said there was not much she could do to remove Stephen K. Bannon from his position as President Trump's chief White House strategist, which prompted the activists to hold up a red "disagree" sign.

Friday's protest was not the first time Feinstein's constituents have confronted her. In January, approximately 200 protesters opposed what they have labeled as her "pro-Trump voting record" because she voted for confirming several of the president's Cabinet picks.

On Friday night, Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA) held a town hall in Glendale, California, where he discussed President Donald Trump's temporary travel ban and the refugee crisis.

Several hundred anti-Trump activists will also hold an "empty chair" town hall on Sunday at 10 a.m., despite the fact that Feinstein will not attend in person. A spokeswoman for Indivisible East Bay told the Chronicle that Sunday "is not really a protest" of the senator. "It's a demonstration of our request that she meet with us."

Title: ISIS Attempts Suicide Bombing on U.S. Airbase Training Iraqi Forces

Article:

ISIS forces, dressed in Iraqi military uniforms, attempted a suicide bomb attack on an airbase in Iraq where 320 U.S. Marines are training Iraqi forces. The attack occurred in the town of Baghdadi, which is less than five miles from the base. The attack was thwarted by Iraqi Security Forces, resulting in the death of the ISIS fighters.

The proximity of ISIS and American military personnel raises concerns, particularly as President Obama seeks authorization from Congress for the use of force, which rejects the notion of "enduring offensive ground forces." The incident highlights the potential risks of American military personnel engaging with ISIS on the battlefield.

Rear Adm. John Kirby, a Pentagon spokesman, stated that the base, which is roughly the size of Boulder, Colorado, has "mini-bases inside the big base." He added that the incident occurred nowhere near where U.S. or coalition forces were operating.

Kirby emphasized that U.S. trainers and advisers are close to danger but do not have a ground combat mission. He stated that they have the right to defend themselves and the responsibility to shoot back if they feel under threat.

The capture of Baghdadi, which remains under militant control, demonstrates ISIS's continued ability to launch offensive operations despite coalition airstrikes and talks of a counteroffensive on major cities held by the group. U.S. officials maintain that the militants are largely on the defensive.

Title: Senate Confirms Eugene Scalia as U.S. Labor Secretary Along Party Lines

Article:

The United States Senate confirmed Eugene Scalia, son of the late Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, as the next Labor Secretary on Thursday afternoon by a vote of 53-44. The confirmation came after a brief stint as the acting secretary by Patrick Pizzella, who filled the position following the resignation of former Secretary of Labor Alex Acosta in July.

Acosta's departure was prompted by backlash over his handling of the case of Jeffrey Epstein, a now-deceased accused child predator, when he was a federal prosecutor in 2008.

Eugene Scalia, who has a professional history representing Wall Street banks, Walmart, UPS, and SeaWorld, among others, has a long track record of fighting labor and financial regulations. This professional history has put him at odds with Senate Democrats.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) described Scalia's nomination as a "slap in the face of the Labor Department," stating that President Trump "could have chosen a union member" instead.

Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.), the top Democrat on the Senate's Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee, expressed disappointment with the vote and vowed to "fight every day to hold him and the Trump administration accountable for the harm they're doing to workers."

Health Committee Chairman Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.), however, praised the confirmation. GOP Sen. Tim Scott (S.C.) called Scalia "an expert in labor, employment, and regulatory law" with "an unmatched resume of experience in both the private and public sector."

"Eugene Scalia is well-qualified to lead the Department of Labor with a steady hand at a time when workers' wages are up and unemployment is near record lows," Alexander said in a statement. "Now that Mr. Scalia has been confirmed, I look forward to his getting to work to help continue to grow our economy and help workers gain the skills they need to succeed in today's workplace."

Title: New York Governor and President Trump Disagree on Authority to Lift Lockdown Orders

Article:

A dispute has arisen between New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and President Donald Trump over who has the ultimate authority to lift coronavirus lockdown orders in the United States. The disagreement began when President Trump claimed he has "total" power to lift virus lockdowns, a statement that Governor Cuomo refuted on Tuesday.

The US is currently the epicenter of the pandemic, with 592,743 cases and 25,239 deaths. New York state, which has the most cases, has seen signs of improvement, with the number of people hospitalized due to coronavirus falling for the first time on Tuesday. However, the state still reported 778 deaths in the past 24 hours.

On Monday, President Trump stated on Twitter that deciding when to reopen states was "the decision of the president," not state governors, although he added that he would make his decision "in conjunction with governors." The US Constitution states that states maintain public order and safety, and it has been individual state governors who have issued lockdown or shelter-in-place orders.

On Monday, several US state governors discussed plans to resume economic activity without apparent input from the Trump administration. Ten states, led by New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and California Governor Gavin Newsom, said they would coordinate how to reopen businesses after the outbreak is contained. All but one of the states are led by a Democratic governor.

The row escalated on Tuesday, with Governor Cuomo telling CBS that President Trump does not have total authority to decide when to reopen businesses, because "we don't have a king, we have a president." During his daily press briefing, Governor Cuomo criticized President Trump, adding he would "not engage" in a fight with him, but would have "no choice" if the president threatened the welfare of New Yorkers.

President Trump took the row to Twitter on Tuesday, criticizing Governor Cuomo and issuing an oblique snipe at other governors. The president aimed particular fire at Governor Cuomo, who he said was calling "daily, even hourly, begging for everything," like hospitals, beds, and ventilators for his state.

Meanwhile, President Trump struck a less combative tone later on Tuesday, saying he would make a decision on the economy "in conjunction with governors" soon. The Trump administration had previously signaled 1 May as a potential date for easing the restrictions. However, the US's top infectious diseases adviser, Dr. Anthony Fauci, told AP on Tuesday that the 1 May date might be "a bit overly optimistic."

Globally, different approaches have been adopted to loosening lockdown restrictions. The Chinese province of Wuhan, where coronavirus was first reported last December, has partially reopened after more than two months of isolation. Spain has allowed around 300,000 nonessential workers to return to their jobs. Italy - the hardest-hit country in Europe - will allow a narrow range of businesses to resume operations this week. In France, President Emmanuel Macron has announced the country's near-lockdown will extend until 11 May. The UK government has said no one should expect any changes to its lockdown restrictions this week.

Title: Romney's Debate Performance Boosts Confidence Among GOP Voters

Article:

Recent events indicate a significant shift in the sentiment towards Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney, as his performance in the debates has led to an increase in support and enthusiasm among Republican voters.

In the past, many GOP voters expressed displeasure with Romney, with some reluctantly endorsing him due to their disdain for President Obama. However, Romney's aggressive performance in the debates has instilled new confidence within the GOP, as his rise in the polls and the positive response from the first debate have increased enthusiasm among the grassroots.

Gary Bauer, a prominent social conservative, notes that Romney is attracting larger crowds, such as 12,000 in Cleveland and 8,000 in suburban Virginia, which would have been inconceivable for him just a few weeks ago. Political rallies typically grow in size as Election Day approaches, but Romney's big moment came during the direct debate with Obama.

Romney's ability to hold his own against a president some Republican voters find "absolutely disgusting" has been emotionally fulfilling for partisans. David Carney, who served as a strategist for Texas Gov. Rick Perry's presidential campaign, notes that conservatives saw Romney as someone who "wants this thing and he's going to fight for it."

During the GOP primary season, the question of who would be most likely to take Obama to task during the fall debates was a hot topic. Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker and Romney's primary rival, stated in January that he was the candidate who could "clearly defeat Obama in a series of debates."

Romney struggled to win any state by a significant margin against Gingrich and former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum, who were considered second-tier challengers but also more reliably conservative. However, Romney's debate performances might have looked like the fulfillment of the worst fears conservatives had about him, as he pivoted to the center and softened his stances on issues such as health care and tax policy.

Despite these concerns, die-hard Republicans have become willing to give Romney their firm support, with Henry Olsen, vice president of the American Enterprise Institute, stating, "It doesn't have anything to do with moving to the center — it's, 'We can be behind a winner.'" Olsen adds, "For the first time in months, they really get the feeling their guy can win." This newfound support is also attributed to Romney's choice of Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan as his running mate, as it signals that he will assemble a conservative team in his Cabinet and the Supreme Court.

Title: U.S. Government Faces Potential Debt Crisis with $100 Trillion in Total Debt by 2048, According to CBO

Article:

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has released its latest long-term budget projections, revealing a disconcerting trajectory for the federal fiscal health of the United States. The report projects a total government debt of $100 trillion by 2048, a figure that represents 152% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) that year.

The CBO's projections depict a significant increase in spending, while taxes will only slightly increase, leading to deep annual deficits that accumulate into a potentially catastrophic debt burden. Debt held by the public, which is currently 78% of GDP, is expected to reach 152% in 2048. Given that GDP will be $65 trillion that year, it means a debt total of $98.8 trillion.

The CBO also projected that Social Security will become insolvent early in the 2030s. The government is projected to pay out a staggering $4 trillion a year in Social Security payments and nearly $4.5 trillion in Medicare benefits in 2048, accounting for about half of the deficit that year. Interest on the debt is also expected to rise, from about $300 billion this year, or less than 2% of GDP, to $4 trillion, or 6.3% of GDP, in three decades.

Government spending is projected to consume nearly one-third of GDP in 2018, approaching the level of some European governments. Tax revenue, meanwhile, is projected to rise slowly and will still be below 20% of GDP in 2048. The CBO used current law to make its calculations, anticipating the GOP tax cuts to expire within a decade.

Should Congress choose to extend the tax cuts and to continue heightened spending envisioned in the latest spending law, the situation gets even more bleak. The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates debt could reach about 200% of GDP—or about $130 trillion—in 2048. As it is, debt at 152%—the CBO's projection—would be the highest in U.S. history, "by far" surpassing even the worst years of World War II, the government analysts said.

Politicians from both parties have expressed concern over the projected debt levels. Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat, stated, "Today's report is another reminder about the true costs of handing out massive tax breaks to billionaires and large corporations." Republicans countered that taxes, while historically low now, will be above average by the end of the three-decade window. They argue that the problem isn't a lack of government money, but too much government payouts.

The CBO did not take sides, but did highlight the large projected growth in spending on entitlement programs such as Social Security and Medicare as major drivers of debt. The government will pay out a staggering $4 trillion a year in Social Security payments and nearly $4.5 trillion in Medicare benefits in 2048, the CBO said. This would account for about half of the deficit that year.

Title: Justice Department Warns of Federal Intervention in State Lockdown Orders

Article:

In a memo issued on Monday, Attorney General William Barr stated that the Department of Justice (DOJ) will intervene if state and local stay-at-home orders in response to the coronavirus pandemic become overly restrictive, potentially violating constitutional rights. The memo comes as states begin to reopen their economies, with businesses such as hair salons and gyms reopening in Georgia, despite health experts' warnings of a potential resurgence of coronavirus outbreaks.

Barr's memo highlights restrictions on religious liberty, discrimination against "disfavored speech," and undue interference with the economy as violations of federal laws. The Justice Department will reportedly be monitoring state and local directives closely, with Eric Dreiband, assistant attorney general for the Civil Rights Division, and Matthew Schneider, the U.S. attorney in the Eastern District of Michigan, leading the effort.

The memo follows thousands of protests against stay-at-home orders in multiple states, including Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania. President Donald Trump has endorsed these protests, encouraging supporters to "liberate" states that have seen large gatherings of protesters.

Governors across the nation, particularly in states with stricter lockdown measures, such as Michigan, are finding themselves on a political tightrope due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and the pressure from anti-quarantine protests and the president's endorsement. Michigan, which has been heavily impacted by the pandemic with about 38,000 COVID-19 cases and 3,400 deaths as of Monday, has imposed some of the most stringent restrictions. Gov. Gretchen Whitmer has ordered residents to stay inside except for essential purposes and nonessential businesses to not require employees to work.

Barr warned last week of potential Justice Department intervention, telling conservative talk show host Hugh Hewitt that officials are reviewing stay-at-home restrictions. "And if we think one goes too far, we initially try to jawbone the governors into rolling them back or adjusting them. And if they ’re not and people bring lawsuits, we file a statement of interest and side with the plaintiffs," Barr said.

Title: White House Considering Temporary Payroll Tax Cut Amid Economic Concerns

Article:

The Trump administration is reportedly considering a temporary payroll tax cut to stimulate the economy and potentially avoid a slowdown or recession, according to a report by The Washington Post on Monday. The administration's top economic advisors have expressed growing concerns about a possible economic slowdown as the 2020 election nears, despite President Trump's positive assessments of the U.S. economy.

However, a White House spokesperson denied that a payroll tax cut is currently under consideration. The Washington Post reported that discussions are still in their early stages, and officials have not decided whether to seek Congress' approval for the cut.

Most working Americans pay a payroll tax on their earnings, a 6.2% levy that funds Social Security programs. The payroll tax was reduced to 4.2% during the Obama administration to encourage consumer spending during the Great Recession but was increased to 6.2% in 2013. A payroll tax cut would provide relief to many middle-class families that did not see such benefits under Trump's tax cuts.

Payroll tax cuts can add to the deficit and potentially take billions from Social Security. The administration's discussions about a new payroll tax cut have only begun in the past few days, according to the report, and specific details about the design have not been finalized.

The talks follow a weekend blitz in which the president and his top economic advisers touted the economy and blamed Democrats for talking it down. "Our Economy is very strong, despite the horrendous lack of vision by Jay Powell and the Fed, but the Democrats are trying to ‘will’ the Economy to be bad for purposes of the 2020 Election. Very Selfish!" Trump tweeted on Monday.

A survey by the National Association for Business Economics, to be released on Monday, shows that 34% of economists believe a slowing economy will tip into a recession in 2021, up from 25% in a survey taken in February. Only 2% of those polled expect a recession to begin this year, while 38% predict it will occur in 2020.

Trump has dismissed concerns about a recession, offering an optimistic outlook for the economy after last week's steep drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. A strong economy is crucial to the Republican president's 2020 reelection prospects.

The economists have previously expressed concern that Trump's tariffs and higher budget deficits could eventually dampen the economy. The Trump administration has imposed tariffs on goods from many key U.S. trading partners, including China, Europe, Mexico, and Canada. Officials maintain that the tariffs, which are taxes on imports, will help the administration gain more favorable terms of trade. However, U.S. trading partners have retaliated with tariffs of their own.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell Reflects on Childhood Polio Experience Amidst Coronavirus Pandemic

Article:

In an interview with The ███, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) shared his personal experience with polio, a disease that gripped the nation in the mid-1940s, when he was a toddler. The image of McConnell sitting with his parents in rural Alabama during that time has been provided by the McConnell Center at the University of Louisville.

As the coronavirus pandemic unfolds, McConnell recalls the fear and uncertainty he felt during the polio crisis, drawing parallels between the two crises. He was diagnosed with polio in 1944, and his left leg was paralyzed. After two years of treatment at a polio center in Warm Springs, Georgia, his mother was told that he would be able to walk without a leg brace.

Seventy years later, McConnell walked into the U.S. Senate to pass a sweeping coronavirus rescue package and shutter the chamber for the foreseeable future. He stated, "There's hope that we're going to get on top of this disease within a year, year and a half."

Stacey D. Stewart, president & CEO of March of Dimes, which started as FDR's National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, described polio as a "scary virus" that particularly struck children, causing swift closures of schools, playgrounds, and swimming pools. Thousands died, others were hospitalized, and some were left permanently paralyzed or with post-polio syndrome.

McConnell was taught to stay off his feet during his recovery, and his mother would run through physical therapy with him "like a drill sergeant." He remembers the embarrassment of having a narrower left leg circumference when putting on a swimsuit and difficulty climbing stairs.

McConnell does not remember much from those earliest days, but he does remember the arrival of the polio vaccine and the relief it brought. As Congress considers the next aid package, he expressed a desire for more funding for healthcare.

McConnell returned to Warm Springs last year, reviewing files about his condition and treatments. He was unsure about how his mother afforded his medical care during that time. One memory that stands clear is the relief the country felt when the polio vaccine was discovered.

Title: EPA Chief Pruitt Under Fire for Alleged Unauthorized Staff Pay Raises and Potential Conflict of Interest

Article:

Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Chief Scott Pruitt came under renewed scrutiny this week following a report by The Atlantic that he had granted unauthorized pay raises to two of his aides, including one who assisted him in finding housing in Washington, D.C.

According to the report, Pruitt requested that the salary of Sarah Greenwalt, his deputy chief of staff, be increased from $107,435 to $164,200, and that of Millan Hupp, his spokesperson, be raised from $86,460 to $114,590. As political appointees, these salary increases required approval from the White House. However, the White House reportedly rejected the request.

In response, Pruitt's team allegedly studied the particulars of the Safe Drinking Water provision, learning that by reappointing Greenwalt and Hupp under this authority, Pruitt could exercise total control over their contracts and grant the raises on his own. Pruitt reportedly ordered the raises, with Greenwalt receiving a raise of $28,130 and Hupp a raise of $56,765, compared to their 2017 salaries.

On Wednesday, Pruitt appeared on Fox News, where he was questioned about the pay raises. In the interview, Pruitt claimed that he was not aware of the pay raises and that his staff had acted without his knowledge. However, when pressed about accountability, Pruitt stated that there would be some accountability, but did not specify whether the individuals responsible were career or political staff members.

In a separate development, it was also reported that before Pruitt rented a room from a top DC energy lobbyist, the lobbyist and his wife had funded Pruitt's political campaigns in his home state of Oklahoma. Campaign finance records show that Steven and Vicki Hart, who last year rented Pruitt a room in their Capitol Hill home for $50 per night, began donating to Pruitt's campaigns for Oklahoma attorney general in 2010. Steven Hart even hosted a fundraiser for Pruitt's reelection effort.

Pruitt's actions have sparked criticism and calls for accountability, with some questioning whether he has been dishonest about his knowledge of the pay raises and the potential conflict of interest presented by his relationship with the Hart couple. The EPA and the White House have not yet responded to requests for comment.

Title: White House Announces National Garden of American Heroes with Statues of Prominent Figures

Article:

The White House has unveiled an executive order to create a "National Garden of American Heroes," which will feature statues of prominent Americans. The order, announced during a Fourth of July celebration at Mount Rushmore, comes amidst calls to remove Confederate statues across the country and address other racist iconography.

The executive order, which President Donald Trump announced, establishes the Task Force for Building and Rebuilding Monuments to American Heroes. This task force will use funding from the Interior Department to establish the site and has 60 days to submit a report to the White House detailing options for the creation of the National Garden, including potential locations.

The garden will include statues of John Adams, Susan B. Anthony, Clara Barton, Daniel Boone, Davy Crockett, Frederick Douglass, Amelia Earhart, Benjamin Franklin, Thomas Jefferson, Martin Luther King Jr., Abraham Lincoln, Ronald Reagan, Jackie Robinson, and Harriet Tubman, among others. The garden will also maintain a collection of statues for temporary display at appropriate sites around the United States.

The garden is expected to be open prior to July 4, 2026, the 250th anniversary of the proclamation of the Declaration of Independence. The executive order also addresses current calls to topple Confederate statues, stating that destroying monuments is a desecration of the nation's shared heritage.

President Trump, in an impassioned speech at Mount Rushmore, criticized those tearing down statues of Confederate leaders, accusing them of wanting to "overthrow the American Revolution" and fundamentally change the country. He also warned against a "new far-left fascism" that seeks to "tear down every statue, symbol and memory of our national heritage."

Title: Congressman Jeff Van Drew Switches Party Affiliation, Cites Far-Left Policies and Threats

Article:

Congressman Jeff Van Drew, a former Democrat, officially left the Democratic Party on Thursday during a meeting in the Oval Office. In a press conference, Van Drew explained that the party's push towards far-left policies and personal threats drove him to become a Republican.

Van Drew, who has been a Democrat for many years, recounted a meeting with a local county chairman two weeks ago, who allegedly threatened him with political retaliation if he did not vote to impeach President Trump. This incident, according to Van Drew, prompted him to reconsider his political allegiance.

Van Drew stated that he had previously considered switching parties during his tenure in the New Jersey state Senate, when he voted on two bills promoting faith and patriotism. These bills, he said, were met with criticism from far-left Democrats who were "disgusted" with his support.

The congressman emphasized his belief in American exceptionalism, capitalism, and the importance of opportunity for all. He also criticized the "extreme" members of the Democratic party who, in his view, denigrate the United States and oppose bipartisan efforts.

Van Drew took direct aim at Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) and the Green New Deal, stating that he believes the proposal should never be considered. He also mentioned his support for lowering taxes, balancing the budget, and honoring first responders and veterans.

Van Drew added that the Democrats are becoming less tolerant of diverse thought as they become more extreme, and he cited former Republican President Ronald Reagan as one of his favorite presidents. Reagan's comment about the Democratic party leaving him also resonated with Van Drew.

The exact details of the threats made against Van Drew and the identity of the county chairman remain unavailable. The Democratic National Committee and Van Drew's office did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Title: Hispanic Republican Leaders Unite Against Donald Trump's Presidential Nomination

Article:

In response to the growing threat of Donald Trump capturing the Republican Party's presidential nomination, Hispanic Republican leaders have taken a unified stand against the billionaire. On the eve of the third GOP debate, about two dozen Hispanic leaders emerged from a closed-door meeting in Colorado with a warning for the Republican Party: they risk losing the Hispanic vote and the White House if Mr. Trump is nominated.

Alfonso Aguilar, director of American Principles Project's Latino Partnership and former official in the administration of President George W. Bush, stated, "Our message to Trump is, 'You're done.' We think if you are the candidate, Republicans will lose the White House."

The Trump campaign declined to comment on the meeting. The Hispanic leaders plan to monitor the rest of the GOP field over the coming weeks and months, and could decide to write off others based on their immigration views.

The GOP presidential debate is set to take place at 8 p.m. Wednesday at the Coors Events Center at the University of Colorado in Boulder. Hosted by CNBC, the prime-time showdown is limited to 10 participants based on national polls and follows a 6 p.m. undercard event featuring four of the lower-tier candidates.

Trump has downplayed the idea that he has fallen out of favor with Hispanics, though an AP-GFK poll this week showed 72 percent of Latinos view him unfavorably, compared to 11 percent who see him in a positive light. Given Colorado's deep pool of Hispanic voters, Wednesday's debate could focus more on immigration, which polls show is a threshold issue for many Hispanics who won't even look at a candidate that comes out against robust legalization.

Rosario Marin, former treasurer of the United States under President George W. Bush, who attended the meeting, said, "Foolishly, some candidates think they don't need the Hispanic vote in the primary, so they pander to the voters with extreme views instead of just showing us who they are. Heed our warning: 'Don't expect us to come to your side during the general election. If you are not with us now, we will not be with you then.'"

The Hispanic "summit" Tuesday was billed as the first of its kind, and attendees said they've scheduled another meeting a day before the Dec. 15 debate in Nevada, which is also home to many Latino voters. The group also vowed to highlight how President Obama broke his promise to push an immigration fight during his first year in office and how Hillary Rodham Clinton, the likely 2016 Democratic nominee, said last year that illegal immigrant children surging across the U.S.-Mexico border should be sent home.

Republicans have wrestled over the issue of immigration since Mitt Romney lost Latino voters by a 71 percent-to-27 percent margin in the 2012 election after he pledged to rely on "self-deportation" to reduce the number of illegal immigrants living in the United States. The pledge contrasted with the executive amnesty that President Obama granted to young illegal immigrants, known as Dreamers, roughly six months out from the general election.

President Obama won the Latino vote by an even wider margin—75 percent to 23 percent—in Colorado, which has produced Republicans with diverse opinions on the issue, including former Rep. Tom Tancredo, a staunch "amnesty" opponent, and Sen. Cory Gardner, who supports a pathway to legal status for illegal immigrants and expanding guest worker programs.

This year, the issue has divided the GOP field, with former Gov. Jeb Bush and Sen. Marco Rubio, both Florida Republicans, Carly Fiorina and Ohio Gov. John Kasich being among the candidates that have backed some sort of a path to legal status for illegal immigrants. Others, including Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas, have vowed to oppose "amnesty" and have supported expanding legal immigration.

Mr. Trump, meanwhile, has focused on the enforcement side of the debate and signaled he is open to reducing legal immigration. In August, he rolled out a six-page plan that called for more border fencing, deporting all illegal immigrants, and ending the policy granting automatic citizenship to almost everyone born in the U.S., including to illegal immigrant mothers.

Sen. Jeff Sessions, Alabama Republican, applauded the Trump plan, saying at the time that it "re-establishes the principle that America's immigration laws should serve the interest of its own citizens." For the Hispanic leaders that gathered in Boulder Tuesday, the proposal was yet another troubling sign for Mr. Trump, who had caught their attention over the summer when he said that Mexico officials were sending drug smugglers, "rapists and some, I assume good people" into the United States.

Mr. Trump has pledged to support whoever wins the GOP nomination. Hispanic leaders, however, said they won't support Mr. Trump. "We still have hope that we can help elect a Republican candidate," said Massey Villarreal, former head of the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, before the meeting. "We are 100 percent united behind the fact that Mr. Trump is not our guy."

"We are not going to shy away from the fact that if Mr. Trump is the nominee, we will encourage Latinos to write their own candidate in," he said. Mr. Aguilar said he would "leave the ballot blank," and also said that it would be "naive" to suggest that Mr. Trump is the only GOP candidate who could jeopardize the party's chances of winning over more Hispanics.

"Trump is in a league of his own, but there is a concern about the way Cruz has been handling the issue," he said. Mr. Aguilar said Mr. Cruz, the son of a Cuban immigrant father, has sent the wrong message by cozying up to Mr. Trump, while also coming out against birthright citizenship and refusing to spell out his plans for the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants living in the country. Others said they are willing to cut Mr. Cruz some more slack. The Cruz camp did not respond to an email seeking comment.

Title: High School Students' Views on Free Speech and Offensive Content: A Mixed Bag, According to a Knight Foundation Survey

Article:

A book titled "End of Discussion," co-authored by Mary Katharine Ham and Guy Benson in 2015, expresses concern over the increasing hostility towards free speech and open debate among Americans, particularly younger generations. The authors argue that the Left often labels ideas they oppose as hateful and offensive, aiming to prevent debates by branding them as morally unworthy of consideration.

Recently, a survey conducted by the Knight Foundation on American high school students sheds light on their views regarding free speech and offensive content. The survey results are somewhat ambiguous, as they rely on the interpretation of terms such as "bullying" and "offensive."

One positive data point from the poll is that 91% of students believe that unpopular speech is a protected right. This percentage has risen by eight points since the survey's 2004 installment, indicating a promising trend. However, only 64% of students believe that free speech is more important than protecting someone from being offended, which is a majority but not a two-thirds majority.

The survey also reveals that students are less disposed than ever to believe that the First Amendment's safeguards of fundamental rights are too excessive. This is reassuring, but the results also show that smaller majorities of high schoolers of color (Asians, Hispanics, and especially blacks) believe that the value of upholding free speech trumps the value of insulating someone from taking offense.

One of the more concerning tactics, according to the authors, is the conflation of offensive speech with physical violence, rooted in a broad definition of what constitutes "safety." The survey's findings suggest that this trick may successfully and lastingly manipulate younger generations, potentially determining whether free speech and expression remain core American values.

David Burge, also known as @iowahawkblog on Twitter, offers a simple but incisive insight that should give anyone inclined toward the "let's ban offensive or bullying speech" position serious pause: "Doucheous @benshapiro tell you what: I'll let you ban hate speech when you let me define hate speech." This point underscores the importance of maintaining a clear and consistent definition of free speech, as well as the potential dangers of allowing it to be defined by those with extreme or biased views.

In conclusion, the survey results offer a mixed bag, with some encouraging signs and red flags. The uniting solution, as suggested by the authors, is to link arms and keep free speech as free as possible, with the exceptions to that rule (excluding hate speech) as narrow as possible, to preserve the principle and everyone's right to open expression. The survey's findings underscore the importance of educators conveying the truth about free speech and passing the American torch to the next generation.

Title: House Republicans Propose Spending Measure to Avert Government Shutdown, Ease Budget Cuts

Article:

Republicans controlling the U.S. House of Representatives have moved to pass a spending measure on Monday, aiming to provide additional funding for military readiness while alleviating the impact of across-the-board spending cuts that are currently taking effect. This measure, which would fund federal operations through September, aims to prevent a potential government shutdown later this month.

The proposed legislation would maintain the detailed 2013 budgets for the Defense and Veterans Affairs departments, while other agencies would be frozen at 2012 levels and subject to the 5 percent domestic agency and 7.8 percent Pentagon cuts ordered by President Barack Obama on Friday.

Both Democrats and Republicans have warned that these cuts, known as sequestration, are draconian and could slow economic growth and cost hundreds of thousands of jobs. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimates that they would slow the economy by 0.6 percent and cost about 750,000 jobs.

The impact of the new cuts has been slow to reach the broader public. The Pentagon has announced plans to furlough thousands of military school teachers worldwide and close stores with consumer goods an extra day each week. Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano has reported delays in customs lines at airports, including Los Angeles International and O'Hare International in Chicago.

President Obama has stated that he is continuing to seek out Republican partners to reach a deal to ease or head off the cuts, but no breakthrough has been reported. "We are going to manage it the best we can to minimize the impact on American families," Obama said at the start of the first Cabinet meeting of his second term. "It is not the right way to go about deficit reduction."

The new Republican funding measure is set to advance through the House on Wednesday. It would provide an increase for military operations and maintenance efforts, as well as veterans' health programs, while putting most of the rest of the government on budget autopilot. After accounting for the across-the-board cuts, domestic agencies would face reductions exceeding 5 percent when compared with last year.

The legislation would provide about $2 billion more than the current level to increase security at U.S. embassies and diplomatic missions worldwide. Last September, a terrorist attack on the U.S. diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, killed Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans.

The across-the-board cuts would carve $85 billion in spending from the government's $3.6 trillion budget for this year, focusing the cuts on the approximately $1 trillion allocated to the day-to-day agency operating budgets set by Congress each year. These so-called discretionary accounts received big boosts in the first two years of Obama's presidency when Democrats controlled Congress, but have borne the brunt of the cuts approved as Obama and Republicans have grappled over the budget.

The FBI and the Border Patrol would be able to maintain current staffing levels and would not have to furlough employees under the proposed legislation. The measure would also provide new funding for embassy security and modernizing the U.S. nuclear arsenal.

Title: White House Celebrates January Job Growth, Cites President Trump's Economic Impact

Article:

The White House announced on Friday the first jobs report of the new administration, which showed the U.S. economy added 227,000 jobs in January. White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer attributed the job growth to the consumer confidence inspired by President Trump's presidency.

According to Spicer, recent polls indicate stronger consumer confidence. He declined to attribute specific job gains to President Trump or his predecessor, former President Obama, as the report covers the transition month. However, Spicer asserted that President Trump's economic effects began before he took office.

"President Trump campaigned on making America work again. Even before he took office, the markets knew he would deliver on that promise," Spicer said.

In contrast to Trump's campaign criticism of the Labor Department's employment level calculations, Spicer did not reiterate such claims in this context.

The strong hiring surpassed expectations, while the jobless rate rose from 4.7 percent to 4.8 percent, as 76,000 more workers entered the workforce to seek employment. The Labor Department reported that employers in the retail, construction, and financial sectors hired the most workers. The government also revised its estimate down for job creation in November and December, lowering the total number of jobs created in that period by 39,000.

Wage growth remains a concern, with average hourly earnings up 3 cents to $26 in January, compared with December's 6-cent increase. For the year ended Jan. 31, wages increased 2.5 percent.

"The president's already taken significant steps to turn our economy around, and he is looking forward to ensuring that every American who wants a job has the opportunity to find one," Spicer said. "While the president's definitely pleased that the job growth has far surpassed expectations and that the labor force participation is rising, he also recognizes that there is a lot more work to be done."

Spicer described the president's jobs agenda as "big and bold." The specifics of this agenda were not detailed in the provided text.
