Title: Milo Yiannopoulos Accuses Former Editor of Bias and Flirting in Unpublished Memoir Dispute

Article:

In a recent turn of events, writer Milo Yiannopoulos has responded to comments made by his former editor, Mitch Ivers, regarding his unpublished memoir. Court documents have revealed Ivers' critical notes, such as "unclear," "unfunny," "delete," which were made when Yiannopoulos sued the publisher, Simon & Schuster. The publishing house cancelled Yiannopoulos' book in February following the emergence of footage where he appeared to condone pedophilia.

Yiannopoulos has since accused Ivers of flirting with him and being biased against his work. The alt-right provocateur's critics have mocked him for the highly critical editorial feedback, with comments like "The way you casually bring up the KKK makes no sense" and "This entire paragraph is just repeating Fake News. There was NO blood, NO semen and there was NO Satanism. Delete."

Ivers also attempted to make Yiannopoulos aware of his perceived image, advising, "You MUST ACKNOWLEDGE that this is EXACTLY what people accuse you and Breitbart of being: a new age of partisan propaganda masquerading as journalism." "This is definitely not the place for more of your narcissism," he added.

When Yiannopoulos accused feminists of being "more desperate to be noticed than Kanye West at an awards show," Ivers responded with "This is what people say about you."

Ivers' scathing remarks were made public when lawyers for Simon & Schuster filed them in court in response to Yiannopoulos' July lawsuit, where he alleges breach of contract after the deal was cancelled in February.

In July 2016, Milo Yiannopoulos was banned from Twitter for "inciting or engaging in the targeted abuse or harassment of others." This action followed his comments directed at Leslie Jones, a black actress in an all-female Ghostbusters reboot, which led to a barrage of abuse from other Twitter users.

Yiannopoulos has also been widely criticized for comments he has made about transgender people, Muslims, Black Lives Matter activism, feminists, and gay people, despite being openly gay himself. Yiannopoulos, in a statement on social media, claimed, "Mitchell Ivers, the liberal gay editor Simon & Schuster put in charge of neutering its edgier conservative authors, hates Republicans and thinks they are all virulent homophobes. He told me so himself." He further stated, "Ivers said one thing in manuscript edits, but quite another when he was giggling and flirting with me.... I look forward to prevailing in court."

Title: "Secret Earpiece Speculation in Presidential Debates: A Recurring Election Theme"

Article:

The Drudge Report, a prominent news aggregator, published a story on Thursday titled "HILLARY AND THE EAR PEARL," which linked to an article from Infowars.com, a website known for promoting conspiracy theories. The story questioned whether Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton was wearing a secret earpiece during the previous night's presidential forum, based on images that appeared to show a flesh-colored device in her ear.

The Infowars article, citing a tweet from actor and right-wing commentator James Woods, suggested that Clinton might have had someone secretly feeding her answers during the forum. The story gained traction, with Donald Trump Jr., the son of the Republican presidential nominee, sharing a link to the Infowars story on Twitter.

This "secret earpiece" story is not a new phenomenon in American politics. The first significant instance of such speculation emerged during the 2004 presidential election, when blogger Joseph Cannon noticed an odd bulge in George W. Bush's suit jacket during a debate. The speculative accusation gained traction, with some mainstream media outlets, including The Washington Post and The New York Times, reporting on the issue. However, no direct evidence was ever produced to support the allegation that Bush was wired during the debate.

In 2008, during the Oct. 7 presidential debate, blogger Ann Althouse noticed an alleged earpiece in Barack Obama's ear and posted a photo of the device. She later retracted her claim, acknowledging that she was looking at light reflecting off Obama's ear, but left open the possibility that a secret earpiece might still exist.

The 2012 election saw less prominent earpiece speculation, though some chain emails circulated, accusing Obama of wearing an earpiece and having a suspicious bulge in his suit. The primary example of overwrought "he's a cheater" attacks during the 2012 cycle were directed at Republican contender Mitt Romney, who was accused of consulting crib notes during the first debate with Obama.

The relative lack of earpiece mania in 2012 has been more than compensated for in 2016, with the Clinton "clandestine listening device" story featured prominently on one of the world's most heavily trafficked political websites and endorsed by the son of the Republican nominee. Other Clinton-related conspiracies have proven to be remarkably persistent this cycle, with her allegedly failing health being the most prominent among them.

Joseph Uscinski, a professor of political science at the University of Miami who has written extensively about political conspiracy theories, explained that these beliefs are dependent on a conspiracy worldview and partisanship. "People point fingers at the other side," Uscinski said. "If you're already predisposed to believe that a candidate from the other party is going to cheat, then you're more likely to take at face value an allegation that he or she cheated during a debate."

These cheating allegations tend to take the form of a secret earpiece because that's the only way someone participating in a nationally televised presidential debate could conceivably cheat, Uscinski added. "It's just like when Hillary Clinton goes on [Jimmy Kimmel Live] and opens the pickle jar," Uscinski explained, referring to a humorous feat of strength that Clinton performed to mock questions about her health. "The only way she could have cheated in that test...was to have a preopened pickle jar. It's sort of obvious that if people are going to be predisposed to thinking that cheating was taking place, that would be the method in which it would be done."

It remains unclear whether Matt Drudge and Donald Trump Jr. genuinely believe that Clinton was wired during the debate, but their actions legitimize the idea in the minds of those who are already inclined to believe it.

Title: New Massachusetts Representative Seth Moulton's Military Service and Political Career

Article:

Seth Moulton, the newly elected House Representative for Massachusetts' Sixth Congressional District, previously stated that he never aspired to become a politician. Instead, he joined the Marines shortly after graduating from Harvard University, just before the 9/11 terrorist attacks in 2001. Moulton served four combat tours in Iraq, a war he has expressed doubts about, stating that this experience influenced his decision to run for office.

During his campaign, Moulton's military service became a significant focus, as he unseated nine-term Democratic incumbent John Tierney in a primary challenge, the first successful primary challenge to a sitting Massachusetts congressman in two decades. He also defeated state Sen. Richard Tisei in the general election. Moulton received endorsements from high-ranking military officials such as Generals Stanley McChrystal and David Petraeus, and he emphasized reforming the Department of Veteran Affairs in his platform.

In an effort to distance himself from the trend of politicians boasting about their military connections, Moulton has been praised for downplaying his service history. He told The Boston Globe, "There is a healthy disrespect among veterans who served on the front lines for people who walk around telling war stories."

Moulton has been so discreet about his military career that he chose not to publicly disclose that he was twice decorated for heroism for his actions in Iraq, including receiving a Bronze Star in 2004. This information was not known to his parents until last month, according to a campaign spokesman.

Besides campaigning for VA reform and criticizing the Iraq war and various aspects of President Obama's foreign policy, Moulton has also focused on other issues, such as fishing regulation in his district and his business experience. After leaving the Marines, he obtained an MBA from Harvard Business School and spent several years working at a startup.

Elected to a House of Representatives that is now Republican-controlled, Moulton's background and his secure position in a deep blue state could make him a significant figure in an otherwise challenging election night for Democrats.

Title: Putin and Poroshenko Discuss Peace Deal for Eastern Ukraine, Ceasefire Agreed Upon

Article:

Russian editor Fyodor Lukyanov stated that Russia aims to demonstrate control over the ongoing conflict in Eastern Ukraine, with a focus on preventing Ukrainian forces from perceiving a potential military victory and accepting separatist leaders as negotiation partners. The specifics of the peace deal remain unclear due to complex diplomatic maneuvers and domestic politics.

On Wednesday, Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Petro O. Poroshenko reportedly held an extensive telephone discussion regarding the conflict. Initially, Mr. Poroshenko's office announced a "lasting cease-fire" agreement, but later clarified that both leaders had only endorsed the need for a cease-fire, with Mr. Poroshenko expressing hope for earnest negotiations to begin on Friday. Mr. Putin claimed his notes were based on the telephone conversation.

The proposed plan, as outlined by Mr. Putin, includes Ukrainian artillery withdrawing and relocating out of range of separatist strongholds, an end to airstrikes, an exchange of all detainees, opening humanitarian corridors for residents of separatist areas, repairing damaged infrastructure, and deploying international observers to monitor the cease-fire.

The agreement does not mention autonomy for the separatist eastern regions, a central political demand that Russia has emphasized since March. This omission is widely perceived as crucial to Russia's long-term goal of maintaining influence over Ukraine's domestic affairs and obstructing any future Ukrainian attempts to join NATO.

The negotiations are set to take place in Minsk, Belarus, on Friday, with all parties involved in the talks, including representatives of the separatists. The two-day NATO summit meeting is also scheduled to conclude on Friday.

Title: U.S. President Trump Defends Migrant Family Separation Policy Amidst Bipartisan Criticism

Article:

President Donald Trump has defended his administration's policy of separating migrant children from their parents at the U.S.-Mexico border, blaming Democrats and reiterating his stance against turning the United States into a "migrant camp." The policy has faced increasing criticism from both Democrats and some Republicans, with former first lady Laura Bush calling it "cruel" and "immoral."

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and Attorney General Jeff Sessions have defended the policy, with Sessions calling on Congress to act and end the "lawlessness." Nearly 2,000 children were separated from their families over a six-week period in April and May.

U.S. protocol prohibits detaining children with their parents because the children are not charged with a crime and the parents are. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen has argued that releasing parents with their children amounts to a "get out of jail free card" for those in the country illegally.

First lady Melania Trump, who has tended to stay out of contentious policy debates, has also waded into the issue, expressing her hope that both sides of the aisle can come together to achieve successful immigration reform.

The Rev. Franklin Graham, a longtime Trump ally, called the policy "disgraceful." Several religious groups, including some conservative ones, have pushed to stop the practice of separating immigrant children from their parents.

Former Trump adviser Anthony Scaramucci has criticized the administration for blaming Democrats and using the issue as a way of pressuring Democrats into negotiating on a Republican immigration bill. Republican Sen. Susan Collins of Maine has expressed deep concerns about the child separation policy.

House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi has called the policy "an utter atrocity that debases America's values and our legacy as a beacon of hope." Trump plans to meet with House Republicans on Tuesday to discuss pending immigration legislation amid the election-season debate. Both House proposals face broad opposition from Democrats, and even if a bill does pass, the closely divided Senate seems unlikely to go along.

Title: Nine Key Battleground States in the 2012 Presidential Election

Article:

The 2012 presidential race has narrowed to a core of nine states, a collection of margin-of-error battlegrounds spread across nearly every region. These states, ranging from New Hampshire in the Northeast to Nevada in the Rocky Mountain West, are generally agreed upon as key battlegrounds by both the Obama and Romney campaigns.

Aside from New Hampshire and Nevada, the seven other states are Colorado, Florida, Iowa, North Carolina, Ohio, Virginia, and Wisconsin. Some of these states are familiar presidential battlegrounds, accustomed to playing a pivotal role every four years. Others are relative newcomers to the swing state roster. Each of these nine states was carried by President Barack Obama in 2008.

Colorado, with nine electoral votes, is the biggest prize in the Mountain West. This explains why, for the two weeks preceding the conventions, two of the nation's top five media markets in terms of ad buys were Denver and Colorado Springs.

The Romney campaign strategy depends on turning out the GOP base, especially on the energy-oriented Western Slope and in El Paso County's Colorado Springs, home to a politically active evangelical Christian community and a heavy military influence. This year, the expectation among Republicans is that Romney will also gain more traction in the Denver suburbs than John McCain.

The Obama campaign strategy closely resembles the one successfully employed by Democratic Sen. Michael Bennet in 2010. Bennet ran well among Hispanics and benefited from an enormous gender gap—17 points, according to exit polls. The same themes Bennet used—notably abortion rights and contraception—have been put to use again in Colorado and were underscored at the Democratic convention in Charlotte last week.

It is worth noting that the president campaigned in Colorado with Sandra Fluke in early August, and he will return again later this week.

A correction has been made to the story. The last year Wisconsin voted Republican at the presidential level was 1984.

Title: Cashless Payments Gain Traction Amid Pandemic, Sparking Debate Over Convenience and Equity

Article:

The coronavirus pandemic has led to a surge in the use of cashless payments, with nearly half of Americans opting for digital transactions when making in-person purchases, according to a YouGov poll. This shift is prompting businesses to implement cashless protocols, such as Starbucks' pledge to transition to cashless payments to minimize virus spread.

Proponents of cashless payments argue that they are more hygienic, faster, and more convenient. Cash can potentially spread germs, and cashless transactions are quicker, as demonstrated by the millions of Americans still waiting for their coronavirus stimulus checks, who could have received the funds directly into their bank accounts. Businesses would also save time and money by eliminating the need to handle cash, and there would be a decrease in thefts due to the absence of money in cash registers and improved payment tracking.

However, opponents of cashless transactions argue that they are discriminatory, as they exclude individuals without bank accounts, such as the young, low-income, homeless, and undocumented. A cashless society would also be challenging for the less tech-savvy, such as the elderly, who may struggle to navigate digital systems. Critics also worry about the potential for increased hacking and privacy concerns, as well as logistical difficulties in a global digital banking system.

China is currently piloting the world's first digital national currency, and other countries are considering following suit. In the United States, there have been discussions about providing Americans with "digital dollars" for future stimulus relief and banking for the unbanked, but no legislation has been passed yet.

Economists and financial experts, such as Kenneth Rogoff and Gary Cohn, argue that digital wallets would have improved the government's ability to help individuals and small businesses during the pandemic. On the other hand, labor union president Stuart Appelbaum contends that a cashless business model is discriminatory and disadvantages low-income people, people of color, undocumented immigrants, and seniors.

The U.S. financial system's outdated and inefficient technologies have been exposed during the pandemic, and there is a growing consensus that the U.S. must invest in its financial infrastructure to promote economic growth and strategic influence abroad. The debate over cashless payments will likely continue as the pandemic evolves and businesses and governments weigh the benefits and drawbacks of going digital.

Title: Hillary Clinton Cites Multiple Factors for 2016 Election Loss in CBS Interview

Article:

In a CBS News interview, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, whose book "What Happened" is set to be released on September 12, outlined several reasons for her 2016 presidential election loss to Donald Trump. Clinton pointed to the FBI Director James Comey's letter announcing the reopening of the investigation into her use of a private email server as secretary of state as a significant factor in her defeat.

"I watched how analysts who I have a great deal of respect for, like Nate Silver, burrowed into all the data and said that 'but for that Comey letter, she would have won,'" Clinton said.

Clinton and her team have previously attributed her defeat to the FBI letter, as well as alleged Russian interference. However, Clinton has also given speeches citing a wide range of other reasons for her loss.

In a speech in New York City on Thursday, Clinton seemed to blame angry voters, stating, "I think the kind of leadership I was offering was not satisfying enough for certain people, and it wasn't enough for me to say, 'Look, I understand, and here's what I want to do to help' if I didn't display more anger so that they could feel I got their anger."

In the CBS News interview, Clinton also cited Russian interference, the leak of John Podesta's emails by WikiLeaks, alleged voter suppression, and sexism and misogyny as reasons for her loss. She claimed that Facebook took money from Russian companies to run negative stories about her, and that voter suppression was implemented in states like Wisconsin and North Carolina.

Clinton also promised a chapter about sexism and misogyny in her upcoming book. More reasons for her election defeat are likely to emerge with the release of "What Happened."

Adam Shaw, a politics reporter based in New York, reported the story. Follow Adam on Twitter: @AdamShawNY.

Title: Greta Thunberg and the Progressive Agenda: A Critical Analysis of Individuality and Conformity

Article:

In a recent commentary, the pro-life movement has drawn attention to the perceived hypocrisy of progressives, arguing that their focus on climate change overlooks the value of human life before birth. This perspective, as presented, is a critique of the progressive approach to individuality and conformity, using the example of climate activist Greta Thunberg.

The article suggests that Thunberg, a 16-year-old climate activist, has been "groomed" into her role as a zealot for the progressive cause. It is argued that her Asperger's syndrome, a neurodevelopmental disorder, has facilitated her transformation into a one-note activist. The piece questions the authenticity of the progressive emphasis on individuality and diversity, suggesting that it is a facade for the pursuit of power and control.

The article further argues that Thunberg's life has been entirely dedicated to the climate cause, mirroring the perceived disregard for individuality in the womb. It suggests that Thunberg's parents have manipulated her condition to serve the ends of the progressive movement. The piece concludes by stating that the progressive model, as represented by Thunberg, encourages conformity, marginalization, and the suppression of individuality.

The article also touches on the devaluation of human value in modern society, suggesting that education has led to a transactional view of worth, with the price of conformity becoming increasingly steep. The piece concludes by suggesting that the current price for conformity is set at "Kamikaze mode," implying a self-destructive approach to life.

It is important to note that this article presents a critical perspective on the progressive movement and Greta Thunberg, and readers are encouraged to form their own opinions based on the information provided. The article does not provide fact-checking or sourcing for the claims made, and some statements may be subject to interpretation.

Title: U.S. Government Modifies Student Visa Program Due to COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The ongoing Wuhan coronavirus pandemic has prompted changes in the way American education is delivered, particularly in secondary and post-secondary schools, colleges, and universities. As a result of the pandemic, educators have had to adapt and teach their lessons online. With the coronavirus pandemic continuing and schools planning for the fall, many are preparing to continue with remote learning. This shift to online classes has led the federal government to reconsider its Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP) for foreign students planning to study in the United States.

On Monday, SEVP announced changes to its visa program in response to the coronavirus pandemic. Foreign students will not be allowed to remain in the United States if they are taking a full online course load. If the institution the student is currently attending is conducting all online classes come the fall, the student has the ability to enroll in other schools or programs to meet the in-person requirements.

The changes apply to F-1 nonimmigrant students, who pursue academic coursework, and M-1 nonimmigrant students, who pursue vocational coursework while studying in the United States.

Here are the guidelines for F-1 and M-1 students:

* Nonimmigrant F-1 and M-1 students attending schools operating entirely online may not take a full online course load and remain in the United States. The U.S. Department of State will not issue visas to students enrolled in schools and/or programs that are fully online for the fall semester nor will U.S. Customs and Border Protection permit these students to enter the United States. Active students currently in the United States enrolled in such programs must depart the country or take other measures, such as transferring to a school with in-person instruction to remain in lawful status. If not, they may face immigration consequences including, but not limited to, the initiation of removal proceedings.
* Nonimmigrant F-1 students attending schools operating under normal in-person classes are bound by existing federal regulations. Eligible F students may take a maximum of one class or three credit hours online.
* Nonimmigrant F-1 students attending schools adopting a hybrid model—that is, a mixture of online and in-person classes—will be allowed to take more than one class or three credit hours online. These schools must certify to SEVP, through the Form I-20, “Certificate of Eligibility for Nonimmigrant Student Status,” certifying that the program is not entirely online, that the student is not taking an entirely online course load this semester, and that the student is taking the minimum number of online classes required to make normal progress in their degree program.

The rule change requires colleges to update their information in the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) within 10 days of the start of the fall semester if instruction starts in-person and is then switched to online-only. Students will be responsible for falling into compliance, either by adjusting their courseload or returning home.

According to the Institute of International Education, international students make up 5.5 percent of the United States' higher education population. These students are said to have contributed $44.7 billion to the U.S. economy in 2018.

Title: Tariff on Aluminum Imports Could Increase Costs for U.S. Brewers and Consumers

Article:

President Donald Trump's proposed 10% tariff on aluminum imports could result in increased production costs for U.S. brewers, potentially leading to higher prices for consumers. This is according to a statement by the Beer Institute, a trade group, which claims the tariff would amount to a $347.7 million tax on brewers and result in the loss of tens of thousands of jobs.

More than half of the beer produced annually in the U.S. is sold in aluminum containers, traditionally marketed to cost-conscious consumers. Cans of popular beer brands such as Natural Ice and Bud Light are staples among cash-strapped college students and working-class America, a key part of Mr. Trump's political base.

Analysts suggest that some of these increased costs could be passed on to consumers. Nico von Stackelberg, a consumer-goods analyst at Liberum, stated, "Businesses don't assume cost increases, they pass them on to consumers."

The tariffs could also impact the craft beer industry, as artisanal brew is increasingly sold in cans due to aluminum's good surface for colorful, effective branding. Industry watchers suggest the planned levies may exacerbate a shift by consumers away from beer toward spirits and wine, which are mainly sold in bottles.

Soda companies, such as Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, use more aluminum cans than makers of alcoholic beverages, though only about 29% of soda and other soft drinks are sold in cans, according to the American Beverage Association. Coca-Cola and PepsiCo declined to comment.

Brewers are not passively accepting the tariff. MillerCoors, the U.S. division of Molson Coors, tweeted that "American workers and American consumers will suffer as a result of this misguided tariff," adding that there isn't enough can sheet aluminum available in the U.S. to satisfy demand.

AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, was presenting its fourth-quarter earnings on the same day Mr. Trump announced the tariff. AB InBev Chief Financial Officer Felipe Dutra stated, "We urge the Department of Commerce and President Trump to consider the adverse impact that the trade restrictions on aluminum will have on the more than two million American jobs before making his final decision."

Roughly 25% of AB InBev's cost of goods sold in the U.S. stems from aluminum purchases, according to analysts.

Food manufacturers that rely on steel and aluminum for packaging have also asked the administration to exempt packaging containers from the tariffs. The Grocery Manufacturers Association, the trade group representing big food companies, stated, "Such tariffs will act as a regressive tax on low income consumers."

The Can Manufacturers Institute, representing can makers, states the tariffs could cause closures to U.S.-based plants. The industry employs 22,000 workers across 34 states in the U.S. The group also argues that domestic metal supplies can't meet its needs, potentially leading to higher food costs for consumers.

In unveiling his plans to impose the tariffs on aluminum and steel, the president cited what he described as a trade imbalance and national security concerns. However, The Beer Institute argues that imported aluminum used to make beer cans is not a threat to national security. Jim McGreevy, the group's president, stated, "Imported aluminum used to make beer cans is not a threat to national security."

Title: U.S. Government Temporarily Halts Prosecution of Parents Crossing Border Illegally with Children

Article:

WASHINGTON - The U.S. government has temporarily halted prosecution for parents crossing the border illegally with their children due to a lack of space to house them, according to officials. The Trump administration had vowed to prosecute all adults crossing the border illegally but faced international criticism for its policy of separating immigrant children from parents.

In an effort to keep detained families together while parents await trial, the Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agency is not referring new cases for prosecution, CBP officials stated. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said the administration was not dropping its "zero-tolerance" policy on illegal immigration but needed a "temporary solution" until it can house migrant families.

The U.S. military has been asked to prepare to house up to 20,000 unaccompanied child migrants on its bases. However, the administration has yet to reunite more than 2,000 children with their parents, and it is unclear how it will house thousands of families while parents are prosecuted.

Republicans control both chambers in Congress, but disagreements between moderates and conservatives over immigration matters have hindered prospects for a speedy legislative fix to the border crisis. Mark Meadows, leader of a conservative faction among Republicans in the House of Representatives, said on Monday he expected an immigration bill being worked on by Republicans to fail.

A group of Republican and Democratic senators met late on Monday to discuss potential legislation establishing a protocol for treating immigrant families as their asylum or other protection from deportation claims are considered. However, after the meeting, Senator Dianne Feinstein, the senior Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said "Nothing's going to happen this week" on legislation in the Senate.

President Donald Trump has expressed frustration with U.S. immigration laws and reiterated on Monday that people should be turned away at the border. Democrats have accused him of wanting to circumvent the U.S. constitution's guarantee of due process for those accused of crimes.

The immigration crisis has triggered new political tension, with Trump lashing out at Democratic Congresswoman Maxine Waters, who urged Americans to confront members of his inner circle in public places. Trump called Waters an "extraordinarily low IQ person." Last week, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen was confronted at a Mexican restaurant in Washington by protesters.

House of Representatives Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi called for cooler heads on both sides, stating, "Trump's daily lack of civility has provoked responses that are predictable but unacceptable. As we go forward, we must conduct elections in a way that achieves unity from sea to shining sea."

Title: Bomb Explosion on Tel Aviv Bus Labeled as Terrorist Attack

Article: A bomb explosion occurred on a bus in central Tel Aviv on Wednesday, injuring at least 10 individuals in what Israeli officials have described as a terrorist attack. The incident took place on a tree-lined street adjacent to Israel's large defense ministry complex.

According to Israel's ambulance service, three of the wounded are in severe condition. The blast shattered the bus's windows. Ofir Gendelman, a spokesman for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, confirmed that this was a terrorist attack.

Israeli authorities are currently searching the area for the individual who planted the device, and reports indicate that a man has been arrested. The bombing occurred on the eighth day of an Israeli offensive against the Hamas-ruled Gaza Strip. Celebratory gunfire was heard across the Palestinian enclave following the news of the explosion.

Yesterday, Israel expressed skepticism about a truce deal with Hamas, despite the presence of Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in the country and international efforts to broker a deal. Hamas spokesman Sami Abu Zuhri praised the bombing but did not claim responsibility.

Abu Zuhri stated, "Hamas blesses the attack in Tel Aviv and sees it as a natural response to the Israeli massacres... in Gaza." He added, "Palestinian factions will resort to all means in order to protect our Palestinian civilians in the absence of a world effort to stop the Israeli aggression."

With this latest attack, Israel may be more inclined to proceed with a ground invasion of Gaza, a move that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu postponed in hopes of reaching a diplomatic solution first.

Title: Polling Shows Increasing Support for Censorship of Extreme Views in the U.S.

Article:

A new poll by YouGov reveals growing support among Americans for censorship of extreme and fringe worldviews, causing concern for those who uphold the First Amendment's protection of free speech. The survey, which asked questions about the Ku Klux Klan (KKK), neo-Nazis, ISIS, and Antifa, shows a significant number of respondents in favor of banning these groups from speaking in their communities, having their literature in local libraries, and teaching at local colleges.

According to Allahpundit's analysis, the impulse appears to be bipartisan, with only small pluralities of Trump supporters making an "exception" for the KKK. Pluralities of Democrats and Republicans agree that neo-Nazis and Klansmen should be subject to bans from speaking in their community (54% of Democrats and 46% of Republicans) and from having their literature carried by the local public library (52% of Democrats and 44% of Republicans). Americans are also roughly evenly split on whether people should be barred by law from joining the Klan (35% in favor, 39% opposed) or the American Nazi Party (38% in favor, 37% opposed).

However, there is one demographic that stands out as an outlier in the case of the KKK: "Narrow pluralities of Trump voters would allow the speech (49% in favor, 39% opposed) and keep the book on the shelves (46% would not remove the book, 39% would)," according to the poll. This is, of course, the correct position if you support the First Amendment, as the amendment protects vile, ugly speech just as much as prim and proper speech.

The survey also asked about ISIS. Results show a stronger inclination toward censorship, fueled disproportionately by Republican responses. According to YouGov, GOPers lead Democrats in wanting to remove ISIS books from the library by 14 points. The interpretation of this depends on what one thinks motivates Republicans. To the left, no doubt, it's a sign that conservatives see this issue more starkly when Muslim radicals rather than white radicals are the problem group. However, ISIS is an explicitly murderous terrorist group whose goal is world domination, achieved through brutal violence and subjugation.

The survey did not poll any explicitly left-wing organizations or movements, such as Antifa. The answer, according to the author, should be straightforward: The speech and political gatherings of communists and hard leftists are absolutely protected, but any criminal conduct is not. That should be the consistently applied standard. Incidentally, does anyone doubt that while self-described Democrats outflank Trump voters on censoring KKK speeches or writings in this poll, the opposite would be true for Antifa?

For those in the hardcore pro-First Amendment camp, the survey also raises concerns about the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), traditionally a bastion of First Amendment absolutism, starting to go "wobbly." The ACLU is reportedly vulnerable to the currents of American political tribalism. On the flip side, the Supreme Court's jurisprudence on the First Amendment has been consistently and lastingly strong for years.

Finally, the article highlights Megan McArdle's important essay on "private coercion," exploring how outrage mobs, often abetted and fueled by corporate actors, are stamping out controversial opinions and ruining lives, often with little recourse for the target.

Title: Military Sexual Assault Reform: Senate Pursues Significant Changes in Response to High-Profile Cases

Article:

In a recent development, the United States Senate is pursuing significant changes to military law in response to the issue of sexual assault in the military. The changes aim to address concerns about commanders' power in prosecuting sexual assault cases and the impact of unlawful command influence.

A Navy judge ruled this week that two defendants in military sexual assault cases could not be punitively discharged due to President Obama's public remarks in 2013, where he stated that offenders should be "prosecuted, stripped of their positions, court-martialed, fired, dishonorably discharged. Period." This decision was first reported by Stars and Stripes.

Eugene R. Fidell, who teaches military justice at Yale Law School, commented on the issue, stating, "Statements by high officials have always been problematic. On the one hand, people do look to them to take a stand on things; on the other hand, we are administering justice here."

The measures in the Senate include a mandatory review of decisions by commanders not to prosecute sexual assault, making retaliation a crime, and subjecting sex offenders to automatic dishonorable discharges. Commanders would also no longer be able to overturn jury convictions unilaterally.

Senator Susan Collins, a Republican of Maine and a co-sponsor of the proposed changes, said, "What’s been lost in all this is that for the first time ever we are going to have strong legislative changes that are going to make a real difference in curbing sexual assault."

Lawmakers from both parties have been pursuing changes to military law to combat sexual assault for years, but a recent series of events, including startling sexual assault data released by the Defense Department, a spate of high-profile cases, and a handful of lawmakers who have perceived that their pursuit of the issue would be politically advantageous, has put a stronger spotlight on the issue.

Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, who has attached herself to the effort, oversaw the first Senate hearing in nearly a decade on sexual assaults in the military in March. Her efforts received support from several committee members who joined her in pressing members of the military every time they came to the Hill to testify this spring, even if the topic was the defense budget.

Title: Hurricane Dorian Strengthens, Florida Declares State of Emergency

Article:

Hurricane Dorian, currently classified as a Category 1 hurricane, is expected to intensify into a major hurricane by Friday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC). As of 5 a.m. ET on Thursday, the hurricane's maximum sustained winds were 85 mph, with higher gusts. Dorian is approximately 150 miles north-northwest of Puerto Rico, moving at a speed of 13 mph towards the northwest.

The storm has already impacted Puerto Rico and St. Thomas in the U.S. Virgin Islands, with sustained winds exceeding 80 mph. Forecasters predict that Dorian will strengthen into a dangerous Category 3 hurricane, defined as sustained winds of at least 111 mph.

Heavy rainfall is expected to affect portions of the Bahamas, Florida, and other areas in the Southeastern United States later this week and into early next week. The NHC stated, "All indications are that by this Labor Day weekend, a powerful hurricane will be near or over the Florida peninsula."

In response to the approaching hurricane, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has declared a state of emergency for 26 counties potentially in Dorian's path. The Hurricane Warning for Vieques, Culebra, and the U.S. Virgin Islands has been discontinued, and the Hurricane Watch and Tropical Storm Warning for Puerto Rico have been discontinued.

Dorian has caused only limited damage in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Culebra Mayor William Solís reported no damages to the AP, with only one community on his island losing power.

Current predictions show Dorian's center making landfall on Florida's coast late Sunday or early Monday. The exact location of the eye's landfall is still uncertain, and the NHC advises everyone in the affected area to make emergency preparations.

The NHC forecasts that the northern Bahamas and coastal sections of the Southeast United States could see 4 to 8 inches of rain, with 10 inches possible in isolated areas. This rainfall may cause life-threatening flash floods.

President Trump has declared an emergency in Puerto Rico, ordering the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to provide "equipment and resources necessary to alleviate the impacts of the emergency." Puerto Rico Governor Wanda Vázquez Garced expressed gratitude for the declaration, stating it would "allow federal aid to arrive more quickly" after the storm passes.

Trump also approved an emergency declaration for the Virgin Islands on Wednesday. In a statement about its preparations, FEMA stated that its stock on the island compared to 2017 levels includes three times as many generators, nine times as many meals, five times as many liters of water, and 16 times as many blue tarps.

Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Erin formed late Tuesday, with winds reaching 40 mph. The storm, several hundred miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C., was downgraded to a tropical depression on Wednesday. Erin is expected to remain on a north-northeastern track, likely arriving at Canada's coast late this week.

Title: "Teen Vogue's Transformation into a Political Rage Pamphlet and the Obsession with Celebrity Footwear"

Article:

In recent times, the American culture seems to be evolving into a pervasive default mode of "All Politics, All The Time." This shift is evident in various aspects of society, including the transformation of Teen Vogue, a once-lighthearted magazine, into a politically charged and sometimes alarming platform.

A recent essay in Teen Vogue declared, "We walk around as if we were bombs about to go off, worried about admitting how livid we really are, even to ourselves." The article suggests that women should always be angry and that apathy might indicate underlying issues. Another Teen Vogue writer publicly threatened to bite off male private parts belonging to "the Evangelicals," highlighting the magazine's increasingly aggressive tone.

Another topic of concern is the obsession with the footwear choices of public figures, particularly first ladies. The recent uproar over Melania Trump wearing high heels during a Hurricane Harvey visit is a prime example. Major media outlets, including The Washington Post, The New York Times, and Politico, published articles criticizing the "optics" of her footwear, despite her bringing tennis shoes for her time in Corpus Christi.

Even celebrities, such as Taylor Swift, are not immune to this political creep. A recent New York magazine article labeled Swift as an embodiment of the Trump era, suggesting that the president's presence has given a home to a grim and cynical strain of pop culture.

This relentless political focus has led to a war on fun, as people seem to find entertainment in political hand-wringing and hectoring. This obsession is not unique to the Trump era, as Michelle Obama faced similar criticism for wearing expensive shoes to a food bank in 2009.

In conclusion, the culture's encroaching default mode of "All Politics, All The Time" is not only exhausting but also cringe-worthy and tedious. It is essential to remember that sometimes, celebrities are just celebrities, and political events do not always require a deep analysis or public outcry. A more balanced approach to politics and entertainment could help preserve the essence of fun in our culture.

Title: Study Finds Partisanship Influences Climate Policy Support Among Democrats and Republicans

Article:

A recent study, which also referenced a similar study, surveyed Democrats, Republicans, and independents in Washington State regarding a carbon tax that was on the ballot in their state in 2016. The study found that participants generally supported climate policies that were perceived as backed by their own party and were neutral toward policies supported by the opposing party.

The research suggests that Democrats and Republicans are swayed by partisanship because they believe their fellow party members are also heavily influenced by partisanship. This was observed when participants were asked to estimate how their fellow citizens would respond to the policies. People overestimated the opposition of Democrats and Republicans to policies backed by the other side. These exaggerated estimates strongly predicted their own support for a policy.

This finding aligns with the fundamental lessons of social psychology, which emphasizes that people are profoundly affected by what other people think. In their desire to be upstanding members of their political tribe, people are pulled toward embracing the stances of their peers and are loath to publicly disagree with them.

As a result, the actual degree of political polarization on climate change belief and support for climate policy is considerably less than people think it is. The study suggests that climate policy gridlock is largely due to exaggerating disagreement for the sake of disagreement.

However, there is some cause for optimism. The study revealed a consistent, if somewhat surprising, pattern: Political disagreement was substantially smaller when it came to Republican-backed policies. In particular, there was very little distance between Republicans and Democrats when evaluating a Republican-proposed carbon tax. This suggests that a carbon tax, such as the one proposed by prominent Republicans like James Baker III and George Shultz, may hold more promise for bipartisan agreement than we have seen with Democratic policies in the past.

Title: Croatia Deploys Army to Manage Border Crossings Amidst Refugee Influx

Article:

Croatia has activated its military forces along the border with Serbia as thousands of refugees and migrants continue to enter the country. The influx follows Hungary's closure of its borders, pushing migrants towards Croatia as an alternative route into European Union (EU) countries.

Speaking to Lauren Frayer at the Croatia-Serbia border, Jamal al-Shahoud, a refugee from Syria, shared his experience, stating, "Here, there's no food, no water. No buses, no trains. Nothing here. Just tired."

The situation has led to migrants and refugees streaming into Croatia, with some breaching police lines and running into the countryside. Croatian Prime Minister Zoran Milanovic commented, "What else can we do? You are welcome in Croatia and you can pass through Croatia. But, go on. Not because we don't like you but because this is not your final destination."

Croatia has closed highways leading from Serbia, and Hungary has begun constructing a fence on its border with Croatia, in addition to fences along its borders with Serbia and Romania. The new developments come as EU member nations prepare to meet next week to discuss their response to a crisis in which over 440,000 refugees and migrants have reached Europe this year, with more than half coming from Syria, fleeing the country's civil war.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has urged Europe to establish reception centers in Greece, where over 300,000 people have made their first landfall. These centers could register and screen those arriving, according to the U.N. agency. The agency also suggested setting up similar centers in Serbia to register and relocate the new arrivals.

Furthermore, the U.N. agency called for each EU member nation to accept 40,000 refugees, in addition to the voluntary amounts they've already committed.

Title: U.S., European Diplomats Convene in Geneva for Unprecedented Nuclear Talks with Iran

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry, along with British, French, and German foreign ministers, have joined nuclear diplomacy talks with Iran in Geneva, marking an unexpected development in the ongoing negotiations to limit Iran's nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief. This sudden shift follows nearly two years of fruitless discussions.

Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif told The ███ today that a joint text is being prepared, but a "very difficult task" lies ahead. Zarif stated, "The only way that we can create confidence and sustain this process is to have balance in the first step, about each side trying to alleviate the most immediate concerns of the other side."

U.S. officials aim for an initial deal that would halt the advancement of Iran's nuclear program in exchange for "very limited" sanctions relief until a final, more comprehensive agreement is reached, possibly within six months. Iran, on the other hand, seeks a defined endgame that allows for a robust peaceful nuclear program, including uranium enrichment on Iranian soil, and all sanctions lifted.

Zarif emphasized the critical nature of the ongoing negotiations, stating, "This is going to be a critical stage today, and a critical process once we start implementing it." He added, "I believe leaders must show courage and leadership in order to take this process forward."

As the day's events began, European Union High Representative Catherine Ashton's spokesman, Michael Mann, reported that "intense" diplomacy was underway to close a deal. The arrival of the three European foreign ministers was also prompted by the news of Kerry's decision to join the talks.

However, as hopes for a nuclear deal with Iran grow, so does the opposition from critics. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has denounced a potential agreement as a "historic mistake," while hardliners in Iran have vocally opposed any accommodation with the West.

Zarif acknowledged the short timeline for all parties involved, but expressed readiness to work as long as necessary to finalize the text. He warned that new U.S. sanctions could deepen mutual mistrust and spark a fierce reaction in Tehran.

In response to the ongoing negotiations, Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has given unprecedented support to Iran's negotiating team, praising them as "sons of the revolution" to quell hard-line opposition. Meanwhile, Ayatollah Movahedi Kermani warned that any deal in Geneva would be harmful to Iran.

As the talks continue, Iran hawks in Congress are moving to speed up fresh sanctions measures, a step that the White House has fought against on Capitol Hill in recent weeks, citing the potential disruption of sensitive talks. Zarif warned that new U.S. sanctions would deepen mutual mistrust and spark a reaction in Tehran.

Zarif also highlighted the dismal record of U.S. sanctions, stating, "Now in 10 years of sanctions and intimidation, what the United States gained, what Congress gained, was 19,000 centrifuges spinning in Tehran. So that's their record, and it's a dismal record." He urged American lawmakers to be cautious not to repeat the past mistakes.

Title: Key Moments from the Final GOP Debate Before New Hampshire Primary

Article:

The final Republican debate before Tuesday's New Hampshire primary saw several key moments, with candidates taking the stage being one of the first. However, the entrance of Ben Carson proved more complicated than usual. Carson initially refused to walk out to his podium, allowing Ted Cruz to go out first. Donald Trump then stood beside Carson instead of walking out himself, and Jeb Bush walked past them as he took the stage.

Another notable moment came when New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie took shots at Sen. Marco Rubio. In a heated exchange, Christie criticized Rubio's pattern of missing votes in the Senate, a criticism that has been a recurring theme in the nomination contest. Rubio, in response, repeatedly used a line attacking President Obama's policies.

Marco Rubio's repeated use of the same line drew attention, with Christie referring to it as a "memorized 25-second speech." Rubio's line was a recurring theme throughout the debate, and Christie called him out on it.

The debate also saw a discussion on ISIS and foreign policy, during which moderator David Muir asked Sen. Ted Cruz whether waterboarding is torture. Cruz responded that it is not torture under the definition of torture, but he was ambiguous when asked if he would bring the practice back as president.

Donald Trump was more forceful in his response, stating that he would bring back waterboarding and "a hell of a lot worse than waterboarding." Jeb Bush seemed to rule out the practice, instead suggesting the need to expand intelligence capabilities.

Rubio was asked directly if waterboarding is torture, but he did not directly answer the question. Instead, he reiterated that he did not want to give away to the U.S.'s enemies what he would want to do.

Towards the end of the debate, Cruz found himself on the defensive, answering questions about his comments on Donald Trump's temperament and the controversial campaign messages his team sent out on the night of the Iowa caucuses. Cruz apologized to Ben Carson for the incident, with Carson earlier describing it as indicative of Cruz's "DC values."

Overall, the debate saw heated exchanges, repeated lines, and defensive moments, as the candidates vied for votes in the upcoming New Hampshire primary.

Title: Pentagon to Maintain Current Transgender Troop Policy Pending Presidential Direction

Article:

In a letter to the military on Thursday, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General Joseph Dunford announced that the Pentagon would not implement a ban on transgender troops until the President's direction has been received by the Secretary of Defense and implementation guidance has been issued. Until that point, there will be no modifications to the current policy, and the military will continue to treat all personnel with respect.

Currently, approximately 15,000 transgender troops are serving openly in the United States military. In June of 2016, then-Secretary of Defense Ash Carter announced that already-serving transgender troops could come out without fear of discharge and established a plan to let openly transgender people enroll in the military within one year. However, on Wednesday morning, President Trump declared on Twitter that "the United States Government will not accept or allow" transgender individuals "to serve in any capacity in the U.S. Military." Trump's proclamation raised the real possibility that the thousands of transgender troops in uniform might be purged.

Trump made his announcement without consulting the Pentagon, reportedly not even discussing the issue with his Secretary of Defense, James Mattis, who has strongly supported open transgender service in the past. Trump's sudden decision threatened to jettison years of careful planning and preparation on the part of the military. It also left military leaders in a lurch, caught between the president's tweets and formal policy. The Navy has clarified that, at least for now, transgender troops may still serve and receive transition-related medical care; Dunford's letter makes clear that remains official policy in every branch of the armed forces.

Dunford's careful wording indicates real discomfort with Trump's declaration. By writing that "we will continue to treat all of our personnel with respect," Dunford strongly implies that Trump's policy would entail treating service members with disrespect. His follow-up—"As importantly, given the current fight and the challenges we face, we will all remain focused on accomplishing our assigned missions"—suggests that Trump's tweets are a distraction.

The Pentagon is not defying Trump. However, it is signaling its discomfort, and perhaps even irritation, with his abrupt attack on transgender individuals who simply want to serve their country in uniform. Mattis will soon have to decide whether to escalate this discomfort into concrete pushback.

Title: Bipartisan Unity in Washington: Focus on Foreign Issues Over Domestic Concerns

Article:

A recent article on the Politico website has highlighted a peculiar trend in Washington, D.C.: the seemingly effortless unification of politicians from both parties over foreign issues, while domestic concerns remain unaddressed. The article, titled "Trump unites the GOP — against him," discusses the ongoing disagreements within the Republican Party regarding President Trump's decision to withdraw troops from Syria.

The article points out that the President's decision to disengage from foreign conflicts, including the Syrian civil war, has sparked a wave of opposition from both Democrats and Republicans. This opposition has led to the drafting of bipartisan legislation, a rare occurrence in recent years, as politicians have not been able to achieve such unity for the benefit of American citizens.

One such bill, reportedly enjoying widespread support in Congress, aims to support the Kurds, a group of people from Syria. The article notes that this bill is said to be "veto-proof," implying that it has garnered such significant support that it would likely bypass a potential presidential veto.

The article also mentions the lack of similar unity for American soldiers and their needs. For instance, the USMCA trade agreement, which has the support of both parties and thousands of family farmers across the United States, remains stalled due to concerns about President Trump receiving credit for its approval.

The article concludes with quotes from various politicians expressing concern for the Kurds and the potential consequences of the troop withdrawal. However, it is important to note that the Kurds are not American soldiers, and the conflict in Syria is a civil war, not an American war.

The article raises questions about the priorities of politicians in Washington, D.C., and the focus on foreign issues over domestic concerns. It is unclear why politicians seem to unite more easily for foreign issues, while issues affecting American citizens, such as the USMCA trade agreement, remain unaddressed.

Title: Hillary Clinton Gains Access to Ready for Hillary Email List for Fundraising and Organizing

Article:

Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign has obtained access to the full Ready for Hillary email list, a significant data resource that is expected to bolster the Democratic front-runner's fundraising and organizing efforts. The campaign gained entry to the independent super PAC's list through a swap with another independent group, according to a Democrat with knowledge of the list. The source declined to identify the other group.

The list, containing nearly 4 million names, was primarily created by Ready for Hillary over the past two years to serve as a plug-and-play list of supporter names with contact information. For the first six weeks of Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign, this data trove was unavailable due to legal reviews regarding the options available to the campaign. The campaign could either trade an old list for the new list or rent "a la carte" pieces of the list, such as names of volunteers in Iowa before a campaign stop there. However, the campaign eventually decided it was easier to have access to the entire list.

Tracy Sefl, a Democratic strategist who served as a senior adviser to the independent super PAC before it shut down, stated, "I could offer about 4 million reasons why the Ready for Hillary list is an important resource."

To illustrate the importance of the list, consider the recent experience of Lynette Hull, a 17-year-old high school student from Las Vegas who was one of the first interns to sign up with the campaign after Clinton announced her presidential bid. Hull was tasked with phone-banking, working through an old database of Clinton supporters to sign up new volunteers. However, she found the work time-consuming and unproductive, with many contacts either not answering or being too old to volunteer.

There is some overlap between the Ready for Hillary list and the campaign's own list of supporters. When Clinton officially announced her presidential bid six weeks ago, Ready For Hillary emailed its list six times, encouraging them to sign up with the official campaign. Clinton staffers have also been signing up new supporters in the early states on their own. A Clinton campaign spokesman declined to comment for this report.

Title: San Francisco's Ongoing Debate on Bans and Subsidies: A Look at Recent Policies

Article:

San Francisco, a progressive city known for its tech industry and environmental initiatives, has been in the news recently for its controversial policies on banning certain items and subsidizing others.

In a surprising turn of events, two San Francisco supervisors proposed a ban on company cafeterias offering free food and drink to employees. This proposal aims to support local restaurants that are reportedly losing business due to in-house dining options provided by tech companies. The city's tech community is known for its large, trendy cafeterias, which offer employees a convenient dining option while they work.

In a different context, San Francisco made headlines for its ban on plastic straws, joining a list of other progressive cities such as Seattle, Malibu, Santa Cruz, and Santa Barbara. The city's ban on straws is part of an effort to reduce plastic waste in the ocean. However, critics argue that plastic straws account for a small percentage of ocean waste and that the ban may have unintended consequences, such as increased use of other plastic products.

Another significant policy change in San Francisco involves the city's supervisors urging the city to screen insurers for their investments in coal and tar sands. This resolution, if implemented, would make San Francisco the first U.S. municipal body to force insurance companies to stop insuring and investing in fossil fuels.

These policies highlight the ongoing debate in San Francisco and other progressive cities about the role of government in regulating businesses and addressing environmental concerns. The city's approach to electric bicycles, cafeterias, plastic straws, and fossil fuel investments demonstrates the complexity and unpredictability of the "ban it or subsidize it" game that cities play in response to various social and environmental issues.

Title: White House Argues Non-Compliance with Impeachment Inquiry Without House Vote

Article:

Fox News senior judicial analyst and Fox Nation host Judge Andrew Napolitano has backed the legal argument behind a White House letter expected to be sent to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arguing that the White House does not have to comply with the Democrats' impeachment inquiry without a formal vote from the House of Representatives. The letter, which may be sent as early as Friday, reportedly dares Pelosi to put the question of a formal impeachment inquiry before the House for a vote.

On Sept. 24, Pelosi announced that House Democrats would undertake the probe without asking for the support of the members of the House. Wall Street Journal Editorial Page Editorial Board member Bill McGurn explored the issue on Fox Nation's "Deep Dive," stating, "If we're hearing how serious impeachment is—what does it say for Mrs. Pelosi to do this in a way that's without precedent? It's just a decree on her part."

However, Pelosi's decision carries other serious implications, as explained by Judge Napolitano, host of Fox Nation's "Liberty File with Judge Napolitano." The White House letter will argue that the White House is not required to comply with the Democrats' investigation because Pelosi has not codified the probe with a formal vote on the House floor.

Judge Napolitano's remarks were recorded before Fox News confirmed that the White House planned to send this letter, but his legal analysis finds that the White House's argument has merit. He explained that Speaker Pelosi is not required to put the question of an impeachment inquiry up for a vote, but if she did, and if it was approved by a majority of House members, then her inquiry would be strengthened.

"Mrs. Pelosi is correct that the Constitution does not require a full House vote, before the House begins an impeachment inquiry, but when it does so… without the full House vote it does so based on federal law… that authority comes from statutes, not the Constitution. That's very significant. When an authority comes from a statute, there are other statutes that can contradict it," the judge said.

He further explained that if Pelosi put the question of an impeachment inquiry up for a vote and a majority of House members approve it, that changes the game. "If… the House of Representatives voted by majority vote to proceed with an impeachment inquiry, that changes the rules all together. There are no privileges because the House's right to impeach comes from the Constitution and the Constitution trumps… any statute that would interfere with it."

In the latest episode of "Liberty File with Judge Napolitano," the judge spoke with two Republicans mounting presidential primary challenges against President Trump in 2020. The judge asked them what they make of Democrats' allegations that the president violated his oath of office by asking the president of Ukraine to investigate his political opponent, former Vice President Joe Biden.

Former Massachusetts Gov. Bill Weld said he agrees with the president's critics. "The conduct that the president has engaged in is precisely the sort of conduct that the Framers were worried about and why they put the impeachment and removal power in the hands of Congress. They were worried about, number one, foreign interference... In the Oval Office, the president said that he doesn't care as much about the interference in the 2016 election, that 'everybody does it.' There couldn't be a more clear instance of inviting foreign interference. And of course, the Ukraine call goes right into the same thing."

To see more of Judge Napolitano's analysis and the full episode of the latest edition of "Liberty File with Judge Napolitano," go to Fox Nation and sign up today. Fox Nation programs are viewable on-demand and from your mobile device app, but only for Fox Nation subscribers. Go to Fox Nation to start a free trial and watch the extensive library from Tomi Lahren, Pete Hegseth, Abby Hornacek, Laura Ingraham, Ainsley Earhardt, Greg Gutfeld, Judge Andrew Napolitano, and many more of your favorite Fox News personalities.

Title: Jussie Smollett Files Counterclaim Against Chicago, Police, and Brothers Involved in Alleged Hate Crime

Article:

Actor Jussie Smollett has filed a counterclaim against the city of Chicago, multiple police officers, two brothers, and the Chicago Police Department in response to a lawsuit filed by the city seeking to recover $130,106 from an investigation into a purported hate crime that occurred in late January.

Smollett, who was initially charged with 16 counts of making false statements to police, pleaded not guilty to the charges and maintained that he was a victim of a racist and homophobic attack. However, the city later determined that the alleged attack was a hoax.

Smollett's counterclaim, reported by the Chicago Sun-Times, alleges "malicious prosecution" and claims that the actor suffered "humiliation, mental anguish, and extreme emotional distress" as a result. The counterclaim was filed in response to the city's lawsuit, which was filed in August. At that time, Smollett requested that the city's lawsuit be thrown out, stating that he could not have known what the police investigation would cost.

As of August, Smollett's team still insisted that it had evidence that the hate crime hoax was real. The counterclaim names the city, the Chicago Police Department, Detectives Michael Theis and Edward Wodnicki, Supt. Eddie Johnson, and the two brothers involved in the alleged attack, Abimiola and Olabinjo Osundairo.

The counterclaim states that the proceedings against Smollett were terminated in his favor and "in a manner which indicates his innocence because all 16 counts of the criminal indictment were dismissed two and a half weeks after the indictment was filed." The claim also insists that the city of Chicago cannot recover investigation costs from Smollett because it already accepted the $10,000 fine from him "as payment in full in connection with the dismissal of the charges against him."

Further details about the case and its background can be found here.

Title: Google, Facebook, and Twitter Accused of Discrimination and Censorship Against Conservatives

Article:

A class-action lawsuit filed by former Google engineer James Damore and other right-of-center Google employees alleges a culture of censorship and discrimination within the tech giant. The lawsuit claims that Google illegally discriminates against white male employees as part of the company's diversity efforts, with managers openly discussing blacklists to sabotage promotions, performance reviews, and employment opportunities for those with conservative viewpoints.

The lawsuit, which was filed in 2018, states that Google employees are pressured to undergo one-sided "Bias Busting" re-education sessions focusing on white male privilege, and employees risk their careers by speaking out against progressive orthodoxy. Internal messages included in the lawsuit reveal employees openly conspiring against Damore after he shared a memo criticizing the company's diversity policies and calling for more tolerance of conservative viewpoints.

Google's new fact-checkers, as revealed by The Daily Caller on Tuesday, are reportedly almost exclusively devoted to policing right-of-center media outlets, with the company allegedly wrongfully attributing false statements to TheDC. Left-of-center outlets received no such policing from Google, which has previously censored content that doesn't align with its political goals.

The lawsuit is not the only instance of alleged discrimination and censorship against conservatives in the tech industry. Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube (which is owned by Google) have all exhibited similar patterns of behavior. Facebook regularly buried conservative viewpoints from its trending topics section, several former employees told Gizmodo. YouTube and Google have targeted conservative and independent video channels for censorship and demonetization. Both Facebook and Google empowered left-wing fact-checkers to discredit conservative voices on behalf of the companies, with little oversight. Twitter buried tweets damaging to the Clinton campaign and censors conservatives but allowed racist death threats against Trump FCC chairman Ajit Pai.

Conservatives face discrimination, censorship, and even violence when left-wing authoritarians run a college campus. But what happens when left-wing authoritarians run the most powerful companies in the world? The lawsuit against Google is ongoing, and the tech industry's handling of conservative viewpoints remains a contentious issue.

Title: TSA Faces Security Failures at Major U.S. Airports as Undercover Tests Reveal 95% Success Rate for Mock Explosives and Banned Weapons

Article:

An internal investigation by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has uncovered security lapses at numerous major U.S. airports, with undercover investigators successfully smuggling mock explosives or prohibited weapons through security checkpoints in 95% of trials, according to a report by ███. The tests were conducted by Homeland Security Red Teams, who pose as passengers with the intention of bypassing security measures.

According to sources briefed on the results of a recent Homeland Security Inspector General's report, TSA agents failed 67 out of 70 tests, allowing Red Team members to surreptitiously transport potential weapons through checkpoints. In one instance, an undercover agent triggered a magnetometer alarm but was not detected after a follow-on pat-down, despite a concealed fake explosive device taped to their back.

The exact timeframe for the testing has not been disclosed, other than it concluded recently. Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson reportedly sought a detailed briefing on the findings last week at TSA headquarters in Arlington, Virginia. U.S. officials have stated that changes have already been implemented at airports to address the identified vulnerabilities.

"Upon learning the initial findings of the Office of Inspector General's report, Secretary Johnson immediately directed TSA to implement a series of actions, several of which are now in place, to address the issues raised in the report," the Department of Homeland Security said in a written statement to ███.

Homeland security officials maintain that security at the nation's airports remains strong, with multiple layers of security including bomb-sniffing dogs and various technologies. However, the officials who spoke to ███ acknowledged the disappointing results of the latest tests.

This is not the first time the TSA has struggled to detect Red Team agents. A similar incident occurred in 2013, when an undercover investigator with a fake bomb concealed on their person passed through a metal detector, underwent a pat-down at New Jersey's Newark Liberty Airport, and was never apprehended.

At the time, the TSA stated that Red Team tests took place weekly across the United States and were designed to "push the boundaries of our people, processes, and technology." In a 2013 blog post, a TSA official wrote, "Our testers often make these covert tests as difficult as possible."

In a 2013 hearing on Capitol Hill, then-TSA administrator John Pistole described the Red Team as "super terrorists," who are adept at exploiting the TSA's weaknesses. "Testers know exactly what our protocols are. They can create and devise and conceal items that... not even the best terrorists would be able to do," Pistole told lawmakers at a House hearing.

More recently, the DHS inspector general's office completed a series of undercover tests targeting checked baggage screening at airports nationwide. That review found "vulnerabilities" throughout the system, attributing them to human error and technological failures, according to a three-paragraph summary of the review released in September. Additionally, the review determined that despite spending $540 million on checked baggage screening equipment and an additional $11 million for training since a previous review in 2009, the TSA failed to make any noticeable improvements in that time.

Title: Twitter Agrees to Remove Racist Tweets in Response to French Legal Threat

Article:

In a significant development, Twitter has agreed to remove racist and hateful tweets following a threat of legal action from a French organization. The social media giant has historically resisted efforts to police its content, but hate speech is illegal in many European countries, and anti-hate groups there are grappling with how to deal with the challenge of social media.

The incident that led to this decision began on October 10, when a hashtag #unbonjuif, or "a good Jew," prompted a flood of anti-Semitic tweets. The influx of hateful messages continued for several days.

Elie Petit, Vice President of the French Union of Jewish Students, explains the situation from the Paris office. He demonstrates how it all started on October 10. The tweets, he says, were not "abuse content" as Twitter claimed, but rather calls for the murder of Jews, which is a crime in France.

Many European countries have strict laws against hate speech targeted at specific groups. These laws evolved in the aftermath of the Holocaust, a result of years of Nazi hate propaganda.

On a conference call with Twitter executives in California, Petit and his colleagues tried to explain the French perspective, but they claim Twitter refused to delete the tweets, insisting that such demands must come from national authorities or police. The Jewish students prepared to file a lawsuit, but on Friday, Twitter reversed its decision, agreeing to erase the offensive tweets.

Manuel Diaz, whose company, Emakina, advises corporations on how to adapt to the digital era, comments on the situation. He is adamantly against controls on free speech, but he argues that, given Twitter's global status, it must take responsibility for its content.

"The content spread through Twitter has to respect the different local laws of the different countries where they are accessible," Diaz says. This, he notes, is not an easy task for a global company.

Twitter's decision in France came a day after the company complied with German law and blocked an account of a neo-Nazi group. However, digital expert Diaz argues that Twitter must react even faster if it wants to succeed in the international media market.

"Waiting for the French state or the French police department to do something, well, the buzz is already out and it's too late," he says. "If they are not able to monitor a buzz and take some decisions very quickly, I would be very disappointed."

Diaz expresses his disappointment in what he considers the best real-time media tool in the world. He suggests that Twitter should not censor but should build global monitoring teams to make quick decisions in cases like the French one. If Twitter can detect and quickly suspend fake accounts, as it has done in the past, then it can easily suspend tweets that do not respect local laws.

Title: Arrested Man Admits No Intention to Harm in Pizzeria Incident, Believes in "Pizzagate" Conspiracy

Article:

Edgar Welch, the man arrested on Sunday for discharging a military-style rifle inside the Washington, D.C. pizzeria Comet Ping Pong, told The New York Times via video chat on Wednesday that he drove up from North Carolina to investigate the restaurant due to its association with the "Pizzagate" conspiracy theory. Welch, a 28-year-old father of two, stated that he had no intention of firing a shot and expressed regret for his actions.

Welch claimed that he was led to believe that Comet Ping Pong was the center of a child sex ring run by associates of Hillary Clinton, but admitted that the information he received was not 100% accurate. He stated that just because no children were found inside the pizzeria, it does not mean that the "Pizzagate" pedophile ring does not exist.

Welch acknowledged that he does not believe in conspiracy theories but listens to Alex Jones, who regularly spreads conspiracy theories on his radio show and websites. He described Jones as "a bit eccentric" and noted that while Jones touches on some viable issues, he goes off the deep end on some things.

The "Pizzagate" myth, built through creative interpretations of emails hacked from John Podesta and released by WikiLeaks to harm Clinton's presidential campaign, is spreading beyond Washington, D.C., and has even reached Austin, Texas, where the pizzeria East Side Pies has become embroiled in the false story.

The owners of East Side Pies became aware of "Pizzagate" through strange comments on the restaurant's Facebook page, then were pointed to Reddit threads linking their pizzeria to the fake story.
