The Austin American-Statesman's Matthew Odam outlines several of the red herrings in the online posts, including wild and baseless accusations about East Side Pies, interpretations of the restaurant's logo as a symbol of the "Illuminati," questions about photos of pizza-eating children on East Side Pies' Facebook account, inferences that a picture of staffers with former Austin Mayor Lee Leffingwell was proof of nefarious political ties, and claims that co-owner Michael Freid, an alumnus of the Culinary Institute of America, had "connections to the CIA."

Owen Shroyer, who makes videos for Alex Jones' Infowars and hosts his own podcast, posted a 2.5-hour video detailing his own investigation of East Side Pies on Saturday. Austin police and the FBI are currently investigating the threats and vandalism of a pizza delivery truck.

Title: Trump Voters Remain Loyal Despite Media Criticism and Political Challenges

Article:

President Donald Trump's voters remain steadfast in their support for the president, despite criticism from the national media, neighbors, and political opposition. These voters attribute their continued support to their frustration with the resistance from Democrats and the stalled Trump agenda due to internal squabbles within the Republican party.

Kevin Madden, a Republican Party strategist, attributes this loyalty to the belief that their support for Trump is yet to be validated and that it can still yield positive results. Trump voters express less trust in the media, political elites, and other institutions that question their decision, compared to their trust in President Trump himself.

Polls, including those released around the 100-day mark of his presidency, have consistently found that stories of Trump voters abandoning their support are rare. Instead, most Trump supporters view him as a powerful leader and celebrate his crusade against political correctness and his combative approach to the news media.

Trump voters have forgiven him for backing off some campaign promises, attributing it to his learning curve as a political novice. A Fox News survey showed 97 percent of Trump backers remained satisfied with their vote, while 2 percent wished they had voted differently. A Washington Post/ABC News poll found that 96 percent of Trump voters said supporting him was the right decision, and 2 percent regretted their choice.

A University of Virginia Center for Politics and Public Opinion Strategies poll showed 93 percent of Trump's backers approved of the job he was doing, compared to 52 percent for House Speaker Paul D. Ryan and 28 percent for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.

"They are more loyal [to Trump] than they are to the GOP, but they are still anti-Democrat and much more inclined to support the GOP," said Glen Bolger of Public Opinion Strategies. "There are not a whole lot of Trump voters who say, 'I am ready to defect.' That is not to say that a year from now things might be different."

Cable news networks have focused on finding Trump voters who may have fallen off the bandwagon, running stories about those who could potentially suffer under the work-in-progress healthcare bill or from his proposed budget cuts. However, this relentless negative focus is met with derision by Trump loyalists who loathe the press.

The University of Virginia survey found 88 percent of respondents agreed with Trump's assertion that the press is "the enemy of the American people." The Washington Post/ABC News poll showed that 8 in 10 Trump supporters believed news organizations regularly publish false stories.

Overall, Trump's approval rating is underwater, as the White House grapples with accusations of campaign operatives having ties to Russian officials and the recent firing of FBI Director James B. Comey, which has ignited calls for Trump's impeachment.

Democrats hope that the anti-Trump wave, coupled with Trump defections, could help them make significant gains in congressional elections next year. However, so far, anti-Trump sentiment has failed to yield results at the polls. Republicans have won two special congressional elections to maintain Republican-held districts, with the Republican candidates winning by considerably less than the double-digit margins Trump himself achieved in those districts.

"I haven't seen any evidence that his core support has faded," said Patrick Murray, director of the Monmouth University Polling Institute. "What may be more important is whether the opposition is hardening. In other words, are folks who have been saying that Trump is not really doing a great job shifting to the view that he is actually being harmful?"

Title: Democratic Party Faces Continuing Rift as Sanders Leads in Iowa Caucuses

The Democratic Party is currently experiencing a rift between its moderate and progressive wings, with criticism directed towards Iowa's use of caucuses. In the ongoing Iowa caucuses, as of the reported results, Senator Bernie Sanders leads in the popular vote with 26.3%, followed by former Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Vice President Joe Biden, and Senator Amy Klobuchar.

Sanders' lead in the popular vote is not due to support from entrenched party powers or institutional backing, but rather, he has managed to secure the lead despite lacking traditional electoral success mainstays and facing a wave of establishment attacks. The results have been less favorable for Biden, who is now facing doubts about his campaign's weak organizing effort in Iowa.

Mayor Buttigieg, who is currently in fourth place, has been a surprise contender in Iowa, and while he has a real chance of finishing first, his ability to expand his support across the country, particularly among minority voters, remains uncertain. This could impact his chances of winning the nomination.

The preliminary results from Iowa show a relatively even split between the party's progressive and moderate wings, with Sanders, Warren, and Yang accumulating 51,821 votes, while Biden, Buttigieg, and Klobuchar have 54,894 votes combined. These numbers suggest a protracted and competitive primary that could potentially lead to a contested convention.

The ongoing Iowa caucuses have sparked discussions about reform, with some calling for Iowa to switch from a caucus to a primary system. Critics argue that the current caucus system is complex, time-consuming, and not representative of the entire electorate. Some have also called for ending Iowa's first-in-the-nation status, citing the state's small population and perceived inability to manage the process effectively.

A former Democratic congressman from Iowa, however, defends the Iowa caucuses, arguing that they provide an opportunity for real voters to assess the candidates and that the state's politics are open, honest, and not governed by a kingmaker. The congressman also highlights Iowa's history of rewarding diverse candidates, such as a black American, a woman, and an openly gay former mayor.

The Iowa caucuses will continue to unfold, and the results could have significant implications for the Democratic Party and the 2020 presidential race. The rest of the primary season, including the New Hampshire and Nevada primaries, will provide further insight into the candidates' abilities to appeal to a broader electorate and secure the Democratic nomination.

Title: Obama Criticizes Romney-Ryan Medicare Plan, Citing Harvard Professor's Study

Article:

President Barack Obama renewed his criticism of the Romney-Ryan Medicare plan on Sunday, citing a study by Harvard professor David Cutler that suggests increased costs for future Medicare recipients and higher insurance company profits. The attack comes after the release of a disappointing August unemployment report last week.

At a rally in Melbourne, Florida, Obama stated, "Your costs would rise by the thousands, and the insurance companies' profits would rise by the billions." He also accused the plan by Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney and his running mate, Rep. Paul Ryan, of increasing insurance profits by $16 billion to $20 billion and of not supporting their plan to transform Medicare into a voucher system.

The president did not specify the source of the numbers, but senior campaign officials attributed them to Cutler's study. Cutler, a Harvard professor and health policy expert who served in the Clinton administration and was Obama's top health care adviser during the 2008 presidential campaign, conducted the study for the liberal Center for American Progress Action Fund.

The Romney campaign responded by labeling Cutler an "Obamacare drafter" and stating that the president's attacks this weekend were a sign of desperation. Campaign spokesman Ryan Williams said, "Only one candidate in this race has robbed today's Medicare of $716 billion to pay for Obamacare – Barack Obama."

Romney's plan aims to control Medicare costs by providing retirees with voucher-like government payments that can be used to purchase either traditional Medicare or private health insurance. However, Cutler argues that older Americans would have to pay more out-of-pocket to cover rising healthcare costs under this plan.

Obama's aides believe they have forced Romney to shift his focus from the sluggish economy following Ryan's selection as the running mate. Romney and Ryan have countered by arguing that Obama planned to cut hundreds of billions of dollars in Medicare spending over 10 years to fund his healthcare plan.

The political impact of this debate is unclear. However, Republican analysts suggest that Romney's focus on Medicare has diverted attention from the economy, which they consider crucial for his election chances, especially after a weak jobs report showing limited job growth and more unemployed people choosing not to seek work.

Vice President Joe Biden, campaigning in Ohio on Saturday, referred to the Romney-Ryan plan as "Vouchercare." Biden said the plan would require "Mom" to find the best insurance deal in the market, with the possibility of needing to borrow money to cover costs exceeding the voucher amount.

Much of Cutler's data is based on studies by the independent Congressional Budget Office, which has projected even higher costs for future retirees under a 2011 budget plan written by Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee. The budget agency stated that, by 2030, a typical 65-year-old would be paying two-thirds of their health costs.

Romney and Ryan are currently off the campaign trail, but both taped appearances for Sunday talk shows.

Title: Presidential Candidates Engage in Comedy Routine at New York Charity Event

Article:

In a departure from the contentious political debates, President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney participated in a comedy routine at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner in New York on Thursday. The event, organized by the Catholic Archdiocese of New York to benefit needy children, followed the presidential contenders' debate at Hofstra University two days prior.

During the light-hearted event, the candidates exchanged humorous jabs on topics such as the deficit, media bias, Romney's wealth, and Big Bird. The evening served as a respite from the bruising campaign, with the event expected to raise $5 million for Catholic charities.

Romney, a teetotaling Mormon, joked about the media's portrayal of his campaign, stating, "People seem to be very curious about how to prepare — first refrain from alcohol for 65 years, then get the biggest straw man and mercilessly attack it." He also made light of the controversy surrounding his statement to cut funding for public broadcasting, saying, "Big Bird did not even see it coming."

Obama poked fun at his own performance in the first debate, which took place on his and first lady Michelle Obama's 20th anniversary. He joked, "I particularly want to apologize to Chris Matthews. Four years ago, [he] gave him a thrill up his leg; this time I gave him a stroke."

The candidates also took jabs at their respective running mates, with Romney making light of Vice President Joe Biden's performance in his debate against Paul Ryan, stating, "I was hoping Biden would be along, because he'll laugh at anything."

Romney, dressed in a tuxedo, commented on the formality of the event, saying, "It's nice to finally relax and wear what Ann and I wear around the house." He also made a jab at Obama, saying, "You have to wonder what he's thinking. So little time, so much to redistribute."

Obama, in turn, took a jab at Romney's wealth, stating, "Earlier today I went shopping at some stores in Midtown. I understand Governor Romney went shopping for some stores in Midtown."

The candidates will resume their debates on Monday in South Florida for their third and final debate, with the focus on foreign policy. The event was overseen by Cardinal Timothy Dolan, president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops.

Title: Americans' Skepticism Towards Government Intervention, Yet Dependence in Times of Crisis

Article:

Americans, in general, exhibit a skepticism towards excessive government intervention, with a majority preferring less government involvement, according to Gallup's three-decade-long data. However, this skepticism wanes during national crises, as people increasingly rely on the government to address issues that individuals and private industries cannot handle.

Currently, the number of Americans desiring government intervention to solve the country's problems is almost on par with those who believe the government is already doing too much. This is one of those times when government intervention is crucial, as it fills the gaps left by individuals and private sectors during hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, economic, and health crises.

President Trump has faced criticism for his handling of information regarding the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. In an attempt to mitigate potential panic and fear, Trump initially downplayed the severity of the virus, and his messages have been inconsistent. This has led to a lack of trust in his statements about the coronavirus, according to the latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll.

Conversely, Americans trust the information provided by their local officials and government health experts regarding the virus. The White House press briefings were absent over the weekend, with Trump tweeting that they are not worth the time and effort. A briefing scheduled for Monday evening was later removed from the White House schedule.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi criticized Trump's efforts to withhold funding from the World Health Organization and other reported steps to sideline the global health agency. Meanwhile, two former federal health officials are spearheading a call for a $46 billion public health investment in the next coronavirus aid package to safely reopen the economy.

Researchers suggest that one standard for safely easing social distancing measures is 1 new infection per million people in a given state. They estimate that states adhering to this level of transmission should be able to control outbreaks even after people start mingling again, though they stress that large gatherings should still be limited.

The World Health Organization stated that there is currently no evidence that recovered COVID-19 patients are immune to a second infection. New York City's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported an uptick in poison control calls following Trump's disinfectant comments, with 30 cases in an 18-hour period compared to 13 cases during the same time frame last year.

As the COVID-19 pandemic dominates the political conversation, Americans' ambivalence towards science and experts is likely to come to the forefront.

Title: American Jewish Congregations Divided Over United Nations' Palestine Vote

Article:

A group of American Jewish congregations, including those from different branches of Judaism, have expressed varying opinions regarding the United Nations' recent vote recognizing Palestine as a non-member observer state. While some congregants have praised the move as a bold and courageous stand, others have expressed shock and dismay over the public expression of support for Palestine.

Gil Kulick, a congregant, commended the congregations for their strong and unequivocal stance, stating, "I thought it was very courageous of them. I think, as of late, there has been a reluctance to speak out on this issue, and that's why I was really delighted that they chose to take a strong stand."

However, Eve Birnbaum, a member of a congregation for about 15 years, expressed her dismay over the rabbis' e-mail, stating, "I am very dismayed, as a longstanding member of the synagogue, that the rabbis and the board would take a position that is contrary to what many members believe, contrary to the peace process."

The rabbis at B'nai Jeshurun, a synagogue in New York City, did not respond to requests for comment on the e-mail. The gist of the e-mail, which expressed cautious optimism about Palestine's new status and the potential for a two-state solution, was not surprising to congregants, but its tone and timing were jarring to some.

The debate over the United Nations' Palestine vote and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has been a long-standing and often contentious issue within the American Jewish community. Samuel Norich, the publisher of The Forward, a Jewish affairs weekly based in New York, stated, "At most times we impose a kind of discipline upon ourselves—nobody imposes it on us—particularly on a matter that the Israeli government has asked for unanimous support from the Jewish community."

The rabbis' e-mail is not the only instance of public criticism of Israeli government policies within the American Jewish community. Rabbi Sharon Brous of Los Angeles sent an e-mail to her congregants during the Gaza conflict stating, "The Palestinian people are also children of God, whose suffering is real and undeniable." This statement was met with criticism from Rabbi Daniel Gordis, who attacked the sentiment in a column for The Times of Israel.

The debate over the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the appropriate level of criticism of Israeli government policies within the American Jewish community continues to be a contentious issue. Rabbi David Ingber of Romemu, another liberal synagogue on the Upper West Side, stated, "This is the constant question among liberal, progressive Jews: what does it mean to support Israel? Does it mean never criticizing Israel?"

Title: Charleston Church Shooting Suspect Identified as Dylann Roof, Former Friend Says He Was Avowed Racist

Article:

A former friend who reconnected with the man accused of the shooting massacre at a historic black church in Charleston, South Carolina, said Dylann Roof had become an avowed racist. Joey Meek reconnected with Roof a few weeks ago and said that while they got drunk together on vodka, Roof began complaining that "blacks were taking over the world" and that "someone needed to do something about it for the white race."

Roof, 21, is accused of fatally shooting nine people during a Bible study at The Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston on Wednesday night, ripping out a piece of South Carolina's civic heart and adding to the ever-growing list of America's racial casualties. Police in Charleston charged Roof with nine counts of murder as well as possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.

Meek called the FBI after recognizing Roof in the surveillance footage, down to the stained sweatshirt he wore while playing Xbox videogames in Meek's home the morning of the attack. "I didn't think it was him. I knew it was him," Meek told The Associated Press after being interviewed by investigators.

According to a CBS News report, a classmate reportedly described Roof as a "pill popper" who "told racist jokes." Those who knew Roof say they remember him talking about a scheme, fueled by his segregationist ideals. Meek said Roof told him he wanted "to start a civil war."

Meek said during their reunion a few weeks ago, Roof told him that he had used birthday money from his parents to buy a.45-caliber Glock pistol and that he had "a plan" that was six months in the making. He did not say what the plan was, but Meek said it scared him enough that he took the gun out of Roof's car and hid it in his house until the next day.

Roof made incriminating statements indicating he was involved in the shooting, according to unnamed sources. Police captured Roof in Shelby, North Carolina, after a motorist spotted him at a traffic light on her way to work. His apprehension ended an intense, hours-long manhunt.

Roof waived extradition and was back in Charleston on Thursday night, authorities said, with a bond hearing pending. On Friday, South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley told NBC's "Today" show the shooter should get the death penalty. "We will absolutely want him to have the death penalty," Haley said.

Charleston officials announced a prayer vigil for Friday evening. The city's mayor described the shooting at the church as an act of "pure, pure concentrated evil." The victims included a state senator who doubled as the church's minister, three other pastors, a regional library manager, a high school coach and speech therapist, a government administrator, a college enrollment counselor, and a recent college graduate - six women and three men who felt called to open their church to all.

President Barack Obama called the tragedy yet another example of damage wreaked in America by guns. NAACP President and CEO Cornell William Brooks said, "There is no greater coward than a criminal who enters a house of God and slaughters innocent people." Others bemoaned the loss to a church that has served as a bastion of black power for 200 years, despite efforts by white supremacists to wipe it out.

"Of all cities, in Charleston, to have a horrible, hateful person go into the church and kill people there to pray and worship with each other is something that is beyond any comprehension and is not explained," said Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. "We are going to put our arms around that church and that church family."

Gov. Haley: After S.C. church shooting suspect was in custody, community could start to heal

Surveillance video showed the gunman entering the church Wednesday night, and a Snapchat video reportedly taken by one of the few survivors of the attack shows a small group of people gathered together inside the church. All of them are black except for one man.

Charleston County Coroner Rae Wilson said he initially did not appear threatening. "The suspect entered the group and was accepted by them, as they believed that he wanted to join them in this Bible study," she said. Then, "he became very aggressive and violent."

It's not clear whether Roof had any connection to the 16 white supremacist organizations operating in South Carolina, but he appears to be a "disaffected white supremacist," based on his Facebook page, said Richard Cohen, president of the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Alabama.

On his Facebook page, Roof displayed the flags of defeated white-ruled regimes, posing with a Confederate flags plate on his car and wearing a jacket with stitched-on flag patches from apartheid-era South Africa and Rhodesia, which is now black-led Zimbabwe.

Roof was arrested in February at a mall in Columbia, South Carolina - charged with felony drug possession. He was wearing all black and suspicious employees called police. They found Roof with strips of the drug suboxone - often abused, but typically used to treat opiate addiction. The mall banned him from the premises but he was arrested for trespassing there in April.

Spilling blood inside a black church - especially "Mother Emanuel," founded in 1816 - evoked painful memories nationwide, a reminder that black churches so often have been the targets of racist violence. A church founder, Denmark Vesey, was hanged after trying to organize a slave revolt in 1822, and white landowners burned the church in revenge, leaving parishioners to worship underground until after the Civil War. The congregation rebuilt and grew stronger, eventually winning campaigns for voting rights and political representation.

Its lead pastor, state Sen. Clementa Pinckney - among the dead - recalled his church's history in a 2013 sermon, saying "we do not see ourselves as just a place where we come to worship, but as a beacon and as a bearer of the culture."

"What the church is all about," Pinckney said, "is the 'freedom to be fully what God intends us to be and have equality in the sight of God. And sometimes you got to make noise to do that. Sometimes you may have to die like Denmark Vesey to do that.'"

Pinckney, 41, was a married father of two and a Democrat who spent 19 years in the South Carolina legislature after he was first elected at 23, becoming the youngest member of the House. The other victims were Cynthia Hurd, 54; Tywanza Sanders, 26; Myra Thompson, 59; Ethel Lance, 70; Susie Jackson, 87; and the reverends DePayne Middleton Doctor, 49; Sharonda Singleton, 45; and Daniel Simmons Sr., 74.

U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch said the attack would be investigated as a hate crime.

Title: FCC Proposes to Repeal Net Neutrality Rules, Shifting Digital Landscape

Article:

The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) announced plans on Tuesday to repeal landmark 2015 rules known as net neutrality, a move that could reshape the digital landscape. The proposal, led by FCC Chairman Ajit Pai, a Republican appointed by President Donald Trump, is set to be voted on at a Dec. 14 meeting.

The net neutrality rules, championed by former Democratic President Barack Obama, prohibited internet service providers from blocking or slowing down access to content or charging consumers more for certain content. The rules aimed to ensure a free and open internet, give consumers equal access to web content, and prevent broadband service providers from favoring their own content.

The repeal of these rules would grant internet service providers such as AT&T Inc, Comcast Corp, and Verizon Communications Inc sweeping powers to decide what web content consumers can access and at what price. This move is a victory for these large internet service providers, which opposed the rules, and a setback for companies like Google parent Alphabet Inc and Facebook Inc, which urged Pai not to rescind the rules. Netflix expressed opposition to the measure on Tuesday, stating it aims to "roll back these core protections."

With three Republican and two Democratic commissioners, the move is all but certain to be approved. Trump, a Republican, has expressed opposition to net neutrality, calling it a "power grab" by Obama in 2014. The White House did not immediately comment Tuesday.

Pai's proposal would prevent state and local governments from creating their own net neutrality rules, as internet service is considered an interstate service. This preemption is likely to handcuff Democratic-governed states and localities that could have considered their own plans to protect consumers' equal access to internet content.

"The FCC will no longer be in the business of micromanaging business models and preemptively prohibiting services and applications and products that could be pro-competitive," Pai said in an interview. He added that the Obama administration had sought to pick winners and losers and exercised "heavy-handed" regulation of the internet.

"We should simply set rules of the road that let companies of all kinds in every sector compete and let consumers decide who wins and loses," Pai added.

Tom Wheeler, who headed the FCC under Obama and advocated for the net neutrality rules, called the planned repeal "a shameful sham and sellout." AT&T, Comcast, and Verizon have stated that repealing the rules could lead to billions of dollars in additional broadband investment and eliminate the possibility that a future presidential administration could regulate internet pricing.

Comcast stated that it would "not block, throttle, or discriminate against lawful content." Verizon said it believed the FCC "will reinstate a framework that protects consumers' access to the open internet, without forcing them to bear the heavy costs from unnecessary regulation."

The Internet Association, representing major technology firms including Alphabet and Facebook, stated that Pai's proposal "represents the end of net neutrality as we know it and defies the will of millions of Americans." The FCC received more than 22 million comments, and New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman disclosed Tuesday he has been investigating for more than six months in a bid to learn who was behind the filing of false comments.

A U.S. appeals court last year upheld the legality of the net neutrality regulations, which were challenged in a lawsuit led by telecommunications industry trade association US Telecom. The group praised Pai's decision to remove "antiquated, restrictive regulations" to "pave the way for broadband network investment, expansion, and upgrades."

The FCC's repeal is certain to draw a legal challenge from advocates of net neutrality. Nancy Pelosi, the top U.S. House of Representatives Democrat, stated the FCC move would hurt consumers and chill competition, saying the agency "has launched an all-out assault on the entrepreneurship, innovation, and competition at the heart of the internet." The planned repeal represents the latest example of a legacy achievement of Obama being erased since Trump took office in January.

Title: U.S. Attorney Assigned by Barr to Investigate Russia Probe's Origins is "Dialed In"

Article:

The U.S. attorney assigned by Attorney General Bill Barr to investigate the origins of the Russia probe is reportedly making significant progress, according to multiple sources familiar with the matter. The attorney, John Durham, has been described as "very dialed in" and "asking all the right questions."

Recent meetings between Barr and Durham, who was in Washington, D.C. this month, have been confirmed by sources within the Justice Department to Fox News. Durham has been briefed on the "four corners" of the investigations into the FBI's use of Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrants, among other issues.

Durham's high level of engagement in the probe comes after Barr stated he has not received satisfactory answers from the intelligence community in the early stages of his review into the origins of the Russia investigation. In an interview with CBS News, Barr expressed that he has "more questions" and that some facts "do not hang together with the official explanations of what happened."

Durham is specifically reviewing the FISA warrant obtained by the FBI to surveil former Trump aide Carter Page, as well as general issues relating to surveillance during the 2016 campaign and matters flowing from the FISA process. Fox News reports that Durham would handle the prosecution of any criminal action he might uncover.

Before the 2016 midterm elections, sources tell Fox News, Republicans who controlled key House committees sought to "tee up" potential targets for future investigation. Particular attention was drawn to the apparent conflict in testimony between the co-founder of the opposition research firm Fusion GPS, Glenn Simpson, and DOJ official Bruce Ohr. Fusion GPS was retained by the Hillary Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee (DNC), which in turn hired British ex-spy Christopher Steele to write the infamous dossier that the FBI relied on in its FISA application to surveil Page.

Simpson testified to the House Intelligence Committee that he contacted Ohr about the largely discredited dossier after Thanksgiving 2016, but Ohr's records point to contact months earlier, in August. Bruce Ohr became a backchannel for Steele to the FBI in the fall of 2016 after the bureau fired the ex-spy over contacts with the media.

Last month, Republican Rep. Mark Meadows made a criminal referral for Ohr's wife, Nellie, who worked for Fusion GPS. Nellie did extensive opposition research on Trump family members and campaign aides while working for Fusion GPS, according to a transcript of her closed-door interview with Congress.

In her transcribed interview, Ms. Ohr testified she "would not have any knowledge of what [was] going on in an ongoing investigation" at DOJ and would not "have any knowledge of the Department of Justice’s investigations on Russia." Ms. Ohr also denied she shared her research on Russian organized crime and Donald Trump with individuals outside of Fusion GPS (her employer), her husband, DOJ attorney Bruce Ohr, and Christopher Steele.

However, documents reviewed by our committees raise concerns that Ms. Ohr not only had knowledge of an ongoing DOJ investigation, but that she shared information and research on Russian organized crime to assist DOJ, in direct contradiction with her testimony.

Title: Congressman Calls for Investigation into Cape Wind Project Amid Allegations of Political Pressure

Article:

Representative Cliff Stearns (R-Fla) has called for a congressional investigation into the nation's first offshore wind farm, Cape Wind, following the release of emails suggesting political pressure was applied to expedite the project's approval. Audra Parker, president of the Alliance to Protect Nantucket Sound, an organization opposing the wind farm's development, claims to have obtained documents that allegedly show the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) fast-tracked the project despite safety concerns for local aviation.

Parker asserts that the documents, obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request, reveal a pattern of political pressure and the FAA's subsequent sacrifice of aviation safety in favor of the project. An internal FAA email from 2009 acknowledges the Cape Wind project in Nantucket Sound as "highly political." A 2010 PowerPoint presentation states that the project's approval was politically motivated due to the administration's push for green energy production.

Rep. Stearns, who previously led the investigation into the failed solar panel firm Solyndra, compares the Cape Wind project to Solyndra, stating, "I think the Cape Wind project is something similar to Solyndra in the sense there's a lot of pressure from the White House."

Cape Wind spokesman Mark Rodgers maintains that the project has undergone extensive review and is confident of its approval, despite the concerns raised by opponents. The FAA is currently reviewing the project again following a federal appeals court's overturning of the agency's ruling that 130 proposed turbines posed "no hazard" to aviation.

Despite ongoing legal battles and the potential for further delays, Cape Wind aims to begin construction next year. The battle over the development, however, continues as both sides accuse politics of playing a role in the project's approval process.

Title: Lana Marks, Palm Beach Designer, Nominated as U.S. Ambassador to South Africa

Article:

Lana Marks, a luxury handbag designer known for her products made with exotic animal skins, has been nominated by President Donald Trump as the U.S. envoy to South Africa. Marks, who was born and raised in South Africa and attended the University of the Witwatersrand, has no diplomatic experience or training.

Professionally, Marks is recognized for her high-end handbags, which can sell for between $19,000 and $400,000. According to CNN, the concept for her luxury handbags was born when she could not find a bag to match the suit she planned to wear to a birthday celebration for Queen Elizabeth.

Marks' nomination has raised questions about her qualifications for the position, as she has no prior diplomatic experience. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will consider her nomination, and her past legal issues may be taken into account.

In the past, Marks has been involved in more than a dozen lawsuits in Aspen, New York, California, and South Florida. She has been accused of stiffing attorneys, accountants, landlords, and employees. In July 2015, she was evicted from her office on Worth Avenue for failing to pay $25,399 in rent and other expenses. In 2004, 2007, and 2009, the landlords for her store on Worth Avenue also filed complaints against her for failing to pay rent, although the cases were settled without eviction.

President Trump's relationship with South Africa has been controversial. Last August, Trump tweeted that he had asked Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to "closely study" the government's "large scale" land seizures and killing of white farmers, which are not actually happening anywhere but in the minds of white supremacists from whom our president apparently gets his policy ideas. With Marks' nomination, it remains to be seen how her qualifications and past legal issues will be evaluated by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Title: Biden Calls for Impeachment of President Trump, Citing Obstruction of Justice and Constitutional Violations

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden has expressed his support for the impeachment of President Donald Trump, citing obstruction of justice and violations of the Constitution. During a campaign event in Rochester, N.H., Biden stated, "With his words and his actions, President Trump has indicted himself by obstructing justice, refusing to comply with the congressional inquiry."

Biden argued that Trump's actions, such as withholding congressionally appropriated aid to Ukraine in exchange for political favors, demonstrate a disregard for the Constitution and the rule of law. He continued, "To preserve our Constitution, our democracy, our basic integrity, he should be impeached."

Biden had previously signaled his support for the House Democrats' impeachment inquiry but had refrained from taking a position on its conclusion. The investigation was triggered by a whistleblower's complaint against Trump over his pressure on the president of Ukraine to investigate Biden and his son Hunter, who served on the board of Burisma Holdings until earlier this year.

The White House released a memo summarizing Trump's July 25 phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, a conversation Trump has defended as "perfect." The call was part of a whistleblower's complaint against the president, which led to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's announcement late last month of a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump.

Since then, a flurry of developments have given added impetus to the impeachment probe. Speaking to reporters on the White House lawn last week, Trump called on China to investigate the Bidens, but the president has yet to provide evidence of any wrongdoing.

In 2016, then-Vice President Biden pressured Ukraine to remove its top prosecutor, Viktor Shokin, who had investigated Burisma. However, Shokin's investigation had been closed by the time Biden made the demand on the Ukrainian government. The European Union and the International Monetary Fund, along with several congressional Republicans, shared the Obama administration's view of Shokin as corrupt.

Biden's response to Trump's attacks over recent weeks has been criticized as slow and ineffective by some Democrats, raising unpleasant memories of the "Swift Boat" attacks by Republicans on Democratic nominee John Kerry in 2004.

In response to Trump's tweets attacking Biden, Biden's campaign manager, Kate Bedingfield, stated, "We're not going to play Donald Trump's game. We're not going to let him distract from the corruption in his own administration."

Trump tweeted, "So pathetic to see Sleepy Joe Biden, who with his son, Hunter, and to the detriment of the American Taxpayer, has ripped off at least two countries for millions of dollars, calling for my impeachment—and I did nothing wrong." Trump also tweeted, "Joe's Failing Campaign gave him no other choice!"

Biden responded, "Thanks for watching. Stop stonewalling the Congress. Honor your oath. Respect the Constitution. And speaking of taxpayers, I've released 21 years of my tax returns. You?"

Title: Romney Outlines Foreign Policy Differences with Obama, Critics Question Substance

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, outlined his foreign policy positions on Monday, emphasizing a two-state solution for Israel and Palestine, conditions on U.S. aid to Egypt, and support for Syrian opposition forces. The speech, delivered at the Virginia Military Institute, aimed to define key differences with President Obama's foreign policy.

Romney accused the Obama administration of passivity on the international stage, stating that the world is left wondering about the U.S.'s stance. He pledged that, if elected, the world would see clear and predictable behavior from the White House.

However, critics, including former Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, questioned the speech's substance, stating that it lacked specifics on how Romney would operate and understand the Arab world.

Romney emphasized "bedrock principles" toward the Middle East, stating that the U.S. must adhere to these principles to provide a stable world. He pledged to champion free trade and reverse the lack of new free-trade agreements signed during Obama's tenure.

On Iran, Romney did not specify whether he would support a pre-emptive military strike, instead stating that the U.S. must make clear to Iran that its nuclear pursuit will not be tolerated. He also called for new conditions on U.S. aid to Egypt, pushing the new regime to respect democracy and honor its peace treaty commitments with Israel.

Weeks after expressing doubts about a two-state solution for Israel and Palestine, Romney reaffirmed his commitment to a democratic, prosperous Palestinian state living peacefully with Israel. He criticized the Obama administration for failing to negotiate a peaceful resolution and for allowing the conflict to devolve into disputes at the United Nations.

Regarding Syria, Romney called for the U.S. to do more to arm opposition forces, particularly those the U.S. trusts. He argued that Iran is supplying arms to Assad's regime because it knows Assad's downfall would be a strategic defeat for Iran.

Critics argued that Romney's speech did not articulate a dramatically different vision from Obama's. Gordon Adams, an international relations professor at American University, stated that when it comes to defining exactly what Romney would do, it is the same as what Obama is already doing. Adams added that when it comes to overall U.S. foreign policy, the elusiveness of strategy in the 21st century is intense, particularly in the Middle East.

On the issue of countering Iranian nuclear ambitions, Albright stated that, short of immediate military action, Romney cannot specify what he would do differently than the president. Regarding U.S. assistance to Egypt, Albright added that the aid is already conditioned on many of the things that Romney listed, such as Egypt meeting its obligations to its peace treaty with Israel and transitioning to democracy.

Title: Constitutionality of Obamacare and Impeachment Discussion

Article:

Since its enactment in 2010, the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, has faced significant changes and controversy. Critics argue that the law has led to the cancellation of many Americans' healthcare plans and has violated President Obama's promise that individuals could keep their insurance if they liked it.

In early 2010, before signing Obamacare, President Obama acknowledged during a healthcare summit that up to nine million people might lose their coverage due to the new legislation. In September 2010, every Senate Democrat voted against a resolution aimed at allowing people to keep their healthcare plans.

In 2013, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius admitted under oath in front of Congress that end-to-end security testing was not conducted on Healthcare.gov before its launch, potentially putting the personal information of Americans at risk.

Associate Professor of Economics at St. John's University, M. Northrop Buechner, has argued in Forbes that President Obama's changes to Obamacare are unconstitutional, as the Constitution does not authorize the President to change existing laws. Buechner contends that by changing the law based on his own wishes, Obama has set a precedent that could potentially allow him to rewrite or ignore any law.

The main responsibility the Constitution assigns to the President is to faithfully execute the laws. If the President rejects this duty, as some argue Obama has done, the implications for the future of American governance are unclear.

While impeachment is unlikely with a divided Congress, Buechner's argument presents a solid case for impeachment based on the President's disregard for the Constitution. The future of American governance and the role of the President in interpreting and executing laws remains a topic of ongoing debate.

Title: Minnesota Rep. Michele Bachmann's Retirement Highlights Her Impact on Washington

Article:

Minnesota Representative Michele Bachmann's announcement on Wednesday that she will not seek a fifth term in Congress has sparked a flurry of commentary, with some on the political left mocking the former 2012 presidential candidate. However, her retirement has also provided a glimpse into Bachmann's impact on Washington.

Bachmann, who was first elected to Congress in 2006, has amassed a portfolio of missteps and fabrications during her tenure. Yet, she has also secured a place in political history by riding the Tea Party wave early and parlaying an unrepentant, cable-ready persona and House seat to national conspicuousness.

Even her detractors acknowledge that Bachmann's audacity helped open the door for conservative female candidates and new Republican Tea Party favorites, such as Texas Senator Ted Cruz and, to some extent, Florida Senator Marco Rubio. Bachmann also established herself as a fundraising juggernaut, raising nearly $15 million for her 2012 race against Democrat Jim Graves, who spent about $2.3 million in a race that was nationalized by her polarizing politics.

Conservative blogger Dan Riehl, who chose to "ignore most of the calamity, the gaffes" that have punctuated her political career, describes Bachmann as a voice against the Republican establishment, a thorn in its side. "In certain ways, she was an iconic figure—effective just because she was there... She was kicking on the door early and was isolated. You have some people benefiting from the heat she took," Riehl says.

Bachmann's national profile was not built on her effectiveness as a legislator; she was rated as a House backbencher during her time on Capitol Hill. However, she founded the House Tea Party Caucus, became a face of the emerging movement, and made "repeal Obamacare" her clarion call, thus guaranteeing a role on the national stage.

Kathryn Pearson, an American politics expert and associate professor at the University of Minnesota, notes that Bachmann skillfully used the media, particularly cable media, to articulate a very conservative message and articulate opposition to the Obama administration in ways that went beyond that of mainstream Republicans. "She did not do a lot legislatively; it was not her focus," Pearson says, "but she gave voice to Tea Party members and made life difficult for her party's leadership."

Bachmann's penchant for hyperbole, if not outright falsity, made her ubiquitous in the cable TV arena but tarnished her reputation as a serious political player and made a wide swath of her home state Republicans cringe. "To the degree that she was a laughingstock—that's not good when you're a Republican in Minnesota," says Sarah Janecek, a GOP activist and founder of Politics in Minnesota, a state public affairs news service.

Bachmann was not always good for national Republicans either, as the party attempted to broaden its appeal. She proved to be a reliable villain for Democrats, who often used her over-the-top comments to fuel their own direct-mail fundraising efforts. "She was a polarizing figure and has drawn a lot of fire, and made some missteps," says Riehl, the conservative blogger. "The Tea Party movement, however, in some ways, has moved ahead of her now, grown beyond her, and is not as handcuffed to the social right."

Even so, Bachmann's improbable, audacious run for the presidential nomination in 2012 still resonates with Riehl and other Republicans. "She wasn't the first conservative bomb-thrower from the House to run for president, but she proved a more viable candidate than any other before her campaign fizzled prior to the Iowa caucuses," Riehl says. "Say what you want, but she was a woman making her way into an all-boys' club, and because she was on the right, she didn't have women's groups rallying around her."

Bachmann's detractors provided her with a lot of material, but earlier this month, 400 people turned out to see her at a local Tea Party gathering. "She packed the house," says Jake Duesenberg, who heads the East Metro Tea Party organization that reaches into her district. "You can say this or that about how she messages, but she stood up for free markets, fiscal responsibility, and respect for the Constitution."

Title: Obama Campaign Faces Questions on Economic Progress

Article:

During the 2008 presidential campaign, then-candidate Barack Obama stated that he would be a "one-term proposition" if people did not feel better off after three years of his presidency. This statement is now being revisited during the current election cycle, as questions about the nation's economic progress under Obama's administration have arisen.

The debate began with Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley's flip-flop on the issue. On CBS's Face the Nation, O'Malley stated that the nation is not better off, but later tweeted that the country is creating jobs and, therefore, better off.

The question of economic progress also followed Vice President Joe Biden on the campaign trail in Detroit. Biden asserted that the nation is better off, but did not provide specific reasons.

Obama campaign senior adviser David Axelrod and Fox News Sunday host Chris Wallace had a back-and-forth discussion about the issue. Wallace asked Axelrod if the average American is better off than four years ago, to which Axelrod responded that it took years to create the economic crisis that occurred in 2008 and peaked in January 2009, and it will take time to work through it.

On CNN's Early Start, anchor John Berman asked Democratic National Committee spokesman Brad Woodhouse if the nation is better off than four years ago. Woodhouse responded that the nation is better off.

Obama campaign deputy campaign manager Stephanie Cutter was also asked on the Today Show if the nation is better off than it was four years ago when Obama was elected. Cutter responded that the nation is better off and proceeded to outline the state of the economy four years ago.

Journalist Jake Tapper noted in a post that being honest about the fact that the nation is not better off may not be a winning strategy, but the soundbites from Democrats on the issue are still being circulated, and many people are aware of the struggles faced by those who are out of a job or whose businesses are still struggling. It remains to be seen if the Obama campaign will provide a more detailed explanation of the nation's economic progress.

Title: U.S. and China Engage in Escalating Trade War

Article:

The United States and China have initiated a trade war, with President Donald Trump imposing tariffs on $34 billion worth of Chinese goods entering the U.S. This marks the beginning of a conflict that shows no signs of abating soon. The tariffs, which took effect just after midnight Washington time on Friday, target products such as farming plows and airplane parts. China retaliated immediately with duties on U.S. exports, including soybeans and automobiles.

Neither side appears to be backing down, with Trump already considering another $16 billion of Chinese goods and indicating that the final tariff total could exceed $500 billion, nearly the same amount the U.S. imported from China in 2017. China's Commerce Ministry has accused the U.S. of "bullying" and igniting "the largest trade war in economic history."

The tariffs, which are the first ever U.S. tariffs aimed solely at China, are expected to rally Trump's voters who support his "America First" argument that China has not played fair for years, stealing American intellectual property and undercutting its manufacturers. However, the risk is that the conflict could undermine economic growth by complicating international supply chains and increasing prices for companies and consumers.

The initial impact of the tariffs on some items will be significant. For instance, the tariff on pure-electric vehicles, such as Tesla, will rise to 40 percent of the value from the current 15 percent. U.S. whiskey will be taxed 30 percent, compared with 5 percent for alcohol from other nations. U.S. soybeans, a key flashpoint in the worsening trade relations, will see their tariff increase to 28 percent of the value, while the soybean duty for some other nations has been lowered to zero recently.

The extent of the economic damage will depend on how far both sides go. If the U.S. and China cool off after a first round of tariffs, the fallout will be modest, according to ███ Economics. Under a full-blown trade war in which the U.S. imposes 10 percent tariffs on all other countries and they respond, the economists reckon U.S. growth would slow by 0.8 percentage point by 2020.

Beijing has shown little interest in making fundamental changes to its economic model. President Xi Jinping has balked at U.S. demands to stop subsidizing Chinese firms under his plan to make the nation a leader in key technologies by 2025. The strength and size of both economies mean the fight could rage on for years.

In the past, the U.S. has used its influence to win trade skirmishes with developing countries. China, whose economy has grown tenfold since it joined the World Trade Organization in 2001, poses a much more formidable adversary. "The dynamic is different from anything we've seen," said James Boughton, a senior fellow at the Centre for International Governance Innovation in Waterloo, Ontario. "China has an ability to ride out this kind of pressure, to weather the storm, that a lot of countries didn't have in the past."

On Friday, Trump was uncharacteristically reserved on Twitter about the trade dispute with China. "JOBS, JOBS, JOBS!" he tweeted after the employment numbers.

Title: Lost Friendship Over Political Differences: A Personal Account of the Divisive Election Aftermath

Article:

In a personal account, a writer recounts the estrangement from a longtime friend, a Hollywood agent, following the 2016 U.S. Presidential election. The friend, a leftist, had been a significant part of the writer's life for decades, but their relationship has been severed since the election due to their differing political views.

The writer voted for Donald Trump, while their friend was a vocal opponent of the President. The writer claims that their friend was terrified of Trump, but they could not understand the reason. On election night, the writer admitted to their friend that they had been wrong about Trump's chances of winning, and that they had voted for Trump out of revulsion at Hillary Clinton's arrogance.

Since the election, the writer has reached out to their friend multiple times, but their attempts have been met with silence or angry responses. The writer sent their friend two large plants and another letter asking for a conversation, but received no response.

The writer notes that similar stories have been shared by friends and colleagues, suggesting a widespread rift among people due to political differences. The writer questions why Trump is causing such rage and bitterness, as policy issues are not typically the source of such strong emotions.

The writer suggests that the reason for the intense hatred and fear of Trump may be due to his personality, citing the theory that some people are repulsed by a strong and dominant father figure. The writer also notes the left's capacity for hate, comparing it to historical events such as the Two Minute Hates in George Orwell's 1984, Kristallnacht, and KKK lynchings.

The writer questions why the left is almost always the source of such hate and rage, and why there are no mass marches or riots from other groups demanding an end to certain policies. The writer concludes by expressing their sadness over the loss of their friend and questioning why Trump, whose speeches are often seen as meaningless clichés, is causing such strong reactions. The writer also mentions the Nobel Peace Prize and Bob Dylan's decision not to accept his Nobel Prize for Literature.

Title: Trump Accuses Mueller's Office of Coercing Witnesses Amidst Ongoing Investigation

Article:

In a series of tweets on Wednesday, President Donald Trump accused the special counsel's office of attempting to coerce witnesses to testify against him. The accusations come after the special counsel's office accused former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort of lying to the FBI about the Russia investigation and violating a plea agreement.

Trump's reference to three "major players" appears to refer to Manafort, long-time political adviser Roger Stone, and conservative writer Jerome Corsi, an ally of Stone who said he rejected a plea deal from Mueller. Lawmakers and legal analysts suggest that the president is trying to damage Mueller's reputation ahead of an expected report on Russian efforts to influence the 2016 presidential election in Trump's favor.

Prosecutors are examining whether Trump and his campaign worked with Russians who hacked Democratic emails and pushed fake news about Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, and whether the president has sought to obstruct that investigation. Trump has repeatedly denied collusion and obstruction, and accused Mueller's office of political motivations.

Trump's legal team has joint defense agreements with witnesses in the Mueller investigation, and they have shared information about the probe. Manafort, Stone, Corsi, and Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani have all accused Mueller's office of coercing testimony.

Giuliani accused prosecutors of treating Manafort "like he’s a terrorist, incarcerating him before trial, solitary incarceration and repeated questioning" about Trump. In a text, Giuliani said they are "willing to exert unusual pressure that could tempt someone to lie and get out of jail."

After his conviction on financial fraud charges, Manafort struck a deal to cooperate with Mueller's team in September – yet maintained his joint defense agreement with Manafort, an unusual development. Former federal prosecutor Renato Mariotti, a CNN legal analyst, tweeted that Manafort's decision to do so was "highly deceptive and undermined Mueller's investigation."

In accusing Trump of seeking to undermine Mueller, some lawmakers have proposed legislation to protect the special counsel's job. They have also accused Manafort and other witnesses of seeking pardons from the president. The proposed legislation "would protect Special Counsel Robert Mueller and future Special Counsels from inappropriate removal or political pressure," said a statement from the office of Sen. Chris Coons, D-Delaware.

White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said Trump has no plans to get rid of Mueller. "The President has had Robert Mueller doing his job for the last two years, and he could've taken action at any point, and he hasn’t," Sanders said. "So we'll let that speak for itself." Sanders also said, "I'm not aware of any conversations for anyone's pardon involving this process at all."

Additional reporting indicates that Manafort has been giving Trump's legal team updates on what Mueller asks, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has vowed to stop the bill to protect Mueller's job even after the No. 2 GOP leader floated the possibility of it.

Title: House Democrats Introduce For The People Act, a Comprehensive Voting and Ethics Reform Bill

Article:

House Democrats have introduced the For The People Act, also known as HR 1, a 571-page bill aimed at addressing issues in four key areas: voting, political money, redistricting, and ethics. The bill, which serves as the first legislative action of the new Democratic House, is a compilation of existing problems and proposed solutions.

Rep. John Sarbanes (D-Md.) stated, "We heard loud and clear from the American people. They feel left out and locked out from their own democracy." If the bill were to become law, it is unlikely to happen this year due to Republican control of the Senate, a Republican president, and the GOP's vehement opposition to the bill's approach.

The bill includes provisions that push the envelope, such as taking away the power of state legislatures to draw congressional districts and having independent commissions do it instead. This move is intended to prevent local politicians from gerrymandering districts to help their party and cripple the opposition.

Other proposals in the bill are not surprising, such as an update of the Disclose Act, a pro-transparency measure that Democrats have introduced regularly since 2010. The bill also includes measures to make voter registration easier, such as allowing citizens to register online or automatically via data from driver's licenses or other government sources. For federal elections, states would have to provide same-day registration and at least 15 days of early voting, with Election Day declared a federal holiday.

The bill also aims to crack down on efforts to take voters off the rolls or prevent them from casting ballots. Felons could regain their voting rights after finishing their sentences. Federal elections would require paper ballots to prevent computer tampering, and state chief election officials could not get involved in federal campaigns.

The bill declares an intent to revive core anti-discrimination provisions of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 that were effectively shut down by the Supreme Court six years ago. It also states that failing to vote is not grounds for taking away a person's voter registration.

Provisions from the Disclose Act would expand the prohibition on foreign political money and mandate the disclosure of the big donors behind politically active 501(c)(4) social welfare organizations. Digital companies, like Facebook and Google, would have to set up public databases cataloging political ad purchase requests of $500 or more and create new measures to block ad buys by foreign nationals.

Presidential inaugural committees would have to disclose expenditures, in addition to the existing requirement for donor disclosure. This is a response to reports of unexplained spending by Trump's inaugural committee.

A new matching-fund program would support House candidates who agree to raise only small-dollar contributions. Similar provisions for Senate candidates would have to come from the Senate. The public financing system for presidential candidates, largely irrelevant since 2012, would be updated.

The bill would quash "sidecar" superPACs that support individual candidates.

Title: Decline in Military Equipment Transfers to Police Departments Despite Trump Executive Order

Article:

The amount of surplus military equipment sent to local police departments across the United States has significantly decreased in recent months, despite an executive order signed by President Trump in August 2017 that aimed to increase such transfers, according to a ███ analysis.

Shipments of military gear in the first three months of 2018 fell by half compared to the same period in 2017, Department of Defense data shows. The value of armored vehicles, high-caliber rifles, and other equipment also decreased.

Trump's executive order rescinded limits imposed on the program by the Obama administration in response to the controversial police response to the Ferguson, Missouri, riots in 2014. Some police officials have approached the program cautiously despite robust support from Trump.

Sgt. Stephen Wells, a spokesman for the Kern County Sheriff's Office in California, which ordered about 90 military items from the Pentagon in 2015 but only one last year, stated, "If you have a long rifle or you have a military vehicle, it looks bad. We're not an occupying force."

Since 1991, the program has recycled approximately $6.8 billion in military equipment purchased by federal taxpayers. The program came under scrutiny following the Ferguson riots, with images of officers wearing tactical gear and standing alongside armored vehicles being broadcast across network news and drawing bipartisan criticism in Congress.

In response, Obama placed limits on some kinds of equipment in 2015. Obama stated then that the show of force opened a rift between the police and the community at a time when both would have benefited from better relations.

However, Trump administration officials argued that the restrictions went too far, limiting police from obtaining equipment that could help them meet modern challenges. Trump's order was touted by those officials as a way to increase the flow of "lifesaving gear" to police.

Announcing the order last year, Attorney General Jeff Sessions criticized Obama for the limits and vowed that the Trump administration would not "put superficial concerns above public safety."

The data show a bump in shipments in September, the month immediately following Trump's action, but that appears to have been an anomaly. The average monthly value of military gear shipped to local departments in 2016 was just over $17 million. So far this year, the average monthly value stands at $5.2 million.

A White House spokeswoman referred questions to the Justice Department. A spokeswoman at Justice referred questions to the Defense Department. A spokeswoman for the Defense Logistics Agency, which oversees the program, stated that this year's decline is "likely due to those… items not being available."

The spokeswoman, Michelle McCaskill, described the change ushered in by Trump's executive order as "minimal."

While some police departments are more aware of the public relations concerns associated with the equipment, Wells and others suggested that local law enforcement is unlikely to abandon the program entirely. The equipment remains crucial for dangerous situations such as an active shooter.

By far the most common item transferred to police last year were military rifles, followed by weapon sights and night-vision goggles.

James Pasco, executive director of the Fraternal Order of Police, stated he believes Trump's order has put police across the nation in a stronger position. Both Trump and Sessions closely aligned with rank-and-file police during the presidential campaign.

Pasco speculated that the drop-off is a coincidence, though he also acknowledged that some local political leaders have been reluctant to embrace the program with zeal.

"If there's a spate of additional unrest, then I predict that there'll be a greater demand," he said.

Critics pounced on the program again last year when the Government Accountability Office created a fictitious agency and obtained more than 100 military items worth $1.2 million, including night-vision goggles and simulated pipe bombs.

███'s analysis focused exclusively on equipment the Department of Defense altered, or "demilitarized," before transferring it to a local government. That means rifles, armored trucks, night-vision sniper scopes, and other war-fighting equipment were included, but not radios, boots, and printers.

The Project on Government Oversight, a Washington-based watchdog group, predicted last fall that Trump's order would have little effect on the shipments. The more significant change, experts said, has been on how the government oversees the program.

"Trump did not make a huge difference in what is or is not allowed, despite statements from some in the administration," said Peter Tyler, a senior policy analyst with the group. "Mostly what the Obama-era order did was put in some very helpful accountability steps."

Rick Myers, executive director of the Major Cities Chiefs Association, stated he was not surprised Trump's order did not result in a sustained increase in demand. The problem with the program, he said, is not the equipment, but how some departments used it.

"Police chiefs across the country are a little more sensitive to the optics," Myers said. "I think we're just maybe a little smarter about it."

Title: The Importance of Mothers in Shaping America's Future

Article:

Matthew Vasser, the founder of Vasser Women's College, once stated that mothers play a crucial role in shaping the destiny of a nation. This belief is echoed in the assertion that families, particularly mothers, are the foundation of society and the key to America's future.

The article argues that the state of America's homes today is a reflection of its future. A friend of the author, who teaches at Schofield Army Barracks in Hawaii, shares her experience of fifth-grade students who no longer pledge the flag, prompting concerns about the future of America's appreciation for its values and freedoms.

The piece emphasizes the role of mothers in instilling a love for liberty, as schools, media, and even churches are no longer teaching these values. The author quotes Peter Wolf, who suggests that parents should become the first line of defense, dedicating time and effort to teach their children about American history, heroes, and the link between liberty and personal responsibility.

The article concludes by highlighting the power of mothers in shaping the future, quoting E.T. Sullivan, who said, "The greatest forces in the world are not the earthquakes and thunderbolts. The greatest forces in the world are babies." The author encourages mothers to recognize their influence and importance in shaping the future of America.

The article ends with a call to action, directing readers to resources such as HomeMakers for America and Libraries of Hope, which aim to promote a love of liberty in children. The author emphasizes that the future of America lies in the hands of mothers, and the ideas they instill in their children.

Title: Donald Trump Discusses Presidential Campaign and Upcoming Speech in ABC Interview

In a pre-recorded interview with ABC's George Stephanopoulos, Donald Trump discussed his presidential campaign, his upcoming acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention, and various political issues.

When asked if he thought he would get this far in the election, Trump replied, "People have asked me that question, and I guess the answer has to be yes, or I don't think I would have done it." Looking forward to his acceptance speech, Trump stated that it would focus on the country's problems and not on a grand entrance.

Trump said, "We have deep problems. It's not about the entrance. It's about the words and it's about getting the words done, and the only way we're going to get that taken care of is we have to, in November, do very well." The speech will include discussions on trade, law and order, and the nation's borders, among "many different things."

Regarding his campaign's key goals, Trump mentioned his call for a temporary ban on Muslim immigration and his insistence on a wall along the Mexican border, stating, "You'll be hearing a lot of things tomorrow."

Trump also addressed the controversy surrounding his wife Melania's speech at the Republican National Convention, stating that Meredith McIver, who has worked with the Trump family, offered her resignation for her role in helping Melania with her speech. Trump, however, declined to accept her resignation.

Trump is expected to start spending more money on his campaign soon, as he stated, "This is an important thing for the country." He also mentioned that his wife was treated well by the media during the speech controversy.

The interview did not include questions about Texas Sen. Ted Cruz's refusal to endorse Trump, as it was pre-recorded.

Title: Researchers Develop Biodegradable Tube for Peripheral Nerve Repair in Mice and Monkeys

Article:

Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh have developed a biodegradable tube that can effectively bridge gaps in peripheral nerves, according to a study published in Science Translational Medicine. The tube, which releases a growth factor protein for several months, guides the nerve to grow along the correct path and induces faster growth.

The device, which professor Kacey Marra has been working on for over a dozen years, is particularly aimed at helping soldiers injured in combat, as more than half of injured soldiers suffer nerve injuries. Combat gear protects a soldier's chest and head, but arms and legs are often exposed, leading to common peripheral nerve injuries.

In the U.S., there are approximately 600,000 nerve injuries each year, though the number of severe injuries requiring the relocation of a second nerve is not currently tracked. The current treatment for severe nerve injuries is to take a nerve from another part of the body, but patients typically recover only about 50 to 60 percent of function in the damaged nerve.

The new device restored nearly 80 percent of function, according to the study. It uses glial-cell-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF), a protein that promotes nerve cell survival. The tube is made of the same polymer as dissolvable stitches, which has already been federally approved for surgical use.

Other researchers are exploring the use of stem cells or other cells to help bridge the gap in the nerve, but Marra and her colleagues' approach is likely to have an easier time receiving federal approval because it does not involve cells. "If they were to go adding stem cells or too many complexities, it would be harder to win a regulatory green light," says Christine Schmidt, a professor and chair of the department of biomedical engineering at the University of Florida, who was not involved with the research.

The nerve the Pittsburgh team tested is relatively small in macaques. "It will still be a challenge to scale up to larger nerves," says Schmidt. "It would be nice to see a little bit larger nerve, which would be more relevant to patients."

The new device is expected to start clinical trials in humans in 2021 and take at least three years. Marra's team is also beginning to study whether its method will work for facial nerves, but she thinks it is unlikely to be effective for spinal cord injuries, which are far more complex and involve more nerves. The researchers are also looking at regenerating the muscles affected by injured nerves.

"I think [this approach] really could revolutionize thinking about nerve repair and the different options a patient will have," Marra says.

Title: U.S. Navy Reduces Carrier Presence in Persian Gulf Due to Budget Constraints

Article:

The United States Navy will reduce its aircraft carrier presence in the Persian Gulf from two to one, according to Pentagon officials. This decision, which goes into effect immediately, is a response to looming budget constraints and the potential for automatic budget cuts that have not been averted.

In a statement, Pentagon spokesman George Little confirmed the Navy's request to Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, who approved the decision. The deployment of the USS Harry S. Truman, scheduled to leave from Norfolk, Virginia, on Friday, has been cancelled.

The USS Dwight D. Eisenhower, which was in the Gulf but returned home in December for maintenance, will return later this month. At that point, the USS John C. Stennis, currently the only carrier in the Gulf, will leave the region and return home.

Officials say that if Congress cannot avert $500 billion in defense cuts over the next 10 years, the Navy cannot justify the cost of two carriers in the region. However, the Navy could be "surge-ready" and deploy more carriers in a crisis situation.

The Navy has 10 aircraft carriers in its fleet, and, as of today, only three were forward-deployed at any given time. Two were in the Persian Gulf and one was permanently stationed in Japan. Now, the Navy will only have two forward-deployed carriers.

Typically, carriers spend six months at sea, but their deployments have lasted closer to nine months due to budget constraints. A Navy official says the Pentagon would save "several hundred million dollars per year" by reducing to one carrier in the Gulf.

The move by the Pentagon comes as lawmakers argue over how, if at all, to avoid a March 1 deadline, after which automatic cuts to the Pentagon and other areas of the budget will begin to take effect. President Obama called Tuesday for a short-term bill to avert the cuts, but Republicans criticized this approach as irresponsible.

A group of Republican lawmakers on Wednesday proposed a bill to cut the federal workforce and use the savings to replace $85 billion in across-the-board budget cuts to the Pentagon and domestic programs. Meanwhile, Defense Secretary Leon Panetta outlined a grim list of spending cuts the Pentagon may have to make in the coming weeks.

In separate, highly detailed memos sent to Congress, the military services described widespread civilian furloughs, layoffs, and hiring freezes that will affect workers around the country. Overall, the military will furlough 800,000 civilian workers for 22 days, spread across more than five months, and will lay off as many as 46,000 temporary and contract employees.

The Navy says it will cease deployments to South America and the Caribbean and limit those to Europe. The Air Force warned that it would cut operations at various missile defense radar sites from 24 hours to eight hours. And the Army said it would cancel training center rotations for four brigades and cancel repairs for thousands of vehicles, radios, and weapons.

In addition to these immediate cuts, U.S. troops are likely to see a smaller pay hike next year than initially planned, due to strains on the budget. According to a defense official, the Pentagon will recommend that the military get a 1 percent pay increase in 2014, instead of a 1.7 percent raise.

Defense Secretary Leon Panetta is expected to leave the Pentagon this month. Former Republican senator Chuck Hagel has been nominated to take his place, and a vote by the Senate Armed Services Committee is expected this week.

Title: Trump and Putin Discuss Election Meddling and Foreign Policy in Call

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin held an hour-long conversation, as confirmed by the White House and the Kremlin. The call, the first since the release of the Mueller report, covered various topics, including the "Russian hoax," as Trump referred to it in a tweet.

In a tweet on Friday, Trump shared details of their latest conversation, stating, "Had a long and very good conversation with President Putin." He further emphasized the importance of good relations with Russia, China, and other nations.

When asked by a reporter if he had warned Putin against meddling in the 2020 elections, Trump responded by labeling the reporter as "very rude." He reiterated his stance on international relations, stating, "Getting along with countries is a good thing and we want to have good relations with everybody."
