However, the White House confirmed that the issue of alleged Russian meddling was discussed during the call. Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stated, "Very, very briefly it was discussed, essentially in the context that it's over, and there was no collusion."

Sanders also mentioned that Trump and Putin had briefly discussed the investigation by US Special Counsel Robert Mueller into alleged Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. The White House press secretary described the call as an "overall positive conversation."

A redacted version of the special counsel's report was made public last month. It concluded that Russia had interfered in the 2016 presidential election "in sweeping and systematic fashion." The interference took the form of an extensive social media campaign and hacking into Democratic Party servers by Russian military intelligence. The inquiry did not determine the Trump campaign had conspired with Russia.

In addition to the election meddling discussion, the leaders also touched upon thorny foreign policy issues. The specifics of these discussions have not been disclosed.

Title: Obama Administration Proposes New Carbon Emission Regulations for Power Companies

Article:

The Obama administration has proposed new regulations aimed at reducing carbon emissions in the United States. The regulations call for America's power companies to generate 28 percent of the country's energy from renewable sources by 2030, up from the current 11 percent. Over the same period, these companies must cut carbon emissions to 32 percent of 2005 levels.

The new rules are intended to position the United States as a leader in addressing climate change ahead of a global climate change conference in Paris later this year. However, the regulations will face numerous challenges, including legal disputes, potential lapses under subsequent administrations, and opposition from energy companies.

The success of the president's new energy vision hinges on public support. In a survey by the Pew Research Center, global warming was ranked as the 22nd priority for the president and Congress, with only 38 percent considering it a top priority, compared to 76 percent who chose terrorism.

The regulations are expected to lead to upheaval in the energy industry, with potentially hundreds of coal-fired power plants being closed. Critics argue that price increases will be significant. Germany, which has pursued a similar path, has experienced high energy prices as a result.

Germany, which currently generates 27 percent of its power from renewable sources, has faced challenges in its transition to green energy. The country's double whammy of ramping up renewable energy while shutting down nuclear power has contributed to price increases.

In contrast, private individuals and farmers in Germany accounted for 46 percent of renewable energy production in 2012, while the "big four" power providers accounted for only 5 percent. This suggests that Germany's green power revolution is being driven by individuals with solar cells and windmills, not major power companies.

Sweden, which has taxed carbon emissions aggressively since 1991, offers some insights. In 2013, President Obama cited Sweden as providing "good lessons." Currently, 47 percent of Sweden's energy comes from renewable sources, mostly hydropower, with virtually no coal usage.

The Obama administration claims that the new regulations will not increase energy prices. However, the transition to renewable energy is expected to bring significant changes to the way power companies operate, including the increased production of green energy and the acceptance of more consumers generating their own power.

The new regulations are based on giving states flexibility, with each allowed to create its own plan under the guidelines laid out by the EPA. If states refuse to create their own plans, the Obama administration will impose a plan. The regulations are likely to face opposition from Republicans, who have labeled the approach as "cap and tax."

Sweden's approach to carbon emissions and renewable energy may provide some guidance for the United States. The country has taxed carbon emissions aggressively since 1991 and currently generates 47 percent of its energy from renewable sources.

Title: U.S. Grand Princess Cruise Ship Reports 21 Coronavirus Cases, Eight More States Confirm First Infections

Article:

Twenty-one individuals aboard the Grand Princess cruise ship have tested positive for coronavirus, U.S. officials announced on Friday. The vessel, carrying approximately 3,500 passengers and crew, was barred from docking in San Francisco.

Vice President Mike Pence, who is leading the White House's response to the outbreak, stated at a news conference that 19 crew members and two passengers out of 46 people tested so far on the ship have the virus. The Grand Princess will be taken to a non-commercial port, where everyone on board will be tested.

U.S. President Donald Trump expressed a preference for keeping passengers on the vessel but stated that he would defer to others regarding disembarkation. "I'd rather have them stay on, personally, but I fully understand if they want to take them off," Trump said after touring the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta.

Allowing passengers onto U.S. soil who might be infected would increase the number of coronavirus cases in the country, Trump noted. "I don't need to have the numbers double because of one ship that wasn't our fault," Trump said.

Keeping passengers quarantined aboard a coronavirus-hit ship has proven disastrous in Japan, leading to one of the world's biggest outbreaks.

Eight states - Pennsylvania, Indiana, Minnesota, Kentucky, Oklahoma, Nebraska, South Carolina, and Hawaii - reported their first cases on Friday, meaning more than half of the 50 U.S. states now have the virus.

The respiratory illness, which emerged in China and has spread to over 90 nations, has killed more than 3,400 people and infected over 100,000 worldwide.

As stocks plunge and U.S. companies grapple with the economic fallout, the Trump administration is reportedly considering tax relief for the cruise, travel, and airline industries.

A poll by ███/Ipsos shows Americans are sharply divided over the dangers of the new coronavirus. Critics of Trump, including Democratic lawmakers, have accused the president of downplaying the significance of the outbreak for political reasons. He has stated the risk to Americans is low.

The crisis has hit stocks hard. The benchmark S&P 500 closed down another 1.7% on Friday, after falling nearly 3% the day before.

As new states report their first cases, others see their tallies grow. Cases in New York jumped to 44 from 22, Governor Andrew Cuomo said on Friday, adding that some 4,000 people in the state are under precautionary quarantine and 44 under mandatory quarantine.

Amid widespread criticism of a lack of available tests for states in need, Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, acknowledged that "some missteps" had initially slowed the distribution of tests, but said the overall response was going well. "In the next couple of weeks, we should be ratcheted up to get many more out," Fauci said on NBC's Today program.

Title: College Republican National Committee Report: GOP Faces Challenges in Attracting Young Voters

Article:

The College Republican National Committee (CRNC) has released a detailed report, titled "Grand Old Party for a Brand New Generation," which offers a critical analysis of the Republican Party's struggles in appealing to young voters. The report, based on extensive polling and focus groups, outlines the challenges the GOP faces in addressing key issues, messaging, and outreach to young voters.

The 95-page study, which examines the party's stance on social and economic issues, as well as its messaging and outreach, paints a grim picture of the current situation. The report is particularly critical of the GOP's focus on downsizing government and cutting taxes, offensive and polarizing rhetoric, and ineffective messaging and outreach efforts.

The report highlights several areas of concern, including:

1. Gay marriage: The report states, "On the ‘open-minded’ issue... we will face serious difficulty so long as the issue of gay marriage remains on the table."
2. Hispanics: "Latino voters... tend to think the GOP couldn’t care less about them."
3. Perception of the party's economic stance: "We’ve become the party that will pat you on your back when you make it, but won’t offer you a hand to help you get there."
4. Big reason for the image problem: "The outrageous statements made by errant Republican voices."

The report also reveals the words that up-for-grabs voters associate with the GOP: closed-minded, racist, rigid, and old-fashioned.

Despite the critical assessment, the report maintains hope for the future, stating, "The Republican Party has won the youth vote before and can absolutely win it again." The report points to presidents Ronald Reagan and George W. Bush, who were competitive with young voters, as examples of past success. However, the report emphasizes that significant work is needed to repair the damage done to the Republican brand among young voters over the last decade.

The report is based on two national surveys of 800 registered voters each, ages 18-29, and six focus groups of young people from diverse backgrounds who had voted for President Barack Obama but were considered "winnable" for the GOP. The surveys were developed by the Winston Group, a Washington-based GOP polling firm. The cost of the study was not disclosed, but Alex Schriver, who served as the chairman of the CRNC during the election and is a co-author of the report, called it a "significant investment."

The CRNC will publicly release the study on Monday and present their findings privately to Republican officials and outside groups. The specific attendees for the private presentation were not specified.

Title: Impact of Leaks on U.S. Intelligence Efforts: A Closer Look

Article:

The recent wave of leaks has sparked debate among experts regarding the potential harm to U.S. intelligence efforts. James Clapper, the Director of National Intelligence, has claimed that the leaks have caused "huge, grave damage" to intelligence gathering capabilities. However, Glenn Greenwald, the Guardian columnist who facilitated the leaks, disputes this claim, stating that the leaks have not jeopardized national security in any way.

While the exact extent of the damage is uncertain, intelligence experts and former officials interviewed by various media outlets suggest that there will likely be some harm to U.S. intelligence efforts. The primary negative impact is expected to fall on the U.S. Internet industry, as some of its international customer base may flee in search of sites thought to be more secure from American government snooping.

The concern is not so much the specifics of what was leaked, but rather the widespread publicity the leaks generated. Every news story could serve as a revelation to some terrorists, and a reminder to others, of the nation's capabilities. This increased awareness could potentially tip off or encourage less skilled terrorists to behave more furtively.

While terrorists are often perceived as well-informed, ex-intelligence officials argue that their skill sets run the gamut. The biggest terror threat in the United States currently seems to be homegrown extremists who are not hardened operatives and who lack first-rate tradecraft. These are the precisely the sorts of novices who could be tipped off or decide to behave more furtively because of the recent spate of surveillance disclosures.

Intelligence agencies rely on other people's mistakes, former NSA general counsel Joel Brenner notes. "You'd be surprised at how many people make mistakes," he said.

Michael Hayden, former NSA Director, insists that even the wording in stories sometimes tips off terrorists. He ran off-the-record seminars for journalists at NSA headquarters, where he and others from the spy agency urged reporters to replace terms like "intercepts" in their stories with vaguer phrases like "intelligence reports." Such seemingly minor changes affect the way targets of U.S. intelligence behave, he said.

There remains considerable dispute about whether the harm in the recent wave of leaks comes directly from the leaks themselves or from media coverage that has treated them as earth-shattering revelations. Before the first leak last week about Verizon call data being gathered on a daily basis, there was ample reason for both privacy-sensitive Americans and well-informed terrorists to suspect that the government had been gathering a great deal of information on calling patterns. However, the extent to which this information was known is difficult to assess.

Title: President Trump's Independence Day Address at Mount Rushmore: A Call to Courage and Preservation of American Values

Article:

In his Independence Day address at Mount Rushmore, President Donald Trump emphasized the nation's birth not as a result of peace and reflection, but out of crisis and courage. The speech served as a call to courage in the face of the current challenges the country is facing, including civil unrest, the pandemic, and societal discord.

The President highlighted the sacrifices made by historical figures such as George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, and Theodore Roosevelt, who risked their lives in battles, on the battlefields of the American Revolution, the frigid desolation of Valley Forge, and in Cuba, respectively. These individuals were instrumental in shaping the United States and embodying the American spirit of courage and bravery.

The monument at Mount Rushmore, depicting these four American heroes, stands as a reminder of the hardships previous generations of Americans faced in preserving their culture and civilization from both foreign and domestic enemies. The President's speech served as an exaltation to this American tradition of courage and a call to honor the legacy of these heroes.

The President's speech also touched upon the current state of the nation, where the radical fringe is attempting to erase the Founding Fathers and American heroes from history. The President compared the isolation experienced under state and local lockdown protocols to the hardships faced by soldiers at Valley Forge and the settlers and pioneers who conquered the American interior.

The President's speech concluded with a call to action for Americans to stand united in preserving and strengthening the heritage passed down by the Founding Fathers. The President warned against the radical fringe's attempts to redefine America and destroy its values, emphasizing the nation's faith in its Creator and reverence for the Founders and their vision of government by and for the people.

Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, a conservative commentator and longtime host of the television show Huckabee, praised the President's speech as an optimistic message that the United States has faced and overcome greater challenges in the past and will do so again with the right leadership. Huckabee is a New York Times best-selling author and host of the popular weekly talk show Huckabee, which airs on TBN.

Title: Obama Administration's Record Deportations: A Look at the Numbers and Controversy

Article:

In October 2010, the Obama administration boasted of deporting a record number of illegal immigrants. This was revealed in a Washington Post report that uncovered a memo from the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) setting a goal of 400,000 deportations. The document urged agents to focus on criminal alien removals but expressed concern about the low number of non-criminal removals.

The memo stated, "the other Agency critical goal of achieving 400,000 removals and returns overall," and later warned they were "well under the Agency’s goal of 400,000" at that time. Under pressure from immigration activists, the administration's record deportations have become a contentious issue, similar to the controversy surrounding the president's health plan.

In a recent statement, President Obama acknowledged the ineffectiveness of immigration enforcement, stating, "It’s not smart, it doesn’t make sense." Vice President Joe Biden responded to a heckler's call to "Stop the deportations" by saying, "We’ll do that too, kid."

Activists have criticized the Obama administration's deportation policies, with some suggesting that deportation is an illegitimate policy tool. However, many argue that criminal aliens should be removed from the country, while those who are merely in the U.S. illegally should not be deported.

One group's statement reads, "Not one more family destroyed, not one more day without equality, not one more indifferent reaction to suffering, not one more deportation." This perspective has been criticized as extreme, as it suggests that no one should be deported until all problems related to immigration are solved.

Barbara Jordan, a civil rights icon who chaired Bill Clinton's commission to reform immigration in the 1990s, understood the importance of enforcing immigration laws. She stated, "Those who should get in, get in; those who should be kept out, are kept out; and those who should not be here will be required to leave." Jordan emphasized that for immigration policy to be credible, people actually have to be deported at the end of the process.

In 2013, 59 percent of deportees were convicted of a crime, and a third were felons, according to the Pew Hispanic Center. When repeat immigration violators, illegal border crossings, and immigration fugitives are included, 98 percent of the people deported last year were deemed removable.

The Obama administration's record deportations have been a source of criticism on the left, with some arguing that the administration has adopted unconventional methods to achieve its record. The Washington Post reported that the administration counted some 19,000 immigrants who had left the previous fiscal year, and the Center for Immigration Studies pointed out that these numbers increased as interior enforcement declined.

Obama's attempt to define deportations down notwithstanding, he acknowledged the need for increased enforcement to maintain credibility on amnesty for enforcement exchanges. Now, the Obama administration can curtail deportations if congressional Republicans do not pass an immigration bill.

Title: Extinction Rebellion Protests Disrupt European Cities, Sparking Debate on Climate Change Activism

Article:

Protesters affiliated with the Extinction Rebellion (XR) group disrupted several European cities, including London, Berlin, and Amsterdam, in recent weeks. The demonstrations, which have resulted in over 1,800 arrests in London alone, have caused significant disruptions to daily life, particularly during rush hour.

The protests began in London with actions such as spraying beetroot juice on delegates at a fossil-fuels conference, dousing the Treasury building with red paint, and blocking key buildings with breastfeeding mothers. One protester even climbed to the top of Big Ben using scaffolding.

The most controversial action took place last Thursday, when two activists climbed onto commuter trains during rush hour and blocked their departure. They unfurled a banner that read "Business as Usual = Death." Angry commuters, many of whom could have faced pay deductions for late arrival at work, removed the protesters from the trains, and London Underground staff escorted them away.

An 83-year-old protester named Phil Kingston also glued himself to a train to stop it, justifying his action by stating, "I'm a Christian, and it really upsets me to see God's creation being wrecked across the world."

Public opinion in London has turned against the protests, with more than 60% of respondents in snap polls expressing frustration with the disruptions. XR leaders have promised that future protests will "evolve," but the meaning of this remains unclear.

XR co-founder Clare Farrell defended the train action, stating, "This is what you do when you think that absolutely everything is at stake. What would you do if you knew your children were in a burning building? Well, you would break down the door, wouldn't you? It wouldn't be pretty. You wouldn't be able to do it in a way that everyone said, 'Oh, that was nice and calm.' But it's not. It's an emergency."

The real enablers of XR's extremism are the donors and celebrities who provide the group with funding and publicity, allowing it to attract fanatical followers. Hedge fund billionaire Sir Christopher Hohn, who donated £200,000 to XR, has a £730 million stake in the owner of Heathrow Airport, despite the airport's high carbon emissions. Over 100 celebrities, including Benedict Cumberbatch, Jude Law, Bob Geldof, and Sienna Miller, have backed XR, despite their high-carbon lifestyles and the carbon footprint of the industries they are part of.

London Mayor Sadiq Khan has faced criticism for his support of the XR protests, while average London commuters have started pushing back against the disruptions, pointing out that poor, working-class people are most affected if they cannot get to their jobs. Economist Andy Critchlow has criticized energy executives for abdicating their responsibility to defend themselves against XR protesters, while Charles Moore, the author of a three-volume biography of Margaret Thatcher, warns that more pushback is needed to prevent XR from escalating its tactics elsewhere.

Title: House Speaker Paul Ryan Delays Endorsement of Donald Trump, Allowing Republican Party Members Flexibility in Support

Article:

House Speaker Paul Ryan, despite anticipating the Republican primary race to continue for several more weeks, spent the last day refining his stance on the presidential nomination, according to his aides. This decision places him in alignment with other notable Republicans, as Donald Trump, the presumptive nominee, has defied conventional campaign norms throughout the election process.

Historically, a party nominee has not failed to secure the support of a House speaker or majority leader from their party in modern times. In 1896, Speaker Thomas Brackett Reed ran against William McKinley and made it clear he would not serve as vice president, but ultimately endorsed the nominee. In 1964, Senator Barry Goldwater had to wait for the endorsement of Senator Everett Dirksen of Illinois, but Mr. Dirksen eventually provided it, ending the "stop-Goldwater" movement.

Ryan's remarks caught the Republican party off guard, providing a degree of freedom for party members in their support of Trump's candidacy. Had Ryan issued a forceful endorsement, it would have put pressure on fellow House Republicans to follow his lead, a step many have been reluctant to take.

"I am not there yet," Ryan said. "And I hope to, though, and I want to. But I think what is required is that we unify the party, and I think the bulk of the burden on unifying the party will have to come from our presumptive nominee." The delay in endorsement allows for a more flexible approach among party members regarding their support for Trump's candidacy.

Title: Dow Jones Industrial Average Experiences Largest Single-Day Percentage Decline Since 1987

Article:

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) experienced a significant drop of nearly 10% on a turbulent trading day, marking the largest single-day percentage decline since the stock market crash in 1987. The Federal Reserve's emergency relief efforts, announced the previous day, failed to stem the market's downward trajectory.

The DJIA closed at 21,200.62, having fallen by 9.99% or 2,352.60 points. The Nasdaq Composite Index declined by 9.43% or 750.25 points, closing at 7,201.80. The S&P 500 also saw a significant drop of 9.5% or 260.74 points, ending the day at 2,480.64.

This marks the third consecutive day of massive declines, following a single day of gains earlier in the week. The ongoing novel coronavirus outbreak and its impact on the global economy appear to be the primary drivers of investor sentiment.

Ebrahim Rahbari, director of global economics at Citi Research, told CNBC that the Federal Reserve's actions may not be sufficient to stabilize market sentiment in the short and long term due to credit concerns and escalating health concerns.

In addition to the stock market turmoil, the novel coronavirus outbreak has disrupted various American institutions. Broadway has been shut down, major sports events have been canceled, and entire seasons are being put on hold. The airline and travel industries have been particularly hard-hit, with shares of United Airlines, Delta, and American Airlines seeing significant drops.

Airlines started canceling flights following President Trump's decision to ban travel between the U.S. and Europe for the next 30 days. Delta, for example, will temporarily cancel flights between cities like Amsterdam and Orlando, Portland and Salt Lake City, as well as flights to Paris from Cincinnati, Raleigh/Durham, and Indianapolis.

Investors continued to sell off stocks, with even cryptocurrencies and SaaS shares experiencing significant declines. Slack's earnings failed to excite investors, leading to a sell-off of its equity after hours.

In this challenging economic climate, there appears to be no silver lining, unless one had shorted oil a month ago. The country is yet to ramp up its COVID-19 testing regime in earnest.

Title: Obama Faces Blame for Looming Sequester as Time Runs Out

 Article:

President Barack Obama returned to Washington on Monday, with only two weeks remaining to find a solution to avoid the implementation of the $1 trillion in across-the-board cuts known as the sequester, a plan he initially proposed. The sequester, which Obama now labels a "really bad idea," is set to take effect on March 1.

Republicans, led by House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, are emphasizing that the public should direct blame towards the president if the sequester cannot be prevented. "Don't forget it's the president who proposed the sequester and designed the sequester," Ryan said on ABC News' This Week. "House Republicans twice passed legislation replacing the sequester with smarter cuts in other areas of government."

Ryan stated that House Republicans are still working on plans to replace the sequester but believes it will occur due to the short timeframe. The Senate has yet to pass a spending bill to replace the sequester, Ryan noted, adding that Obama "gave a speech showing he'd like to replace it, but he has not put any details out there."

In his State of the Union Address on Feb. 12, the president explained that in 2011, Congress passed a law stating that if both parties could not agree on spending cuts, "about a trillion dollars worth of budget cuts would automatically go into effect this year." Obama described the "sudden, harsh, arbitrary cuts" as jeopardizing military readiness, devastating priorities like education and energy, and medical research, and slowing the recovery and costing hundreds of thousands of jobs.

However, Ryan argued that the sequester is looming and will likely happen "because the president back in the last session of congress refused to cut spending in any place and therefore we wound up with the sequester."

While Ryan has previously stated that he and other conservatives are fighting for statutory caps on spending, he said Sunday he was referring to budget caps on discretionary spending, which were implemented and the party wanted them. "Everybody wants budget caps," Ryan said, pointing out "the sequester we're talking about now was backing up the supercommittee." The committee was supposed to have come up with $1.2 trillion in savings, Ryan said, and Republicans offered even higher revenues in exchange for spending cuts. "It was rejected by the president and the Democrats," Ryan said. "No resolution occurred and therefore the sequester is occurring."

Ryan is not the only person who places the blame for the sequester on Obama's shoulders. Washington Post associate editor Bob Woodward, sitting on the discussion panel on Fox News Sunday, also stated that the sequester was the White House's idea. "It was the White House, it was Obama and Jack Lew and Rob Nabors who went to the Democratic leader in the Senate Harry Reid and said this is the solution," said Woodward. "But everyone has their fingerprints on this," he added. "What is important about it is, it is a governing travesty."

Woodward continued, "The idea that you are going to go around and in random ways just cut things, it would be like a family that has to cut their budget, saying, oh, let's cut the medicine that keeps the children alive. It is stupid." Woodward said the White House does not dispute proposing the sequester, "and they really do not want to talk about the origins of the sequester now."

House Speaker John Boehner also blames the White House for the sequester. "It's taking a meat axe to government spending," he said following the State of the Union speech. "That's why the president ought to be forthcoming about a plan to replace the sequester. His Number Two, Majority Leader Eric Cantor agreed with Boehner that the GOP will do what it can to avoid the cuts kicking in. "We mean business, Mr. President. We are willing to work with you," he said.

The threat of the sequester starting has been made worse by Congress' decision to take a 10-day President's Day break. It won't return to session until Feb. 25, giving it just four working days to find a solution. Obama spent his weekend playing golf in Florida, including a game with Tiger Woods. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid claims Democrats will issue their answer at some point in that time. "Democrats believe the right way to eliminate the deficit is to target waste and abuse with smart spending cuts with closing tax loopholes," Reid said.

However, Reid's decision to hold off, just adds to the brinksmanship that Obama slammed during his address, when he said, "The greatest nation on Earth can not keep conducting its business by drifting from one manufactured crisis to the next." Obama continued, "Let's agree, right here, right now, to keep the people's government open, pay our bills on time, and always uphold the full faith and credit of the United States of America." The American people have worked too hard, for too long, rebuilding from one crisis to see their elected officials cause another, said the president.

Title: U.S. President Donald Trump Announces "Most Dishonest and Corrupt Media Awards"

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump announced the winners of the "Most Dishonest and Corrupt Media Awards" on Wednesday, handing out prizes to news organizations including CNN and the New York Times. The awards, which were announced via Twitter, were met with backlash from critics who argue that the president himself is often economical with the truth.

In June 2017, it was reported that Republicans had won five special elections to the Democrats' nil. However, this was not accurate, as Democrats won one of the five special congressional elections held up to that point in 2017.

In another instance, it was reported that the U.S. had a $17 billion trade deficit with Canada. This was not the case, as the U.S. actually had a trade surplus with Canada of $8.1 billion in 2016.

The Amazon Washington Post and NBC were also named as recipients of the "Fake News" awards, with the president claiming that the media outlets knowingly do not tell the truth and are a great danger to the country.

Other instances of alleged "Fake News" included claims that Colbert's Late Show had the highest rating it had ever had when Donald Trump appeared on it, which was not the case. Additionally, it was reported that President Obama and other U.S. presidents did not make phone calls to the families of U.S. military personnel lost in action, which was also not true.

The president also claimed that his tax plans would not benefit him, but with the data available from 2005, it was found that Donald Trump paid $31,261,179 in AMT (alternative minimum tax), a tax which is being repealed under Trump's plans.

The U.S. Coast Guard was also named as a recipient of the "Fake News" award, with the president claiming that the Coast Guard saved more than 15,000 lives during Hurricane Harvey. However, the official life-saving toll was put at just over 11,000.

CNN International was also named as a source of "Fake News," with the president claiming that the network's ratings were "way down" when they were not. Politifact assessed that CNN's ratings were at a five-year high.

The president also claimed that the murder rate in the U.S. was the highest for 47 years, which is not true. Murder rates were higher in the 1980s and 1990s.

The president's claims of "Fake News" have been met with criticism from media outlets and political opponents, who argue that the president's own statements are often inaccurate and misleading. The president has also been criticized for his use of Twitter to spread information and for his attacks on the media.

Title: House Democrats and White House Reach Agreement on USMCA Trade Deal

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) announced Tuesday that House Democrats had reached an agreement with the White House over the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) trade deal, one hour after announcing articles of impeachment against President Trump.

Pelosi stated, "It is infinitely better than what was initially proposed by the administration. It's a victory for American workers, and it's one that we take great pride in advancing."

During the press conference, Pelosi dismissed the announcement as a victory for the president, saying, "We came a long way from what he originally proposed. There are some people who would say 'why make it look like he has a victory?' Well, we're declaring victory for the American worker."

Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal (D-Mass.) detailed the final days of negotiations, stating, "This got really hot on a number of occasions," but calling the deal a "transformative agreement" and "an opportunity we couldn't let get away from us."

AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka, who represents the largest federation of unions in the country and was a key party in negotiations, confirmed Tuesday that the AFL-CIO would back the trade agreement. Trumka stated, "Working people are responsible for a deal that is a vast improvement over both the original NAFTA and the flawed proposal brought forward in 2017."

The USMCA overhauls the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and is designed to raise wages and improve working conditions for both Mexican and American auto workers by tightening regulations. The deal will be signed on Tuesday by officials from the U.S., Canada, and Mexico.

President Trump tweeted in anticipation of the deal, stating, "America's great USMCA Trade Bill is looking good. It will be the best and most important trade deal ever made by the USA. Good for everybody – Farmers, Manufacturers, Energy, Unions – tremendous support. Importantly, we will finally end our Country's worst Trade Deal, NAFTA!"

Title: EPA Proposes National Rules to Reduce Sulfur in Gasoline

Article:

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed new national rules to reduce the amount of sulfur in gasoline. The aim is to significantly decrease harmful pollution, prevent thousands of premature deaths and illnesses, and improve the efficiency of cars and trucks.

According to NPR's Richard Harris, the lower-sulfur gasoline, already in use in California, Europe, and Japan, will help catalytic converters function more effectively and reduce emissions that contribute to smog. If the rule is adopted, gas prices are expected to rise by a penny per gallon, but the oil industry opposes the rule, stating it will add 6 to 9 cents to the cost of a gallon of gasoline. The rule, if adopted, would take effect in 2017.

The rules have drawn criticism from some Republicans who argue that the mandate will increase consumer costs. The EPA estimates that by 2030, the rules will annually avoid up to 2,400 premature deaths, 23,000 cases of respiratory ailments in children, and other benefits, totaling between $8 billion and $23 billion in yearly health-related benefits. However, House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton, R-Mich., stated that "increases in gas prices disproportionately hurt the nation's most vulnerable individuals and families."

USA Today reports that automakers support the proposal, with Gloria Bergquist of the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers stating, "Our cleaner cars will need even cleaner fuels like those already sold across Europe and Asia, and we are pleased EPA is proposing cleaner fuels."

Title: Americans' Opinions on Obamacare, Same-sex Marriage, and the Supreme Court

Article:

A new CNN/ORC poll reveals that 43 percent of Americans approve of Obamacare overall, matching a previous high in 2013, while 55 percent are opposed. Fifty-three percent say it's too soon to make a judgment about the healthcare law. The poll, conducted at the end of May, surveyed 1,025 adults.

On the issue of same-sex marriage, 63 percent of respondents believe gay and lesbian couples have a constitutional right to marry, with 49 percent holding this view as recently as 2010. Support for same-sex marriage reaches across most age demographics, including 73 percent of those under age 50 and 52 percent older than 50.

The poll also shows that Democrats (74 percent) and independents (69 percent) agree that gays have a constitutional right to marry, while only 35 percent of Republicans agree. Republicans under 50 agree on the issue by 59 percent, compared with 36 percent of Republicans older than 50.

Sixty-three percent of those who agree on a constitutional right to same-sex marriage say they trust the court at least a moderate amount on the issue, while only 25 percent of those who disagree trust the court.

Voters across party lines agreed that everyone should be eligible for the same subsidies, including Democrats (74/20 percent), independents (56/38 percent), and Republicans (49/41 percent). Sixty-two percent of voters said they would be more likely to vote for someone who works to ensure a universal subsidy level, compared to 28 percent who said they would not.

Republicans could pay the biggest price, as 41 percent of voters say they'd be less likely to vote for a Republican who didn't vote to fix Obamacare, compared to only 31 percent who say they would be more likely.

The Supreme Court's trust levels rose on freedom of speech (69 percent), voting rights (65 percent), and the death penalty (60 percent). However, the court's trust levels were worse on healthcare and same-sex marriage, with only about half saying they have at least a moderate amount of trust in the court as it considers those issues.

The Supreme Court's upcoming decision on the King v. Burwell case could determine the future of Obamacare itself. The plaintiffs in the case argue that President Barack Obama's signature legislation allows only for federal subsidies on state-run exchanges, not for those in states that use the federal exchange. If the court agrees, 7.5 million people in those states could lose their subsidies, driving the price for their insurance policies up too high for them to afford.

The decision is also coming as many Americans who already do not qualify for coverage have been scrambling to find other ways to afford the mandatory healthcare plans. Many people who purchased the lower-cost silver or bronze individual plans on the exchanges have still seen their premiums and out-of-pocket payments climb from anywhere between 14 percent and 28 percent.

The Supreme Court's decision could also slam Americans who are facing insurance companies' calls for double-digit premium hikes in some states, like New Mexico, where Blue Cross Blue Shield has proposed a 50 percent premium increase for its Obamacare plans.

On the issue of same-sex marriage, the poll revealed that the court is currently divided on the issue, which is expected to be decided later this month. The court is considering cases from Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio, and Tennessee, four of the 14 remaining states that allow only heterosexual marriage.

Just 10 years ago, Massachusetts was the first state that allowed same-sex marriages, and as recently as last October, just one-third of states permitted the unions. Now, same-sex couples can marry in 36 states and Washington, D.C., marking a dramatic change in public opinion.

The CNN/ORC poll also showed that Chief Justice John Roberts' opinion among those polled is still positive, with 33 percent seeing him favorably and 24 percent unfavorably. This is a drop from 41 percent seeing him favorably after the court upheld the Obamacare individual mandate provision, the CNN poll shows. Roberts' decline was most marked among Democrats, with 51 percent of them seeing him favorably in 2012 compared to 35 percent now.

Title: Diplomatic Efforts Aimed at Ending Renewed Fighting in Eastern Ukraine

Article:

Diplomatic efforts are underway to end renewed fighting in eastern Ukraine, with French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel holding urgent talks in the capital Kiev. The leaders presented a new peace initiative, and US Secretary of State John Kerry, who is also in Kiev, stated that the US wanted a diplomatic solution but would not ignore Russian aggression.

Fighting between Ukrainian forces and pro-Russian rebels has resulted in nearly 5,400 deaths since April, according to the United Nations. Ukraine and the West have accused Russia of arming rebels in eastern Ukraine and sending regular troops across the border, while Russia denies direct involvement but acknowledges some Russian volunteers are fighting alongside the rebels.

Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko expressed hope for a ceasefire following the talks with Ms. Merkel and Mr. Hollande. Earlier, he thanked the German and French leaders for their visit at "a very urgent time." The German and French leaders made no public comments after Thursday's meeting, in what appeared to be a speedily arranged visit.

Ahead of the talks, Mr. Hollande said he and Mrs. Merkel would present a new peace proposal based on Ukraine's "territorial integrity," which could be "acceptable to all." Mr. Hollande and Mrs. Merkel will now meet Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow on Friday.

Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk stated that the country needs peace but will never consider anything that undermines its territorial integrity. US Secretary of State John Kerry accused Russia of violating Ukraine's sovereignty, stating that Russia had been acting with "impunity," crossing the Ukrainian border "at will with weapons [and] personnel."

The US is currently only providing "non-lethal" assistance, such as night-vision goggles and body armor. Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman Alexander Lukashevich stated that any decision by the US to supply weapons to Ukraine would "inflict colossal damage to Russian-American relations." Several senior Western officials have also expressed concern at the prospect of US arms being sent to Ukraine.

The consensus view up to now has been not to supply weapons, but to give non-lethal support like radars, medical gear, body-armor, and so on. Only Poland has explicitly stated that it might arm Ukraine if asked. Now, the balance of the debate is shifting in the US, but there is no clear will to provide weapons to the Kiev government. There is a growing sense of urgency and concern within NATO, and if diplomacy fails, arming Kiev may become a serious option.

A spokesman for the Kremlin said Mr. Putin would discuss "the fastest possible end to the civil war in south-eastern Ukraine." Correspondents say it is not clear how the latest attempt will differ from previous, aborted peace efforts, but there is speculation that Mr. Hollande and Mrs. Merkel hope to discourage the US from supplying Ukraine with weapons.

The talks in Kiev come as NATO unveils details of a plan to bolster its military presence in Eastern Europe in response to the Ukraine crisis. A new rapid reaction "spearhead" force of up to 5,000 troops is expected to be announced, with its lead units able to deploy at two days' notice. NATO is also establishing a network of small command centers in Estonia, Lithuania, Latvia, Poland, Romania, and Bulgaria.

Meanwhile, officials said on Thursday that the European Union is adding 19 people, including five Russians, to its sanctions list over the Ukraine crisis. Nine "entities" will also be targeted by the sanctions, which were reportedly agreed at an emergency meeting of EU foreign ministers last week. Fighting has intensified in eastern Ukraine in recent weeks amid a rebel offensive. The fiercest fighting has been near the town of Debaltseve, where rebels are trying to surround Ukrainian troops. The town is a crucial rail hub linking the rebel-held cities of Donetsk and Luhansk.

Some 1.2 million Ukrainians have fled their homes since last April, when the rebels seized a big swathe of the Luhansk and Donetsk regions following Russia's annexation of Crimea.

Title: GOP Leaders Meet to Discuss Party Unity Amidst Ongoing Tax Return Controversy and Split over Trump's Conservative Credentials

Article:

A meeting between former President Donald Trump and Speaker of the House Paul Ryan is being considered critical as Trump heads to Capitol Hill on Thursday to attempt to unify the Republican Party following a contentious primary election. House Republicans are urging Speaker Ryan to endorse their party's presumptive nominee, but Ryan, who has been hesitant to support Trump, emphasizes the importance of a unified front.

"To pretend we are unified as a party after coming through a very bruising primary, which just ended a week ago, to pretend to unify without actually unifying, then we go into the fall with half strength," Ryan stated.

The meeting takes place amid ongoing questions regarding Trump's refusal to release his tax returns. Trump has stated that he will not release them until after an Internal Revenue Service audit is completed, which may not occur until after the election. Democratic rival Hillary Clinton has seized on this issue, stating, "My husband and I have released 33 years of tax returns. So you got ta ask yourself why doesn't he want to release them?"

In terms of taxes, Politico reports that Trump has enlisted well-known conservative economists Larry Kudlow and Stephen Moore to help him revise his initial tax plan. The plan, according to one group, could potentially add an additional $10 trillion to $12 trillion to America's already burgeoning national debt, while promoting economic growth.

Trump has expressed his intention to ensure the middle class receives good tax breaks and to fight vigorously for businesses.

Furthermore, Trump is reportedly considering former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani to head a commission on radical Islam. The commission would study Trump's immigration policies, including his call for a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States.

More than a week after becoming the party's presumptive nominee, there remains a split within the GOP over Trump's conservative credentials. Despite questions about Trump's ability to defeat Clinton in November, a new Reuters poll places Trump and Clinton in a dead heat, with Clinton at 41 percent, Trump at 40 percent, and 19 percent undecided.

Title: Vice President Pence Rallies Conservatives at CPAC, Promises Repeal of Obamacare

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence addressed the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) on Thursday, rallying conservatives around President Donald Trump's agenda. In his speech, Pence emphasized the administration's commitment to keeping the promises made to the American people.

"President Trump is a man of his word, and we're in the promise-keeping business these days," Pence told the CPAC audience. He criticized the Democratic Party for making promises they could not fulfill and called for a renewed demonstration that "our answers are the right answers."

Pence outlined a four-point agenda: a strong military, more jobs, less taxes, respect for the Constitution, and a deep and abiding faith in the goodness of the American people. Despite former House Speaker John Boehner's statement on Thursday that Republicans would not repeal Obamacare but simply fix it, Pence maintained that the GOP would indeed repeal and replace the healthcare law.

"President Donald Trump is leading the fight to repeal and replace Obamacare. And let me assure you, America's Obamacare nightmare is about to end," Pence said. He added that the American people, despite the efforts of liberal activists, understand that Obamacare has failed and must be abolished.

Other key members of the Trump White House, including top advisers Steve Bannon and Reince Priebus, also spoke to the conservative crowd. Bannon stated that the battles between the media and the administration are far from over, and he predicted that they would worsen.

"It's not only not going to get better, it's going to get worse every day with the media. And here's why... By the way, the internal logic makes sense—they're corporatist, globalist media that are adamantly opposed, adamantly opposed to an economic nationalist agenda like Donald Trump has," Bannon said.

He emphasized that the Trump administration would continue to fight and encouraged the audience to hold the president's team accountable for delivering on the promises it has made. The specifics of the Obamacare replacement plan were not detailed in the provided text.

Title: Obama's State of the Union Address: A Repeat of Campaign Proposals and Emphasis on Executive Action

Article:

President Barack Obama's State of the Union address on Tuesday night could have been mistaken for a campaign speech from last year, as many of the proposals he presented were repeats of ideas that went unaddressed in a divided Washington during his re-election campaign. The president emphasized a balanced approach to deficit reduction, the need to protect the middle class, and the importance of reigniting "the true engine of America's economic growth."

The recovery remains weak, with unemployment at 7.9% and the nation's growth rate shrinking in the last three months of 2012. With much of his legacy potentially dependent on helping to reignite the economy, Obama proposed 15 manufacturing hubs to help spur high-tech job growth.

The president also addressed the impending $85 billion in automatic across-the-board spending cuts set to take effect on March 1, warning that they could lead to a recession. However, he did not offer any ground on what he would accept as an alternative, setting up the next major fiscal fight with Republicans.

Facing hundreds of members of the opposing party, Obama took a decidedly different approach than in his aggressive inaugural address. "They do expect us to put the nation's interests before party. They do expect us to forge reasonable compromise where we can," the president said early in the address.

He praised some Republicans, such as Sen. John McCain, his 2008 opponent, for their work on climate change, and mentioned his 2012 opponent, Mitt Romney, for his idea of tying the minimum wage to the cost of living.

While the president talked about the potential for bipartisan approaches on tax and immigration reform, Republicans may be expected to say they have not seen a different approach from the president on many key issues. The president wants more tax revenues and more government spending on his priorities, which are non-starters among Republicans.

The proposals Obama floated included making high-quality preschool available to every child, providing tax credits for businesses to hire and invest, promoting more scientific research and development, further shifting cars and trucks away from gasoline, and investing in infrastructure. "Nothing I'm proposing tonight should increase our deficit by a single dime," he said. "It's not a bigger government we need, but a smarter government that sets priorities and invests in broad-based growth."

However, White House officials refused to put a price tag on the programs or to reveal how, in fact, they would be paid for. They promised more details when the White House's budget proposal is released in a few weeks.

The president also demonstrated his plans to aggressively use executive actions to push policy if Congress thwarts him. He announced action on climate change and cybersecurity, stating, "If Congress won't act soon to protect future generations, I will." He directed his Cabinet to come up with executive actions to reduce pollution, prepare communities for the consequences of climate change, and speed the transition to more sustainable sources of energy.

After efforts dealing with cybersecurity failed to pass Congress, the president signed an executive order to increase information-sharing and to help the private sector develop standards. These moves came after the president last month approved 23 executive actions dealing with gun control.

Obama also used the speech to address his base by emphasizing liberal priorities such as climate change and equal treatment and benefits for gay Americans, as well as announcing a bipartisan commission to improve the voting system and pushing for a hike in the minimum wage.

The White House tried to build up suspense around what the president would say, but as soon as news broke Tuesday afternoon that accused cop-killer Christopher Dorner was believed to be holed up in a cabin in the California mountains, much of the media immediately switched gears. What would have been hours of coverage of the speech, the president's message, and discussion of his agenda did not happen.

Would this be another split-screen State of the Union, similar to when networks flashed news of the verdict in O.J. Simpson's civil trial during Bill Clinton's 1997 address? That did not happen this time, but as soon as Obama wrapped up, most news organizations quickly updated viewers on the Dorner story. However, the president might have gotten an unintended benefit from the other story of the day—interest in Dorner might have helped boost the audience for the address.

Title: Macron, Merkel, and Other Leaders to Launch Global COVID-19 Fight Initiative; US Declines Participation

Article:

French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel will join a global initiative to accelerate efforts in fighting COVID-19, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced on Friday. However, the United States has declined participation.

The WHO announced late on Thursday that it would unveil a "landmark collaboration" on Friday to expedite the development of safe, effective drugs, tests, and vaccines to prevent, diagnose, and treat COVID-19. WHO spokeswoman Fadela Chaib revealed this during a United Nations briefing on Friday, stating that Macron, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, British Foreign Minister Dominic Raab, and United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres would take part in the 1300 GMT announcement, led by WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.

According to diplomatic sources, Raab and Guterres will participate in the event. Chaib explained that the aim of the collaboration is to ensure that when new tools become available, no one is left behind, and that those who can afford vaccines or therapeutics will make them accessible to the global population.

A spokesman for the US mission in Geneva confirmed that the United States would not take part in the initiative. "There will be no US official participation," he said in an email response to a query. "We look forward to learning more about this initiative in support of international cooperation to develop a vaccine for COVID-19 as soon as possible."

US President Donald Trump has criticized the WHO for its slow response to the outbreak and for being "China-centric." He announced a suspension of funding. When asked whether the United States would participate in the meeting, a WHO source said, "No, but almost everyone else is."

More than 2.7 million people have been infected with the disease, which has claimed nearly 190,000 lives since emerging in the central Chinese city of Wuhan late last year, according to a Reuters tally. Over 100 potential COVID-19 vaccines are being developed, including six already in clinical trials, said Dr. Seth Berkley, CEO of the GAVI vaccine alliance, a public-private partnership that leads immunization campaigns in poor countries.

"We need to ensure that there are enough vaccines for everyone," Berkley said during a separate Geneva news briefing before taking part in the formal WHO announcement. "We are going to need global leadership to identify and prioritize vaccine candidates."

Global manufacturing capacity must be increased ahead of choosing "a winner" vaccine, Berkley said, noting that GAVI and the World Bank are looking at the issue. "We can't have a repeat of what happened in 2009, the H1N1 vaccine, when there was not enough supply for developing countries or when supply did come, it came much later," he said.

Another important question is how well a vaccine will work in people most at risk from COVID-19, Berkley said. "How well do they work in the elderly? Are they single or multiple dose etc.?" he said, noting that older people have weaker immune systems.

Title: North Carolina Democratic Convention Faces Multiple Challenges Ahead of Presidential Nominating Event

Article:

The upcoming Democratic National Convention (DNC) in Charlotte, North Carolina, is facing multiple challenges as President Barack Obama prepares to accept his party's nomination. The convention, initially envisioned as a triumphant and unifying event, is being overshadowed by a series of scandals, boycotts, and financial woes.

One issue arises from an ongoing sexual harassment scandal within the North Carolina Democratic Party (NCDP). In early 2013, former party communications staffer Adriadn Ortega accused former executive director Jay Parmley of repeated sexual harassment and physical groping. Leaked documents revealed a financial settlement involving the two men, leading to Ortega's termination and Parmley's resignation. The party has been embroiled in a crisis since, with local candidates expressing concern about the potential impact on the election.

Another challenge comes from Democratic officials choosing to boycott the convention to avoid association with President Obama himself. At least seven Democratic representatives, including Bill Owens and Kathy Hochul from New York, Mark Critz from Pennsylvania, and Earl Ray Tomblin, Joe Manchin, and Nick Rahall from West Virginia, have announced they will not attend. The reasons for their boycott range from disagreements on immigration policy to criticisms of Obama's jobs programs and his stance on coal.

The convention's left-leaning supporters are also expressing dissent. Progressives, who gave Obama a pass during his first term, are critical of the decision to deliver the presidential nomination acceptance speech at Bank of America Stadium. The bank, which received a $45 billion banking bailout in 2008 and an estimated $931 billion in secret federal emergency loans, is a source of contention for some Democrats.

In addition to these internal challenges, the convention is facing external opposition. Thousands of anarchists, socialists, and professional agitators plan to protest in Charlotte. The DNC's association with Bank of America, a financially troubled bank with a history of political contributions to Obama, is also a point of contention for some progressive Democrats.

The DNC, initially billed as "The People's Convention," is being criticized for its association with Bank of America and the ongoing scandals within the NCDP. The event promises to be a public relations challenge for Obama's campaign team.

Title: President Obama's Tennessee Visit Met with Criticism Over ACA Impact

Article:

President Obama's visit to Tennessee, aimed at celebrating the Supreme Court's upholding of Obamacare subsidies for individuals in states without state-based exchanges, has been met with criticism from Republican Representative Diane Black of Tennessee.

Rep. Black, a former nurse, suggested that the president should have researched the impact of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) in Tennessee before choosing the state for his visit. In a statement, she criticized the ACA for causing a 36% premium increase for Obamacare customers in the state, contradicting the president's promise of average savings of $2,500 per year for families. She also pointed out the 28,000 Tennesseans who lost their insurance coverage in a single day, despite the president's pledge that individuals could keep their health care plans if they liked them.

A nationwide CNN poll revealed that twice as many Americans were hurt by Obamacare than benefited from it. The impact was particularly felt in Tennessee, where state-sponsored insurance programs, relied on by thousands of residents, were effectively shut down due to the ACA. Families covered by AccessTN, a program for people with pre-existing medical conditions, and by CoverRX, a prescription benefits program, are receiving letters explaining the changes. The 16,000 people enrolled in CoverTN, a limited benefits plan, have already been notified that it will end on December 31. Many families have also received notice that they will no longer be able to buy into CoverKids.

Rep. Black's statement underscores the challenges faced by families in Tennessee due to the ACA. The full repeal of the ACA remains a priority for Black and her conservative colleagues.

Title: Bipartisan Budget Deal: A Compromise Between Republicans and Democrats

Article:

The recently crafted bipartisan budget deal between Republican Rep. Paul Ryan and Democratic Sen. Patty Murray has received mixed reviews, with the Los Angeles Times stating that it "has something for everyone to dislike." The deal, which aims to avoid a government shutdown during the Christmas break, has been criticized by both parties.

According to the Los Angeles Times, the agreement does not cut federal spending or reduce the national debt, which displeases conservative Republicans. On the other hand, it does not restore much funding for domestic programs or extend unemployment insurance, which disappoints Democrats.

The Washington Post reports that the deal denies both Republicans and Democrats their most desired outcomes. Republicans did not secure any changes to Medicare and Social Security, while Democrats did not receive any new taxes.

NPR's Tamara Keith, on Morning Edition, summarized the agreement as follows: "The deal...would set the federal budget at just about $1 trillion this year and next. It would replace a big chunk of the sequester cuts with other trims and increased fees. And that's pretty much it."

Ryan may face challenges in selling the deal to skeptical House conservatives, as reported by The National Journal. However, Ryan, who is known for his fiscal conservatism, seems confident in his ability to persuade his colleagues. During a Tuesday press conference, Ryan emphasized that the agreement reduces the deficit without raising taxes and addresses long-ignored mandatory spending.

The deal has received varied reactions from other news outlets. Fox News headlined their article as "Conservative groups sound alarm over tentative budget deal," while the Wall Street Journal titled their editorial "A Least Bad Budget Deal." Reuters and The Financial Times published headlines suggesting the deal could usher in a new era of cooperation, while USA Today reported that the House is on track to vote on the deal on Thursday.

Sen. Patty Murray, in an interview with Morning Edition host Steve Inskeep, described the agreement as a compromise, stating, "Neither one of us got everything we wanted and we were able to keep the other person from getting some of the big things they wanted, and that's called compromise."

Title: Former House Majority Leader Dick Armey Leaves Conservative Group FreedomWorks Over Disagreements on Future Direction

Article:

Washington, D.C. — Former Republican House Majority Leader Dick Armey has left the conservative Tea Party group, FreedomWorks, following a $8 million payout from a prominent GOP fundraiser, according to a contract obtained by The Associated Press. The contract, dated September 24, stipulates that Armey would resign from his role as chairman of both FreedomWorks and its sister organization, the FreedomWorks Foundation, by the end of November.

The payout, in annual $400,000 installments, is to be provided by Richard J. Stephenson, a board member of FreedomWorks and the founder and chairman of the Cancer Treatment Centers of America, a national cancer treatment network.

Armey's departure comes amidst growing acrimony within conservative and Republican ranks as the party grapples with its November electoral losses and uncertainty over its future direction. Armey confirmed his departure on Tuesday, stating that his departure was a matter of principle. He declined to elaborate on his specific concerns but told the Mother Jones website that the Tea Party group was moving in an unproductive direction.

In an internal resignation memo published by Mother Jones, Armey requested that FreedomWorks CEO Matt Kibbe remove his name, image, and signature from all group materials and web operations. Kibbe and other FreedomWorks officials were not immediately available for comment.

Armey, who co-founded FreedomWorks in 2004, is a veteran Texas GOP political figure who was intimately involved in the GOP's conservative "Contract with America" congressional movement in the 1990s. While Armey, 72, was the group's public face, FreedomWorks' most active official, Matt Kibbe, has been its most visible figure, appearing at FreedomWorks' public gatherings.

FreedomWorks flourished after a wave of Tea Party House candidates swept into office in 2010, but despite spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to back favored GOP candidates in November, the group's influence appeared to wane at the polls. Among the GOP losers supported by FreedomWorks in November were Senate candidates Josh Mandel in Ohio, Connie Mack in Florida, and Richard Mourdock in Indiana.

Overall, Tea Party-influenced House legislators fared better in the recent elections, though their ranks thinned. At least 83 of 87 Republican House members who were allied with Tea Party anti-government spending causes ran for re-election in November, and all but eleven were returned to office. A twelfth, Rep. Jeff Landry (R-La.), faces an uphill runoff election this month against another GOP incumbent.

FreedomWorks' internal secrecy and its role as a high-financed super political action committee became an issue in the weeks before the election when federal campaign finance documents revealed that a shadowy Tennessee-based corporation had funneled seven donations totaling $5.28 million to the Tea Party group. The amount was the largest political contribution to a super PAC in 2012 from a business group that would not identify its donor.

FreedomWorks would not identify the anonymous donor, and a Tennessee lawyer who helped set up the group would also not divulge the head of the firm, Specialty Group Inc. The Tennessee firm later changed its name to Specialty Investments Group Inc. on November 28.

Title: "Clinton Ally's Political Organization Aids Campaign of FBI Official's Wife"

Article:

In a development that has sparked renewed Republican criticism, a top political ally of Hillary Clinton's donated nearly half a million dollars to the campaign of the wife of an FBI official who would later oversee part of the investigation into Clinton's email practices. The revelation, first reported by The Wall Street Journal, has fueled fresh complaints about the investigation's integrity.

At a rally in Florida on Monday, Donald Trump cited the findings, stating, "We've never had a thing like this in the history of this country." The Journal reported that Virginia Governor Terry McAuliffe's Political Action Committee (PAC) donated $467,500 to Dr. Jill McCabe's 2015 state Senate campaign. The Virginia Democratic Party also contributed an additional $207,788 to the campaign, according to the Journal.

Dr. McCabe, who lost to Republican incumbent Dick Black, is married to Andrew McCabe, the FBI's deputy director. At the time of the campaign and of McAuliffe's support, McCabe was an associate deputy director. He was later promoted to deputy after the campaign ended, assuming an oversight role in the Clinton email investigation.

McCabe reportedly sought ethics guidance from the FBI and followed it, but his supervision of the email case was not seen as a potential conflict since Jill McCabe's campaign was over, and McAuliffe was not directly involved in the email case. The FBI's "Ethics and Integrity Program" manual makes clear that McCabe would have had to flag the connections to senior management, and the final decision would come in writing.

In the section prohibiting employees from participating in criminal investigations in certain cases where there's a personal or political relationship, the manual states that an exception would be if "The employee's participation would not create an appearance of a conflict of interest to affect the public perception of the integrity of the investigation or prosecution."

The FBI, in a statement, confirmed that McCabe sought internal guidance "to prevent against any actual or potential conflict-of-interest" and when his wife chose to run, "McCabe and FBI lawyers implemented a system of recusal from all FBI investigative matters involving Virginia politics, a process followed for the remainder of her campaign." During the campaign, he played no role, attended no events, and did not participate in fundraising or support of any kind.

However, a law enforcement official acknowledged an optics issue, given that while McCabe was barred from investigations into Virginia politics, the donation did come from the Virginia governor.

McAuliffe and other state figures reportedly recruited Dr. McCabe to run in the first place, but a spokesman pushed back on any suggestion of impropriety. McAuliffe "supported Jill McCabe because he believed she would be a good state senator. This is a customary practice for Virginia governors... Any insinuation that his support was tied to anything other than his desire to elect candidates who would help pass his agenda is ridiculous," the spokesman told the Journal.

McCabe continues to be involved in the email investigation aftermath. He was recently asked to brief House Oversight Committee members on allegations – contained in newly released FBI files – that a State Department official offered a "quid pro quo" with the bureau in a bid to un-classify a particular server email.

The revelations in the Wall Street Journal report could dovetail with Donald Trump's persistent claims that the Justice Department and FBI investigation into Clinton's email use was compromised. Trump has repeatedly complained about Attorney General Loretta Lynch meeting with Bill Clinton on a Phoenix tarmac days before the FBI announced no charges in its Clinton investigation.

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus said in a statement that the funding looked like a "down payment" to influence the FBI probe. "Given all we know about how the corrupt Clinton machine operates, it's hard not to see this as anything other than a down payment to influence the FBI's criminal investigation into Hillary Clinton's private email server," Priebus said.

According to the same report, the PAC and Virginia Democratic Party money amounted to more than a third of Dr. McCabe's campaign funds. She also reportedly was the third-largest recipient of the governor's Common Good VA funds.

Title: Congress Fails to Act on Sequestration Cuts as Finger-Pointing and Political Blame Intensifies

Article:

In a day of political maneuvering and finger-pointing, Congress failed to take any significant action on the impending $85 billion in forced spending cuts, known as sequestration. The cuts, set to take effect in four days, were the main topic of discussion as members of Congress returned from their week-long recess.

There were no votes scheduled until the late afternoon, with the GOP-controlled House focusing on a bill to rename a NASA flight research center at Southern California's Edwards Air Force Base after Neil Armstrong, the late astronaut who was the first man to step foot on the moon. The bill is sponsored by House Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy (R-California).

In the Democratic-controlled Senate, members were scheduled to vote on the nomination of a new judge for the 10th Circuit.

Despite the lack of action on the sequestration issue, there were numerous accusations and finger-pointing throughout the day. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina) appeared on CNN and stated that there was not enough time to work out a deal, saying, "So sequestration is going to happen." He added, "We do not need new taxes to run the government, we need new taxes to get out of debt."

Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) and other House GOP leaders met with reporters on Capitol Hill, stepping up their effort to blame President Barack Obama for the unpopular cuts. Boehner stated, "The president proposed [these cuts]. And yet he's far more interested in holding campaign rallies than he is in urging his Senate Democrats to actually pass a plan."

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nevada) responded by warning that 70,000 kids would be kicked out of the Head Start program if the planned governmentwide cuts are set in motion. He also stated that air traffic controllers, FBI, and border patrol agents will be placed on furlough.

House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Maryland) took to the House floor to argue that while many "Republicans have been praising the sequester as a viable path forward, Democrats recognize this mindless policy for the danger it is." Hoyer urged Republicans to either work with the Democrats or "abandon this reckless policy."

One development to watch closely is that Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and his Republican counterpart, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, are expected to introduce their own bills for replacing the cuts early this week. It remains to be seen whether this will be more political posturing or the start of a bipartisan effort to give Obama more flexibility in implementing the cuts.

Title: Over 750 Arrested During Opposition Protest in Moscow Ahead of City Council Elections

Article:

More than 779 individuals were arrested during a demonstration in Moscow on Saturday, according to OVD-Info, a Russian organization that monitors political arrests. The protest, organized by opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, was held outside city hall, where demonstrators were calling for fair elections following the exclusion of opposition candidates from the upcoming city council elections on Sept. 8.

The Moscow police initially reported 295 arrests but did not provide a final figure until later. The protest was reportedly unauthorized by the government, and people were seen clashing with police officers and shouting slogans such as "Russia will be free!" and "Who are you beating?"

Opposition politician Ilya Yashin was among those arrested, with his Facebook page stating that 10 masked officers took him from his apartment in Moscow the night before the demonstration. Navalny, who was arrested and sentenced to 30 days in jail on Wednesday, posted on Instagram, "I have been detained and am now at a police station wearing shorts like a stupid man."

The opposition politicians' names were reportedly not included on the ballot because they had not received enough signatures to qualify, according to election officials. Supporters of the opposition party argue that the government is forcing them out, preventing their participation in the elections.

Helmeted police reportedly barged into Navalny's video studio during a YouTube broadcast of the protest and arrested program leader Vladimir Milonov. Police also searched Dozhd, an internet TV station covering the protest, and its editor in chief Alexandra Perepelova was ordered to undergo questioning at the Investigative Committee.

The exact charges the detainees may face remain unclear. The September vote for Moscow's city council, which has 45 seats, has become a significant event in Russia's political scene, as the Kremlin grapples with opposing views in its capital of 12.6 million. The city council, responsible for a large municipal budget, is currently controlled by the pro-Kremlin United Russia party. All of its seats, which have a five-year term, are up for grabs in the Sept. 8 vote.

Over 22,000 people gathered for a protest in downtown Moscow last Saturday, marking one of the largest demonstrations in years.

Title: Senate Panel Endorses Hagel for Pentagon Leadership in Party-Line Vote

Article:

The Senate Armed Services Committee narrowly endorsed Chuck Hagel's nomination to lead the Pentagon on Tuesday in a 14-11 vote that underscored intense Republican opposition to his nomination. The vote advanced Hagel to the floor for a final decision, with all Republicans present voting against him.

Hagel, a former Republican senator from Nebraska, is a twice-wounded Vietnam War combat veteran. His supporters lauded his service, while critics pointed to his history of controversial votes and statements regarding Iran, Israel, terror groups, the Iraq war, and other issues.

Republican lawmakers had various reasons for opposing Hagel or trying to hold up his nomination. Some wanted him to provide more financial background information. Others voiced interest in holding up the nomination until the administration provides more information about the Benghazi terror attack, while voicing concerns about Hagel's background as well.

Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., criticized Hagel's performance during his confirmation hearing, stating, "His performance before this committee was the worst that I have seen for any nominee for office." Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., also opposed Hagel, saying, "There are very few people who have been this wrong about so many things."

Democratic Chairman Carl Levin, however, pushed for a vote just hours before President Obama was set to deliver his State of the Union address. "The time has come for the committee to act on this nomination," Levin said.

Obama tapped Hagel, 66, to succeed Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, who is stepping down after four years as CIA director and Pentagon chief. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat, is pressing for a full Senate vote later this week, most likely on Thursday.

Hagel now faces Republican delaying tactics in the full Senate, with the panel's top Republican, Sen. Jim Inhofe, insisting that any confirmation be based on 60 votes rather than a majority of the 100-member Senate. However, this effort has divided Republicans, with several longtime members opposed to the unprecedented step of stalling, or filibustering, a president's Cabinet nominee for Defense secretary.
