Late Monday, McCain met privately with several committee Republicans and urged them not to filibuster the Hagel nomination, pointing out that the roles could be reversed someday with a Republican president and Republican-controlled Senate. "I'm encouraging my colleagues if they want to vote against Sen. Hagel that's one thing and that's a principled stand," McCain told a group of reporters. "We do not want to filibuster. We have not filibustered a Cabinet appointee in the past and I believe that we should move forward with his nomination, bring it to the floor and vote up or down."

All 55 Democrats are expected to back Hagel, and two Republicans—Sens. Thad Cochran and Mike Johanns—have said they will vote for the nominee. At least five Republicans, including McCain, have said they oppose a filibuster despite their reservations or opposition toward the nominee. More than a dozen Republicans have said they will oppose their former colleague, and several others have indicated they are likely to vote no. Sen. Kelly Ayotte, a Republican member of the Armed Services Committee, said Tuesday she would vote against the nominee, citing his performance at his confirmation hearing.

Title: Republican Party Elders Express Concern Over Conservative Lawmakers' Shutdown Strategy

Article:

A split among Republicans is becoming increasingly apparent in town hall meetings across the country, with the focus on a strategy by a new group of conservative lawmakers to shut down the federal government in protest of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. This strategy, primarily championed by lawmakers elected in the past few years, has exposed a rift in the GOP about how best to deal with the controversial health care law a year before the 2014 elections.

The plan, more of a bargaining strategy, is not supported by a critical mass of Republicans, even as 13 lawmakers have signed a letter pledging opposition to any spending bill that does not defund the health law. To be successful, supporters of a government shutdown would need almost every Republican in the Senate to join their effort.

The GOP establishment is undoubtedly against a shutdown, with many of them becoming more vocal about it. Former 2012 GOP presidential nominee Mitt Romney this week at a New Hampshire fundraiser expressed concern about the possibility of a shutdown, stating that it would result in Medicare benefits being skipped and troops not getting paid. Arizona Sen. John McCain said on the conservative Michael Medved radio show last month that most Americans are tired of such Washington shenanigans.

Prominent conservative opinion maker, columnist Charles Krauthammer, called the idea "nuts." Oklahoma Sen. Tom Coburn, who has shown a willingness to disrupt government if he disagrees with something, told the Washington Examiner that a shutdown could cost Republicans control of the House. His Oklahoma colleague, Rep. Tom Cole, said on Fox News that shutting down the government would be like a legislative "temper tantrum."

However, there is evidence that many in the outspoken party base would seriously disagree. Tea party activists have posted a video critical of freshman North Carolina Rep. Rob Pittenger, who drew jeers when he said during a town hall event in his district this week that the party should not shut the government down. In an interview with CNN's Jim Acosta on Wednesday, Pittenger defended his decision to stand against tea party activists who called for a shutdown to defund Obamacare.

But Pittenger appears to be an exception as a younger lawmaker standing against shutdown proponents. "The reality is, if we're willing to take a government shutdown unless we repeal Obamacare,... we will lose that vote and Obamacare will survive it," Pittenger said. "Why would we go about a strategy that is doomed to failure?"

Seeking to find middle ground in the party, a separate group of conservatives, including anti-tax activist Grover Norquist, have suggested instead to use the threat of shutdown to force a one-year delay in implementing the law in place of pursuing a full repeal.

Backlash against Obamacare helped propel Republicans to take back control of the House in 2010. However, exhaustive efforts since to repeal it have been ineffective. Utah Sen. Mike Lee, the leader of the shutdown effort, was elected in 2010 after defeating longtime Republican Sen. Bob Bennett in the primary.

While Lee's proposal to shut down the government is not embraced by establishment Republicans, it has drawn praise from Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, two conservative stars who are believed to be considering runs for president in 2016. Both also, like Lee, defeated more establishment GOP candidates on their way to Washington in 2010.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, who has not taken a definitive position on the shutdown plan, is now facing a primary challenge in his bid for reelection in Kentucky. Add to all of this the default, shutdown, economic calamity show that has been a Washington rerun due to a string of battles over the federal borrowing limit and government spending. These conservative newcomers to Washington have seen the White House make dire warnings about how the recent forced spending cuts, known formally as sequestration, would have a negative effect on the government and military.

However, months later, the forced spending cuts have been largely swept out of the news, and the federal government—from the Pentagon to the Health and Human Services Department—has shown an ability to absorb it for now. Cruz recently argued in a speech at the Heritage Foundation that shutting down the government would not be that bad and could help the GOP. "There are some Democrats, some in the media, and some Republicans who portray a shutdown as a horrible calamity," Cruz said. "I think the term'shutdown' is a misnomer. It's actually a partial, temporary shutdown. We have seen them before."

Cruz argued that Saturday and Sunday are kind of like government shutdowns. However, it is Romney, who has acknowledged that he's probably the last person Republicans are now looking to for advice, who gave the most earnest argument on Tuesday against shutting down the government. "I badly want Obamacare to go away, and stripping it of funds has appeal," said Romney, according to a prepared text of his remarks at the private fundraiser. "But we need to exercise great care about any talk of shutting down government. What would come next...what would come next when soldiers are not paid, when seniors fear for their Medicare and Social Security, and when the FBI is off duty? I'm afraid that in the final analysis, Obamacare would get its funding, our party would suffer in the next elections, and the people of the nation would not be happy."

A spokesman for Cruz responded to Romney on Wednesday, arguing that Americans see Obamacare as "a train wreck." "They expect their elected representatives to fight to undo it," said Cruz spokesman Sean Ruston. "If Republicans stand up for principle, we can win this debate."

Title: Judge Kavanaugh Accepts President Trump's Nomination to the Supreme Court

Article:

Brett Kavanaugh, a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, accepted President Trump's nomination to succeed Justice Anthony Kennedy on the Supreme Court on July 9. Kavanaugh's family, including his wife Ashley, daughters Margaret and Liza, his mother Martha, and father Ed, were present at the White House for the announcement.

Kavanaugh, in his speech, highlighted his 28-year career as a lawyer, primarily in public service. He discussed his 12-year tenure as a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals and his five-year service in the White House for President George W. Bush. Kavanaugh emphasized his long-standing record of advancing and promoting women, with a majority of his 48 law clerks being women and his history of coaching girls' basketball teams.

Kavanaugh stated that a good judge should be an "umpire" - a neutral and impartial arbiter who does not favor any political party, litigant, or policy. He explained that he has ruled for both prosecution and criminal defendants, workers and businesses, environmentalists, and coal miners, following the law in each case. Kavanaugh stated that he is not a pro-plaintiff or pro-defendant judge, nor is he a pro-prosecution or pro-defense judge. He is, according to Kavanaugh, a "pro-law judge."

Kavanaugh emphasized the importance of an independent judiciary, stating that the Supreme Court is the last line of defense for the separation of powers and the rights and liberties guaranteed by the Constitution. He stressed that the Supreme Court should not be viewed as a partisan institution, and if confirmed, he would be a team player, committed to deciding cases according to the Constitution and laws of the United States.

During the confirmation process, Kavanaugh met with 65 senators, participated in more than 30 hours of hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee, and submitted written answers to nearly 1,300 additional questions. Kavanaugh was subjected to allegations that he stated were wrongful and sometimes vicious, which affected his family and led to vile and violent threats against his wife and daughters.

Kavanaugh testified before the Judiciary Committee last Thursday to defend his family, his good name, and his lifetime of public service. His testimony reflected his frustration at being wrongly accused without corroboration of horrible conduct contrary to his record and character. Kavanaugh stated that he was emotional during the hearing, and he might have been too emotional at times.

Kavanaugh concluded by reaffirming his commitment to being the same kind of judge and person he has been for his entire 28-year legal career: hardworking, even-keeled, open-minded, independent, and dedicated to the Constitution and the public good. He emphasized his respect for colleagues and litigants and his reputation for courtesy on and off the bench. Kavanaugh stated that he will continue to be the same kind of judge he has been for the last 12 years and will continue to contribute to the country as a coach, volunteer, and teacher. He expressed his optimism and commitment to seeing the day that is coming, not the day that is gone.

Kavanaugh reiterated his reverence for the Constitution and his belief in an independent and impartial judiciary as essential to the constitutional republic. If confirmed by the Senate to serve on the Supreme Court, Kavanaugh pledged to keep an open mind in every case and always strive to preserve the Constitution of the United States and the American rule of law.

Title: U.S. Military Reports Failed Attempt to Strike Iranian Commander in Yemen

Article:

The U.S. military reportedly attempted, but failed, to carry out an airstrike targeting Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) commander Abdul Reza Shahlai in Yemen on the same night as the successful airstrike that eliminated Qassem Soleimani, the commander of the Iranian Quds force, in Iraq.

U.S. military officials, speaking anonymously, confirmed the unsuccessful strike against Shahlai, a key figure in financing the Iranian military force. The State Department has stated that Shahlai "has a long history of targeting Americans and U.S. allies globally," and planned multiple assassinations of coalition forces in Iraq. His activities were said to include providing weapons and explosives to Shia militia groups and directing a plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador in Washington eight years ago.

The revelation of the failed strike comes as the Trump administration is defending the military necessity of the strike in the face of skepticism from Democrats and even some Republicans on Capitol Hill.

Pentagon spokesperson Navy Cmdr. Rebecca Rebarich, in a statement to The Washington Post, which first reported the second mission, said, "We have seen the report of a January 2 airstrike in Yemen, which is long understood as a safe space for terrorists and other adversaries to the United States." Cmdr. Rebarich declined to discuss the operation or confirm the failed strike.

Defense Secretary Mark Esper, in a tweet on Friday afternoon, avoided explicitly addressing reports of the failed strike but said, "I want the American people to rest assured knowing they have the best military in the world. As we defend our people and interests in the Middle East, we continue to call on Iran to de-escalate the situation and cease its malign activities throughout the region."

Title: Trump Presides Over First Security Council Session, Iran Policy Tensions Expected

Article:

Donald Trump will preside over his first United Nations Security Council session today, with Iran policy expected to be a primary point of contention. The US president's efforts to isolate Iran and his rejection of globalism are likely to face determined opposition from fellow leaders.

The US ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, has predicted the session to be "the most watched security council meeting ever." However, it may further deepen perceptions of Trump's increasing isolation on the world stage, following the UN General Assembly's open laughter at Trump's boasts about his achievements.

US allies, including the UK's Prime Minister, Theresa May, and French President, Emmanuel Macron, side with Russia and China in their opposition to Trump's withdrawal from the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran. They are uneasy about US saber-rattling towards Tehran.

French President Macron, in his own address to the UN General Assembly on Tuesday, presented himself as an alternative leader of the western world, flatly rejecting Trump's appeal for national "patriotism" to take precedence over multilateral action.

"Nationalism always leads to defeat," Macron said. "If courage is lacking in the defense of fundamental principles, international order becomes fragile and this can lead, as we have already seen twice, to global war. We saw that with our very own eyes."

While Trump's address was met with a mix of laughter, murmurs, long periods of silence, and polite applause at the end, Macron's speech was given a rapturous reception.

Trump is chairing the meeting because the US currently holds the rotating presidency of the security council. The original plan was to devote the session to Iran, to allow Trump to highlight Iran's role in the Syrian and Yemeni conflict, its missile developments, and the full range of what Washington calls Tehran's malign activities.

However, the administration came to fear that this would also highlight the transatlantic rifts over the Iran nuclear deal, from which Trump withdrew in May, as his fellow leaders are equally determined to speak in defense of the agreement. The Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani, would also have had a right to attend and to speak in a session exclusively about his country.

The subject of Wednesday's session has therefore been widened to counter-proliferation, including North Korea, but Iran is still likely to be a central point of contention.

The Trump administration has set out its campaign against Iran at the UN General Assembly, producing a special booklet, "Outlaw Regime," chronicling Iran's "destructive activities."

The US sent several senior officials to a conference organized by anti-Tehran activists, United Against a Nuclear Iran (UANI), to denounce the Iranian government. The national security adviser, John Bolton, issued a series of threats, saying that Iran would "have 'hell to pay' if it does not change its behavior."

Bolton singled out the commander of the external arm of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, Qassem Soleimani, who has led the Iranian military campaign in Syria in support of the Assad regime, and IRGC operations in Iraq.

"We will use every tool available to pursue Soleimani and others like him," Bolton said. "Iran's leadership will no longer enjoy a life of security and luxury while their people suffer and starve."

Bolton stressed that the campaign against Soleimani would focus on funding and arms supplies. However, asked for clarification later, the US envoy on Iran and the head of the state department Iran Action Group, Brian Hook, did not rule out military action. Asked what Bolton meant by using "every available tool" against Soleimani, Hook said: "I think it speaks for itself."

"So, looking at Iraq with Soleimani, the IRGC is responsible for so much violence and bloodshed in the Middle East, and as part of restoring our deterrence, we will be focusing on him and his operations," Hook said.

In his own remarks to the UANI conference, the secretary of state, Mike Pompeo, said that an Iranian-backed militia was responsible for rocket attacks against the US embassy compound in Baghdad and the US consulate in Basra, in southern Iraq. He warned that the US would respond directly against Iran in the event of another such attack from Iran, or a militia deemed to be an Iranian proxy.

"The United States will hold the regime in Tehran accountable for any attack that results in injury to our personnel or damage to our facilities. America will respond swiftly and decisively in defense of American lives, and we will respond against the source of the attack on American interests," Pompeo said.

The National Iranian American Council condemned the administration's rhetoric, noting Bolton's role in the buildup to the ill-fated Iraq invasion in 2003.

"No serious person believes that Bolton and this administration is working towards a diplomatic end with Iran," the NIAC statement said. "He earned his credentials in the Bush White House as an Iraq war architect, he made his intentions for war with Iran well-known as a private citizen, and he is now putting that plan into action."

Title: FBI Team Deployed to Aid Investigation of Lebanese Intelligence Official's Assassination

Article:

An FBI team is en route to Lebanon to assist in the investigation of the assassination of Brigadier General Wissam al-Hassan, a top Lebanese intelligence official, who was killed in a car bombing last week. The assassination has triggered sporadic clashes across Lebanon.

According to a lawmaker, Ahmad Fatfat, al-Hassan was on his way to discuss a recent threat allegedly linked to Syria when he was assassinated last Friday. The car bomb killed al-Hassan, a bodyguard, and a bystander, 30 minutes before he was to meet with Lebanese lawmaker Amar Houri to discuss a threatening text message sent to the lawmaker from a Syrian phone number. Similar threats had been sent via text message to three other lawmakers, including Fatfat, although they did not realize it until after al-Hassan's assassination. All four are members of Lebanon's Future Movement, the largest member of the vocally anti-Syrian March 14 political coalition led by Saad Hariri.

After al-Hassan's assassination, Fatfat said he and his colleagues received another text from a similar phone number threatening further killings: "Congratulations, the countdown has started," the text read. "One of ten."

Al-Hassan, who was killed along with a bodyguard and a bystander, was an icon among many fellow Sunni Muslims for his leadership and efforts in rooting out those responsible for targeted killings in Lebanon. However, he angered others, especially those backing Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and many affiliated with Hezbollah, the Shiite militant and political movement that has a prominent role in Lebanon's government. The U.S. government labels it a terrorist organization. Hezbollah is widely popular with many of Lebanon's Shiite Muslims.

The lawmakers had told al-Hassan about the threatening texts they had received before Friday's attack, and al-Hassan had agreed to meet with one of them Friday to discuss the details.

U.S. State Department spokesman Mark Toner said Monday that an FBI team will be sent to Lebanon to assist in the investigation into al-Hassan's death.

Since the assassination, sporadic fighting has erupted across Lebanon, threatening to plunge the country into chaos and raising fears that it could be drawn into the bloody 19-month-old civil war in neighboring Syria. After al-Hassan's funeral Sunday, angry protesters clashed with security forces and rushed toward the prime minister's office, calling for his dismissal.

By midday Monday, at least three people had been killed in the northern city of Tripoli, while another person was killed in the southern city of Sidon, and another killed in Beirut, Lebanon's official National News Agency reported. More than two dozen people were injured nationwide.

Amid the unrest, the youth wing of the March 14 coalition called for a peaceful rally in Beirut's Martyrs' Square on Monday evening. The March 14 movement is an anti-Syrian coalition that emerged after the 2005 assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. His son, Saad, leads the coalition.

Syria has condemned the attack but that has not stopped accusations it is behind Friday's killing, which marked the country's highest-profile assassination in more than seven years. The United States has also condemned the attack and vowed to assist in investigating the bombing.

Title: Rep. Rashida Tlaib Joins Airline Catering Workers in Protest Against "Poverty Wages" and "Unaffordable Healthcare"

Article:

U.S. Representative Rashida Tlaib joined airline catering workers employed by Delta Airlines in a protest at Detroit Metropolitan Airport on Friday, demonstrating against "poverty wages" and "unaffordable healthcare."

Tlaib, along with eight airline workers, blocked traffic at the airport while approximately 100 union members from Unite Here rallied outside Delta's McNamara Terminal departures. The protesters displayed signs reading "Delta: one job should be enough."

Eight airline workers were arrested by airport officers for refusing to move. Tlaib, though, was not arrested, according to union officials.

In a statement, Tlaib expressed solidarity with the workers, stating, "The airline catering workers are desperate for a better quality of life and put their bodies on the line in their fight against the exorbitant corporate greed by the airlines, denying them of their right to a living wage and good healthcare."

Tlaib continued, "Working people in the kitchens at DTW and airports across the U.S. have been hurting for too long, but today we are saying no more. Today, we are calling on Delta Air Lines to say that if it wants to really prove that it cares about the working families more than it does its bottom line, than it will commit to ending poverty in the airline catering industry so one job is enough for all airline workers."

The protest took place as Delta Air Lines distributed $1.6 billion in profit-sharing to its employees on the same day. Delta did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Friday.

Protests also occurred in other key Delta hubs in Minneapolis and Seattle, as well as United and American hubs in Boston, Charlotte, Dallas, Honolulu, Houston, Los Angeles, New York, Philadelphia, and San Francisco.

Unite Here Local 24 President Nia Winston, who was among those arrested at Metro Airport, said the airline catering industry workers help to make DTW one of the best airports in the country, but cannot afford to take their children to the doctor.

"Until airlines like Delta recognize all the workers whose labor contributes to its record-profits, until airline catering workers get what they deserve in a fair contract, we will keep coming out at the airport and anywhere else Delta will hear us," Winston said.

Title: U.S. Congress Agrees on Sanctions Legislation Targeting Russia, Iran, and North Korea

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. lawmakers have reached an agreement on legislation that imposes new sanctions against Russia, Iran, and North Korea. According to congressional Democrats, the bill aims to limit any potential effort by President Donald Trump to ease sanctions against Moscow.

The Countering Iran's Destabilizing Activities Act, which was passed by the Senate a month ago, was initially held up in the House of Representatives due to Republican proposals to include North Korea sanctions in the bill. The House is scheduled to vote on Tuesday on a package of bills covering sanctions for all three countries.

The proposed bill requires President Trump to submit a report on proposed actions that would significantly alter U.S. foreign policy in relation to Russia, including easing sanctions or returning diplomatic properties in Maryland and New York that were vacated by former President Barack Obama in December. Congress would then have at least 30 days to hold hearings and vote to approve or reject Trump's proposed changes.

Many lawmakers hope the bill will send a message to Trump to maintain a strong stance against Russia. Trump, who met with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Group of 20 summit earlier this month and described the meeting as an "honor," has been criticized for seeking to improve U.S.-Russian relations. His administration has been embroiled in ongoing investigations of possible ties between his 2016 campaign and Russia.

The bill is intended to punish Russia for its 2014 annexation of Crimea, a peninsula belonging to Ukraine, and for meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Putin has denied any meddling in the U.S. democratic process last year. Trump has stated that his campaign did not collude with Russia.

House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi described Russia's "outrageous and unacceptable" behavior in the 2016 U.S. election and in Europe as demanding "strong statutory sanctions enacted as soon as possible." However, she expressed concerns that including North Korea in the legislation could lead to procedural delays in the Senate.

Senior Republican lawmakers did not immediately comment on the latest bill. In Brussels, the European Union expressed concern about the U.S. moves to strengthen sanctions on Russia, urging coordination with its Group of 7 partners. The European Commission warned of potentially "wide and indiscriminate" unintended consequences, notably on the EU's efforts to diversify energy sources away from Russia.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Ed Royce, chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said in a statement that the revised bill helps "bolster the energy security of our European allies by maintaining their access to key energy resources outside of Russia."

Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer stated that a strong sanctions bill "is essential," and expects "the House and Senate will act on this legislation promptly, on a broad bipartisan basis." Senator Ben Cardin, the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the agreement was reached after "intense negotiations."

"A nearly united Congress is poised to send President Putin a clear message on behalf of the American people and our allies," Cardin said in a statement. "We need President Trump to help us deliver that message."

Title: Hong Kong Police Use Tear Gas and Water Cannon to Disperse Protesters in 24th Weekend of Anti-Government Unrest

Article:

Hong Kong authorities deployed tear gas and water cannon to disperse protesters who blocked roads and vandalized shopping malls across the New Territories and Kowloon peninsula on Sunday, marking the 24th consecutive weekend of anti-government demonstrations.

Protesters shouted abuse at the police, referring to them as "black police," in reference to perceived police brutality in the Chinese-ruled city. The demonstrations show no signs of abating after more than five months.

In the central new town of Sha Tin, pro-democracy protesters vandalized a train station and a restaurant perceived as pro-Beijing. Violence also spilled out onto the streets of Tuen Mun, with running battles between riot police and protesters outside the "V city" mall.

Now TV reported that one of its reporters was hit by a tear gas canister in Tsuen Wan, west of the New Territories, where police fired tear gas late into the evening to clear the streets. The rail station in Sha Tin was closed due to scuffles between police and protesters, young and old, on a day of planned shopping mall protests throughout the territory.

Protesters daubed graffiti and damaged shops at Festival Walk in Kowloon Tong and "stormed" stores in Tsuen Wan, according to police. The violence spread to the Kowloon district of Mong Kok, one of the world's most densely populated areas.

Police used water cannon and volley after volley of tear gas to try to clear the main artery of Nathan Road, which was littered with loose bricks under the bright, neon lights. Police also fired tear gas late at night in the New Territories district of Tai Po, north of Sha Tin.

Protesters are angry about what they see as police brutality and meddling by Beijing in the former British colony's freedoms, guaranteed by the "one country, two systems" formula in place since the territory returned to Chinese rule in 1997.

China denies interfering and has blamed Western countries for stirring up trouble. Thousands of people gathered at a Saturday night vigil for a student who died in a hospital this week after falling from a car park during a protest.

Thousands also gathered in Chater Garden, in Central on Hong Kong island, to mourn the student, Chow Tsz-lok, 22. Pastor Yuen Tin Yau said Chow's family had decided to donate his organs.

Seven pro-democracy city lawmakers have been detained or face arrest and are due to appear in court on Monday on charges of obstructing a May meeting of the local assembly, according to police and several of the lawmakers.

One of the arrested lawmakers, Gary Fan, said the detentions were the result of "political prosecutions and judicial crackdowns" by Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam. The colony of Hong Kong island and the Kowloon peninsula, acquired after two "opium wars" with China, was expanded to include the much larger, rural New Territories on a 99-year lease in 1898. Britain returned all the land to China when that lease expired in 1997.

Protesters have called for a general strike on Monday and urged people to block public transport, although such calls in the past have often come to nothing. They have also demanded an independent inquiry into police tactics, something Lam has refused. A five-member international panel said an analysis of the Hong Kong police watchdog, the Independent Police Complaints Council, indicated a shortfall in its "independent investigative capability" to look into policing during the protests.

Title: Senate Opposition to Rex Tillerson's Nomination as Secretary of State: A Potential Departure from Republican Orthodoxy

Article:

The nomination of Rex Tillerson, CEO of ExxonMobil, as the U.S. Secretary of State by President Donald Trump has sparked controversy, with several Republican senators expressing concerns about Tillerson's ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, Arizona Sen. John McCain, and South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham have voiced doubts about Tillerson's nomination, with Rubio referring to Tillerson as a "Friend of Vladimir," a reference to Putin's highest accolade for foreigners. McCain called Putin a "murderer, a thug, and a KGB agent," while Graham also expressed grave doubts about the nominee.

The potential for Senate rejection of Tillerson's nomination on the floor is a possibility, given the GOP's 52-seat majority. Tillerson's ties to Putin and his lack of government experience have raised concerns among some senators, particularly those who are critical of Trump's defense of Putin and his divergence from the Republican Party's longstanding commitment to NATO.

Environmental groups and government watchdogs have also criticized Tillerson's nomination, citing his ties to the fossil fuel industry and potential conflicts of interest. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders called Tillerson's nomination "very troubling" and "very dangerous," while the Environmental Defense Fund said Trump was putting the oil-and-gas industry's interests above Americans' health.

Despite the criticism, Tillerson's nomination makes sense in a Trumpian world, as he breaks the mold of diplomats and politicians who typically command the U.S. State Department. Tillerson has no government experience, but that is not disqualifying in the Trump administration.

Tillerson and Trump are two tough-minded corporate businessmen who have spent decades atop large companies with global interests. Both have a penchant for big projects and a professed devotion to the works of philosopher-novelist Ayn Rand. Tillerson's nomination may signal a redefinition of the Russia relationship, with Trump potentially pursuing a combination of Tillerson's diplomatic skills and a hard-line, old-fashioned Cold Warrior.

The confirmation hearings for Tillerson's nomination are likely to feature discussions about his stance on U.S.-NATO sanctions on Russia, as well as his views on climate change and alternative energies. Tillerson's nomination has drawn predictable pushback from environmental groups and government watchdogs, but it remains to be seen whether he will face significant opposition in the Senate.

Title: Christian Students Seek Supreme Court Review Over Free Speech Rights on Campus

Article:

Two Christian students, Chike Uzuegbunam and Joseph Bradford, have petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court to review a lawsuit against Georgia Gwinnett College (GGC), alleging that the college's speech zone and speech code policies violated their First Amendment rights. The students, represented by the religious rights law firm Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF), claim that these policies prevented them from exercising their freedom of speech and freedom of religion.

In 2016, Uzuegbunam attempted to distribute religious literature on the GGC campus but was told to stop by a campus security officer, who informed him that he was not allowed to distribute materials at the location. The campus speech zone policy required students to reserve one of the two zones available on campus to exercise their free speech, with the two zones making up only 0.0015 percent of the campus.

Uzuegbunam reserved and was granted one of the speech zones to distribute religious literature for three separate dates. On one of those days, Uzuegbunam was ordered to stop because the campus had received complaints about his efforts. A lieutenant for campus police told Uzuegbunam that his faith-sharing efforts amounted to "disorderly conduct" under a GGC policy, which applies to any expression that "disturbs the peace and/or comfort of person[s]." Bradford, who shared the same religious views as Uzuegbunam, self-censored after seeing how Uzuegbunam was treated.

ADF filed a lawsuit against the GGC officials, but the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia dismissed the case, which was affirmed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. During the time when the case was in the district court, GGC amended its speech zone policy and eliminated its speech code but did not provide any relief for the students. The policies now allow students to engage in expressive activity in open outdoor areas on campus without obtaining a permit, unless the group is over 30 people.

The lower courts found that the lawsuit became moot when Uzuegbunam graduated from GGC and after the college had changed its speech zone policy and code. However, ADF attorneys argue in the petition filed on Jan. 31 that the case is still alive, citing opinions from other circuit courts. They argue that the 11th circuit is the only federal appellate court that does not hold officials accountable for violating constitutional rights when they change the policies later during the litigation.

"[T]he Eleventh Circuit's outlier view allows these institutions to violate constitutional rights with impunity—avoiding judicial review through a well-timed policy shift," the petition states. "This rule sends a clear message to students when school officials trample their freedoms: 'Don't bother retaining counsel; we know how to game the legal system.' And it signals that colleges can keep censoring students without consequence..."

ADF Senior Counsel Tyson Langhofer, director of the ADF Center for Academic Freedom, said in a statement that he hopes the top court would intervene to "make sure that this denial of justice doesn't occur to anyone else."

"We need to ensure that the wrong done to our clients is righted—something that both the district court and the 11th Circuit failed to do," Langhofer said.

The case came under the spotlight in 2017 after the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a Statement of Interest supporting the two students. At the time, the DOJ argued that the students had adequately provided enough evidence to allege a violation of their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights and that GGC's speech policies were not "content-neutral, established an impermissible heckler's veto, and were not narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling government interest."

"A national recommitment to free speech on campus and to ensuring First Amendment rights is long overdue. Which is why, starting today, the Department of Justice will do its part in this struggle. We will enforce federal law, defend free speech, and protect students' free expression," former Attorney General Jeff Sessions said at the time.

Title: Obama Administration Pursues "Politically Binding" Climate Change Agreement, By-passing Senate Ratification

The Obama administration is reportedly planning to bypass the U.S. Senate's approval for a treaty by forging an international climate change agreement at a United Nations meeting in Paris next year. This alternative agreement, described as "politically binding," would serve as a substitute for a formal treaty due to the Senate's unlikely ratification of an international climate treaty.

The New York Times reported that the agreement would not have the full force of a treaty but would "name and shame" countries into reducing fossil fuel emissions. The proposal is a hybrid, combining the legally binding conditions from an existing 1992 treaty with "new voluntary pledges." Negotiators claim the new agreement would not require a ratification vote.

Under the terms, co-signers would have to enact climate change policies but would be on the honor system for meeting specific emissions levels and sending funds to developing countries. The State Department has downplayed the reported developments, stating that no agreement has been written, and it is premature to determine whether it will require Senate approval.

Republican lawmakers have criticized the move, with Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.) stating, "Once again, the president is trying to go around Congress and ignore Americans who cannot afford more expensive, extreme energy regulations." House Science Committee Chairman Lamar Smith (R-Texas) also expressed concern, stating, "This is another example of a president who is willing to ignore the rule of law to get what he wants."

Sen. James Inhofe (R-Okla.) reiterated that the Senate would not ratify a treaty and vowed to continue fighting the president's "economy-crushing domestic greenhouse gas regulations." He added that additional U.S. restrictions on greenhouse gas emissions would harm the United States as other nations like Australia either scrap or water down their greenhouse gas policies.

Title: Trump Suggests DACA Program is "Probably Dead," Calls for Merit-Based Immigration

Article:

President Donald Trump has stated that the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which protects immigrants brought to the U.S. illegally as children, is "probably dead." In a series of tweets on Sunday, Trump placed the blame on Democrats, claiming they are not genuinely interested in the program but are instead seeking to divert funds from the military.

"DACA is probably dead because the Democrats don’t really want it, they just want to talk and take desperately needed money away from our Military," Trump wrote on Twitter.

The DACA program, established during the Obama administration, has been under threat since Trump announced last year that he would rescind it, giving Congress six months to craft a legislative fix. However, lawmakers have yet to reach a deal with the White House, and the president has stated that a wall on the U.S.-Mexico border "must be part of any DACA approval."

On Saturday, U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services announced that it would begin taking new requests for immigrants seeking protections under the DACA program following a preliminary injunction last week that blocked Trump's decision to end DACA.

In another tweet on Sunday, Trump expressed a desire for immigrants to come to the U.S. based on merit, stating, "I, as President, want people coming into our Country who are going to help us become strong and great again, people coming in through a system based on MERIT. No more Lotteries!"

This statement comes after a heated controversy over a report that said Trump, during a White House meeting with lawmakers last week, referred to immigrants from African nations, El Salvador, and Haiti as coming from "shithole countries." According to the report, the president said, "Why are we having all these people from shithole countries come here?"

Title: Massive Unity March in Paris Following Terrorist Attacks; World Leaders Join in Show of Solidarity

Article:

Hundreds of thousands of Parisians marched through the streets on Sunday in a display of unity, solidarity, and defiance following last week's terrorist attacks. The demonstration, which attracted an estimated one million participants, was also attended by "more than 40 world leaders," according to the BBC.

Notable attendees included British Prime Minister David Cameron, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and Palestinian Authority leader Mahmoud Abbas. President Obama did not attend, sending Attorney General Eric Holder to represent the United States. The march focused on themes of freedom and French national pride, with chants of "liberte" (freedom) and "Charlie" in reference to Charlie Hebdo magazine.

Scenes from the march depicted a human tide flowing through streets closed to traffic, with the slogan "Je suis Charlie" (I am Charlie) prevalent on homemade placards, armbands, and T-shirts. A family marched four abreast, holding up print-outs in plastic sleeves, and there were flags too: full-sized French tricolors carried by demonstrators, and the colors of the Republic on the square of the Republic.

French law enforcement officers have been advised to erase their social media presence and to carry their weapons at all times due to the activation of terror sleeper cells over the past 24 hours in the country, according to a French police source who attended a briefing Saturday. Amedy Coulibaly, a suspect killed Friday during a deadly kosher market hostage siege, had reportedly made several phone calls about targeting police officers in France, according to the source.

In a separate incident, several stones and an incendiary device were thrown through the window of the archive of the regional tabloid daily, the Hamburger Morgenpost, early on Sunday morning. The paper had splashed three Charlie Hebdo cartoons on its front page after the Paris massacre, running the headline “This much freedom must be possible!” No one was hurt in the attack in the northern port city, and two people were detained, with an investigation underway.

Corresponding events were held throughout France and all over the world. However, the specter of violence remains, with British intelligence's chilling admonition on Friday and French authorities warning that new terror cells have been "activated" after the Charlie Hebdo massacre. A branch of Al Qaeda has claimed responsibility for the deadly raid, with both jihadist brothers believed to have received training in Yemen, and their associate who took hostages and shed blood at a Kosher supermarket reportedly recorded a martyrdom video pledging his allegiance to Al Qaeda and ISIS.

In 2011, Charlie Hebdo's offices were firebombed in Germany, a precursor to last week's horror. Amid rising antisemitic violence in France and across Europe, many Jews are heading for the exits. According to a survey last year from the European Jewish Congress and Tel Aviv University, France had more violent anti-Semitic incidents in 2013 than any other country in the world. Jews were the target of 40% of all racist crimes in France in 2013 – even though they comprise less than 1% of the population. Attacks on Jews have risen sevenfold since the 1990s.

On Friday, the author wrote a piece exploring the difficult questions of defining "true Islam" and "extremism" at Hot Air. The "not all Muslims" caveats are not feel-good window dressing; please read these two stories. The article concludes with images of solidarity among heads of state and other dignitaries.

Title: Opinion on Second Amendment Evolves After Sandy Hook Tragedy

Article:

The author, in a personal account, discusses their change in perspective regarding the Second Amendment and gun safety reform following the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in 2012. Initially, they believed that a few sensible gun laws could address the issue, but the tragic event led them to reconsider their stance.

Before the Sandy Hook shooting, the author believed that the Second Amendment, which guarantees the right to bear arms, was not problematic and could be regulated with common sense. However, after the shooting, they came to believe that the Second Amendment no longer promotes the life, liberty, and pursuit of happiness but poses a daily threat to these values.

The author argues that the need for a well-regulated militia, as stated in the Second Amendment, is no longer relevant, as the military provides adequate security for the nation. They question the necessity of widespread gun ownership, citing the increasing number of gun-related deaths in the United States each year and the need for bulletproof backpacks in schools.

The author criticizes the National Rifle Association (NRA) for their stance on gun rights, comparing them to the supporters of the Scopes monkey trial, who fought to preserve a worldview that is no longer widely accepted. They also question the motives behind the increase in gun sales, suggesting a possible connection to the decline of the white majority in the United States.

The author concludes by expressing their belief that the United States must address the fear and ignorance that fuel the gun culture to ascend as a nation and cure the virus of violence. They call for the nation to grow up and become adults, so children like Noah Pozner, one of the Sandy Hook victims, have a fighting chance to do the same.

Title: Vatican Rejects Concept of Self-Chosen Gender, Issues Document on Gender Theory

The Vatican has released a document titled "Male and Female He Created Them," which rejects the idea that individuals can choose their gender and emphasizes the sexual complementarity of men and women for procreation. The document, published during LGBTQ Pride Month, calls for a "path of dialogue" and listening on the issue of gender theory in education.

The document, intended to help Catholic teachers, parents, students, and clergy address the "educational crisis" in teaching sexuality, relies on previous papal pronouncements, Vatican documents, and philosophers and theologians. The Rev. James Martin, a Jesuit priest known for his work on improving the Catholic Church's outreach to the LGBT community, noted that the real-life experiences of LGBT people seem absent from the document.

LGBT Catholics have denounced the formal document, labeling it harmful and contributing to hatred, bigotry, and violence against gay and transgender people. Pope Francis, who has argued against self-chosen gender, is credited with first articulating the Vatican's position in a 2012 speech.

The document calls for a new alliance among families, schools, and society to offer a "positive and prudent sexual education" in Catholic schools, ensuring that children learn the "full original truth of masculinity and femininity." It characterizes gender fluidity as a symptom of the "confused concept of freedom" and "momentary desires" that characterize post-modern culture. The document also rejects terms such as "intersex" and "transgender" and argues that the purpose of the biological complementarity of the male and female sex organs is to ensure procreation.

Title: Baltimore Courts Immigrants to Revitalize City Population and Economy

Article:

Hundreds of individuals gathered at Baltimore's harbor in September, with nearly 50 of them set to be sworn in as U.S. citizens. The event, held amidst the wind gusting off the water's edge, saw a diverse group of individuals, including young and old, uniformed members of the U.S. military, parents and children, immigrants from El Salvador, China, Honduras, and various other countries in between.

The national conversation on immigration reform has been stalled for years, and while President Obama has identified it as a top priority for his second term, Baltimore is moving ahead with its own agenda. The city is actively courting immigrants in an effort to revitalize its shrinking population.

Baltimore, once a major port city and destination for people moving to America, experienced a significant population decline since 1950, with the city's population falling to just half of what it was in the 1960s. Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake aims to bring in 10,000 new families over the next decade, focusing on immigrants, a group that has helped other large cities grow. She hopes new families will boost income and property tax revenue, helping to reignite the city's economy.

One of those new immigrants is Zakaria al-Saghir, who moved to Baltimore County with his wife and their three kids in September. He is currently participating in a small discussion group at Baltimore's International Rescue Committee, an organization that helps newcomers learn the ropes in the U.S. Al-Sagheer chose Baltimore over other states due to the positive word of mouth from relatives who spoke about the city's population, treatment of new immigrants, and lifestyle.

Baltimore's administration is making efforts to ensure all immigrants feel safe and welcome. The city has prohibited police and city officials from asking residents about immigration status, and is offering Spanish-language nutrition and exercise classes, Spanish story time at the library, and cultural training for the police.

Catalina Rodriguez, Baltimore's Hispanic Community Liaison, is responsible for ensuring many of these programs run smoothly. She is currently training about 20 officers to recognize foreign identification cards, with immigrants who cannot get a state-issued driver's license encouraged to carry ID cards from their home countries.

The city is spending money on training programs like this one, but Mayor Rawlings-Blake states that the costs are negligible compared to the revenue new families will generate in taxes. It is too early to calculate Baltimore's return on investment, but there is another Northeast city that also tried to fight population decline by recruiting immigrants: Philadelphia.

Philadelphia, like Baltimore, experienced a similar population crash and growth in the 1950s and 2010, respectively. The bulk of the newcomers in Philadelphia were Asian and Hispanic immigrants. Amanda Bergson-Shilcock, who has worked for nearly a decade at The Welcoming Center for New Pennsylvanians, states that the city's immigrant population growth was crucial to its population growth and economic revitalization.

Steven Camarota of the Center for Immigration Studies, however, is skeptical that Baltimore, or any city, can grow its immigrant population simply by ignoring immigration status or offering services. He argues that immigrants go where there are jobs and that even if cities like Baltimore, which has had a stubbornly high unemployment rate, could attract immigrants, it would not mean much for the local economy.

David Kallick, director of Immigration Research at the Fiscal Policy Institute, disagrees with Camarota on this point. Kallick states that attracting new immigrant residents does help a city, whether they make a million dollars a year or $30,000. He argues that having people move into a neighborhood and pay property taxes is beneficial, as having empty buildings is expensive to a city.

In the short-term, Baltimore's open-door policy is unlikely to fill city coffers, as there is a cost to providing new immigrants services like language classes and healthcare. For Baltimore to be successful, Kallick states, it will have to do more than roll out a nice welcome mat to newcomers; it will have to invest long-term.

Title: U.S. Security Officer in Libya Requests Additional Personnel Ahead of Benghazi Attack, Receives No Response

Article:

The Regional Security Officer in Libya, Eric Nordstrom, requested additional security personnel for the U.S. consulate in Benghazi several months before the diplomatic post was attacked, but did not receive a response from superiors, according to documents obtained by CNN. The disclosure comes ahead of a congressional hearing on Wednesday regarding the September 11, 2012, armed assault that resulted in the death of Ambassador Christopher Stevens and three other Americans.

U.S. intelligence believes the incident was a terrorist act. Nordstrom had conveyed concerns about the Libyan government's ability to protect American diplomatic facilities and sent two cables to State Department headquarters last March and again in July requesting additional security agents for the Benghazi post.

In a summary of his interview with House Oversight and Government Reform Committee Democrats, Nordstrom stated that Deputy Assistant Secretary Charlene Lamb wanted to keep the number of U.S. security personnel in Benghazi "artificially low." Nordstrom said Lamb generally believed that extra security was unnecessary because there was a residential safe haven to fall back on in an emergency.

Nordstrom also said that Lamb thought the "best course of action was to assign three agents" to the Benghazi post, while the facility usually had three or four agents. However, Nordstrom also told the committee that Undersecretary of State for Management Patrick Kennedy issued a memo last December requiring five agents be assigned to Benghazi.

Senior State Department officials have stated that security personnel in Benghazi were outmanned and outgunned during the attack, and that no reasonable security presence could have successfully fended it off. A senior agency official said, "The lethality and the number of armed people is unprecedented. There had been no attacks like that anywhere in Libya - Tripoli, Benghazi, or anywhere - in the time that we had been there. And so it is unprecedented, in fact, it would be very, very hard to find precedent for an attack like in recent diplomatic history."

The Oversight Committee hearing has been criticized by Democrats as election-year political grandstanding rather than a serious effort to find answers about the attack. Nordstrom, Lamb, Kennedy, and Army Lt. Col Andrew Wood, commander of a security support team in Tripoli, are expected to testify at the hearing.

Nordstrom also described in an email a list of specific security incidents that occurred in Libya from June 2011 to June 2012. The email and the list of incidents provided to CNN by the Oversight Committee outline examples of common conflict zone incidents, such as carjackings and grenade attacks, to more serious cases that include assassinations and an attack on the motorcade of the British ambassador.

The document describes a general increase in crime in Tripoli, the large numbers of armed civilians, clashes between rival militias, widespread unemployment, random violence, and revenge killings. One incident refers to a June 6, 2012, bomb attack on the consulate in Benghazi and notes that an al-Qaeda-affiliated group had claimed credit.

The list concludes that "the risk of U.S. mission personnel, private U.S. citizens, and businesspersons encountering an isolating event as a result of militia or political violence is 'HIGH.' The government of Libya does not yet have the ability to effectively respond to and manage the rising criminal and militia-related violence, which could result in an isolating event."

Democratic staff allege that Oversight Chairman Darrell Issa and his staff have failed to consult them, refused to make witnesses available to Democratic staff, and withheld documents. Democrats also assert that Rep. Jason Chaffetz (R-Utah), chairman of the Oversight panel's security, homeland, and foreign operations subcommittee, effectively excluded them from joining his delegation on a trip to Libya last weekend. However, Chaffetz denied that was the case.

Title: Intelligence Agencies and Former Obama Officials Submit "Unmasking" Requests for Michael Flynn Information

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden, along with the directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), and Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) submitted "unmasking" requests for information about Michael Flynn contained in highly classified intelligence reports, according to documents released on Wednesday.

The documents show that an unmasking request was made in Biden's name on January 12, 2017. Similar requests were made under the names of James Comey, John Brennan, and James Clapper, the former directors of the FBI, CIA, and ODNI, respectively. Denis McDonough, who served as chief of staff to President Obama, also submitted a request on January 5, 2017, according to the documents.

Unmasking refers to the process whereby high-level U.S. government officials request information regarding American citizens mentioned in classified foreign intelligence reports. It is not illegal to make unmasking requests, but the Flynn case is unique because information about phone calls he had with Russia's ambassador was leaked to the media during the presidential transition period.

The documents do not specify whether Biden or others who submitted the unmasking requests saw the information related to Flynn. The document released on Wednesday stated that the unmasking requests were made under 16 different government officials' names for an unspecified number of intelligence reports.

The list of recipients who may have received Lt. Gen. Flynn's identity in response to a request processed between November 8, 2016, and January 31, 2017, to unmask an identity that had been generically referred to in an NSA foreign intelligence report, was also included in the documents. The list includes several high-profile Obama administration figures, including Brennan, Clapper, and Biden, but also includes lesser-known officials at the Treasury Department and State Department.

Republicans have focused on the unmasking issue to try to figure out who leaked information about communications that Flynn had in late December 2016 with Sergey Kislyak, who then served as Russian ambassador to the U.S. Kislyak contacted Flynn on December 28, 2016, the same day that the Obama administration ordered 35 Russian diplomats to leave the U.S. because of Russian hacking during the presidential campaign.

The records do not settle the question of who made the unmasking request for information from Kislyak's communications with Flynn. Comey suggested in testimony to the House Intelligence Committee on March 2, 2017, that someone in the FBI made the request that revealed that Flynn spoke with Kislyak. Clapper submitted an unmasking request on December 28, 2016, according to the declassified documents. However, Clapper suggested in testimony to the House Intelligence panel that the FBI submitted the request regarding the Kislyak phone calls.

The declassified records list Comey as the only FBI official to make an unmasking request for Flynn records. That request was submitted on December 15, 2016, two weeks before Flynn spoke with Kislyak. John Bass, who served as U.S. ambassador to Turkey, submitted a request for Flynn information on December 28, 2016. The next request was not submitted until McDonough, the White House chief of staff, did so on January 5, 2017.

Both McDonough and the Biden campaign did not respond to requests for comment. The documents do not specify whether the unmasking requests were made for information other than Flynn's communications with Kislyak. The documents were released by Sens. Chuck Grassley and Ron Johnson. Richard Grenell, the acting director of national intelligence, declassified the information last Thursday and provided it to the senators this week. Paul Nakasone, the director of the National Security Agency (NSA), provided the list to Grenell on May 1.

Title: U.S. Military Conducts Airstrikes to Protect Haditha Dam in Iraq

Article:

The United States military has launched airstrikes to protect the Haditha Dam in western Iraq, according to a statement by Navy Rear Adm. John Kirby, the Pentagon press secretary. The airstrikes, which are part of the ongoing air campaign against the Islamic State, targeted Islamic State positions around the dam.

The Haditha Dam, a hydroelectric facility on the Euphrates River, is the second-largest hydroelectric contributor to Iraq's power system, according to National Security Council spokeswoman Caitlin Hayden. The military stated that the airstrikes were conducted to prevent the Islamic State from threatening the dam's security, which remains under control of Iraqi security forces with support from Sunni tribes.

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, speaking in Georgia, rejected the suggestion that the strikes open a new front in the war against the Islamic State or represent an escalation of U.S. military operations. The announcement comes after President Obama stated that the United States was prepared to "take the fight" to the militant group, which poses a threat to the region and the West.

The new strikes mark the first shift toward targets in western Iraq, a region with a patchwork of conflicting loyalties. Some Sunnis have supported the Islamic State as a bulwark against the Shiite-dominated government, but tribes have taken different stands in the face of the militant offensive. Some tribes are fighting against the militants, while others are supporting the Islamic State or remaining neutral.

Tribes in the Haditha dam region have been fighting against the militants for months. The U.S. military stated that the dam remains in the hands of tribes working in support of the Iraqi government and Iraqi security forces.

The U.S. air campaign began on August 8 and has expanded as it has taken on more missions. U.S. planes have targeted areas around the Mosul Dam, allowing a combination of Iraqi counterterrorist forces and Kurdish peshmerga fighters to retake the facility from Islamic State militants. U.S. aircraft also targeted militants around Mount Sinjar, where a religious minority had taken refuge after militants had overrun their community, and more recently, U.S. aircraft helped break the siege of Amerli, a Shiite Turkmen town.

Since the air campaign began, the U.S. military has conducted 138 airstrikes in Iraq.

Title: Five Protesters Arrested, Businesses Damaged in Ferguson Following Destruction of Michael Brown Memorial

Article:

Five protesters were arrested and some businesses were damaged Tuesday night in Ferguson, Missouri, after a memorial to Michael Brown was destroyed in a fire. The incident reignited tensions in the St. Louis suburb that experienced violence this summer following the shooting of Brown, an unarmed teenager, by a Ferguson police officer.

During a news conference Wednesday, Capt. Ron Johnson with the Missouri State Highway Patrol reported two St. Louis County police officers were injured during the unrest. One officer was hit with a rock, sustaining an injury under his eye, but is expected to recover.

The unrest began Tuesday when a beauty supply store was looted and vandalized. Capt. Jeremy Corcoran with the Ferguson police stated this was the third time the store had been broken into in the last six weeks.

Following the break-in, a fire was reported at a restaurant on Carson Road. An investigation revealed gasoline was poured around the restaurant, and the fire was put out by Ferguson firefighters.

Some protesters stated they were in the streets because the makeshift memorial to Brown had been burned earlier in the day. Protesters believed the fire was set intentionally.

The fire started around 6:45 a.m. CT Tuesday on Canfield Drive, the street where Brown was killed by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson.

Capt. Johnson stated the fire started small enough to have been put out with a cup of water, but instead, some people stood watching the fire for 11 minutes until police and firefighters arrived. The cause of the fire has not yet been determined, but Johnson does not believe a police officer started it. A full investigation is underway to determine the cause.

Later Tuesday, residents rebuilt the memorial. The blaze angered many people who live near the scene, with one man describing it as a grave being desecrated.

Around 12:15 a.m., unpeaceful protesters started shining lights into the eyes of police, shouting about shooting officers and burning down the town, according to Johnson. He stated the protesters were positioning themselves close to officers, so the decision was made to disperse the crowd. Johnson said when they attempted to break up the group, some started throwing bottles, rocks, and other items at police, injuring two officers.

The unrest continued, Johnson said, when someone near Canfield fired shots at the officers. He stated he saw the muzzle flash from the gun and sought shelter. Officers were wearing bulletproof vests, but Johnson said a lot of the heavy equipment used during the unrest in August was not used Tuesday, but they will start to respond to the area in riot gear if it becomes necessary.

Johnson also reported a Molotov cocktail was thrown at a parking facility.

Of the five people arrested for failing to disperse, Johnson believed one person also is facing assault and inciting a riot charges.

Brown's death led to weeks of protest and unrest in the St. Louis suburb. After a month without an arrest, Brown's parents and activists questioned why Wilson had not been indicted in the killing. At the time of the shooting, witnesses in the area stated Brown had raised his hands to surrender as he was shot. A state grand jury and the U.S. Department of Justice are continuing to investigate.

Title: Mother Confronts EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt in Washington D.C. Restaurant

Article:

In a recent incident, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Scott Pruitt was approached by a mother and her 2-year-old son while dining out in Washington D.C., making him the latest Trump administration official to be confronted in public. The woman, identified as Kristin Mink, a 33-year-old sixth-grade teacher at Sidwell Friends, the school former President Obama’s daughters attended, walked up to Pruitt while he was at a restaurant.

Mink addressed Pruitt, stating, "This is my son, he loves animals, he loves clean air, he loves clean water." She then urged Pruitt to resign due to the numerous ethics complaints and federal inquiries he faces.

Pruitt is under investigation by the EPA's inspector general, the Government Accountability Office, and the White House, concerning allegations of Pruitt's spending on first-class travel and security, his dealings with subordinates and lobbyists, and other matters. The EPA's senior counsel resigned last month following an investigation into allegations of mismanagement and spending at the EPA. Pruitt has also been criticized for his rental of a Capitol Hill condo tied to a prominent oil and gas lobbyist, and the use of first-class travel and luxury hotel suites, among other things.

Mink had notes that she occasionally glanced at while talking to Pruitt. "I had to decide what to say; he's so scandal-ridden," Mink told The New York Post. "I jotted down just a couple of points that I wanted to make to him that were a little on the specific side."

Pruitt left after the encounter, but his spokesman, Lincoln Ferguson, stated that this was not the reason. "Administrator Pruitt always welcomes input from Americans, whether they agree or disagree with the decisions being made at EPA," Ferguson said in a statement. "This is evident by him listening to her comments and going on to thank her, which is not shown in the video. His leaving had nothing to do with the confrontation; he had simply finished his meal and needed to get back to EPA for a briefing."

Title: Federal Judge Holds Education Secretary Betsy DeVos in Contempt for Violating Court Order on For-Profit College Loans

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — Education Secretary Betsy DeVos was held in contempt of court after a federal judge said she violated an earlier order to stop collecting loans from former students of a defunct for-profit college chain. U.S. Magistrate Judge Sallie Kim issued the ruling Thursday in San Francisco, stating that DeVos and the department made "only minimal efforts" to comply with a 2018 court order.

The dispute stems from a lawsuit filed by thousands of former Corinthian Colleges students who claim they were defrauded by the chain before it collapsed in 2015. The suit seeks full forgiveness of their federal student loans under a rule created by the Obama administration, and challenges DeVos' 2017 decision to provide only partial relief based on borrowers' incomes.

In a May 2018 decision, Kim ruled that the partial-relief formula was unlawful. She ordered the department to stop using the formula and to stop collecting student loans from former Corinthian students.

However, in a September court filing, the department acknowledged that it incorrectly sent loan bills to more than 16,000 former Corinthian students, prompting more than 3,000 to send payments. The department also garnished wages or tax refunds from 1,800 borrowers and provided credit agencies with negative reports about 800 borrowers.

The judge wrote that there was "no question" the department and DeVos violated the May 2018 injunction. She said the defendants had "not provided evidence that they were unable to comply with the preliminary injunction, and the evidence shows only minimal efforts to comply with the preliminary injunction."

The Education Department did not respond to requests for comment.

Lawyers for the former Corinthian students called the ruling a "rare and powerful action" that provides consequences for the "extreme harm" DeVos caused.

DeVos "repeatedly and brazenly violated the law to collect for-profit college students' debts and deny their rights," said Toby Merrill, director of the Project on Predatory Student Lending, which helped file the suit. "The judge is sending a loud and clear message: Students have rights under the law, and DeVos's illegal and reckless violation of their rights will not be tolerated."

In her ruling, the judge said the department sent just a single, three-sentence email with instructions to loan servicers, along with an "equally cursory" email to certain borrowers. There were no meetings or phone calls, Kim wrote, and little effort to make sure loan servicers received the emails.

The judge threatened to impose further sanctions if the department fails to follow her order, saying she would appoint a court official to help enforce the injunction. The $100,000 fine will repay students for expenses they incurred to raise the issue to the court. The fine is to be paid by the department, not by DeVos personally.

Title: Delivery Services Surge Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic: Ethical Dilemma and Worker Rights

Article:

The coronavirus pandemic has led to a significant increase in demand for delivery services as people opt to stay at home and practice social distancing. This surge in demand has caused restaurants to transition to takeout-only businesses, and food delivery services like GrubHub and DoorDash to scramble to meet the increased orders. Grocery orders were up 150 percent in March compared to the same period last year.

The delivery system relies on an army of delivery workers to bring food from stores or restaurants to people's front doors. These couriers, who face one of the highest risks of exposure to disease, are predominantly independent contractors who lack health coverage and other benefits. In March, workers for the grocery delivery service Instacart held a nationwide strike, demanding sick leave and protective gear like masks.

The ethical question of whether it is fair to ask someone else to take on the health risks associated with spending time in public while avoiding these risks oneself has arisen. Health experts argue that limiting the number of people shopping for food is beneficial in the nationwide effort to limit the spread of the virus. Additionally, delivery workers rely on the income they receive from deliveries, and choosing not to order could negatively impact both the workers and the struggling restaurants that prepare the food.

However, delivery apps have been accused of exploiting the workers and restaurants they contract with by taking a large share of the income from deliveries. In some cities, delivery slots have become scarce, potentially denying those who are unable to shop for themselves the opportunity to acquire food.

Industry experts suggest that anyone ordering delivery should acknowledge the burden the courier is taking on for the public good by tipping well, giving good ratings, and taking steps to protect them from infection. Labor rights activists view the increased importance of delivery workers and other essential jobs as an opportunity to push for better conditions and benefits, potentially leading to more strikes and protests in the coming weeks and months.

Adele Peters of Fast Company states, "If a gig worker relies on orders to make a living, not ordering could affect their ability to pay their bills. But the sheer volume of deliveries now makes that unlikely." Luke Tsai of Eater comments, "If you do order via one of the apps, at a minimum, please, please, please tip your driver beyond generously. People are out there risking their health so you get that carton of chow mein!"

Food labor expert Saru Jayaraman told The Atlantic, "Our industry is definitely worried about people's safety, including their own, but they're also worried about survival and feeding their kids... It's not that they don't think this is a scary time to be doing delivery, but they also need their jobs."

Khushbu Shah of Food & Wine suggests, "Delivery apps should not be allowed to continue the same vulturous practices they deployed in a pre-coronavirus world. Until these apps actively start agreeing to commission caps, it's time to delete your delivery apps and let them burn."

Title: Lawsuit Challenges University of Michigan's Speech Regulation Policies

Article:

A legal challenge is being mounted against the University of Michigan, with its president, Mark Schlissel, and several administrative officials being sued for alleged constitutional violations related to speech suppression. The lawsuit, spearheaded by the organization Speech First, aims to invalidate Michigan's "elaborate investigatory and disciplinary apparatus" that allegedly exists to suppress and punish speech deemed "demeaning," "bothersome," or "hurtful" by students.

Speech First's complaint alleges that the university's speech regulation system, which includes "restorative justice," "individual education," and "unconscious bias training," amounts to unconstitutional prior restraint of speech and is too overbroad and vague to provide due notice of what is proscribed. The organization argues that the most sensitive student on campus effectively dictates the terms under which others may speak.

The university's warning that "bias comes in many forms" and that the "most important indication of bias is your own feelings" is cited by Speech First as evidence of the Orwellian nature of the threat of punishment for offending speech. The vaguely defined terms such as "verbal conduct that victimizes" or jeopardizes a "safe and inclusive" social climate could potentially have a chilling effect on humor, parody, satire, or plain speech about almost any topic.

When the Wall Street Journal's Jillian Kay Melchior requested records of one year of bias incident reports, the university reportedly thwarted this inquiry by imposing a fee of over $2,400 for the public records. This secretiveness suggests that the university may be embarrassed by the nature of these reports.

The Foundation for Individual Rights in Education (FIRE) has given Michigan a red rating, identifying a university that has at least one policy that clearly and substantially restricts freedom of speech. FIRE argues that bias response teams create a surveillance state on campus where students and faculty must guard their every utterance for fear of being reported to and investigated by bureaucrats.

The American Enterprise Institute's Frederick M. Hess and Grant Addison, in their National Affairs article "Restoring Free Inquiry on Campus," note that ideological homogeneity in academia is producing "formal policies and practices" whereby "limits on speech and expression have become ingrained in campus culture." Hess and Addison propose that taxpayer funds should not be subsidizing research at higher-education institutions where the conditions of free inquiry are compromised.

According to FIRE, almost 40% of all federal research funds went to 25 institutions that have formal policies that restrict constitutionally protected speech in 2015. The University of Michigan ranks third among all universities as a recipient of federal research funding, with $735 million in federal funding in 2015, which was 54% of the university's total R&D grants. Although President Schlissel may be ideologically blinkered, tone-deaf, and complacent about his own biases, his bias-response teams may not be worth $735 million to him.

Title: Conservative Movement Shows Signs of Shift in Military Policy Perspective at CPAC

Article:

In a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC), Texas Representative Louie Gohmert criticized several decades of U.S. foreign policy, primarily blaming former President Jimmy Carter for the wars in Vietnam, the 1979 Iranian hostage crisis, and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Gohmert's hawkish comments received a tepid response from the crowd, with some attendees expressing disinterest and others commenting that the topic could be found on the History Channel.

The conservative movement may be undergoing a change in its approach to military power, as younger members seem to be gravitating toward the restrained view espoused by Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.). Paul, who gained media attention with his 13-hour filibuster last week against the president's unchecked drone authority, received an enthusiastic response from the crowd during his speech at CPAC.

Sen. Paul, the son of the libertarian, anti-war icon former Rep. Ron Paul, called attention to the cultural divide within the GOP, stating, "The GOP of old has grown stale and moss-covered. I do not think we need to name any names, do we? Our party is encumbered by an inconsistent approach to freedom."
