The theme of the conference, as indicated by the title of the opening panel on which Gohmert spoke, was "Too Many American Wars? Should We Fight Anywhere and Can We Afford It?" The scene at CPAC a few hours after Gohmert's talk was much different, with a standing-room-only crowd gathered to watch Paul and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio.

Paul, in his speech, said, "The new GOP will need to embrace liberty in both the economic and the personal sphere. If we're going to have a Republican Party that can win, liberty needs to be the backbone of the GOP. We must have a message that is broad, our vision must be broad, and that vision must be based on freedom."

Sen. Paul's 13-hour filibuster drew criticism from influential Republicans like Sens. Lindsey Graham and John McCain, but it also won praise from civil libertarians on both sides of the aisle. The filibuster generated over a million tweets, with 450,000 using the hashtag #standwithrand.

Conservatives of all stripes will have the opportunity to be heard at CPAC, with both the hawkish old guard and the cost-conscious, conflict-averse new guard, including figures like Paul and Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, speaking in prime spots at the three-day gathering. For younger attendees, the Paul message seemed to have a certain appeal.

"I appreciate the old guard and the hard-line conservatives, but there are a lot of different policies, both Libertarian and conservative – and I don't want to be disrespectful, but I see his (Paul's) appeal in the 21st century too," Taylor University student and CPAC participant Kasey Leander told FoxNews.com.

The CPAC gathering comes as the GOP is struggling with identity issues and trying to carve out a future. By most accounts, Democrats pushed a more unified message harder, faster, and more effectively than Republicans in the last election cycle. With the sting of 2012 behind them and midterm elections around the corner, the GOP is racing to retool their image and their message.

The roster of speakers at this year's CPAC speaks to the struggle. While there are some marquee names, there have been some big snubs, with popular New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell not invited to the conservative conclave. American Conservative Union chairman Al Cardenas told reporters he didn't invite Christie because the conservative movement is "not a home for everybody."

"I am a firm believer that if the Republican Party's going to have success, it's going to do so by being a conservative party and not a home for everybody," he said. "And that's how you grow. I mean, look, you grow your tent by convincing others, and persuading others, that yours is the way, and you build your tent by reaching out to the new demographics of America not with a watered-down version of who we ought to be but with a true, real, solid version of who we are."

Title: American Airlines' Raise for Employees Sparks Controversy Among Wall Street

Article:

American Airlines' decision to grant preemptive raises to flight attendants and pilots has sparked controversy, with Wall Street expressing concern over the potential impact on the airline's stock and the broader industry. The move, which aims to close a compensation gap with rival airlines Delta and United, has been criticized by financial analysts who argue that higher wages could increase costs and set a problematic precedent.

In a widely circulated note, Citi analyst Kevin Crissey wrote, "This is frustrating. Labor is being paid first again, shareholders get leftovers." The outcry from major financial players led to a drop in American Airlines' shares and a broader impact on the airline industry.

However, some argue that the Wall Street perspective on labor compensation is misguided. By paying its workforce more, American Airlines could help address a long-standing issue of lower wages compared to competitors, potentially improving employee morale and setting the stage for future negotiations.

JP Morgan's Jamie Baker was more critical, suggesting that the move was not just contestable as a matter of business strategy, but illegitimate. The argument from American Airlines' management and unions is that the raises are a matter of fairness and long-term sustainability.

The raises could be seen as a demonstration of good faith to the workforce, keeping employees happy and setting the table for future negotiations. However, Baker takes a darker view, arguing that the raise increases costs and establishes a worrying precedent.

The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) reported last year that workers as a whole have been receiving a smaller and smaller share of national income in both the United States and other rich countries. The reason for this trend is a topic of debate among economists, with monopoly power, global trade, robots, and landlords being the leading contenders for villain.

One underrated factor, according to Noah Smith of Bloomberg View, is a management fad for treating workers poorly. The backlash American Airlines faced in the stock market and the outraged tone of the analyst letters is a clear sign of the constant pressure that modern companies are under to be as stingy as possible with their workforce.

A company like Apple, which invests money in environmental or accessibility initiatives, would never dream of taking a similarly high-minded attitude toward labor issues, even though it could make Apple Store retail employees as well-paid as any manufacturing worker from the "good old days" if it wanted to.

The controversy surrounding American Airlines' decision to raise wages for its employees highlights a broader issue: the tension between the interests of shareholders and the well-being of workers. While obsessive cost-cutting may be a good strategy for a given business, it is a terrible strategy for a national economy.

Broad-based income growth creates broad-based business opportunities. The vast majority of Americans earn a living supplying services to other Americans, so when wages don't rise, we struggle to find economic opportunities. As the rich get richer, they still find limits to what they can realistically consume, plowing money instead into financial assets. That creates low interest rates that the government could take advantage of to go deeply into debt and massively expand public sector employment.

However, politicians are reluctant to embrace a growth strategy that is so heavily dependent on debt and centralized control. A far better approach would be something more like a generalization of the American Airlines model. Profitable companies could pay workers more and shareholders less, leading to more spending on the products made by other companies. Those companies would then see their revenue, profits, and wages rise, and people might find themselves buying more plane tickets. That's how functioning market economies used to work, and in the end, even executives and shareholders ended up just fine.

With the unemployment rate finally down to a reasonably low level after years of painfully slow improvement, there's a chance we just may get it. But for it to happen, economic elites will have to learn to live with a world where labor really does get paid first.

Title: President Trump Outlines New Rules for White House Press Conferences Following Jim Acosta's Restoration

Article:

President Donald Trump has stated that he will remove CNN White House reporter Jim Acosta from press conferences if he "misbehaves" going forward, following a federal judge's temporary ruling to reinstate Acosta's press pass. In an interview with Fox News' Chris Wallace on Friday, Trump discussed the decision, marking the first time Wallace has interviewed Trump since he took office.

During the interview, Wallace brought up the judge's ruling, which stated that the White House must reinstate Acosta's press credential. Trump responded, "Yeah, it's fine. I mean, it's not a big deal. What they said, though, is that we have to create rules and regulations for conduct, etc., etc. We're doing that; we're going to write them up right now. It's not a big deal, and if he misbehaves, we'll throw him out or we'll stop the news conference."

When asked about the rules the administration would implement moving forward, Trump stated, "We're writing them now. We'll have rules of decorum; you can't keep asking questions. We had a lot of reporters in that room, many many reporters in that room, and they were unable to ask questions because this guy gets up and starts, you know, doing what he's supposed to be doing for him and for CNN, and you know, just shouting out questions and making statements."

The temporary order from U.S. District Judge Timothy J. Kelly lasts for 14 days, and further hearings are expected to take place in the coming weeks to determine if yanking the credential violated CNN and Acosta's First and Fifth Amendment rights. If the court rules in favor of CNN and Acosta, a permanent injunction may be granted.

Trump emphasized his support for the First Amendment, stating, "I will say this, look, nobody believes in the First Amendment more than I do, and if I think somebody is acting out of sorts, I will leave. I will say thank you very much, everybody, I appreciate you coming, and I'll leave."

Acosta's "hard pass," which provided expedited access to the White House grounds, was suspended last week after a contentious exchange with Trump during a press conference. CNN filed a federal lawsuit against the Trump administration on Tuesday, demanding the restoration of Acosta's press credential, but Press Secretary Sarah Sanders called the move "more grandstanding from CNN."

In a statement following the judge's decision on Thursday, Sanders stated, "Today, the court made clear that there is no absolute First Amendment right to access the White House. In response to the court, we will temporarily reinstate the reporter's hard pass. We will also further develop rules and processes to ensure fair and orderly press conferences in the future. There must be decorum at the White House."

Earlier this week, Fox News announced that it would support CNN's effort to restore Acosta's White House credential and filed an amicus brief with the U.S. District Court. The entire interview will air Sunday on "Fox News Sunday" at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. ET.

Title: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel Faces Challenges in Confronting Defense Cuts and Internal Pentagon Issues

Article:

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, who has maintained a low profile at the Pentagon since his appointment nine months ago, is facing what some sources close to him describe as his biggest challenge as he prepares to confront a new round of defense cuts. According to a report in Politico Magazine, Hagel, who some administration officials refer to as a "paper tiger," has shown signs of fighting back against sequestration cuts by reinstating five of 11 furlough days for Pentagon civilian employees without White House approval.

With a new round of defense cuts on the horizon that could take $100 billion a year from the Pentagon, Hagel and his commanders will need to choose between retaining troops and their benefits programs or paring back on modern weapons systems. The fight may determine the military's future as the nation winds down its war presence in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Hagel shares President Obama's goal of a more efficient, if leaner, military, reports Politico, but he is pushing to separate Pentagon spending entirely from the rest of the nondefense budget, putting him at odds with the White House, which is trying to put pressure on Republicans to spare social programs at the same time they are moving to restore some defense cuts.

"If you just start to carve out certain popular items from the sequester, you don't solve the problem," a source close to Obama told Politico. "Chuck is just doing his job. He wants to exempt the military from the sequester, and that's understandable. But we're looking to get rid of the sequester across the board."

Politico also notes that Hagel is facing a set of challenges within the Pentagon itself, including finding a replacement for top deputy secretary Ashton Carter, who is leaving the Pentagon at the end of the year. Hagel is reportedly still interviewing people for the job, but Politico reports that Robert Work, a former undersecretary of the Navy, is considered the top candidate.

"To some extent you are seeing the Clinton effect," an unnamed former defense official told Politico, explaining why filling important positions at the Pentagon may be difficult. "Why take the risks of working in a second Obama administration when you can make $300,000 in the private sector and then go work for Hillary?"

Dealing with the budget cuts will be Hagel's most pressing and constant challenge, and that may eventually lead to a more public conflict with the president, according to Sen. Jeff Sessions, an Alabama Republican who voted against Hagel during his confirmation.

"The first thing he's got to do is confront the political team in the White House, which is asserting too much influence over policy decisions," Sessions told Politico. "I just think it's his duty to speak the truth to the president and stand up. You can't just always continue in office if you are asked to execute a policy that you truly believe is harmful. You have to make up your mind if you should stay or leave."

Title: Congressional Debate and Vote on U.S. Military Intervention in Iraq and Syria Triggered by ISIS Threat

Article:

The recent U.S. airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq (ISIS) have triggered a congressional debate and potential vote, as President Barack Obama's actions could impact his pledge to cut the Pentagon budget and his administration's approach to military intervention. The White House has justified the airstrikes under the president's constitutional powers as commander in chief, with Iraq's central government and Kurdish regional officials requesting U.S. assistance in combating ISIS.

President Obama has been sending notifications to Congress regarding the airstrikes under the War Powers Act, which restricts American troops from engaging in military action for more than 60 days without congressional authorization. However, recent presidents have disregarded this requirement. Some lawmakers from both parties are growing uncomfortable with the president's unilateral decision-making regarding military action in Iraq and potentially Syria.

Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader from Kentucky, has called on the president to clarify how any additional authority he might seek to strike ISIS would protect Americans. McConnell argues that training and equipping the militaries of partner nations to counter ISIS, as the president has done in Iraq and is proposing to do in Syria, is insufficient to protect the United States.

If the president presents a strategic plan to protect the United States and its allies from ISIS, McConnell stated in a Saturday statement, "I believe he will have significant congressional support." McConnell emphasized the growing ISIS threat and called for the president to take a more active role in formulating a response.

In a Sunday interview, President Obama expressed his vision of the Free Syrian Army providing the ground presence needed to confront ISIS in Syria. He acknowledged the opposition's fractured state and the moderate militias' perceived lack of capability compared to ISIS.

Regarding Syria's President Bashar al-Assad, Obama stated that through his actions, such as using chemical weapons on his own people and dropping barrel bombs that killed innocent children, Assad has forfeited legitimacy. However, the president's policy and the coalition being assembled focus specifically on ISIS, not on ousting Assad. (ISIL is the name used by administration officials for the militant group.)

Title: Louisville Police Chief Announces Intent to Fire Officer Involved in Breonna Taylor Shooting

Article:

Louisville Metro Police Department (LMPD) Chief Robert Schroeder announced on Friday his intention to fire Detective Brett Hankison, one of the officers involved in the shooting death of Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old emergency medical technician. Taylor was killed on March 13 when drug investigators, who had a "no-knock" arrest warrant, mistakenly entered her apartment.

In a letter to Detective Hankison, posted on Twitter, Chief Schroeder stated his intention to terminate the officer for what he described as "extreme" violations of standard operating procedures when Hankison used deadly force upon entering the apartment.

"Your actions displayed an extreme indifference to the value of human life when you wantonly and blindly fired ten (10) rounds into the apartment of Breonna Taylor," Schroeder wrote. "I find your conduct a shock to the conscience."

The River City Fraternal Order of Police, which represents LMPD officers, did not respond to a request for comment.

Detective Hankison, who was hired by the department in 2003, had previously been disciplined in January 2019 for reckless conduct that injured an innocent person, according to Schroeder's letter. Hankison will have the opportunity, with counsel or a union representative, to provide "additional information or mitigating factors" before his termination is finalized.

Benjamin Crump, an attorney for Taylor's family, called the police chief's letter "damning," and on Twitter, he expressed a desire to see the other officers fired and criminally charged.

Taylor's death, along with the May 25 death in Minneapolis police custody of George Floyd and other police killings of Black people, has become a rallying cry for the Black Lives Matter movement and has sparked nationwide protests against racism and police brutality.

Hours after the March 13 raid, Louisville police Lieutenant Ted Eiden told reporters the officers had knocked on the door before forcing entry and were shot at by Taylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker. One officer was struck in the leg, and all three returned fire, hitting Taylor at least eight times, according to the Louisville Courier-Journal. Walker was charged with attempted murder and assault, but last month state prosecutors dropped the charges, the Courier-Journal reported.

Title: Trump Jr., Campaign Advisers Previously Denied Meeting Russians Amid Allegations of Collusion

Article:

Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of President Donald Trump, admitted to having a meeting with a Kremlin-connected Russian lawyer during the 2016 presidential campaign. The meeting was arranged under the premise that the lawyer had damaging information about Hillary Clinton. In light of this admission, it is worth revisiting the numerous instances where Trump Jr. and other campaign advisers denied any contacts with Russians.

The Washington Post has compiled a list of seven such denials, with three of them coming from Donald Trump Jr. himself. In one of his denials, made on Saturday, he stated that his meeting with Natalia Veselnitskaya, the Russian lawyer, was primarily about a program concerning the adoption of Russian children. However, in March, he claimed that during the campaign, he had met with Russians, but he was not representing the campaign in any capacity. In July 2016, shortly after his meeting with Veselnitskaya, when asked about the Clinton campaign's allegations that Russia was attempting to aid Trump, Junior responded that "I can't think of bigger lies, but that exactly goes to show you what the DNC and what the Clinton camp will do. They will lie and do anything to win."

President Trump himself also denied collusion, though he made the denial off-camera after making himself appear guilty by evading the question during a press conference. After being asked twice, "Can you stand here today, once and for all, and say that no one connected to you or your campaign had any contact with Russia leading up to or during the presidential campaign?", Trump reportedly gave a firm denial off-camera to two reporters later.

Vice President Mike Pence responded with "of course not" to two different versions of the collusion question. Kellyanne Conway, a senior advisor to the President, stated "absolutely not." Sean Spicer, the former White House Press Secretary, referred reporters back to Donald Trump's off-camera denial.

All of these denials were made after Donald Jr. met with a Russian with Kremlin ties who claimed to have damaging information on Clinton. Lies, lies, and also lies.

Title: Obama Hails Iran Nuclear Deal as Success, Amidst Bipartisan Concern Over Use of Dollar in Iranian Business Transactions

Article:

President Barack Obama declared the Iran nuclear deal a "substantial success" on Friday during a meeting with leaders of major nuclear powers in Washington, amidst bipartisan concern in Congress that the administration may allow Iran to use the U.S. dollar in business transactions.

"This deal has achieved a substantial success, and it has focused on the dangers of nuclear proliferation in an effective way," Mr. Obama said. "This is a success of diplomacy that hopefully we'll be able to copy in the future."

Critics of the agreement, including Republican lawmakers, presidential candidates, and the Israeli government, argue that the pact provides Iran with too much leeway to continue nuclear weapons development undetected by international inspectors.

Reports suggest that, as the deal is being implemented, the administration will allow Iran to use the dollar for business transactions. The administration had previously stated it would not permit such a move.

Republicans argue that the U.S. should not further reward Iran, given its recent ballistic missile tests.

"As Iran continues to undermine the spirit of its nuclear agreement with illicit ballistic missile tests, the Obama administration is going out of its way to help Tehran reopen for business," said House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, a Wisconsin Republican. "The president should abandon this idea."

House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer, a Maryland Democrat, also expressed opposition.

"I want to make clear my concerns that the administration had indicated that there would be no further concessions beyond those specifically negotiated and briefed to Congress," Mr. Hoyer said in a statement. "I do not support granting Iran any new relief without a corresponding concession. We lose leverage otherwise, and Iran receives something for free."

Mr. Hoyer suggested that Iran's further reintegration into the global economy should only occur "when Iranian banks fully absolve themselves of involvement in terror financing and missile procurement, when the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps ceases its saber-rattling against America's allies, and when Iran's leadership ends its despicable threats against Israel and the Jewish people."

"Until such a time, I think we ought to go no further than fulfilling only our obligations as laid out in the [nuclear agreement], and I look forward to being briefed on what the administration has planned," he said.

U.S. officials stated that the Treasury Department is considering the matter, and any changes would not provide Iran with substantial access to the U.S. financial system.

At the start of the second day of the bi-annual Nuclear Security Summit, Mr. Obama said the Iran nuclear deal is achieving its intended results of preventing Tehran from developing nuclear weapons.

"Iran has dismantled two-thirds of its installed centrifuges," the president said. "Iran has shipped 98 percent of its enriched uranium stockpile out of Iran. Iran has removed the Arak reactor core and filled it with concrete. If Iran were to cheat, the breakout time to build a nuclear weapon has gone from two to three months to about a year."

The agreement lifts economic sanctions on Iran in exchange for limits on its nuclear program and international inspections of its facilities.

Title: Sen. Tom Cotton Accuses Media of 'Stalin-like' Cover-up of Ocasio-Cortez's Green New Deal FAQ

Article:

Sen. Tom Cotton, an Arkansas Republican, has accused the news media of engaging in a "Stalin-like" cover-up of a Green New Deal document produced by the office of Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY), a freshman congresswoman. The controversy stems from a "frequently asked questions" (FAQ) explainer released and then retracted as part of the Green New Deal resolution's rollout.

During a discussion of the ambitious environmental resolution introduced last week, Cotton pointed to the FAQ, which contained several ideas not included in the actual resolution. The most widely derided lines included a call for "high-speed rail at a scale where air travel stops becoming necessary"; expanding public transit "with goals to replace every combustion-engine vehicle"; "economic security for all who are unable or unwilling to work"; and a goal to "fully get rid of farting cows and airplanes."

President Donald Trump referenced ideas from the FAQ in his criticism of the Green New Deal during a rally in El Paso, Texas, on Monday. Ocasio-Cortez has tried to distance herself from the FAQ, claiming that "doctored" Green New Deal documents were "floating around" and that a "draft version" had been uploaded and then taken down.

Saikat Chakrabarti, Ocasio-Cortez's chief of staff, said "an early draft" that "was clearly unfinished and that doesn't represent the GND resolution got published to the website by mistake." Chakrabarti also stated that there was a "doctored FAQ floating around."

Cotton called it "a classic example of a gaffe being when you say what you really mean." He accused the Democrats who proposed the Green New Deal of immediately trying to retract the white paper that went along with their resolution and criticized the media for being complicit in the cover-up.

On Wednesday, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) announced he plans to bring the resolution to the floor for a vote to give senators an opportunity to go on record regarding their stance on the Green New Deal. Most of the declared 2020 Democratic candidates have expressed support for the Green New Deal, including Sens. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.), Cory Booker (D-N.J.), Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), and Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.). Klobuchar plans to vote for the resolution but also implied she might not vote for it as written if it came to the Senate floor as "actual legislation."

Title: CNN's John Avlon Accused of Misinformation in "Reality Check" Segment

Article:

In a segment on CNN's New Day show on Wednesday, July 8, analyst John Avlon delivered a "Reality Check" that was criticized for spreading misinformation. The segment aimed to fact-check Fox News host Tucker Carlson, but it inadvertently perpetuated false claims made by Illinois Democratic Senator Tammy Duckworth during her appearance on CNN's State of the Union.

During the segment, Avlon criticized Carlson for his comments about Senator Duckworth, highlighting her family's military service and her own public service record. The crux of the issue stemmed from Duckworth's statement on the State of the Union that President Trump spent more time at Mt. Rushmore "honoring dead Confederates" than discussing the coronavirus pandemic.

Avlon played a clip of Duckworth's statement, but failed to fact-check her claim. In reality, President Trump's speech at Mt. Rushmore did not honor any Confederates, as he spoke about former Presidents and other historical figures, none of whom were Confederates.

Later in the interview, not shown by Avlon, Duckworth went further by claiming that Trump "spent all his time talking about dead traitors." Carlson later quoted this false claim on his Tuesday show, referencing Duckworth's rejection of an invitation to discuss the issue of statue removal.

In the "Reality Check" segment, Avlon allowed Duckworth's misinformation to stand, implying that it was Carlson and Fox News who could not be trusted to provide accurate information to their viewers. Avlon concluded by suggesting that some individuals resort to fearmongering when they lack facts, and that viewers should question the reliability of Fox News in the current political climate.

This episode was sponsored by Finishing Touch beauty products and Liberty Mutual insurance.

Title: Secret Service Protection of President Obama Sparks Concern Among African Americans

Article:

During the 2008 presidential campaign, concerns about the safety of President Barack Obama arose, with some supporters expressing worry due to perceived threats. Obama reassured his supporters, stating, "I've got the best protection in the world. So stop worrying."

Following Obama's presidency, the Secret Service reported a spike in threats, but they denied claims that he received three to four times more threats than other presidents. According to Joseph Clancy, the director of the Secret Service, the number of threats has since leveled out and remained consistent with his predecessors.

For many African Americans, recent security lapses at the White House have resonated deeply. Talk show host Roland Martin commented on his radio program this week, "One of the greatest fears of a first black president was harm being done to him." The incident involving a fence-jumper making it into the White House underscores this concern.

Charles D. Ellison, writing for The Root, a black-oriented online news site, raised questions about the security lapses. He suggested that either the Secret Service missed the memo about Obama being the first black president or they are overwhelmed.

Many African Americans feel a personal connection to Obama's security, with Joshua DuBois, a former White House aide to Obama, stating, "There's a broad extended family around the country of moms and aunts and uncles who feel a real sense of kinship with this first family, and they want to make sure they're protected and whole."

Some supporters of the president have long asserted that he has been treated with less respect by political opponents and the media, attributing this to his race. This has fueled suspicion that perhaps the Secret Service has not been as committed to him either.

Donald W. Tucker, a retired black member of the Secret Service, stated that he had no reason to believe the agency had not protected Obama vigorously but that he heard the concern regularly.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Political Ads: Distinguishing Issue Ads from Express Advocacy

Article:

The distinction between political issue ads and express advocacy ads has become increasingly blurred, making it difficult for the general public to discern the difference. This issue was addressed in the 2010 Citizens United case, where the Supreme Court ruled that a film produced by the tax-exempt social welfare organization Citizens United, which was critical of then-Senator Hillary Clinton, was considered express advocacy against her candidacy.

In the case, the Supreme Court rejected the argument that the film, titled "Hillary the Movie," was not express advocacy against Clinton's candidacy. Justice Anthony Kennedy, in his decision, stated, "We reject that argument. The film is quite critical of Sen. Clinton."

Today, another social welfare organization, Crossroads GPS, is one of the most prominent political advertisers this spring. Crossroads GPS, co-founded by Republican strategist Karl Rove, has run ads attacking President Obama on a wide range of issues. Crossroads GPS President Steven Law states that the group is not just focused on the election but aims to change policies in Washington.

Crossroads GPS spends a significant amount of time figuring out how to explain issues in a way that is viscerally appealing to viewers and persuades them to take action. The donors who finance these ads remain anonymous, a significant advantage for Crossroads GPS and other social welfare organizations, or 501(c)(4) groups as they are known in the tax code.

Political scientists argue that the line between issue ads and express advocacy has almost been erased. Deborah Jordan Brooks, a government professor at Dartmouth College who studies political attack ads, explains that ads with a personal zinger or those with a lot of personal zingers but still contain some issue content can be difficult to categorize.

Campaign finance lawyer Robert Kelner is not surprised by the vagueness, stating that it is all about free speech. He notes that the price we pay for the benefits of the First Amendment is that we have to essentially give a pass to some ads that look like campaign ads.

However, it still matters which side of the line a group is playing on. A federal judge recently ruled that for certain types of issue ads, 501(c)(4)s have to name the donors. Yet, some groups are switching to express advocacy ads to avoid disclosing their donors. This is risky, as social-welfare organizations cannot make politics their primary purpose. Without 501(c)(4) status, an organization would lose the ability to take anonymous contributions, which gives it political clout. The line between what constitutes political activity and what does not remains unclear, and it is unknown how many ads a 501(c)(4) could run before it would jeopardize its 501(c)(4) status.

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Intervene in Partisan Redistricting Disputes

Article:

The Supreme Court has declined to intervene in disputes related to partisan gerrymandering, ruling that such conflicts are best resolved through the political process and not through federal courts. The two cases, decided on Thursday, presented a strong opportunity for the judiciary to influence the political landscape, as North Carolina Democrats and Maryland Republicans alleged that redistricting plans discriminated against them based on their political views and hindered their First Amendment associational freedoms.

However, the high court has historically declined to validate the theory of partisan gerrymandering. Various justices have identified the fundamental flaw in every partisan gerrymandering claim: it always reduces to the "group right" of a political party or faction to control a proportional number of seats. This "group right" has never been recognized by the court because it is foreign to the U.S. Constitution. Defining each political association that deserves a proportion of seats and assigning each voter to one of those groups remains unclear.

The court was curious to learn whether these problems had been solved in the latest set of cases. The court considered whether the plaintiffs had addressed the doctrinal problems and whether better mathematical approaches could provide a justiciable cause of action.

Ultimately, the majority found that there was nothing new under the sun. The individual right the plaintiffs claimed - to be "free" of partisan gerrymandering - turned out to be the same thing as the long-discredited group right to proportional representation. As a result, federal courts will not adjudicate claims for partisan gerrymandering, keeping redistricting judgments with the political branches. This decision is a victory for the Constitution, according to the Supreme Court.

Eddie Greim and Lucinda Luetkemeyer, partners at Graves Garrett LLC, represented the National Republican Redistricting Trust in one of the redistricting cases.

Title: Biden Criticizes House Speaker's Stance on Immigration Bill at Naturalization Ceremony

Article:

Vice President Joe Biden delivered a keynote speech at a naturalization ceremony in Atlanta on Thursday, where he strongly criticized House Speaker John Boehner's comments regarding an immigration bill that passed the Senate earlier this year. Boehner stated on Wednesday that the House had "no intention" of voting on the bill.

Biden expressed his disappointment over Boehner's announcement, stating, "I am extremely disappointed that Speaker of the House of Representatives announced yesterday that he will not allow the process to work, he will not allow the House to play by fair play, the American way, and let Congress actually vote their conscience to fix a broken system."

Addressing a crowd of 104 naturalized citizens and their families at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change, Biden encouraged the new citizens to help the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants living in the United States. He said, "Do not pull up the ladder behind you when you come on board... there are millions of people who are already acting as decent Americans that deserve a chance, that deserve a path, to earn their way... so reach back, help as you move on, and do not be afraid."

With immigration reform talks at a standstill and the fate of undocumented immigrants uncertain, it is unclear what President Obama could do if the bill dies. In 2012, the President stopped the deportation of undocumented minors under a deferred action program.

The House is in session for 14 days between now and the end of the year, and the third-ranking House Republican, GOP Whip Kevin McCarthy, stated there is not enough time for the bill to be considered.

Biden thanked the new citizens for "picking us," and got big laughs from the audience when telling a story about his Irish-Catholic mother and one of her quintessentially American beliefs.

In closing, Biden pledged to let undocumented immigrants "out of the shadows," saying "they all came for the promise of a better life, and they're incredibly capable of contributing, and many are already contributing."

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell Faces Opposition in Push to Repeal Obamacare

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, may have faced significant resistance from within his own party. McConnell had reportedly anticipated that pressure from a majority of Republicans, who have long promised to dismantle President Barack Obama's signature domestic policy achievement, would persuade senators from Medicaid expansion states to support the repeal.

However, McConnell's endeavors have encountered numerous obstacles. These include opposition from doctors, hospitals, patient advocacy groups, and, notably, governors—many of whom are Republicans—from states where the health care law has led to tens of thousands of residents gaining insurance coverage.

Governor John R. Kasich of Ohio, a Republican, stated at a news conference in Washington on Tuesday, "There may be some philosophical, you know, kind of textbook disagreement. But when you sit in a room and you say to people, ‘Should we strip coverage from somebody who’s mentally ill?’ I’ve never heard anybody say yes."

Last week, Senator Dean Heller of Nevada, a Republican, stood alongside Brian Sandoval, the state's popular Republican governor, and declared, "The bill that’s currently in front of the United States Senate is not the answer—it’s simply not the answer." Heller added, "It’s going to be very difficult to get me to a yes."

Senator Heller's stance, expressed early in the process, seems to have resonated with several senators across the political spectrum who are feeling pressure from their governors and, in some cases, state insurance officials, to resist any bill that could potentially increase premiums, the number of uninsured, or anything else disliked by officials in their states.

In addition, there is the complicating factor of President Trump, who, in any other scenario, would have been an asset to McConnell, but has instead proven to be a hindrance. Republican senators have closely observed Trump as he at times berated, cajoled, and mildly wooed House Republicans to secure their support for their version of a health care bill, which also faced internal divisions.

Title: Obama Proposes Protections for Clean Water, Air, Threatened Species, and Landscapes; Republican Opposition Mounts

Article:

President Barack Obama has announced or is proposing important protections for clean water, clean air, threatened species, and threatened landscapes. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and other Republicans in Congress are counterattacking with a legislative blitz, reminiscent of the legislative assault led by Newt Gingrich and his "Contract With America" Republicans in 1994.

The opposition's arguments revolve around "executive overreach" and "job-killing regulations." However, beneath the political rhetoric lies a deeper, unspoken grievance that President Obama is attempting to implement the promises of environmental laws passed by Congress years ago but unlikely to pass with the current Congress.

In May, the administration approved a rule that significantly increased the number of streams and wetlands protected by the Clean Water Act. The rule aims to ensure cleaner drinking water and minimal impact on responsible development. Despite this, the House has already passed a stand-alone bill to weaken the rule, and Senator John Barrasso of Wyoming introduced a similar bill in the Senate in April, citing potential harm to private property rights.

President Obama is expected to veto any such measures.

In the realm of climate change, President Obama has utilized his authority under the Clean Air Act to increase automobile efficiency, crack down on mercury emissions, and reduce harmful smog. His most significant initiative lies ahead: a final rule due later this summer to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from existing coal-fired power plants. This rule requires individual states to develop emission-reduction plans tailored to their energy mix and is central to President Obama's pledge to reduce America's greenhouse gas emissions by 28% from 2005 levels by 2025, and to his credibility as a leader in the fight against global warming.

Senator McConnell, in service to the coal industry, has been urging states not to cooperate, while sending unhelpful messages to the rest of the world that President Obama will not be able to deliver. The Republicans are weighing how to undermine the rule, but there is little doubt they will attempt to do so.

Title: White House Explores Repurposing Federal Funds for Border Wall in Case of Emergency Declaration

Article:

The White House is reportedly investigating potential federal funds that could be redirected for the construction of a border wall, should President Trump invoke emergency powers to do so. According to sources from Congress and the Pentagon, the Army Corps of Engineers has been asked to identify projects that could be canceled or delayed to free up funds for a border barrier.

Projects under consideration include military construction and civil engineering works designed to prevent damage from future disasters. President Trump has previously threatened to declare a national emergency if he fails to reach a deal with Democratic lawmakers regarding border wall funding, but on Friday, he stated he was not going to do it "so fast because this is something Congress should do."

An emergency declaration would activate special powers that allow the president to redirect federal funds without additional authorization from Congress. Some view an emergency declaration as a potential way out of the ongoing spending stalemate that has led to the partial shutdown of the federal government for the past three weeks.

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) urged Trump to declare a national emergency and build the wall immediately in a statement on Friday following a meeting with the president. On Thursday, Graham tweeted in support of the emergency powers, stating, "I hope it works."

However, tapping emergency powers to bypass a political dispute would likely result in a legal challenge. Trump reiterated on Friday that he was not inclined to take that step immediately. With negotiations at an impasse over the president's demand for $5.7 billion in border wall funding and 800,000 federal workers missing their paycheck on Friday, the White House is evidently considering this option.

According to a Democratic congressional aide, funds that could be redirected include those appropriated in February 2018 for flood control and disaster prevention, as well as the Army Corps' current budget for energy and water projects. Raiding these funds for the border wall would likely face opposition from lawmakers who rely on Army Corps projects in their districts and those concerned about losing control of the purse strings.

Rep. Adam Smith (D-Wash.) stated, "It's a spectacularly bad idea, a complete waste of money." He added, "The only emergency we have on the border right now is people seeking asylum. And people seeking asylum are not trying to sneak in. They're turning themselves in and asking for a hearing."

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) declined to comment on Friday about a potential emergency declaration and the administration's use of Army Corps funds for the wall. "When the president acts, we will respond to whatever he does," she said.

Trump continues to argue that a wall is necessary. On Friday, the president hosted a roundtable discussion with state, local, and community leaders to highlight what he describes as a humanitarian and national security crisis. A new NPR/Ipsos poll indicates that the president's Oval Office speech on the subject had little impact on public opinion. Only 38 percent of those surveyed believed there is a crisis on the border, and fewer still were convinced of the need for a border wall.

Illegal border crossings were lower in 2018 than in 2014 and 2016, but there has been a recent increase.

Title: FBI Decides Not to File Criminal Charges in IRS Targeting Scandal, Raising Questions About Investigation Integrity

Article:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has reportedly decided not to file any criminal charges in connection with the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) admitted, systemic, multi-year targeting of conservative nonprofits for improper scrutiny. The decision was made without interviewing any of the American Center for Law and Justice's (ACLJ) 41 targeted clients, and other Tea Party attorneys report their clients were not interviewed either.

The FBI's decision to leak its conclusions without interviewing the potential victims of the potential crime has been criticized as inexcusable. The timeline of events suggests a quick reversal from public contrition and damage control by the Obama Administration to aggressive anti-conservative spin and, ultimately, an attempt to bury the scandal.

On May 10, 2013, the IRS's Lois Lerner admitted to systematic targeting, blamed lower-level employees, and apologized on behalf of the IRS. On May 14, with the media in full cry, Attorney General Holder announced a criminal investigation, and the next day President Obama condemned IRS misconduct. However, by July, only two months later, the IRS scandal transformed from a source of outrage to a "phony scandal," with the President openly dismissing its significance in public statements.

The ACLJ lawsuit on behalf of 41 clients in 22 states is ongoing. Representatives Darrell Issa and Jim Jordan have called for an investigation into the Department of Justice's (DOJ) Inspector General to answer questions about the FBI's investigation, including why the FBI did not interview the victims before making its determinations, why the lead attorney's partisan giving created an appearance of a conflict of interest, and whether the investigation was cursory and conclusive with a predetermined outcome.

Regardless of the outcome of the criminal investigation, the Obama Administration faces civil litigation and accountability before a federal judge. Justice may be delayed, but it will not be denied.

Title: Trump Admits Mistake on Iran Cash Payment, Clarifies Video Claim

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump admitted on Friday that he had made a mistake regarding the $400 million cash payment made to Iran by the Obama administration. The admission came after a week of intense scrutiny following Trump's initial claim that he had seen "top secret" footage of the payment.

On Wednesday, Trump suggested that the money transfer was a hostage payment to a terrorism-sponsoring government. "We paid $400 million for the hostages," Trump said, according to CNN. "Such a bad precedent was set by Obama."

However, the money was not Iran's cash in the first place. The $400 million was paid to the U.S. by the deposed Shah of Iran in 1979 to buy fighter jets. The U.S. froze those assets but paid the $400 million back to the current government as part of the 2015 nuclear deal.

Trump went further by insisting that he had seen a video of the plane carrying the cash to Iran. "I'll never forget the scene this morning," Trump said Wednesday, describing the alleged footage in detail. However, it was later revealed that Trump had not seen a classified video but had merely seen widely-circulated news footage of the plane carrying the U.S. hostages in Geneva.

Two days after Trump first described the video he had seen, the Republican presidential nominee admitted that the video he'd seen was the widely-circulated news footage of the plane carrying the U.S. hostages in Geneva.

In a campaign as fact-averse as Trump's has been, the acknowledgement, however unapologetic, of basic reality seems like the dawning of a new era. Trump's latest "pivot," which has never quite stuck, may be as simple as acting like a normal human being, capable of recognizing facts and being nice to fellow humans. We'll see how long it lasts.

Title: House Republicans Indicate Little Appetite for Comprehensive Gun Control Legislation

Article:

In the aftermath of the school shooting in Newtown, Connecticut, there are strong indications that any comprehensive gun control legislation will not be voted on by the House of Representatives. Interviews with multiple House Republicans from the Midwest and Northeast reveal a lack of appetite for a sweeping gun bill.

Speaker John Boehner has not received internal pressure from center-right Republicans, and given his difficulties with conservative elements within his conference, there appears to be little political incentive for him to move on the gun issue. This may leave President Barack Obama with few options other than focusing on background checks and executive action.

The political realities of Congress have received little attention in the media coverage of Obama's campaign-style blitz for new gun control measures. Leaders in both chambers have stalled on the issue, using the Biden commission as a cover to avoid taking a definitive stance. Even if Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid were to attempt to push a bill through, there is minimal support among rank-and-file House Republicans for gun control.

Representatives Charlie Dent and Jim Gerlach, two moderate Pennsylvania Republicans from swing districts, have expressed interest in addressing mental health issues to prevent future shootings but do not believe additional gun restrictions are the solution. Dent, who represents the Allentown area, stated that semi-automatic weapons are "commonly owned" in his district and beyond, and that the AR-15, which is often discussed in the context of gun control, is one of the most popular hunting rifles in the country.

Gerlach, who represents suburban Philadelphia, does not support new curbs on firearms or ammunition. He stated that gun politics post-Newtown may not be a significant issue in his district, as most people recognize that responsible gun owners use their weapons responsibly. Gerlah expressed openness to tightening background checks but not gun restrictions.

Other House members and senior GOP aides report that the fiscal cliff and the supplemental spending bill for Hurricane Sandy have dominated the conference's internal conversation for the past month. The gun issue is expected to be raised at their retreat later this week in Williamsburg, Virginia, and additional pressure is likely to come with Obama's inaugural and State of the Union speeches.

Title: President Trump Defends Immigration Restrictions, Blames Protests and Senator Schumer's "Fake Tears"

Article:

President Donald Trump launched a defense of his controversial refugee and immigration restrictions on Monday, attributing the chaos at U.S. airports to a Delta computer outage, protests, and Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer's "fake tears."

On Friday, Trump signed an executive order that imposed a 120-day suspension of the refugee program and a 90-day ban on travel to the U.S. from citizens of seven terror-prone countries, including Iraq, Syria, Somalia, and Sudan. The order led to confusion at U.S. airports as customs agents grappled with interpreting the order, and sparked outrage from civil rights groups and Democratic lawmakers, some of whom attended protests at the nation's airports where some travelers were detained.

Senator Schumer, D-N.Y., who has vowed to fight the order "with every fiber of my being," tweeted Saturday that "there are tears running down the cheeks of the Statue of Liberty tonight." On Sunday, Schumer struggled to hold back tears at a press conference as he called the order "mean-spirited and un-American."

Trump responded Monday morning, stating that only 109 people out of 325,000 were detained and held for questioning. He blamed the chaos at airports on a Delta computer outage, protesters, and "the tears of Senator Schumer."

Trump was referring to a Delta systems outage Sunday night that led to a number of delays. However, the chaos began Saturday, and so most of the chaos was not related to the outage.

After promising again to "Make America Safe Again," Trump reminded his Twitter followers that "there is nothing nice about searching for terrorists before they can enter our country" and urged them to "study the world!"

Trump later doubled down on his criticism of Schumer, telling reporters after a White House meeting with small business owners that he thought "there's about a 5 percent chance [the tears were] real."

"I noticed Chuck Schumer yesterday with fake tears," Trump said. "I’m going to ask him who is his acting coach."

Trump aide Stephen Miller also defended the move Monday morning, stating on Fox & Friends that the list of countries was from a list drawn up by the Obama administration, and that the move was a preventive measure to stop terror attacks like those seen in Europe.

"Our task in this new administration is to prevent what happened in parts of France and Belgium and Germany from happening in the United States," Miller said. "Where you have large pockets of radicalization that extend through generations and that become a long-term security problem."

Responding to criticism that the order had been dropped on agencies with little-to-no warning, both Miller and Trump said that a window would have allowed potential terrorists to come in before it closed.

The Trump administration was forced to make a number of clarifications on the status of permanent legal residents or "green card" holders, while a federal judge issued a stay on deportations late Saturday.

Title: UK Government Faces Legal Challenge Over Approval of Gas-Fired Power Plant Amid Climate Change Concerns

Article:

The UK government is facing a legal challenge over its approval of a large gas-fired power plant, with environmental lawyers ClientEarth filing a judicial review. The power plant, being developed by Drax in north Yorkshire, would become the biggest gas power station in Europe and could produce 75% of the UK's power sector emissions when fully operational, according to ClientEarth.

The planning inspectorate had recommended that the 3.6GW gas plant be refused permission due to its potential adverse effects on the government's commitment to cut greenhouse gas emissions. This marked the first big project rejected due to the climate crisis. However, Andrea Leadsom, the secretary of state for business, energy, and industrial strategy, overruled the advice and gave the go-ahead in October.

ClientEarth has been granted permission by the high court to sue ministers, with the case expected to be heard in about two months. The environmental lawyers have previously inflicted three defeats on ministers over their failure to tackle air pollution.

Sam Hunter Jones, a lawyer at ClientEarth, stated, "With scientists ringing the alarm bells for decades, we shouldn't need to take the government to court over its decision. [Leadsom's] decision is at odds with the government's own climate change plans. As the planning inspectorate found, if this plant goes ahead, the public risks a carbon budget blowout, or a huge stranded asset that would require propping up by the taxpayer, or a combination of the two."

A Drax spokeswoman argued that the company's ambition was to remove, not add, carbon to the atmosphere by 2030. This would be achieved by burning wood or plants and then capturing and storing the emissions. The spokeswoman also stated that Drax's carbon-negative ambition could be achieved alongside "new, high-efficiency gas power capacity as part of our portfolio" and provide electricity when the wind was not blowing or the sun shining.

The UK government's actions to tackle the climate emergency are under particular scrutiny this year as it will host a vital UN summit in Glasgow in November. The world's nations must dramatically increase their pledges to cut carbon emissions at the summit to avoid a disastrous 3-4C rise in global temperatures.

In its planning application, Drax stated that its proposal for four new gas turbines was warranted to replace its existing two coal-fired units ahead of the government's proposed phase-out of coal in 2025. It also claimed that the new gas plant would be "capable" of having carbon capture technology fitted in the future.

In overruling the planning inspectorate, Leadsom argued that the plant's high carbon emissions were not a reason to block approval under the existing rules. However, ClientEarth argues that the combination of the project's large scale, level of carbon emissions, and long operating life make it a significant threat to the UK's carbon targets.

The planning inspectorate also concluded that wind and solar power would cut payers' bills, while the proposed gas plant would not. "Both [Drax] and [National Grid] confirmed that it is the production of renewable plants that will deliver cheaper energy," the planning inspectorate stated.

Title: Victoria Toensing's Allegations of Benghazi Cover-up: A Review of Past Claims and Current Developments

Article:

Republican attorney Victoria Toensing has resurfaced in the news, this time claiming that anonymous State Department and CIA whistleblowers have been prevented from testifying about the September 2012 attack on the U.S. diplomatic facility in Benghazi, Libya. Fox News' Ed Henry brought up the story during a press conference with President Obama, who stated he had no knowledge of the matter.

It is worth noting that this is not the first time Toensing has made allegations of a cover-up regarding the Benghazi attack. In November 2012, she wrote an op-ed for Fox News, attempting to draw a connection between the Benghazi attack and the abrupt resignation of former CIA Director David Petraeus.

Toensing's argument was complex and convoluted. She suggested that Petraeus' support for the White House's initial indications that an anti-Islam video had incited the Benghazi attackers was "strange," given that Petraeus, in her view, must have known otherwise. Toensing posited that the administration's initial response was a deliberate attempt to downplay the role of radical Islamic groups in the attack, which she believed was a cover-up.

Toensing's theory involved several interconnected elements. She suggested that Obama was blackmailing Petraeus with knowledge of an extramarital affair that led to Petraeus' resignation. Furthermore, she claimed that the administration had concealed the affair to use it against Petraus at a later date.

Toensing's theory was met with skepticism, as it relied on several tenuous connections and speculative assumptions. For instance, she suggested that Petraeus' memory of the affair would have been fresh during a 2011 polygraph test, despite the fact that polygraph tests do not typically delve into personal details of a candidate's life.

Toensing's column was published just before Petraeus was scheduled to testify before Congress on the Benghazi attack. However, her predictions proved incorrect, as Petraeus testified as planned a few days later and explained the administration's initial response to the attack.

In conclusion, Victoria Toensing's past allegations of a Benghazi cover-up have been largely discredited. Her latest claims regarding whistleblowers and alleged obstruction should be approached with caution, as they rely on speculative connections and a lack of verifiable evidence. It is essential to maintain a critical and fact-based approach when evaluating such claims.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidate Beto O'Rourke Proposes Classifying White Supremacist Violence as Organized Crime

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke has unveiled a plan to classify white supremacist violence as an organized crime problem and establish federal domestic terrorism offices as a means to combat hate crimes and gun violence in the United States. The proposal comes after a white gunman's attack on a Walmart store in El Paso, Texas, on August 3, which resulted in the deaths of 22 people.

O'Rourke, a former congressman, announced his plan a day after he recalibrated his presidential campaign, emphasizing the plight of immigrants and addressing what he characterized as racially charged and divisive rhetoric from Republican President Donald Trump.

In a statement, O'Rourke stated, "The terrorist attack on El Paso, fueled by the racist rhetoric of Donald Trump, was not only an attack on America, but an attack on the aspirational ideals of this nation." He further added, "It's time for bold solutions... without fear of political ramifications so we can finally start making progress and saving lives."

Senator Cory Booker, another Democratic presidential candidate and O'Rourke's rival, had previously announced his intention to create a White House office to combat white supremacy and hate crimes if elected.

Under O'Rourke's plan, if elected president, he would ensure that the FBI and the Department of Justice prioritize neo-Nazi and white supremacist violence, and he would create dedicated domestic terrorism offices within the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Justice.

O'Rourke also plans to hold internet companies and social media platforms accountable for hosting hate speech and the amplification of domestic terrorism, take on the National Rifle Association gun lobby group, and implement a mandatory national buyback program for assault weapons and a voluntary buyback program for handguns.

O'Rourke is one of many Democratic candidates vying to become the nominee to take on Trump in next November's election who have criticized what they perceive as the president's divisive and incendiary rhetoric about undocumented migrants.

Title: Senate Health Care Bill Negotiations: GOP Senators Disagree on Current Proposal, Consider Bipartisan Approach

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that if Republican senators cannot agree on the current health bill, they will have to devise an alternative approach. Senator John McCain (R-Ariz.) said on CBS's Face the Nation that the Republican bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, is "probably going to be dead."

Support for the bill has been waning during the July 4th recess, and McCain suggested that Republicans should collaborate with Democrats to draft health care legislation. This possibility was floated last week by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who said, "No action is not an alternative."

Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas) reiterated his push to simply repeal Obamacare, let it take effect for a year or two, and use that time to debate replacement. "I continue to believe we can get this done," he said on Face the Nation.

Republicans need at least 51 votes to pass their repeal and replace proposal, and they have not been able to secure the necessary support. Senator Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) said on NBC's Meet the Press that he would support the current proposal, but expressed uncertainty about whether Republicans can come together. "Mitch is trying," Graham said. "I would support the proposal before us, but you've got different camps in the Republican Party."

Graham noted that with insurers withdrawing from exchanges and premiums rising, the failure of Obamacare is imminent. "My advice is if it does fail, work together in a bipartisan fashion to replace it," he said.

President Trump took to Twitter later on Sunday to encourage senators to move forward. "For years, even as a 'civilian,' I listened as Republicans pushed the Repeal and Replace of ObamaCare," he wrote. "Now they finally have their chance!"

The Senate health care bill negotiations are ongoing, with key issues such as Medicaid expansion, essential health benefits, and subsidies for low-income individuals still under discussion. The future of the current health bill remains uncertain, and the possibility of a bipartisan approach to health care reform is being considered.

Title: White House Installs Senior Aides at Federal Agencies to Maintain Control Over Policy Implementation

Article:

The White House is installing senior aides atop major federal agencies, creating a direct line with loyalists who can monitor and shape the administration's goals across the federal bureaucracy. These aides, given the title of senior adviser in each agency, have already been responsible for hiring at some departments and crafting the blueprint of Trump policy before the Cabinet members win Senate confirmation to take office.

The arrangement, described by four people involved in the transition planning, appears designed to help the White House maintain control over its priorities despite pledging to give Cabinet secretaries unusual autonomy. Having senior advisers reporting to both the agency chiefs and the White House could spur early tensions and create conflicts with that pledge of autonomy.

"They want to keep kind of a West Wing-infused attachment to the agencies," said a person familiar with the arrangement. "There will be tentacles from the White House to these agencies...The effort is to demonstrate that all points lead back to certain people," such as Donald Trump's son-in-law, White House senior adviser Jared Kushner, or chief of staff Reince Priebus.

Another person involved in the transition said Trump's team wanted a "real strong line at the agencies to have someone monitoring and directing what they're doing." This approach bears out in the administration's picks for these posts, people who are far more political players than policy experts.

For instance, Wells Griffith will serve as the White House's new senior adviser for the Department of Energy, following stints as the battleground states director for Trump's campaign and as the former deputy chief of staff to Priebus at the Republican National Committee. Other campaign staffers have been given similar roles at several agencies, according to people familiar with the matter.

Historically, the liaison positions are held by more junior staffers. Administrations typically left the bigger tasks, such as the policy agenda or management of the agency, to the Cabinet secretary, deputy secretary, and chief of staff.

Prior administrations have used liaisons to help coordinate low-level policy, staffing, and operations between the White House and Cabinet agencies. President Barack Obama had them across the government for policy areas such as climate change and health care. They often gave the White House a lens into the agency and some understanding of the day-to-day operations, along with keeping tabs on their problems.

What's different about the Trump hierarchy is the power these advisers are likely to have, according to people familiar with it. Obama's liaisons were often less powerful, while Trump's will connect directly to senior White House officials such as Kushner and Rick Dearborn, Trump's deputy chief of staff for policy.

In Trump's Cabinet, a number of the secretaries have expressed disagreement with Trump during lengthy confirmation hearings on issues ranging from Russia to climate change to the use of NATO. Some of the picks were neutral in the election or criticized Trump's policies.

Two people involved in the transition said the new advisers are expected to maintain constant contact with the White House and the agencies and sign off on major decisions. The liaisons will also give the White House a window into agencies where Trump is not as personally close to the Cabinet secretaries. Some of the senior White House advisers in the agencies have frequently met with their respective secretaries, who did not pick them for the post.

Former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani said he modeled his own government that way, with a handpicked senior aide installed in every agency. "I told my commissioners when I was mayor, you're going to have a spy in your agency," Giuliani said. "I'm going to want to get two different perspectives of what's going on."

The jobs have rattled Obama administration political appointees, who have been surprised at young campaign hands having such authority at federal agencies. The advisers at each agency will not face Senate approval, like more than 1,200 other federal government positions, including deputy secretaries and administrators.

Trump himself is likely to have little involvement in the minutiae of the agencies; people close to him expect him to want top-level briefings and little else. He tends to like conflict among his top aides and advisers, with them competing for his attention and respect.

"The government is too big to run everything out of the White House," added Stier. "That pipeline is too small to deal with the breadth and complexity of the federal government."

Tevi Troy, a former White House aide and deputy secretary at Health and Human Services under President George W. Bush, said there are potential upsides for these advisers. For instance, they are not likely to face subpoenas in the event of mishaps at the agencies.

Yet, they also could face tensions with the Cabinet secretaries for micromanaging or feel torn about where to spend the majority of their time, in the West Wing or at the agency itself.

Title: Maryland Gubernatorial Candidate Doug Gansler Criticizes ACA Implementation in State

Article:

Maryland gubernatorial candidate Doug Gansler, a Democrat and current attorney general, has expressed displeasure over the botched rollout of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) in his state. He is particularly critical of the state's online enrollment platform and the decision to hire a company from North Dakota for the implementation of the state's exchange.

The ACA, also known as Obamacare, has been a subject of partisan battles in Washington, D.C., and within the Republican Party. However, it is Maryland, the state just north of the capital, that has provided the country's first instance of a Democrat-on-Democrat dispute over the inept implementation of the law.

In the race to succeed outgoing Democratic Governor Martin O'Malley, Gansler is running against state Delegate Heather Mizeur and Lieutenant Governor Anthony Brown, the front-runner for the Democratic nomination who chairs the state panel on ACA implementation and has been presented as the O'Malley administration's point man on Obamacare.

After promising to make deep-blue Maryland an ACA success story, Brown and O'Malley watched as the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange struggled, allowing fewer than 4,000 Marylanders to enroll in insurance plans by the end of November. The executive director of the state exchange resigned at the start of December.

Gansler has criticized Brown over the performance of the state exchange, arguing that it has "failed miserably" and provided "fodder for Republicans" who want to scrap the ACA altogether. He has used the health care mess as an example of Brown's perceived lack of substance.

"Brown and others were so boastful about Maryland leading the country, [but] here we are behind such states as Nevada and Kentucky, let alone California and states like that," Gansler said, emphasizing his support for the president and the ACA, but also expressing concern over the enrollment process in individual states.

The Maryland race is unique in that it features an open-seat contest for the heart of the Democratic base between two major candidates, one of whom was directly tasked with implementing a state health care exchange. For health care reform critics, Gansler is an imperfect messenger, a combative politician who replaced his campaign manager last week in an effort to steady his bid for governor.

Even still, the success or failure of Gansler's biting message could reveal the level of frustration or patience among rank-and-file Democrats with the progress of a law that was supposed to usher in a new era of activist government. There is little chance of a competitive general election in Democratic Maryland, but success by Gansler could also presumably cheer Republicans who have put the ACA's implementation woes front and center for their 2014 message.

Gansler's campaign has faced several setbacks this year, including a recording that surfaced in The Washington Post, capturing Gansler dismissing Brown, who is black, for relying on his race as a campaign asset. Gansler's campaign called the recording a dirty trick. There was also a Post story on accusations that Gansler ordered his state trooper detail to violate traffic laws, a charge Gansler also attributed to political skulduggery. Most embarrassing was an ABC News report featuring photos of Gansler at a raucous high school beach party featuring apparent underage drinking.

Brown, meanwhile, has garnered support from a host of unions and prominent elected officials, including O'Malley, Senators Ben Cardin and Barbara Mikulski, Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, and U.S. House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer.

Even with all that weighing on his campaign, bashing Obamacare—even just on the details of implementation—is a striking turn of events for Gansler, an Obama stalwart who fought in court to uphold the constitutionality of the president's signature achievement.

Asked whether his ACA attacks were merely an attempt to turn the page for his campaign, Gansler said he had "a rough rollout because of political dirty tricks on the part of the Brown campaign," but called health care the real issue in the race. Brown, a former state legislator and Iraq War veteran, declined an interview request and has generally shied away from engaging attacks from Gansler and others.

Justin Schall, Brown's campaign manager, dismissed Gansler's ACA criticism as opportunistic and faulted Gansler for taking potshots on the ACA now, despite having done little to help with implementation as part of the advisory committee that Brown chairs.

"As attorney general, Doug Gansler is a member of the Health Care Reform Council, and he hasn't bothered to show up to a meeting in the last two years, so it's a little disingenuous when Doug opines on the importance of Obamacare," Schall said. "When input on health care reform was needed, Gansler was nowhere to be found, and now Doug hopes people will forget his absence as he attacks a fellow Democrat on ACA."

Title: House Judiciary Committee to Examine Legality of President Obama's Executive Action on Immigration

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee is set to hold a hearing on Tuesday regarding the legality of President Obama's recent executive action on immigration. The hearing, which will take place on Capitol Hill, will question witnesses about the constitutionality of the president's move.

Chairman of the Committee, Bob Goodlatte, previewed the hearing on Fox News' The Kelly File, stating that Obama's executive amnesty is "one of the largest unconstitutional power grabs by any president ever."

The witness list for the hearing includes Ronald Rotunda, a professor at Dale E. Fowler School of Law, Jay Sekulow, the chief counsel at the American Center for Law and Justice, Thomas H. Dupree Jr., a partner at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, and Marielena Hincapi, the executive director at the National Immigration Law Center.

In his prepared testimony, Sekulow argues that President Obama's recent action on immigration violates the Constitution. He contends that the actions contradict Congress's express and implied intent, violating the test articulated in Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer. Sekulow also claims that by enacting a sweeping new program under the guise of "prosecutorial discretion," President Obama has violated controlling precedent and defied clear instructions from his own attorneys at the Office of Legal Counsel.

Last week, the Congressional Research Service determined that Congress does have the power to defund President Obama's executive amnesty action, despite the agency being primarily funded by fees. The Supreme Court has recognized that Congress may restrict agency discretion to allocate resources by putting restrictions in the operative statutes. If a statute were enacted which prohibited appropriated funds from being used for some specified purposes, then the relevant funds would be unavailable to be obligated or expended for those purposes.

The hearing is scheduled to start at 1 p.m. ET and can be watched live here.

Title: Congress Approves Budget and Hurricane Relief Deal, Raises Debt Ceiling

Article:

Congress, in a bipartisan vote, has approved a budget and hurricane relief deal brokered between President Donald Trump and top Democrats. The House of Representatives approved the bill by a vote of 316 to 90, with all 90 votes against coming from Republicans. The Senate approved the deal on Thursday by 80-17.

The deal, which was the result of an Oval Office meeting on Wednesday between Trump, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, Vice President Mike Pence, and congressional leaders from both parties, raises the debt ceiling, funds the federal government through December 8, and provides $15 billion for relief from Hurricane Harvey, which hit Texas and Louisiana last month.

The deal came as Hurricane Irma approached Florida. The deal's genesis was an Oval Office meeting on Wednesday between Trump, Mnuchin, Pence, and congressional leaders from both parties. Trump agreed to a Democratic proposal to tie hurricane relief to funding the federal government and increasing the debt ceiling for a three-month period.

Republican leaders had pushed for a longer-term deal, to raise the debt ceiling through the 2018 midterm elections. Democrats welcomed the deal, which they saw as Republicans being forced to grudgingly accept. Many congressional Republicans have long been opposed to raising the debt ceiling without taking steps to reduce federal spending.

Mnuchin and Office of Management and Budget director Mick Mulvaney received a frosty welcome when they pitched the deal to congressional Republicans in a conference meeting on Friday morning. Mnuchin, a former Democrat, and Mulvaney, a stalwart of the House Freedom Caucus before joining the Trump administration, made less than ideal surrogates.

At the meeting, Mnuchin provoked hissing and groans when he closed with a plea for members to "vote for the debt ceiling for me."
