The meeting also got "a little warm for Mulvaney at times" according to Mark Walker, a North Carolina representative who noted that people in the room "reminded him [of] some of the statements he had made in the past about relief packages tied to the debt ceiling."

After leaving the meeting, Mulvaney dodged a question about whether he would have voted for the bill, choosing to praise Trump's decision to reach across the aisle. "I thought it was absolutely the right thing to do," the former South Carolina congressman said. "The president is a very results-driven person, he wants to see results."

Peter King, a moderate from New York, saw the vote as a precursor to better days to come. "We continue to work across the aisle, we'll get things done, we can't let one faction control everything," he said in a veiled shot at the Freedom Caucus. "We represent the country, not a party."

With these must-pass measures out of the way, Trump is expected to spend the coming months focusing on promoting his plans for major tax cuts. No bill has yet been introduced in Congress, but Trump has made several speeches touting his proposals to lower corporate taxes to as little as 15%.

On Friday morning, after tweets about hurricane Irma and his frustration with Senate rules and the failure of healthcare reform, the president wrote: "Republicans must start the Tax Reform/Tax Cut legislation ASAP. Don't wait until the end of September. Needed now more than ever. Hurry!"

Title: Democrats Call for Investigations and Potential Impeachment of Attorney General Bill Barr

Article:

Following the acquittal of President Donald Trump by the Senate, Democrats have set their sights on Attorney General Bill Barr as a new target for investigations and potential impeachment. The focus on Barr stems from his apparent move to overrule prosecutors' recommended sentence for former Trump adviser Roger Stone.

Criticism of Barr comes from various sectors, including members of Congress, members of the media, political operatives, and law professors. The Attorney General is under intense scrutiny for alleged "misuse of the criminal justice system," not only in the Stone case but also in relation to the removal of U.S. Attorney Jessie Liu in January and accepting Ukraine-related information from Trump's personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani.

Barr is also facing pressure from President Trump himself, as Trump pushed back against Barr's comments Thursday that he had never asked the Attorney General to intervene in a criminal case. Trump tweeted, "This doesn’t mean that I do not have, as President, the legal right to do so, I do, but I have so far chosen not to!"

On March 31, Barr will answer questions on these issues in a hearing before the Democrat-controlled House Judiciary Committee. House Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler, D-N.Y., wrote a letter confirming Barr's testimony, stating that the Attorney General's actions in legal matters relating to the President raise significant questions for the Committee.

Earlier this week, four Department of Justice prosecutors resigned after top DOJ officials stepped in to soften their 7- to 9-year recommended sentence of Stone following a tweet by Trump about the case. Democrats called the move "without precedent" and sharpened their already simmering criticisms of Barr.

Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., said Barr "ought to be ashamed and embarrassed and resign as a result of this action directly interfering in the independent prosecution of Roger Stone." He also stated that the controversy was yet another example of "political interference by the president to alter the independent decisions of the Department of Justice."

Nadler did not answer a question on whether Barr should resign, but said, "I think the behavior is extremely egregious."

Barr, on ABC News Thursday, pushed back on Trump's tweet while also defending his handling of the Stone case. "I'm gonna do what I think is right," he said, "and you know, I can not do my job here at the department with a constant background commentary that undercuts me."

White House officials told Fox News that they knew Barr was doing the ABC interview but that they did not know what the AG would say.

Jon Cooper, chairman of the anti-Trump organization Democratic Coalition, tweeted, "What Bill Barr REALLY means is that Trump’s tweets saying the quiet part out loud are making it harder for him to do the crimes and cover-up."

Some on the left have even called for Barr's impeachment, including MSNBC legal analyst Glenn Kirschner, who tweeted before the Stone developments last week that Barr has lied "to Congress, he lied about the Mueller report, he refuses to investigate obvious crimes by the administration, he is conflicted out of many matters but refuses to recuse."

Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-Calif., told CNN Wednesday that he would not rule out launching a new impeachment inquiry into Trump himself over the drama around Stone and Barr. "You know, we’re not going to take our options off the table," he said. "We want to work with him on prescription drugs, background checks, and infrastructure, but we’re not going to let him just torch this democracy because he thinks that he’s been let off once and we’re not going to do something about it."

Other politicians, such as Sens. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., and Cory Booker, among others, have also called for investigations into Barr's actions. House Speaker Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., condemned Barr on Thursday and called for an investigation but did not outright call for impeachment.

At the same time, Democratic Sens. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., Kamala Harris, D-Calif., Chris Coons, D-Del., and Booker, among others, have hit Barr in a joint statement on "the politicization and maladministration of American immigration courts under President Donald Trump." The statement announced a letter they sent to Barr asking for documents on the matter.

Republicans, meanwhile, have largely stuck by Barr. Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., released a statement backing the AG on Thursday. "President Trump, in selecting Bill Barr to be Attorney General, has done a great service to the people serving in the Department of Justice and our nation as a whole," Graham said. "He is the right man at the right time to reform the Department and stand up for the Rule of Law. Attorney General Barr has my complete confidence."

Title: Fox News Hosts Engage in Public Dispute over Donald Trump Interviews

Article:

A public disagreement between two prominent Fox News hosts, Megyn Kelly and Sean Hannity, has arisen over Donald Trump's interview choices. The dispute was initiated when Kelly criticized Trump for limiting his interviews to Hannity, stating that he does not engage with other interviewers.

During her television show, The Kelly File on Wednesday night, Kelly commented, "Donald Trump, with all due respect to my 10 o'clock colleague, will go on Hannity and pretty much only Hannity and will not venture out to the unsafe spaces these days, which doesn't exactly expand the tent."

Hannity responded to Kelly's statement on Twitter, posting, "@megynkelly u should be mad at @HillaryClinton Clearly you support her. And @realDonaldTrump did talk to u."

This exchange marks the latest drama at the conservative-leaning cable news channel, which has been embroiled in internal discord since the revelation that its longtime CEO, Roger Ailes, allegedly engaged in serial sexual harassment over decades. Ailes resigned in July and has since become an informal adviser to the Trump campaign.

Kelly herself became a campaign issue in the summer of 2015 after moderating the first Republican primary debate. Trump took issue with her tough questioning and, in an interview on CNN the following day, made a comment widely interpreted as a reference to menstruation when he suggested she "had blood coming out of her eyes, blood coming out of wherever." The ensuing uproar led Trump to be banned from a major gathering of conservatives and sparked the biggest crisis of his campaign at that time.

Since then, Kelly has continued to be a target of Trump, who called her "crazy Megyn" in March and even tweeted at her during Tuesday's vice-presidential debate. In contrast, Hannity has appeared in an advertisement for Trump and consistently speaks of the Republican nominee in glowing terms. Trump has appeared in numerous one-on-one primetime interviews with Hannity and even cited Hannity as a character witness in the first presidential debate.

When asked why there was no evidence for his claims that he had opposed the second Iraq war, Trump stated, "Nobody called Sean Hannity." However, it is a matter of record that Trump supported the invasion of Iraq in 2002.

Title: House Republicans Disrupt Impeachment Probe, Alleging Lack of Fairness

Article:

On Wednesday, a group of House Republicans stormed a secure room where the impeachment inquiry against President Trump was being conducted, causing a disruption and upending a scheduled deposition. The move was met with anger from Democrats, who accused the Republican lawmakers of creating a potential security lapse by bringing electronics into the secure area.

The Republicans argued that the hearing they disrupted, involving Defense Department official Laura Cooper, was not classified, and they claimed that Democrats have violated fairness by excluding them from the impeachment process.

Rep. Mark Walker, a North Carolina Republican, stated, "House Democrats are bypassing constitutional norms and basic standards of due process with their impeachment obsession. The president is not above justice. But, as you know, neither is he below it."

Rep. Debbie Lesko of Arizona was more direct, asserting that the Democrats' impeachment inquiry into President Trump's communications with Ukraine over former Vice President Joseph R. Biden, a political opponent, is not following any of the precedents for impeachment proceedings.

Democrats countered that Republicans on the impeachment committees can participate and ask questions, and that they have access to transcripts and information. They argued that the Republican protesters, who are not on the impeachment committees, have no right to see what's going on.

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam B. Schiff, a California Democrat, threatened to bring ethics charges against the Republican protesters, and Homeland Security Committee Chairman Bennie G. Thompson asked the sergeant at arms to investigate the breach of the room, known as a Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility or SCIF.

Rep. Eric Swalwell, a California Democrat, said the problem was that lawmakers brought in electronic devices, which are usually banned. "And they not only brought in their unauthorized device, they may have brought in the Russians and Chinese with electronics in a secure space," Mr. Swalwell said.

Ms. Cooper ultimately testified, five hours after she was scheduled to begin. The details of her testimony remain undisclosed. Her testimony comes a day after a former U.S. diplomat to Ukraine testified that President Trump made the release of military aid to Ukraine contingent on that country investigating Mr. Biden and his son Hunter, who was on the board of directors of Ukrainian energy company Burisma.

The impeachment committees leading the inquiry have issued a new demand for State Department documents, including text messages from witnesses and any memos regarding efforts to press Ukraine to open investigations. Meanwhile, three Democratic senators have filed a Freedom of Information Act request with the Justice Department for documents related to Ukraine.

A federal judge has also ordered the State Department to begin releasing Ukraine-related documents within 30 days. These documents include communications between Mr. Giuliani and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. The judge's ruling was in response to a Freedom of Information Act request by American Oversight, a left-leaning government watchdog organization.

Title: Senator Rand Paul Addresses Temperament and Interview Controversies

Article:

Senator Rand Paul, a Republican presidential candidate, acknowledged on Wednesday the need to "get better at holding my temper" after clashing with two reporters over uncomfortable questions about his stance on abortion and foreign aid.

During an interview with CNN's Wolf Blitzer, Paul denied a tendency to interrupt female reporters, stating, "I think I've been universally short-tempered and testy with both male and female reporters."

Paul attributed his behavior to the challenging nature of being interviewed, particularly when facing only a camera and not the reporter, and when dealing with a hostile interviewer. He expressed a preference for questions over editorializing, stating, "I do think interviews should be questions and not editorializing. You feel somewhat at a loss at the other end."

In a contentious exchange with "Today" show anchor Savannah Guthrie, Paul objected to what he perceived as biased questioning about his foreign policy views. The interview took a turn when Guthrie detailed perceived shifts in Paul's foreign policy positions over the years. Paul attempted to interject, stating, "Why don't you let me explain instead of talking over me, OK?"

Paul contended that his views on foreign aid have been consistent, and that his views on Iran's threat level have evolved over time. He stated, "What I would say is that there has always been a threat of Iran gaining nuclear weapons, and I think that's greater now than it was many years ago. I think we should do everything we can to stop them."

Later in the day, Paul bristled at a question about abortion while talking with reporters in New Hampshire. He referred to the Democratic National Committee and stated, "Why don't you ask the DNC, 'Is it OK to kill a seven-pound baby in the uterus?'" His comment followed a report by The Associated Press that Paul had ducked questions about his views on abortion exceptions.

In the past, Paul has clashed with other interviewers, including CNBC anchor Kelly Evans, whom he chastised in February for posing "slanted" questions. Paul offered Evans a suggestion on how to conduct a better interview, stating, "So, frankly, I think if we do this again, you need to try to start out with a little more objectivity going into the interview."

When asked about his testy interview with Guthrie later on Wednesday, Paul decried questions about apparent changes in his positions, stating, "That is not journalism."

Title: Obama Administration Announces New Policy on Deportation of Illegal Immigrant Students

Article:

The Obama administration announced a new policy on Friday that has elicited a wave of elation among illegal immigrant students, praise from Democrats and Latino leaders, and criticism from Republicans. The policy change, according to administration officials, was initiated by Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano, who proposed using existing laws to lift the threat of deportation for large numbers of illegal immigrant students.

Since the beginning of the administration, Ms. Napolitano had been increasingly criticized by Latino and immigrant advocates for perceived obstruction of President Obama's policies. Mr. Obama had pledged his support for the Dream Act, a proposal before Congress that would provide a path to legal status for illegal immigrant students, during his first campaign in 2008.

The shift in policy was reportedly aimed at easing rising impatience at the White House with Ms. Napolitano's department. A significant hurdle, White House officials said, was resistance from career staff members and enforcement agents at Immigration and Customs Enforcement to a policy adopted a year ago. This policy required them to use prosecutorial discretion in picking and choosing among illegal immigrants facing deportation, marking the first time immigration officers had been asked to make such judgments as a regular practice.

The National ICE Council, a union representing deportation agents, openly questioned the policy, stating that its members had not been consulted and that they faced serious risks in distinguishing among immigrants who had violated the law. A review, initiated in November, of more than 411,000 deportation cases before the nation's immigration courts revealed that prosecutors had halted the deportation of only 593 illegal immigrant students.

Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a Republican whose political star is rising within his party, was reportedly close to introducing a bill to help illegal immigrant students by providing them with a temporary status, a proposal similar to what White House officials had in mind. There was concern among White House officials that Mr. Rubio's proposal might pre-empt the president, making it appear he did not want to work with Republicans.

The White House was also awaiting a ruling from the Supreme Court on the administration's lawsuit against Arizona over a tough state immigration enforcement law. Campaign officials feared an adverse decision could leave Mr. Obama empty-handed when he tried to mobilize Latino voters for the November election.

A significant concern for Mr. Obama, White House officials said, was whether he had legal authority to offer relief to so many immigrants. In recent weeks, the White House counsel, Kathryn Ruemmler, and Homeland Security lawyers pored over the law and concluded they were on firm ground. The main point, the officials said, was that the policy would have to be carried out case by case, meaning the workload for the immigration bureaucracy would be substantial.

Under the policy, officials are to exercise discretion in deferring deportations of immigrants who qualify for two years. A grant of deferred action, as it is formally known, allows immigrants to apply for work permits. To be eligible, they must be 30 or younger and have come to the United States before they were 16. They must be in school or high school graduates or military veterans, with no criminal records.

Mr. Obama was hearing often from exasperated Democratic lawmakers. Senator Durbin, who first introduced the Dream Act 11 years ago, said he advised the president recently that he would not be able to muster enough votes in the Senate to pass the bill before the November election. In a vote in late 2010, the Dream Act was blocked by Republicans in the Senate.

"Meanwhile," Mr. Durbin said, "we were getting calls every week saying that young people were being deported. We would jump in and save them. But there was anger and uncertainty and fear among them."

Mr. Durbin said he had urged Mr. Obama to "do something much more sweeping." Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, a leading Hispanic Democrat, also prodded the White House. The Democratic leaders' message found a sympathetic hearing from Cecilia Muñoz, a former immigration reform advocate who is a senior White House adviser to Mr. Obama.

In the end, the policy shift came quickly, White House officials said, with Mr. Obama making his choice early last week, leaving officials scrambling to prepare the logistics in time for his announcement on Friday. The White House agreed that Ms. Napolitano would make the initial statements. Later, Mr. Obama went before the news cameras in the White House Rose Garden.

"As long as I'm president," Mr. Obama vowed, "I will not give up on this issue." He called it "the right thing to do."

Title: Democrats Address "Are You Better Off?" Question at 2012 National Convention

Article:

The question of whether individuals are better off now than they were four years ago has become a central topic of debate as the Democratic Party gathers for their 2012 national convention in Charlotte, North Carolina.

Over the weekend, Democratic Governor Martin O'Malley provided an opening for the Republican party when he answered the "are you better off" question by telling CBS News' Bob Schieffer, "No, but that's not the question of this election. The question, without a doubt, we are not as well off as we were before George Bush..."

Republican vice presidential nominee Rep. Paul Ryan swiftly responded, stating, "President Obama can't tell you that you are better off. Simply put, the Jimmy Carter years look like the good old days compared to where we are right now."

Democrats offered some quick clarifications. Vice President Joe Biden, speaking in Detroit, told supporters, "You want to know whether we're better off? I got a little bumper sticker for you. Osama bin Laden is dead and General Motors is alive! Osama bin Laden is dead and General Motos is alive!"

Much more is expected to be said about this topic between now and late Thursday evening, when the president is set to accept his party's nomination. As during last week's Republican National Convention in Tampa, NPR is providing coverage and analysis through their Elections Desk and It's All Politics blog. Eyder and Liz Halloran are filing reports from Charlotte this week, and Frank James will host nightly chats on the blog during the convention proceedings. Tonight's featured speakers include first lady Michelle Obama.

Title: Attorney General Holder Recuses Himself from AP Leak Investigation, Announces New IRS Probe

Article:

Attorney General Eric Holder announced Tuesday that he has recused himself from the national security leak investigation involving the Associated Press (AP) and has initiated a new inquiry into the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) scrutiny of conservative political groups. The comments were the first from Holder or the Justice Department on the twin Obama administration scandals that have come to light in recent days.

During the press conference, Holder described the AP story that sparked the probe as "a very, very serious leak" but revealed that he had recused himself from the investigation because he had been interviewed by the FBI as part of the initial inquiry. Explaining his recusal from the leak case, Holder said he took the step "out of an abundance of caution."

"I was one of the people who had knowledge of this matter. I have frequent contact with the media," Holder said. He added, "I stepped aside to try to make sure this was independent and to avoid even the possibility of the appearance of a conflict."

The decision to subpoena AP phone records was made by Deputy Attorney General James Cole, according to a Justice Department official who asked not to be named. The leak probe was launched following an AP story last May about a counter-terrorism investigation in Yemen that involved efforts to bomb an aircraft headed for the United States.

Holder stated that the leak warranted an aggressive response from the federal government. "I have to say this is among, if not the most serious, among the top two or three most serious leaks I have ever seen. It put the American people at risk. That is not hyperbole. It put the American people at risk," he said.

Regarding the IRS investigation, Holder announced on Friday that he had launched the probe, calling the agency's actions targeting Tea Party-related groups "outrageous and unacceptable." He said the FBI was coordinating with the Justice Department to see if any laws were broken.

In a letter to the Associated Press Monday, Cole defended the decision to seek the AP's phone records. The attorney general's comments and actions come as he and the Justice Department find themselves under increasing pressure, with both Republican and Democratic senators, including Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.), being critical of the administration's actions on both fronts. Holder is set to appear before Congress on Wednesday for previously scheduled hearings that have been reoriented to address the recent inquiries.

Title: Trump's Twitter Tirade: A Shift in National Conversation to the "War on Women"

Article:

Tara Setmayer, former communications director for Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-California) and a CNN political commentator, has provided commentary on the recent shift in the national conversation from the War on Terror to the War on Women, following Donald Trump's controversial tweets about rival Ted Cruz's wife.

Last week, Trump's tweet threatening to "spill the beans" on Cruz's wife in response to an anti-Trump super PAC's use of a Melania Trump modeling photo in a political ad occurred amidst the aftermath of an ISIS terrorist attack in Brussels. The timing was particularly poor, as Belgium is a member of NATO, and its headquarters are in Brussels.

The tweet marked a significant change in the national discourse, with the conversation shifting from foreign policy to personal attacks on women. This shift came at a time when Trump was facing growing criticism for his lack of foreign policy knowledge, as demonstrated by his mediocre speech to pro-Israel group AIPAC and his refusal to rule out the use of nuclear weapons to fight ISIS during a Washington Post editorial board meeting.

Trump's actions in the Utah caucuses, where he suffered a crushing defeat with 14% of the vote compared to Cruz's 69%, may have contributed to his Twitter war with Cruz. Although Trump handily won Arizona, he has yet to secure over 50% in any state thus far. Cruz, on the other hand, has achieved this milestone in two contests and is the only candidate to beat Trump in multiple races.

The Twitter war began with Trump's direct attack on Heidi Cruz's appearance, which some argue was a defense of his wife since spouses are traditionally considered off-limits in elections. However, Trump's actions extended beyond this defense, as he later retweeted an unflattering picture of Heidi Cruz next to an appealing picture of his wife.

Critics argue that Trump's reaction to the Melania photo was more about distraction than chivalry. They claim it was a form of bullying and demeaning women, as this behavior aligns with Trump's modus operandi. An honorable man, they contend, would not need to objectify another man's wife to effectively defend his own.

Attacking Heidi Cruz's appearance was a direct assault against all women and young girls, who are often harshly and unfairly judged by their looks. The message this sends from a presidential front-runner is questionable.

Trump has a history of throwing temper tantrums and insulting women. He has made derogatory comments about women, calling them disgusting, fat pigs, and bimbos, and has made remarks about women dropping to their knees and having a nice piece of a * * on his arm.

According to the latest CNN poll, 73% of registered female voters in the United States have an unfavorable view of Trump. This result is consistent with a Reuters poll that found more than half of the women in this country hold a "very unfavorable" view of him. This presents a significant challenge for Trump in a general election if he becomes the GOP nominee against Hillary Clinton.

Political observers had suggested that Trump should pivot toward becoming more presidential and unifying the party after his big wins on March 15. However, Trump's latest antics demonstrate once again that he lacks the temperament, judgment, and common decency to be President of the United States.

Title: Hewitt Outlines Suggestions for Future Republican Elections, Debates, and Conventions

Article:

Hugh Hewitt, speaking at the annual RedState Gathering, outlined several suggestions for the future of Republican elections, debates, and conventions.

One of the proposals is to end open primaries. Hewitt argued that political parties are vehicles for change in government and should be protected. He also expressed concern about the process of deciding presidential candidates being influenced by non-party members, which could lead to chaos during primaries.

Secondly, Hewitt suggested that the Republican National Convention should be permanently located in either Cleveland or Denver, both of which are swing states. He praised the execution of the 2016 Republican Convention in Cleveland, while criticizing the Democratic convention and previous Republican conventions in other cities. He argued that planning early and getting organized is crucial for a successful convention.

Third, Hewitt emphasized the benefits of holding the Republican convention early in the election cycle, citing advantages in campaign finance and messaging for the 2020 election.

Lastly, Hewitt touched upon the media, praising CNN for its professionalism during the debates, but expressing a desire for more conservative moderators. He questioned why mainstream media figures should be the ones moderating debates, suggesting that conservative personalities such as Katie Pavlich, Ed Morrissey, or Guy Benson could moderate debates. Hewitt also questioned the necessity of the Commission on Presidental Debates, comparing it to a dinosaur in the process. He expressed an affinity for PBS's Jim Lehrer, but questioned whether he and Gwen Ifill were the only ones capable of moderating a presidential debate. He suggested that talent from Salem Media Group or other conservative personalities could moderate debates.

Hewitt described the current cycle as a transition year, stating that networks do not run the conventions or debates, and that conservatives should run the debates themselves. He also noted that the debates ratings for networks were astronomical, with only one debate (CNBC) being a complete and total disaster. He added that the media has a heavy liberal bent, and that allowing mainstream media figures to question candidates who care little about what the other side cares about is not ideal.

Title: Rep. Chris Collins Resigns Ahead of Insider Trading Hearing

Article:

Rep. Chris Collins (R-NY) has resigned ahead of a hearing related to insider trading charges. On Monday, Collins submitted a resignation letter to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, which will be effective when it is read on the House floor during a pro forma session Tuesday, according to Pelosi's office.

Collins, who had previously entered a not guilty plea in his federal criminal fraud case, has a change of plea hearing scheduled for Tuesday afternoon. The hearing was first reported by The Buffalo News. Collins faces eight counts of federal criminal charges involving conspiracy to commit securities fraud, securities fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud, wire fraud, and false statements. His trial is scheduled for Feb. 3.

Collins, along with his son, Cameron, and Stephen Zarsky, the father of Cameron's future fiancée, are alleged by federal prosecutors to have engaged in an insider trading scheme involving an Australian biotechnology company—Innate Immunotherapeutics. Collins, who was on the company's board, allegedly provided nonpublic information to his son about confidential drug test results, paving the way for Cameron Collins and others to trade on that privileged information before the public could.

Since Collins was indicted in August 2018 on fraud charges, half of his full-time staff has left the office. Seven of 14 full-time staffers are no longer working in the office, according to payroll records from May 2019, the most recent filing available at the Legislative Resource Center. Those who departed include his deputy chief of staff, Michael Kracker, communications director Sarah Minkel, and health policy adviser, Charlotte Pineda.

New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, would set the date of a special election if he were to call one before November 2020. For such an election, county party officials would select their respective party's nominees.

Collins, one of President Donald Trump's earliest backers in the House GOP conference, hails from the deep-red 27th District in Western New York. Trump won the seat by 25 points in 2016, but Collins won reelection by less than half a percentage point last fall against Democrat Nate McMurray, the supervisor of the town of Grand Island.

McMurray was already seeking a rematch against Collins, and he said in a statement Monday that "the real victims of Collins' crimes are the people of his district that he repeatedly lied to about his guilt."

Collins' exit could boost Republicans' chances of holding onto the seat, given its partisan lean. Inside Elections with Nathan L. Gonzales has changed its race rating from Leans Republican to Solid Republican.

Several GOP candidates are likely interested in running for Collins' seat, whether for a special election or for a full term in 2020. A trio of Republicans had already jumped in the race to challenge Collins, who, until Monday, had been non-committal about running for reelection.

GOP State Sen. Chris Jacobs had the most cash on hand at June 30, the end of the second fundraising quarter, with nearly $748,000. He also loaned his campaign $325,000. Collins had claimed Jacobs was a "Never Trumper" for dodging questions in 2016 about his support for the president, but Politifact found that claim was false. GOP state Sen. Rob Ortt and Beth Parlato—an Afghanistan War veteran and attorney—were also in the race.

The Republican field could grow with Collins' departure. Two sources said another potential candidate to watch is Erie County Comptroller and former local television news reporter Stefan Mychajliw, who has been making the rounds at GOP events. State Assemblyman Steve Hawley is another potential candidate.

"There are candidates who I think will be in before we get off the phone. Things are moving fast," said GOP consultant Michael Caputo, who advised Trump's 2016 presidential campaign. Caputo said Monday that he was launching an effort to draft Army veteran and local radio host David Bellavia for the seat, although Caputo would not rule out running himself if Bellavia chose not to run.

Bellavia, who was recently awarded the Medal of Honor for his service in the Iraq War, is often mentioned as a potential candidate in the district, although it is not clear if he is interested in running. He ran for the seat in 2012, losing to Collins in the GOP primary—while winning a majority of the counties in the district. Bellavia discussed the 27th District race with Trump when he was awarded the Medal of Honor in June, according to a source with knowledge of their discussion. Bellavia did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

McMurray may not be alone on the Democratic side in an open-seat race. Erie County Democratic Party Chairman Jeremy Zellner said in a phone interview that he was already hearing from Democrats who could be interested in running, but he noted that the party is "laser-focused" on next month's election for county executive.

"This district has always been a challenge for Democrats... We're looking for the strongest person who represents that community," Zellner said.

Title: Senate Minority Leader Schumer Previews Partisan Clash Over Impeachment Trial Procedures

Article:

Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic minority leader from New York, has previewed a coming partisan clash over the procedures for an impeachment trial in the Senate. Schumer has called for the Republican party to summon senior White House officials to testify as witnesses in the impeachment trial.

As of now, approximately a dozen moderate Democrats have yet to announce their voting decision for the impeachment trial, which is scheduled for Wednesday. To date, only two Democrats have indicated they will vote against impeaching President Trump, a decision that could potentially initiate a Senate trial early next year.

Representative Collin C. Peterson of Minnesota has signaled his intention to vote no. Representative Jeff Van Drew of New Jersey also plans to oppose the impeachment articles, but he intends to switch parties, either immediately before or just after the vote, leaving his re-election prospects uncertain in his swing district.

Lawmakers returned to the Capitol on Monday as Congress prepared for one of the most significant weeks in recent memory. On Tuesday, they are scheduled to vote on a $1.4 trillion spending deal to prevent a government shutdown. On Thursday, lawmakers are expected to approve a new North American trade pact to replace NAFTA.

On Wednesday, the House will formally vote on the recommendations contained in the Judiciary Committee report. This report mirrors similar documents produced during the impeachment inquiries involving Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Bill Clinton. The report does not provide new allegations or evidence, but it offers a detailed supporting argument for the two articles of impeachment the committee approved, charging that President Trump abused the power of the presidency to enlist Ukraine in tarnishing his political rivals and obstructed Congress by blocking witnesses from testifying and refusing to provide documents.

The report states, "President Trump has placed his personal, political interests above our national security, our free and fair elections, and our system of checks and balances. He has engaged in a pattern of misconduct that will continue if left unchecked. Accordingly, President Trump should be impeached and removed from office."

Title: US President Trump Accuses Democrats of Dishonesty and Treason in Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

US President Donald Trump has criticized congressional Democrats after they announced plans to summon the White House to produce documents this week in relation to the administration's dealings with Ukraine, which is at the center of an impeachment inquiry. Committees are demanding documents concerning the administration's interactions with Ukraine, and the president has accused Democratic leaders of dishonesty and even treason.

During a joint news conference with Finnish President Sauli Niinistö, Mr. Trump called former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter, "stone-cold corrupt." He directed much of his anger towards House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, labeling him "shifty Schiff," a "lowlife," and stating he "should resign from office in disgrace." He added, "Frankly, they should look at him for treason."

Mr. Trump also stated that he believed Mr. Schiff had "helped write" a complaint about the call filed by a whistleblower, without offering evidence. The US president told reporters that only "legitimate" whistleblowers should be protected. "This country has to find out who this person was, because that person's a spy, in my opinion," Mr. Trump said.

The impeachment inquiry, which may seek to remove Mr. Trump from office, stems from a whistleblower's complaint about his July 25 phone conversation with President Volodymyr Zelensky. In the call, Mr. Trump pressed for an investigation of his Democratic political rival Joe Biden and his son, who worked for a Ukrainian gas firm that faced allegations of corruption.

As vice-president and the Obama administration's point man on Ukraine, Mr. Biden threatened to withhold US loan guarantees to the country unless it fired its top prosecutor, at a time when Hunter Biden's employer had been under official scrutiny. European countries and international bodies had also wanted Viktor Shokin fired, accusing him of failing to clamp down on corruption.

The Ukrainian prosecutor general who took over from Mr. Shokin has told the BBC there was no evidence of wrongdoing by Joe or Hunter Biden. However, questions were raised at the time about a potential conflict of interest for the US vice-president.

Democrats have pointed out that Mr. Trump's call with the newly elected Mr. Zelensky took place at the same time as the US president decided to withhold military aid from Ukraine. From what has been shared of the call so far, Mr. Trump did not directly reference withholding aid, but a full verbatim transcript has not been made available.

Mr. Trump's opponents say he was pressuring a vulnerable American ally to interfere in the 2020 US election for the US president's personal benefit. Democrats have accused the White House of blocking congressional inquiries and refusing to respond to record requests, which has prompted the subpoena threat this week.

House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings said in a memo, "I do not take this step lightly. Over the past several weeks, the committees tried several times to obtain voluntary compliance with our requests for documents, but the White House has refused to engage with - or even respond to - the committees." The subpoena will request documents on Mr. Trump's call with Ukraine and any related items from acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney.

Mrs. Pelosi and Mr. Schiff held a joint news conference on Wednesday, defending the impeachment proceedings. "We're not fooling around here," Mr. Schiff said, adding that Democrats did not want the inquiry to "drag on." He also criticized the president's comments against the whistleblower as "a blatant effort to intimidate witnesses" and "an incitement of violence."

Mr. Schiff has also issued a statement saying his committee never reviewed or received the whistleblower's complaint in advance, as Mr. Trump claimed. Impeachment is the first part - the charges - of a two-stage political process by which Congress can remove a president from office. If the House of Representatives votes to pass articles of impeachment, the Senate is forced to hold a trial. A Senate vote requires a two-thirds majority to convict, which is unlikely in this case, given that Mr. Trump's party controls the chamber. Only two US presidents in history - Bill Clinton and Andrew Johnson - have been impeached, but neither was convicted and removed.

Title: Trump Announces Creation of Space Force as Sixth Military Branch, Faces Criticism

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump announced on Monday the creation of a sixth branch of the military focused on space, a move that has faced criticism from some, including senior military officials. The proposed Space Force would operate alongside the existing Air Force, with the aim of achieving "American dominance in space."

Trump made the announcement during a meeting of his National Space Council, stating, "It is not enough to merely have an American presence in space. We must have American dominance in space." The president later added, "We are going to have the Air Force and we're going to have the 'Space Force.' Separate but equal. It is going to be something."

The United States is a signatory to the 1967 Outer Space Treaty, which prohibits the stationing of weapons of mass destruction in space and restricts the use of celestial bodies for military purposes to peaceful purposes only. The idea of a Space Force has been proposed in the past, with proponents arguing that it would streamline the Pentagon's operations.

However, the proposal has faced criticism from military officials, including Air Force Chief of Staff General David Goldfein, who stated in a 2017 congressional hearing that creating a new space branch would "move us in the wrong direction." The Air Force currently oversees most of the country's space-related military activity.

The move requires the budgetary approval of the U.S. Congress, which has been divided on the idea. U.S. Senator Bill Nelson, a Democrat, tweeted, "Thankfully, the president can't do it without Congress because now is NOT the time to rip the Air Force apart. Too many missions at stake."

Pentagon spokeswoman Dana White stated that the department's policy board would prepare to implement Trump's order. "Working with Congress, this will be a deliberate process with a great deal of input from multiple stakeholders," White said in a statement.

In December, the president signed a directive aimed at enabling astronauts to return to the moon and eventually lead a mission to Mars. The U.S. first landed on the moon in 1969, achieving a goal set by former President John F. Kennedy in 1961 and marking the end of a decade-long space race between Washington and Moscow.

Since then, U.S. efforts to explore beyond the Earth's orbit have primarily focused on remote spacecraft without human crew members, though American presidents have periodically raised the idea of sending humans back to the moon or further.

Title: President Obama Announces Executive Actions to Tighten Firearms Laws, Draws Criticism from NRA

Article:

President Barack Obama has announced his intention to meet with Attorney General Loretta Lynch on Monday to discuss measures aimed at curbing gun violence. This follows his order to his White House team several months ago to identify "new actions" he can take, as Congress has failed to act on gun control legislation.

The president is expected to use executive orders to tighten federal firearms laws, with a focus on small-scale firearms sellers and background checks for gun buyers, according to Politico. The anticipated changes would require small-scale gun sellers to submit background checks for potential buyers, but they are not expected to completely close the so-called "gun show loophole."

Obama's new plan follows the third anniversary of the 2012 mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, where a deranged gunman killed 20 children and six adults. However, the Obama-driven effort to tighten gun laws in the aftermath of the massacre failed to gain enough support for passage from Senate Democrats and Republicans.

In response to the president's renewed effort, Jennifer Baker, spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association (NRA), stated, "President Obama failed to pass his anti-gun agenda through Congress because the majority of Americans oppose more gun-control. Now he is doing what he always does when he doesn't get his way, which is defy the will of the people and issue an executive order."

The president's course of action is expected to follow recommendations from Everytown, the gun-control nonprofit led by billionaire and former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg. This action will likely result in a rematch with the NRA, the group that led the successful attempt to defeat Obama's post-Sandy Hook efforts.

In 2014, the ATF proposed that federal officials be notified about lost firearms, but the gun industry successfully argued that voluntary reporting was sufficient. Existing law states that those who sell guns with the "principal objective of livelihood and profit" have to get a dealer's license through the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. This means they also have to conduct a background check on buyers no matter where they sell, including online or at a gun show.

Title: Voting Rights Under Threat: A Look at the Controversies and Challenges in U.S. Elections

Article:

The right to vote is a fundamental aspect of any democratic system. However, in several states across the United States, particularly in the past five years following the Supreme Court's decision to weaken the Voting Rights Act, the exercise of this right has become a contentious issue.

Republican-led states, predominantly representing older, white voter demographics, have implemented a series of measures aimed at making it more difficult for minority groups, such as African Americans, Hispanics, and the young, to vote or for their votes to count. These measures, backed by right-wing think tanks, are increasingly challenged in courts and met with protests on the streets.

In Alabama, a state with a significant African American population, the state has had all-white appellate court justices for a quarter-century. This is due to the practice of statewide at-large elections for both appellate and Supreme Court judges, rather than district elections, where African American candidates would have a better chance of being elected in some areas. This practice, also followed in Texas against Hispanic voters, is currently being challenged in a lawsuit filed by the Alabama State Conference of the NAACP.

Alabama has employed various tactics to suppress the vote, including requiring a photo ID to vote, closing driver's license offices disproportionately in black areas, imposing a "proof of citizenship" mandate for voter registration, and closing polling stations disproportionately in areas with large African American populations. Get-out-the-vote efforts have been made more difficult with the passage of a ban on financial transfers from one Political Action Committee (PAC) to another, an act aimed at leading organizations working on African American turnout. Alabama has also begun the process of purging the voting rolls, and when the state legislature passed a measure giving felons who had served their sentences the right to vote, the state government refused to inform people that their rights had been restored.

Across the country, instead of making voter registration automatic and adopting same-day registration, Republican-led states are making registration more difficult. Instead of expanding voting days, they are limiting them. Instead of encouraging voter registration drives, they are adopting various measures to criminalize the activities of voter registration groups. Partisan gerrymandering continues to evolve, and hackable voting machines pose a potential threat to an honest count. Closing polling stations forces some, disproportionately those from minority or poor districts, to travel longer and wait in long lines to vote.

The only way to counter these measures is through massive citizen mobilization and electing leaders who prioritize the right to vote. In 2018, efforts to restrict the right to vote outpaced a voter turnout that was the highest since 1914. In 2020, with the fundamental direction of the country at stake, another record turnout is crucial. Upon gaining the majority in the House of Representatives in 2018, Democrats immediately passed HR 1, the most extensive election and democracy reform bill since the Voting Rights Act. The bill, which includes same-day voter registration, limits the role of big money in elections, curbs political gerrymanders, and much more, currently sits on the desk of Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who has refused to allow it to come to a vote.

If voters manage to overcome the obstacles designed to make voting difficult and vote in large numbers in 2020, fundamental democratic reform could be on the horizon.

Title: Senate Immigration Hearing Marked by Partisan Tensions Over Boston Bombings

Article:

A partisan divide emerged during a Senate immigration hearing on Monday, as top Democrats accused opponents of comprehensive immigration reform of exploiting the Boston Marathon bombings to slow or derail the bill.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vermont) stated, "Last week, opponents of comprehensive immigration reform began to exploit the Boston marathon bombing." He urged restraint and added, "Let no one be so cruel as to try to use the heinous attacks of these two young men last week to derail the dreams and futures of millions of hard-working people."

Leahy emphasized that the bill, crafted by the bipartisan "Gang of Eight," would strengthen national security by allowing the focus of border security and enforcement efforts against those who would do harm. He also stated, "We are capable of vigilance in our pursuit of these values, and we have seen the tremendous work that the local law enforcement as well as the federal law enforcement have done in the Boston area."

Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), the panel's top Republican, responded sharply to Leahy's statement. He stated, "I want you to take note of the fact that when you proposed gun legislation, I did not accuse you of using the (Newtown, Connecticut) killings as an excuse." Grassley also mentioned the 14 people killed in West, Texas, and some political activists who took advantage of that tragedy to warn about more government action to ensure that fertilizer factories are safe.

The hearing became more heated when Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-New York) said, "Those who are pointing to what happened—the terrible tragedy in Boston—(are looking for an) excuse for not doing a bill or delaying it many months or a year." Sen. Grassley responded, "I never said that!" and interrupted Schumer. Schumer replied, "I didn't say you did, sir."

Alabama GOP Sen. Jeff Sessions accused Schumer of "demeaning" anti-reform witnesses, partly by characterizing them as representatives of narrow interests. Schumer, in turn, insisted that "what I am saying is, if there are things that come up as a result of what happened in Boston that need improving, that require improvement, let's add them to the bill because certainly our bill tightens up things in a way that would make a Boston less likely."

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Kentucky) sent a letter Monday to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nevada), urging a delay of any immigration legislation until more is learned about the alleged Boston bombers. Sen. Paul wrote, "We should not proceed until we understand the specific failures of our immigration system."

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney dismissed Paul's concern, arguing that "comprehensive immigration reform, as anyone who has looked into it can attest, would enhance our security." The bill now under consideration would prevent undocumented residents from gaining legal status if they have been found guilty of felonies or more than two misdemeanors.

Monday's hearing was the second by the Judiciary Committee on the nearly 900-page proposal put together by the eight senators. Over twenty witnesses were slated to testify, a schedule characterized by Sen. Sessions as part of a plan "to rush through this massive legislation before the American people know what's in it." The first hearing, held last Friday, was also marked by several references to security fears raised by the recent bombings. Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano is scheduled to testify before the panel Tuesday.

Assuming the immigration bill clears Leahy's committee, full Senate consideration of the legislation will probably occur in June, according to multiple sources. A bipartisan group of legislators in the House of Representatives is crafting its own immigration reform proposal.

Title: Obama's Executive Actions on Immigration Moving Forward Despite Court Halt on Deportation Amnesty

Article:

President Obama's marquee deportation amnesty, known as Deferred Action for Parental Accountability (DAPA), has been stalled by the courts, but the rest of his executive actions on immigration, announced a year ago, are progressing. The DAPA, intended to grant temporary legal status and work permits, Social Security numbers, and driver's licenses to over 4 million illegal immigrants, has been halted by a federal appeals court, with its fate soon to be decided by the Supreme Court.

However, the remaining actions announced on Nov. 20, 2014, are advancing. These actions, often mislabeled by the press as executive orders, include a wide-ranging set of priorities that effectively instructs agents not to pursue the deportation of nearly all illegal immigrants.

Rep. Luis V. Gutierrez, an Illinois Democrat, who was among the chief advocates for the unilateral steps, stated, "There are 7 or 8 or 9 million people who are now safe under the current policy. That is a victory to celebrate while we wait for the Supreme Court."

The actions also encompass changes to the legal immigration system, such as making it easier for spouses of guest workers to find employment, allowing foreigners who study science and technology at U.S. universities to remain and work in the country longer, encouraging legal immigrants to apply for citizenship, and waiving the penalty on illegal immigrant spouses or children of legal permanent residents, so they no longer have to leave their families to await legal status.

On enforcement, Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson announced changes that would let most rank-and-file illegal immigrants off the hook and instead focus deportation efforts on serious criminals, gang members, and other security threats, as well as the most recent of illegal border crossers.

Deportations, which peaked at nearly 410,000 in fiscal year 2012, dropped to about 230,000 in fiscal year 2015, which ended on Sept. 30. However, Mr. Johnson stated that more of those being deported are the serious criminals and security threats he wants his agents to focus on.

According to an estimate this year by the Migration Policy Institute, if agents adhere strictly to the enforcement priorities, some 9.6 million of the estimated 11.5 million illegal immigrants in the country have no real danger of being deported.

Marc Rosenblum, deputy director of the institute's U.S. immigration policy program, stated, "The enforcement priorities announced last year, if strictly enforced, do protect the vast majority of unauthorized immigrants from being deported, because most immigrants have been here a long time and haven't committed a serious crime."

Immigrant rights activists are still waiting for the special circumstances to be applied more broadly. Mr. Johnson has also been pushing, with some success, to get sanctuary cities to cooperate with his deportation agents. He scrapped the Secure Communities program and replaced it with the Priorities Enforcement Program, which targets only serious criminals.

Jessica Vaughan, policy studies director at the Center for Immigration Studies, which advocates for stricter immigration controls, stated, "It is tremendously harder now to deport even criminals, much less garden-variety illegal aliens. They have truly dismembered the immigration enforcement system, from the Border Patrol to the immigration courts."

The jewel of the executive actions was the deportation amnesty, which was delayed first by a federal district court in Texas and last week by an appeals court. All sides in the debate agree that this was a significant setback for Mr. Obama.

Ms. Vaughan stated, "Without being able to give away a benefit, like a work permit, these changes are less permanent, and easier to undo in some ways, than would have been the case had the president been able to implement DAPA."

Mr. Obama stated he took the series of steps in response to inaction from Congress, where his push for a broad bill granting illegal immigrants a path to citizenship stalled in 2013. Frustrated by Republicans, Mr. Obama waited until after the 2014 elections, then announced his go-it-alone approach.

Homeland Security has issued proposals to carry out the leniency program for illegal immigrant spouses and children of green-card holders and to allow foreign students in science and technology to stay longer. Both of these still need to be finalized, as does a proposal expanding hardship waivers. Other moves were easier to accomplish: Homeland Security now accepts credit card payments for citizenship fees.

Title: White House Launches Campaign to Refocus on Affordable Care Act Benefits

Article:

President Barack Obama will initiate a three-week campaign on Tuesday, led by the White House, congressional Democrats, and their allies, to emphasize the benefits of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The renewed push aims to rebuild public confidence in the law and refocus attention on its advantages, following two months of intense media coverage of the HealthCare.gov website's rollout issues.

The White House will highlight a different benefit each day until the Dec. 23 enrollment deadline for Jan. 1 coverage. This message will be amplified through press events and social media by Democratic members of Congress, the Democratic National Committee, congressional campaign committees, and advocacy organizations.

The renewed focus on the ACA is a response to the faulty website that forced the administration into damage control mode. The White House believes that with the website now functioning more effectively, they can return to promoting the law.

"Healthcare.gov met our self-imposed November 30th deadline and even as we continue to make improvements to the website, we’ll also remind the public about how the Affordable Care Act is already making a positive difference in the lives of millions of Americans today," said Josh Earnest, a White House spokesman.

President Obama will not declare the website fixed during Tuesday's event. White House officials acknowledge that HealthCare.gov is not working as smoothly as it should, and the renewed messaging push will run alongside efforts to make further repairs to the insurance marketplace and to target key populations for enrollment.

Republicans are not expected to abandon their efforts to weaken the ACA, and officials have prepared for the Democratic offensive. "Democrats will spend the next year promising to 'fix' ObamaCare, but they’ve already lost all credibility with voters," said Brad Dayspring, spokesman for the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

The focus on ACA benefits is a political necessity for congressional Democrats, who will face voters in less than a year. Democrats wrote and passed the law in the face of unified Republican opposition, and if voters are not aware of the law's upside or can't remember it amid all the problems with the rollout, Democrats will be holding onto an anchor rather than a buoy.

Democratic leaders are welcoming the renewed White House push. "The consequences of Republican repeal are exactly the case that we need to be making—because Republican repeal would take us backward to a broken system that hurts too many Americans—like forcing millions of seniors to pay $1,200 more for their prescription drugs," said Rep. Steve Israel (D-N.Y.), chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. "Every poll tells us that when we make that case, voters choose Democrats."

The White House and Democratic allies will focus on different aspects of the ACA's benefits each day, starting with less expensive preventative care on Wednesday, coverage for people with preexisting conditions on Thursday, and slowing growth in healthcare costs on Friday.

"We are able to hit reset on the conversation," said Lori Lodes, senior vice president of the liberal Center for American Progress Action Fund. "We have to make sure people understand how the law will benefit them."

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell Files Cloture on Police Reform Legislation, Setting Vote Date

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) filed cloture on the Republican police reform legislation on Monday, setting an official date for the vote. The Senate will vote on the GOP's police reform bill, which requires 60 votes to pass. To advance, Republicans would need seven or more Democrats to vote with them.

Senate Republicans released their police reform legislation on Wednesday in response to the killing of George Floyd and the ongoing protests. In a press conference, Republican South Carolina Sen. Tim Scott and McConnell introduced the legislation.

Sen. Scott stated that the legislation will include a "notification act" to provide more information about the over 30,000 no-knock warrants that occur nationwide. The legislation is also expected to include anti-lynching legislation that was stalled by Republican Sen. Rand Paul (R-KY) in the Senate. Additionally, the legislation calls for more funding for body cameras.

Sen. McConnell appointed Sen. Scott (R-SC) to lead the party's effort in passing a police overhaul bill before July 4. Sen. Scott has ruled out including a revision to qualified immunity, a key measure supported by Democrats and others.

The group of Republican senators who worked on the bill includes Sens. Lindsey Graham (R-SC), Ben Sasse (R-NE), James Lankford (R-OK), John Cornyn (R-TX), and Shelley Moore Capito (R-WV). (RELATED: Sen. Tim Scott Lays Out What He Expects In GOP Police Reform Legislation, Sen. Tim Scott Fires Back At Those Calling Him A'Token'For Drafting GOP Police Reform Legislation)

Title: TSA Fails 95% of Airport Security Tests, Raising Questions About Effectiveness and Budget

Article:

A recent report has revealed that the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) missed 95% of guns and bombs in airport security tests, raising concerns about the effectiveness of the agency and the $7 billion annual budget it receives.

The high failure rate in the tests, which were conducted at multiple airports and used realistic simulations of terrorist behavior, has led some to argue that the current level of airport security is not necessary. They contend that the TSA's primary role should be to deter potential terrorists rather than achieve a perfect security record.

The argument is that a moderate chance of being caught is enough to deter a sane terrorist, and a 95% failure rate is too high, but a 20% one is acceptable. The TSA's previous excuses, such as the results being isolated to a single airport or not representative of realistic terrorist behavior, are no longer valid, given the widespread nature of the latest tests.

The high failure rate is consistent with anecdotal evidence, with many individuals reporting having inadvertently carried knives through airport security and some having mistakenly carried guns on airplanes. The TSA's own statistics show that it detected 2,212 guns last year, but this does not necessarily mean that it missed 44,000 guns.

The reasons for the high failure rate are not clear, and the report does not provide an explanation. It is speculated that the cause may be a combination of factors, including the boredom of security screening jobs, the high number of false alarms, and technological limitations in detecting certain types of weapons or explosives.

Despite the numerous failures, there have been no successful terrorist attacks against airplanes since 9/11. If there were numerous terrorists waiting for an opportunity to attack American planes, we would have seen attempts or successful attacks in the years since the implementation of airport security measures.

The article concludes that while the TSA needs to improve its performance, the actual risk of terrorism does not justify its $7 billion budget. The author suggests that the money could be better spent on intelligence and investigation, which would provide security that does not require guessing the next terrorist tactic and target. The author also emphasizes the importance of vigilant passengers and good intelligence and investigation in dealing with potential terrorists.

The article also raises concerns about the effectiveness of security measures that require guessing the terrorists' tactics and targets, as the terrorists may simply adapt their methods to evade detection. The author argues that a more proactive approach, focusing on intelligence and investigation, would be more effective in preventing terrorist attacks.

Title: Labor Secretary Scalia: U.S. Economy Well-Positioned to Rebound Post-COVID-19 Shutdown

Article:

Labor Secretary Eugene Scalia stated on Wednesday that the American economy is "well-positioned" to rebound following the coronavirus-related economic shutdowns across the country. During an interview on "America's Newsroom," Scalia compared the current situation to a war, stating, "As the president said, we are in a war, a war that has drawn on Americans across the country in a way I don't think we've seen since World War II."

Scalia attributed the United States' "incredible productive capacity" to its success in winning two world wars. He highlighted the efforts of both the front lines and the home front, including the iconic Rosie the Riveter, as examples of the ingenuity, creativity, and energy in the private sector that are helping the country turn the corner in slowing the spread of coronavirus.

Meanwhile, private employers slashed 20.2 million jobs in April, according to the ADP National Employment Report released Wednesday morning. This represents the largest decline on record since the survey began in 2002, surpassing the previous record of 834,665 job losses in February 2009 during the Great Recession.

Ahu Yildirmaz, co-head of the ADP Research Institute, stated, "Job losses of this scale are unprecedented." Yildirmaz added, "The total number of job losses for the month of April alone was more than double the total jobs lost during the Great Recession."

The report may understate the actual damage inflicted by the stay-at-home measures, as the ADP study is only based on data collected through April 12. Since the virus outbreak gained a foothold in the U.S. about two months ago, forcing a majority of states to shutter nonessential businesses and direct residents to stay at home, 30 million Americans have filed for first-time jobless benefits.

Job losses were concentrated heavily in the leisure and hospitality industry, with 8.6 million job losses in total, despite businesses trying to compensate with delivery and takeout options.

Scalia said that "somewhere near 90 percent of people who have gone on unemployment said that they expect to return to their jobs." He expressed optimism that the country can quickly return to the strong economy it had under the president's policies just weeks ago.

Title: Romney Criticizes Obama's Economic Policies in Response to Job Growth Report

Article:

In an exclusive interview with ███ Channel, Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney criticized the latest Labor Department report showing a decline in job growth in America. The report, released a day after President Obama's speech at the Democratic National Convention, showed only 96,000 new jobs created in August, with hundreds of thousands of Americans leaving the workforce.

Romney stated, "It's another disappointing monthly figure." He further explained that the continued pattern of job creation over the last several years indicates that the U.S. is not creating the jobs needed to put Americans back to work. For every net new job created, about four people have dropped out of the workforce, according to Romney.

The former Massachusetts governor also criticized the Federal Reserve, stating that their actions will not have an immediate impact on the economy. He added that business-friendly policies from the White House are the best hope for turning around the moribund economy.

Romney also expressed his dissatisfaction with President Obama's speech, stating that it lacked confidence in the President's ability to handle jobs and the economy. He claimed that there was nothing in the speech that gave confidence that the President knows what he is doing when it comes to jobs and the economy.

The unemployment rate did inch downward in August, but economists attribute this to the fact that so many out-of-work Americans have become so discouraged that they have taken themselves out of the workforce. The proportion of the adult population that is either working or looking for work fell to 63.5 percent, the lowest level in 31 years for the so-called labor force participation rate.

Romney believes his private sector experience gives him an edge over Obama in the issue Americans care most about—the economy. He stated that Obama's speech was a reminder of the promises he made in 2008 that have not come to fruition.

Romney also addressed claims by Democrats that his own speech in Tampa was short on specifics, noting he laid out five steps he said will lead to increases in jobs and income for Americans. He also rejected former President Clinton's claim in Charlotte that "no president" could have turned around the economic mess Obama inherited in 2009, stating he "could have done a heck of a lot better job."

Romney also addressed claims that he wanted American automakers to go bankrupt, stating that the structured bankruptcy he proposed for General Motors would have allowed the company to survive without costing American taxpayers billions in bailout money. He also rejected claims that by not mentioning U.S. troops in his acceptance speech in Tampa he showed a disregard for service members.

With just 60 days to go, Romney stated that the choice will be clear for voters. He said, "I think people will make up their mind. I can't tell you when everyone will settle down—the day before or day of the election. It's a horse race [between] two candidates who would take the country in different directions."

Later Friday, at a campaign rally in Orange City, Iowa, Romney laid out a five-point plan to create 12 million new jobs if elected, including taking "full advantage" of the nation's energy resources to become independent by 2020 and not catering to small businesses. He also stated that massive federal spending will end if he assumes the White House.

Title: Obama to Campaign for Clinton, Emphasizing Unity and Strong Leadership

Article:

In an effort to generate excitement and support for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, President Barack Obama is preparing to campaign for her, emphasizing his personal journey from being a critic to a supporter. This strategy is aimed at ensuring Clinton has a strong mandate to govern and gain public and Congressional support for her agenda.

David Plouffe, Obama's 2008 campaign manager and an outside political adviser to both the president and the Clinton campaign, stated, "You want people to feel as passionate about Hillary Clinton being president as they do about stopping Donald Trump. If this isn't a close race, it's still going to matter a great deal for her presidency."

President Obama's message will be a key focus when he joins Clinton for a rescheduled joint rally in Charlotte, North Carolina, on July 5. Jen Psaki, White House communications director, said, "He can make the case as the highest profile convert to be her supporter."

Obama's campaigning will not only involve supporting Clinton but also continuing to criticize and mock Republican nominee Donald Trump. Jen Psaki noted, "The way the president sees it is: there will be a lot of people out there talking about Donald Trump—there's more than enough material."

The conversations around Obama's message are being led out of the West Wing, while logistics and scheduling discussions are being handled by the Clinton campaign in Brooklyn. The White House and the campaign maintain a few points of contact to minimize leaks and potential legal issues.

Obama and his aides believe he can appeal to skeptical sections of the Democratic base, particularly young, progressive, and anti-establishment voters who supported Bernie Sanders this year. The White House is also working on finalizing the convention speech that will be Obama's last big speech with the full political spotlight on him.

Planning the fall campaign calendar is still in progress, with the needs of the Clinton campaign and Senate candidates yet to be determined. Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney noted, "Don't discount Bill [Clinton] either." Bill Clinton, Hillary's husband, is expected to play a significant role in the campaign as well.

David Plouffe stated, "When he [Obama] speaks about her [Hillary Clinton]... I think that will obviously have more authenticity than any other messenger." The White House is weeks away from finalizing the convention speech that aides know will be Obama's last big speech with the full political spotlight on him.

Title: Florida and Ohio Primary Polls Show Trump, Cruz, Kasich Leading; Rubio Trailing in Home State

Article:

New polls indicate that Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump is leading in his home state of Florida, with Sen. Marco Rubio trailing behind him significantly. According to the latest Marist/NBC/Wall Street Journal poll, Trump has a double-digit lead over Rubio, with 43% to Rubio's 22%. The same poll shows Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Rubio essentially tied, with Cruz at 21% and Rubio at 21%. A separate CBS News 2016 Battleground Tracker poll shows Rubio slipping behind Cruz.

In Ohio, a Marist survey shows Gov. John Kasich holding a slight edge over Trump, with 39% to Trump's 33%. The latest Quinnipiac poll shows Trump and Kasich tied, with 38% each. The primaries in Ohio and Florida, among five Tuesday, are considered a must-win for both Kasich and Rubio, respectively, as both significantly trail front-runner Trump and Cruz in the delegate count.

Rubio's drop in the polls appears to be another indication that his campaign might soon come to an end. On Sunday, he continued to criticize the violence at Trump rallies, saying the candidate and protesters share the blame. Rubio's poll numbers have also fallen in the CBS News 2016 Battleground Tracker poll, with Trump maintaining his lead in the state's winner-take-all primary, in which 99 delegates are at stake. Trump has 44% of the vote among registered voters in the state, compared with Cruz at 24% and Rubio at 21%.

At a rally Sunday in Ohio, Trump hit Kasich for voting in favor of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) as a congressman, a move that critics say has taken away millions of manufacturing jobs, especially in Rust Belt states such as Michigan, Illinois, and Ohio. Kasich faces a similar situation as Rubio, needing to win in his home state to keep his campaign headed toward the GOP convention in July.

Trump leads the delegate count with 460, followed by Cruz with 370, Rubio with 163, and Kasich, who has yet to win a primary or caucus, with 63. The three other states on Tuesday also holding primaries are North Carolina (72 delegates), Missouri (52 delegates), and Illinois (69 delegates). Trump also leads in Illinois, with 38%, followed by Cruz at 34%, Kasich at 16%, and Rubio at 11%.

On the Democratic side, frontrunner Hillary Clinton has a big lead in Florida over rival Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, 62-to-34%, according to the CBS poll. However, she leads Sanders by single-digits in Ohio, 52-to-43%, and Sanders has a narrow 48-46% lead in Illinois. Early voting in Florida's primary comes to an end Sunday, with more than 1.9 million voters having already made their presidential choice. Republican voters far outnumber Democratic ones, according to the latest figures released Sunday by the state Division of Elections. Republican voters account for more than 1.1 million early voters, while about 819,000 Democrats have cast ballots. Early voters are projected to account for at least half the total number expected to vote in Tuesday's primary. Florida's closed primary is open only to those registered to one of the major parties.

Title: State Department Faces Criticism for Lack of Security Risk Management at Foreign Missions

Article:

A year after the Benghazi terrorist attacks, the State Department is still struggling to manage security risks at foreign diplomatic missions, according to a report released by the department's internal auditor on Wednesday. The report, a "special review" conducted by the State Department's Office of Inspector General, criticizes the department for lacking a systematic approach to enhancing security personnel beyond the assistance provided by host nations at 27 high-risk posts. The report also highlights gaps in the department's ability to balance security needs with the necessity of being involved in volatile regions worldwide.

The OIG report concludes that the State Department "neither has a conceptual framework nor a process for risk management." The report states that there is no single person or office responsible for overseeing the assessment of risk in critical, high-threat locations.

However, the OIG report refutes claims made by prominent Republicans over the past year who argued that the Obama administration-appointed panel that investigated the September 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, was politically biased and failed to hold anyone accountable for security failures surrounding the incident. Four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, were killed when armed Islamist terrorists attacked a shoddily protected diplomatic outpost in Benghazi.
