Rep. Darrell E. Issa, a California Republican and chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, has been one of the loudest critics. He has claimed that last year's Accountability Review Board (ARB) investigation, a process mandated by federal law whenever an attack occurs on a U.S. diplomatic post overseas, fell short of uncovering the truth behind the security failures in Benghazi.

The OIG findings contradict these assertions, concluding instead that the "Accountability Review Board process operates as intended—independently and without bias—to identify vulnerabilities in the Department of State's security programs."

The State Department welcomed the findings. "This independent report underscores that the partisan and political assault on the ARB must end," department spokesman Alec Gerlach said in an email to The ███. "The IG looked at all 12 ARBs conducted between 1998 and 2012 and determined that the ARB process occurs 'independently and without bias.'"

The report also gave the ARB process a positive evaluation, stating that it operates free of bias and political pressure. However, it found mixed results regarding the State Department's implementation of the recommendations made by the ARB. For instance, one of the ARB's key findings had called for boosting U.S. assets at high-risk posts where the host countries are incapable or unwilling to protect U.S. missions. The department's actions to date do not comply with this recommendation, according to Wednesday's OIG report.

The report, however, did credit former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton for taking a direct role in ensuring the Benghazi ARB recommendations were implemented, and stated that current Secretary of State John F. Kerry is following through. "The Benghazi ARB recommendations, when implemented, should significantly improve the department's ability to provide better security for U.S. diplomatic missions and employees," the report said.

Title: Jeb Bush and Clint Bolick Propose Overhaul of U.S. Immigration Laws, Offering Legal Residence but Not Citizenship to Undocumented Immigrants

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, son and brother of U.S. presidents, has co-authored a new book titled "Immigration Wars" with Clint Bolick. In the book, they propose overhauling U.S. immigration laws to make it easier for illegal immigrants to gain legal residence, not citizenship.

Bush, in an interview with NPR's Steve Inskeep, explains that their plan involves legalizing undocumented immigrants after they pay a fine or perform community service and have no serious criminal records. He states, "Over a period of time, they can have a legalized status that allows them to live a life of dignity, but not necessarily a path to citizenship."

The authors propose that those who wish to become citizens could return to their country of origin and apply. Bush notes, "Right now, in effect, we tell people to get in the back of the line, but the line is either so long or it doesn't exist—I mean, we do not really have that option. Our proposal...would allow for that option to exist."

Clint Bolick, a lawyer and director of the Goldwater Institute's Scharf-Norton Center for Constitutional Litigation in Phoenix, explains that their proposal aims to increase the number of people who can immigrate to the United States for work. Bolick states, "We think we ought to dramatically increase the number of people who can come for low-skilled jobs, for high-skilled jobs, for education or just because they want to become American citizens."

Jeb Bush, often mentioned as a potential presidential candidate, has not yet announced his intentions for the 2024 election. When asked about the need for Republicans to support an immigration overhaul, Bush responds, "Being against other people's policies eventually puts you in a downward spiral. It's fine to be principled and oppose views that you don't agree with, but you also have to have an alternative."

Bush further discusses the need for spending restraint and reform of the entitlement system, emphasizing the importance of presidential leadership in driving change. He states, "My brother did it, Bill Clinton did it, my dad did it, Ronald Reagan did it, Lyndon Johnson did it. Why is it such a hard thing for us now to expect presidents to lead?"

When asked about the timing of his potential presidential run, Bush responds, "We just had an election, and a lot will happen between now and the time that I would even begin to consider something like that. So, time would be the leading indicator."

Title: Putin Endorses Trump as "Absolute Leader" of U.S. Presidential Race

Article:

Christian Whiton, a former deputy special envoy for human rights in North Korea for the George W. Bush administration, is the president of the Hamilton Foundation, a principal with DC Advisory, and the author of "Smart Power: Between Diplomacy and War." In a recent CNN report, Vladimir Putin, the President of Russia, has expressed support for Donald Trump, the U.S. presidential candidate, calling him the "absolute leader" of the race.

Putin, who has been running Russia since 2000, has a history of interest in American politics. The endorsement comes as Putin identifies similarities between himself and Trump, particularly their shared love for spectacle and appreciation of the impact of such spectacle on low-information voters.

Putin's endorsement may be rooted in his understanding of politics as a form of showbiz, as depicted in Mel Brooks' darkly comical musical "The Producers." The line "Everything is showbiz" from the musical could be seen as the leitmotif of Trump's campaign.

Trump's approach to politics and his self-referential style are reminiscent of Putin, who has been known to exploit character flaws in political figures to further his own interests. Putin's past manipulation of American presidents, such as George W. Bush and Barack Obama, has been well-documented.

Trump's statements regarding U.S. policy toward Russia have also caught Putin's attention. In September, Trump praised Putin's leadership and expressed support for Russia's actions in Syria, stating that Putin is "getting an 'A'... He's going into Syria, and he frankly wants to fight ISIS, and I think that's a wonderful thing."

However, Putin's praise of Trump's personal flaws and policy positions may be a strategic move to exploit Trump's naivety and self-delusion about Russia's intentions. Putin's actions in Syria, primarily to support the dictator Bashar al-Assad and fight Assad's non-ISIS opponents, contradict the positive image Trump has portrayed.

Putin's endorsement of Trump and his stated desire for closer relations with the U.S. has raised concerns about the potential for Russia to expand its sphere of influence, particularly in light of Putin's history of aggression and suppression of domestic dissent. The endorsement serves as a reminder of the need for careful consideration and scrutiny of foreign leaders' intentions and actions.

Title: Early Voting Surges in the U.S. Ahead of Election Day

Article:

Every Election Day for as long as he can remember, Angel Del Carpio would head to the polls and cast his vote. He did it when he lived in California and New York. Now a resident of Nevada – a closely watched swing state – Mr. Del Carpio decided to make an early appearance this year. The Wednesday before the election, the retired hairdresser drove to The Boulevard Mall, about three miles east of The Strip, to vote at a polling station set up inside.

"I did my part," says Del Carpio, holding up his "I voted" sticker. "It's very important because our vote is what's going to save this country."

Del Carpio's ballot is one of more than 34 million already cast ahead of the election this year via in-person, mail-in, or absentee ballots. The figure is on its way to topping 50 million and setting a record for votes cast before Election Day, according to the Pew Research Center.

Early voter turnout remains a questionable indicator of victory. But the surge in early voting may suggest that Americans continue to value their role in the electoral process, particularly when they perceive that the stakes are high, political analysts say. And voters are eager to take advantage of ways that make it easier for them to play their part, they add.

"People want to choose the most convenient thing, especially if they're anticipating long lines" on Election Day, says David Damore, professor of political science at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.

In this election in particular, he says, Democrats and Republicans alike tend to see a win for the other side as an existential threat. "The importance of the outcome looms over most people," Dr. Damore says. "That may not fire enthusiasm, but it becomes important to people to participate."

As voting options expand, the percentage of voters nationwide casting their ballots early have soared from about 11 percent in 1996 to 33 percent in 2012, Pew reports. Data for 2016 suggests the trend will hold. In states such as Nevada and Colorado, nearly half the total electorate had already cast their votes five days before the election, says Paul Gronke, founder and director of the Early Voting Information Center at Reed College in Portland, Ore. In Tennessee and Arizona, nearly two-thirds have turned in their ballots.

"That's the biggest story, the earliness," Professor Gronke says. His theory as to why is somewhat less optimistic: "People are very unhappy with this campaign. They want to get it over with."

The notion of casting ballots ahead of Election Day has been around since the Civil War, when Republicans – in an effort to secure the soldier vote for Abraham Lincoln – pushed for legislation to allow servicemen to cast their vote while away from their home states.

Early voting for convenience, however, took shape only in the 1970s: first when Congress passed a law allowing overseas voters without legal homes in the U.S. to mail in their ballots, and then when California introduced a "no-excuses" law that let any registered voter cast an absentee ballot. By the 1980s, Oregon had adopted the country's first vote-by-mail election system, sending registered voters ballots that they could either mail in or drop off in person.

Today, 37 states and the District of Columbia allow some form of early voting. The shift makes sense, says Dan Schnur, director of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California. The democratic ideal is to make it as easy as possible for people to participate, he says. In an earlier era, that meant face-to-face communication at an appointed time and place.

"You don't have to go to your bank to withdraw money. You don't have to harvest your food before dinner," he says. "Even without crossing the divide into online voting – which is an idea of debatable value – there's no reason in the world that a voter should be required to cast their ballot at a single precinct location."

For some Las Vegas voters, the expansion of early voting – and laws that require employers to give workers time to vote – provides a chance to reaffirm their role in the democratic process.

"We're fortunate to get to do it on the clock," says Belinda, a hotel employee who declined to give her last name. She and two of her coworkers had arrived at a polling station about a mile off The Strip on a charter bus that takes hotel workers to and from the site.

"It makes a big difference," she says. "Our voices are being heard."

Some say the main draw is the luxury of getting in their ballots minus the hassle of Election Day crowds – particularly in a race as volatile as this one.

"With everybody split up the way they are, the country's going to be crazy" come Nov. 8, says Timothy Salmon, a father and video producer, as he left a satellite polling station in the parking lot of a local shopping center. Except for work, he says, "I don't want to go out that day."

For others, the chance to vote early simply means an easy way to fulfill a sense of obligation. After all, voters had only to go online to find the site closest to their home or workplace.

"It was very fast. I thought it was going to be more difficult," says Raul Sanchez, who plays in a mariachi band. Though in his 50s, Mr. Sanchez is a first-time voter, spurred to the polls by a desire to see someone who isn't Donald Trump win the White House. Sanchez says the experience left him encouraged – and inspired him to take part in future elections.

That Nevada is a swing state has also led residents here to feel more keenly the weight of each individual vote.

"We have to make the election count," says Del Carpio, the retired hairdresser.

"This is a state where your vote actually matters," adds Alex Zachary, who works at the Marquee, a popular nightclub, as he inched forward in line. "I want to make sure I have my say."

Title: 2020 Democratic Candidates Face Calls to Address Border Wall Stance After Beto O'Rourke's Remarks

Article:

The call for a clear stance on the border wall issue among Democratic presidential hopefuls has gained momentum following Beto O'Rourke's statement supporting the destruction of existing barriers along the southern border with Mexico.

O'Rourke, the former Texas Democratic congressman, called for the demolition of the El Paso wall after the White House announced President Trump's intention to declare a national state of emergency to fund the remainder of his border wall project. During an interview on MSNBC, O'Rourke confirmed he would remove the wall, stating, "Yes, absolutely. I'd take the wall down."

O'Rourke's stance has prompted questions for other potential 2020 Democratic candidates, including Kamala Harris, Cory Booker, Elizabeth Warren, Julian Castro, Kirsten Gillibrand, and Amy Klobuchar, regarding their views on the existing border walls.

New York Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand has signaled an openness to O'Rourke's proposal, stating, "I could look at it and see which part he means and why and if it makes sense I could support it."

Republicans have seized the opportunity to portray Democrats as extreme and pro-open borders, with Sen. John Cornyn (R-TX) tweeting, "Correct me if I am wrong, but did Beto say he would tear down existing border fencing and walls?"

Not all Democrats have embraced the idea of tearing down existing walls. House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (D-MD) stated during an interview on Fox News' "Special Report with Bret Baier" last month that border walls "obviously" work in some areas and rejected suggestions that barriers should be removed where they already exist.

In January, Democratic Texas Rep. Veronica Escobar told CNN that walls do not work and suggested she was open to destroying existing walls, describing them as "really ugly" and "monuments to division."

The border wall issue has become a potential litmus test for the 2020 Democratic field, with O'Rourke being the first likely candidate to call for tearing down walls, while other lesser-known Democrats have suggested support for the idea in recent weeks.

Title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Obama's Deportation Amnesty, Potential 4-4 Split Possible

Article:

The United States Supreme Court grappled with the legality of President Obama's deportation amnesty on Monday, as conservative justices questioned the president's encroachment on Congress's lawmaking powers, while liberal justices argued for non-intervention, leaving the president with a potential free hand. Outside the courthouse, thousands of Hispanic rights activists rallied, demanding leniency from the justices and vowing political retribution on Congress, particularly Republicans, if President Obama loses the case.

Inside the courtroom, attorneys debated the intricacies of immigration law and the intentions of Congress when it stated that illegal immigrants should be deported but provided only enough funding for a small fraction. Texas and 25 other states argued that it is time for the high court to get involved, and they appeared to have allies among the four Republican-appointed justices, who questioned the president's power to grant temporary legal status.

Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who is expected to be a key voice in the decision, stated, "It's as if the president is setting the policy and the Congress is executing it. That's just upside down."

At issue is a set of policies announced by President Obama and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson in November 2014. One of these policies set deportation priorities, carving most illegal immigrants out of any danger of deportation, a policy not being challenged. However, another policy granted as many as 5 million illegal immigrants with children who have legal status in the U.S. a three-year stay of deportation, accompanied by work permits, entitling them to driver's licenses and some taxpayer benefits, including Social Security.

President Obama argued that since he is not going to deport them anyway, it makes sense to let them enter the legal economy, where they will earn better wages and help the economy overall. The four Democrat-appointed justices seemed to agree.

Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the only Hispanic member of the court, stated, "They are here whether we want them or not." She argued that what President Obama did appears to be in line with actions of previous presidents, who deferred deportations and offered work permits to illegal immigrants caught in a legal limbo in the 1980s and 1990s.

With the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, a 4-4 split is possible. In such a case, the lower appeals court's ruling, which decided 2-1 that President Obama's amnesty violated immigration law, would remain in place. This would also leave for future courts the biggest questions over the extent of presidential powers, limits that President Obama has repeatedly tested.

During oral argument on Monday, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. read out a quote from one of more than a dozen times President Obama said he did not have such expansive powers. "What was he talking about?" the chief justice prodded Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr., President Obama's liaison to the high court. Mr. Verrilli stated that President Obama must have changed his mind after asking the Justice Department's legal advisory branch to take a closer look.

President Obama's amnesty has been controversial among voters overall but is very popular with Hispanics, who are a growing power in elections. Hispanic leaders have vowed to rally their community to punish Republicans for their strict stance on illegal immigration, and they made that clear at rallies in front of the Supreme Court on Monday.

The case, United States v. Texas, has drawn intense interest from Congress, where Democrats and Republicans filed opposing briefs, and from activists on issues ranging from presidential power to immigration law to business interests. "This has tremendous political valence," Justice Stephen G. Breyer said. However, the possibility of a 4-4 tie could sap much of the energy from the case, since it would mean the court would not issue a definitive opinion on the limits of presidential power.

The court had asked all sides to submit briefs on whether President Obama was violating the Constitution's admonition that the president "take care" that the laws are faithfully executed, but there was no discussion of that during oral argument. The liberal justices also questioned whether Texas even had standing to sue in the first place, doubting the state's worry that it will face a flood of new illegal immigrants and will have to subsidize driver's licenses and pay for other benefits for the folks who qualify for President Obama's policy. Justice Sotomayor stated that if Texas could sue to stop immigration policy like this, it would open the door for states to sue any time they find fault with a federal policy, making judges the referees in myriad disputes. "That really pits the states against every federal agency," she said.

Title: Clinton Employs Animal Impersonations in Nevada Campaign Rally

Article:

In a bid to secure victory in the upcoming Nevada caucuses, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton employed animal impersonations during a campaign rally in Reno on Monday. The former secretary of state mimicked a barking dog to fact-check potential false statements made by political opponents, specifically referencing the Great Recession.

Clinton's humorous anecdote began with a recollection of a political ad that aired on the radio in Arkansas, featuring a dog that supposedly barked whenever a candidate made an untrue statement. Clinton, before yelping, "Arf! Arf! Arf! Arf!" to general applause, said, "We need to get that dog and follow him around, and every time they say these things, like, 'oh, the Great Recession was caused by too much regulation,'" Clinton said, mimicking the dog's barks.

Clinton and her opponent, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, have been actively campaigning in Nevada in recent days. On Sunday, they found themselves at opposite ends of a pew in the same Las Vegas church.

Sanders' ground game is reportedly catching up to Clinton's campaign machine. The self-proclaimed Democratic socialist's campaign has over 100 staffers on the ground and has more than doubled its paid staff in Nevada since last month, along with spending double on television ads compared to Clinton - $2.93 million to Clinton's $1.46 million.

The uncertainty surrounding the outcome of the Nevada caucuses is heightened by a relative lack of polling and a sense of momentum behind Sanders following his resounding victory over Clinton in the New Hampshire primary last week. Clinton opted to skip a campaign event in Florida, sending her husband, former President Bill Clinton, to stump in her stead.

As in Iowa and New Hampshire, Sanders has publicly pinned his hopes in Nevada on voter turnout. "Everything in my political gut tells me that we have the momentum here in this state," he told a rally in Las Vegas Sunday. "And if people come out in large numbers on caucus day, we're going to win."

It is possible to win the Nevada caucuses but lose the all-important battle for Democratic National Convention delegates. That's exactly what happened to Clinton in 2008 against then-Senator Barack Obama.

The Clinton campaign may not have helped its cause in Nevada with comments made last week by campaign spokesman Brian Fallon, who compared Nevada to the more racially and ethnically homogenous Iowa and New Hampshire. "There's an important Hispanic element to the Democratic caucus in Nevada," Fallon said. "But it's still a state that is 80 percent white voters. You have a caucus-style format, and [Sanders will] have the momentum coming out of New Hampshire presumably, so there's a lot of reasons he should do well."

This remark reportedly angered allies of Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid, with one telling Politico that Reid had "pushed hard to move Nevada near the front of the primary calendar precisely because of its diversity."

Title: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo Criticizes Alleged Meeting Between Democrat Senators and Iranian Foreign Minister

Article:

In a joint press conference with Ethiopian Foreign Minister Gedu Andargachew on Tuesday, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo addressed reports that a number of Democrat Senators had secretly met with Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif during the Munich Security Conference.

Pompeo stated, "I have seen that piece about some senators meeting with Foreign Minister Zarif. This guy is designated by the United States of America. He’s the foreign minister for a country that shot down a commercial airliner and has yet to turn over the black boxes. This is the foreign minister of a country that killed an American on December 27. And it’s the foreign minister of a country who is the largest world sponsor of terror and the world’s largest sponsor of anti-Semitism."

The initial report of the alleged secret Zarif meeting was first published by The Federalist, stating, "Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut and other Democratic senators had a secret meeting with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif during the Munich Security Conference last week." Murphy's office did not respond to repeated requests for comment by press time.

Zarif was designated for sanctions by the U.S. Treasury Department last summer for sponsoring terrorism around the world. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated at the time, "Javad Zarif implements the reckless agenda of Iran’s Supreme Leader, and is the regime’s primary spokesperson around the world. The United States is sending a clear message to the Iranian regime that its recent behavior is completely unacceptable."

Senator Murphy, along with other Democrats, have repeatedly worked to preserve the Iranian Nuclear Agreement. The United States officially left the deal, struck during the Obama administration, in 2018.

Former Secretary of State John Kerry, who has been openly undermining U.S. foreign policy since President Trump took office in 2017, was also seen with Zarif in Munich.

Pompeo referred to a commercial airline flight that had 176 innocent people on board from Iran, Canada, Ukraine, Sweden, Afghanistan, Germany, and Great Britain. The Iranian government lied about shooting down the plane for days and blamed the crash on engine failure. The regime arrested the individual who took video of two missiles being launched at the aircraft, leading to its demise.

UPDATE: Senator Murphy has confirmed he did in fact meet with Zarif in Munich.

Title: U.S. Presidential Race: Free Trade Emerges as a Clear Casualty Amid Economic Uncertainty

Article:

In the ongoing presidential race, free trade has emerged as a significant casualty, with both major parties expressing growing opposition to trade agreements. According to exit polling, a majority of voters view free trade as an economic burden on the U.S., costing American jobs.

Notably, the opposition within the Republican Party is higher than among Democrats, a shift that challenges conventional wisdom, which traditionally positions Democrats as the free trade opponents due to their ties with labor unions. In Wisconsin's primary, only a third of Republican voters believed free trade creates American jobs, while a staggering 54% held the opposite view. Among Democratic primary voters, the numbers were more evenly split, with 41% saying free trade helps jobs and 42% saying it costs the country jobs. Similar results have been observed in states including Illinois and Mississippi.

Matthew J. Slaughter, dean of the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth, attributes this shift in attitudes to the downward pressures on American earnings in recent years, regardless of political affiliation.

The economic downturn and the ready target of trade have pushed both parties' presidential candidates toward protectionism. Four out of the five remaining candidates oppose the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a 12-nation deal signed by President Obama but yet to be submitted to Congress for final approval.

Businessman Donald Trump, the Republican frontrunner, has threatened to scrap not only the TPP but also previous agreements such as the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). This has forced Sen. Ted Cruz, Trump's closest competitor and the winner of Wisconsin's primary, to adopt a tougher stance on the issue.

In the Democratic race, Sen. Bernie Sanders has made his opposition to trade deals a key campaign point, and front-runner Hillary Clinton has been playing catch-up, recanting her previous praise for TPP as a secretary of state and now stating that the deal signed by her former boss, Mr. Obama, falls short.

However, she has been surprised by how effectively Mr. Sanders has used the issue against her. "We need a president who doesn't just rail against trade. We need a president who knows how to compete against the rest of the world and win," she said in a Twitter post after Mr. Sanders won the Democratic primary in Wisconsin.

Only Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who is trailing in the Republican race, remains a supporter of the TPP.

While economists can calculate the benefits to the overall U.S. economy from trade, these benefits do little to comfort those who lose out, and these are the voices to which the candidates are responding.

Gene M. Grossman, a Princeton University professor who has studied the politics of trade, notes that trade is always a hard sell in difficult times. "What's needed in such times is leadership from some with a longer horizon and broader vision. Alas, such leaders seem to be in short supply these days," he said.

The near-uniform opposition at the top of the ticket this year could doom the chances for trade deals for years to come, though some analysts see a brief opening this year, with both President Obama and House Speaker Paul D. Ryan supporters of a deal while their window of opportunity is closing.

Simon Rosenberg, a longtime trade supporter and founder of NDN, a center-left think tank, hopes that Mr. Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell somehow manage to get the TPP passed during an Obama presidency.

The Democrats' confliction on trade has long been apparent in Washington, where the party has experienced deep rifts. However, the Republican voters' aversion to free trade is striking given the near-monolithic support for free trade agreements by the party's officeholders in Washington. In the vote last year to grant President Obama fast-track powers to negotiate trade deals, nearly 80% of House Republicans and 90% of Senate Republicans voted in favor.

Since then, as the presidential campaign has intensified, so has opposition among Republicans. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who voted for the fast-track powers, now has serious questions about the TPP deal reached with those powers. He has told President Obama not to submit the deal until after the elections, leaving a lame-duck Congress as the only chance for passage.

Rosenberg suggests that the Republican opposition isn't surprising, as it's been Democrats who have advanced every major trade deal of the last century. He notes that NAFTA, the creation of the World Trade Organization, and normalized trade relations with China were all Democratic priorities, with President Obama completing the TPP. "The truth is the heavy lifting on trade has been done by Democrats, and the Republicans haven't been nearly as involved in putting together the deals and the legislative pieces to get these done in the way Democrats have," he said.

Title: Attorney General William Barr Skips House Hearing on Mueller Report, Tensions Escalate Between Congress and Trump Administration

Article:

WASHINGTON – Attorney General William Barr did not attend a House hearing on Thursday regarding special counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 election, leading to a confrontation between lawmakers. This is the latest escalation of tensions between President Donald Trump's administration and the House of Representatives, which has launched wide-ranging investigations into the president.

Trump's administration has stated its intention to fight lawmakers' demands for information and has taken legal action to block some of these demands. Barr refused to testify before the House Judiciary Committee about Mueller's Russia report because the committee agreed to add an hour of questions by staff lawyers. The hearing was to have been Barr's second day of testimony about the investigation and his handling of the special counsel's final report.

Chairman Jerry Nadler (D-N.Y.) accused the Trump administration of ignoring subpoenas and refusing to testify, a pattern he said reflects an effort to prevent Congress from providing any check whatsoever to even the most reckless of the president's decisions.

"The challenge we face is that if we don’t stand up to him together, today, then we risk forever losing the power to stand up to any president in the future," Nadler said.

Rep. Steve Cohen (D-Tenn.) brought a bucket of Kentucky Fried Chicken into the House hearing room to mark Barr's absence. The top Republican on the panel, Rep. Doug Collins of Georgia, called the meeting a "circus political stunt" that prevented Barr's testimony for lawmakers of either party.

"They want it to look like an impeachment hearing because they won't bring impeachment proceedings," Collins said.

Nadler said Barr did not attend because he was afraid of being questioned by trained lawyers. The clash marked the latest confrontation over congressional investigations into Trump and his administration. Lawmakers contend they are being stonewalled across a variety of inquiries by an administration that ignores subpoenas and avoids testimony, but Trump says the partisan requests are presidential harassment.

The Justice Department refused Wednesday to provide an unredacted version of the Mueller report to Congress despite the subpoena deadline. Barr redacted portions dealing with grand jury testimony, information about pending cases, intelligence gathering secrets, and information that could infringe on the privacy of people who were not charged.

Congressional Democrats insist they deserve to receive the full report and the underlying information that Mueller's team gathered during 22 months. In a letter Wednesday to Nadler, the Justice Department's Assistant Attorney General Stephen Boyd said the committee has not "articulated any legislative purpose for its request" for documents relating to Mueller's investigation.

"The committee has no legitimate role in demanding law enforcement materials with the aim of simply duplicating a criminal inquiry – which is, of course, a function that the Constitution entrusts exclusively to the executive branch," Boyd wrote.

Nadler said in an opening statement facing an empty chair for Barr that lawmakers must come together to protect the integrity of the House.

"Every member of this committee should understand the consequences when the executive branch informs us that they will simply ignore a congressional subpoena," Nadler said. "The challenge we face is also bigger than the Mueller report."

Collins said Democrats wanted a circus rather than to pose questions to Barr.

"Not hearing from him is a travesty for this committee today," Collins said.

Mueller's report identified "systematic" efforts by the Kremlin to interfere in the 2016 election by hacking emails and posting disinformation to help Trump win, and it detailed how Trump and his aides appeared to welcome that help. It found no conspiracy between Trump's campaign and Russia, and it did not reach a conclusion about whether Trump sought to obstruct justice.

After Thursday's abbreviated hearing, Democrats said they supported Nadler's plan to negotiate with the Justice Department for "a few more days" to obtain the full report.

"The next step is to hold the attorney general in contempt for failing to comply with our subpoena," Rep. David Cicilline (D-R.I.) said. Another step would be to subpoena Barr to testify. Democrats plan to call Mueller to testify, tentatively scheduled for May 15.

Title: Senate Cloture Vote on Budget Compromise Hinges on Internal GOP Politics

Article:

The upcoming cloture vote on the short-term budget compromise in the Senate on Tuesday primarily rests on the 14 Republicans on the Appropriations Committee. Six of these members are up for reelection in 2014, and some may choose to oppose the deal. However, this leaves more than enough support for Democrats to reach the 60 votes required, given the backing from fellow Republicans on the House Appropriations Committee.

The recent decision by Sen. Thad Cochran (R-Miss.) to seek reelection could potentially impact the chairmanship of the Appropriations Committee. Cochran could lay claim to the position at the expense of Alabama Sen. Richard Shelby, the current ranking Republican. A spokesperson for Shelby stated that the potential competition with Cochran has no bearing on his opposition to the budget deal. However, Shelby's office announced that he will vote against cloture on Tuesday.

The internal Republican politics within the Senate Appropriations Committee could overshadow the budget deal itself. By opposing cloture, Shelby may help himself become chairman, but if he kills the deal, the committee's effectiveness could be compromised. Many on Appropriations view Tuesday's vote as existential, as the budget agreement would negate sequestration in January, reset the Budget Control Act with more manageable caps on discretionary spending for fiscal 2014 and 2015, and allow the Appropriations Committee to regain its relevance in the Congress.

The contrast between House and Senate Republicans could not be more stark. House Appropriations Chairman Hal Rogers (R-Ky.) worked hard to secure support for the deal within his committee, losing only two votes. Equally important, Republicans on House Appropriations from seven states, also represented by Republicans on the Senate committee, voted for the deal. These states were Alabama, Arkansas, Kansas, Kentucky, Nebraska, Mississippi, and Tennessee, represented in the Senate by Shelby, John Boozman, Jerry Moran, Mitch McConnell, Mike Johanns, Cochran, and Lamar Alexander, respectively.

Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) expressed bafflement as to why this is a close call for her fellow Republicans on Appropriations, stating, "I would think appropriators would welcome the chance to have a top-line and write our bills. We Republicans have said for years that we want to get back to normal order and a budget. Now we have a bipartisan agreement negotiated by a conservative House budget chairman. Why is this close?"

Title: Republican Memo Fails to Exonerate Trump on Collusion and Obstruction Allegations

Article:

The recently released Republican memo, drafted by Representative Devin Nunes, has failed to clear President Donald Trump of allegations of collusion with the Russians or obstruction of justice, as claimed by Mr. Trump. The memo, instead, confirmed that contacts between former Trump foreign policy adviser George Papadopoulos and Russian intermediaries, not the material from former British intelligence officer Christopher Steele's dossier, were the primary factors in the opening of the investigation in July 2016.

Democrats have criticized the document, viewing it as a tactic to undermine the ongoing investigation and protect Mr. Trump. They argue that the Democratic memo, yet to be released, will reveal that the FBI was more forthcoming with the surveillance court than Republicans had claimed. According to sources familiar with the Democratic document, it is said to disclose that the FBI informed the court that the information it received from Steele was politically motivated, although it did not name the Democratic National Committee or Hillary Clinton's campaign.

On Monday, when confronted with Democratic claims that such a disclosure was included in the application, Mr. Nunes admitted on Fox & Friends that there was a "footnote" to that effect. However, he characterized its inclusion as a "far cry from letting the American people know that the Democrats and the Hillary campaign paid for dirt that the FBI then used to get a warrant."

Democrats also contest Republican claims that Andrew G. McCabe, the deputy director of the FBI at the time, had testified before the Intelligence Committee late last year that the agency would not have sought a wiretap of Carter Page, a former Moscow-based investment banker under investigation once before, without Steele's dossier of information.

The FBI suspected that Page was acting as a Russian agent. In response to the ongoing investigation, The New York Times filed a motion on Monday asking the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to unseal all materials related to the wiretap of Page, including the FBI's application for the warrant and other court documents. Since the enactment of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act in 1978, no such wiretapping application materials have been made public.

Title: House Republicans Unveil American Health Care Act, Replacing Obamacare with Challenges Ahead

Article:

House Republicans have unveiled the American Health Care Act, a plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The new legislation, which follows GOP principles, effectively repeals the individual and employer insurance mandates, replacing them with tax credits for individuals to purchase their own policies.

The plan also overhauls Medicaid, a federally supported health care program for the poor, which many Republicans view as too costly as the federal debt approaches $20 trillion. However, independent analysts question the plan's ability to provide "insurance for everybody" and cover people while reducing costs.

G. William Hoagland, senior vice president of the Bipartisan Policy Center, estimates that 8 million to 12 million fewer people would be covered under the GOP plan, while the ACA added coverage for more than 20 million people. The independent Congressional Budget Office has yet to report on the plan's costs or its effect on the number of insured.

The plan faces opposition from both conservative and moderate Republicans. Conservatives view the tax credits as a new "entitlement" program, while moderates argue that the tax credits are too meager to help low-income Americans. Many Republican governors, who expanded Medicaid under Obamacare, are also expected to object to reduced outlays under the House plan.

The American Health Care Act includes several key provisions:

1. Dropping the individual and employer mandates by repealing their penalties immediately, with insurers imposing a 30 percent premium increase for consumers who let their coverage lapse.
2. Replacing subsidies with tax credits that can be applied to private plans. The credits, based on age, range from $2,000 to $4,000 for individuals and up to $14,000 for families.
3. Funding Medicaid expansion fully through 2019, after which funding will decline. A $100 billion "stability fund" will be available to all states to lower health costs.
4. Continuing popular parts of Obamacare, such as allowing young adults to stay on their parents' health insurance until age 26 and prohibiting denial of coverage for a preexisting condition.

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) stated that the plan would "drive down costs, encourage competition, and give every American access to quality, affordable health insurance." However, Democrats strongly disagree, even as premiums have risen and choices have declined in many Obamacare insurance markets.

Republicans will have to pass the plan using a budget process known as "reconciliation," which requires only a majority vote for passage in both houses of Congress. However, even this low threshold seems elusive given Republican division over the plan.

Sen. Rand Paul (R-KY) stated, "It still looks like Obamacare-lite to me. It's going to have to be better." Two other Senate conservatives and four GOP senators from states that expanded Medicaid have voiced similar objections. The concerns over changes to Medicaid are well-founded, according to Daniel Derksen, director of the Center for Rural Health at the University of Arizona. The capping and then cutting of Medicaid eligibility and funding over several years shifts costs and risks from the federal government to states, rural hospitals, physicians, and individuals and their families.

Passing health-care reform took more than a century, as Presidents Harry Truman, Richard Nixon, and Bill Clinton witnessed. It required a filibuster-proof effort of 60 votes in the Senate for President Obama to get there. "The House bill starts the process," writes political science professor and health-care policy expert Lawrence Jacobs. "The question is whether it has a future."

Title: Top Democrats Caution Against "Blue Wave" Predictions for Midterm Elections

Article:

Top Democrats are urging caution about predictions of a "blue wave" sweeping the party into power on Capitol Hill, as fresh signs indicate that the midterms could be much closer than anticipated. With just over two weeks to go before the critical elections, Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez stated Monday that he does not use the term "blue wave" to describe a possible Democratic victory.

Perez, who was speaking to CNN, predicted a tight race for control of Congress. "We always knew that this election was going to be close—I don’t use the term 'blue wave,' I always talk about the need for the blocking and tackling," Perez said. "I always talk about the need for organizing, to make sure you’re leading with your values, and that’s how we’ve been winning throughout this year and throughout 2017."

Despite this, Perez expressed confidence that Democrats will take control of the House and win in a number of gubernatorial races. "I don’t think the Democratic advantage has ebbed," Perez said. "We’re talking about the issues that matter most to people."

Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders cast further doubt on the "wave" narrative. "A lot of people talk about this 'blue wave' and stuff," Sanders told The Hill. "I don’t believe it." Sanders, an independent who ran for president in 2016 as a Democrat, added: "I happen to think that on election night we’ll find a very, very close situation, and maybe a handful of votes determining whether Democrats gain control of the House."

The cautious comments come as the shifting midterm landscape reflects a Republican advantage in the Senate and a tough fight for control of the House, which could be determined by just a handful of races. Republican National Committee Chairwoman Ronna McDaniel said Monday on "America’s Newsroom" that the GOP should hold the Senate and has a shot at the House.

The statements from Perez and Sanders stand in stark contrast to the optimism displayed last week by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi. Pelosi, D-Calif., expressed little doubt of a major Democratic victory in the midterms during a speech at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

Pelosi, who has her eyes on the speaker's gavel, said, "I think if the election were today, we would win the majority." However, an NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll released over the weekend found that Democrats continue to hold a sizeable lead in the closing weeks before the midterms, but noted that in districts rated as the most competitive by the nonpartisan Cook Political Report, they are now in a dead heat with Republicans on the question of which party should control Congress.

Title: Former Trump Campaign Chairman Paul Manafort Faces Trial for 18 Criminal Counts

Article:

The first trial to emerge from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe is set to commence on Tuesday, as former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort appears before a federal judge in Alexandria, Virginia. Manafort is facing 18 criminal counts, including bank and tax fraud, which could potentially result in a 30-year prison sentence. He has pleaded not guilty to all charges.

The charges against Manafort stem from his lobbying activities in Ukraine on behalf of politicians with ties to Russia. Prosecutors have alleged that he was paid over $60 million for his work, which includes support for former Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovich.

Government attorneys claim that Manafort engaged in a scheme to conceal his income from the Internal Revenue Service and other authorities in the United States. Instead of paying taxes on the income, they assert that he used it to support a lavish lifestyle that included owning three homes, a $21,000 watch, a $105,000 car, and New York Yankees season tickets.

Approximately 500 pieces of evidence and up to 35 witnesses are expected to be presented by prosecutors. One of these witnesses is Manafort's former business associate Rick Gates, who was charged alongside Manafort but pleaded guilty and has cooperated with Mueller's team.

Manafort's work as a Ukrainian political operative occurred nearly a decade before he joined the Trump campaign in mid-2016. He organized the Republican convention in July 2016, but resigned from President Trump's team one month later.

Prosecutors have stated that they will not present evidence of Russian collusion during Manafort's trial, but have claimed they have the authority to prosecute him under a May 2017 order by Deputy Attorney Rod Rosenstein.

Manafort's attorneys have challenged that order, claiming that Mueller exceeded his authority. District Judge T.S. Ellis III, who is overseeing the Virginia trial, denied their motion, holding that Mueller's mandate authorizes him to pursue charges in the case.

The Virginia trial marks the first of two trials that Manafort will face this year. He has a September trial scheduled in Washington, D.C., on charges of failing to register as a foreign agent and making false statements to investigators.

Title: Obama and Romney's Closing Arguments: A Look at Their Final Messages Before the 2012 Election

Article:

In the final two weeks of the 2012 presidential race, both candidates, Mitt Romney and President Barack Obama, are making their closing arguments. With few opportunities remaining to significantly shift the race, both campaigns are relying on strong turnout operations and well-crafted messages to secure a slight advantage.

President Obama, in a 60-second TV ad released Tuesday, outlined his plans for the next four years, focusing on education, manufacturing, energy, and deficit reduction. This move by the Obama campaign appears to be an attempt to counter criticism of a thin second-term agenda, as the president's specific policy proposals are now more clearly presented in a list-like format.

Obama senior adviser David Axelrod stated on a conference call that the new tactics are not a response to the "where's the beef" criticism, but rather a reflection of the campaign's entry into the closing argument phase. Axelrod explained, "Obviously, a lot of people have made up their minds. There is a small universe of voters who haven't. We want to make sure those voters have access to the information they need."

On the other hand, Romney spokesman Kevin Madden, speaking to reporters onboard the campaign plane, expressed confidence in Romney's performance during the foreign policy debate, stating, "I think many swing voters looked at the foreign policy debate last night, and they were asking themselves, 'Does Gov. Romney pass the commander in chief test? And clearly he did. He also gave people a sense of confidence that he has a plan for what he wants to do over the next four years as it relates to positioning America around the globe, and that they feel safer and more secure that he does have a plan.'"

This article provides a neutral and factual account of the candidates' closing arguments, without personal commentary or speculation. The information presented is based on the user-provided text.

Title: White House and House Speaker Disagree on Fiscal Cliff Plan B

Article:

The White House has rejected House Speaker John Boehner's proposal for a fall-back plan to avoid the impending fiscal crisis, a move that Boehner's office described as "defying common sense." The disagreement comes as both sides approach a potential middle ground in private negotiations, but differences remain.

Boehner introduced his alternative plan on Tuesday, calling for taxes to rise only on households with an income exceeding $1 million. His plan also includes entitlement cuts and a tax reform debate for next year. The White House, however, criticized the plan, stating that it does not ask enough from the wealthiest taxpayers and could not pass the Senate.

In response, Boehner's spokesman, Brendan Buck, argued that the White House is "moving the goal posts" and is threatening every American family with higher taxes. Boehner, with his leadership at stake, is trying to navigate a tightrope in negotiations as the president demands tax hikes that many Republicans oppose.

Boehner's call for a "Plan B" could serve as a failsafe option if he is unable to secure the votes for any future deal with the White House. However, it could also be aimed at pushing Obama to compromise more. A Boehner aide stated that the speaker is "hopeful an agreement will be reached," but expressed concern that the president's latest counteroffer includes $1.3 trillion in revenue increases and only $850 billion in spending cuts.

House Republican Leader Eric Cantor is also putting pressure on the president, stating that the "alternative plan" is being discussed in case Obama "cannot come our way." Without a deal, tax rates would rise for everyone, with middle-income families facing a roughly $2,000 increase next year. Capital gains and dividends rates would also go up, and long-term unemployment aid would expire.

For taxpayers, a host of benefits and tax provisions are at stake. With a deal, most Americans would likely be spared major tax increases, but those making above a certain threshold could still be affected, depending on what both sides agree to. Certain entitlement programs could also be cut, including Medicare and Social Security. Obama has indicated he is willing to agree to smaller cost-of-living increases for Social Security recipients.

In terms of logistics, the House is tentatively planning to take up the "Plan B" proposal later this week, as early as Thursday. They would do so by amending a bill previously passed by the Senate that tracks more with Obama's original offer. Then, the House would send the bill back to the Senate, where it would likely sit as a potential last resort in case Obama and Boehner cannot strike a deal.

The Boehner alternative plan received mixed reviews from Republican House members on Tuesday, but on the Democratic side, leaders expressed swift opposition even before the White House came out against it. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's office stated that Boehner's "plan B" is "the farthest thing from a balanced approach" and will not protect middle-class families because it cannot pass both Houses of Congress. House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer called it a "political ploy," and Democratic leaders urged their members to vote against it.

Title: Federal Report Predicts Slight Increase in U.S. Health Care Spending Over Next Decade Due to Affordable Care Act

Article:

The U.S. government has released a new estimate indicating that the country will spend slightly more on healthcare over the next decade due to the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. According to the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), a federal agency within the Department of Health and Human Services, the ACA is expected to add $478 billion to healthcare costs over the next decade, resulting in a slightly faster rate of spending growth compared to if the law had not been passed.

The CMS report states that, if upheld by the Supreme Court later this month, the ACA will cause average spending growth to increase by one-tenth of a percent per year more than it would have without the law. Republicans have criticized the ACA, arguing that the data proves the law will not address the issue of rising healthcare costs.

In response, the administration has defended the ACA, stating that Americans' out-of-pocket expenses will decrease beginning in 2014, particularly in relation to prescription drugs. Secretary of Health and Human Services Kathleen Sebelius wrote in a blog post that the law will return "real money" to the pockets of millions of Americans.

The CMS report also indicates that health care spending is expected to grow at unusually low levels in the next year due to the slow economic recovery. However, spending growth will increase significantly in 2014, rising from 3.8 percent in 2013 to 7.4 percent in 2014 as major provisions of the ACA take effect. Spending growth will remain higher for several years, before dropping to around 6 percent annually.

By 2021, federal, state, and local governments will make up nearly 50 percent of all healthcare spending in the U.S., up from 46 percent in 2011. Republicans have criticized the ACA, stating that it does not fulfill President Obama's promise to control the growth of healthcare costs as a percentage of the American economy.

The CMS report's projections have changed little since last summer, when the agency first projected that the ACA would cause healthcare spending to increase slightly over the next decade. The administration has dismissed the data, stating that the ACA only appears to raise spending because it is measured against unusually low recent growth rates during the economic recession.

Key provisions in the ACA, such as bringing more healthy Americans into insurance pools, allowing Medicare to experiment with new "bundled payment" methods, and cutting down on emergency room visits by mandating coverage for everyone, could help control spending further. However, it remains to be seen whether these provisions will be sufficient to control spending in future decades.

The newly insured population is expected to be younger and healthier than the currently insured, and they are expected to drive up the demand for prescription drugs and doctors. This could be a positive sign for reducing spending in the long term, as patients who regularly visit the doctor and practice preventative medicine can avoid more expensive health problems in the future.

Title: Understanding the Iran Nuclear Negotiations: The Role of Sanctions and Domestic Politics

Article:

As the third round of talks on the Iranian nuclear program begins in Geneva, it is crucial for the United States to approach the negotiation table with caution. The danger lies in misinterpreting Iran's entry into negotiations as a result of economic pressure due to sanctions and the country's increasing economic and political vulnerability.

However, this narrative overlooks the internal politics of the Islamic Republic of Iran and the election of President Hassan Rouhani, who is navigating a delicate political balancing act on the domestic political scene. While sanctions played a role in changing Iran's behavior, they did not force Iran to return to the negotiation table out of fear of economic collapse. Instead, sanctions facilitated a transformation of the balance of power within the Iranian political system that was already underway since 2009, prior to the enactment of the current sanctions regime.

The election, rather than sanctions, was the key to Iran's shift on foreign policy and nuclear negotiations. The victory of another candidate, such as former nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili, would not have produced such a change in foreign policy despite the same sanctions regime. The impact of sanctions should be viewed through the lens of electoral turnover and the domestic shifts of power that brought Rouhani to office.

The current realignment of forces in Iran and the country's intention to engage with the international community presents the U.S. with a significant opportunity. The success of the Rouhani administration and his coalition alliance is critical for reaching a mutually beneficial deal on the nuclear program and for advancing a more moderate and politically inclusive Iran.

However, the persistence of sanctions without any meaningful relief or significant incentives can undermine the Rouhani administration and hinder the potential for a resolution. Not only will continued sanctions contribute to the mistrust between the U.S. and Iran, but they will strengthen the hand of Iranian hardliners. A recalibration of political forces back toward the hardline elite would divide the cross-factional coalition supporting the Rouhani presidency.

In negotiating over the nuclear program with Iran, it is essential that the U.S. and its partners get the sanctions narrative right. While sanctions contributed to an ongoing re-alignment of political factions conducive to Rouhani's electoral victory and the shift in Iranian foreign policy, they alone did not bring Iran to the negotiating table. And their continuance can also undermine the new government that is now in power.

Given the opportune environment to reach a negotiated deal with Iran, the U.S. would be best served to devise a meaningful incentives package with an eye on the domestic Iranian political scene rather than increasing sanctions on Iran.

Payam Mohseni, a visiting assistant professor in the Department of Government at Harvard University and a postdoctoral research fellow in the International Security Program at the Harvard Kennedy School's Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs, made these observations.

Title: Senate Shutdown Showdown: Trump's Negotiations and the Government Funding Impasse

Article:

The ongoing government funding impasse is centered on the Senate side, with the Democratic leader, Chuck Schumer, and Republican leader Mitch McConnell, as key figures in the negotiations. The current proposal is a one-year "continuing resolution" (C.R.) that temporarily funds parts of the government at their current levels.

Some Hill Republicans suggested that President Trump should push for a shorter, two-week C.R., delaying the funding battle until early January, allowing Republicans to potentially shift some of the blame onto the incoming Democratic House majority. However, the president reportedly did not favor this option.

Early this week, the White House signaled that the president was not in an accommodating mood, with hard-liner Stephen Miller appearing on "Face the Nation" to state that a shutdown was "absolutely" on the table without wall funding. President Trump also tweeted that a wall was essential for "good Border Security."

By Tuesday, the president had reversed course, seeking a way out of the impasse without appearing to cave. Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders stated that he would be open to a bipartisan compromise, which included $1.6 billion for fortifying existing barriers, with the remaining $5 billion potentially siphoned from other agencies. This proposal prompted immediate pushback from Democrats.

Senate appropriators had previously agreed on a spending plan that contained an extra $1 billion for what Democrats deemed an immigration "slush fund." Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell offered a spending plan containing this additional funding, but Schumer and Pelosi rejected it.

Lawmakers from both parties suggest that a continuing resolution is still the most likely way forward. However, the specifics of what the president would agree to remain unclear, with Press Secretary Sanders providing no clarity at a Tuesday afternoon press briefing.

Regardless of his plan, it appears that the president is seeking to extract maximum drama from this government funding standoff. These standoffs align with his belief that negotiations and life are a constant battle of wills. He thrives on making the other side blink and is eager to signal his willingness to take drastic measures to get his way, even if he ultimately capitulates.

Shutdown showdowns provide fertile ground for President Trump, as they pit him against a political establishment that, as he sees it, obstinately refuses to pay proper deference to his leadership. He has repeatedly expressed frustration with Congress' unwillingness to defer to his decisions. Threatening to cause chaos, such as furloughing or withholding paychecks from hundreds of thousands of workers, allows him to exact a cathartic form of retribution, reminding lawmakers of his ability to make their lives uncomfortable.

Title: Clinton Campaign Aims to Maintain Momentum Amidst FBI Email Investigation

Article:

In the final week of the U.S. presidential race, Hillary Clinton's campaign is focusing on maintaining its momentum, emphasizing the extensive ground game and get-out-the-vote efforts that have been established over the past 18 months. The sudden revival of Clinton's private email server as a campaign issue, following an announcement by FBI Director James Comey regarding newly discovered emails potentially pertinent to the probe, is being viewed as a test of the campaign's infrastructure and message.

Clinton, while campaigning in Kent, Ohio, on Monday, downplayed the investigation, stating that most voters have already made up their minds on the email issue. She emphasized that the focus should be on choosing the next president and commander-in-chief of the United States.

The Clinton campaign has built a robust ground game across battleground states, dedicating significant time and resources to early voting and Get Out the Vote campaigns. Notable celebrities such as Jennifer Lopez, Marc Anthony, Katy Perry, and Jay-Z have been enlisted to aid these efforts.

Early voting data show that over 3.5 million people have already voted in Florida, making up nearly one-quarter of all registered voters in the state, with Democrats outpacing 2012 vote-by-mail numbers. In Nevada, where nearly one-quarter of registered voters have already cast their ballot, Democrats are outpacing Republicans by nearly 30,000. Clinton aides attribute this early voter turnout, particularly among Hispanic voters, as evidence of the campaign's ground game success.

However, the campaign is monitoring any potential damage from Comey's announcement. In some swing states, aides acknowledge that the FBI's renewed probe has created some volatility with voters. There is anecdotal evidence of Clinton volunteers fielding questions about the FBI's investigation while door-knocking over the weekend. On the flip side, the campaign has also seen evidence of Democrats who are now more eager to vote for Clinton as a way to rebuke the FBI.

Since Friday, Clinton and her aides have maintained that Comey's action is unprecedented this close to an election and that there is nothing new to be discovered. Clinton has repeatedly stated that while she regrets using a private server, the FBI simply has "no case."

The campaign is also pressing Comey, with top campaign officials criticizing his decision not to publicly comment on the Trump campaign's potential ties to alleged efforts by Russia to meddle with the U.S. election. Trump, in contrast, has been lauding Comey and his announcement.

Throughout the campaign, Clinton has relentlessly attacked Trump's temperament and readiness to be president, a strategy that has been in place since Trump became the GOP nominee. In the final days before the election, Clinton aides are confident that voters have had ample time to digest the contrasting choices presented in the election.

Title: Trump Rallies Supporters in Pennsylvania, Mocks Impeachment Process as "Impeachment Lite"

Article:

President Donald Trump addressed a rally in Hershey, Pennsylvania on Tuesday, mocking the ongoing impeachment inquiry as "impeachment lite" and asserting that the process has boosted his approval ratings. The visit followed a significant day at the U.S. Capitol, where House Democrats unveiled articles of impeachment and signaled their support for the United States-Mexico-Canada trade agreement (USMCA).

Trump's comments came less than a week after an early departure from a NATO meeting in London following the release of a video depicting world leaders gossiping about him. In 2016, Trump won Pennsylvania, the first Republican presidential candidate to do so since 1988, by garnering support in rural areas and among working-class whites. The state, along with Michigan and Wisconsin, is expected to be a key battleground in the 2020 presidential election.

House Democrats unveiled two articles of impeachment on Tuesday: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. They allege that Trump put U.S. elections and national security at risk by asking Ukraine to investigate his political rival, former Vice President Joe Biden, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination. They also claim Trump impeded Congress' investigation into the matter.

If the House votes to impeach Trump, the case moves to the Senate, where a two-thirds vote is required for conviction. With Republicans holding 53 of 100 seats, it is unlikely that Republican senators would cross party lines and vote to remove Trump from office.

During the rally, Trump also addressed the long-awaited release of the Justice Department report into the 2016 Russia investigation. The inspector general found that the FBI was justified in opening its investigation into ties between the Trump presidential campaign and Russia, and that the FBI did not act with political bias, despite "serious performance failures" up the bureau's chain of command.

Trump claimed Tuesday that the inspector general's report detailed "outrageous, scandalous, and unprecedented abuses of power." He also called FBI agents "scum" and said they had "destroyed the lives of people that are great people." Trump also mentioned his anticipation for a report from John Durham, the prosecutor whom Attorney General William Barr has selected to investigate how intelligence was gathered in the Russia probe.

Trump stated, "A regular president would be under the table, thumb in mouth, saying: 'Take me home, Mommy. This is enough for me.'"

Title: Breitbart's Traffic Decline: A Comparative Analysis

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2016 U.S. presidential election, right-wing news outlet Breitbart News, with Steve Bannon as its White House chief strategist, was poised for significant growth, aiming to become a media powerhouse with unparalleled access and a passionate audience. In January 2017, Breitbart boasted of its impressive web traffic, ranking as the 45th most visited site in the United States, surpassing Fox News, Huffington Post, Washington Post, and Buzzfeed, according to Alexa.com.

However, recent data suggests a different story. As of May 26, 2017, Breitbart's rank has dropped significantly, with Fox News, Huffington Post, Buzzfeed, and Washington Post all outperforming it. According to Alexa.com, Fox News is the 64th most-trafficked site in the country, while Huffington Post is at 60, Buzzfeed is at 50, and The Washington Post is at 41.

Comparative analysis of Breitbart's global rankings against other news sites it has compared itself to, such as Fox News and Buzzfeed, shows an unusually steep decline in traffic. ComScore estimated that Breitbart had nearly 23 million unique visitors during the month of November 2016, but only drew 10.7 million in April 2017, a 53% drop. Last month, the site had fewer visitors than it did in April 2016, when 12.3 million people visited the site.

The decline in Breitbart's traffic is not unique to the right-wing media landscape. Other conservative media sites, such as National Review Online, Infowars.com, The Daily Caller, and Drudge Report, have also experienced traffic slumps. Notably, over the last week, as President Trump was engulfed in the Comey scandal, Fox News's viewership dropped to third place behind CNN and MSNBC for the first time in 17 years.

The decline in Breitbart's traffic, as measured by Alexa, is peculiar, with a graph that shows a high plateau followed by a precipitous drop around April 30, Trump's 100-day mark. An Alexa customer representative suggested that this could be due to Breitbart enabling, then disabling, Alexa's certified-results feature, which temporarily created an apples-to-oranges comparison with sites that don't enable the feature, like The Washington Post.

In conclusion, while other conservative media sites have experienced declines in traffic in recent months, Breitbart's decline appears to be more pronounced. The reasons for this decline are not entirely clear, but it is evident that Breitbart's web traffic has significantly decreased since its post-election high.

Title: Vice President's Office Disputes Interpretation of Trump Administration's Immigrant Remarks

Article:

The office of Vice President Mike Pence has disputed a characterization of comments made by Marc Short, the Vice President's chief of staff, regarding President Donald Trump's tweets criticizing four Democratic congresswomen of color. In an email to a journalist, Darin Miller, the deputy press secretary for Vice President Pence, argued that the journalist had misconstrued Short's comments about Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao and Representative Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.).

Miller's email, sent after the publication of a roundup of responses to President Trump's tweets, stated that Short's comments were not intended to compare Chao and Omar's immigration stories, but rather to highlight Chao's story as an example of what the President supports: a legal immigrant who worked hard, assimilated, and is dedicated to giving back and serving her country.

However, the email also stated that Omar, unlike Chao, seems content to criticize America at every turn, instead of trying to fix problems she sees. This contrast was drawn by Omar's opposition to the overwhelmingly bipartisan emergency border aid bill, which provided humanitarian aid for asylum seekers.

The truth is there isn't a meaningful difference between Chao and Omar's immigration stories. Both immigrated legally to the country and now serve in the federal government, albeit with different agendas. As of Wednesday, the saga of Trump's racist tweets is continuing to play out in Congress.

Title: Cruz Campaign Leverages Santa Claus at Minnesota Rally to Collect Voter Data

Article:

In a unique twist during the first night of Senator Ted Cruz's seven-day, 12-city tour, a Santa Claus made an appearance at a reception hall in Minnesota. The campaign, known for its data-driven approach, used the Santa to collect voter information from attendees.

Visitors were greeted by the Santa, who posed for photos with children and adults. To retrieve these photos, visitors were handed cards directing them to Mr. Cruz's website, where they were asked to provide their names, email addresses, and ZIP codes.

Jeff Roe, Mr. Cruz's campaign manager, explained the campaign's strategy, stating, "The Santa's optically good anyway. It's a Christmas tour, it makes total sense. But you still have to run a campaign when these are over. You can't just come out and do rallies and have nothing left when you leave except for a bunch of uneaten cookies. Now we're going to have living data of people. They'll have an experience they'll remember forever."

The campaign had been brainstorming ways to connect with supporters since an August swing through several southern states. About 19,000 people attended 13 rallies during that trip, but the campaign was disappointed not to collect more information from them. Past efforts to amass voter data through photography had been too complicated and time-consuming, according to Mr. Roe.

The Santa at the event was Red Bartholomew, a 64-year-old supporter with past performances at Tea Party events, fund-raisers, and church functions. Mr. Bartholomew was contacted by the campaign through his work with "constitutional-minded people," noting that he was a member of Overpasses for America, a group that flies flags and posts signs along pedestrian overpasses.

Mr. Bartholomew, who is also known as "Liberty Claus," seemed to have found a kindred spirit in Mr. Cruz. In an interview, he summarized his worldview, described an alternative character he has portrayed, and lamented the burdensome Santa industry regulations that had in the past hamstrung his work.

Attendees at the rally seemed broadly grateful for the Santa's presence, though some snapped photos on their phones and left before receiving a "photo number" and a card directing them to the campaign's website. Mary Kay Storhaug, a 45-year-old attendee from Andover, Minnesota, said Mr. Bartholomew provided a welcome distraction for her children during the rally.

Mr. Roe stated that the photos were part of building "a lasting relationship" with voters, particularly in states like Minnesota that often receive little attention from candidates until just before voting begins. "When they do engage with a presidential campaign," Mr. Roe said, "I want it to be a meaningful engagement that lasts for hopefully their whole life and our whole life."

At least one attendee seemed wary of letting his information reach the wrong hands. Mr. Bartholomew, when asked to provide a phone number where he could be reached, said he would not answer his landline unless a caller left a message. "I have to screen my calls," he said, "for a lot of different reasons."

Title: Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson's Evolution in the Political Landscape

Article:

In 2010, George Will, a renowned political commentator, described Wisconsin businessman Ron Johnson as the embodiment of the Tea Party movement. Johnson, a manufacturer of plastic products from Oshkosh, was a political neophyte who rose to political prominence through Tea Party rallies across Wisconsin, driven by his opposition to Obamacare.

At a Madison Tea Party rally, Johnson expressed his support for conservative values, stating, "We need to elect true conservatives, not politicians but citizen legislators, people who actually listen to us. People who will tell the truth and in the end will do what actually needs to be done."

Johnson, a self-proclaimed social conservative, is known for his admiration for the famous atheist Ayn Rand. He has criticized Obamacare as the "greatest assault on freedom in my lifetime." In a video interview for the Ayn Rand Institute, he expressed concern over what he perceived as American suffering from Stockholm syndrome.

However, Johnson's definition of freedom primarily revolves around economic issues. His stance on government overreach in non-economic matters is minimal, aligning him more with traditional conservatives than libertarian-leaning figures like Rand Paul.

Recently, Johnson criticized the Tea Party movement at the Republican Leadership Conference, stating, "You can be very doctrinaire, you can demand purity, but in the end if you want to advance policy that you want enacted, you have to win elections." He acknowledged the influence of Tea Party groups but emphasized the importance of winning elections to enact desired policies.

Johnson's comments about "groups" leading the Tea Party astray have been interpreted as a reference to organizations like Americans for Prosperity, a Tea Party group closely associated with the Koch brothers. Reports suggest that Johnson remains close to the Koch brothers and is often referred to as their "model senator."

The truth is that there is ample GOP Big Donor money to go around, making it a non-zero-sum game. However, it appears that Johnson, the Tea Party's favored senator, may be tasked with maintaining control over the Tea Party grassroots and reassuring major donors.

The future of Johnson's political career remains uncertain, with some questioning his ability to navigate the complexities of Washington politics. However, as a Tea Party favorite and a self-proclaimed capitalist hero, he may be the best the movement has to offer at this time.

Title: Sequester Impasse: Neither Side Willing to Budge as Americans Feel the Cuts Remain Uncertain

Article:

The ongoing sequester, a series of $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts, remains unresolved as both President Barack Obama and congressional Republicans show no signs of compromise. The sequester, designed in 2011 to be so severe that it would discourage its implementation, has become a point of contention between the two parties.

House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) admitted in a recent interview that the full impact of the sequester is not fully understood.
