Republicans have accepted sequestration as the only guaranteed method to reduce government spending, and there is speculation that the actual impact may not be as severe as anticipated.

Congress could potentially pass legislation to mitigate the impact of the sequester, such as granting department heads the ability to target the cuts more precisely. A Republican-sponsored bill aimed at this goal failed in the Senate last week, but a Senate Democratic leadership aide suggested that the bill could be rewritten to attract Democratic support, particularly from representatives of military states who would be concerned about the impact on their constituents. House Republicans are also planning to vote on a bill that aims to make the budget cuts more manageable for the military and veterans.

However, administration officials argue that even added flexibility would not significantly alter the overall impact of the sequester. White House economics adviser Gene Sperling stated that the harsh spending cuts over a short period would still result in a loss of 750,000 jobs, as projected by the Congressional Budget Office.

If the sequester remains in place until the end of the fiscal year in September, it would mark a temporary pause in the emergency budget wars that have dominated Washington since Republicans took control of the House in 2011. The debt limit would not need to be raised until May at the earliest, and it could potentially stretch until August, according to calculations by top-level aides. The prevailing wisdom in the Capitol is that House Republicans cannot demand concessions in exchange for extending the country's borrowing authority, as they lost that right when they agreed to lift the ceiling in January without insisting on an equal amount of cuts.

Title: Donald Trump and Jeb Bush Tied in Reuters-Ipsos Poll for 2016 Republican Presidential Nomination

Article:

In a recent Reuters-Ipsos poll released on Saturday, real estate developer and 2016 Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has tied with former Florida Governor Jeb Bush for the lead in the race for the Republican presidential nomination. The poll, conducted online among self-identified Republicans, showed Trump with the support of 15.8 percent of respondents, compared to 16.1 percent for Bush.

The poll also showed New Jersey Governor Chris Christie in third place with 9.5 percent, followed by Kentucky Senator Rand Paul with 8.1 percent, surgeon and author Ben Carson with 7.2 percent, and Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker with 5.8 percent.

However, when respondents were given a choice of three candidates - Bush, Trump, or Florida Senator Marco Rubio - Bush had a comfortable lead at 42 percent, compared to 28.4 percent for Trump and 20 percent for Rubio.

In the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton remained in front with the support of 48.3 percent of self-identified Democrats polled, with Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders continuing to inch up, at 22.9 percent, and Vice President Joe Biden, who has not entered the race, at 10.7 percent.

The controversy surrounding Trump's immigration comments has dominated news coverage of the Republican campaign in recent weeks, with numerous businesses, including NBC Universal, Univision, Macy's, Serta, and NASCAR, cutting ties with Trump since he accused Mexico of sending rapists and other criminals into the United States in his June 16 speech announcing his candidacy. Trump also stated in a July 6 speech that illegal border-crossers from Mexico are carrying "tremendous infectious disease."

The poll showed Trump's support climbing in the wake of the immigration controversy, with the poll on June 30 showing Bush at 16.9 percent and Trump at 12.8 percent. A hard line against illegal immigration may find a receptive audience in Republican primary voters, with U.S. conservatives often accusing President Barack Obama of doing too little to secure America's border with Mexico.

Trump has also come under fire from some of his Republican rivals, including Bush, who has accused Trump of making "ugly comments" that are not reflective of the Republican Party. "Everybody has a belief that we should control our borders," Bush said last week. "But to make these extraordinarily kind of ugly comments is not reflective of the Republican Party. Trump is wrong on this."

The Reuters/Ipsos poll of the Republican race was conducted among 404 self-identified Republicans age 18 or over from July 6-10, with a credibility interval of 5.7 percentage points. The poll of the Democratic race was conducted among 504 self-identified Democrats age 18 or over over the same time period, with a credibility interval of 5.1 percentage points.

Title: The Negative Impact of Trade Wars and Recessions on Economy and Society

Article:

The article discusses the negative effects of trade wars and economic recessions on society and the economy. It argues that trade wars are not beneficial and are not easy to win, citing potential job losses, business failures, and increased rates of mental health issues such as anxiety, depression, and suicide.

The article mentions that the past few recessions in the United States have led to "jobless recoveries," where the labor market struggles for years even after GDP starts growing. This is attributed to companies using recessions to adopt "labor-saving" technology, which could lead to job losses in low-skill, routine-based jobs.

The article also highlights the potential concentration of pain from long-term unemployment among the poorest workers, which could undo the recent progress in wage growth for the poor. The deplorable treatment of migrants at border facilities is also mentioned as a moral stain on the Trump administration, and the article suggests that a global downturn could worsen the living conditions of Central American workers, who are the largest trading partners of the region.

Title: Beto O'Rourke Releases 10 Years of Tax Returns, Reports $370,412 Income in 2017

Article:

Former Texas Representative Beto O'Rourke has joined the growing list of 2020 presidential candidates releasing their tax returns. O'Rourke and his wife, Amy Sanders O'Rourke, who filed joint returns for 2008 through 2017, reported a total income of $370,412 in 2017, the latest year reported.

The couple's largest annual income in the 10-year period was $496,280 in 2009, when they reported a $272,775 gain from an investment partnership. Their lowest reported income in the 10-year period was $163,539 in 2012, the year after O'Rourke left the El Paso City Council, and just before he took his seat as a United States congressman in January 2013.

In 2017, the O'Rourkes reported selling Stanton Street Technology, the El Paso Internet web design firm started by Beto O'Rourke about 20 years ago, for $300,000, making a net gain of $195,627 after costs. However, they ended up losing $3,000 after all capital gains and losses were calculated for that year, according to their income tax return.

O'Rourke earned $162,211 for serving in Congress in 2017, according to his tax return. His wife, who works for the Council on Regional Economic Expansion and Educational Development (CREEED), an El Paso business leaders group aimed at improving education levels in the El Paso area, reported $53,364 in income. She is the group's Choose to Excel director, according to its website.

The O'Rourkes paid $81,019 in federal income tax in 2017. They paid $88,798 in 2009, when they had their largest reported income. Other Democratic presidential candidates have released their tax returns, including Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders and California Senator Kamala Harris.

Sanders' 2018 return showed he and his wife, Jane, earned more than $550,000, including $133,000 in income from his Senate salary and $391,000 in sales of his book, "Our Revolution: A Future to Believe In," according to the Associated Press. He made more than $1 million in 2017 from his U.S. Senate salary and sales and royalties from his books.

Harris' 2018 returns showed she and her husband had an adjusted gross joint income of about $1.9 million last year, The AP reported. The O'Rourkes plan to release their 2018 tax return "as soon as possible after they are filed," according to a campaign news release. This follows his commitment to increasing accountability and transparency, the campaign reported.

Title: Federal Judge Releases 400 Pages of Trump University "Playbooks," Detailing Sales Tactics

Article:

A federal judge has made public more than 400 pages of documents from Trump University, detailing the sales tactics used to sell high-priced real estate courses. The documents, which are central to a class-action lawsuit against Trump University in California, were released by US district court judge Gonzalo Curiel on Tuesday.

The documents describe how Trump University staff were instructed to target prospective students' financial weaknesses to encourage them to sign up for a $34,995 Gold Elite three-day package. The courses are now subject to legal proceedings from unhappy clients.

The documents contain an undated "personal message" from Donald Trump to new enrollees at the school: "Only doers get rich. I know that in these three packed days, you will learn everything to make a million dollars within the next 12 months."

The documents were released despite repeated public attacks from Trump, who had fought to keep the details secret. Judge Curiel ruled that the documents were in the public interest now that Trump is "the front-runner in the Republican nomination in the 2016 presidential race, and has placed the integrity of these court proceedings at issue."

Trump hit back, calling Curiel a "hater," a "total disgrace," and "biased." "I have a judge who is a hater of Donald Trump. A hater. He's a hater," Trump said at a rally near the courthouse in San Diego. "His name is Gonzalo Curiel. And he is not doing the right thing...[He] happens to be, we believe, Mexican."

Curiel, who is Hispanic, is American and was born in Indiana. Trump went on to attack Curiel further on Twitter on Monday and at a press conference in New York on Monday.

The playbook contains long sections telling Trump U team members how to identify buyers and push them to sign up for the most expensive package, and to put the cost on their credit cards. "If they can afford the gold elite, don't allow them to think about doing anything besides the gold elite," the document states.

If potential students hesitate, teachers are told to read a script encouraging them to be honest with themselves and fix their broken financial plans. Trump University staff are instructed in how to persuade students to put the cost of the course on their credit cards, even if they have just battled to pay off debts.

The documents also reveal that Trump University staff were told to spend lunch breaks in sign-up seminars "planting seeds" in potential students' minds about how their lives won't improve unless they join the program. They are also told to ask students personal questions to discover weaknesses that could be exploited to help seal the deal.

New York attorney general Eric Schneiderman, who has also sued Trump University, renewed his attacks on Trump on Tuesday. "You are not allowed to protect the trade secrets of a three-card Monte game," Schneiderman said ahead of the document's release. "If you look at the facts of this case, this shows someone who was absolutely shameless in his willingness to lie to people, to say whatever it took to induce them into his phony seminars."

Title: Presidential Debate: Obama and Romney Clash in Final Showdown

Article:

In the final presidential debate of the 2012 election cycle, President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, engaged in a more subdued and less confrontational exchange than their previous encounter, held in Boca Raton, Florida. The debate, the last before a two-week sprint of campaigning, focused primarily on foreign policy, with the candidates' differences on display despite the less contentious setting.

Romney accused Obama of overseeing a decline in American influence, citing Iran as an example of emboldened enemies. Obama, in response, characterized Romney as "all over the map" on foreign affairs, alleging that the Republican nominee's foreign policy proposals were either incorrect or similar to the president's own policies, but with a louder approach.

Romney, who has seen a surge in national and battleground polls after trailing Obama for much of the campaign, at times seemed to reprimand Obama for being too aggressive. In one instance, when Obama pointedly stated that Romney had been wrong every time he offered an opinion, Romney responded, "Attacking me is not an agenda."

Both candidates found areas of agreement, including ruling out military action in Syria, continuing to support sanctions against Iran, and supporting the withdrawal timetable in Afghanistan. Romney rejected Obama's suggestion that he would revert to the foreign policies of the previous administration, and he also dismissed Obama's claims that Romney would be eager to engage in war with countries like Iran.

Romney's main criticism of Obama was that he had not provided a clear example of American leadership on the world stage, whether in Syria, Iran, or Russia. Obama, in turn, sought to portray Romney as unsteady and out of his depth on foreign policy matters. The president employed sharp, at times sarcastic, language to cast Romney as inexperienced.

The debate touched on the Libya terror attacks only briefly, with Romney criticizing Obama's response to the Benghazi incident and Obama accusing Romney of focusing on the wrong geopolitical threats. The candidates also sparred over Al Qaeda, with Obama reminding Romney of his previous statements downplaying the threat of Al Qaeda, and Romney asserting that Al Qaeda remained an enormous threat despite Obama's claims that the terror group was on the path to defeat.

On the issue of Iran, both candidates insisted that, under their administration, Iran would not obtain a nuclear weapon, and that the U.S. would stand by Israel if it were attacked. Romney, however, accused Obama of wasting four years while Iran moved closer to nuclear weapon capability, while Obama defended his efforts to unite the international community against Iran.

The 90-minute debate at Lynn University, moderated by CBS News' Bob Schieffer, offered the last opportunity for either candidate to significantly impact the race before Election Day. The debates this month have been among the most consequential in modern campaign history, with Romney entering the debates as the slight underdog in most polls but surging since his opening performance. An NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll on Sunday showed the president and Romney tied at 47 percent nationally, while a Suffolk University survey released Monday showed the two tied at 47 percent in the crucial swing state of Ohio. Other recent polls have given Obama a slight edge.

Title: President Obama's Economy: Net Job Creator According to New Data

Article:

In a recent development, data released on Thursday indicates that President Obama may now be a net job creator. Following his inauguration in 2009, the U.S. economy experienced a job loss of approximately 4.3 million. However, new figures show that 4.4 million jobs have been added back since then.

Since early 2010, jobs have gradually returned, particularly in professional services, health care, and manufacturing. As of August, the Labor Department had indicated about 4 million jobs had been recovered overall. These figures are subject to frequent revision as the Labor Department receives more complete data over time.

On Thursday, the Labor Department revised the numbers again, using unemployment insurance records that employers are required to file. Based on this data, the government now believes it under-counted jobs created in much of 2011 by around 386,000. These preliminary figures could still be slightly adjusted in February.

If accurate, these figures mean the economy has recovered 4.4 million jobs since early 2010, enough to fully account for the jobs lost during Obama's first term. In fact, Obama would be ahead by exactly 125,000 jobs.

President Obama is unlikely to boast about this on the campaign trail. In a blog post on Thursday, his top economic adviser, Alan Krueger, stated, "The jobs recovery over the last 2.5 years has been a bit stronger than initially reported, although much work remains to be done to return to full employment."

Meanwhile, the Republican nominee, Mitt Romney, still has ample material to criticize Obama on economic issues. "President Obama's administration promised, with the passage of the stimulus, that unemployment would currently be at 5.4% with 9 million more people working," said Romney campaign spokeswoman Andrea Saul, referring to a 2009 report by Obama's then chief economic adviser, Christina Romer.

"With unemployment at 8% or higher for the 43rd consecutive month and 23 million Americans struggling for work, President Obama's policies have failed miserably by his own standards," Saul added. It is important to note that the jobs decline started before Obama entered office, and employment is still far below 2007 levels.

Hiring has barely kept pace with population growth, and that's why the unemployment rate is still stuck at 8.1%. A survey of households shows the U.S. population has grown 3.8% since Obama entered office, but jobs have only grown by 1.5% over the same time period. About 12.5 million Americans were still counted as unemployed in August.

Title: Former Obama Administration Officials Criticize Trump's Decision to Withdraw from Iran Nuclear Deal

Article:

In response to President Trump's announcement of the United States' withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal, also known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), former Obama administration officials have expressed criticism and concern.

Former United Nations Ambassador Samantha Power tweeted, "I will never forget the dark cloud that hung over the White House in the years Iran was advancing nuclear program & Obama was briefed on all the risks of using military force. Trump has demolished America's credibility & paved the way for Iran to re-start its nuclear program."

Ben Rhodes, a former Obama national security aide and amateur-turned-professional fiction writer, tweeted, "One tragicomic element of Trump's presidency is that the more he tries to tear down Obama's legacy, the bigger he makes Obama look."

Former Secretary of State John Kerry, who has been traveling the world in an attempt to conduct his own personal foreign policy on behalf of the Iranian government, stated, "Today's announcement weakens our security, breaks America's word, isolates us from our European allies, puts Israel at greater risk, empowers Iran's hardliners, and reduces our global leverage to address Tehran's misbehavior."

President Obama himself stated, "Walking away from the JCPOA turns our back on America's closest allies."

In response to these statements, it is important to note that Iran has been actively involved in terrorism in Yemen and Syria, sponsoring the takeover of Lebanon by the terrorist group Hezbollah, funding the Palestinian terror group Hamas, and developing long-range ballistic missiles while leading chants saying "Death to America." The Middle East has been a region of conflict and instability during Obama's presidency, and the situation has not improved significantly since then.

It is also important to clarify that the Iranian government is currently led by hardliners, and the JCPOA did not alleviate the possibility of an Iranian nuclear program, as some have suggested. The deal explicitly paved the way for an Iranian nuclear program free and clear of consequences from the international order. Furthermore, the Middle East allies opposed the deal and are celebrating its end.

In conclusion, the withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal has sparked criticism from former Obama administration officials, who have expressed concern about the potential consequences of the decision. However, it is important to consider the context and the actions of the Iranian government in the Middle East, as well as the fact that the deal did not alleviate the possibility of an Iranian nuclear program or improve the situation in the Middle East.

Title: Bernie Sanders' Proposal to Allow Convicted Felons to Vote While Incarcerated Sparks Controversy Among Democratic Presidential Candidates

Article:

In a recent development, Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders has endorsed the idea of allowing convicted felons to vote while they are still in prison. This stance has sparked a debate among the Democratic candidates, with some expressing support, while others have rejected the idea.

During a CNN town hall event, Sanders argued that this stance is a matter of voting rights, implying that opposing the idea could be seen as an endorsement of GOP-backed voter suppression efforts. However, his proposal has been met with criticism from some of his fellow candidates.

For instance, Pete Buttigieg flatly rejected the notion, earning strong applause from the Democratic audience. Kamala Harris, on the other hand, initially expressed openness to the idea but later walked it back after realizing the potential backlash.

The idea of allowing incarcerated individuals to vote has been met with skepticism and criticism from various quarters. Saikat Chakrabarti, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's chief of staff, has advocated for the idea, questioning why incarcerated people, who are often the most affected by unjust laws, should not have a say in electing people to change them.

However, the argument against this proposal is that the right to vote is a privilege granted to eligible U.S. citizens. As Guy Benson, a political commentator, pointed out, the violent vs. non-violent felon dichotomy is problematic, and treating people convicted of "unjust" laws more generously is subjective and unworkable.

The argument is that the right to vote is a privilege that is forfeited by individuals who commit felonies, as they are, by definition, not law-abiding. Convicted felons are deprived of various rights, including freedom of speech, the right to bear arms, and the right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures. By committing a crime, they forfeit their ability to vote for lawmakers while serving out their sentences.

While some argue for the restoration of felons' voting rights upon release, Sanders' proposal to allow voting from behind bars is seen as a far cry from that. Sanders openly favors the idea that the Boston Marathon bomber should be voting from inside prison walls, as should convicted murderers, rapists, child molesters, and others. This proposal has been criticized as wrong and unpopular, with some suggesting that it could be used as a ready-made attack ad against Sanders in a general election.

In conclusion, the proposal to allow convicted felons to vote while incarcerated has sparked a heated debate among the Democratic presidential candidates. While some argue that it is a matter of voting rights, others believe that it is a privilege that is forfeited by individuals who commit felonies. The debate is ongoing, and it remains to be seen how this issue will play out in the upcoming elections.

Title: Obama Administration Purchases Illinois Prison for Overcrowding Relief, Not Guantanamo Housing, Officials Say

Article:

The Obama administration has announced its intention to purchase the Thomson Correctional Center, an under-used state prison located 150 miles west of Chicago, Illinois. The move is aimed at alleviating overcrowding in high-security prisons and creating jobs, according to administration officials.

However, some Republican lawmakers, including Virginia Rep. Frank Wolf, have expressed concerns that the purchase could potentially facilitate the transfer of Guantanamo detainees to Illinois. Wolf, who chairs a key House subcommittee overseeing the sale, claimed on Tuesday that the Obama administration could still carry out its plan by moving prisoners from another federal prison to Thomson and then using the facility to house Guantanamo detainees.

Administration officials have denied these claims, insisting that the Thomson Correctional Center will not be used as a new home for Guantanamo inmates. Illinois Democratic Sen. Dick Durbin and Gov. Pat Quinn first announced the $165 million purchase. In a statement, Durbin said, "This historic action will lead to the creation of hundreds of construction jobs and over 1,000 permanent jobs at this federal facility."

Opposition to the transfer of prisoners stateside has been met with a fierce backlash among some lawmakers, who worry it would pose a security risk. House Appropriations Committee Chairman Hal Rogers, R-Ky., warned his committee would oppose the purchase. Rogers stated, "The Obama administration has been trying for years to open Thompson prison in order to transfer terrorists from Guantanamo Bay onto U.S. soil."

The Thomson Correctional Center was built in 2001 but was not fully opened due to budget troubles. The Obama administration and the Federal Bureau of Prisons have stated that the purchase is strictly for the purpose of easing overcrowding, not for housing Guantanamo detainees.

Title: Clinton Takes Aim at Trump in National Security Speech, Aims to Appeal to Moderate Republicans

Article:

In a departure from some expectations, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton delivered a scathing speech on Tuesday, focusing on her national security stance rather than attempting to woo supporters of her rival Bernie Sanders ahead of the California primary. The speech, billed as a national security address, lacked new proposals but was a forceful rebuke of presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump.

Clinton, in San Diego, a city with a significant military presence, presented herself as a defender of American values and a steady commander-in-chief who believed in America as an exceptional country. She criticized Trump's views on American strength, quoting him as calling the military a "disaster" and referring to the United States as a "third-world country."

Clinton was introduced by the spouse of an active duty naval officer and spoke with 20 US flags prominently displayed behind her. Although still fighting a primary, Clinton is clearly making a play for independent and Republican voters concerned about Trump's erratic foreign policy pronouncements, as well as his statements on women, Mexican immigrants, and Muslims.

In late April, during her speech after her victory in the Pennsylvania primary, Clinton appealed to "thoughtful" Republicans, independents, and Democrats to stand together against divisive candidates on the Republican side. Although House speaker Paul Ryan finally endorsed Donald Trump on Thursday after weeks of hesitation, prominent Republicans are not rushing to back the presumptive Republican nominee just yet. At least nine Republican governors, and a number of senators, are steering clear from their party's convention in July.

There has also been a trickle of lifelong, prominent Republicans who openly say they will vote for a Democrat for the first time in their life in November. Clinton's message on American global leadership may not resonate widely with the GOP base, which is turning more isolationist, but it is finding an audience with many moderates and foreign policy thinkers.

On Twitter, the hashtag #RepublicansforHillary was trending for a day this week, after an interview on US cable TV with a former Reagan administration official, Doug Elmets, who said that "four years of Hillary Clinton is better than one day with Donald Trump as president." Widely quoted in the US media was retired army colonel Peter Mansoor, a former aide to General David Petraeus during the Iraq war.

Mr. Mansoor said he would be voting for Clinton not because he had converted to being a Democrat, but because Trump was dangerous. Elections are not won on Twitter and a handful of Republicans won't tip the balance in November, but the chatter on social media is bringing out voices from the Republican party silent during the raucous days of the Republican primaries and raising questions about a ripple effect.

Clinton campaign aides were not willing to discuss their strategy to appeal to moderate Republicans, especially while the Democratic primary is still underway. But they acknowledged there were Republicans, particularly those concerned with foreign policy issues, who could support her.

Vin Weber, a Republican strategist and former congressman who supported Jeb Bush in the primaries, said Clinton should enlist Republican advisors. "If she were campaigning like her husband, she would move to the center, and try to get votes that are not locked up by the Republican Party," said Mr. Weber, who said he was still doing some hard thinking about how to vote in November.

Democratic pollster Stanley Greenberg says a recent poll shows moderate Republicans represent a "stunning 31% of the GOP base," what he describes as the alienated third of the party. "They are disproportionately college graduates in a white, working-class party, and they are socially liberal," said Greenberg.

On marriage equality, climate change, or abortion rights, those GOP moderates are more in sync with the Democratic party. The poll, conducted in February when all the Republican candidates were still in the race, showed that 10% of Republican moderates would vote for Clinton.

Kori Schake, a fellow at the conservative Hoover Institution, said Clinton's challenge would be to convince anti-Trump Republicans they actually need to vote for her - not simply refrain from voting for Trump. "Republican refuseniks are not enough to make a difference," she said.

Ms. Schake said presenting Trump as dangerous was an effective strategy, but it was also key for Clinton to frame her pitch in economic terms. She had to press home the damage she believed a Trump presidency would cause to the economy - but to do so would require moving decisively to the right of Sanders, and risk alienating many in her own party.

"I've just come back from Cuba, and I've seen what a Sanders economy looks like," said Ms. Schake. Clinton will seek to unify the Democratic party ahead of the convention, but to win those moderates Republicans, she will now need to present herself not just as the candidate of her party's middle but of America's center.

Title: President Obama to Discuss Economic Opportunity and Poverty at Georgetown Summit

Article:

In a three-day Catholic-Evangelical leadership summit on poverty, President Barack Obama will discuss his belief that recent high-profile confrontations between police and African Americans are often a result of a lack of economic opportunity. The summit, held at Georgetown University, is a response to a call from Pope Francis to focus on the issue of poverty.

The President's remarks come after rioting in Baltimore last month in response to the death of a black man who was fatally injured in police custody. In response, President Obama stated that tensions between minority communities and police departments have been simmering for decades in the U.S. He described the situation as a "slow-rolling crisis" that has been ongoing for a long time.

White House Director of Intergovernmental Affairs Jerry Abramson, who is also the former mayor of Louisville, Kentucky, stated that President Obama will talk at the summit about the need to provide more opportunities for urban children. Abramson noted that in America, too many young people are limited by the ZIP code into which they are born.

Since his first day in office, President Obama has worked to address these issues by rebuilding the economy, protecting civil rights, expanding college access, providing tax credits to working families, and targeting more money to high-poverty neighborhoods.

Title: US, Canada Reach Last-Minute Deal on USMCA, Updating NAFTA

Article:

The United States and Canada reached a last-minute deal on Sunday night, agreeing to a framework for a revised trilateral trade agreement known as the USMCA, or the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement. This new agreement is an updated version of the original North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) between the three countries.

In a joint statement issued late Sunday, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland announced the "new, modernized trade agreement" that will "result in freer markets, fairer trade, and robust economic growth in our region." The statement emphasized that the USMCA will "strengthen the middle class, and create good, well-paying jobs and new opportunities for the nearly half billion people who call North America home."

The breakthrough came after a weeks-long impasse and intense negotiations, particularly between the U.S. and Canada. Last week, the U.S. indicated a willingness to move forward with a bilateral deal between the U.S. and Mexico, potentially leaving Canada out. However, on Friday, the U.S. and Mexico agreed to hold off publishing the bilateral text, allowing for negotiations between the U.S. and Canada to continue over the weekend.

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called it a "good day for Canada," while President Donald Trump, in a series of tweets on Monday, congratulated both Canada and Mexico, calling the deal a "great deal for all three countries."

Senior Trump administration officials have hailed the USMCA as a significant victory for the U.S., Canada, and Mexico, with one official stating that the deal "represents fulfillment of one of the president's most important campaign promises."

Key components of the deal include increased access for U.S. farmers to Canada's dairy market, the elimination of Canada's Class 7 milk pricing, and the preservation of NAFTA's Chapter 19, an independent panel for resolving special trade disputes, albeit renumbered in the final USMCA agreement. Canada also secured protections from Section 232 tariffs, but did not receive guarantees over steel and aluminum tariffs, which will be addressed separately.

The USMCA also includes rules of origin for automobiles, new digital trade rules, intellectual property protections, and strengthened labor rules, among other components. The agreement incorporates the components of the bilateral agreement between the U.S. and Mexico.

Title: Strategies for a Potential Republican Presidential Nominee to Win a Majority in the Primary

Article:

In the approaching final stretch of the Republican primary season, a potential nominee for the presidency of the United States is advised to implement several strategies to close the gap between their current support and the 50 percent needed to secure a majority. The following are five key recommendations:

1. Moderate tone and language: The nominee should avoid engaging in personal attacks and confrontations, as these tactics may drive away voters needed to reach 50 percent. Instead, the nominee should choose their battles more carefully and present their arguments in a less belittling and pejorative manner.

2. Accurate facts and information: The nominee should support their statements with accurate facts or anecdotes to demonstrate a strong command of the issues and avoid raising doubts about their substantive knowledge.

3. Increase policy knowledge: The nominee should take the time to learn about various issues and demonstrate a level of fluency and expertise in policy discussions. This will help to address concerns that the nominee lacks the necessary knowledge to occupy the Oval Office.

4. Deliver policy announcements: As an outsider with business experience, the nominee should provide specific policy proposals to address various issues, such as energy policy, corporate welfare, agriculture policy, and others. This will help to demonstrate the nominee's ability to govern and grow support among voters.

5. Avoid citing polls: The nominee should refrain from discussing polls, as this can be perceived as self-centered and may harm their image if they start losing contests. Instead, the nominee should focus on the hopes and dreams of the voters and present themselves as a candidate who can lift up the country, defend it, and grow the economy.

The nominee's success in the primary will depend on their ability to earn a majority, and these strategies are intended to help the nominee achieve that goal. The nominee's best moments demonstrating a more thoughtful approach have been their Super Tuesday news conference at Mar-A-Lago and their policy speech to AIPAC.

Title: Senate's Strategy to Prevent Recess Appointments: Pro-forma Sessions

Article:

In the aftermath of the passing of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has expressed his intention to refuse considering any nominee President Obama may submit to fill the vacancy. In response, President Obama may consider a recess appointment as an end-run option. However, the Republican-led Senate can prevent this by scheduling pro-forma sessions every three days, ensuring they are not in recess and thus, blocking a recess appointment.

According to the Constitution, the House and Senate must meet every three days unless there is an agreement between the two bodies to skip meetings and go on recess. With the ongoing battle over a Supreme Court pick, it is unlikely that the Senate will agree to recess in the near future.

Pro-forma sessions are brief meetings of the House and Senate, lasting only a minute or two, and sometimes even just seconds. During these sessions, the Senate does not conduct any business, and they are often referred to as "gavel-in, gavel-out." No votes are taken, no speeches are made, and few words are uttered at all.

The House and Senate do not consider themselves adjourned or on recess if they are meeting every three days. This strategy, employed by both parties in the past, effectively blocks a recess appointment for the remainder of the president's term.

In 2011 and 2012, when Democrats still controlled the Senate, Republicans controlled the House. The GOP-controlled House refused to agree to an adjournment resolution to block Obama from scuttling a Senate filibuster of his nominees to the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) and Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB). As a result, the House and Senate met every three days.

In early 2012, President Obama made four recess appointments in the window between the three-day pro-forma sessions. However, the Supreme Court later voided these appointments, ruling that the Senate was indeed in session and the appointments were made during the three-day sessions.

In 2003, during the final two years of President George W. Bush's term, the Democrat-controlled Senate met every few days to block Bush from making a recess appointment. In 2003, Senate Republicans criticized minority Democrats for holding up a number of judicial nominations, particularly the nomination of Judge Bill Pryor to the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Georgia. Democrats filibustered Pryor, and during a summertime adjournment, Bush appointed Pryor without the Senate's advice and consent.

Democrats may attempt to force Republicans to take a vote this summer to confirm a nominee, but Republicans can prevent a recess appointment later this year by simply meeting every three days.

Title: Sen. Ted Cruz Exits D.C. Restaurant Amid Protests Over Supreme Court Nominee

Article:

Washington, D.C. - Senator Ted Cruz was driven out of an upscale restaurant on Monday night by a crowd of protesters chanting "We believe survivors." The incident occurred at Fiola, an Italian restaurant in Washington's Penn Quarter neighborhood.

In a video posted on social media, a woman approaches Cruz and his wife Heidi as they prepare to sit at their table. She asks Cruz about his vote on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, as the chant grows louder in the background.

"Hi. I'd love to talk with you about Brett Kavanaugh tonight," the woman says. "I'm a constituent. Love to know what your vote is going to be tonight. I know that you're very close friends with Mr. Kavanaugh. And do you believe survivors, sir?"

Two women, Christine Blasey Ford and Deborah Ramirez, have accused Kavanaugh of past sexual misconduct. Kavanaugh has denied the allegations.

"Senator, I have a right to know what your position is on Brett Kavanaugh," the protester tells Cruz.

The woman then identifies herself as a survivor of sexual assault and mentions the women who have accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault.

"I know that you're close friends with him, could you talk to him about that?" she asks.

At this point, Cruz tells his wife, "Let's go ahead and go," and he rises and begins to put his coat back on. In a second video, more than a dozen people are seen shouting at the couple and recording the incident on their phones as Cruz and his wife try to exit.

Cruz politely says "excuse me" as he tries to work his way through the chanting crowd and adds, "God bless you," as one protester waves a middle finger in his direction.

"Excuse me, let my wife through," the senator says, turning back toward Heidi Cruz. A few protesters cheer and yell "bye" after Cruz and his wife exit the establishment. "We booted him out," one voice exclaims.

A restaurant employee is then heard asking the protesters to "leave the premises."

One protester asked Cruz, "Are you going to confirm your best friend, Brett Kavanaugh?"

"Beto is way hotter than you, dude," another shouted in reference to Cruz's Democratic opponent in his re-election fight, Texas Rep. Beto O'Rourke.

O'Rourke tweeted Tuesday that Cruz should not have been treated that way.

"Not right that Senator Cruz and his wife Heidi were surrounded and forced to leave a restaurant last night because of protesters," O'Rourke wrote. "The Cruz family should be treated with respect."

Title: UN General Assembly Vote: 128 Countries Call for Reversal of U.S. Jerusalem Decision

Article:

In a significant move, 128 countries, including some of the United States' most trusted allies, voted in favor of a United Nations resolution on Thursday calling for a reversal of President Donald Trump's decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital. Only nine countries voted against the resolution.

The resolution, while not explicitly referring to the U.S., is clearly directed at the White House. The measure declares that any changes to the status of Jerusalem "have no legal effect, are null and void and must be rescinded." It also "calls upon all States to refrain from the establishment of diplomatic missions in the Holy City of Jerusalem," another shot at the administration, which announced plans to move the U.S. Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

The closest the U.S. got to support from allies was 35 abstentions. Friends of the U.S. like Canada, Mexico, and Australia refrained from voting on the resolution, which means that while they didn't support the U.S. with a vote against it, they didn't criticize the U.S. either with a vote in favor of it.

Thursday's vote took place at a rare emergency session of the 193-member UN General Assembly. Turkey and Yemen, on behalf of two international organizations of Arab and Muslim countries, called for the emergency session after the U.S. vetoed a similar resolution at the UN Security Council on Monday. Unlike at the Security Council, the U.S. does not have veto power at the broader General Assembly.

The administration made a concerted effort to swing countries to its side before the UN vote. U.S. Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley promised the U.S. would be "taking names" of those who voted against the U.S. She also sent a letter to the UN ambassadors of more than 180 member countries warning that any vote in favor of the resolution would be taken "personally" by the president himself.

President Trump suggested during a Cabinet meeting on Wednesday that he would withhold billions of dollars in aid for countries that voted against the U.S. "Let them vote against us; we'll save a lot," Trump said. "We don't care."

And in a speech before the General Assembly right before the vote on Thursday, Haley escalated things even further, threatening to cut off U.S. funding to the UN over the vote.

"When we make generous contributions to the UN, we also have a legitimate expectation that our goodwill is recognized and respected," Haley said. "When a nation is singled out for attack in this organization, that nation is disrespected."

"We have an obligation to demand more for our investment," she said.

But the pressure campaign didn't work very well. Even close U.S. allies like the U.K. and Egypt were unmoved by America's dark warnings. And the fact that the vote stacked so heavily against the U.S. after an unusually aggressive campaign from the Trump administration against it only exacerbated the optics of isolation.

Richard Gowan, a UN expert at the European Council on Foreign Relations, told me Haley's abrasive politicking was a bit surprising. "While diplomats expect Trump to be crude, they may have expected a bit better from Haley. She is normally more pragmatic."

There are even signs that the heavy-handed threats backfired. Barak Ravid, a correspondent for Israel's Channel 10 news, reported that Canada switched from voting against the resolution to abstaining in order to avoid looking like a puppet of the U.S.

That Haley had to resort to such measures to try to convince even a few countries to side with the U.S. highlights the extraordinary sensitivity surrounding Jerusalem, which has sites holy to Jews, Christians, and Muslims, and which both the Palestinians and the Israelis claim as their capital.

Jerusalem has always been polarizing. Now it's even more so. Trump's December 6 speech recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital broke with decades of bipartisan American foreign policy about the city's future. Presidents of both parties have supported the idea of creating an independent Palestinian state alongside Israel, with the final status of Jerusalem to be decided as part of a peace agreement between the two sides.

Trump's language during his speech wasn't quite as inflammatory as it could've been. As Sarah Wildman pointed out for ███ at the time of the announcement, Trump didn't call Jerusalem the undivided capital of Israel—suggesting the U.S. would still support potentially dividing Jerusalem between the Israelis and the Palestinians as part of future peace negotiations.

But the move—along with the announcement that the U.S. would move its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem—sparked outcry in the international community and further polarized one of the most contentious territorial disputes in the world.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan said on Sunday that he intends to open an embassy in East Jerusalem—the part of the city that Palestinians officially want as the capital of a future Palestinian state. That came days after he convened a gathering of Muslim leaders to call for the world to see East Jerusalem as the capital of the Palestinian state.

A statement signed by more than 50 Muslim-majority countries at that summit declared that the U.S. had lost its role as a "sponsor of peace" in the Middle East. And Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said in a speech last week that Trump's Jerusalem announcement was a "crime" and that he no longer wants the U.S. to broker peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians.

Gowan, the UN expert, says that ultimately all the UN theatrics probably won't actually end up hurting the U.S.

"This is, ironically, a diplomatic win for all concerned," he said. "The vast majority of UN members have shown that they are principled defenders of international law and the Palestinian people. The U.S. has shown that it will go to the wire for Israel, and Trump can boast he is tougher than Obama on the Middle East. And everyone can go home for the holidays with a warm glow."

Title: National Donors Influence Wisconsin Sheriff Race: Bloomberg, NRA Back Opposing Candidates

Article:

In the upcoming primary election on Tuesday, voters in Milwaukee County, Wisconsin, will decide between controversial Sheriff David Clarke Jr. and police lieutenant Chris Moews. This local race has attracted significant national attention and funding, with gun control groups and the National Rifle Association (NRA) spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on the contest.

Sheriff Clarke, a proponent of Second Amendment rights, made headlines last year for a radio ad encouraging citizens to enroll in firearms classes following budget cuts. In a 30-second commercial, Clarke urged residents to "point that barrel center mass and pull the trigger" because "911 is not our best option."

Clarke's primary race opponent, Moews, is backed by substantial financial support aimed at undermining Clarke's campaign. Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who has publicly committed to spending $50 million on gun-control politics in 2014, has invested $150,000 in a series of television ads targeting Clarke's conservative pro-gun policies. This funding surpasses the combined spending of both Clarke and Moews on their campaigns.

Bloomberg's spokesman, Howard Wolfson, told the Wall Street Journal that the decision to get involved in the sheriff's race was made to shape policy on a local level. "The issue of guns is one that [Bloomberg] cares an awful lot about, and there’s a very clear contrast on that issue in this race," Wolfson stated.

The Greater Wisconsin Committee, an independent expenditure group, has also contributed $400,000 to the race through anti-Clarke advertisements.

Clarke, who identifies as a Democrat but often aligns with conservative Republicans, spoke at the NRA's annual meeting in April. The NRA, who considers Clarke a "rising national star," has come to Clarke's defense, soliciting donations from its members and purchasing online ads for his re-election bid.

Chris Cox, executive director of the NRA's Institute for Legislative Action, stated, "Make no mistake: Sheriff Clarke is fighting the reelection battle of his life right now because he dared to stand on principle by standing up for you, me, and the NRA."

Clarke, in a recent interview with Wisconsin News Radio 620 WTMJ, expressed his support for the right to self-defense, stating, "If I have the opportunity to defend myself and my family, I will do so to the best of my abilities, but I'm certainly also going to call 911 if I have the ability because I need the cavalry to come and help me."

Moews, in the same political event, expressed a different perspective, stating, "If I have the opportunity to defend myself and my family, I will do so to the best of my abilities, but I'm certainly also going to call 911 if I have the ability because I need the cavalry to come and help me."

The winner of Tuesday's primary will likely become the next county sheriff, as no Republicans are contesting the position. Both candidates are running as Democrats. The winner will move on to the November general election.

Title: Egypt Launches Airstrikes Against Islamic State Targets in Libya in Response to Execution of Egyptian Christians

Article:

Egypt has reportedly launched airstrikes against Islamic State (IS) targets in the eastern Libyan city of Darna, in retaliation for the gruesome execution of 21 Egyptian Christians shown in a video released on Sunday. The mass murder threatens to open a new front in the ongoing battle against the self-declared Islamic State, potentially drawing Western powers once more into military intervention in Libya.

According to Egyptian state television and various news outlets, including the BBC and Reuters, the strikes, made in coordination with the military of the recognized Libyan government based in Tobruk, targeted "camps, training sites, and weapons storage areas" of the IS affiliate in Libya. A Libyan air-force commander reportedly stated that 40 to 50 militants were killed in the strike. The Associated Press reports that a second airstrike is currently underway.

The strikes were in response to an IS video released on Sunday showing the execution of 21 Egyptians, all Coptic Christians, at the hands of masked IS supporters. The video, shot in IS signature style, demonstrates the group's Libyan branch's ability to hold captives for weeks and carry out a highly-produced murder show without fear of intervention from Egypt or any other country.

However, Egypt's ability to respond effectively is limited, as the Egyptian military is primarily trained for domestic control and running the business empires of its senior officers. The extent of Egypt's ability to counter the group in Libya, rather than its hundreds of followers in the Egyptian Sinai peninsula, remains to be seen.

The recognized Libyan government in Tobruk has already called for the US-led coalition attacking IS forces in Syria and Iraq to turn its attention to Libya. Libyan Prime Minister Abdullah al-Thinni, speaking to Reuters, has requested Western military intervention against IS and Al Qaeda members he claims are present in his country.

Reuters notes that the Islamist rival government in Tripoli, a group called Libyan Dawn, denies any affiliation with either IS or Al Qaeda. The New York Times adds that at least three groups among the multitude fighting in Libya's civil war have declared loyalty to IS, "one in each of the country’s component regions: Barqa in the east, Fezzan in the desert south, and Tripolitania in the west, around the capital."

The Islamic State’s self-proclaimed provinces have compounded Libya’s instability by introducing the prospect of Islamist-against-Islamist violence between those who support and those who oppose the group. However, Tripolitania has emerged as the province that most clearly threatens Westerners and Western interests. Last month, fighters under the group’s banner claimed responsibility for a brazen attack on a luxury hotel in the capital, Tripoli, that is a hub for visiting Westerners and leaders of the Islamist-backed provisional government.

In a commentary published in the Daily Telegraph, Shashank Joshi warns that "it’s important to separate [the IS] role in Libya from the broader civil war there. Not every Libyan opposition faction is jihadist, and acting as if it were, by taking firm sides, is a recipe for disaster."

Title: Trump Campaign Strategies: A Reality TV Perspective

Article:

The presidential campaign of Donald Trump, a former reality TV star, has been marked by a distinct influence from his background in television. While much attention has been focused on his political ascendancy, less emphasis has been placed on the impact of reality television on his campaign strategies.

Robert Thompson, founder of the Bleier Center for Television and Popular Culture at Syracuse University in New York, suggests that the Trump campaign has incorporated numerous elements from reality TV, shaping the candidate's approach and, in turn, the broader presidential campaign landscape.

Thompson asserts, "The Trump campaign has used a whole bunch of tricks from reality television to run his campaign and extend control over other people's campaigns." He explains that Trump's success can be attributed to the fact that, despite differences between his TV show and the presidential race, he is "playing by the rules of reality TV, and the people covering him are largely unconsciously playing by the same reality show rules as well."

While Trump's success can also be attributed to factors such as nativist and populist insurgencies and voter hunger for "outsiders" in an era of frustration with Washington elites, prominent features of his candidacy align closely with his chosen television genre. Here are six significant ways in which this is evident:

1. Conflict: Trump's campaign is characterized by frequent confrontations, a common element in reality TV shows.
2. "Confession Rooms": Trump's use of private, off-camera conversations, reminiscent of the "confession rooms" in reality TV, allows him to express his thoughts and emotions without the constraints of a public forum.
3. Soundbites: Trump's concise, attention-grabbing statements, often delivered in a dramatic manner, are a staple of reality TV and have become a defining aspect of his campaign.
4. Ratings: Trump's campaign has been successful in capturing media attention and generating high ratings, a key metric in the reality TV world.
5. Sensationalism: Trump's penchant for making bold, attention-grabbing statements, often without providing specifics, is a tactic borrowed from reality TV.
6. Control: Trump's efforts to control the narrative and shape the media coverage of his campaign, as well as his attempts to influence other candidates' campaigns, reflect the power dynamics often seen in reality TV.

This analysis offers a unique perspective on the Trump campaign, highlighting the ways in which his reality TV background has influenced his approach to politics. However, it is essential to recognize that this is just one of many lenses through which to view his campaign. Other factors, such as the role of nativist and populist insurgencies, also play significant roles in understanding Trump's success.

Title: Defense Secretary Mattis Earns Title of 'Clarifier' for Trump as He Modifies President's Statements

Article:

Defense Secretary James Mattis, also known as "Mad Dog" Mattis, is quickly earning the title of President Trump's clarifier. In Trump's seven-month tenure, Mattis has deftly shifted the tone and message of the president's seemingly never-ending stream of off-the-cuff comments.

On various topics, including torture, the importance of NATO, the regional conflict between Qatar and neighboring countries, and leadership confidence in Afghanistan, Mattis has altered Trump's words into more diplomatic and less emotional messages, without drawing the ire of the commander-in-chief.

One source close to the Defense secretary described Mattis as "the great clarifier." "He's just providing a more detailed clarification to the president's statements," the source said. "He's very methodical in his process."

In his most recent show of savvy, Mattis on Wednesday sought to downplay Trump's assertion that seemed to rule out a diplomatic solution to North Korea's missile tests. Trump tweeted Wednesday morning that the United States "has been talking to North Korea, and paying them extortion money, for 25 years. Talking is not the answer!"

The former Marine Corps general, when asked about the tweet later that day, said, "We're never out of diplomatic solutions."

The source close to Mattis said of the secretary's message delivery, "I think he expresses in a terminology that he feels fits. He's very methodical in his process."

It's no secret Mattis has remained a favorite of Trump's even as the notoriously unpredictable president has soured on a number of administration officials. "I think they communicate to each other very openly, very clearly, even warmly," the source told ███.

That open dialogue, which includes frequent working dinners and regular phone calls and meetings, has earned Mattis significant leeway in interpreting Trump's public and Twitter comments. Mattis's savvy became apparent within the first few weeks after Trump's election.

The retired Marine Corps general, who has long disapproved of using torture to gather intelligence, prompted Trump to change his tune after meeting with him to discuss the Defense secretary position. "Mattis said that he does not intend to use [torture]. I'm with him all the way," Trump later said in an interview on Fox News in January.

The secretary also opposed Trump's early views that NATO was "obsolete" and later placated world leaders after Trump did not reaffirm America's commitment to the military alliance while at an opening ceremony for NATO's new Brussels headquarters in May.

"To quote a British observer of us from some years back, bear with us," Mattis said at the Asian security forum in Singapore when asked about Trump's omission and recent pledge to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. "Once we have exhausted all possible alternatives, the Americans will do the right thing."

More recently, when Trump reportedly sought to fire the top U.S. commander in Afghanistan, Gen. Jon Nicholson, because the United States is "losing" the war, Mattis defended the general while not disparaging Trump's view.

"I will tell you right now, he is our commander in the field, he has the confidence of NATO, he has the confidence of Afghanistan, he has the confidence of the United States," Mattis told reporters earlier this month when asked if Trump has confidence in Nicholson. "The president, again, is looking at all aspects of our effort over there, as he must in his responsibilities as the commander-in-chief."

One source familiar with the situation said Mattis's interpretations are simply "holding the line until a semblance of normalcy is restored during the tumultuous first year of this administration."

"I believe [Mattis] hopes that once the administration gets its feet under it and learns D.C., that things will get better and move toward the campaign agenda," the source said.

Mattis also is adept at responding when faced with criticism that he is pushing back on Trump's assertions. He himself called the idea that he contradicted Trump "ludicrous" and "widely misinterpreted."

"I was asked if there were any diplomatic efforts left, and I said of course," Mattis told reporters at the Pentagon on Thursday. "It did not contradict anything the president said. We're not talking to the North Koreans right now."

He continued, "I can't help people who misinterpret things. I'll do my best to call it like I see it, but right now if I say six and the president says half-a-dozen, they're gonna say I disagree with him."

The secretary did admit that there are issues he and the president disagree on but revealed the division of opinions in a complimentary tone.

"The first time I met with President Trump, we disagreed on three things in my first 40 minutes with him, on NATO, on torture, and something else, and he hired me. This is not a man who's immune to being persuaded if he thinks you've got an argument," Mattis said.

When asked about critics who say he and other national security leaders should step down when Trump makes divisive remarks, Mattis pointed to service to the greater good.

"You know, when a president of the United States asks you to do something, I come—I don't think it's an old-fashioned school at all. I don't think it's old-fashioned or anything. I don't care if it's Republican or Democrat, we all have an obligation to serve. That's all there is to it."

Title: Biden Vows to Counter Foreign Interference in U.S. Elections

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has stated that he will take aggressive action against foreign governments interfering in U.S. elections if he is elected president. The statement came hours after Democratic leaders issued a new warning that Congress appears to be the target of a foreign interference campaign.

Biden, in a statement on Monday, said he would treat foreign interference as an "adversarial act that significantly affects the relationship between the United States and the interfering nation's government." He criticized President Donald Trump for not doing enough in response to U.S. intelligence agencies' assessment that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election.

"If any foreign power recklessly chooses to interfere in our democracy, I will not hesitate to respond as president to impose substantial and lasting costs," Biden said.

The new alarms give a renewed urgency to concerns that foreign actors could be trying to influence the vote or sow disinformation. Biden said last week that he had begun receiving intelligence briefings and warned that Russia, China, and other adversaries were attempting to undermine the presidential election. Biden gave no evidence, but he said that Russia was "still engaged" after 2016 and that China was also involved in efforts to sow doubts in the American electoral process.

During an online fundraiser on Monday, Biden added, "It's going to be tough, there's not much I can do about it now except talk about it, and expose it, but it is a serious concern. It is truly a violation of our sovereignty."

In an interview on MSNBC, Biden said Russian President Vladimir Putin "knows I mean what I say."

The Democratic leaders said in a letter to FBI Director Christopher Wray on Monday that they are concerned that Congress appears to be the target of a "concerted foreign interference campaign" to influence the 2020 presidential election. They asked Wray for an all-members, classified briefing on the matter before the August recess.

The letter from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer, and the top Democrats on the House and Senate intelligence committees contains no details about the threats, though they describe them as serious and specific.

While the Democrats' exact concerns were unclear, there have been worries since Trump was elected that Russia's efforts to sow American chaos are ongoing in the 2020 election. The 2016 effort included hacking of Democratic email accounts during the campaign by Russian military intelligence officials and the subsequent disclosure by WikiLeaks.

Intelligence authorities said that hack-and-leak operation was aimed at helping Trump's presidential campaign and harming that of his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. Russians also used a covert social media campaign to spread misinformation and posts aimed at dividing American public opinion. In the end, former special counsel Robert Mueller charged 25 Russian nationals for their roles in foreign interference and influence during the campaign.

Democrats, including members of the Senate intelligence panel, have voiced concerns that an ongoing Republican probe into Biden's son, Hunter Biden, and his work in Ukraine would amplify Russian disinformation. That probe is being led by Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Chairman Ron Johnson, R-Wis.

In a statement, Johnson spokesman Austin Altenburg said the committee's staff had already requested and received a briefing on Russian disinformation, and Johnson had requested an additional briefing at the member level.

Title: New York's Liberal Immigration Policy Affects Family of Undocumented Immigrant Living in Staten Island

Article:

The family of Nancy Paredo, a resident of Staten Island, New York, has been living in the United States for 13 years after she allegedly entered the country illegally from Ciudad Juarez. Due to New York's liberal immigration philosophy, Paredo and her family, including her American-born son Axel, are not afraid of being deported every day, but they are cautious and closely monitoring Washington this summer.

Axel, a five-year-old, was born in the United States. His brothers Yan, who is 15, and Demis, 13, were born in Mexico and remain undocumented.

On June 30, President Obama announced a new effort to address the U.S. immigration system. However, only Congress has the power to grant people like Paredo and her family legal status, and President Obama's options are limited. The focus will be on reducing deportations among people who have been in the country for years.

One of Obama's easiest options would be to refine a 2010 policy that states undocumented, non-criminal, breadwinning immigrants would not be high deportation priorities. Such a change could ease some of the fears in the family, but immigrant advocates and families say it's unclear whether it would make a significant difference.

A more forceful step from the President could fully eliminate deportation for some immigrants - at least for a time. Yan Carlos Valdez, who is currently applying for protection under a policy known as DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals), could benefit from such a move. DACA lasts two years and would give him work permits and a social security number. A move from the President could grant DACA-like protections to the parents of United States citizens.

Extending these protections could impact an estimated 3.8 million people. The number would be higher if the President chose to extend protections to the parents of DACA-recipients. However, that's a step that government lawyers say would almost surely invite legal scrutiny and Republican opposition.

President Obama's most far-reaching - and controversial - move would be to extend DACA-like protections to all undocumented immigrants who meet a certain criteria. That's an estimated 9.6 million people. Nancy Paredo and her family could be free from deportation fears, but it's another move that would almost surely bring a legal challenge.

Paredo and her family often visit Washington to add their voice to the pressure for reform. "What do you want for your mom and dad?" Emily asked Axel. "I want them to be safe," Axel replied.

Title: Analysis: The Extreme Pendulum Swing Theory of Presidential Displacement and the 2020 Democratic Candidates

Article:

The recent incident involving former Vice President Joe Biden's interaction with an Iowa farmer has sparked discussions about the qualities needed to beat President Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential election. The Extreme Pendulum Swing Theory of Presidential Displacement suggests that changing the party in power requires a total opposite of the current chief executive, not in policy but in style and attitude.

In 1980, a feckless and besweatered Jimmy Carter gave way to the robust Ronald Reagan, whose strong and confident approach offered a shot in the arm to a country that had been down on itself for over a decade. In 1992, fuddy-duddy George H.W. Bush lost to the cool and modern Bill Clinton. In 2000, George W. Bush restored "honor and dignity" to the White House after eight years of personal scandal and drama, as the nation turned to a moral, conservative family man as it punished Al Gore for Bill Clinton's numerous sins. In 2008, Barack Obama, who formed articulate and complete sentences, shot hoops, hung with celebrities, and sounded like he had all the answers, was elected. In 2016, a nation no longer concerned with experience bought Donald Trump's anti-elite pitch, as he railed against the elitist in the White House and the one opposing him.

According to this theory, three 2020 Democratic candidates - Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar, and Andrew Yang - provide enough opposite magic. Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren, and Mike Bloomberg are considered too similar to Trump or lack the necessary contrasting qualities.

Pete Buttigieg, a young, Ivy League-educated Navy veteran, offers a contrasting attitude regarding America's place in the world. He enjoys Middle America street cred while espousing big-city liberal values. His biggest similarity to Trump? His confidence and ambition far outstrip his experience.

Amy Klobuchar, another Midwesterner, is a U.S. senator with real-deal political experience. Her deliberate and understated style (at least in public) is the opposite of bombastic. Nominating a woman plays to the gaping gender gap that has opened on Trump's job approval. Her most Trump-like trait could be in the way she treats staff in private, if you believe the stories.

Andrew Yang is a detail-oriented Asian American technocrat who, as he often says, likes math. He's young and has worked in the modern economy as well as the nonprofit sector. He appears to be having fun - how novel! While I find him to be Trump's opposite in almost every way, his one similarity comes in his instinct that impeachment is "a loser" for Democrats.

In conclusion, the Extreme Pendulum Swing Theory of Presidential Displacement suggests that the 2020 Democratic candidates who offer the most opposite magic are Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar, and Andrew Yang. These candidates, while not exactly the '27 Yankees of American politics,' represent a near opposite choice. Democrats often gravitate to and win with "nerdy wonks," according to one Democratic strategist. This theory originally appeared in the Louisville Courier-Journal.

Title: Pakistani High Court Upholds Allowing Marriage of Underage Girls Based on Sharia Law

Article:

A Pakistani high court has issued a ruling based on Islamic sharia law that permits men in Pakistan to marry girls who have undergone their first menstrual cycle, despite the Sindh Child Marriage Restraint Act, which forbids marriage below the age of 18. The ruling was made during a court hearing regarding the kidnapping, forced conversion, and marriage of Huma Younus, a 14-year-old Christian girl.

According to reports, Younus was kidnapped by three men from her home in Karachi last October. The men waited for her parents to leave before forcibly taking the young girl, who was then taken to Dera Gazi Khan, a city in the Punjab province of Pakistan, more than 370 miles from her home. Since then, Younus' parents have been working to recover their daughter.

Younus' parents received documents from the abductors a few days after she was taken, including papers showing her alleged conversion to Islam and a marriage certificate. The girl's mother, Nagina, stated that the papers are fake because the date on the documents was the same as the day when her daughter was abducted.

In an effort to rescue their daughter, the family argued that the marriage to a man named Jabbar was invalid under the Sindh Child Marriage Restraint Act. The Christian couple supplied the court with baptismal and school documents proving Huma is 14, according to the International Christian Concern (ICC). She was born on May 22, 2005, the Independent Catholic News reports.

The law in question was passed almost six years ago in an effort to stop forced marriages to minors in the province. The practice is prevalent among Hindus and Christian girls, according to various media outlets.

During the court hearing, judges Muhammad Iqbal Kalhoro and Irshad Ali Shah ruled that the marriage between Huma and Jabbar is valid because she has already had her first period.

"Once again, justice has been defeated, and, once again, our state has shown itself unable to treat Christians as Pakistani citizens," Nagheena Younus, Huma's mother, told Aid to the Church in Need (ACN).

Huma's parents have vowed to take her case to the Supreme Court of Pakistan. "On February 3rd, we went to the Sindh High Court, but our little girl was not in the courtroom. If we do not get justice, we will address the case to the Supreme Court of Pakistan. We believe that the government and the judges are delaying the decision because our girl is 14 years old," she explained.

Tabassum Yousaf, Younus' lawyer, told the ACN they hoped the law could have been applied for the first time in Huma's case. "But evidently in Pakistan, these laws are formulated and approved only to improve the image of the country in front of the international community, ask for development funds, and freely trade Pakistani products on the European market," he said.

Another hearing in the case has been scheduled for March 4. In an email to ███ News, ICC President Jeff King responded to the court's ruling. "Pakistan's High Court decision to rule in favor of underage marriage is wrong on so many levels. In the last few years, the world has been awakened to the disastrous practice and effects of child marriage (child brides) through various organizations and brave female voices throughout the world," King wrote. "I've yet to see these campaigners, though, touch on one aspect of the practice that allows Christians around the world to have their daughters kidnapped, often never to be seen again. That is the issue of forced marriage and forced conversion in Muslim countries."

King explained that young Christian women are frequently targeted by Muslim men. "In the most fundamentalist Muslim countries (i.e., Pakistan, Egypt, and others), where Christians are a minority, young Christian girls are routinely targeted by Muslim men," he noted. "It usually starts with a young Christian girl being approached by a Muslim boy or man with a request to date or marry. If these requests are ignored, she will start to hear how she's too pretty to be a Christian and other statements that represent a more dangerous level of harassment."

The ICC president adds that the family usually knows the perpetrator. "Usually, and often tragically, the next step is that she will be kidnapped, drugged, beaten, and raped multiple times, and often the family knows who is responsible," King continued. "In a fundamentalist, shame-based culture, the girl's prospects for marriage, and a decent life, are permanently ruined. She is left feeling incredibly useless and ashamed. Then, she will be presented with an offer to save her dignity by being married to her rapist. If she refuses, she will be raped and beaten repeatedly."

King says Pakistani law enforcement officials are of little help to parents. "When the parents inquire of the police and try to get them to do something, they will be presented with a statement from their daughter saying that she has become a Muslim," he continued. "If the Christian parents continue to fight, they're often slapped around and threatened with arrest. If the parents are especially brave, the daughter is often then dragged in front of them in a drugged state (with her torturer and rapist in the room) to say that she is a Muslim and does not wish to come home – never making eye contact with her parents."

King pointed out to ███ News that none of this is a rare occurrence, unfortunately. "So it is with tremendous sadness that we receive the news that Pakistan's High Court has allowed this practice to continue. Even more tragically, it means that for 14-year-old Huma, whose case the trial was based on, will not be returned to her parents and is probably lost to them forever," he concluded.

Title: California Positions Itself as a Progressive Counterbalance to Trump Administration

Article:

California, a state that heavily favored Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election, is gearing up to lead a progressive resistance against President-elect Donald Trump. The Golden State, home to industries such as Silicon Valley and Hollywood, is a political powerhouse for the left and contributes 13 percent to the nation's gross domestic product.

California's political landscape is marked by a powerful group of Democratic politicians, including Senators Kamala Harris and Dianne Feinstein, Governor Jerry Brown, and Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi. The state also has a growing Latino population, making it a focal point for Trump's immigration agenda, as about 40 percent of the state's population is Hispanic.

Outgoing Representative Xavier Becerra, who was appointed earlier this month to succeed Sen.-elect Kamala Harris as state attorney general, will lead the local charge in California's immigration fight. Becerra has already vowed to fight federal immigration enforcement in his new role through legislation and litigation.

California mayors have also pledged to resist aggressive immigration enforcement. Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti has announced a fund to defend immigrants from deportation and has maintained his commitment to keeping L.A. a "sanctuary" city.
