Senator Dianne Feinstein, who will be the top Democrat on the Judiciary Committee next year, will lead the opposition to Trump's pick for attorney general, Senator Jeff Sessions. Becerra and Feinstein have stated that all legal options, including litigation and political action, are on the table when it comes to fighting to defend California's policies.

Voter turnout in California was 73.5 percent, the state's second-highest in history. This is almost 20 points higher than the 54.4 percent national turnout rate, according to figures from the United States Elections Project. Some believe the higher turnout reflects the interest taken in the election by Hispanics who were concerned about Trump's promises to build a U.S.-Mexico border wall and implement mass deportations.

Trump has accused California of voter fraud, claiming this contributed to his loss in the popular vote. However, Trump and his allies have provided no evidence to support these accusations. California's Secretary of State, Alex Padilla, has criticized Trump's comments about voter fraud, stating they are unsubstantiated, reckless, and unbecoming of a president-elect.

While California and Trump have been at odds, state politicians say they are willing to work with the president-elect where their interests align. However, they have also made it clear they will confront Trump's administration where necessary, particularly on issues such as Social Security, Medicare, and healthcare reform.

Kenneth Romero, executive director of the bipartisan National Hispanic Caucus of State Legislators, argued that California's local leaders are likely to turn to the issue of states' rights in making their case against Trump's agenda. Romero suggested that the potential conflict between California and the federal government is not unprecedented, as states have resisted federal policy in the past.

Title: "Democrats' Call to Abolish ICE Gains Mainstream Support, Sparking Political Debate"

Article:

The call to abolish Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has moved from the fringes of the Democratic Party to the mainstream, with several high-profile Democrats expressing support for the idea. In an interview with Maria Bartiromo on "Sunday Morning Futures," President Trump predicted that Democrats campaigning on the policy of abolishing ICE would face electoral defeat.

Trump stated, "Well I hope they keep thinking about it. Because they're going to get beaten so badly. You know ICE, these are the guys that go in and take MS-13, and they take them out. Because they're much tougher than MS-13, like by a factor of 10. And these are the ones – you get rid of ICE, you're going to have a country that you're going to be afraid to walk out of your house."

The shift in Democratic sentiment towards ICE is largely a response to the Trump administration's tough policies on illegal immigration, particularly the "zero tolerance" policy on detaining all illegal border crossers. In New York, far-left primary challenger Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, an ICE opponent, shocked the party's establishment by beating Rep. Joseph Crowley, D-N.Y. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand and Mayor Bill de Blasio have since added their support to the cause.

Gillibrand stated, "I believe that [Immigration and Customs Enforcement] has become a deportation force … and that's why I believe you should get rid of it, start over, reimagine it and build something that actually works." De Blasio said, "We should abolish ICE."

Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif, and Rep. Mark Pocan, D-Wis, have also expressed support for abolishing ICE, with Harris suggesting the U.S. should consider "starting from scratch."

While the call to abolish ICE is gaining traction among Democrats, Trump and many Republicans are opposing the idea. Trump tweeted on Saturday that he was backing ICE agents and that there was "zero chance" of ICE being abolished. "To the great and brave men and women of ICE, do not worry or lose your spirit. You are doing a fantastic job of keeping us safe by eradicating the worst criminal elements," he said.

The political debate over ICE is expected to continue as the 2020 election approaches, with both parties presenting contrasting views on immigration policy.

Title: Book Unjust: Social Justice and the Unmaking of America Critiques Lack of Logical and Definitional Rigor

Article:

Noah Rothman, a writer and editor at Commentary magazine, has recently published his first book, titled "Unjust: Social Justice and the Unmaking of America." The book, far from being nonsensical, is described as crisp, insightful, and passionate. The central theme of the book, as captured in the title, is a critique of social justice, which Rothman argues is nonsensical due to its lack of interior logic and definitional rigor.

Rothman embarked on a quest to find a universally agreed-upon definition of social justice while writing his book, The Tyranny of Clichés. However, he found that the term is used by various groups, including labor unions, universities, gay-rights groups, and even the American Nazi party, with each group claiming to be champions of social justice. The only disagreements hinged on who is most in need of this resource.

Common to most definitions of social justice is the concept of "economic justice," which Rothman describes as "distributive justice" - the redistribution of wealth from the haves to the have-nots. However, Rothman argues that what social justice is really about is power, with its advocates seeking the power to do what they want, and using the label of social justice to justify their actions.

Rothman's book criticizes the Green party's social justice platform, which is nearly 60 pages long and includes planks such as stopping speech that perpetuates "oppression and abuse," reform of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, sovereignty for Hawaii, compensation for gays and lesbians who have suffered from "injustice," and the encouragement of young people's potential. Rothman argues that social justice is not a theory, but a wish list.

Rothman also discusses the connection between social justice and identity politics, arguing that historically oppressed or disadvantaged groups want payback in the name of social justice. He calls this "retributive justice." According to this view, whites have historically enjoyed privileges that non-whites did not, and therefore non-whites are owed something, and "white privilege" must be overthrown. The argument follows the same form for males, heterosexuals, and so on.

One of the problems with this worldview, according to Rothman, is that individual circumstances are boiled away, with vast abstract categories of human beings being swept up into notions of collective guilt or victimhood. This is partly why philosopher Friedrich Hayek loathed the concept of social justice, seeing it as the very negation of plain old justice.

When Rothman appeared on MSNBC's Morning Joe to discuss his book, the reaction from critics often boiled down to the claim that he cannot criticize social justice because he does not belong to a category of people in need of social justice. A white man's arguments can be dismissed out of hand because of the color of his skin.

Rothman's book argues that social justice is a kind of magical incantation that renders inconvenient impediments to its champions' agenda illegitimate. Free speech is good unless it hurts certain groups. Property rights are fine except when social justice dictates that someone else needs your stuff more. The right to confront your accuser is negated by the need to "believe all women." Even facts are irrelevant in the face of social justice.

In conclusion, Rothman's book, "Unjust: Social Justice and the Unmaking of America," provides a critical analysis of the concept of social justice, arguing that it lacks interior logic and definitional rigor, and is often used as a justification for power grabs and the suppression of free speech, property rights, and due process.

Title: Democrats Emphasize Potential Public Safety Risks Amid Sequester Cuts

Article:

Democrats in the U.S. Congress have shifted their focus from warnings about mid-air plane crashes, troop deaths, and tainted meat to emphasize the potential impact of sequester cuts on law enforcement and public safety. The shift in strategy aims to sway public opinion and place blame on the Republicans for the spending cuts.

Senate Appropriations Committee Chairwoman Barbara Mikulski (D-MD) has highlighted the consequences of the sequester cuts on local law enforcement officials, who rely on federal grants for staffing and equipment purchases. Mikulski stated that the spending cuts jeopardize the ability to "catch the bad guys," referring to white-collar crime, street crime, and human trafficking.

Rep. G.K. Butterfield (D-NC) suggested that a significant event would be necessary to change the public's perception of sequestration. He noted that the lack of immediate, visible effects of the cuts has made it challenging to convince voters of the dangers they pose.

In the realm of public safety, Democrats have emphasized the potential increase in crime and other dangers. Federal prison union officials have pointed to past budget cuts and staffing shortages, citing a federal prison inmate's stabbing of a guard last month in Canaan, PA, as an example of the potential consequences of sequester cuts. Dale Deshotel, president of the Council of Prison Locals, expressed growing concern as the Bureau of Prisons begins to cut $339 million this fiscal year and impose 12 mandated furlough days for all its employees.

Additionally, warnings have been issued about the potential increase in illicit drugs reaching U.S. soil due to sequester cuts. At a hearing last week before the House Armed Services Committee, Southern Command chief Marine Gen. John Kelly stated that sequestration could result in a loss of critical air and water surveillance for monitoring cocaine trafficking. Gen. Kelly warned that if these assets are reduced or eliminated, all cocaine would reach U.S. shores, with more likely to follow.

Polls indicate that roughly half of Americans are undecided about sequestration due to a lack of knowledge about the effects of the cuts. Frank Newport, Gallup's editor-in-chief, described the situation as a "fascinating case of wait and see."

-End of Article-

Title: The Ongoing Refugee Crisis in Europe: A Complex and Multifaceted Issue

Article:

The refugee crisis in Europe, characterized by the influx of desperate individuals fleeing conflicts in the Middle East, presents a complex and multifaceted challenge that defies simple solutions. While some may argue that there are no absolute solutions, it is crucial to acknowledge the humanitarian aspect of the situation and the need for international cooperation.

The immediate problem is the mass migration of individuals from the Middle East, seeking refuge from war and terrorism, into Europe. However, the current crisis cannot be addressed in isolation, as it has roots in both the past and the future.

The future is a significant constraint on the present response to the refugee crisis. As refugees settle in Europe, they will have children who will grow up with no memory of the Middle East. These new generations may face challenges integrating into Western societies, as their values may clash with those of their host countries. This could potentially lead to strife and even terrorism, as some may be influenced by extremist ideologies.

The capacity of any nation to absorb immigrants is not unlimited, especially when the cultures of the immigrants are antagonistic to the values of the host society. The admission of a foreign population, particularly one with a history of maintaining distinct cultural identities, presents long-term challenges.

The past and future of the refugee crisis cast a shadow over the present situation. The decision to admit foreign populations, especially those with a history of maintaining distinct identities, is an irreversible one. The Obama administration's policies in the Middle East, such as the withdrawal of troops from Iraq and the destabilization of governments in Egypt and Libya, have contributed to the current refugee crisis.

While Middle Eastern countries could take in more refugees, oil-rich countries like Saudi Arabia have not done so in significant numbers. The West, including the United States, could provide more financial aid to Middle Eastern countries like Jordan and Egypt, to ease the burden of the refugees they have already taken in. This approach may encounter less political opposition at home and could be a more effective means of addressing the underlying causes of the refugee crisis.

A comprehensive solution to the refugee crisis will likely require a long-term, multifaceted approach that addresses the root causes of the conflict in the Middle East and the challenges faced by refugees in integrating into Western societies. This may require a change in leadership and policy, as the current administration has been criticized for its handling of the situation in the Middle East.

Title: Romney and Obama Differ on Iran Nuclear Policy and Middle East Intervention

Article:

In the past few days, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has focused on accusations that President Barack Obama has shown weakness and apologized for America, linking these actions to the recent protests in Cairo and the violence in Libya. During a speech in Fairfax, Virginia, on Thursday, Romney avoided discussing the challenges in dealing with Egypt and Libya, instead offering a general critique of the president's foreign policy.

When asked about Iran's nuclear program, Romney and President Obama present different approaches. Obama has stated that he aims to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon but has resisted calls from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to set a "red line" that would warn Iran of potential military action if it continues to develop nuclear capabilities. In a phone call on Tuesday night, Obama and Netanyahu debated this issue.

According to Paul Pillar, a professor at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies and a former senior official in the State Department under President George W. Bush, Romney would not tolerate Iran being "one screwdriver's turn away from a nuclear weapon." However, Pillar did not specify where exactly Romney would draw the line.

The vagueness of Romney's stance is significant because, by some definitions, Iran already has the capability to produce a nuclear weapon, though it might take several months or years to realize this capability. Pillar stated, "Once they get a weapon, or on the verge of getting it, it's too late."

Romney has said he would never allow Iran to enrich uranium, suggesting he would enforce a series of United Nations Security Council resolutions demanding that Iran "suspend" its production of all nuclear fuel. However, Iran was in violation of that demand during most of President Bush's second term, and suffered fewer economic consequences than it has under Obama, who has imposed the first sanctions against Iran's oil revenues.

Both Pillar and former ambassador Robert W. Kelley, who has served several Republican presidents, criticized Obama for being too cautious in supporting opposition forces in Syria. Kelley described Obama as too risk-averse in the Middle East, stating, "We are not better off in letting things drift. We have 20,000 dead, and the more it goes on, the fewer choices we have."

On Egypt, Pillar suggested that the administration had failed to make clear that American aid was contingent on the protection of American interests. In fact, Obama's aides, during trips to Cairo, have been careful not to threaten pulling that aid, but they have warned the Egyptian authorities that Congressional approval could be difficult unless the country's leaders reaffirmed the peace treaty with Israel.

Kelley continued the Romney campaign's attack on a statement issued by the American Embassy in Cairo hours before protests began there, saying "you don't issue a conciliatory statement that says we don't support freedom of speech." The statement did condemn a virulent anti-Muslim video that set off the violence, but it also included references to both the importance of free speech and religious tolerance.

Both men stopped short of saying that the United States should provide lethal arms. A senior Obama administration official said that "sounds a lot like they are endorsing our position."

Title: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi Calls for Briefing on U.S. Military Strike, Criticizes Trump's Syria Policy

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has demanded a briefing on the U.S. military operation that resulted in the death of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. In a statement, Pelosi expressed the need for Congress to be informed about the raid and the Administration's strategy in the region.

Pelosi stated, "The House must be briefed on this raid, which the Russians but not top Congressional Leadership were notified of in advance, and on the Administration’s overall strategy in the region." She further added, "Our military and allies deserve strong, smart, and strategic leadership from Washington."

President Trump, in announcing the operation, singled out Pelosi, stating that congressional leaders could not be trusted in the planning of the attack in Syria. Trump said, "Washington is a leaking machine."

Pelosi commended the U.S. military for carrying out the raid but did not mention Trump, who had made the killing of al-Baghdadi a priority and gave the order for the strike.

Pelosi also criticized Trump's military policy in Syria, stating that it had potentially strengthened ISIS. This criticism mirrors comments made by Democratic presidential hopeful and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden.

Trump faced harsh criticism from both sides of the aisle this month when he pulled out U.S. troops from the Turkey-Syria border, which allowed a Turkish military advance on U.S.-allied Kurdish forces in the region. Pelosi noted, "This month, the House passed a joint resolution on an overwhelmingly bipartisan 354-60 basis which rejects President Trump’s green-lighting of Turkish aggression into Syria against our Kurdish partners, and calls on him to present a clear strategy to defeat ISIS."

Title: New IRS Withholding Guidelines Result in Increased Take-Home Pay for Many Workers

Article:

The new tax overhaul is beginning to deliver a change that many workers are welcoming — bigger paychecks. Workers are starting to see more take-home pay as employers implement the new withholding guidelines from the IRS, which dictate how much employers withhold from pay for federal taxes. Those whose checks have remained the same should not worry, as employers have until Feb. 15 to make the changes.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has estimated that the new rules will mean more take-home pay for about 90 percent of American workers. The amount of extra cash depends on several factors, such as workers' income, how often they are paid, and the number of withholdings allowances they claim on their IRS Form W-4 with their employer.

Workers who have already experienced the change have welcomed the extra money, with some seeing an increase of a few dollars to a few hundred dollars. Wayne Love, who works in managed care in Spring Hill, Florida, got an extra $200 in his paycheck last week, which he said will help offset a $300 increase in the cost of his health insurance.

Julia Ketchum, a secretary at a public high school in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, said she was pleasantly surprised her pay went up $1.50 a week. She didn't think her pay would go up at all, let alone this soon. That adds up to $78 a year, which she said will more than cover her Costco membership for the year.

Todd Anderson of Texas and his fiance, who are both educators, got an extra $200 in their paychecks combined that they plan to use to cover the costs of a second baby on its way.

According to the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center, a middle-income household would on average get a tax cut of $930 this year, lifting their after-tax income by about 1.6 percent. However, that increase won't be perfectly reflected in their paychecks, as lower tax withholding on paychecks is just a piece of a complicated set of changes to tax law.

As a result, taxpayers may find they are unintentionally over- or underwithholding for their taxes if they don't do some legwork. Senators Ron Wyden and Richard Neal, both Democrats, have asked the Government Accountability Office to analyze the new tables to make sure workers' paychecks weren't being systematically underwithheld, which would make paychecks bigger now but lead to a bigger bill at tax time.

Experts suggest that all taxpayers take a look at the new IRS calculator when it becomes available later in February to ensure they are having the correct amount withheld. And they should update the information on their W-4 after the IRS releases a revised version later this year.

The IRS said the new withholding tables should produce an accurate withholding amount for people with simpler tax situations. However, tax experts say those who will still itemize, have larger families, or more complicated tax situations may want to take a closer look.

"If they haven't done it before, this is a really good year to talk to your tax professional," said Pete Isberg, vice president of government relations for ADP, a payroll provider.

The IRS, payroll, and tax professionals have been scrambling to react to the passage of the new tax law. And the IRS says it plans to make further changes involving withholding matters in 2019. Many in the industry say they expect the IRS to update the W-4 form in 2019 in a more dramatic fashion to fully reflect the scope of the law.

No worker should anticipate a negative impact from the new withholding table if their pay remained the same, said Joseph Rosenberg, a senior researcher at the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center. However, someone who got a raise may face a higher tax rate as a result. And some corporations have been handing out bonuses and wage increases in reaction to passage of the law. A worker's net pay may also fall if other factors that go into their paycheck changed — such as an increase in health insurance premiums or higher state taxes.

Still, a little extra money in the hands of most Americans may also help boost support of President Donald Trump and his tax plan. Trump and the Republican backers of the plan have deflected criticism of the legislation, insisting that Americans will come to love the new law when they see their heftier paychecks.

"It's tough to be upset about more money in my pocket," said Jefferey Snively, an aerospace engineer who got a 4 percent bump in his last paycheck due to the lower tax rate. He said that's not enough to feel like a windfall or change his spending habits, but is a pleasant change. Yet, he thinks the tax overhaul wasn't really about him or other workers, but more about corporations and the wealthy.

"I think the people this bill made the most difference for are the ones who needed it least," he said.

Title: Former President Obama's Midterm Endorsements Divide Democrats Over Timing and Impact

Article:

Former President Barack Obama's midterm endorsement list has sparked controversy among some Democrats, with critics arguing that the list, which includes 81 endorsements, came too late in the midterm season and failed to significantly impact Democratic primaries.

Strategists, former Obama aides, and fundraisers interviewed by various sources expressed confusion over Obama's list, which was released after most states had held their primaries. One former senior Obama administration official stated, "I think a lot of us have wondered why he didn't feel the need to get involved earlier. There are a lot of folks that could have used his help much earlier. And there are a lot of people who think he should put a stamp on the party."

Obama's decision to largely stay away from primaries is consistent with the behavior of many other former presidents, who have generally sought to stay above internal party fights. However, some Democrats argue that the political environment demands more input from Obama, citing the need for his influence in the face of Donald Trump's presidency.

Democratic strategist Brad Bannon stated, "These are not traditional times. He's the most popular Democrat in our nation, and we really need all the help we can get. So if I were advising him, I would have told him to get out there much sooner and get in the trenches because we're playing high stakes poker."

The release of the endorsement list was consistent with Obama's post-Oval Office goal of seeking to stay above the fray and to not become more of a foil to Trump. Aides and others close to Obama have repeatedly stated that his desire is to allow a new crop of Democrats to take over the party.

Despite Obama's decision to stay out of primaries, his endorsement was seen as helpful in some races. Katie Merrill, who helps head up the super PAC Fight Back California, stated that Obama's endorsements "created quite a buzz and are very helpful to the candidates" in California.

However, Obama's decision to stay out of primaries has also left some former aides running for office without his endorsement. In Texas, for example, Ed Meier, who served as a State Department official under the Obama administration, fell short in a congressional primary. Similarly, Alison Kiehl Friedman, who was running for Congress in Virginia, and Sam Jammal, who was running for a seat in California, also failed to secure Obama's endorsement.

One top Obama fundraiser stated, "His endorsement during the primary would have changed the outcome of a number of races. Some of the candidates lost because the opposition used the lack of endorsements as a sign of weak job performance."

Some former aides and donors argue that Obama didn't want to choose sides and hear from allies of various candidates. The president still needs many fundraisers to help build his library and foundation.

However, others, such as Katie Merrill and Seth Bringman, a Democratic strategist based in Ohio, argue that Obama's endorsements were helpful to candidates in their respective states. Bringman stated, "Just knowing that their campaigns are on his radar energized volunteers and helped candidates raise money. There's even a little impatience to get him back on the trail, because he can come to any media market in the Buckeye State and help us get back a lot of the voters we lost in 2016."

Despite the controversy surrounding Obama's endorsement list, some strategists argue that his decision to stay out of primaries has hurt the party. One Democratic strategist stated, "I was on a call this morning where it was coming up a lot. I think a lot of people say it as lazy, a bit half-assed and a little too methodical. There are ramifications for this, and I hope we don't suffer the consequences. We can't just go red to blue. We need to make states blue for the long term."

"Now's not the time to sit out and be too cute by half," the strategist continued. "Where's the audacity of hope?"

Title: Court Sides with Ohio Business Owners Challenging Birth Control Mandate under ACA

Article:

A divided three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has sided with two Ohio business owners, Francis and Philip M. Gilardi, who challenged the birth control mandate under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) on religious grounds. The Gilardis, owners of Freshway Foods and Freshway Logistics of Sidney, Ohio, argue that the mandate to provide contraceptive coverage would force them to violate their Roman Catholic beliefs and moral values by providing contraceptives such as the morning-after pill for their employees.

The ruling, one of several on the birth control issue, is likely to be resolved by the Supreme Court. There are at least three other rulings by federal appeals courts on the mandate: one sided with Oklahoma businesses, and two sided with the Obama administration in challenges brought by Pennsylvania and Michigan companies.

Writing for the majority, Judge Janice Rogers Brown stated that the mandate "trammels the right of free exercise -- a right that lies at the core of our constitutional liberties -- as protected by the Religious Freedom Restoration Act."

Friday's ruling reversed a lower court ruling that had denied the Gilardis' request for a preliminary injunction to block the Department of Health and Human Services from enforcing the mandate against them as business owners. The appeals court ruled that the lower court erred when it concluded the Gilardis were unlikely to succeed on the merits, and sent the case back to the lower court to consider other factors for an injunction.

However, Brown upheld the lower court's dismissal of an injunction for the brothers' companies, writing, "we have no basis for concluding a secular organization can exercise religion."

In an opinion dissenting from the court's main holding in the case, Judge Harry T. Edwards wrote that legislative restrictions may trump religious exercise. He asked what, if the Gilardis' companies were exempted from covering contraception, would stop another company from seeking an exemption from a requirement to cover vaccines?

"The mandate does not require the Gilardis to encourage Freshway's employees to use contraceptives any more directly than they do by authorizing Freshway to pay wages," wrote Edwards. He added that the Gilardis remain free to publicly express their disapproval of contraceptives.

Coming from the other direction, Judge A. Raymond Randolph joined Brown's main conclusion about the Gilardis but dissented from her conclusions about Freshway companies' exercise of religion.

"Why limit the free-exercise right to religious organizations when many business corporations adhere to religious dogma?" asked Randolph. "If non-religious organizations do not have free-exercise rights, why do non-religious natural persons (atheists, for example) possess them?"

The Gilardis' lawyer, Francis Manion, senior counsel for the American Center for Law and Justice, an anti-abortion legal group that focuses on constitutional law, said he was pleased that the court accepted the "bulk" of his arguments, but will appeal the part of the ruling on the free exercise religious rights of corporations.

"It's a big victory, but not total," he said in a telephone interview.

In a statement, the Rev. Barry W. Lynn, executive director of Americans United, a church-state watchdog group, said the Friday's ruling turns "the concept of religious freedom on its head."

"Religious liberty means the right to make decisions for yourself, not other people," Lynn said. "Freedom of religion should never be a blank check to meddle in the personal medical decisions of others."

The Department of Health and Human Services was unable to comment on pending litigation.

Title: Former Presidents' Public Criticisms: A Comparative Analysis of Obama and Trump

Article:

In a recent series of public statements, former President Barack Obama has continued his criticisms of his successor, President Donald Trump. The former president's charges, however, have been paradoxical, as he seems to attribute Trump's successes to his own administration, while also criticizing Trump's policies as pernicious and failing.

Obama's economic policies during his tenure were markedly different from Trump's. Obama had argued that the U.S. could not drill its way out of oil shortages and advocated for making the use of coal expensive. In contrast, Trump has championed domestic fossil-fuel production, pipeline construction, and deregulation of fracking and horizontal drilling.

Economic indicators suggest that Trump's economic policies have been successful. Since Trump's election, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has climbed approximately 7,000 points, unemployment has hit near-record lows, wage gains are up, and the economy is growing. In 2016, economist and Obama supporter Paul Krugman predicted a global recession, but the U.S. economy is currently on track to match or exceed Trump's promise of 3% annualized GDP growth over a twelve-month period.

It is worth noting that, historically, presidents are held accountable for the state of the economy during their tenure, regardless of whether their policies had a direct impact on economic conditions. Trump ran on a platform of economic revitalization, promising deregulation, fair trade, and tax reform. His policies, if successful, could be seen as a vindication of his approach, while failures could be attributed to missteps in implementation.

As of now, it is too early to make definitive judgments about Trump's legacy. It may be prudent to wait until the end of his term before evaluating his administration's successes or failures. Similarly, former President Obama might benefit from taking a step back and allowing history to adjudicate his own economic and foreign policy record.

The contrasting worldviews of Obama and Trump offer a unique opportunity for historical analysis. History will ultimately decide whether a more managed or more deregulated economy works best, and whether a focus on traditional energy sources or an emphasis on subsidized green energy is preferable.

In the past, ex-presidents such as Ronald Reagan, George H.W. Bush, and George W. Bush have chosen to leave the political limelight at the end of their tenures, allowing history to be the judge of their relative successes or failures. Obama, like his predecessors Jimmy Carter, Bill Clinton, and Obama himself, has been more inclined to remain politically active and to engage in public discourse about his successor.

As of now, there are four living ex-presidents (Carter, Clinton, George W. Bush, and Obama) and five living former vice presidents (Walter Mondale, Dan Quayle, Al Gore, Dick Cheney, and Joe Biden). If all ex-presidents and ex-vice presidents were to weigh in nonstop on the current president and present-day politics, the result would be as chaotic as it would be boring. It may be wise for all former presidents to take a step back and allow history to be the final arbiter of their legacies.

Title: GOP Candidates' Inflammatory Language and American Political Polarization

Article:

The use of extreme rhetoric by Republican presidential candidates, notably Sen. Ted Cruz and Donald Trump, has sparked nationwide debates about American political polarization. The candidates' inflammatory language, such as Cruz's call for carpet-bombing the Islamic State group and Trump's characterization of Mexican immigrants as rapists and drug traffickers, has been a subject of media attention.

Frederick Mayer, professor of public policy, political science, and environment at Duke University, explained that the candidates have found a way to frame their message that resonates with the anxieties about American decline, threats from terrorists, and perceived threats to the American way of life.

In his State of the Union address last Tuesday, President Barack Obama assured Americans that the country is not in decline, despite inflammatory claims. He stated, "I told you earlier all the talk of America’s economic decline is political hot air. Well, so is all the rhetoric you hear about our enemies getting stronger and America getting weaker. Let me tell you something—the United States of America is the most powerful nation on Earth, period."

Mayer noted that factors such as low unemployment, low crime levels, and fewer instances of terrorism on American soil should also ease the anxiety of Americans. He said, "It’s ironic because you can make the claim that we have less to fear today than just about any people in any time in history."

Junior Adam Lemon, president of the Duke College Republicans, said that extreme rhetoric was necessary for the success of Trump and Cruz in a field of more than 15 candidates, where standing out in any way was imperative. He also noted that cable news has used stories about Trump to boost ratings.

Freshman Steve Hassey, communications director for Duke Democrats, said that Trump's polarizing nature contributes to the mass coverage of him, making the news even more polarizing.

Both Lemon and Mayer discussed how news can have a negative impact when it focuses on polarizing comments. However, Mayer expressed optimism that bipartisan reform is possible and will occur on certain issues. On campus, there have been a few bipartisan discussions, such as the Battle of the Brains debate between college Democrats and Republicans hosted by Duke Student Government last November.

Despite the bipartisan discussions, Lemon noted that there are barriers to fostering discussion between students of opposing political parties on campus. He said, "There are a lot more liberals on campus than conservatives. Liberals tend to talk amongst themselves. Conservatives are afraid to express their opinions, so they don’t really talk, and neither side is really willing to engage too much."

Mayer attributed the polarization and the lack of engagement between the two sides to something more than just extreme rhetoric. He said, "At some deep level, many of the problems we’ve been talking about are really manifestations of a loss of trust in each other, in our institutions, and the like. This whole dysfunction is a trust problem. We stopped trusting institutions. We don’t trust politicians. A world where you have very little trust is a much less functional world."

Title: U.S. Senator Tammy Duckworth Criticizes President Trump's Actions Regarding Peaceful Protesters and Military

Article:

U.S. Senator Tammy Duckworth, a former U.S. Army lieutenant colonel and combat veteran of the Iraq War, has criticized President Donald Trump's actions regarding peaceful protesters and the use of the military. In a statement, Duckworth expressed her disapproval of the president's actions during the recent protests in Washington D.C., stating that Trump had violated the First Amendment rights of Americans to peaceably assemble for a redress of grievances.

During the protests, federal law enforcement forcibly removed Americans, including a priest and seminarian, to clear a path for the president during a photo-op. Duckworth argued that Trump's actions revealed his contempt for the truly faithful and disrespected the troops by threatening to exploit the military to achieve political goals.

Secretary of Defense Mark Esper and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Mark A. Milley, were also criticized by Duckworth for their actions during the protests. Duckworth stated that Esper's excuse that he didn't know where he was going was not an exoneration, but rather a "downright chilling" demonstration of blindly following the president when he violates the Constitution.

Duckworth also expressed her disappointment in Republican Senator Tom Cotton, who defended Trump's threats in the New York Times, suggesting that he would pervert what the military stands for to earn a slap on the back from the current occupant of the Oval Office.

Duckworth concluded her statement by emphasizing the importance of the ballot box as the last off-ramp for Americans to make their views known and to prevent any commander in chief from using the military to silence their neighbors and drive further wedges between Americans. Duckworth stated that Americans deserve a commander in chief who unites the nation, not one who abuses the military to push the country further apart.

Title: Franklin Graham Criticizes Robert Gates for Reversing Boy Scouts' Gay Scoutmaster Ban

The prominent evangelist Franklin Graham has denounced Robert Gates, the President of the Boy Scouts of America, for his call to end the organization's ban on openly gay scoutmasters. In a post on Facebook, Graham accused Gates of putting children at risk and lacking the moral courage to uphold traditional values.

Gates, the former Secretary of Defense, made his remarks at the Boy Scouts' annual meeting in Atlanta on Thursday. He stated that the status quo in the organization's membership standards could not be sustained, and called the ban on openly gay scoutmasters unsustainable.

Gates clarified that he would not revoke the membership charters of any local troops known to have gay adults in supervisory roles. This apparent reference to a New York chapter hiring an openly gay scoutmaster this spring prompted Graham's response.

"Robert Gates, shame on you for not having the moral courage to do what is right," Graham wrote. He expressed concern that the organization was bending to LGBT activist groups and could put young, innocent boys at risk.

Gates stated that he was not asking the organization's board to make an immediate policy change at the annual meeting. However, he emphasized the need for change, stating, "I must speak as plainly and bluntly to you as I spoke to presidents when I was director of CIA and secretary of defense."

Gates oversaw the repeal of the "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy, which allowed openly gay service members in the U.S. armed forces, while he was at the Pentagon. He was elected as the Boy Scouts' president in 2014, after the organization voted in 2013 to allow openly gay scouts.

Advocates for gay scouts have cheered Gates' remarks, while others have expressed ambivalence. David Barton, an Orange County, California, cubmaster and father of two boys in scouting, told the Los Angeles Times, "It would be silly to think that a higher percentage of gay men want to do harm to boys than straight men, but I still have concerns about gay scout leaders accompanying boys on camping trips."

The Boy Scouts of America has faced criticism and lost partnerships with companies such as Lockheed Martin and Walt Disney due to the ban on openly gay scoutmasters. The organization's decision to potentially lift the ban remains a contentious issue, with supporters and opponents voicing their opinions on both sides.

Title: Trump Campaign Launches "Impeachment Defense Task Force," Promises Doubtful Fundraising Incentives

Article:

In response to the growing calls for impeachment from Democratic lawmakers, President Donald Trump's reelection campaign has launched an "Impeachment Defense Task Force" and initiated a fundraising campaign. The email, sent out Tuesday afternoon, solicits donations to support the president and promises to add donors to the "Official Impeachment Defense Task Force."

The email also claims that immediate contributions will be "double matched," a claim that is unlikely to be true due to federal campaign finance laws that impose strict limits on political donations. The Trump campaign did not respond to questions about the "Official Impeachment Defense Task Force," how many donors had joined, or how it plans to "double-match" contributions.

The number of Democrats calling for impeachment has gradually increased over the summer, but as recently as last week, this step was still opposed by the Democratic Party leadership. Following revelations that Trump pressured Ukraine's president to investigate discredited allegations against Joe Biden and withheld military aid from the country to ramp up pressure, dozens of Democratic lawmakers joined the call to begin impeachment proceedings.

Ahead of a 5 p.m. press conference Tuesday afternoon, at which House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is expected to publicly call for an impeachment inquiry, the Trump campaign fired off its fundraising pitch. The email states that the "Impeachment claims have nothing to do with the President - the Democrats thrive on silencing and intimidating his supporters, like YOU." It goes on to say, "We won't stand for this any longer, and neither should you."

The email also suggests that by donating to the campaign, supporters would be defending the very integrity of America: "As a member of the Official Impeachment Defense Task Force, you will be a leader in defending the President against these baseless and disgusting attacks. You will be responsible for defending American Greatness. The future of American freedom rests on the shoulders of men and women willing to defend it from these hateful attacks, and today is a day for action."

The fundraising appeal claimed that Trump had personally requested to see a list of people who had joined his "Official Impeachment Defense Taskforce" and urged donors to send their money before 3:30 p.m., when the list was supposedly to be sent to the president. Shortly after the deadline passed, Trump's campaign sent a nearly identical email, this one saying the deadline was 4 p.m.

Campaigns have fairly wide latitude to make promises in campaign fundraising emails, so Team Trump's claims of an official "Task Force" or that Trump would personally review the names of donors don't have to be true. Another suspect claim: the email's pledge that donations would be "double-matched."

Donor match programs are common in the nonprofit fundraising world and are considered to be highly effective in encouraging donors who might be on the fence about giving. In the nonprofit world, a match program typically involves a one or several particularly generous donors, who are poised to write big checks if smaller donors start giving. However, in the political sphere, federal campaign finance laws make things a little more complicated, since individual donors are legally capped at giving no more than $5,400 to a campaign per election cycle. That means a single generous donor can't "match" new small donations. If a campaign wants to raise money on any large scale, even a handful of generous matching donors won't work—hundreds or thousands would be necessary. It's unlikely that would really happen.

Title: Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus to Close After Over a Century of Operation

Article:

The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, a staple of American entertainment for over a century, has announced its closure, according to a press release from Feld Entertainment, the company that has owned the circus for the past 50 years.

In the statement, CEO Kenneth Feld explained, "I have made the difficult business decision that Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey® will hold its final performances in May of this year."

The decision was attributed to high operating costs and the decline of ticket sales, which made the circus an unsustainable business for the company. Feld further elaborated, "After the transition of the elephants off the road, we saw an even more dramatic drop in ticket sales."

Before taking its final bow, the Ringling Bros. circus will perform 30 shows across the United States between now and May. The exact date and location of the final performance have not been disclosed.

Title: Bipartisan Praise for Sen. Orrin Hatch Amidst Political Tensions

Article:

In a rare moment of bipartisan unity, the United States Senate recognized Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-UT) as the longest-serving Republican senator in history on Thursday. The occasion, which saw the majority and minority leaders put down their swords, marked a brief pause in the ongoing partisan tensions that have characterized the new Congress.

Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY), the Republican leader, praised Sen. Hatch, not only for his political career but also for his work as a songwriter, with gold and platinum albums to his name. The Democratic leader, Sen. Charles Schumer (D-NY), described Sen. Hatch as a "terrific guy" and an "honorable man," acknowledging his ability to work across the aisle despite deep ideological differences.

Sen. Hatch, in his response, expressed a "gee, shucks" attitude towards the praise and pleaded for patience with President Trump and for senators to work together. He expressed concern about the state of the Senate and the presidency, stating, "I'm concerned about this body and how it's going. I'm also concerned about the president."

Sen. Hatch also praised President Trump's cabinet choices and asked the Senate to be "a little bit considerate in criticizing" the president, as he is a brand new president coming out of the private sector. He also expressed hope for a reduction in political animosities, stating, "I'm hoping that we can set aside some of these animosities, give the president his cabinet and his leaders, so that he has at least a shot at pulling this country out of the mess it's in."

The slow pace of confirming cabinet nominees was a point of concern for Sen. Hatch, who expressed a desire for the Senate to continue its debates and arguments while maintaining a sense of comradeship and working together. He also invoked his work with the late Sen. Edward Kennedy (D-MA) and their ability to find common ground despite their ideological differences.

Sen. Hatch also praised both Sen. McConnell and Schumer, stating, "These are two really potentially great leaders. Together, they could really help us save this country." He concluded by expressing a desire for the Senate to continue its political debates but not let them consume everything, stating, "We have to have some politics here or this would be an uninteresting body. But we don't have to have it on everything."

Sen. Schumer acknowledged Sen. Hatch's service to the country and thanked him for his kind words. The Senate adjourned at 2:30 a.m., having tussled its way to a party-line confirmation of Tom Price as the next secretary of Health and Human Services. The political winds resumed, and the party differences flared once again.

Title: Trump Family Files Lawsuit Against Deutsche Bank and Capital One to Block House Subpoenas

Article:

President Donald Trump and several family members have filed a lawsuit against Deutsche Bank and Capital One to block subpoenas issued by House Democrats seeking the president's financial records. The lawsuit, filed on Monday in New York, argues that the subpoenas serve "no legitimate or lawful purpose."

The lawsuit, which is the latest escalation in Trump's fight against mounting House investigations, claims that the subpoenas are designed to "rummage through every aspect" of the president's personal finances, businesses, and private information. House Financial Services Chair Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) and House Intelligence Chair Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) have described the lawsuit as a "meritless lawsuit" not designed to succeed but to delay accountability.

Democrats have said they are seeking Trump's financial records as part of investigations into potential foreign influence on the U.S. political process and the abuse of the U.S. financial system for illicit purposes. Deutsche Bank, a German lender that has served as Trump's go-to lender for years, has faced scrutiny for money-laundering scandals.

The lawsuit was filed on behalf of the president, his sons Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump, his daughter Ivanka Trump, and the Trump Organization. Deutsche Bank intends to begin producing documents in response to the subpoena on May 6, and Capital One also feels obligated to comply before May 6 absent court intervention, according to the lawsuit.

The lawsuit describes a sweeping inquiry into the Trump family's finances going back decades. The two banks provide the Trumps with numerous "personal, family, and business accounts." The committees, the Trumps' lawyers said, have refused to provide copies of the subpoenas to the Trump family, and their scope was learned from Deustche Bank and Capital One. The committees are seeking "all banking and financial records not just concerning the individual plaintiffs, but also their own family members," according to the lawsuit.

The lawsuit also claims that the subpoenas violate the Right to Financial Privacy Act. Lawyers representing the Trumps include Marc Mukasey, a former law firm partner of Rudy Giuliani's, the president's personal lawyer. In a statement, Mukasey and Patrick Strawbridge, who is also representing the Trumps in the case, said the lawsuit was filed to "protect the privacy rights of the President, his family, and their businesses."

Monday's lawsuit comes a week after the president asked a federal court to block the House Oversight and Reform Committee's subpoena to accounting firm Mazars USA. The Democrat-led committee subpoenaed the firm to obtain eight years of Trump's financial records. The Oversight Committee said it needs the documents in order to corroborate testimony from former Trump attorney and fixer Michael Cohen, who alleged that the president artificially inflated and deflated the value of his assets for his personal benefit.

During an explosive public hearing in February, Cohen disclosed copies of Trump's financial statements, which he said were turned over to Deutsche Bank as Trump was seeking a loan to place a bid on an NFL team, the Buffalo Bills. Those statements, according to Cohen, contained false information. The committee has requested similar records from Capital One, which asked for a "friendly" subpoena before it could comply.

On Capitol Hill, Republicans have rushed to Trump's defense amid the onslaught of investigations and subpoenas, claiming Democrats are abusing their authority to take down the president and eventually impeach him. Democratic leaders remain opposed to launching impeachment proceedings against Trump, preferring instead to continue investigating the president for obstruction of justice allegations and financial misdeeds.

Title: Jury in Paul Manafort Trial Sends Four Questions to Judge During Deliberations

Article:

The jury in the trial of former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort has yet to reach a verdict, with deliberations ongoing as of Thursday evening. The jury sent four questions to Judge T.S. Ellis III during the day, but he answered only two of them.

One question pertained to the charges related to Manafort's offshore accounts, which contained tens of millions of dollars. Prosecutors charged Manafort with four counts of failing to file a Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR), a legally required form to disclose foreign holdings to the U.S. government. The jury inquired about the FBAR filing requirements if a person owned less than 50% of a company and had no signatory authority. Judge Ellis answered this question, stating that if a person controlled the disposition of money from the account or if the listed owner of the account was acting as an agent for that person, the person would be legally required to file an FBAR.

Another question concerned the definition of a "shelf company," a term used to describe Manafort's complex offshore holdings structured as inactive companies in Cyprus. The jury asked for the definition of a shelf company, but Judge Ellis declined to answer, instructing the jury to rely on their collective recollection.

Jurors also asked Judge Ellis to define the concept of "reasonable doubt" again, as Manafort's lawyers emphasized during their closing argument that the prosecution must prove his guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, a high and difficult standard to meet. Judge Ellis answered this question by telling jurors that prosecutors do not have to prove their case beyond "all possible doubt," but instead beyond doubt that is based on reason.

Lastly, the jury asked whether they could get a list of which particular pieces of evidence are said to match up with each of the 18 separate charges against Manafort. Judge Ellis declined to provide such a list. The jury's deliberations will continue on Friday.

Title: New IRS Commissioner Vows to Restore Trust, Address Scandals

Article:

In his first appearance before a Congressional committee, newly appointed Internal Revenue Service (IRS) Commissioner Daniel Werfel has pledged to restore trust in the tax collection agency, following allegations of political targeting of conservative groups. Werfel, who has been in office for 12 days, has ordered a review of a "broad spectrum of IRS operations" and installed new leadership at several critical levels of the IRS.

During Monday's hearing of the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Subcommittee, Werfel called the conduct "inappropriate and unacceptable." The hearing followed the release of a report in May by the IRS Inspector General, which revealed that during the 2010 and 2012 elections, groups with conservative-sounding names that applied for tax-exempt status were singled out for extended questioning by an IRS office in Cincinnati.

The hearing saw members of Congress from both parties criticizing IRS misconduct. Rep. Hal Rogers (R) of Kentucky, chairman of the full appropriations committee, stated that the IRS "has committed grave violations of the public trust" and that "we will not tolerate another political enemies list."

In addition to the political targeting allegations, the IRS is facing scrutiny over "incredible waste" in IRS spending on employee conferences and videos. The Inspector General's office is scheduled to release a report on the conferences on Tuesday, which the Associated Press reports will show the IRS spent $50 million to hold 220 employee conferences between 2010 and 2012.

Among the embarrassing evidence is a video showing IRS employees dancing to the rhythm and blues song "Cupid Shuffle" at a 2010 conference. Rep. Rita Lowey (D) of New York, the ranking Democrat on the full Appropriations Committee, said reports of the spending on employee conferences left her "simply wondering what the IRS was thinking."

The IRS scandals come at an especially sensitive time for the agency, as it will play a key role in implementing the Affordable Care Act, President Obama's signature legislative achievement. The Obama administration is seeking a 9 percent increase in IRS funding for the federal budget year that starts in October. Representative Crenshaw said Congress would have to "think very carefully about how much money to provide the IRS."

At Monday's hearing, Commissioner Werfel stated, "The solution here is not more money." He said "the right starting point is" finding the "optimal footprint" for agency operations and only then turning to the question of agency funding.

The political impact of the controversy has been on display. On CNN's "State of the Union" Sunday, Rep. Darrell Issa (R) of California said interviews with workers in the Cincinnati IRS office show the targeting of conservative groups was "a problem that was coordinated in all likelihood right out of Washington headquarters – and we're getting to proving it."

Representative Lowey asked IRS Inspector General J. Russell George whether there was evidence that the targeting of conservative groups was ordered by the White House. "Within the White House, no," Mr. George replied.

Congressional scrutiny of the agency will continue. The House Ways and Means Committee will hold a hearing Tuesday featuring representatives from conservative groups that were targeted by the IRS. As ABC News' "The Note" reports, some of those groups filed a joint lawsuit against the agency last week.

Later in the week, the Inspector General will appear before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform to discuss his audit of IRS spending on employee gatherings. Material from the Associated Press was used in compiling this report.

Title: U.S. Embassy in Baghdad Under Siege by Iraqi Protesters, Airstrikes in Iraq and Syria Follow

Article:

Crowds of Iraqi protesters, some reportedly wearing militia uniforms, stormed the U.S. Embassy compound in Baghdad on Tuesday, prompting U.S. guards to fire tear gas in response. The protesters set up tents outside the embassy, intending to stage a sit-in "until American troops leave Iraq and the embassy is closed."

The embassy attack followed deadly U.S. airstrikes on Sunday that killed 25 fighters of the Iran-backed group, Kataeb Hezbollah. The U.S. military said the airstrikes were in retaliation for last week's killing of an American contractor in a rocket attack on an Iraqi military base, which the U.S. blamed on the militia.

Military jet fighters conducted "precision defensive strikes" on five sites belonging to Kataeb Hezbollah, according to Jonathan Hoffman, a spokesperson for the Pentagon. Two defense officials added that Air Force F-15 jet fighters carried out the strikes.

As of Tuesday night, about 100 Marines were being sent to the embassy to bolster security, and an Army Apache helicopter flew over the premises and dropped flares in a "show of force" to disperse the crowd.

Dozens of protesters came within 200 yards of the embassy after busting through an entrance used by cars. The mob shouted "Down, Down USA!" as they hurled water and stones over the embassy's walls. They raised yellow militia flags and taunted the embassy's security staff who remained behind the glass windows in the gates' reception area. The mob also sprayed red graffiti on the wall and windows, in support of the Kataeb Hezbollah, reading: "Closed in the name of the resistance."

No one was immediately reported hurt in the rampage, and security staff withdrew inside the embassy when protesters started to gather outside. The embassy, on its Facebook page, urged American citizens not to approach the compound and "to review their personal security and emergency preparedness."

U.S. officials have stated that the U.S. ambassador and staff were not evacuated, despite initial reports suggesting otherwise. A State Department spokesperson later told Fox News that "U.S. personnel are secure." Secretary of Defense Mark Esper added, "We have taken appropriate force protection actions to ensure the safety of American citizens, military personnel, and diplomats in country, and to ensure our right of self-defense. We are sending additional forces to support our personnel at the Embassy."

As tempers rose, the mob also set fire to three trailers used by security guards along the embassy wall. Iraq's interior minister, Yassine al-Yasseri, appeared outside the embassy at one point and walked around to inspect the scene. He told the Associated Press that the prime minister had warned the U.S. strikes on the Shiite militiamen would have serious consequences.

"This is one of the implications," al-Yasseri said. "This is a problem and is embarrassing to the government." He added that more security would be deployed to separate the protesters from the embassy, an indication the Iraqi troops would not move in to break up the crowd by force.

Seven armored vehicles with about 30 Iraqi soldiers arrived near the embassy hours after the violence erupted, deploying near the embassy walls but not close to the breached area. Four vehicles carrying riot police approached the embassy later but were forced back by the protesters who blocked their path.

Sen. Marco Rubio took to Twitter Tuesday and said Iran was directly responsible for orchestrating the breach. U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also stated that Sunday's strikes send the message that the U.S. will not tolerate actions by Iran that jeopardize American lives.

Title: Hillary Clinton Outlines Four Priorities for First 100 Days as President

Article:

In the run-up to the American presidential election, Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton has outlined her four priorities for her first 100 days in office. The following are the key issues she intends to address:

1. Job Creation and Infrastructure Investment: Clinton plans to invest in infrastructure and manufacturing to stimulate economic growth. This investment will focus on renewable energy, with the goal of powering every home in America within a decade. Additionally, she aims to cut red tape for small businesses and make it easier for entrepreneurs to secure credit. The funding for these initiatives will come from increased taxes on the wealthy, Wall Street, and large corporations.

2. Comprehensive Immigration Reform: Clinton intends to work with Congress to pass comprehensive immigration reform, similar to the legislation signed by President Ronald Reagan. The proposed reform will keep families together, create a path to citizenship, secure the border, and focus enforcement resources on violent criminals.

3. Campaign Finance Reform: Within her first 30 days in office, Clinton plans to introduce a constitutional amendment to overturn the Citizens United decision, which allows corporations to donate to political campaigns. She believes that this move will protect citizens' right to vote and not allow corporations to buy elections.

4. Criminal Justice Reform: Clinton is committed to addressing the issue of mass incarceration by reforming the criminal justice system. She believes that the country will be stronger and safer when everyone respects the law and is respected by the law.

Clinton emphasizes that these priorities are not exhaustive and that there is much more work to be done. She aims to work with Americans of all political affiliations, races, and backgrounds to achieve these goals.

Clinton's opponent, Donald Trump, has run a divisive campaign, according to Clinton. She encourages voters to consider the kind of change they want for the country, emphasizing that the election is not just about the candidates but about the values and direction of the nation.

Title: House Intelligence Committee Launches Second Phase of Probe into Origins of Anti-Trump Dossier

Article:

The House Intelligence Committee, led by Chairman Devin Nunes (R-Calif.), has initiated "Phase 2" of its investigation into the origins of the unverified anti-Trump dossier. In a letter obtained by Fox News, Nunes posed a series of dossier-related questions to current and former intelligence, law enforcement, and State Department officials.

The Feb. 20-dated letter, which threatens subpoenas if answers are not provided voluntarily, seeks information on when the officials learned the document was funded by Democratic sources and how it was used to obtain one or more surveillance warrants at the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court.

Nunes, with cooperation from the White House, earlier this month released a controversial memo alleging the anti-Trump dossier, compiled by former British spy Christopher Steele and funded by the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton campaign, was crucial in the application for a surveillance warrant against Trump associate Carter Page.

The new letter includes a dozen questions about the dossier, including how the officials in question learned of the document's Democratic funding and whether they held meetings about the unverified allegations against Trump or took any other official action. Fox News understands the questionnaire went out to about two dozen current and former officials.

Among them were former FBI Director James Comey, former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, and former CIA Director John Brennan, who testified in May 2017 that the Trump dossier was virtually unknown to him.

The newly released GOP memo states that the FBI and Justice Department relied heavily on the Trump dossier and downplayed its Democratic roots. A source close to the investigation is not ruling out the possibility that more officials could be questioned as the next phase of the probe continues.

Perhaps anticipating this phase of the investigation, an Obama State Department official earlier this month acknowledged he had regular contact with the dossier's author. In a Washington Post column, Jonathan Winer detailed an extensive exchange of documents with Steele, a friend of his since 2009. He said he shared "more than 100 of Steele's reports with the Russia experts at the State Department" over a period of two years. These weren't related to American politics – but he would later share information about the Trump dossier with the top levels of the Obama State Department.

Further, Winer said he shared separate Trump-related material passed on by a Clinton contact with Steele. And he acknowledged that material, originally from Clinton-tied activist/journalist Cody Shearer, made its way to the FBI. In publishing his Op-Ed, Winer wrote that he suspects Nunes wants to know about his own relationship with Steele while at the Obama State Department.

A spokesman for the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, Adam Schiff, said the California lawmaker was unavailable for an interview.

Title: Tulsa Rally Attendances Low: Implications for Trump's Reelection Bid

Article:

President Donald Trump's rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, on Saturday saw significantly lower attendance than anticipated, with approximately 6,200 people attending, despite claims of over a million ticket requests. The event, intended to reignite his reelection campaign, was marred by empty seats and an unused second stage.

Various explanations have been proposed for the low turnout. The president's campaign attributed the low numbers to protesters blocking supporters from entering the arena, a claim refuted by reporters on the ground. Reports also suggest that some TikTok users, with no intention of attending, reserved tickets. Health concerns due to the ongoing pandemic may also have contributed to the low attendance.

The event's impact on Trump's reelection prospects is a subject of debate. Some observers view the low turnout in a state Trump won by 36 points in 2016 as a sign of eroding enthusiasm among his base supporters. With the public disapproving of Trump's handling of the pandemic and Black Lives Matter protests, Joe Biden has built a lead in national and swing state polls. The Tulsa event could have been an opportunity to reverse this trend, but instead, it may have reinforced the narrative of a campaign in crisis, some political analysts argue.

Critics and allies alike agree that the rally was a letdown. However, there is significant disagreement over its implications for Trump's reelection chances. Some argue that the small crowd size indicates a shrinking base of devoted supporters, while others caution against drawing too many conclusions from a single event, especially during uncertain times.

The content of Trump's speech has also been a point of contention. The speech's focus on his walking awkwardly down a ramp and his claim of advising his coronavirus task force to "slow the testing down" to keep the number of positive cases lower has drawn criticism. Some argue that the speech lacked a clear case for why voters should want him in office for another four years.

Elections, it is argued, are not determined by rally crowd sizes. Concern over the virus may have kept many Trump supporters from attending the rally, but it may not have the same impact on Election Day. Trump's reelection chances will hinge on his ability to manage the economic, public health, and social crises currently gripping the country, some experts argue. If he is able to do so effectively, a poorly attended rally months before the election will likely be mostly forgotten.

Trump held small campaign events in Arizona focused on border security on Tuesday. His campaign is planning upcoming rallies in Florida, Texas, and North Carolina, with dates yet to be set.

Quotes:

- Jonathan Allen, NBC News: "To explain how he might be able to win despite poor polling numbers — and amid national crises — he has posited that a ‘ silent majority ’ of Americans backs him. But the poor turnout suggests just the opposite — that enthusiasm for him is weaker than it appears."
- Kevin Liptak and Kaitlan Collins, CNN: "Once viewed inside the White House and Trump’s campaign as a reset button for a presidency beset by crises and self-inflicted wounds, Saturday evening’s campaign rally in Tulsa instead became plagued with pitfalls, a disappointing microcosm of the blindspots, denial, and wishful thinking that have come to guide the president as he enters one of the most precarious moments of his first term."

Title: John Kerry Holds First Calls as Secretary of State with Leaders from Israel, Palestine, and Other Countries

Article:

In his first weekend as the 68th U.S. Secretary of State, John Kerry spoke with leaders from Israel, the Palestinian Authority, Japan, South Korea, Turkey, Mexico, and Canada. The conversations, detailed in a readout released by the State Department on Sunday, covered various international issues, including the Middle East peace process, terrorist attacks, and the Keystone XL pipeline.

Kerry's first call was with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, discussing the recent Israeli elections and the Middle East peace process. He also spoke with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas about Israeli-Palestinian relations and pledged to continue efforts with Congress to send funds to the authority.

The following day, Kerry spoke with Israeli President Shimon Peres, whom he has known since he was a freshman senator. On Sunday, he conversed with Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida and South Korean Foreign Minister Kim Sung-hwan.

Kerry also spoke with Turkish Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu on Saturday, discussing Friday's terrorist attack on the perimeter of the U.S. Embassy in Ankara. Davutoglu updated Kerry on the investigation of the suicide bomber who killed himself and one other. The bomber was identified by Istanbul police as Ecevit Sanli, a member of the Marxist Leninist organization known as the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party, or DHKP-C, which the U.S. government and others label a terrorist organization.

Kerry and Davutoglu also discussed the violent unrest in Syria and broader Middle East issues. On Saturday, Kerry spoke with Mexican Foreign Secretary Jose Meade, expressing condolences for those killed and injured in Thursday's explosion at the offices of the state oil company, Pemex, in Mexico City. President Enrique Peña Nieto posted on Twitter Sunday afternoon that a 35th body had been found.

Canadian Foreign Minister John Baird was also on the list of phone calls Saturday. They agreed to stay in touch on the Keystone XL pipeline, which would extend from Canada's tar sands down to the Gulf of Mexico. Construction on the southern portion of the pipeline has already begun, while the northern leg in the United States awaits approval.

Kerry had a discussion Saturday with former Secretary of State George Shultz, who served under President Ronald Reagan. According to State Department spokeswoman Victoria Nuland, Kerry has now met with or spoken by phone with each living secretary of state.

These conversations took place after President Barack Obama announced Kerry as his nominee on December 21.

Title: Republicans Slightly Favorable in Senate Takeover Bid, According to New York Times Analysis

Article:

The latest nonpartisan polling, including a YouGov online panel published on Sunday, indicates that the Republican Party has a 60% chance of capturing the six seats needed to regain control of the U.S. Senate, according to The New York Times. The most likely outcome, as per the Times' forecasting model, is a Republican gain of six seats, which would result in a 51-to-49-seat majority. However, the Times notes that a gain of anywhere from four to eight seats is also possible.

The Times' model takes into account surveys, fundraising data, and other factors such as candidates' political experience, a state's past election results, and national polling, with varying weights assigned to each factor based on the races being analyzed.

The YouGov poll suggests that the Republicans have made gains in Michigan, Georgia, and North Carolina, but these shifts are offset by positive numbers for the Democrats in Colorado and Alaska, according to the Times. In addition, the Republicans have a slight lead in Arkansas, Louisiana, North Carolina, Iowa, and Michigan, according to the highest quality data, as per the Times. However, the Republican advantage in these states is not significant, suggesting that the races remain competitive.

The Times emphasizes the importance of polling techniques in the accuracy of predictions. Most polls still use traditional random-digit dialing to reach a sample of people by phone, but declining response rates are leading to less accurate predictions. Young voters and nonwhite voters, who are least likely to own a landline or respond to telephone pollsters, are underrepresented in these polls, leading to inaccurate predictions.

The YouGov survey, being the first set of data from an online panel this year, is likely to be more accurate than traditional methods, according to the Times. The Times concludes, "Republicans appear to have narrow leads in enough states to win the Senate, but only narrow leads."

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Calls Special Senate Election Amidst Political Speculation

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's decision to call a special election on October 16 to fill the vacant Senate seat left by the late Democratic Senator Frank Lautenberg has sparked political speculation. The move, according to Christie, was primarily driven by the need for immediate representation in the U.S. Senate.

During a press conference on Tuesday, Christie emphasized the importance of having a representative in the Senate, stating, "The citizens of New Jersey need to have an elected representative to the U.S. Senate, and have it as soon as possible."

However, some critics argue that Christie's decision was strategically motivated, aiming to secure a larger margin in his re-election bid in November. The theory suggests that by scheduling the special and general elections on separate dates, Christie hoped to minimize the potential impact of Newark Mayor Cory Booker, a Democratic candidate for the Senate seat, on the November election.

The separate elections will reportedly cost New Jersey taxpayers approximately $12 million more than if both elections were held on the same day. In response to these costs, Christie stated, "The cost associated with having a special primary and general election, in my mind, can not be measured against the value of having an elected representative in the United States Senate when so many consequential issues are being debated and determined this year."

Despite some skepticism, Christie's explanation for the decision has been met with a degree of plausibility. The governor is running for a second term and is rumored to have White House ambitions. However, the political implications of the decision remain a topic of discussion among political analysts and the public.

Title: Obama and Xi Agree on Cyberattacks and South China Sea, but Challenges Remain

Article:

Presidents Barack Obama and Xi Jinping of the United States and China, respectively, have agreed on two of the most contentious issues during their summit in Washington: alleged Chinese cyberattacks on U.S. entities and China's island-building in the South China Sea. The commitments from Beijing have temporarily staved off the threat of U.S. sanctions on Chinese entities over cyberattacks and robust military action around China's artificial islands.

President Xi's words need to be followed by swift Chinese actions, U.S. officials cautioned, as President Xi headed to New York to attend U.N. meetings for the final three days of his weeklong U.S. visit. The first state visit to the U.S. by President Xi has been overshadowed by mounting U.S. concerns on these two issues, as well as China's handling of an economic slowdown and its commitment to open its market further to U.S. firms.

President Obama directly accused Beijing of engaging in cybertheft from U.S. companies, stating at the joint news conference, "It has to stop."
