President Xi denied China's involvement in the theft of commercial secrets or other hacking and said the proper approach was to strengthen cooperation to avoid confrontations and not to politicize the issue.

The U.S. and China announced an agreement not to direct or support cyberattacks that steal corporate records for economic benefit, likely staving off the immediate prospect of U.S. sanctions. However, it wasn't clear how effective the measures would be. "The question now is, are words followed by action?" said President Obama. "We will be watching carefully as to make an assessment as to whether progress has been made in this area."

U.S. officials reacted with similar caution to President Xi's apparent commitment for the first time not to "militarize" the islands Beijing has been building in the South China Sea, where several of China's neighbors have conflicting territorial claims. President Obama had pressed President Xi to freeze island-building in the Spratly chain, which has raised concern in the U.S. and among its allies about Beijing's military ambitions.

At the news conference, President Xi repeated China's long-standing position that it has had sovereignty over the South China Sea islands "since ancient times." President Xi added, "Relevant construction activities that China is undertaking in the [Spratly] islands do not target or impact any country and China does not intend to pursue militarization."

A senior U.S. administration official said President Xi's commitment was new, although it sounded similar to statements made by lower-level officials to Secretary of State John Kerry over the summer. "It is new language," said Bonnie Glaser, an expert on the Chinese military at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. "Unclear what he means by militarization, however. Hopefully, there's some detail. No fighters using the airstrips? No deployment of missiles?"

Satellite imagery released Friday showed that China had recently completed a runway on one of its artificial islands, which could allow it to accelerate construction and begin air patrols in the area, according to IHS Jane's Defence Weekly. China has said in recent months that its new facilities on the islands are designed to improve living conditions, marine safety, and weather monitoring, but would also be used for military purposes.

U.S. officials say China's facilities could be used to enforce territorial claims in the area and to establish an air defense identification zone over much of the South China Sea. President Obama voiced concern over the issue, saying China is "now a powerhouse and that means it's got responsibilities" to help uphold international rules. "That's part of the deal of being on the world stage when you're a big country...You've got more to do," he said.

Outside the White House were hundreds of demonstrators, about half supporters of President Xi and the rest detractors calling on the U.S. president to raise human rights concerns with his Chinese counterpart. President Xi's supporters wore red shirts with a bald eagle and a panda holding up peace signs that said "China, U.S.A. partner to win-win," a phrase adopted from the Chinese leader's words. The protesters included a group seeking independence from China for Tibet and another speaking out against President Xi's treatment of Uighurs in northwestern China. Their roars were audible during the televised news conference.

Before appearing in the Rose Garden, the two leaders rolled out a stack of agreements, including the cyber measure and a climate-change pledge from Beijing to cap some emissions and put a price on carbon. The two sides also made progress this week toward what could someday be a far-ranging trade and investment agreement that would open up closed sectors of China's economy, U.S. officials said. In talks connected with President Xi's visit, senior U.S. officials said they were able to get China to shrink the list of sectors it is seeking to exclude from the framework, known as a bilateral investment treaty. The U.S. and China have held intense negotiations over cybersecurity measures after a series of computer breaches the White House has blamed on Beijing. U.S. officials have prepared economic sanctions against Chinese companies they believe benefited from information stolen as part of the cyberattacks, but have held off on implementing them. Moments after he welcomed President Xi to the White House, President Obama pledged to "candidly" address issues on which he and his Chinese counterpart disagree. President Xi, who was treated to a formal arrival ceremony that included military honor guards and a 21-gun salute, said the U.S. and China are building a new model for major country relations and called for the pursuit of "win-win cooperation." Some critics said President Obama should not have given President Xi the honors of a state visit, given U.S. concerns about China's economic policies and allegations that Chinese hackers have stolen sensitive data from American corporations. But the White House hoped that engaging President Xi, rather than shunning him, would yield cooperation on cybersecurity and reassurances that China is committed to its promised economic reforms. Messrs. Obama and Xi began their discussions Thursday night with a private dinner at the Blair House, the presidential guest residence across from the White House, lasting 2 1/2 hours. President Xi was due to leave Washington after a state banquet on Friday evening and fly to New York, where he will attend meetings on sustainable development and women's rights, before addressing the U.N. General Assembly on Monday.

Title: U.S. Issues Waivers for Iran Nuclear Sanctions on Adoption Day

Article:

The United States has issued waivers for Iran nuclear sanctions on Sunday, marking what is being called "adoption day" for the international agreement aimed at limiting Iran's nuclear program. The move comes 90 days after the United Nations Security Council approved the agreement.

President Obama signed a presidential memorandum on Sunday, directing his administration to begin issuing waivers to Iran nuclear sanctions. However, the waivers will only go into effect once Iran meets its obligations under the agreement.

The agreement, known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), requires the U.S. and the European Union to direct the issuance of waivers on adoption day. The waivers allow businesses to know what sanctions are being waived, even though they won't go into effect for months.

Under the agreement, implementation will come only when the International Atomic Energy Agency certifies that Iran has lived up to its obligations to reduce its stockpiles of enriched uranium, dismantle two-thirds of its centrifuges, and halt construction of new nuclear facilities. Western officials have said they expect this to take four to six months.

Most of the sanctions being lifted apply only to non-U.S. citizens and companies doing business with Iran. Most sanctions will still apply to U.S. citizens under separate sanctions imposed on Iran for its support of terrorism and human rights violations. But sales of civilian passenger aircraft and handicrafts—most notably carpets—will be allowed.

The sanctions against Iran are authorized by Congress but implemented via executive order. Obama can waive those executive orders after Democrats in the Senate filibustered a resolution that would have blocked the agreement last month.

The adoption day comes amid renewed tensions with Iran over its involvement in Syria's civil war and its October 10 test launch of a ballistic missile, reportedly capable of carrying a nuclear warhead. However, President Obama maintained that these issues are separate from the more urgent need to ensure Iran does not develop a nuclear weapon.

In Munich on Saturday, a top Iranian military official said Iran was eager to cooperate with international inspectors and would implement the agreement with "utmost prudence."

Title: Mueller's Reported Questions for President Trump Detail Investigative Focus

Article:

Special Counsel Robert Mueller is reportedly seeking to question President Donald Trump on a range of topics, as outlined in a list of inquiries obtained by The New York Times. The questions provide insight into Mueller's areas of investigation and their potential connection to the president.

The questions cover potential ties between Trump campaign associates and the Russian government, as well as possible attempts to obstruct justice by the president. The list includes queries related to Michael Flynn, Trump's knowledge of his contacts with the Russian ambassador, and whether Trump offered a possible pardon to his former national security adviser, who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI.

Other questions delve into Trump's motivations behind the firing of FBI Director James Comey, the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting, and Trump's contacts with Roger Stone. The list also includes questions about the purpose of Trump's Jan. 27, 2017, dinner with then-FBI Director Comey and what was discussed during that meeting.

According to The Times, Mueller's team presented the list of questions to Trump's legal team as part of negotiations to secure a sit-down interview with the president. The president's lawyers transcribed the questions, which The Times obtained from a person outside Trump's legal team.

Mueller has reportedly been pushing to interview the president directly, a move that Trump's lawyers have expressed concern over due to the president's tendency towards exaggeration and lying. Trump's top personal lawyer, John Dowd, resigned in March, following reports that Trump was unwilling to heed legal advice, including about sitting for a Mueller interview. Rudy Giuliani, a former prosecutor, New York City mayor, and Trump confidant, was brought onto the president's legal team in April and is reportedly deciding whether a Mueller interview will proceed.

For the full list of Mueller questions, readers can refer to The Times' exclusive report.

Title: Clinton's Delegate Lead Grows as Sanders' Path to Nomination Narrows

Article:

As Bernie Sanders' victories in the Kansas and Nebraska caucuses seemed to revive his flagging campaign, Hillary Clinton's delegate lead continued to grow. Hours before the results were declared on Saturday, the Clinton campaign announced that its pledged delegate lead had grown to 199, a figure larger than Barack Obama's highest margin during the 2008 primary and a significant advantage that makes it difficult for Sanders to catch up.

Clinton's delegate lead increased further with her victory in the Louisiana primary, even as Sanders prepared to add another small caucus state to his column. Maine, which votes on Sunday, is expected to support Sanders as well.

Clinton's campaign has yet to call for Sanders to suspend his campaign as his path to the nomination narrows. However, since Clinton's resounding victory in South Carolina late last month, the campaign has emphasized the delegate math, hoping the deficit will make the argument itself.

Sanders' campaign has argued that his continued participation in the process will boost Democratic voter turnout and keep Clinton in the news, an alternative to ceding months of headlines to Donald Trump and the fractured Republican Party. Bernie Sanders' senior strategist, Tad Devine, cited exit polls from Massachusetts, a Super Tuesday state Clinton won, that showed 17 percent of voters were new to the process and overwhelmingly supported Sanders.

Democratic turnout could be a time bomb for the party, with about 3 million fewer Democrats voting in the 15 states that held primaries or caucuses through March 1 than in 2008. Meanwhile, Trump's candidacy has turned out droves of new voters.

"It's important to vigorously contest these contests, and Bernie Sanders is capable of bringing millions of new people into the process," said Sanders' senior strategist Tad Devine. "If Bernie can turn out voters all across America, that's very important for the nominee; it's important for Democrats up and down the ballot. If not, you cede the ground to the opposition in the months ahead, and they're putting on quite a show. If you look at John McCain in 2008, you can see that argument makes a lot of sense."

In 2008, Devine seemed to make a different argument about the value of an extended primary. In an appearance on "Hardball" with Chris Matthews that year, he said of the raging primary battle between Clinton and Obama: "if this race degenerates, it will hurt who the nominee is."

The constructiveness of the rest of the primary remains a question for Clinton. "As long as she is winning, and as long as she isn't forced to constantly try and maneuver to the left of Bernie Sanders," it's not a bad thing for Sanders to remain in the race, said former Mitt Romney strategist Kevin Madden. "That's the biggest risk that Bernie Sanders has posed and could continue to pose, which is that a number of times during this campaign, Hillary Clinton has been forced to abandon the centrist Clinton brand to try and out-liberal an avowed socialist."

Leading into the weekend, Sanders was still playing offense, releasing the transcript of a speech Clinton delivered in India as secretary of state, discussing the benefits of outsourcing jobs abroad, just before Clinton's big jobs speech in Detroit on Friday.

So far, Clinton's campaign has interpreted many of Sanders' attacks as a stealth campaign to raise questions about her authenticity and character. However, other progressives agreed that a tussle over the issues would be positive for Clinton. "Democrats could go dark for weeks as Donald Trump gets tons of election night airtime with the 'winner' label attributed to him over and over again, uninterrupted," said Adam Green, co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee.

Steve Schmidt, who served as chief strategist for McCain's failed 2008 bid, disagreed with Devine's argument that the prolonged Democratic battle hurts the Republican nominee. "There are two finite commodities on a political campaign—time and money," Schmidt said. "The more time you have, the more money you can raise. The notion that you are better off in being delayed in being able to turn to the general election is wrong." The spring months, he said, would be better used building the billion-dollar organizing infrastructure needed to hone a general election message and win in November.

Some Republican operatives also expected between 35 percent and 40 percent of the GOP electorate to walk on Trump, if he becomes the party's nominee. And Clinton needs to move to the middle to begin reaching out to those voters and convincing them: We agree on more than you think.

In recent weeks, Clinton ally and Correct the Record founder David Brock has been pushing the idea within Clinton circles that the trend lines in the Republican race present a big opportunity for a GOP crossover vote for Clinton—and that there should be an organized effort to help make that happen. Last week, for instance, former Republican New Jersey Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said she would support Clinton over Trump, a move that is expected to be a gateway for other Republican voters to follow suit.

However, with Clinton stuck in a battle against Sanders—she faces him in a debate Sunday night in Flint, Michigan, and will debate him again Wednesday in Miami—it's harder to begin making the pivot. "Sen. Sanders remaining in the race allows his anti-Wall Street, anti-elite rhetoric to target Clinton constantly," said Democratic strategist Hank Sheinkopf. "Bernie Sanders helps Trump, the angry populist, every day he remains a candidate."

Title: Media's Ongoing Allegations Against President Trump: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

The media landscape, particularly on networks like MSNBC, has been filled with recurring criticisms of President Donald Trump, often without substantial evidence or factual basis. These discussions, more akin to prosecutorial monologues, have not progressed beyond allegations such as Trump's presidency being a get-rich scheme and his interest in the position being driven by greed.

MSNBC's Joe Scarborough, whose maturity level has been compared to a high school cheerleader, has suggested that Trump's involvement in politics was a get-rich scheme, with recent media narratives involving Russian innuendo supporting this claim. However, these claims do not provide concrete evidence of such a scheme.

Recurring stories about minor figures associated with Trump, such as Carter Page, have generated headlines about potential connections to Russia, but offer little in the way of substantive information or reasons for the media's interest.

The media's persistent focus on these minor figures and their alleged connections to Trump is seen as a result of partisan spite rather than genuine concern for fact-finding. The term "associates" is used imprecisely, and the alleged links are often tenuous at best.

The media's repeated claims of Trump's collusion with Russian President Vladimir Putin to defeat Hillary Clinton are widely known to be unfounded. However, they continue to perpetuate the myth in the hopes that it will become ingrained in the minds of Americans.

Similarly, the media seeks to portray Trump as a racist, a characterization that began in the early days of his campaign due to deliberate misrepresentations of his comments about illegal immigrants.

The media's willful construction of anti-Trump narratives is exemplified by their interruptions of Trump's speeches to inform viewers that the president is lying. This approach is not only questionable in its accuracy but also raises concerns about the media's role in shaping public opinion.

What is particularly concerning is the role that rattled or envious Republicans have played in the construction of these anti-Trump narratives. Even members of Trump's own staff have contributed to these narratives, such as Gary Cohn, who gave an interview that did not reference Trump's explicit and repeated condemnations of racists, neo-Nazis, and white nationalists.

In essence, the media's relentless pursuit of anti-Trump narratives, regardless of their veracity, raises questions about the credibility of the information they present and their role in shaping public opinion.

Title: Republican Primary Strategy Faces Challenges as Trump Remains Frontrunner

Article:

In the political landscape, the Republican primary race is proving to be a challenging endeavor for those aiming to derail Donald Trump's bid for the party's nomination. The party's decision to frontload this year's primaries and caucuses has left only a fraction of the total delegates allocated, with 1,537 of 2,472 delegates already claimed following Super Tuesday.

The issue at hand is that, for the first time in modern GOP history, the insurgent candidate, in this case, Trump, has become the frontrunner. With only 15 states having allocated delegates, and another 15 set to vote by March 22, the anti-Trump forces are running out of opportunities to change the GOP narrative.

One proposed solution to beating Trump is through a head-to-head contest. However, this notion should be taken with a grain of salt, as recent polls suggest that Trump would still emerge victorious in such scenarios. For instance, in a hypothetical matchup between Trump and Texas Sen. Ted Cruz or Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, Trump would win by six points in the former case and 13 points in the latter, according to the latest NBC News/SurveyMonkey Weekly Election Poll.

Another strategy is to keep Trump from exceeding 50% in each state, as the number of delegates needed to secure the nomination (1,237) is the most crucial factor, rather than the number of states won. Of the remaining 1,744 Republican delegates, 391 are in winner-take-all states, with Florida and Ohio, on March 15, being the most important. Trump must be stopped in one, if not both, of these states to slow down his momentum.

In the remaining proportional states, Trump's ceiling of around 30% could still allow anti-Trump forces to catch up, provided they can win a significant number of delegates. Wisconsin's April 5 primary, Indiana's May 3 primary, and California and New Jersey's June 7 primary are crucial states to watch.

If Trump goes into the Republican National Convention close but short of a first-ballot victory, the convention could become a battleground for delegates willing to switch their support to another candidate. The GOP's 437 "pledged" delegates, including 269 Republican officeholders and 168 members of the Republican National Committee, would be key targets for anti-Trump forces.

In the end, the Republican primary race remains a complex and challenging endeavor, with Trump's momentum and the limited number of remaining delegates making it a daunting task for those aiming to derail his bid for the nomination. The race will likely come down to a combination of strategic maneuvers, grassroots mobilization, and a bit of luck.

Title: FBI Investigation and Email Controversy Impact on U.S. Presidential Election

Article:

As the United States presidential election approaches, pollsters and observers are expressing concerns about the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, losing support while Republican nominee Donald Trump experiences a resurgence. A week ago, Clinton held a significant lead in the polls following a series of gaffes by Trump. However, the FBI's recent intervention regarding Clinton's use of a private email server while serving as secretary of state, along with the release of damaging emails from Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta, has caused a shift in the polls.

The FBI's letter to congressional officials, penned by Director James Comey, came at a challenging time for Clinton. With only a week remaining until the election, it is difficult to prove a negative and re-establish Clinton's innocence. The letter followed a series of news events that had already made a significant dent in Clinton's polling lead.

The release of emails to and from Podesta, obtained by WikiLeaks and allegedly from Russian hackers, has been trickling out for weeks. While the content has been mostly embarrassing rather than damaging, Wednesday's release of a report that appeared to confirm the Clinton family's blurring of business, charitable, and political interests provided Trump supporters with fresh ammunition during a time when they were desperate to shift attention from their candidate's own scandals.

In an election described as an unpopularity contest, small shifts in opinion can significantly impact independent voters. By Friday, the combination of no news from Trump and bad news from Clinton had halved Clinton's average lead in the polls since the last presidential debate.

Political consultant Frank Luntz predicted that the winner of the 2016 election will be the campaign that keeps the focus on its opponent. Sunday's average lead for Clinton in national polls of 3.4% remains a healthy safety margin, but it is smaller than Clinton's lead in the final days of the 1992 election, which she won by nearly double that margin.

However, few polls have been conducted since the news broke about the FBI and the emails. One reputable survey, an ABC News-Washington Post tracking poll released on Sunday, showed just a one-point overall lead for Clinton. The poll found that the news had mostly hardened existing opinions but could also play a role at the margins.

The potential for a pullback in motivation among Clinton supporters or a further resurgence among Trump's supporters may cause concern in the Clinton camp, especially because this dynamic was already underway. Intention to vote has grown in Trump support groups in the past week as the intensity of criticisms about him has ebbed.

A poll of voters in 13 battleground states showed that only 5% of Democrats said the issue might make them less likely to support Clinton, compared with more than a quarter of registered Republicans. This risk also helps explain the ferocity of Democratic calls for the FBI to urgently exonerate Clinton.

Many loyalists are convinced the latest trove of emails, discovered on equipment shared by Clinton aide Huma Abedin and her estranged husband Anthony Weiner, are an irrelevance. However, so long as this is not categorically established, there may be a nagging doubt in some minds that the FBI suspects otherwise. Not everyone will be prepared to give Clinton the benefit of the doubt. Some studies have shown that only 11% of voters describe Clinton as "honest and trustworthy," lower even than Trump's score of 16%.

While it may not be enough to tip the balance, running for president while facing potential criminal investigation is never a good look.

Title: The National Debt and Entitlement Programs: A Threat to the Republic's Sustainability

Article:

The United States faces a significant challenge in the form of a growing national debt and entitlement programs, which some argue pose a threat to the sustainability of the Republic. This issue, while not new, has gained renewed attention due to the latest White House budget proposal.

The unveiling of the presidential budget is a ritual in Washington, often perceived as a document of great significance. However, its unveiling is typically nothing more than a symbolic act, with little bearing on the fundamental problems the country faces. The budgetary process often resembles a gladiatorial contest, with various interest groups vying for funding, while the underlying issue of the national debt and entitlement programs remains largely unaddressed.

Non-defense discretionary spending amounts to roughly 16% of the budget. Even if this were to be completely eliminated, it would only delay the fiscal reckoning that would come from the metastasizing growth of the national debt and the entitlement spending that fuels it. In 2008, the federal debt was 39% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP). Last summer, it was 75% of GDP. According to the Congressional Budget Office, if the current course is maintained, it will reach 86% by 2026 and 141% of GDP by 2046.

With regard to the president's rumored plan to cut $10.5 trillion over the next ten years, Michael Tanner of the Cato Institute writes, "Without making changes to our insolvent entitlement programs—Social Security and Medicare alone face some $80 trillion in future red ink—there is simply no way to get anywhere near $10.5 trillion in spending cuts." However, neither President Trump nor the Democratic leadership seems inclined to address entitlement reform.

The causes of Rome's fall are the subject of endless debate, but nearly all historians agree that one of the major factors was the endless accumulation of debt driven by entitlements, largely in the form of land and titles of nobility, given to more and more segments of Roman society. The Caesars and the senators found it too difficult a problem to fix, so they played their ritualistic games until reality had its say.

In conclusion, the national debt and entitlement programs are a significant challenge facing the United States. Without addressing these issues, the country risks following in the footsteps of empires past, where the rituals that once helped enforce order became distractions from the demands of reality. The real threat to the Republic is not the gladiatorial arenas of talk radio and cable television; it is the barbarian horde of debt and entitlement.

Title: Jeb Bush Announces Exploration of 2016 Presidential Run

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush has announced that he will "actively explore" running for President in 2016, according to posts on his Facebook and Twitter accounts on Tuesday. In a note shared on Twitter, Bush stated, "I am excited to announce I will actively explore the possibility of running for President of the United States."

In his announcement, Bush discussed spending the holidays with his family and having conversations with them about the future of the nation. He explained that these discussions, along with "thoughtful consideration of the kind of strong leadership I think America needs," led him to "decide to actively explore the possibility of running for President of the United States."

Bush also revealed plans to establish a Leadership PAC in January. This PAC, he said, will facilitate conversations with citizens across America to discuss the most critical challenges facing the nation and support leaders, ideas, and policies that will expand opportunity and prosperity for all Americans.

Bush previously fell short to Democrat Lawton Chiles in the 1994 elections but was elected governor of Florida in 1998 and served two terms. If successful, he would be the third in his immediate family to serve as Commander-in-Chief, following his father, George H.W. Bush, and his brother, George W. Bush. Bush's son, George P. Bush, was recently elected as Texas' next Land Commissioner.

Bush did not specify when he would make a final decision about officially entering the race, but the formation of a leadership PAC has become a new preliminary step for prospective presidential candidates. Florida Senator Marco Rubio, also rumored to be considering a presidential run, formed his own PAC, Reclaim America, after being elected to the Senate in 2010.

In his note, Bush extended holiday wishes to his followers and expressed hope to visit with many of them in the coming months to discuss restoring the promise of America. The full note can be found on his Twitter account.

Title: Virginia Newspapers Criticize Democratic Candidate's Tactics in Gubernatorial Race

Article:

In the final days of the Virginia gubernatorial race, the Democratic candidate, Lt. Gov. Ralph Northam, has been criticized by Virginia newspapers for using the Charlottesville tragedy to score political points. The controversy stems from a mailer issued by Northam's campaign, which links his Republican opponent, Ed Gillespie, to white nationalism.

The mailer, which has been criticized as "practically libelous" by the Richmond Times-Dispatch, features a photo of the Charlottesville Tiki-torch marchers and condemns Gillespie for not speaking out against President Trump's "good people on both sides" comment made during the Charlottesville rally. However, it is important to note that Gillespie did denounce the white supremacists before the rally took place.

The Daily Progress, a Charlottesville-based paper, has been particularly critical of Northam's tactics, describing them as "stomach-turning." The paper argues that the mailer politicizes the Charlottesville tragedy, which has already been a contentious issue. The Northam campaign is accused of trying to tie Gillespie to the unpopular president, exploiting the Charlottesville tragedy for political advantage.

The controversy has sparked criticism from both sides of the political spectrum, with some arguing that it is fair game for Northam's opponent to challenge Gillespie on his endorsement of the Trump agenda. However, the exploitation of the Charlottesville tragedy for political gain is seen as a step too far by many, including The Daily Progress. The paper's criticism highlights the delicate balance between political campaigning and respect for the pain and suffering experienced by the community during the white supremacist invasion in Charlottesville.

Title: Interpretation of Pardon Clause in U.S. Constitution Challenges Presidential Pardon Power in Impeachment Cases

Article:

A debate has arisen regarding the interpretation of the pardon clause in the United States Constitution, specifically in relation to the president's power to pardon individuals associated with impeachment proceedings. Some argue that the clause also prohibits a president from commuting the sentences of individuals charged with crimes related to impeachment proceedings against him.

The impeachment of President Donald Trump focused on allegations of withholding foreign aid from Ukraine to pressure the Ukrainian president into investigating his political opponents, and his refusal to cooperate with the congressional investigation into this matter. The articles of impeachment also mentioned his "previous invitations of foreign interference in United States elections" and "previous efforts to undermine United States Government investigations into foreign interference in United States elections."

This interpretation suggests that President Trump could not use the pardon and reprieve power to commute the sentences of those charged with crimes related to Russian interference in the 2016 campaign, including Roger Stone, who was convicted of lying to Congress and obstructing its investigation into Russian election interference.

The argument for this interpretation is rooted in the Constitution's text, history, values, and structure. The Framers were concerned about presidents abusing power to protect co-conspirators, as evidenced by Edmund Randolph's concern at the Constitutional Convention that "the prerogative of pardon in these cases was too great a trust. The President may himself be guilty. The Traytors may be his own instruments."

On August 25, 1787, delegates voted on the pardon clause. The president was initially granted the power to grant reprieves and pardons, but unanimously voted to insert "except in cases of impeachment" after the word pardon. Directly afterward, they rejected the addition of the phrase "but his pardon shall not be pleadable in bar" in a six-to-four vote.

These votes suggest that the Framers saw the new phrase as having a meaning distinct from the traditional interpretation. If "except in cases of impeachment" already covered both of those limits on presidential pardons, why would the Framers then need to vote on whether to include the British phrase, language that would have merely imposed the first limit they had already unanimously approved?

Given the unclear record of what the Framers meant to do that day, any interpretation of its meaning based only on the evidence we have about the day the phrase was adopted is speculative at best. However, this interpretation provides a compelling argument for limiting the president's pardon power in impeachment cases.

Title: Washington Navy Yard Shooting: A Call for Caution and Reflection

Article:

Monday morning saw the latest in a series of shooting incidents in the United States, with at least one gunman reportedly killing 12 people and wounding several others at the Washington Navy Yard. The incident, while still under investigation, serves as a grim reminder of the prevalence of gun violence in the country.

The Washington, D.C., area, like many other parts of the U.S., is not immune to such incidents. Individual shootings occur frequently, but a mass shooting, as in the case of the Washington Navy Yard, is a particularly violent and disruptive event.

This article aims to provide an objective account of the incident, avoiding speculation and drawing only on verified information.

The 2002 "Beltway sniper" attacks serve as a stark reminder of the potential for such incidents. Over a 20-day period, two snipers killed 10 people across the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area. The motives behind the attacks were unclear, with speculation ranging from terrorism to personal grievances.

The Washington Navy Yard shooting, like the Beltway sniper attacks, is still in its early stages of investigation. Law enforcement is currently searching for an additional suspect, while a first suspect, identified as Aaron Alexis, was killed at the scene. If the shooting did, in fact, involve multiple shooters, this suggests a level of coordination and deliberation that goes beyond a lone-wolf attack.

However, the early reports are contradictory and often incorrect. It is crucial, in the aftermath of such tragedies, to avoid drawing conclusions too early. The rush to be first with the news often results in the dissemination of incorrect information, ultimately harming the public's understanding of the events.

In these first few hours after the tragedy, it is essential to wait patiently for credible information and to reflect on the broader implications of such incidents. This includes questions about terrorism, mental health, gun control, and public safety.

As the investigation continues, Americans will mourn those who have passed, the FBI will investigate, and the affected areas will be cleaned. In the meantime, it is crucial to carry on with our days, waiting and reflecting with wisdom rather than fearful speculation.

Joshua Foust, a freelance journalist with a background in counterterrorism and foreign policy, offers insights on these issues. His website is joshuafoust.com, and he can be followed on Twitter @joshuafoust.

Title: The Case for Using Professional Women as Fashion Role Models

Article:

The article discusses the argument for using professional women, such as Hillary Rodham Clinton, Julia Gillard, and Kirsten Gillibrand, as fashion role models, particularly in the context of the modern world where personal appearance plays a significant role, especially in the digital age. The author suggests that these women, who have had to navigate traditionally male-dominated environments, can provide valuable insights into how to manage one's image and appearance in professional and public settings.

The author argues that using celebrities like Jennifer Lawrence, Nicole Kidman, or Rihanna as fashion role models may not be practical, especially for those over 25 or not involved in pop culture. The author contends that these celebrities, who are often airbrushed and photographed primarily for red carpet events or charity trips, may not be suitable examples for dressing for professional settings such as pitching a new client, negotiating a deal, or teaching.

The author also mentions that even women who have become fashion icons due to non-celebrity public roles, such as Michelle Obama and the Duchess of Cambridge, are primarily symbolic figures whose dressing is a mode of diplomatic expression. The author questions whether the same rules apply to women with a more palpable professional voice.

The author suggests that learning from the wardrobe strategies of professional women like Christine Lagarde, Sheryl Sandberg, Indra Nooyi, and Mary Barra could be beneficial. However, the author notes that these women, who dress well, rarely discuss their fashion choices, possibly due to the fear of not being taken seriously. The author argues that the solution is not to ignore the issue but to embrace it and move forward.

Title: Global Warming Ranks Low in UN Survey of 6.7 Million People Worldwide

Article:

A United Nations survey of 6.7 million people across 194 countries, including the Palestinian territories, has revealed that climate change ranks low in global priorities. The survey, which went online in March, found that education was the most important issue, while climate change ranked below access to telephones and the Internet.

The survey results were consistent across gender, age groups, and education levels. In the United States, climate change was ranked as the 10th most important issue, while in Britain, it was placed at number nine.

Willis Eschenback, a contributor to the website Watts Up With That, which covers news on global warming and climate change, commented on the survey results, stating, "The revealed truth is that of the sixteen choices given to people regarding what they think are the important issues in their lives, climate change is dead last."

Meanwhile, delegates to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, meeting in Lima, Peru, are facing difficulties in reaching a final agreement by the end of the forum on Friday. The Associated Press reported on Sunday that the momentum from a historic U.S.-China pact to combat global warming is showing signs of fading at the U.N. climate talks, with the familiar rich-poor conflict persisting over who should take action to prevent global warming.

The news service was referring to an agreement reached between U.S. President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping in November, which commits the United States to real cuts in greenhouse gas emissions, while China essentially made another promise to cut pollution. Foreign Policy recently reviewed the agreement and concluded that China offered little in terms of concrete commitments.

Title: White House Blocks Lev Parnas Testimony in Senate Impeachment Trial

Article:

Lev Parnas, an associate of Rudy Giuliani, exited the Manhattan Federal Court in New York on December 17, 2019, following a bail hearing. According to a report by the Wall Street Journal on Monday, the White House has indicated it will block any attempt to summon Parnas to testify in the Senate impeachment trial.

Parnas, who was involved in Giuliani's efforts to investigate Joe Biden, made several claims regarding President Trump's involvement in Ukraine during a series of interviews released on Wednesday. In an interview with MSNBC's Rachel Maddow, Parnas stated, "President Trump knew exactly what was going on. He was aware of all my movements. I wouldn't do anything without the consent of Rudy Giuliani or the President."

Parnas accused Attorney General William Barr of being aware of Giuliani's and Trump's actions, but Barr denied having any knowledge of such dealings. In testimony during House impeachment hearings, former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch alleged Parnas and associate Igor Fruman, along with Giuliani, were working to oust her to advance Parnas's and Fruman's business interests. The two are also thought to have worked with former top Ukrainian prosecutor Yuriy Lutsenko to obtain information on the Bidens.

Parnas was indicted in October on campaign-finance charges and is accused of disguising donations to Republican candidates to advance his personal interests and those of other Ukrainian politicians.

President Trump's impeachment defense team, which includes heavyweight attorney Alan Dershowitz and former Clinton impeachment manager Ken Starr, announced on Monday it will call on the Senate to "swiftly reject" the articles of impeachment. In a trial brief released by the team, it states, "The Senate should speedily reject these articles of impeachment and acquit the President. All that House Democrats have succeeded in proving is that the President did absolutely nothing wrong."

Democrats allege President Trump withheld military aid from Ukraine to pressure the country to investigate corruption allegations against Joe and Hunter Biden.

Title: Barr Assures Senators He Will Not Interfere with Mueller's Russia Investigation

Article:

WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump's attorney general nominee, William Barr, has assured Republican senators he will not interfere with special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. On Wednesday, Barr met with Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-SC) ahead of his confirmation hearings, which are scheduled for next week.

During the meeting, Graham recounted that he asked Barr directly, "Do you think Mr. Mueller is on a witch hunt?" Barr responded, "No." When asked, "Do you think he would be fair to the president and the country as a whole?" Barr replied, "Yes." "And do you see any reason for Mr. Mueller's investigation to be stopped?" Barr said, "No." "Do you see any reason for a termination based on cause?" Barr said, "No." "Are you committed to making sure Mr. Mueller can finish his job?" Barr responded, "Yes."

The news comes as Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who is overseeing the investigation, announced he is stepping down after Barr is confirmed. Some Democrats want Barr to recuse himself from the Mueller probe due to his previous statements criticizing the investigation. Specifically, they are referring to a controversial memo Barr wrote last year to Rosenstein, calling the probe "fatally misconceived."

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) said Wednesday, "The Senate... should subject Mr. Barr's views to the strictest of scrutiny next week, and I still believe, after the revelations about Mr. Barr's unsolicited memo, President Trump ought to withdraw this nomination." Likewise, Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) said the memo was "deeply worrisome because in effect he says the president is above the law... that's incorrect as a matter of law, but certainly for an attorney general to have that position is deeply wrong."

However, Graham says Democrats' fears are unfounded, noting that Barr and Mueller are good friends of more than 20 years, and their wives attend a Bible study together. "I can assure you he has a very high opinion of Mr. Mueller and he is committed to letting Mr. Mueller finish his job," the South Carolina lawmaker said.

Title: John Hinckley Jr., Assassination Attempt Suspect, Granted Freedom After 35 Years

John Hinckley Jr., the man who attempted to assassinate President Ronald Reagan in 1981, has been granted freedom by a federal judge in Washington, D.C. The release could occur as early as next week, with Hinckley residing full-time with his elderly mother in Williamsburg, Virginia.

On March 30, 1981, outside the Washington Hilton Hotel, Hinckley, with shaggy hair, aimed his gun at President Reagan and fired six times. Reagan spent nearly two weeks in the hospital recovering from wounds and blood loss. James Brady, the president's press secretary, was shot in the head. Brady survived but spent the next 28 years in a wheelchair. A court found Hinckley not guilty by reason of insanity a year after the attack.

President Reagan's daughter, Patti Davis, expressed her disapproval of the not guilty verdict last year, stating that Hinckley knew right from wrong at the time of the attack. Davis argued that attempting to kill the president is a unique crime, stating, "You can't say well, if he shot the butcher, it would be different. He did try to shoot a president. We hold that crime in a different category than we do other attempted murders."

The Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute released a statement, stating, "Contrary to the judge's decision, we believe John Hinckley is still a threat to others and we strongly oppose his release."

For the past decade, Hinckley has been gradually moving towards freedom. Saint Elizabeths Hospital, where he has resided, states that he no longer poses a danger to himself or others. Doctors report that his depression and psychosis are in full remission. In court, his lawyer described a man who plays guitar, goes to movies, and browses in bookstores.

Hinckley already spends 17 days each month with his mother in the Kingsmill resort community in Williamsburg, which bothers his neighbor Joe Mann. "It could be a grave mistake to try to force fit him into that community with his 90-year-old mother," Mann told NPR before the ruling. "What I think of is Hinckley may be OK as long as he is on his drugs. What goes off when he misses a dose or two? Or decides, I don't need this stuff?"

Under the terms of the order, Hinckley is not allowed to contact his victims, their relatives, or actress Jodie Foster, with whom he was obsessed. Hinckley also will not be permitted to "knowingly travel" to areas where the current president or members of Congress are present. The judge said Hinckley could be allowed to live on his own or in a group home after one year.

Hinckley's longtime lawyer, Barry William Levine, argued to the court last year that his client is entitled to live under the least restrictive conditions in keeping with public safety. Levine told NPR in an interview Wednesday that Hinckley is "profoundly sad and sorry for the pain he caused his victims, their families, and the nation."

Levine stated that the voluminous court record demonstrates Hinckley is not a threat to anyone. "This case shows that people who are ravaged by disease, mental disease, can get well and become productive members of society without imposing any threat of danger," he said.

However, Justice Department prosecutors have been leery. The prosecutors want to be able to monitor Hinckley's whereabouts and his Internet use. Former prosecutor Thomas Zeno explained why in an interview with NPR a few years ago, stating, "The question with Mr. Hinckley is because he has this basic character flaw or personality flaw, as it is called, of narcissism, can he really be changed? And will he really be a different person?"

John Hinckley is now 61 years old, and, as the judge wrote, "suffering from arthritis, high blood pressure, and various other physical ailments like many men his age."

Title: Palestinian Student's Harvard Dream Ends as Visa Revoked After Arrival in U.S.

Article:

An incoming Harvard University freshman, Ismail B. Ajjawi, a 17-year-old Palestinian refugee living in Lebanon, had his visa revoked hours after landing in the U.S. on Friday night. Ajjawi, who intended to study Chemical and Physical Biology, spent a total of eight hours in Boston, Massachusetts, before being deported back to Lebanon.

Upon landing, Ajjawi and several other international students faced questioning from immigration officials. However, Ajjawi was held back while his peers were allowed to proceed. He alleges that an immigration officer continued to question him about his religion and religious practices in Lebanon. That officer then asked the student to unlock his phone and laptop, which were searched for five hours, according to Ajjawi.

The officer then asked him about his friends' social media activity, stating that they found posts sharing political views that were against the U.S. Ajjawi responded that he had no business with such posts and that he did not like, share, or comment on them, stating that he should not be held responsible for what others post.

Despite his defense, the immigration officer canceled Ajjawi's visa and told him he would be deported. Ajjawi was allowed a phone call to his parents before returning to Lebanon.

Ajjawi is now in contact with a lawyer and the university with the hopes of resolving his visa before classes start next Tuesday, September 3. U.S. Customs and Border Protection told the Harvard Crimson that Ajjawi was deemed inadmissible to the country.

Harvard University says they are working closely with the student's family and appropriate authorities to resolve this matter so that he can join his classmates in the coming days. Ajjawi was coming to Harvard on a scholarship given by AMIDEAST, a nonprofit, which is now aiding him with legal assistance.

Ajjawi's revoked visa comes after he was highlighted on a local news site, Alaraby Entertainment, for his success story, from being a refugee in Lebanon to getting into the coveted Ivy League school on a full scholarship. His father was also included in that news cast, proudly gushing about his son's success.

Ajjawi's friend, Selah Chehade, stated to DailyMail.com, "Deporting him back is of course an unfair act. He is a very clever student, and it is not appropriate to act with him this way."

Title: Post-Election Self-Examination Expected for GOP if Romney Loses

Article:

If Mitt Romney loses the 2012 presidential election to incumbent Barack Obama, the Republican Party will likely undergo a period of introspection and debate to understand the reasons behind their defeat. The election's outcome, regardless of Romney's victory, will significantly influence the party's approach to governing and campaigning in the future.

Even before the election results are announced, discussions about the reasons for a potential Romney loss are already emerging. If Romney wins, he will become the President of the United States. However, if he loses, he will serve as a symbol of the Republican Party's shortcomings.

One of the main criticisms of Romney throughout the 2012 race was his perceived ineptitude as a competitor. Republicans were not overly enthusiastic about nominating Romney due to his moderate leanings and his struggles in the 2008 primaries. During the 2012 campaign, Romney was criticized for various missteps, such as his response to the Supreme Court's Affordable Care Act ruling, his comments about the British during the London Olympics, and his remarks about Americans who do not pay income taxes.

On a deeper level, Romney's close ties to Wall Street, an industry still recovering from the financial crisis, may have made him a vulnerable candidate. Former Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour noted in August that Democrats had successfully branded Romney as a "wealthy plutocrat married to a known equestrian."

The post-election analysis and self-examination by the Republican Party will provide insights into the party's future direction and campaign strategies. The outcome of the 2012 election will undoubtedly shape the political landscape for years to come.

Title: Deficit Reduction Experts Express Optimism, Yet Warn of Entitlement Challenges in Fiscal Cliff Talks

Article:

In a recent appearance on CBS's "Face the Nation," two deficit reduction experts discussed the ongoing stalemate in Washington regarding the "fiscal cliff." Despite the lack of progress between President Obama and House Speaker John Boehner on averting year-end spending cuts and tax hikes that could potentially plunge the economy back into recession, former President Clinton's chief of staff Erskine Bowles expressed increased optimism.

Bowles, who co-chaired Mr. Obama's fiscal commission in 2010, stated, "I think we made some progress this week, Bob. I'm more encouraged than I was." He attributed this progress to both sides taking positions that differ from their previously hardened stances, with Speaker Boehner showing a willingness to increase taxes and President Obama demonstrating openness to entitlement cuts.

However, Bowles noted that the president's proposal to cut around $350 billion from Medicare is "not enough." He emphasized the need for further entitlement reform, stating, "We simply made promises we can't keep. We've got to face up to it."

Former Senator Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., who co-chaired the president's fiscal commission with Bowles and now runs the Fix the Debt campaign, agreed with this assessment. Simpson highlighted the entitlements as the primary drivers of the looming fiscal cliff, stating, "The entitlements are the engine on the train driving us to the cliff. They were on automatic pilot."

Simpson also expressed concern about the rising cost of healthcare and the number of baby boomers aging into entitlement programs, going so far as to dance the "Gangnam Style" in a YouTube video to persuade young kids to "get off your can." He noted that if current trends continue, senior groups like the AARP will "strip the treasury dry in 30 years."

Both Simpson and Bowles advocated for similar positions, with Simpson promoting raising taxes by limiting tax expenditures through tax reform after the New Year, and emphasizing the need for entitlement reform. In 2010, they co-chaired a bipartisan committee that proposed a plan to reduce the deficit by $4 trillion over 10 years; however, the president did not embrace the plan, and Congress failed to pass it.

Bowles warned that going over the "fiscal cliff" would result in a four percent slowdown in the economy, with businesses already "slowing their head count" and cutting capital expenditures. Simpson criticized Washington lawmakers for playing politics with the "fiscal cliff," stating that such behavior is "terribly bizarre and juvenile."

In conclusion, while deficit reduction experts like Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson expressed optimism about the ongoing fiscal cliff talks, they also highlighted the significant challenges posed by entitlement programs and the need for comprehensive reform. The stalemate in Washington continues, with the potential for significant economic consequences if a resolution is not reached.

Title: Steve Bannon Warns White House of Imminent Impeachment Threat, Predicts Surprising 2020 Challengers for Trump

Article:

Former White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon has warned that the impeachment of President Donald Trump is a "serious" and imminent threat, stating that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi will likely initiate impeachment proceedings within the next six weeks. In an interview with The Post, Bannon expressed concern over the White House's seemingly uncoordinated approach to the impeachment inquiry.

Bannon, the former chairman of Breitbart News, criticized the performance of Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, citing a disastrous press conference where Mulvaney confirmed Trump's decision to withhold military aid to Ukraine was part of a quid pro quo. Mulvaney later walked back his comments.

Bannon suggested that the White House should establish an "impeachment squad" to focus on the impeachment inquiry 24/7, bifurcating the White House Counsel's office, as was done during the investigation by Robert Mueller into Russian interference.

If Trump manages to survive a House impeachment probe, Bannon anticipates potential challenges from surprising and viable candidates in the 2020 election, such as Michael Bloomberg or Hillary Clinton. He expressed dissatisfaction with the current field of Democratic candidates, predicting a total Biden implosion by the end of the year and a centrist revolt against Elizabeth Warren.

In the event that Biden falters and Warren appears to be marching toward the nomination, Bannon predicted that both Bloomberg and Clinton would enter the race. He described the current Democratic candidates as insufficiently competitive compared to Bloomberg or Clinton.

Bannon also suggested that the Democratic nominee would need to focus on states like Arizona, Texas, Georgia, and the Carolinas, which he referred to as Trump's "southern arc." He also emphasized the importance of campaigning in Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin, states that Clinton neglected in her 2016 race and that turned against the party for the first time in a generation.

Since leaving the White House in 2017, Bannon has been traveling extensively, speaking at conferences, meeting with billionaires, and promoting his vision of populist nationalism. He has also taken a growing interest in China, which he views as the primary threat to the United States. Bannon spoke with The Post shortly after a screening of his new film, "Claws of the Red Dragon," in New York. The movie is a loose retelling of the arrest of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou in Canada last year.

Title: FBI Lawyer Suspected of Altering Document Related to Carter Page Surveillance

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — An FBI lawyer is under suspicion for allegedly altering a document related to the surveillance of former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page, a person familiar with the situation said Friday. The allegation is part of a Justice Department inspector general review of the FBI's Russia investigation, a politically sensitive probe that has been one of the most contentious elements of the Russia probe and has shadowed President Donald Trump's presidency since its beginning.

The allegation against the lawyer was first reported by CNN, and the Washington Post subsequently reported that the conduct of the FBI employee did not alter Horowitz's finding that the surveillance application of Page had a proper legal and factual basis, an official told the Post, which said the lawyer was forced out.

The inspector general report, centered in part on the use of a secret surveillance warrant to monitor the communications of a former Trump adviser, is likely to revive debate about an investigation that has been a contentious issue since the beginning of Trump's presidency. It will be released amid a House impeachment inquiry into Trump's efforts to press Ukraine's leader to investigate Democratic rival Joe Biden at the same time as military aid was being withheld from the country.

Trump and his supporters are likely to seize on any findings of mistakes or bad judgment in the report to support their claims of a biased investigation. Supporters of the FBI, meanwhile, are likely to hold up as vindication any findings that the investigation was done by the book or free of political considerations.

The FBI obtained a secret surveillance warrant in 2016 to monitor the communications of Page, who was never charged in the Russia investigation or accused of wrongdoing. The warrant, which was renewed several times and approved by different judges in 2016 and early 2017, has been one of the most contentious elements of the Russia probe and was the subject of dueling memos last year issued by Democrats and Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee.

Republicans have long attacked the credibility of the warrant application since it cited information derived from a dossier of opposition research compiled by Christopher Steele, a former British spy whose work was financed by Democrats and the Hillary Clinton campaign.

Carter Page, in an interview with Maria Bartiromo on Fox's "Mornings with Maria," said, "They got my warrant — a fraudulent warrant, I believe — to spy on myself as a way of getting into the Trump campaign." He added, "There has been a continued cover-up to this day. We still do not have the truth, but hopefully, we'll get that soon."

FBI Director Chris Wray has told Congress that he did not consider the FBI surveillance to be "spying" and that he has no evidence the FBI illegally monitored Trump's campaign during the 2016 election. Wray said he would not describe the FBI's surveillance as "spying" if it "follows investigative policies and procedures."

Attorney General William Barr has said he believed "spying" did occur, but he also made clear at a Senate hearing earlier this year that he had no specific evidence that any surveillance was illegal or improper. Barr has appointed U.S. Attorney John Durham to investigate how intelligence was collected, and that probe has since become criminal in nature, a person familiar with the matter has said.

However, Trump insists that members of the Obama administration "at the highest levels" were spying on his 2016 campaign. "Personally, I think it goes all the way... I think this goes to the highest level," he said in the Fox interview. "I hate to say it. I think it's a disgrace. They thought I was going to win and they said, 'How can we stop him?'"

Spokespeople for the FBI and the inspector general declined to comment Friday.

Title: President Trump Announces Ryan Zinke's Departure, Suggests Sen. Joe Manchin as Potential Replacement for Interior Secretary

Article:

President Donald Trump announced via Twitter on Saturday that Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke would be leaving the administration at the end of the year. In a series of tweets, the president commended Zinke for his nearly two-year tenure atop the Department of Interior.

"Ryan has accomplished much during his tenure and I want to thank him for his service to our Nation," said Mr. Trump in one of his tweets. The Trump Administration will be announcing the new Secretary of the Interior next week.

One early name suggested as a replacement is Sen. Joe Manchin III, a West Virginia Democrat who recently won re-election. Manchin has had a complex relationship with President Trump, seeking areas to collaborate with the president.

If selected, Sen. Manchin's confirmation process is expected to be smooth, and one influential strategist stated that Manchin would align with Trump's policies. "He is going to toe the line," the strategist said.

The departure of Mr. Zinke, who faced numerous ethics investigations and was criticized by environmentalists, is part of a year-end shakeup at the White House. Attorney General Jeff Sessions was cut loose shortly after the November elections, and this month, the president announced that Chief of Staff John Kelly was on his way out. The president has hinted at more staff changes, although he stated that he "loves" his Cabinet secretaries for the most part.

Mr. Zinke's job has been under stress for months due to the scandals surrounding him. The scandals range from high-priced travel on government planes to an alleged shady land deal in his hometown of Whitefish, Montana, involving the Zinke family and Halliburton chairman David Lesar. The Interior Department inspector general referred the land deal scandal to the Justice Department. Rep. Raul Grijalva, the Arizona Democrat who will lead the House Natural Resources Committee next year, has vowed a probe of the land deal.

Kierán Suckling, executive director of the Center for Biological Diversity, stated, "Zinke will go down as the worst Interior secretary in history. His slash-and-burn approach was absolutely destructive for public lands and wildlife. Allowing David Bernhardt to continue to call the shots will still be just as ugly. Different people, same appetite for greed and profit."

Title: Primary Voting Results Shake Up Democratic and Republican Races

Article:

The latest round of primary voting has brought significant changes to the ongoing Democratic and Republican presidential nomination races.

In the Democratic race, Hillary Clinton's expected victories in Mississippi and Michigan did not materialize, while Bernie Sanders defied expectations in Michigan. Clinton's loss in Michigan, despite her strong performance in the debate and her lead in more populous states, was attributed to lower-than-expected African-American voter turnout and her failure to win the county that is home to Flint, the city with lead-poisoned water. Sanders, on the other hand, reprised his dominance among the youth vote and won an overwhelming number of counties throughout the state.

In the Republican race, Donald Trump's momentum seemed to stall out, with late-deciders breaking against him in Kentucky and Louisiana. However, Trump still won these states, albeit with a smaller margin than earlier tests. John Kasich, who was expected to gain momentum in Michigan as an establishment alternative to Trump, finished third, a hair or two behind Texas Sen. Ted Cruz.

Ted Cruz, who won in Idaho, showed his strength in small state events and second-place finishes. Despite his struggles in Southern states with big populations of evangelical white Protestants, Cruz has hung tough and racked up delegates. He is now just 99 delegates behind Trump, and if he can win a few of the winner-take-all states, he could catch up to Trump.

Marco Rubio, who was expected to be the anti-Trump, has struggled in recent primaries and caucuses, finishing third or worse in Michigan, Mississippi, Idaho, and Hawaii. Rubio has now staggered winless through two-dozen primaries and caucuses.

In the cold light of the day-after, it is possible the results from Tuesday will look different. Clinton's 66-point dominance in Mississippi won her nearly all that state's delegates, while Sanders' razor-thin margin in Michigan meant the two candidates split that state's delegates almost evenly. This makes it difficult for Sanders to overcome Clinton's delegate lead, even if he continues to best her in the voting booths from here through June. Sanders strategist Tad Devine is fond of saying the race is a marathon, not a sprint, but winning a race of any duration still requires you to finish first. Sanders needs to make a habit of doing just that, and by wider margins than his breakthrough in Michigan gave him.

Title: American Democracy: A Call for Focus on Voting Rights and Process Reform

Article:

Joshua A. Douglas, a law professor at the University of Kentucky College of Law who specializes in election law and voting rights, has expressed his support for the Electoral College result despite his personal disagreement with the election outcome. In an article published by CNN, Douglas argues that the Electoral College process worked as intended and reflects the will of the people in each state.

Douglas acknowledges that external factors such as Russian influence, FBI Director James Comey's announcement of the continued investigation of Hillary Clinton's emails, and other issues may have affected the election. However, he emphasizes that these factors did not prevent people from voting and that the Electoral College vote represents the will of the people in each state.

Douglas argues that the real issues that should concern Americans are the low voter turnout and barriers to voting for many Americans. He highlights the need to remove barriers to voting, encourage civic participation, and protect the fundamental right to vote against undue barriers. Douglas also suggests that the Electoral College system, which he believes is anti-democratic, should be abolished, but acknowledges that it is the current system in place.

Douglas concludes by urging Americans to focus on fixing the voting process, abolishing the Electoral College, and addressing potential conflicts of interest, ties to Russia, and discriminatory policy positions of the incoming administration. He emphasizes that fighting the clear results of the November 8 election is unproductive, and instead, Americans should focus on exercising their fundamental right to vote, which he believes is the real battle that can save our democracy.

Title: Trump Announces Afghanistan Strategy: Five Core Pillars, No Troop Level Increase Decision

Article:

President Donald Trump unveiled his strategy for Afghanistan on Monday, outlining five core pillars for the approach. The plan, which follows seven months of deliberation, includes adjustments to the current strategy rather than a complete change.

The five core pillars are:
1. Eliminating any timelines for U.S. troop presence in Afghanistan.
2. Utilizing all elements of power, including diplomatic and economic means.
3. Toughening the stance on Pakistan.
4. Encouraging India to contribute more to economic development.
5. Expanding authorities for U.S. forces to combat terrorists.

The president did not specify the number of additional troops that would be deployed to Afghanistan, a decision he made earlier this year and left to Defense Secretary Jim Mattis to determine. However, it has been reported that the president has approved a plan to send approximately 4,000 more troops.

The U.S. currently has about 8,400 troops in Afghanistan. The president stated that the U.S. would no longer discuss troop levels or withdrawal dates, leaving the possibility of troop increases unclear.

The president also mentioned the possibility of a political settlement that includes elements of the Taliban and Afghanistan, but acknowledged that the timing and success of such a settlement is uncertain. He emphasized that the people of Afghanistan must take responsibility for their future and achieve lasting peace.

Trump did not discuss the additional costs of the new strategy, but stated that the U.S. would seek more contributions from its NATO and other allies. The U.S. currently spends about $45 billion per year in Afghanistan.

The president acknowledged the frustration of Americans after 16 years of war without an end in sight, but stated that he did not want to repeat the mistakes made in Iraq by withdrawing too early, leaving a vacuum for terrorists to fill.

Trump announced the new strategy at Army Post Fort Meyer in Arlington, Virginia, surrounded by soldiers, and emphasized the unity among forces working towards one mission. He called for the same unity among Americans.

Title: States Face COVID-19 Budget Shortfalls: A Call for Federal Bailout vs. Long-Term Fiscal Solutions

Article:

In response to COVID-19-related budget shortfalls, some state and local officials are advocating for a nearly $1 trillion federal bailout. This equates to approximately $7,800 per household in new federal spending, surpassing the projected COVID-related state and local revenue losses for 2020 and 2021 combined.

However, the issue with federal bailouts is not just the burden on taxpayers in fiscally responsible states to subsidize irresponsible ones. Federal bailouts also incentivize financially imprudent state and local lawmakers to avoid the consequences of their fiscal mismanagement.

For instance, states like Wyoming, Alaska, North Dakota, and New Mexico have saved more than 25% of their annual revenues in rainy day funds. In contrast, states such as Illinois, Kansas, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey have set aside 1% or less.

While some states have implemented austerity measures like pay freezes and hiring limits in response to COVID-19 shortfalls, others have opted for minimal restraint, relying on federal aid instead. Illinois, for example, adopted a 2021 budget that includes record-high spending, a $6 billion deficit, no reductions in personnel costs, large pay raises for unionized state workers and lawmakers, and excessive retiree costs that consume almost one-third of the state's own revenues.

Historically, big-spending states have benefited from federal bailouts, but these only drive up state spending and delay necessary reforms. Instead, states can address COVID-19 budget shortfalls, stimulate economic recovery, and pave the way for long-term prosperity without bailouts.

One approach is to safely reopen parts of society, balancing the need to save lives and livelihoods. Data-driven, localized reopening decisions that prioritize child care availability and in-person school options can help mitigate some of the damage caused by COVID-19 shutdowns.

Another strategy is for state and local lawmakers to focus on paring back recent spending increases. Florida, for example, has reduced per-capita and inflation-adjusted spending by 16% over the last two decades. In contrast, New York and California have increased their spending by 49% and 52%, respectively, during the same period.

Education and Medicaid spending are areas of excessive spending. Florida spends $9,075 per student on education, while New York spends $23,091. Yet Florida has experienced greater achievement gains, particularly among minorities. New York's Medicaid spending has increased 20% per recipient over just three years, amounting to a difference of $20 billion in 2019.

States can also achieve significant long-term savings by aligning public employee compensation with the private sector. Short-term changes, such as forgoing the annual 2% cost-of-living adjustment for 2021, could save states a collective $26 billion. A one-year pay freeze could save up to twice as much.

Suspending public employee pension contributions and accruals for one year, a move some private-sector companies have taken to avoid layoffs, could save states up to $234 billion, enough to cover a 13% decline in state and local revenues for 2020.

While the federal government can provide assistance, it would be more beneficial to help states cope with revenue losses by relieving them of the burden of unfunded federal mandates such as the Davis-Bacon Act, the new paid family and sick leave mandate, and education mandates.

In conclusion, the federal government can aid states, but federal bailouts are not the solution. State and local officials can respond sensibly, through short-term adjustments and responsible budgeting, to boost recovery and set the stage for a stronger future.

Title: Record Number of Fires in Brazil's Amazon Rainforest in 2019

Article:

Fires in Brazil's Amazon rainforest have reached a record high number this year, according to data from the country's space research agency, the National Institute for Space Research (INPE). Nearly 73,000 fires were recorded between January and August, compared with 39,759 in all of 2018, marking an 83 percent increase over the same period last year and the highest since INPE records began in 2013.

Satellite images showed more than 9,500 new forest fires since Thursday, mostly in the Amazon basin, home to the world's largest tropical forest and seen as vital to slowing the pace of global warming. Images revealed that the northernmost state of Roraima was covered in dark smoke, while neighboring Amazonas declared an emergency in the south of the state and in its capital Manaus over the blazes. Acre, on the border with Peru, has been on environmental alert since Friday due to the fires.

A daytime blackout on Monday in Sao Paulo caused by smoke brought in by strong winds from forest fires in Amazonas and the state of Rondonia, more than 2,700km away, prompted tens of thousands of people to take to social media and voice their concerns for the welfare of the Amazon rainforest. The hashtag #prayforamazonia subsequently became a global Twitter trend, with some commentators criticizing President Jair Bolsonaro for not doing enough to protect the environment.

The unprecedented surge in fires has occurred since Bolsonaro took office in January, vowing to develop the Amazon region for farming and mining, ignoring international concern over increased deforestation. Wildfires often occur in the dry season in Brazil, which ends in late October or early November, but they are also deliberately started in efforts to illegally clear forest for cattle ranching.

INPE said the large number of wildfires could not be attributed to the dry season or natural phenomena alone. "There is nothing abnormal about the climate this year or the rainfall in the Amazon region, which is just a little below average," said INPE researcher Alberto Setzer.

President Bolsonaro brushed off widespread concerns, saying it was the time of the year of the "queimada" or burn, when farmers use fire to clear land. "I used to be called Captain Chainsaw. Now I am Nero, setting the Amazon aflame. But it is the season of the queimada," he was quoted by Reuters news agency as saying.

Environmental activists pointed to a recent increase in deforestation as the trigger for the fires. "What we are seeing is a consequence of the increase in deforestation seen in recent figures," said Ricardo Mello of WWF's Amazon Program.

Deforestation in Brazil's portion of the Amazon rainforest soared more than 88 percent in June compared with the same month a year ago, according to INPE data. Last month, INPE published preliminary data showing deforestation in Brazil's portion of the Amazon rainforest soared more than 88 percent in June compared with the same month a year ago, the second consecutive month of rising forest destruction under Bolsonaro.

Bolsonaro fired the director of INPE following the publication of the statistics, saying they were inaccurate and smearing Brazil's reputation abroad. The Brazilian leader has faced mounting domestic criticism over his rhetoric regarding the environment, which activists blame for emboldening loggers, miners, and farmers in the Amazon.

Bolsonaro has also come under increased pressure from international powers to protect Brazil's environment under the terms of a landmark free trade deal brokered over two decades between the European Union and South American bloc Mercosur - of which Brazil is a member - and agreed to last month. The pact requires the Latin American giant to abide by the Paris climate accord, which Bolsonaro has threatened to pull out of, and also aims to end illegal deforestation, including in the Brazilian Amazon.

Amid the rise in deforestation, Norway and Germany halted tens of millions of dollars of Amazon protection subsidies to the Amazon Fund, accusing Brazil of turning its back on the fight against deforestation. The move came after Bolsonaro's administration unilaterally changed the fund's governance structure and closed down the steering committee that selects the projects to back, making no formal proposal for the composition of a new committee.
