Bolsonaro reacted angrily to the suspension of funding and said Brazil would not take any lessons from the donor countries. "Isn't Norway that country that kills whales up there in the North Pole?" he told reporters. "Take that money and help Angela Merkel reforest Germany," he said.

Title: Hillary Clinton Faces No Real Pressure to Address Ferguson, Despite Calls for Involvement

Article:

In an article published by MSNBC, Alex Seitz-Wald suggests that pressure is building on Hillary Clinton to address the situation in Ferguson, Missouri. However, the article asserts that Clinton is not under any real pressure to engage with the issue, given her strong position as the presumptive 2016 Democratic Party nominee.

The article notes that President Barack Obama is not expected to address the question of systematic racial injustice in the American criminal justice system, leaving a potential opportunity for the next Democratic Party presidential nominee to step in. The article suggests that the changing demographics of the country, with younger voters being less white and more liberal on economic issues, could push the party to tackle new issues that were too hot for previous Democratic leaders to handle.

The article further explains that the lack of a contested primary in the 2016 Democratic Party presidential race is denying the country the circumstances in which high-profile Democrats are forced to address the issues that Ferguson has placed on the national agenda. The article concludes by stating that the Democratic Party, with its more multiracial coalition, is expected to continue being the political vehicle for the interests of people of color for years to come.

Title: Three Members of the "Squad" Endorse Sen. Bernie Sanders for President

Article:

Three members of the progressive congressional group known as the "Squad" have announced their support for Sen. Bernie Sanders in his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY), Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN), and Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) have expressed their endorsement for Sanders.

On Saturday, Ocasio-Cortez will appear with Sanders at a "Bernie's Back" rally in Queens, NY. Omar has also endorsed the candidate, and while it is not immediately clear if Omar and Tlaib will attend Saturday's event, Tlaib is expected to endorse Sanders as well.

In a statement posted on Twitter by the Sanders campaign, Omar was quoted as saying, "Bernie is leading a working-class movement to defeat Donald Trump that transcends generation, ethnicity, and geography." Omar added, "I believe Bernie Sanders is the best candidate to take on Donald Trump in 2020."

The endorsements come after Tuesday night's Democratic debate in Ohio, where Sen. Elizabeth Warren was under attack from multiple candidates following her rise in the polls in recent weeks. The endorsements could be a significant blow to Warren's campaign, as she, like Sanders, represents the party's progressive wing.

Winning the support of the "Squad" members is also crucial in attracting young voters, as the top three Democrats in the polls are all senior citizens: Sanders is 78, former Vice President Joe Biden is 76, and Warren is 70 years old.

There is no indication that the fourth member of the Squad, Rep. Ayanna Pressley (D-MA), is ready to make an endorsement, either of Sanders or any other candidate.

Title: Sen. Ted Cruz Links Debt Ceiling to Affordable Care Act Funding in CNN Interview

Article:

In an exclusive interview on CNN's "State of the Union" with Candy Crowley, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) discussed the ongoing debate over the debt ceiling and its connection to funding the Affordable Care Act (ACA). Cruz stated that historically, the debt ceiling has been a powerful tool for Congress to rein in executive spending.

Cruz outlined three objectives for Republicans as they approach the debt ceiling:

1. Pursue a significant structural plan to reduce government spending.
2. Avoid new taxes.
3. Seek ways to mitigate the harms from the ACA.

The senator noted that since 1978, the debt ceiling has been raised 58 times, with 20 instances involving specific and stringent requirements, often resulting in significant spending restraints. Cruz criticized the idea of increasing the nation's credit limit without any constraints, stating it as unreasonable.

The United States is expected to reach its borrowing limit on October 17. The government temporarily shut down on October 1 due to the House Republicans' refusal to pass a spending bill that would allow the government to pay its bills, as they sought changes or delayed implementation of the ACA. Sen. Cruz is often cited as the driving force behind the government shutdown, as he has urged fellow Republicans in the House to demand that any plan to fund the government be tied to defunding the ACA.

Cruz expressed concern that allowing the ACA to continue without changes would "destroy the private health care system." He accused Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of refusing to take up a series of piecemeal bills passed by the House to fund certain parts of the government. Democrats in the Senate and the White House have stated they will only pass a "clean" spending bill that does not carry restrictions or changes to the health care law.

Cruz has faced criticism from both Democrats and some Republicans for the shutdown standstill. He responded to the criticism by stating that the intensity of the attacks indicates that they are winning the argument and that the ACA is not working.

A CBS News poll released this week showed that 72% of Americans disapprove of the shutdown, with more Americans blaming congressional Republicans than President Obama. Despite this, Cruz does not believe his actions have negatively impacted his party's image.

"Not remotely," Cruz said. "But I also think far too many people are worried about politics."

Title: Houston Rockets GM Apologizes for Tweet Supporting Hong Kong Protests, Aims to Mollify Chinese Fans and Sponsors

Article:

Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey has issued an apology for a tweet he posted on Sunday that expressed support for the Hong Kong anti-government protests. The tweet, which has since been deleted, sparked a backlash from the Chinese Consulate-General in Houston, the Chinese Basketball Association, and the NBA.

Morey's apology, posted on Twitter, stated, "I have always appreciated the significant support our Chinese fans and sponsors have provided and I would hope that those who are upset will know that offending or misunderstanding them was not my intention." He continued, "I have had a lot of opportunity since that tweet to hear and consider other perspectives. I did not intend my tweet to cause any offense to Rockets fans and friends of mine in China."

The original tweet, which read, "Fight for Freedom. Stand with Hong Kong," drew thousands of replies, most of them urging Morey not to apologize. The Hong Kong protests have been ongoing for four months, with thousands of protesters demonstrating against Beijing's influence over the city.

The Chinese Consulate-General in Houston criticized Morey's tweet, stating, "We are deeply shocked by the erroneous comments on Hong Kong made by Mr. Daryl Morey, general manager of the Houston Rockets. We have lodged representations and expressed strong dissatisfaction with the Houston Rockets, and urged the latter to correct the error and take immediate concrete measures to eliminate the adverse impact."

The Chinese Basketball Association also condemned Morey's tweet, stating, "The Chinese basketball association has expressed strong opposition to the remarks, and will suspend communication and cooperation with the Houston Rockets club." The current chairman of the Chinese Basketball Association is Yao Ming, who previously played for the Houston Rockets.

Rockets owner Tilman Fertitta publicly rebuked Morey for the tweet, stating on Twitter that Morey "does NOT speak for the @HoustonRockets" and that they are "NOT a political organization."

The NBA released a statement in English on Sunday, stating, "We recognize that the views expressed by Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey have offended so many of our friends and fans in China, which is regrettable. While Daryl has made it clear that his tweet does not represent the Rockets or the NBA, the values of the league support individuals' educating themselves and sharing their views on matters important to them."

The NBA's statement in Chinese, posted on popular social network Weibo, varied slightly from the English version, according to a translation. It stated, "We are extremely disappointed by the inappropriate remarks made by Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey, who has undoubtedly seriously hurt the feelings of our Chinese fans. Morey has now clarified that his comments do not represent the position of the Rockets or the NBA."

The NBA was not immediately available for a follow-up request for comment. The NBA is China's most popular sports league and has formed partnerships with some of the country's biggest tech companies, as well as opened NBA retail stores there.

Title: Attorney General Barr to Skip House Judiciary Committee Hearing, Dispute Over Questioning Methods Arises

Article:

Attorney General William Barr will not appear at a highly anticipated hearing before the Democrat-led House Judiciary Committee on Thursday, as negotiations over his appearance have stalled, according to a source on the committee who spoke to Fox News on Sunday.

The disagreement follows a series of criticisms from congressional Democrats, who have accused Barr of compromising his integrity to appease President Donald Trump. Barr has overseen the release of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report in recent weeks, a move that has made him a target for progressives who are frustrated that Mueller's investigation found no evidence of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russians.

The House Judiciary Committee Chairman, Jerry Nadler (D-NY), reportedly wants Judiciary Committee staff to question Barr on his handling of Mueller's report, but DOJ officials insist that members of Congress should conduct the inquiry.

Meanwhile, tensions between the House Democrats and the Trump administration have escalated over full access to Mueller's report and government witnesses who have defied congressional subpoenas to testify. Democrats have been eager to question Barr as they attempt to build on Mueller's findings with their own investigations into the president.

The dispute over Barr's testimony could potentially end up in court. In the past, committees have made exceptions for committee counsels to question witnesses, but it is unusual for this to occur. For example, during Supreme Court Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation hearing last year, Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee hired an outside prosecutor to question a witness who had accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault.

At a previous House hearing, Barr faced a grilling from Democrats over his decision to release a four-page summary of Mueller's findings, which they deemed "unacceptable." The new dispute comes as the House Democrats and the Trump administration continue to clash over the release of the complete Mueller report and government witnesses who have defied congressional subpoenas to testify.

In addition to the ongoing dispute over the Mueller report, the House Oversight Committee has scheduled an interview with Carl Kline, a former White House staffer who was at risk of being held in contempt of Congress. Kline has agreed to testify, potentially averting a separate showdown between Democrats and the White House. The panel subpoenaed Kline after a former subordinate told the panel that dozens of Trump administration officials were granted security clearances despite "disqualifying issues" in their backgrounds.

Title: Obama and Romney Differ on Economic Policies in Ohio Speeches

Article:

In separate speeches in Ohio on Thursday, President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, outlined their contrasting views on economic policies and the nation's economic future. The speeches, delivered in the crucial swing state, highlighted the divergent approaches the two candidates propose to address the country's economic challenges.

President Obama, in his remarks, emphasized the importance of the election in shaping the nation's economic future. "There is one place I stand in complete agreement with Mr. Romney," Mr. Obama said. "This election is about our economic future."

The president did not present new policy prescriptions in his speech but instead contrasted his agenda with a detailed account of the Republican alternative. He criticized Republican policies over the past decade for driving up the deficit and benefiting the rich at the expense of the middle class. He also blamed these policies for the 2008 and 2009 recession, citing tax cuts for the wealthy, deregulation, and spending on the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan as key factors.

"I don't believe that the government is the answer to all of our problems," Mr. Obama said. "But what is holding us back is not a lack of big ideas, not a matter of finding the right technical solution."

Mr. Obama argued that the stalemate in Washington between two fundamentally different views on the direction America should take is what is hindering the economic recovery.

Mitt Romney, who spoke earlier in the day, emphasized private enterprise as the key to expanding the economy. He criticized the Obama administration's policies on financial regulation, health care, and energy, stating that these policies had stifled growth and hindered the recovery.

"I think he's made it harder for the American enterprise system to work," Mr. Romney said. "And I want to change that. I want to make it once again, America the most attractive place in the world for job creators."

The speeches were delivered in front of smaller audiences, with about 1,500 people attending Mr. Obama's speech at a community college. The lower attendance was intentional, as the event was described as a "speech, not a rally." However, the crowd was energetic, with many engaging in the wave, chanting the "fired up, ready to go" slogan from Mr. Obama's 2008 campaign, and cheering raucously.

The speeches came as both candidates grapple with the high national jobless rate, which remains above 8 percent. The president acknowledged the challenging environment, stating, "There will be no shortage of gaffes and controversies that keep both campaigns busy and give the press something to write about."

The Romney campaign released a campaign advertisement titled "Doing Fine" on Thursday, which features a series of sour statistics and repeated video and audio of Mr. Obama stating that "the private sector is doing fine." The ad closes with the statement, "How Can President Obama Fix Our Economy... if He Doesn't Understand It's Broken?"

The Obama campaign responded with a Web video featuring a highlight reel of Mr. Romney's own off-key moments, including quotes such as "Corporations are people too, my friend" and "I'm also unemployed."

The simultaneous visits to Ohio underscored the state's significance in the fall election, with polls showing the two candidates in a virtual dead heat. Ohio's unemployment rate, at 7.4 percent, is almost a point below the national rate.

Title: U.S. Senators Call for Open and Bipartisan Approach to Tax Reform

Article:

Two U.S. Senators, Tim Kaine (D-VA) and Angus King (I-ME), have expressed concerns about the ongoing tax reform process in Congress, urging a more open, bipartisan approach to the legislation. They argue that the current process lacks input from Democrats, outside experts, affected communities, and ordinary citizens, and is rushing to pass a bill before an arbitrary deadline without proper consideration of its long-term implications.

The senators emphasize their concern over the significant reduction in revenues that both the Senate and House bills entail, which they believe will exacerbate the growing deficit and debt. They argue that the deficit spending, particularly during relatively good economic times, is unnecessary and counterproductive, as any rational business would be paying down debt rather than adding to it.

One of the senators' primary concerns is the disproportionate benefits the current tax proposals would provide to the largest companies and wealthiest individuals, while offering little to small businesses and middle-class families. They argue that the tax plan, if passed, would likely have minimal positive impact on the American economy, citing a strong consensus of economists.

Senator Ron Johnson (R-WI) has proposed a solution to address this issue by treating all businesses the same, regardless of their organizational structure. Johnson suggests attributing the income of Subchapter C corporations to their owners and taxing that income at personal rates, a concept the senators find worth further examination.

The senators criticize the current closed process, which they believe has excluded important ideas that could promote economic growth without ballooning the debt or favoring one class of taxpayers over another. They point out that the current Senate Republican tax plan disproportionately benefits the 20% of businesses that organize as Subchapter C corporations, while doing less for the small businesses that drive the economy.

The senators argue that the current tax reform process lacks the necessary hearings, expert input, and compromise, and they call for a more open, bipartisan approach similar to the 1986 tax reform, which involved 36 hearings over ten months. They warn that missing the opportunity to pass tax reform in a responsible, bipartisan manner could lead to regret for years to come.

Title: Treasury Department's Move Regarding Russia Sanctions Not a Sanctions Easing, Says White House

The Treasury Department's decision to allow U.S. companies to make limited transactions with the Federal Security Service (FSB), Russia's intelligence agency, was not a sanctions easing, according to the White House. The move was a "technical fix" planned by the Obama administration to address an unintended consequence of the sanctions regime that prevented U.S. exporters of non-sanctioned electronic devices from complying with both U.S. and Russian law.

On Thursday, numerous media outlets and journalists claimed that President Donald Trump was easing or even lifting sanctions against Russia. However, President Trump and White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer stated that no sanctions were being eased.

"I haven't eased anything," Trump told reporters at the White House. "We're not easing sanctions," Spicer said, adding that it was a "regular course of action."

Senior Justice official John Harwood of NBC News reported that the Department had no input in the decision, and another DOJ official said the proposed immigration order was reviewed by Department lawyers before it was issued.

The media has been criticized for its coverage of the Trump administration, with some claiming that initial reports have been inaccurate or misleading. Arizona Sen. John McCain, who has called for tougher sanctions on Russia, agreed that Thursday's move was "largely a technical fix."

The media whirlwind that followed the Treasury Department's actions proved unjustified almost instantaneously. The Twitter accounts of the two Supreme Court nominees, Neil Gorsuch and Thomas Hardiman, were not set up by the White House, as initially reported.

The White House's handling of information and the media's reporting of it has been a source of controversy and criticism. The incident with the Treasury Department's move regarding Russia sanctions is a prime example of the problem. Headlines struck in a matter of hours, followed by the release of information contradicting the initial reports.

Title: New Racial Profiling Rules for Border Patrol Agents Announced by Obama Administration

Article:

The Obama administration has announced new rules for Border Patrol agents that will include training requirements and the keeping of records on complaints related to profiling. These changes come in the wake of the president's decision to grant legal status to millions of immigrants who entered the country illegally.

The new rules are likely to be met with disappointment by some advocacy groups that have lobbied the administration on racial profiling for several years. Tanya Clay House, the public policy director of the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, expressed her group's disapproval, stating that racial profiling is ineffective, both in general and at the border.

Attorney General Eric Holder, the nation's first black attorney general, has been vocal against racial profiling. He has recounted personal experiences of being stopped by the police as a college student and as a federal prosecutor. However, law enforcement officials have generally supported his efforts to broaden protections for minorities.

The Justice Department initially planned to announce the revisions to the racial profiling rules earlier this year, but the White House intervened and ordered a broad review that included the Department of Homeland Security, the parent agency of the Border Patrol. The new guidelines result from months of negotiations between the Justice Department, Homeland Security, and the White House.

The rules offer more protection against discrimination than the Supreme Court has said the Constitution requires. The court has stated that border agents may not conduct roving traffic stops based on a motorist's apparent Mexican descent, but agents at checkpoints may single out drivers for interviews based on apparent Mexican ancestry.

Representative Beto O'Rourke, a Texas Democrat who represents the border city of El Paso, questioned the effectiveness of such policies, stating, "How can race help a Border Patrol agent or customs officer do a better job in a city like El Paso, where 85 percent of the people are Hispanic?"

Last year, the Border Patrol settled a racial-profiling lawsuit in which Washington State residents accused border agents of racial profiling while making traffic stops near the Canadian border. The government admitted no wrongdoing but agreed to retrain its agents on the profiling rules.

The new guidelines prohibit federal agents from relying on broad stereotypes, but they can consider race when responding to specific leads. For example, an agent investigating a crime could consider the race of a suspect if a witness describes them as tall, white, and blond.

Title: Gun Manufacturers Respond to Lawsuits: Argue Lawsuits as Frivolous, Point to Voluntary Safety Measures

Article:

In response to ongoing lawsuits, gun manufacturers have argued that the legal actions are a frivolous attempt to financially burden them. They have also pointed to voluntary safety measures, such as the National Shooting Sports Foundation's distribution of safety locks to gun owners, as evidence of their concern for reducing accidents.

The New York Times reached out to several gun manufacturers for comment, with most declining or not responding. Timothy A. Bumann, a lawyer for Taurus International Manufacturing, reiterated arguments made by gun executives in their depositions, stating that Taurus is not a law enforcement agency and has no legal duty to police its dealers and distributors. However, he added that the company is "proactive in all the things it reasonably can do vis-à-vis the safe and lawful use of its product."

Lawrence G. Keane, senior vice president of the National Shooting Sports Foundation, the industry's trade association, stated in an email that the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives "does not want manufacturers to play Jr. G-man." He also highlighted various collaborative efforts with the A.T.F., including a more than decade-old education program to prevent illegal gun purchases, as evidence of the industry's commitment.

The lawsuits have been bolstered by testimony from several former industry insiders. Notable among them is Robert Ricker, a former lawyer for the National Rifle Association and executive director of the American Shooting Sports Council, the main gun industry trade association before its disbandment. In a 2003 affidavit on behalf of the City of San Diego, Mr. Ricker wrote, "Leaders in the industry have consistently resisted taking constructive voluntary action to prevent firearms from ending up in the illegal gun market and have sought to silence others within the industry who have advocated reform."

Mr. Ricker detailed the backlash he faced from the N.R.A. and trade groups due to his calls for reform. As a result, he was forced to resign as the head of the trade group. Another insider, Robert Hass, a former Smith & Wesson executive, testified that "the nature of the product demands that its distribution be handled in such a way as to minimize illegal and unintended use." Yet, he stated in an affidavit, "the industry's position has consistently been to take no independent action to ensure responsible distribution practices." When Smith & Wesson voluntarily adopted a set of safeguards, including requirements that its dealers limit multiple sales of firearms, it was ostracized and boycotted, forcing it to abandon the changes.

Title: Violent Protests at Middlebury College Disrupt Speech by Conservative Political Scientist Charles Murray

Article:

The violent protests that occurred at Middlebury College last week, preventing conservative political scientist Charles Murray from delivering a speech, should not be dismissed as another episode in the ongoing campus speech wars. Murray is not just another right-wing provocateur; he is a scholar whose work has sparked significant debate and controversy.

The events at Middlebury College followed a familiar pattern. Murray was invited to speak by a conservative student group, and protesters assembled to prevent him from speaking. The speech was disrupted to the point of cancellation, and Murray recorded his speech for those who wished to hear it. Protesters continued to disrupt the proceedings, and Murray was physically threatened as he attempted to leave the building. One of the professors who accompanied him was injured by the mob.

Murray's account of the events is distressing, but one point he makes is worth reiterating: this has not been his experience with past protests. The college did all the right things in advance, attempting to negotiate with the protesters and arranging for a backup plan to record the speech if the protests proved too disruptive. The college administration stood firmly and unequivocally for free speech and the marketplace of ideas. In his past experience, these measures have been adequate to ensure that protests remained civil and did not prevent him from speaking. This time, that was not enough.

Murray is no stranger to protest; if he says something has changed, it is worth taking him seriously. He is infamous primarily for his 1994 book, The Bell Curve, which argued that IQ measured important differences in intelligence between individuals that were highly predictive of success across multiple dimensions, and because of this, our society was becoming increasingly stratified by cognitive ability. The primary locus of the controversy around the book related to his comments on differences in IQ between racial and ethnic groups, which Murray believes to be at least partly innate. It is understandable why such views would invite a furious response.

However, the larger point about class stratification has only become more evident over time and became the focus of his most recent book, Coming Apart. And with the election of Donald Trump, the cultural consequences of that stratification have powered the most astonishing political upheaval of our time.

All of which is to say: Murray is someone students need to hear from. He may be utterly wrong in his explanations for the phenomena he is studying, and he may be thoroughly misguided in his proposed solutions. But he is asking questions that must be asked—and that must be asked in particular of a community of higher education, which is a primary vehicle for the stratification he worries about.

Moreover, the concerns Murray is airing should be of particular interest to the left, which historically stands against the concentration of economic and political power, and against domination by a ruling class. If meritocracy and equality of opportunity do not increase social mobility and reduce class stratification, but the opposite, that would seem to be at least as powerful an argument for old-school left-wing solutions, like strong labor unions and the redistribution of wealth, as it is for Murray's own conservative libertarianism.

Left-wingers should want to hear Murray—and hear what answers can be had from his analysis—more than conservatives should, because he is asking precisely the questions they need to answer. By ruling Murray unworthy of consideration, the radicals who protested him have not just traduced important norms related to free speech and civil respect (which would be bad enough), they have traduced those norms in the name of preserving themselves from having to question the institution they attend and its place in our society. A less-radical agenda than theirs is hard to imagine.

This is not a phenomenon limited to the left by any means. The same week that Murray was attacked at Middlebury, a bill was introduced into the Arkansas legislature to ban the work of radical historian Howard Zinn from public schools. But the right has an anti-liberal tradition to justify the notion that people should be "protected" from subversive, unpatriotic, or blasphemous views. And a right-wing legislator seeking to protect the existing power structure is at least acting in their own interest. The radical left is doing precisely the opposite.

At some point in an article like this, the writer typically says that they abjure Murray's abhorrent views but stand firmly for his right to air them, or that by engaging in violent and disruptive protest, you merely turn him into a martyr and thereby enhance his stature rather than silencing him. And if I were writing about an odious troll like Milo Yiannopoulos, and I bothered to write an article about him at all, I might say something like that.

But I'm not going to say that about Charles Murray. He deserves to be debated not only because free speech belongs to everyone, but because he is asking absolutely vital questions. And any left worth its salt would jump at every chance to demonstrate that they have better answers.

Title: Grand Jury Decision: No Indictment for Officer Darren Wilson in Shooting of Michael Brown

Article:

A grand jury has decided that there is not enough probable cause to indict police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed 18-year-old, which led to violent protests in Ferguson, Missouri. The grand jury's decision, like the shooting that sparked the unrest, has been a subject of intense debate.

In a rare move, the prosecuting attorney, Robert McCulloch, made public the evidence presented to the grand jury in an attempt to allay concerns about bias. The evidence includes thousands of pages of witness interviews, including testimony from Wilson and many witnesses.

The grand jury's decision hinges on the interpretation of events leading up to the shooting, particularly whether Brown was charging at Wilson or surrendering. Witness testimony has been inconsistent, with some witnesses stating that Wilson started shooting after he got out of the car, while others claim he started shooting from within the car. Some witnesses describe Brown as clearly surrendering, while others claim he did not appear to have been hit at all.

One witness, Witness 14, who is sympathetic to Brown, stated that Brown was "executed" and that Wilson had "made up his mind to kill him." However, when federal investigators interviewed Witness 14, the witness's assumptions became less clear. The witness's account of Brown's hands being up as a sign of surrender is questioned, with the investigator leading the witness to admit that Brown was moving toward Officer Wilson, who was screaming as he fired his weapon.

Officer Wilson's testimony to the grand jury presents the image of an officer who was scared for his life during the confrontation with the larger man who he says was physically assaulting him. Wilson described Brown and his associate, Dorian Johnson, walking in the middle of the street, preventing normal traffic from passing. He stated that he told them to move to the sidewalk, and after a brief exchange, Brown used a vulgarity at him. Wilson said he called for backup and tried to open the door of his police car, but Brown slammed the door shut. They struggled, and Brown hit him in the face twice, Wilson said.

Wilson said he considered using Mace, his baton, and his flashlight before drawing his gun and telling Brown, "Get back or I'm going to shoot you." Brown then grabbed his gun, Wilson said, and twisted it and dug it down into the officer's hip. The officer said he feared he would die if Brown got hold of the gun. He said he managed to raise the gun and fired twice. It just clicked. But the third time, the gun went off, startling both men.

That's when, Wilson said, Brown looked up at him "and had the most intense aggressive face. The only way I can describe it, it looks like a demon, that's how angry he looked." He comes back towards me again with his hands up." Wilson said he tried firing again but nothing happened. When he tried once more, it went off. Brown then hit him again, he said.

The officer said that when he looked up, Brown was running away. Wilson said he got out of the car, called for backup, and began chasing Brown. He said Brown then stopped and he did, too. He said he ordered Brown to get on the ground, but the 18-year-old did not. He said Brown made an "aggravated sound" and ran back toward him. He said he warned Brown repeatedly to get on the ground, but when he did not comply, the officer fired "a series of shots."

"I do not know how many I shot, I just know I shot it," he said.

Wilson explained his rationale for why he chased Brown, stating that he wanted to keep Brown "contained" until support arrived. He said he thought that if he could buy 30 seconds of time, until other officers arrived, they could "make the arrest, nothing happens, we are all good."

One important part of this case is the physical evidence. The autopsy found that Michael Brown was never shot in the back, as some early witnesses claimed. Second, they found Brown's blood inside the police car and on Wilson's gun, implying close-range contact as Wilson alleges. Photographs taken of Wilson on the day of the confrontation show doctors diagnosing him with a bruise, which seems to cast some doubt on Wilson's testimony about the intensity of the confrontation.

We have uploaded most of the documents we received from prosecutors. We invite you to look through them and tip us off to anything you find interesting in the comments.

Title: House Democrats' Impeachment Inquiry: Yovanovitch Testimony Kicks Off Friday

Article:

House Democrats' second public hearing in their impeachment inquiry begins at 9 am ET on Friday, featuring the testimony of former U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch. The hearing can be watched on CSPAN or other major networks, with a live stream available.

Friday's hearing will delve into the ouster of Yovanovitch, a career diplomat who was removed from her ambassador post in April, just days after Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine's president, was elected. The hearing will provide a chronological step back from the alleged quid pro quo efforts that unfolded after Yovanovitch's departure from Kyiv.

Yovanovitch, a career foreign service officer for over three decades, was sworn in as ambassador to Ukraine in August of 2016 and held the post until her abrupt removal in the spring of 2019. She is currently a teaching fellow at Georgetown University.

According to the accounts of other witnesses who have testified in the impeachment inquiry, Yovanovitch was highly respected among her colleagues. However, she ran afoul of two powerful individuals: Rudy Giuliani, Trump's personal lawyer, and Ukraine's prosecutor general, Yuri Lutsenko, under the previous administration.

In an apparent effort to win President Trump's favor, Lutsenko and Giuliani began discussing the possibility that the Ukrainian prosecutor general could launch investigations into Trump's enemies. They discussed investigating Burisma, the Ukrainian natural gas company whose board included Hunter Biden, as well as purported Ukrainian interference in the 2016 US presidential election.

Yovanovitch objected when Lutsenko asked the US embassy to set up meetings with FBI or Justice Department officials, stating that such meetings were not typical. Instead, she encouraged him to meet with the FBI's legal attaché in Kyiv. "I don't think he really appreciated it," she told investigators.

In response, Lutsenko began spreading what Yovanovitch says was a completely fabricated story about her: that she gave him a list of people she didn't want him to prosecute. (Lutsenko has since recanted that story.) Rumors also spread that Yovanovitch was a Trump critic who was bad-mouthing the president in private. The purpose of these rumors seems to have been to push her out of the ambassadorship.

The smear campaign exploded into public view in March of 2019, when Lutsenko gave an interview to conservative journalist John Solomon of The Hill repeating the unsubstantiated allegation that Yovanovitch had given him a "do not prosecute" list.

Soon, top Trump allies like Giuliani and Fox News talk show host Sean Hannity were openly attacking Yovanovitch. The president's son, Don Jr., also tweeted an article about calls to remove her, writing that the US needs "less of these jokers as ambassadors."

In late April, just three days after Zelensky's election meant a new administration would come in, Yovanovitch received a call from a State Department official who told her to leave Ukraine on the next plane. The Deputy Secretary of State later explained to her that Trump had decided she had to go—and the haste was due to fear Trump would attack her in a public tweet.

Yovanovitch was out. But when Trump spoke to Zelensky during their now-infamous phone call on July 25, her name came up. "The former ambassador from the United States, the woman, was bad news, and the people she was dealing with in the Ukraine were bad news, so I just wanted to let you know that," Trump said, according to a quasi-transcript released by the NSC. Later, he added: "Well, she's going to go through some things."

For more of an idea of what Yovanovitch will say, read the transcript of her closed-door deposition at this link.

Friday's hearing will close out this first week of impeachment inquiry hearings, but Democrats have set up a full slate of events for next week. On Tuesday, November 19, the morning will feature Jennifer Williams (a State Department official advising the vice president's office) and Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman (a National Security Council staffer). The afternoon will feature Kurt Volker (the former US special representative to Ukraine) and Tim Morrison (a National Security Council staffer).

On Wednesday, November 20, US Ambassador to the EU Gordon Sondland will testify in the morning. Defense Department official Laura Cooper and Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs David Hale will testify in the afternoon.

Then, on Thursday, November 21, former National Security Council staffer Fiona Hill is scheduled to testify. It is unclear whether that will be the end of the public hearings or whether there will be more to come. But Democrats had hoped to complete this phase of their inquiry before Thanksgiving.

Title: MSNBC Host Joy Reid Corrects Errors in Tweet About President Trump's Wives

Article:

MSNBC host Joy Reid faced criticism for a tweet she posted on July 21, 2017, regarding President Donald Trump's wives. In the tweet, Reid attempted to suggest a connection between Trump and Russia by stating that two of his three wives are from nations that were once part of the Soviet Union.

The tweet read, "Donald Trump married one American (his second wife) and two women from what used to be Soviet Yugoslavia: Ivana-Slovakia, Melania-Slovenia."

However, there were several errors in the tweet. Reid was correct that one of the three women Trump has married is an American, Marla Maples, who was born in Georgia, a southern U.S. state, not the former Soviet republic. She was also correct that Melania Trump, whom Trump married in 2005, is from Slovenia.

However, Trump's first wife, Ivana, is not from Slovakia. Nor was Slovakia part of Yugoslavia. Yugoslavia, while communist, was not a member of the Soviet bloc. Ivana Trump, the mother of Trump's first three children, was born in what is now the Czech Republic, formerly known as Czechoslovakia. Czechoslovakia became a part of the Soviet bloc in 1948, a year before Ivana was born.

Reid later corrected one of the errors in her tweet, stating, "Right- correction. Ivana is from Czechoslovakia (now the Czech Republic). Good catch." She also noted that Slovenia, where Melania was born, is one of the five nations that once made up Yugoslavia.

Despite the corrections, the tweet still contained an error, as Yugoslavia was not a part of the Soviet Union. Reid later tweeted, "Melania is from Slovenia (which, plus Slovakia, used to be Yugoslavia)."

Title: House Progressives Call for Vote on Iran War Powers Legislation, Blocking Funding for Military Action

Article:

House progressives have called for immediate votes on legislation to block funding for military action against Iran and to repeal the 2002 authorization of military force. The push comes after an airstrike last week that killed top Iranian General Qassem Soleimani.

Freshman Rep. Elissa Slotkin, a former CIA and Pentagon analyst who served multiple tours in Iraq and represents a competitive district, is expected to lead a resolution that would require the Trump administration's military hostilities with Iran to cease within 30 days if no further congressional action is taken.

In addition to the War Powers Resolution, members of the Congressional Progressive Caucus are pushing for votes on two other measures. One, from Rep. Ro Khanna, would prohibit funds for offensive military force in or against Iran without prior authorization from Congress. The other bill, previously introduced by Rep. Barbara Lee last year, would repeal the 2002 authorization of military force against Iraq.

"In addition to the War Powers Resolution, we believe it is imperative to simultaneously pursue all avenues to prevent a disastrous war with Iran," Lee and Congressional Progressive Caucus Co-Chairmen Mark Pocan and Pramila Jayapal said in a joint statement. "Given the lack of any coherent strategy by the White House to de-escalate tensions and protect U.S. troops, regional partners, and innocent civilians, Congress must act swiftly to prevent another endless war."

The House passed an annual defense authorization bill last summer that included the proposals from Khanna and Lee. However, both of their measures were ultimately left out of the final version that President Trump signed into law last month.

The War Powers Resolution to be unveiled by Slotkin and Democratic leaders this week to limit the Trump administration's actions against Iran is expected to pass easily with widespread support from Democrats. A House vote on the resolution has not yet been scheduled but is expected later in the week.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi wrote in a letter to her colleagues on Sunday that "As Members of Congress, our first responsibility is to keep the American people safe. For this reason, we are concerned that the Administration took this action without the consultation of Congress and without respect for Congress’s war powers granted to it by the Constitution."

It's unlikely that Senate Republicans, who have largely backed Trump for ordering the strike that killed Soleimani, will support the measure to restrict his powers. Congress did pass a resolution last year to force the Trump administration to end U.S. involvement in the Saudi-led war in Yemen, but Trump vetoed it. An attempt to override Trump's veto in the Senate fell short of the necessary two-thirds majority.

Trump administration officials, including Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Defense Secretary Mark Esper, are slated to brief members of the House and Senate about Iran on Wednesday.

Title: GOP Presidential Debate: Rubio Emerges Victorious as Bush Faces Criticism

Article:

The Republican presidential debate on Wednesday in Boulder, Colorado, saw a significant shift in the political landscape, with Marco Rubio emerging as the clear winner and Jeb Bush facing criticism for his performance. According to a special edition of the ███ Caucus, a weekly survey of top operatives, activists, and strategists in Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina, and Nevada, nearly 60 percent of respondents deemed Bush's debate performance as a loss.

Bush's attempt to attack Rubio's Senate attendance record was met with swift counterpunches, leaving him looking opportunistic, desperate, and weak, according to several GOP insiders. Rubio, on the other hand, was praised for his preparedness and ability to handle Bush's attacks effectively.

Jeb Bush's sharpest attack, a well-rehearsed line about Rubio's missed Senate votes, was parried by the Florida senator, who responded calmly, "Someone has convinced you that attacking me is going to help you." Bush failed to respond effectively and was largely invisible for the rest of the night, finishing last in terms of speaking time.

Marco Rubio's victory was not a solo effort; New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and Texas Senator Ted Cruz finished second and third, respectively. Rubio's handling of the attendance issue and his response to Bush's attacks were highlighted as key factors in his victory.

Democrats also rendered a similar judgment, with 61 percent seeing a clear Bush loss and 42 percent giving Rubio the victory. The debate itself was choppy, with moderators struggling to control the dialogue and facing criticism for their tough questions.

Donald Trump, the Republican front-runner, was not rated as the victor by any GOP insider, but barely any said he lost. Trump's performance was described as lackluster by some, with one respondent rating his performance a "C" and another finding him "banal" and disengaged in the latter portion of the debate.

Ben Carson, who recently surpassed Trump in a national poll, also failed to leave a significant mark, with just 6 percent saying he won and 10 percent saying he lost.

The debate marked a significant moment in the Republican primary race, with Rubio emerging as a strong contender and Bush facing criticism for his performance. The next Republican debate is scheduled for November 10 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

Title: House Republicans Work to Limit Defections on Trump's Emergency Declaration Vote

Article:

House Republicans are making efforts to limit the number of defections on a legislative measure aimed at blocking President Donald Trump's emergency declaration to potentially under a dozen on Tuesday. The White House and GOP leaders are making a last-minute push to avoid a humiliating defeat for the president, according to multiple Republican sources.

So far, only one Republican, libertarian Rep. Justin Amash (R-Mich.), has backed a Democratic measure to overturn Trump's national emergency declaration. The House vote on Tuesday could set the tone in the Senate by offering political cover to Republican senators who have expressed concerns about Trump's move to secure billions of dollars without Congress's approval.

House Democrats believe they could win support from between five to 10 Republicans in Tuesday's much-anticipated floor vote, according to two sources. In an attempt to drum up GOP support, Democrats have circulated a spreadsheet of hundreds of military construction projects that the White House could potentially take money from for its border project.

Pressure has been building, with Pentagon officials visiting Capitol Hill on Friday to brief top defense spending leaders of both parties on where the administration could divert $3.6 billion from military projects to the border. Trump has vowed to veto the Democratic resolution, and House Republican leaders are confident that they will fall far short of the more than 50 Republican votes they'd need for an override.

Rep. Mike Turner (R-Ohio) and four other House Republicans sent a letter to Trump earlier this month urging him to look elsewhere for the money. Turner, a defense hawk whose state could lose as much as $90 million in military construction funds, has said Trump's move would be a "dangerous precedent." However, he has not specifically said if he would support the Democratic resolution.

Rep. Roger Williams (R-Texas) initially feared that Trump's move could take money from Fort Hood, which is in his district. But last week, he received a personal assurance from Pentagon officials that no existing funding would be used. "That's a big deal to me," Williams said Monday night, confirming that he would vote against the resolution.

Trump began applying public pressure to his own party on Monday, warning Republicans not to fall into the Democratic "trap." The White House legislative affairs team has also been making the case privately to Republican lawmakers over the weekend and on Monday, according to a White House official. Officials have been doing outreach to provide "as much information as possible," and plan to take a more targeted approach after they learn which GOP members are considering voting for the measure.

House Minority Whip Steve Scalise sent talking points to the GOP caucus on Monday, stating that there are already 31 national emergencies in effect, and that Trump is specifically working to address a "humanitarian and security crisis." Separately, House Minority Whip Steve Scalise will begin formally counting votes Monday night. The White House is eyeing a total of $8 billion in border cash, which would also include $2.5 billion from a Pentagon drug interdiction program as well as $600 million from a Treasury Department forfeiture fund. Since Trump's announcement earlier this month, groups of former national security officials and former GOP members of Congress have also expressed opposition to the move.

Title: Scarlett Johansson Clarifies Comments on Artistic Freedom and Casting

Article:

Actress Scarlett Johansson, who faced backlash for her role in the live-action Ghost in the Shell remake and the controversial casting in the upcoming biopic Rub & Tug, has expressed further thoughts on the issue of casting in an interview with As If magazine. In the interview, Johansson discussed the confrontation between political correctness and art, stating that "as an actor, I should be able to play any person, or any tree, or any animal because that is my job and the requirements of my job."

The comments made by Johansson were picked up by the Daily Mail and caused an uproar, leading Johansson to release a statement claiming the article was "edited for clickbait and is widely taken out of context." The interview was not a standard profile, but rather a collaboration between Johansson and contemporary painter David Salle, during which they worked on a photoshoot featuring Salle's work.

In the interview, Johansson discussed her acting role models of the 1950s, such as James Dean, Natalie Wood, and Marlon Brando, and their liberated and unapologetic portrayal of emotions. Johansson also addressed the issue of casting, stating that "today there's a lot of emphasis and conversation about what acting is and who we want to see represent ourselves on screen. The question now is, what is acting anyway? Right. Who gets to play what roles... You know, as an actor I should be allowed to play any person, or any tree, or any animal because that is my job and the requirements of my job."

Johansson clarified her point in a statement, stating that "I personally feel that, in an ideal world, any actor should be able to play anybody and Art, in all forms, should be immune to political correctness. That was the point I was making, albeit didn't come across that way." Johansson also acknowledged the widespread discrepancy in the industry that favors Caucasian, cis-gendered actors and the need for diversity in any industry.

In a separate interview, co-star, screenwriter, and director of Johansson's upcoming movie Jojo Rabbit, Taika Waititi, discussed his role in the movie and his general theory of casting, stating, "Week one down of our anti-fuckface satire, Jojo Rabbit. Can't wait to share it with the world. Also, what better way to insult Hitler than having him portrayed by a Polynesian Jew?" This example shows that racially insensitive casting can be used for good as well as evil, as long as it is used to be disrespectful.

Title: Boston Residents Celebrate Capture of Marathon Bombing Suspect, Mourn Victims and Fallen Officers

Article:

Following the capture of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the suspected perpetrator of the Boston Marathon bombings, Boston residents expressed feelings of joy and relief after a tense "shelter at home" lockdown during the manhunt. The 19-year-old immigrant of Chechen heritage, who authorities believe set two bombs near the race's finish line, was apprehended on Friday night.

The Boston Police Department announced the capture with a Twitter post that read, "CAPTURED!! The hunt is over. The search is over. The terror is over. The city is safe." Boston Mayor Thomas M. Menino stated, "I am so proud of all our first responders. Thanks to them – the people of Boston will sleep well tonight."

The manhunt, which lasted a day, had initially labeled the suspect as "Suspect #2" by the FBI. He was last seen after a Friday shootout that killed his brother, "Suspect #1" Tamerlan Tsarnaev, in the Boston suburb of Watertown. The suspect was eventually captured in Watertown.

Unfortunately, another person was killed during the manhunt – Sean Collier, a campus police officer at MIT. Transit officer Richard Donahue was severely injured.

The lifting of the lockdown, early Friday evening, aided in the apprehension of Suspect #2. A Watertown resident noticed a trail of blood leading to a boat parked on his property, and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was found inside. The arrest took some time, as police took precautions against possible explosives on the scene.

An investigation by the FBI continues, preparing for a high-profile prosecution, even as Dzhokhar Tsarnaev is being treated for wounds in a local hospital. Boston residents were able to rest easy by bedtime and to go about life as usual on Saturday.

Title: Trump Campaign Aides Reportedly Had Frequent Contact with Russian Intelligence Officials

Article:

The Russian influence scandal surrounding the White House has intensified as reports emerged on Tuesday that some of Donald Trump's campaign aides had regular contact with Russian intelligence officials throughout 2016. The New York Times reported that four current and former US intelligence officials, who remain unnamed, have not found evidence in intercepted phone communications that Trump campaign officials cooperated with Russian intelligence in Moscow's attempts to sway the election in Trump's favor. However, the contacts' purpose remains unclear.

CNN reported that "high-level advisers close to then-presidential nominee Donald Trump were in constant communication during the campaign with Russians known to US intelligence."

These reports contradict White House spokesman Sean Spicer, who, on Tuesday, reiterated his previous assertions that there were no pre-election contacts between the Trump team and Russian officials. Last month, Trump himself also denied any such contacts.

The reports add pressure on the Republican congressional leadership to launch committee hearings on Russian election interference, which were promised but have yet to materialize. They also indicate that intelligence officials are willing to leak against the Trump administration, making it risky for the White House to try to shut down investigations into collusion with Moscow that are reportedly being carried out by several intelligence agencies.

The reports add circumstantial weight to the reports on the Trump campaign's Kremlin links compiled last year and passed to the FBI by a former MI6 officer, Christopher Steele. His reports alleged active, sustained, and covert collusion to subvert the election, which, if confirmed, could constitute treason.

Trump responded with a series of angry tweets on Wednesday, claiming the Russian connection allegations are merely an attempt to cover up mistakes made in Hillary Clinton's losing campaign. He also accused the intelligence community of "unAmerican" leaks to newspapers and called the reports "fake news."

The only Trump associate named in the New York Times report as having participated in the contacts was Paul Manafort, who was the Trump campaign manager for several months last summer. Manafort has repeatedly denied any contacts with Russian officials.

Manafort left the Trump campaign in August, after allegations about his activities in Ukraine first surfaced. At about the same time, the campaign also distanced itself from a US businessman, Carter Page, whom Trump had previously described as an adviser, after Page was reported to have had contacts with Vladimir Putin's top lieutenants. Page called the reports "complete garbage."

The new reports of the Trump campaign's contacts with Moscow rekindled bitterness among former campaign aides to Hillary Clinton, over a pre-election announcement by the FBI director, James Comey, that new material was being studied in an investigation of her use of a private internet server for her emails. That investigation came to nothing, but Clinton officials were convinced the bad publicity, just 11 days before the election, cost her crucial votes. By contrast, they point out, the Republican Comey said nothing about investigations underway at the same time into Trump's Russian links.

"I'd like the FBI to explain why they sent a letter about Clinton but not this," Clinton's former campaign manager, Robby Mook, said in a tweet on Tuesday night. Her former spokesman, Brian Fallon, tweeted, "Everything we suspected during the campaign is proving true. This is a colossal scandal."

Title: Former High School Biology-Laboratory Assistant Shares Insights on the Importance of Work Experience

Article:

Ben Carson, professor emeritus of neurosurgery at Johns Hopkins University, reflects on his early work experiences as a high school student. He recounts his first job as a high school biology-laboratory assistant, where he gained valuable skills and scientific knowledge that proved beneficial in his future endeavors.

Carson held various jobs throughout his youth, each providing unique skills and experiences. He worked as a mailroom clerk, learning the importance of accuracy, speed, and organization. He also worked as a student assistant to the police department, meeting distinguished individuals and gaining exposure to various experiences.

As a supervisor for a highway cleanup crew, Carson learned about managing people and eventually secured a higher-paying factory job and his dream summer job of driving sports cars off the assembly line. He emphasizes that working leads to the acquisition of knowledge, experience, relationships, and opportunities for advancement, which are crucial components of realizing the American dream.

Carson acknowledges the challenges in today's job market and the potential appeal of public aid for those seeking sustenance. However, he argues that pursuing minimum-wage jobs offers valuable skills and opportunities that may not be available through public aid.

Carson recalls his experiences finding summer jobs during his college years, emphasizing the importance of persistence and initiative. He suggests that young people looking for jobs should approach small businesses directly, expressing their eagerness to work and their college status. Carson believes that employers are more likely to retain valuable, productive employees, and that such opportunities may not present themselves to those relying on public entitlements.

Carson concludes by emphasizing the importance of supporting and encouraging young people in their job-seeking endeavors, as the grooming of youth is essential for the future success of the nation and the pursuit of happiness for all.

Title: World War II Memorial Closure and Healthcare.gov Issues Highlight Government Inefficiency During Shutdown

Article:

This week, the ongoing U.S. government shutdown resulted in the closure of the World War II Memorial, preventing veterans from visiting their own memorial. Despite the shutdown, some World War II veterans disregarded the barricades and gathered at the memorial. Meanwhile, the rollout of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) faced significant issues, with the healthcare.gov website crashing and millions of Americans experiencing difficulties with the new healthcare system.

The shutdown has been a source of controversy, with many Americans expressing frustration over the closure of the World War II Memorial. Some speculate that it may have cost more to place the barricades than to leave them unrestricted. Regardless, the veterans' determination to visit their memorial was evident, as they managed to gather at the site despite the government-imposed barriers.

In addition to the World War II Memorial closure, the rollout of Obamacare has faced numerous challenges. The healthcare.gov website, designed to facilitate the enrollment process for the new healthcare system, experienced technical difficulties, causing frustration for many Americans. President Barack Obama compared the issues to the glitches that occur when Apple unveils a new product, but the analogy has been met with criticism.

It is important to note that all members of Congress will be required to obtain healthcare through the Obamacare exchanges, as will their staff. In some states, such as Kentucky, the number of insurance providers available has decreased significantly compared to previous options. While the author experienced only minor issues with Obamacare, many Americans have faced more substantial concerns, including the potential loss of their current plans, new law-related worries, potential fines, privacy concerns, and even job security.

The shutdown has been a contentious issue, with both parties offering compromises to keep the government operating. The author, for example, proposed an amendment to extend the government shutdown for an additional week to allow for continued negotiations. However, all proposals have been rejected by the Democrats.

Critics argue that the government's handling of the shutdown and the rollout of Obamacare highlights the inefficiency and incompetence of the U.S. government. The author suggests that the government's inability to effectively manage national healthcare and even smaller-scale operations, such as overseeing a war memorial, demonstrates a systemic problem within the government.

Annual trillion-dollar deficits and a $17 trillion debt are further evidence of the government's inefficiency. The author concludes that the shutdown serves as a reminder of the government's dysfunctional nature, particularly in taking on too many functions and ultimately failing to meet the needs of the American people.

Title: Justice Ginsburg Denies Temporary Block on Official Depositions in Census Lawsuit

Article:

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has denied the Trump administration's request for the Supreme Court to temporarily block lower court-ordered document requests and depositions of two key officials behind the controversial plan to add a question about citizenship status to the 2020 census. However, Ginsburg left the door open for the administration to request a permanent block in the future.

The administration has signaled its intention to escalate the legal fight over the citizenship question to the high court. This move could involve a request for the Supreme Court to order lower courts to stop the depositions or for the high court to hear the case.

Lawyers for the plaintiffs in the two lead cases have been preparing to question Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross and Justice Department official John Gore in their final weeks of evidence-gathering, which is scheduled to end on Oct. 12. A potential trial for these lawsuits is set to start on Nov. 5 at the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.

Last month, a judge on the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals put Ross' deposition on hold while the request was under review. In a filing on Wednesday, Solicitor General Noel Francisco at the Justice Department, which is representing the administration in the six lawsuits around the country over the hotly contested question, wrote that he was preemptively asking the Supreme Court to consider blocking Ross' Oct. 11 deposition in case the 2nd Circuit refuses to do so.

A three-judge panel is set to review the administration's earlier request for the 2nd Circuit to stop Ross' deposition on Oct. 9.

The Trump administration has been trying to convince the courts that deposing Ross and Gore is not necessary to resolve these lawsuits and that the judges should instead rely on the record of internal memos, emails, and other documents already released by the administration.

In their earlier request for the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to block Ross' deposition, Justice Department attorneys wrote, "The validity of the Secretary's decision is properly judged on that objective record, without inquiry into Secretary Ross's deliberative process and any subjective reasons he might have had for favoring the reinstatement of a citizenship question."

The Trump administration has repeatedly tried to block discovery in the lawsuits, and courts have repeatedly rejected their attempts. U.S. District Judge Jesse Furman had previously allowed the plaintiffs' attorneys to question Ross, who oversees the Census Bureau as the head of the Commerce Department. Ross announced in March that he approved the Justice Department's request to add a citizenship question to forms for the upcoming national head count.

A three-judge panel of the 2nd Circuit recently upheld Furman's separate order for the deposition of Gore, who leads the Justice Department's civil rights division, which argues that it needs responses to the citizenship question to better enforce the Voting Rights Act's protections of racial and language minorities from discrimination.

The plaintiffs, who include dozens of states, cities, and other groups that want the question removed, claim that Ross misused his authority and discriminated against immigrant communities of color by ordering the 2020 census to inquire about U.S. citizenship status—a topic that has not been included in the census for all U.S. households since 1950.

Critics of the question point to Census Bureau research suggesting that asking about citizenship status could discourage households with noncitizens, including unauthorized immigrants, from participating in the once-a-decade head count of every person living in the U.S., as required under the Constitution.

However, Furman has ruled, in part, that the officials should be deposed because of documents suggesting that better enforcement of the Voting Rights Act was not the main driver behind the push for a citizenship question.

"Secretary Ross must sit for a deposition because, among other things, his intent and credibility are directly at issue in these cases," Furman wrote in an opinion filed last month.

As NPR has reported, an internal email exchange released as part of the lawsuits provided an early indication that the Trump administration was preparing to defend the citizenship question at the Supreme Court months before the Justice Department formally submitted its request for the question in December 2017.

Title: Trump Suggests Apple Move Production to U.S. to Avoid Tariff-Related Price Increases

Article:

President Donald Trump has suggested that Apple Inc., a major tech company based in Cupertino, California, could avoid potential price increases on some of its products due to proposed additional tariffs on Chinese-made goods by moving production to the United States. In a tweet on Saturday, Trump stated, "Apple prices may increase because of the massive Tariffs we may be imposing on China — but there is an easy solution where there would be ZERO tax, and indeed a tax incentive, if the company made its products in the U.S. instead of China."

This week, Apple announced that a proposed new round of $200 billion in additional tariffs on Chinese imports could raise prices on some of its products, including the Apple Watch and the Mac mini. The company is heavily exposed to the ongoing trade war between the U.S. and China, as it manufactures many of its products for the U.S. market in China and sells gadgets, including the iPhone, in China, making them potential targets for Chinese retaliation against the Trump tariffs.

Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The company has not announced plans to move manufacturing from China to the U.S.

In a letter this week to the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative, Apple stated, "because all tariffs ultimately show up as a tax on US consumers, they will increase the cost of Apple products that our customers have come to rely on in their daily lives." The company added that tariffs would hit "a wide range of Apple products," including computers, watches, adapters, chargers, and tools used in its U.S. manufacturing, repair, and data centers. Apple stated that the tariffs would raise the cost of its U.S. operations and put it at a disadvantage to foreign rivals.

The White House has accused China of stealing U.S. intellectual property and forcing American companies to share their technology with Chinese companies. The tariffs are intended to pressure China to stop this behavior, the administration has said. However, Apple stated, "it is difficult to see" how tariffs would advance the government's goal.

The presidential tweet is the latest development in a dispute between the Trump administration and companies that fear tariffs will hurt their business. The Trump administration has already imposed tariffs of $50 billion on imports from China, mostly equipment and material used by manufacturers. In July, Apple CEO Tim Cook stated that these measures had no effect on Apple. However, the company is concerned about the Trump administration's proposal to add 25 percent duties on another $200 billion in Chinese goods, including a wider assortment of consumer-related items.

Title: U.S. and Allies Face Tension Over Palestinian Resolution at United Nations

Article:

A diplomatic standoff is developing at the United Nations as Palestinian officials, along with their allies, push for a resolution demanding Israel's withdrawal from the West Bank and East Jerusalem within two years. The Obama administration is grappling with the situation, attempting to ease tensions and establish a position that prioritizes halting the escalating Israeli-Palestinian violence and creating conditions for future peace talks.

Initially, Palestinian officials planned to submit the resolution for a potential vote on Wednesday. However, with the U.S. likely to veto the resolution, the vote may be postponed.

On Tuesday, Secretary of State John Kerry urged against any actions that could interfere or be perceived as interfering in Israeli elections scheduled for March. Kerry emphasized the importance of lowering tensions and ending the violence to create an opportunity for both Israelis and Palestinians to find a mutually desired path for peace.

Kerry declined to categorize the U.S.'s position on suggestions for the U.N. Security Council to set a framework for negotiations, which Israel strongly opposes. The U.S. is currently engaged in constructive conversations with all parties involved.

Kerry's meetings on Monday included discussions with chief Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat, Arab League chief Nabil Elaraby, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and foreign ministers from Britain, France, and Germany.

For the Obama administration, this issue represents a delicate situation. The administration has recently quelled speculation about potential U.S. sanctions on Israel, but it has expressed objections to certain settlement expansions in territory the Palestinians desire for a future state.

The most hard-line, pro-Palestinian U.N. resolution is being drafted by Jordan, on behalf of the Palestinians. This resolution would demand a full Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank within two years and full recognition of Palestine as a state, without mention of land swaps or security measures.

The U.S. and France have also drafted versions of a Security Council resolution, though they have not been submitted. Council diplomats, who requested anonymity, told Fox News that the French draft of the resolution is less hostile toward Israel than the one being put forward by Jordan, but it does parallel concepts in that text, most notably calls for an Israeli withdrawal by a determined deadline. The U.S. Mission is not disclosing details of its draft, but its existence indicates the Obama administration may feel a U.N. resolution of some kind is necessary.

France's resolution reportedly uses the 1967 Mideast borders as the basis for dividing the land, which President Obama has publicly endorsed, but it does not include key Israeli and U.S. conditions such as Palestinian recognition of Israel as a Jewish state.

In Paris on Tuesday, French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius made his case to Elaraby, Egyptian and Palestinian ministers, and former Israeli President Shimon Peres. Fabius emphasized the need to resume peace talks, but Peres stated that a Palestinian state would be better achieved "through an agreement than through an imposition."

Support for France's resolution within Europe is uncertain, despite mounting pressure for legislators across the continent to hold votes recognizing a Palestinian state. Countries are divided over the idea of setting a 2016 deadline, with Germany particularly reluctant, diplomats said.

Kerry cited several examples of the downward security trend in Israel and the West Bank, including Israelis being stabbed, axed, or subjected to acid attacks, as well as the recent loss of a senior Palestinian official during protests, the burning of a mosque near Ramallah, and "price tag" attacks by Jewish extremists.

"We want to find the most constructive way of doing something that therefore will not have unintended consequences, that also stems the violence," Kerry said.

"It's a particular sensitive moment because we understand the frustrations of Palestinians," he added. "They do not see another course at this moment."

The key, Kerry said, is to "try to find whether or not there are other options, other ways, other courses...to respect the process that Israelis are about to undergo."

Title: Trump Announces Deployment of ICE to Sanctuary Cities for Immigration Enforcement

Article:

Last Monday, former President Donald Trump announced via Twitter his intention to deploy Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents to various American sanctuary cities to detain and deport undocumented immigrants. The announcement sparked a heated response from the left, illegal immigrant rights groups, and the media.

The statement was met with criticism, but Trump's proclamation was based on the need to address the issue of illegal immigration, which he argued is detrimental to the nation's sovereignty, economy, and national security. Current estimates put the total number of undocumented immigrants in the United States at over 12 million, although exact numbers are difficult to determine due to questions about citizenship on the national census.

The Federation for American Immigration Reform (FAIR) conducted a study regarding the financial impact of illegal immigration, finding that services provided to these individuals and their families totaled over $135 billion. This figure highlights the financial burden that the presence of undocumented immigrants places on the government.

The article also points out the connection between illegal immigration and crime, citing high-profile cases such as the 2015 murder of Kate Steinle by an undocumented immigrant and the 2018 brutal killing of Mollie Tibbetts. The federal government's report of 2,028 murders by undocumented immigrants arrested in 2018 is also mentioned.

The article argues that the presence of sanctuary cities, which do not comply with federal immigration laws, exacerbates the problems associated with illegal immigration. Citing examples of homelessness and crime in cities like Los Angeles and San Francisco, the article suggests that sanctuary cities attract more illegal border crossers and contribute to the overall problem.

The article also addresses the argument that the issue of illegal immigration is framed as a racial issue by the left. The article argues that this framing is a logical fallacy and that the focus on race obscures the real issues at hand.

Finally, the article compares the issue of illegal immigration to a cancer, with sanctuary cities being the tumors and ICE being the chemotherapy. The article concludes by stating that Trump has placed a two-week hold on his plan, hoping that Congress can address the issue of illegal immigration.

Title: Bipartisan Immigration Legislation Proposed as Government Funding Deadline Approaches

Article:

Senators John McCain (R-Ariz.) and Chris Coons (D-Del.) will introduce immigration legislation on Monday, aiming to address the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and border security measures. The bill, if passed, would provide legal status and a path to citizenship for individuals who meet certain criteria, primarily those who have lived in the U.S. since December 31, 2013.

The proposed legislation, details of which were shared on Sunday, would not include funding for the border wall, a key demand of President Trump and conservative Republicans. The bill instead calls for a study to determine necessary border security measures and a strategy for situational awareness and operational control of the border by 2020.

The bill also includes provisions to address the backlog in the immigration court system by hiring 55 new judges per year, as well as dozens of staff attorneys, for three years. Additionally, it directs the State Department to submit a three-year strategy aimed at addressing the underlying causes of immigration from Central America.

President Trump, in a statement on Monday, expressed his disapproval of any proposed solution that does not include border wall funding, calling it a "total waste of time."

Senator McCain, in a statement on Sunday, emphasized the need for bipartisan cooperation to address the impending expiration of the DACA program and secure the southern border.
