He stated, "It's time we end the gridlock so we can quickly move on to completing a long-term budget agreement that provides our men and women in uniform the support they deserve."

Title: President Trump to Declare National Emergency for Border Wall Funding

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced plans to declare a national emergency in an effort to secure funding for his proposed U.S.-Mexico border wall without congressional approval. This move is expected to spark a constitutional conflict between the President and Congress.

After conceding defeat in his demand for $5.7 billion in wall funding from Congress, Trump agreed to sign a government-funding bill that lacks money for the wall but prevents another government shutdown. The bill, which was passed by both the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives, contains funding for fencing and other forms of border security, but it does not include the wall, a key promise in Trump's 2016 campaign.

The bill is expected to be signed by the President on Friday before he departs for his Mar-a-Lago golf club in Florida for a holiday weekend break. "President Trump will sign the government funding bill, and as he has stated before, he will also take other executive action - including a national emergency," White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said.

The top Democrat in Congress, House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi, denounced the President's move. Asked about a potential legal challenge to an emergency declaration, Pelosi said, "I may, that's an option." Top Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer accused Trump of a "gross abuse of the power of the presidency."

Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated he will support Trump on the emergency declaration, despite earlier cautioning the President that such a move could divide Senate Republicans. An emergency declaration could infringe on Congress' authority to make major decisions about taxpayer funds, a fundamental check and balance spelled out in the Constitution.

For weeks, the White House has explored the possibility of invoking a national emergency to redirect taxpayer funds committed by Congress for other purposes toward the wall. The national emergency strategy, expected to be declared by Trump on Friday, is already dividing Republicans.

The administration has identified nearly $7 billion to reallocate for the wall, including $600 million from a Treasury Department forfeiture fund, $2.5 billion from a Defense Department drug interdiction fund, and $3.5 billion from a military construction budget. These funds would cover only part of the estimated $23 billion cost of the wall promised by Trump along the 2,000-mile (3,200-km) border with Mexico.

The Republican-led Senate passed the government funding bill by a vote of 83-16, and the Democratic-led House by a vote of 300-128, with 86 House Republicans voting in favor. The measure would provide more than $300 billion to fund the Department of Homeland Security and other agencies through Sept. 30, the end of the current fiscal year. It also includes $1.37 billion in new money to help build 55 miles (88.5 km) of new physical border barriers.

Funding for those agencies was due to expire on Friday, which would trigger another partial federal shutdown on Saturday morning if Trump unexpectedly refuses to sign the bill. Some of Trump's fellow Republicans have warned him that declaring a national emergency could set a dangerous precedent, opening the door for a future Democratic president to circumvent Congress and declare emergencies on perhaps climate change, gun control, or healthcare insurance.

Pelosi stated, "If the president can declare an emergency on something that he has created as an emergency - an illusion that he wants to convey - just think of what a president with different values can present to the American people." Democratic Senator Ron Wyden said, "I will pull out all the stops to stop this horrendous, bizarre idea. As people get a chance to sort through what the implications really are, we will have strong bipartisan support for opposing this.... We are the appropriators, not the president."

Title: White House Celebrates President Obama's 2015 Policy Wins, Despite Congressional Opposition

Article:

In his final press briefing of the year, White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest highlighted President Obama's achievements in 2015, emphasizing that the administration successfully advanced many of its priorities despite Republican majorities in Congress. The president's accomplishments, according to Earnest, were primarily achieved through executive action or treaty-like agreements that avoided the need for congressional approval.

The restoration of diplomatic ties with Cuba, the Paris climate change agreement, and the halting of the Keystone pipeline were among the administration's key victories. The Paris agreement, reached with other world leaders, was a significant achievement despite Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's efforts to scuttle it.

House Speaker Paul D. Ryan countered that the budget deal reached this week demonstrates the GOP's effectiveness as an opposition party. He stated that the deal reins in the IRS, stops EPA overreach, and blocks several Obamacare provisions and the taxpayer bailout of the "risk corridor" program for health insurance companies that lose money under the Affordable Care Act.

The White House did not mention the federal courts, which have dealt a major setback to the president's immigration plan, or the rise of the Islamic State, the failure of economic sanctions on Russia, or the administration's inability to impact the civil war in Syria and the resulting refugee crisis in Europe.

The administration's repeated call for raising the federal minimum wage has also gone unfulfilled, leading to collaborations with states and employers to raise their own wage rates. When asked about the president's low job-approval rating, Earnest attributed it to the December 2 terrorist attack in San Bernardino, California.

Earnest claimed that the president does not worry about polls or news cycles, stating that the unifying theme of the administration's accomplishments was their long-term impact rather than productive management of the news cycle. One of the few legislative initiatives that Mr. Obama won in Congress this year was the measure that granted him trade promotion authority, which helped him conclude the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade agreement in October with 11 other nations.

However, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has indicated that the Senate will likely postpone consideration of TPP until after the presidential election in November or until after President Obama leaves office in January 2017. Democratic lawmakers are uniformly opposed to the pact. Republicans control both the House and Senate, and few legislative initiatives typically get done in a presidential election year.

President Obama will depart Washington on Friday for his annual two-week vacation in Hawaii, stopping in California on the way to meet with families of the victims of the San Bernardino terrorist attack.

Title: Supreme Court Overturns Texas Abortion Law Requiring Hospital-Like Standards for Clinics

Article:

The United States Supreme Court has ruled 5-3 against a Texas pro-life law that mandated physicians who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals and required clinics to meet hospital-like standards for outpatient surgery. The ruling is being described by some as another example of "abortion distortion" by Matthew Clark, with the American Center for Law and Justice.

The law, signed by former Governor Rick Perry in 2013, was argued by Texas lawmakers to protect women's health. It required abortion doctors and clinics to meet the same standards for other doctors, clinics, and hospitals in the state. However, Justice Stephen Breyer, joined by Justices Anthony Kennedy, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sonia Sotomayor, and Elena Kagan, argued that the surgical requirement, including the admitting privileges requirement, provides few, if any, health benefits for women and constitutes an "undue burden" on their constitutional right to have an abortion.

Chief Justice John Roberts, and justices Samuel Alito and Clarence Thomas disagreed with the ruling. Thomas stated that the court's decision "exemplifies the court's troubling tendency to bend the rules when any effort to limit abortion, or even speak in opposition to abortion, is at issue."

The law, when first signed, cut the number of clinics from 40 to 20. Had it taken full effect, the 20 would have been cut in half. Amy Hagstrom Miller, founder and CEO of Whole Women's Health, led the challenge against the law. "Every day Whole Women's Health treats our patients with compassion, respect, and dignity – and today the Supreme Court did the same. We're thrilled that today justice was served and our clinics stay open," she said.

Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton also commented on the ruling on Twitter, stating it was a "victory for women in Texas and across America." Clinton added, "The fight is not over. The next president has to protect women's health. Women won't be 'punished' for exercising their basic rights."

The Center for Reproductive Rights says the decision could have "far-reaching implications." It represents "a clear statement by the court about what the standard should be in these types of cases," said Julie Rikelman, director of the litigation group. Twenty-two states currently have facility requirements that are similar or the exact same as the requirements for ambulatory surgical centers. According to The Washington Post, the ruling will cast a "long shadow" among states with similar laws.

Title: Study by Pew Research Center Finds Liberals Less Tolerant Than Conservatives on Social Media

Article:

A new study by The Pew Research Center has found that liberals are less tolerant than conservatives when it comes to social media interactions, based on the likelihood of unfriending or blocking individuals who express political views contrary to their own.

According to the study, approximately 44% of consistent liberals on Facebook have blocked or defriended someone due to political disagreements, compared to 31% of consistent conservatives and 26% of all Facebook users.

The study also revealed other findings related to political polarization in the United States. Consistent liberals tend to be tightly clustered around a single news source, with 88% of consistent conservatives expressing trust in Fox News. They are also more likely to hear political opinions that align with their views when on Facebook.

Liberals are more likely to have friends who share their political views, with 66% stating that most of their close friends share their views on government and politics. They also exhibit less media loyalty, relying on a broader range of news outlets, including those like NPR and the New York Times that others use less frequently.

Consistent liberals express more trust than distrust in 28 of the 36 news outlets measured in the survey. They are more likely to block or defriend someone on a social network, as well as to end a personal friendship, due to political differences.

Lastly, liberals are more likely to follow issue-based groups rather than political parties or candidates on their Facebook feeds.

The study aims to gauge political polarization in the country and provides insights into the social media habits and news consumption patterns of different ideological groups. Readers are invited to share their thoughts on the findings in the comments.

Title: White House Communications Director Hope Hicks Resigns After House Intelligence Committee Interview

Article:

Washington, D.C. - White House Communications Director Hope Hicks, one of U.S. President Donald Trump's longest-serving and most trusted aides, has resigned from her position. This departure marks a significant blow to the president, whose inner circle has been depleted by firings and scandals since he took office over a year ago.

Hicks, 29, announced her resignation a day after she spent nine hours in a closed hearing of the House of Representatives Intelligence Committee as part of their investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders stated that Hicks' decision to leave was not related to her appearance before the panel.

President Trump called Hicks "a truly great person" whom he would miss having at his side. Hicks, who served as Trump's spokeswoman during the 2016 election campaign, reportedly answered House panel questions on Tuesday about her time with the campaign and the transition months between the November election and the January 2017 inauguration.

Hicks' exact departure date is unclear, but she is expected to leave within the next few weeks. Hicks, who had no previous experience in politics, was one of the first people hired by Trump when he began his campaign for the presidency.

Hicks' role extended beyond steering messaging. She was a constant presence in Trump's orbit, sitting in on interviews with reporters and quietly guiding press-related policy while maintaining a low-profile. Despite her proximity to the president, Hicks managed to stay above the fray of staff backbiting and palace intrigue that has characterized the Trump White House.

Hicks was caught up in a controversy surrounding former White House staff secretary Rob Porter, another close Trump aide whom Hicks had been dating. She worked to defend him when charges of domestic abuse against his two former wives emerged. Porter ultimately resigned.

Among the issues Hicks declined to discuss with the House panel was her part in drafting a statement in July 2017 that misrepresented a July 2016 meeting at Trump Tower that included the president's eldest son, Donald Trump Jr., other Trump associates, and Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya. Trump Jr. initially stated the meeting was about adoptions, but later revealed that Veselnitskaya had promised damaging information about his father's election campaign opponent, Democrat Hillary Clinton.

U.S. intelligence agencies concluded that Russia ran a program of hacking and disinformation to interfere in the elections, and it later developed into an attempt to help Republican candidate Trump defeat Clinton. On Feb. 16, a U.S. special counsel indicted 13 Russians and three companies on charges of tampering in the campaign. Russia denies interfering in the U.S. election, and Trump denies any collusion between his campaign and Moscow officials.

Hicks took over as communications director in September, following the difficult, 11-day tenure of Anthony Scaramucci, who was fired. She is credited behind the scenes for stabilizing the communications operation.

In a statement, Trump praised Hicks, stating, "Hope is outstanding and has done great work for the last three years. She is as smart and thoughtful as they come, a truly great person." Hicks, in her own statement, expressed her gratitude to President Trump and wished him and his administration the best as he continues to lead the country.

Title: Duval County Beach Reopening Sparks Debate Over Risky Activities and COVID-19 Restrictions

Article:

In the city of Jacksonville, Florida, residents took advantage of the partial reopening of local beaches on April 18, 2020, amid coronavirus restrictions. The event sparked a national debate, with CNN airing a disapproving segment and the hashtag #FloridaMorons trending on Twitter.

The CNN report described the scene at Jacksonville Beach as not one of caution during a worldwide pandemic. People were seen swimming, biking, surfing, running, and fishing. However, none of these activities have been shown to be vectors for the spread of COVID-19, and no outdoor activities have been proven to be dangerous.

Despite the lack of evidence linking outdoor activities to the disease, parks have been closed throughout the United States, with some closures enforced rigorously. Notable figures, such as Tom Brady and a Colorado father playing T-ball with his 6-year-old daughter, have been subject to enforcement actions.

The debate over the appropriate response to the coronavirus pandemic has been marked by a lack of distinction between risky and non-risky activities and between areas heavily affected by the virus and those less so. For instance, Duval County, home to Jacksonville, has had 17 COVID-19 deaths, a relatively low number compared to other counties in the United States.

The article suggests that a more nuanced approach to reopening areas, taking into account local conditions and population density, could help alleviate some of the controversy surrounding the pandemic response. The piece also highlights the need for flexibility in adopting a patchwork approach to opening up around the country.

Title: House Speakership Election Chaos: McCarthy Withdraws, Postponement of Vote, and Speculation of Caretaker Speaker

Article:

The House of Representatives experienced a significant disruption on Thursday as front-runner Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) withdrew his name from the House speakership election. The closed-door House Republican meeting, intended to determine a speaker nominee, spilled into the hallway outside the House Ways and Means Room in the Longworth Office Building.

Rep. Jason Chaffetz (R-Utah), a more conservative alternative running against McCarthy, described the announcement as "absolutely stunning." He stated, "Look, it was totally, it was just absolutely stunning what happened. Nobody anticipated that that was going to happen. I love Kevin McCarthy; he's a good man, and that was a tough thing to do, but God bless him."

Rep. Tim Huelskamp (R-Kan.) offered his own account of McCarthy's decision: "I am not the one" is what he said. "I am not the one to get to 218. I do not know if that was possible or not, he apparently decided he'd much rather stay as majority leader."

The House GOP announced the postponement of the speakership election, and speculation about potential new candidates soon followed. Some suggested a "caretaker" speaker—an individual who would temporarily hold the position until new elections can be held in January 2017. This would likely be a senior member who would not run in '17.

Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) proposed that a caretaker would help the party "stay unified in our basic principles." He suggested Rep. Hal Rogers of Kentucky as a potential caretaker, but Rogers declined the offer.

Rep. Charlie Dent (R-Pa.) addressed a potential compromise, an elephant in the hallway, which he said could be a "very real possibility" and a bipartisan coalition to elect the next speaker.

Rep. Daniel Webster (R-Fla.), another candidate running for speaker who was endorsed by the House Freedom Caucus, did not call for bipartisanship but instead for Republicans to "come together and be a group."

Despite the chaos, Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) remained optimistic, stating, "Again, we're in kind of, somewhat, chaotic territory, but we will find a way through this and it's going to be a way that serves our party and the American people the best."

Title: Senate Report Alleges Obama Administration Granted Iran Access to U.S. Financial System Contrary to Pledges

Article:

The Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations has released a draft report stating that the Obama administration granted a license allowing Iran to access the United States financial system, contradicting previous official pledges.

According to the report, on February 24, 2016, the Treasury Department issued a specific license to Bank Muscat, authorizing the conversion of Iran's rials to euros through "any United States depository institution." Despite this, U.S. government officials continued to testify in Congress that Iran would not be granted access to the U.S. financial system.

Senator Rob Portman (R-Ohio), subcommittee chairman, stated, "The Obama administration during the negotiation of the Iran deal misled the American people. I think they did so because they were desperate to get a deal."

At the time the Iran nuclear agreement was implemented, Iran had $5.7 billion in assets at Bank Muscat in Muscat, Oman, according to the subcommittee. Iran sought to access this money, and using the U.S. financial system for conversion was the most efficient means, even though U.S. sanctions prohibited it, according to the report.

Two U.S. banks were approached to execute the conversion, but they declined, citing the complexity and the unwanted appearance involved in processing an Iranian transaction, according to the report. Without a compliant American bank, a senior State Department official believed Bank Muscat and Iran eventually used European banks to convert the funds, according to the committee.

Portman said his subcommittee began investigating the transaction last summer. In an interview with an unnamed senior State Department official, the panel said, the official acknowledged that the administration "exceeded our JCPOA commitments" because there was nothing in the JCPOA that required the issuance of the specific license, according to the report. (JCPOA is the acronym for the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action with Iran.)

A former administration official disputes the subcommittee's conclusion, stating that the Treasury Department never authorized Iran to access U.S. investments or markets, conduct commercial transactions in U.S. dollars, or open correspondent accounts at U.S. banks.

"This specific license can not be described as 'granting access to the U.S. financial system,'" the former official said. "This specific license was in fulfillment of JCPOA commitments to give Iran access to pools of its money held overseas. It was aimed solely to allow the movement of Iran's own funds stranded at an Omani bank into euros at a European bank, where Iran could then make use of them."

Title: Former GOP Presidential Nominee Mitt Romney Refuses to Endorse Trump, Expresses Disappointment with Party

Article:

Former 2012 Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney has joined House Speaker Paul Ryan in refusing to endorse Donald Trump, the presumptive GOP nominee. During a Q&A at a fundraising gala in Washington on Thursday, Romney expressed his disappointment with the Republican Party and declined to support Trump or Hillary Clinton.

Romney ruled out the possibility of a third-party candidacy but stated that he could not support Trump in good conscience. He expressed his dismay at the state of American politics and wished for "better choices" that no longer exist.

Earlier this year, Romney championed the Never Trump movement, attempting to block Trump's nomination by proposing the remaining Republican candidates unite to force a contested convention. However, the dream ended this week with Ted Cruz and John Kasich dropping out of the race.

Romney praised Ryan, his former running mate, for his leadership in the House of Representatives. He expressed hope that Ryan would remain Speaker, despite the ongoing presidential race.

Romney's public disavowal of Trump marks a significant departure from the Republican Party's support for their nominee. So far, there have been rumblings within the GOP that they could never support Trump. High-profile Republicans, including George H.W. Bush, George W. Bush, and Senator John McCain, have refused to endorse or comment on the nomination. Senator McCain was recorded saying that Trump would severely hurt his re-election chances in Arizona, a Latino-heavy state that borders Mexico.

Furthermore, Hillary Clinton highlighted in an e-mail blast that the anti-Trump sentiment is not limited to high-profile Republicans. Dozens of other GOP congressional representatives, governors, and major political figures are also quickly boarding the anti-Trump train or, at the very least, refusing to comment.

Title: Atlanta Police Shooting: Autopsy Reveals Rayshard Brooks Suffered Two Gunshot Wounds, Death Ruled Homicide

Article:

The medical examiner in Atlanta has ruled the death of Rayshard Brooks, a 27-year-old black man who was shot by police on Friday, a homicide. The Fulton County Medical Examiner's office performed an autopsy on Brooks on Sunday and found that the gunshot wounds to his back caused organ failure due to blood loss.

The encounter between Brooks and two Atlanta police officers late Friday night, which was initially a routine sobriety check outside a Wendy's restaurant, escalated and ended in gunfire. According to police, Brooks appeared to be cooperating during the initial interaction, but the situation quickly became violent as they wrestled on the ground and Brooks took a Taser from one of the officers and pointed it at them. Seconds later, three gunshots were heard, and Brooks fell to the ground.

Atlanta police released a video of the incident on Sunday, which shows the seemingly routine sobriety check that quickly spiraled out of control. The department has terminated Officer Garrett Rolfe, who fired the fatal shots, and Officer Devin Brosnan has been placed on administrative duty. Rolfe had been with the department since October 2013, and Brosnan since September 2018.

In related news, Atlanta Police Chief Erika Shields resigned on Friday, following the shooting. Shields had been with the department for 25 years and was the first woman to hold the position of police chief in Atlanta.

In other news, China has locked down 10 more neighborhoods and fired officials amid a resurgence of the coronavirus. At least 10 residential communities near the Yuquandong market in Beijing's Haidian District were placed under lockdown after multiple cases were found over the weekend. Residents were ordered to go under home quarantine and take nucleic acid tests for the virus. All of the infections reportedly had ties to the Xinfadi market in Beijing's southern Fengtai district, which has been identified as the center of a new cluster of cases.

In the United States, the surgeon general, Jerome Adams, said wearing masks will give Americans "more freedom." Meanwhile, the stock futures plummeted to begin the new week on coronavirus concerns. Steve Hilton argued that the 2020 presidential election will be a referendum on the country's commitment to "reform the police with Trump or abolish the police with Democrats."

Title: Supreme Court Allows Arkansas to Enforce Medication Abortion Restrictions

Article:

The Supreme Court on Tuesday granted Arkansas the authority to enforce a law restricting medication abortions, denying an appeal from the Planned Parenthood affiliate in the state. The high court's decision reverses a lower court order that had previously blocked the enforcement of the abortion pill rules.

The law in question requires doctors who provide abortion pills to hold a contract with another physician who has admitting privileges at a hospital and would agree to handle and treat complications. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals had previously overturned the lower court's order, but put that ruling on hold as Planned Parenthood appealed to the Supreme Court.

Planned Parenthood argued that if the law stands, Arkansas would be the only state where women would not have access to a pair of drugs that end pregnancies—mifepristone, which makes it difficult for the fetus to attach to the uterine wall, and misoprostol, which causes the body to expel the pregnancy, similar to a miscarriage. Planned Parenthood offers these abortion medications at clinics in Fayetteville and Little Rock, but has stated it cannot find an obstetrician in the state willing to handle the hospital admissions.

The organization also argued that the law prevents women from obtaining medication abortions and would infringe on their right to an abortion, otherwise known as an undue burden. Undue burden is the standard set by the Supreme Court when measuring whether restrictions go too far in limiting women who seek to have an abortion. Critics of the law say it could end medication abortions in the state.

It is unavailable whether the legal battle will continue, but at this point, Arkansas is allowed to enforce the law. The law is similar to a provision in a Texas law, which the Supreme Court struck down in 2016.

Title: Allegations of Sexual Misconduct: A Spectrum of Severity and the Dilemma of Zero Tolerance

Article:

There is a growing consensus that there should be zero tolerance for sexual harassment, exploitation, and violence of any kind. However, the application of this principle is proving to be a complex issue, with varying perspectives on its implications.

Recent allegations of sexual misconduct have been levied against several high-profile individuals, including Republican Senate candidate Roy Moore, Democratic Senator Al Franken, and numerous Hollywood personalities. These allegations range from inappropriate advances to rape.

The logic of zero tolerance often leads to every bad act being considered equally unacceptable. While it is crucial to address and condemn all forms of sexual misconduct, it is also important to recognize the varying degrees of severity. Rape is a criminal offense, while making a pass at an adult woman is different from molesting a minor. Groping a woman is not the same as raping a woman.

The problem lies in the conflation of these acts, with some media outlets and partisan groups lumping alleged miscreants together indiscriminately. This leveling is partly due to journalistic laziness, but it is also a result of partisan demagoguery and opportunism.

Partisanship also leads to what can be called anti-leveling: people who ignore wrongdoing on their side while attacking their enemies. Some argue that Franken should resign, while others maintain that the people of Alabama should decide what to do about Moore.

The White House argues that denials should matter, and accusations without evidence should invite skepticism. However, this logic implies that alleged miscreants should simply deny wrongdoing rather than admit and apologize. This was seen in the case of former President Bill Clinton, who was initially given the benefit of the doubt until evidence forced him to admit some of his misdeeds.

The most dangerous and corrupting force in this situation is not the weaponization of bad behavior, but the weaponization of hypocrisy. The obsession with hypocrisy leads to a repugnant immorality, as partisans end up defending the underlying behavior itself in an effort to defend their team.

As the investigation and resolution of these allegations continue, the public is reminded of the importance of making serious distinctions in the severity of sexual misconduct and the need for a balanced approach to addressing these issues.

Title: Judge Rules Paul Manafort Breached Plea Deal by Lying About Dealings with Alleged Russian Operative

Article:

A federal court in Washington ruled on Wednesday that Paul Manafort, former presidential campaign chairman for Donald Trump, breached his plea deal by making false statements to Robert Mueller's inquiry team, the FBI, and a grand jury about his dealings with Konstantin Kilimnik, an alleged Russian intelligence operative.

The ruling means that Mueller's team is no longer obliged to endorse the lighter punishment that Manafort was promised for his crimes when he agreed to cooperate with investigators and tell the truth. Manafort, who denied lying, was found to have lied about three disputed issues: his interactions with Kilimnik, a payment he took from a pro-Trump campaign group, and another investigation that has not been identified.

Judge Amy Berman Jackson, who issued the order, failed to establish that Manafort lied on two other subjects: his recent contacts with Trump administration officials and Kilimnik's role in a conspiracy to obstruct justice for which they were both indicted.

Mueller is investigating Russia's interference in the 2016 presidential election, which US intelligence agencies concluded was aimed at boosting Trump's bid for the White House, and any coordination between Russian operatives and Trump's team. Manafort, 69, was accused by Mueller of lying about the fact he had shared polling data on the 2016 election with Kilimnik, a former colleague on election campaigns for pro-Kremlin politicians in eastern Europe.

Manafort is also said to have misled investigators about plans that he and Kilimnik were developing for a settlement relating to Russia's aggressive actions in Ukraine. Kilimnik, 48, trained at a university connected to Russia's military intelligence agency, formerly known as the GRU, which allegedly spearheaded the Kremlin's effort to disrupt the US election in 2016.

Mueller has also previously said that Rick Gates, Manafort's deputy on the Trump campaign, described Kilimnik as "a former Russian intelligence officer with the GRU." Kilimnik denies that characterization. The special counsel moved to tear up Manafort's plea deal in November, alleging that the former campaign chairman had breached the agreement by continuing to lie. Mueller said the lies amounted to new crimes.

Manafort was known to have met Kilimnik twice during 2016. He passed the polling data to Kilimnik during an August meeting in New York, according to investigators. Mueller's team also found Manafort met Kilimnik in Spain during 2017.

Manafort's attorneys strenuously denied that he had intentionally misled the investigators. They said he could not remember some details and worked to promptly clarify any misstatements. His attorneys did not deny that Manafort gave Kilimnik the polling data, instead stating that he had not lied about it but was merely "unable to recall specific details prior to having his recollection refreshed."

As part of the plea deal struck last September, Manafort pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the US and conspiring to obstruct justice, in relation to unregistered lobbying work for pro-Russian politicians. Other charges against him were dropped. By then, Manafort had been convicted of eight criminal counts in a separate fraud case brought against him by Mueller in Virginia.

Title: California Chrome Allowed to Wear Nasal Strip in Belmont Stakes, Potential Triple Crown Contender

Article:

California Chrome, the current favorite for the Triple Crown, will be allowed to wear a nasal strip during the Belmont Stakes on June 7, according to track officials. The decision comes after concerns were raised about the horse's ability to wear the nasal strip, which he has been using in previous races.

The nasal strip, a small adhesive strip placed on the horse's nose, is intended to help the horse breathe more easily. California Chrome has won six consecutive races with the nasal strip, and its removal could potentially impact the horse's performance.

The nasal strip controversy arose during the 2012 Belmont Stakes, when I'll Have Another, another California-bred horse, was prohibited from wearing a nasal strip. The decision was made by the Belmont's racing officials and the New York Racing Association, as each organization has the final say on whether to permit nasal strips.

California Chrome's trainer, 77-year-old Art Sherman, expressed concern that the horse's owners might withdraw him from the race if the nasal strip is not allowed. The horse's co-owner, Perry Martin, has been a strong advocate for the nasal strip and has been pleased with the horse's success since it was first used.

The Belmont Stakes is the final and longest race of the Triple Crown, with a distance of 1.5 miles. If California Chrome wins the Belmont, he will join an elite group of horses that have won the Triple Crown, a feat last achieved by Affirmed in 1978. The Triple Crown consists of the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes, and the Belmont Stakes. California Chrome has already won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes.

The Triple Crown winners to date are Sir Barton (1919), Gallant Fox (1930), Omaha (1935), War Admiral (1937), Whirlaway (1941), Count Fleet (1943), Assault (1946), Citation (1948), Secretariat (1973), Seattle Slew (1977), and Affirmed (1978). If California Chrome wins the Belmont Stakes, he will join this esteemed group of horses.

Title: Armed Assault at Pearl Continental Hotel in Gwadar Results in Deaths of Security Guard and Attackers

Article:

At least three armed militants stormed the Pearl Continental hotel in the city of Gwadar, Balochistan province, Pakistan, on Saturday afternoon. The attackers exchanged fire with government forces, and the fighting continued for several hours. According to the assistant superintendent of police in the city, the shooting ended at approximately 8pm local time.

A hotel security guard was reportedly killed during the attack, as confirmed by a spokesperson for Pakistan's military. A senior security official told the Associated Press that all four attackers were killed. Security forces cornered the assailants in a staircase during the hours-long gunfight, the military stated in its official statement.

The Majeed Brigade of the Balochistan Liberation Organisation, a separatist group active in Pakistan and Afghanistan, claimed responsibility for the attack on Twitter. The group stated that their fighters carried out the attack on Chinese and other foreign investors.

The Majeed Brigade has previously claimed responsibility for attacks on the Chinese embassy in Karachi in November 2020 and another assault on Chinese engineers in the Baloch district of Chagai.

Gwadar, a small city in Balochistan province, is the site of a large port under construction by a Chinese company as part of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, a significant project of China's Belt and Road infrastructure-building initiative. Beijing has invested approximately $50bn (£38bn) in the port and road links between Gwadar and China's western Xinjiang province.

The city of Gwadar, including its major hotels, is heavily guarded by the Pakistan army and paramilitary forces. Balochistan province is Pakistan's poorest and most restive, with Baloch separatists killing at least 11 members of the military in an attack in April. The founder of the Majeed Brigade, Aslam Baloch, was killed in a blast in Kandahar, Afghanistan, in December 2020, along with five other members of the militant group.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey to Testify on Alleged Pressure from President Trump over Russia Investigation

Article:

Former FBI Director James Comey is set to testify before the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee this week, facing questions about whether President Donald Trump attempted to influence an investigation into alleged ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. The testimony follows Comey's dismissal by Trump last month, four years into his 10-year term as FBI Director.

Senator Mark Warner, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, expressed interest in understanding the extent of any pressure or conversations Trump had with Comey regarding the Russia investigation. Comey is due to testify on Thursday as part of the committee's own Russia-related investigation.

Reports emerged after Comey's dismissal that Trump had asked Comey to end the probe into former national security adviser Michael Flynn during a February meeting in the Oval Office, following Flynn's firing for misrepresenting his contacts with the Russian ambassador. The account, first reported by the New York Times, was based on a memo Comey wrote after the meeting.

The Comey memo caused concern on Capitol Hill and raised questions about whether Trump may have interfered with a federal investigation. Senator Warner stated, "It would be unthinkable if the president actually did what was reported, asked FBI Director Comey to, in effect, back off of at least the investigation into General Flynn."

The potential for explosive testimony from Comey could significantly impact a sitting president, making Thursday's hearing a highly anticipated event. According to Linda Peek-Schacht, a political adviser who worked in President Jimmy Carter's White House, "There are only a few times when Americans come together to watch one thing. Americans will be watching this."

U.S. intelligence agencies concluded in January that Moscow attempted to influence the November election in Trump's favor. Russia has denied involvement, and Trump has denied any collusion between his campaign and Russia. Russian President Vladimir Putin stated in an interview that he does not have a relationship with Flynn and only spoke briefly with him at a 2015 dinner for Russian TV network RT.

Republican Senator Susan Collins, who sits on the Senate Intelligence Committee, expressed eagerness to question Comey to gain more insight into Trump's claim that Comey told him on three separate occasions that he was not under investigation. Collins stated, "We need to hear directly from Mr. Comey on these important issues."

Trump has referred to the investigation into alleged ties between his campaign and Russia as a "witch hunt" designed to undermine the legitimacy of his electoral win. After reports that Trump asked Comey to stop investigating Flynn, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein hired former FBI chief Robert Mueller as special counsel to lead the FBI's Russia probe.

Title: Fox News Host Criticizes Washington Post's Characterization of ISIS Leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi

Article:

Fox News host Sean Hannity criticized The Washington Post on Sunday following the confirmation of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi's death at the hands of U.S. special forces. Hannity took issue with The Washington Post's characterization of al-Baghdadi as an "austere religious scholar" in a headline, describing it as "sick and repulsive."

According to a U.S. defense official, al-Baghdadi, who took over as the head of ISIS after his predecessor Abu Omar al-Baghdadi was killed in 2010, was located in a compound in northern Syria and was said to have detonated a suicide vest as U.S. special forces closed in. No U.S. Special Operations forces were harmed or killed during the mission, and President Trump claimed the operation had been in the works for several weeks.

Hannity described al-Baghdadi as an "evil SOB," whom the might of the American military finally defeated. He wrote that The Washington Post needed to be "educated" about the horrors al-Baghdadi perpetrated upon innocent people.

"An 'austere religious scholar'? 'Dead at 48'? No — he was cornered by the greatest, toughest, best military heroes on earth! We killed the evil SOB. This is exactly why America will never trust these mainstream, corrupt, fake news outlets ever again," Hannity tweeted.

Hannity also claimed ISIS forces took pleasure in torturing their victims and shamed The Washington Post for trying to paint al-Baghdadi as anything other than a terrorist.

"ISIS terrorists take pleasure in beheadings and burning people alive in cages. They use cars and trucks to mow down innocent people. To describe Al-Baghdadi as an 'austere religious scholar' is sick and repulsive," he wrote.

In response to Hannity's criticism, Washington Post Vice President of Communications Kristine Coratti Kelly told Fox News that the headline should never have read that way and was quickly changed.

Title: Janet Napolitano Resigns as Homeland Security Chief, Nominated to Lead University of California

Article:

Janet Napolitano, a long-time confidant of former President Barack Obama, has announced her resignation as the head of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to assume the presidency of the University of California. The move was announced on Friday, with Napolitano stating that she has been nominated to lead the California university system.

In a statement, Napolitano expressed gratitude for her four-year tenure at DHS, during which she worked with the department's employees to protect the nation from harm. However, her tenure was marked by a series of lawsuits and controversies, particularly regarding the enforcement of immigration law.

Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents accused the department leadership of failing to properly enforce immigration law in a lawsuit. The complaint centers on the practice of using "prosecutorial discretion," which allows department lawyers to selectively determine which immigrants to pursue for deportation and which to let go.

Napolitano's department later enacted a Dream Act-style policy, granting young illegal immigrants a reprieve.

Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.), one of Napolitano's chief critics, described her tenure at DHS as "defined by a consistent disrespect for the rule of law."

The news of Napolitano's departure reportedly caught her staff by surprise. The secretary has been criticized for her handling of several high-profile terrorist incidents, including her comments on the attempted bombing on a Detroit-bound flight in 2009 and the Times Square bombing in 2010.

Napolitano has been working with other agencies to address illegal immigration and natural disasters. Obama praised Napolitano for her service in a written statement, highlighting her efforts to secure the borders and her role in responding to natural disasters.

Napolitano, a former Arizona governor, has led the Homeland Security Department since the start of the Obama administration. She is one of the few Cabinet members to have stayed with the administration this long. The California university system announced Napolitano's nomination for president on Friday, with a vote scheduled for next Thursday. If confirmed, Napolitano will be the first female president of the university.

Title: U.S. Surpasses Pre-Recession Jobs Total, but Recovery Remains Slow

Article:

The United States reached a significant milestone on Friday as the monthly jobs report from the government revealed that the country surpassed the number of jobs it had before the recession began in May. The gain of 217,000 jobs brought the total U.S. payroll number to nearly 138.5 million jobs.

However, analysts note that the recovery has taken more than six years and has excluded many workers. The labor-force participation rate, a widely watched barometer for how many people are actively participating in the labor market, held steady at 62.8% in May, near the lowest levels since the late 1970s.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that total nonfarm payroll employment rose by 217,000 in May, and the unemployment rate was unchanged at 6.3%. May marked the fourth straight month payrolls have increased at least 200,000, the first time that's happened since September 1999 to January 2000.

Before today's numbers were released, economists expected an increase in payrolls of around 210,000 jobs, according to a Dow Jones survey. The unemployment rate was expected to tick up a notch, to 6.4%.

Economists say some of the problems that are still holding the economy back include weak consumer demand that has crimped hiring plans, as well as employers who can't find workers with the right skills for their job openings. The picture has been bleak in California's San Joaquin Valley, where the dominant farm economy is blamed for low wages that leave workers unable to contribute to new growth in an area where unemployment rates are double the national average.

Heidi Shierholz of the Economic Policy Institute notes that despite approaching the milestone, it's not a time to celebrate. She states that the jobs recovery is the longest since before World War II, and while job growth has been steady, it's been too slow to absorb young workers who have come of age since 2007 and to help millions of other people who were laid off.

"We should have added around 7 million jobs" in that time, Shierholz says. "So, just getting back to where we were before the recession began nearly 6 1/2 years ago leaves us in a really big hole."

Title: Gulf States' Refusal to Accept Syrian Refugees Sparks Controversy

Article:

Five of the wealthiest Muslim countries on the Arabian Peninsula, including Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Qatar, Kuwait, and Bahrain, have not accepted any Syrian refugees, citing the risk of terrorism as a reason. This contrasts with the United Kingdom, which has donated more than Saudi Arabia, UAE, and Qatar combined in aid to Syrian refugees.

According to the United Nations Refugee Agency (UNHCR), between 10 and 12 million Syrians have been displaced due to the ongoing civil war in their country. Most remain within Syria's borders, but around four million have fled to neighboring countries, primarily Turkey, Jordan, and Lebanon, and beyond.

Lebanon, which hosts 1.1 million Syrian refugees, closed its borders to Syrians in June 2020. Jordan, home to another 630,000 refugees, followed suit in August 2020, preventing more Syrians from leaving their country.

By early August 2015, European states had received nearly 350,000 asylum applications from Syrians, with nearly a third applying for asylum in Germany. Sweden and Serbia have received 65,000 and 50,000 applications, respectively. Hungary and Austria have received close to 19,000 applications each, while the UK is processing 7,030 applications, according to the UNHCR.

The decision by these Gulf States not to accept Syrian refugees has been met with criticism. Sherif Elsayid-Ali, Amnesty International's Head of Refugee and Migrants' Rights, has called their inaction "shameful." He stated, "The records of Gulf countries are absolutely appalling, in terms of actually showing compassion and sharing the responsibility of this crisis... It is a disgrace."

None of the Gulf States have signed the 1951 Refugee Convention, which legally defines a refugee as "A person who owing to a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality." However, they have taken refugees in the past.

Twenty-five years ago, hundreds of thousands of Kuwaitis fleeing Saddam Hussein's invasion were given refuge. Arabian expert Sultan Sooud al-Qassemi noted, "in Abu Dhabi, the government rented out entire apartment blocks and gave them to families for free."

Instead of accepting refugees, these countries have opted to donate aid to those affected by the crisis. The UAE has funded a refugee camp in Jordan, providing shelter for tens of thousands of Syrians, while Saudi Arabia and Qatar have donated funds, food, shelter, and clothing to Syrians in Lebanon, Turkey, and Jordan.

Total donations from the Gulf States are believed to total £589 million, less than a quarter of America's £2.8 billion, and a fraction of the £65 billion they spent on defense in 2012 alone. The UK has handed over £920 million so far, but the Prime Minister pledged to increase that figure to £1 billion yesterday and promised to take in thousands more refugees.

Arabian expert Sultan Sooud al-Qassemi has argued that the Gulf States' standing in the world confers on them a moral obligation to step in. "The Gulf States have emerged as the nerve centers of Arab diplomacy, culture, media production, commerce, and tourism, amassing an unprecedented degree of soft power unrivaled in the region and beyond," he said.

They also form "the most influential bloc within the 70-year-old Arab League." Al-Qassemi further stated, "But with great power comes great responsibility. The Gulf must realize that now is the time to change their policy regarding accepting refugees from the Syria crisis. It is the moral, ethical, and responsible step to take."

Title: US, UK, and France Prepare for Potential Military Strike on Syria in Response to Alleged Chemical Attack

Article:

The United States, the United Kingdom, and France have agreed to work together and are believed to be preparing for a military strike in response to an alleged chemical attack on the rebel-held town of Douma, Syria, on Saturday. President Donald Trump has tweeted that Russia should "get ready" for missiles to be fired at its ally Syria, while President Bashar al-Assad's government denies mounting a chemical attack.

In a series of tweets on Wednesday, Mr. Trump called the Syrian leader a "gas killing animal" and painted a dark picture of US-Russia relations but said it did not have to be that way. The US, UK, and France have not officially announced a decision on military action, but the US President's early morning tweets suggest a larger military operation may be forthcoming.

Defense Secretary James Mattis said the US was still assessing the chemical attack and that the US military stood ready to provide military options if they are appropriate as the president determines. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said a final decision had not been made, and "all options remain on the table."

French President Emmanuel Macron said any strikes would target "the regime's chemical capabilities." In the UK, Prime Minister Theresa May is reportedly considering joining military action in Syria without seeking parliamentary consent first.

The US Navy guided-missile destroyer, the USS Donald Cook, is in the Mediterranean Sea. Reports suggest that Russian battleships have left the country's naval base in the Syrian port city of Tartus.

Opposition activists and rescuers say government aircraft dropped bombs filled with toxic chemicals on the town, the last major rebel stronghold near the capital Damascus. The Syrian-American Medical Society (Sams), which operates in rebel-held areas, and local aid workers said more than 500 people had been treated for symptoms "indicative of exposure to a chemical agent."

The UN's World Health Organization (WHO) has demanded access to verify reports from its partners, which include Sams, that 70 people had died, including 43 who showed "symptoms consistent with exposure to highly toxic chemicals." A team from the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) is due to deploy to Syria "shortly" to determine whether banned weapons were used.

Douma was under renewed assault from Syrian and Russian forces last week. Rebels have now been evacuating the town under an agreement involving the Russian military. The Syrian government has described the reports of the chemical attack as a "provocation" designed to justify Western intervention against its ally. It said on Wednesday that samples taken from the site had not revealed any chemical substances.

Senior Russian figures have warned of a Russian response to a US attack. On Wednesday, Alexander Zasypkin, Moscow's ambassador to Lebanon, repeated a warning by the head of the military that missiles would be shot down and their launch sites targeted if they threatened the lives of Russian personnel. Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova asked whether the aim of Western strikes might be "to quickly remove the traces of the provocation...[so] international inspectors will have nothing to look for in terms of evidence."

Addressing new ambassadors in Moscow, President Vladimir Putin said he hoped common sense would prevail and that the situation would stabilize. Mr. Putin said Russia would "keep all its international obligations in full."

Title: China's Economic Growth Slows, Government Cuts Lending Rates to Boost Economy

Article:

Recent months have seen a significant slowdown in China's economic growth, surpassing most people's expectations. Last week, the Chinese government reduced lending rates for the first time since the global financial crisis in an attempt to stimulate growth. This development has sparked concerns about the future direction of the world's second-largest economy.

In the past week, news headlines have been grim, with statements such as "A cloud hanging over China's previously booming economy" and "The world's second-largest economy is running out of steam." These sentiments were accompanied by figures showing a decline in consumer prices and a potential drop in growth rates below 7 percent for the April-June quarter.

Weakness has been observed in various sectors, including air travel. Brian Pearce, the chief economist at the International Air Transport Association, reported that air travel in China has experienced a significant decline. He stated, "For a number of years, we were seeing growth rates of 15, 20 percent, but that seems to have slowed down quite sharply over the last year, and we're seeing growth rates down to single figures, which is quite strong for most markets, but for China, that's a pretty weak outcome."

Most travel in China is for business, and many businesspeople are anxious. Confidence has weakened, particularly among smaller businesses, and export business has decreased due to problems in Europe. The government has tightened its grip on the housing market and public infrastructure construction, which has contributed to the current decline.

When discussing China's economy, people often focus on exports. However, most of the factors driving the current decline are domestic. Andy Rothman, China macro-strategist for CLSA, an independent brokerage and investment group, asserts that the slowdown promised by the Communist Party is underway. He explains that China's blistering growth is no longer sustainable, and the government has been trying to slow it down and improve its quality.

The problem, according to Rothman, is that the Communist Party overdid it, tightening up too much in the housing market and on construction of public infrastructure. The government's restrictions on real estate sales have led to a decrease in demand for goods such as steel and concrete, hurting factories. The government is now encouraging home buying and approving new public projects to help stabilize the economy.

If the government does not implement reforms, China's economy will remain in a structural downshift for an extended period. Ren Xianfeng, a senior analyst with IHS Global Insight in Beijing, is optimistic about the next six months but pessimistic about the medium and longer term. She believes that China's economy needs serious reform, including building a more innovative economy that favors private firms and provides better financing options.

After decades of spectacular growth, a prolonged structural downshift would be a significant shock—one that no one wants to see.

Title: Senator Richard Burr Sells Off Significant Portion of Stocks Amidst Coronavirus Outbreak

Article:

Senator Richard Burr, the powerful chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, sold off a substantial portion of his stocks on February 13, unloading between $628,000 and $1.72 million of his holdings in 33 separate transactions. As the head of the intelligence committee, Burr, a North Carolina Republican, has access to the government's most highly classified information about threats to America's security. His committee was receiving daily coronavirus briefings around this time, according to a Reuters story.

A week after Burr's sales, the stock market began a sharp decline and has lost about 30% since. On Thursday, Burr came under fire after National Public Radio (NPR) obtained a secret recording from February 27, in which the lawmaker gave a VIP group at an exclusive social club a much more dire preview of the economic impact of the coronavirus than what he had told the public.

Burr's spokesperson stated, "Senator Burr filed a financial disclosure form for personal transactions made several weeks before the U.S. and financial markets showed signs of volatility due to the growing coronavirus outbreak." The spokesperson added, "As the situation continues to evolve daily, he has been deeply concerned by the steep and sudden toll this pandemic is taking on our economy."

Burr is not a particularly wealthy member of the Senate, with a net worth estimated at $1.7 million in 2018, indicating that the February sales significantly shaped his financial fortunes and spared him from some of the pain that many Americans are now facing. He was one of the authors of the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act, which shapes the nation's response to public health threats like the coronavirus.

Burr's office did not respond to requests for comment about what sort of briefing materials, if any, on the coronavirus threat Burr may have seen as chair of the intelligence committee before his selling spree. According to the NPR report, Burr told attendees of the luncheon held at the Capitol Hill Club, "There's one thing that I can tell you about this: It is much more aggressive in its transmission than anything that we have seen in recent history... It is probably more akin to the 1918 pandemic."

He warned that companies might have to curtail their employees' travel, that schools could close, and that the military might be mobilized to compensate for overwhelmed hospitals. The luncheon was organized by the Tar Heel Circle, a club for businesses and organizations in North Carolina that are charged up to $10,000 for membership and are promised "interaction with top leaders and staff from Congress, the administration, and the private sector."

Burr's public comments had been considerably less dire. In a February 7 op-ed that he co-authored with another senator, he assured the public that "the United States today is better prepared than ever before to face emerging public health threats, like the coronavirus." He wrote, "No matter the outbreak or threat, Congress and the federal government have been vigilant in identifying gaps in its readiness efforts and improving its response capabilities."

Members of Congress are required by law to disclose their securities transactions. Burr was one of just three senators who, in 2012, opposed the bill that explicitly barred lawmakers and their staff from using nonpublic information for trades and required regular disclosure of those trades. In opposing the bill, Burr argued at the time that insider trading laws already applied to members of Congress. President Barack Obama signed the bill, known as the STOCK Act, that year.

Stock transactions of lawmakers are reported in ranges. Burr's February 13 selling spree was his largest stock selling day of at least the past 14 months, according to a ███ review of Senate records. Unlike his typical disclosure reports, which are a mix of sales and purchases, all of the transactions were sales. His biggest sales included companies that are among the most vulnerable to an economic slowdown. He dumped up to $150,000 worth of shares of Wyndham Hotels and Resorts, a chain based in the United States that has lost two-thirds of its value. And he sold up to $100,000 of shares of Extended Stay America, an economy hospitality chain. Shares of that company are now worth less than half of what they did at the time Burr sold.

The assets come from accounts that are held by Burr, belong to his spouse, or are jointly held.

Title: Political Strategist David Horowitz Outlines Strategy for Republican Victory in 2016 Presidential Election

Article:

In a recent interview, political strategist David Horowitz outlined his strategy for the Republican Party's success in the 2016 presidential election. Horowitz, author of "Take No Prisoners: The Battle Plan for Defeating the Left" (Regnery, 2014), argues that the Republican Party will likely win the upcoming midterm elections due to six years of perceived radical policies under the current administration.

According to Horowitz, the Democratic Party has shifted to the left, becoming driven by ideology rather than pragmatism. This ideological focus, he suggests, has led to policies that have negatively impacted the economy, healthcare, and national security. As a result, Horowitz asserts, the American people are disillusioned with the Democratic Party and will turn out in large numbers to vote against them in the midterms.

Looking ahead to the 2016 presidential election, Horowitz believes that the Republican Party will focus on policy and maintain a positive message, while the Democratic Party will attack Republicans with moral indictments, portraying them as racists, sexists, homophobes, and enemies of the poor. Horowitz argues that the only way for Republicans to counter such attacks is to fight fire with fire, indicting the Democratic Party's moral character in response.

Horowitz cites examples of the Democratic Party's perceived moral failings, such as their support for policies that disproportionately affect poor black and Hispanic children, and their failure to address issues of crime and violence in inner cities. He also criticizes the Democratic Party for not holding Al Sharpton, the President's chief adviser on race, accountable for his controversial statements and actions.

Horowitz concludes by emphasizing the importance of a moral indictment in political warfare, stating that attacks on an opponent's character can be a powerful tool in winning elections. He warns that if Republicans fail to attack the Democratic Party in this way, they can expect to be attacked themselves.

Title: Russia Increases Military Presence in Syria, Launches Naval Bombardment on ISIS Targets

Article:

Russia has launched a naval bombardment on ISIS targets in Syria, according to a senior Russian official. The strikes, which took place on Wednesday, were launched from the Caspian Sea using long-range missiles that traveled 1,500 kilometers (930 miles) to their targets.

Russia's Defense Ministry reported that the strikes were aimed at Syrian targets. Wednesday's attacks also appear to mark new and closer military cooperation between Russia and the Syrian regime of President Bashar al-Assad.

According to an opposition group, Russia and Syria launched coordinated attacks on Islamist factions in towns in Hama and Idlib provinces in western Syria. The Syrian shelling seemed to be conducted in concert with Russian airstrikes.

The U.S. Defense Secretary Ashton Carter described the Russian campaign of airstrikes in Syria as a "fundamental mistake." The U.S. is not ready to cooperate with Russia on operations in Syria, Carter said.

Russian airstrikes in Syria from September 30 to October 5. Russian Deputy Defense Minister Anatoly Antonov appeared to indicate that cooperation was in the works. He said Russia was prepared to take information and intelligence the U.S.-led coalition had obtained against ISIS, and he called on all sides to share targeting reconnaissance.

The U.S. military recently had to divert one aircraft over Syria to ensure it could maintain a safe flying distance from a Russian fighter. Until the two countries agree on mutual flight safety rules in Syrian airspace, U.S. pilots are under orders to change their flight path if a Russian plane is within 20 nautical miles, a senior defense official told CNN.

Russian warplanes conducted heavy airstrikes on Wednesday on Islamist factions, accompanied by shelling from government forces, according to the UK-based, anti-Assad Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The head of the observatory said there were no ISIS positions in the areas targeted, and fierce clashes were taking place on the ground between regime forces and their allies and armed Islamist rebel factions, including the Ahrar al-Sham and al Qaeda-affiliated al-Nusra Front.

Wednesday's clashes are the fiercest in the last month, the observatory said. Syria's ambassador to Russia, Riad Haddad, said Wednesday that around 40% of ISIS infrastructure had been destroyed since Moscow's military operation began.

However, Turkey, Syria's neighbor to the north, cast fresh doubt on whether Russia's goal was to go after ISIS. Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said that only 3.5% of Russia's airstrikes in Syria so far have targeted the terror group.

NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg condemned Russia's incursion into Turkish airspace. "These air raids are not against ISIS. There were 57 air raids by Russian air forces. Fifty-five of them were against moderate opposition and only two were against Daesh," Turkey's Anadolu news agency quoted Davutoglu as saying, reflecting government thinking. Daesh is another name for ISIS.

The developments come a day after NATO's secretary-general expressed alarm over how the Russian military had grown on several fronts in Syria, including boots on the ground. "So we have seen a substantial military buildup by Russia in Syria, both in the air with the combat planes and air defense systems, but also an increasing number of ground troops," Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said. "In addition to that, they have deployed naval assets, a large number of naval assets close to the Syrian shores."

Russian planes have also incurred into Turkish airspace twice, he said. "It's unacceptable, it's dangerous, and it's reckless behavior and it adds to the tensions," Stoltenberg told CNN. Stoltenberg said he doubted that Russia was interested primarily in fighting ISIS. "I'm also concerned that Russia is not targeting ISIL but instead attacking the Syrian opposition and civilians," he said.

Title: Vice President Pence Discusses Coronavirus Progress, Testing, and Economic Relief

Article:

In an exclusive interview with ███ News, Vice President Mike Pence discussed the country's progress in the battle against the coronavirus. The interview took place on Friday, following a rapid COVID-19 test for the reporter.

When asked about the timeline for returning to normal after the April 30th guidelines, Pence stated, "We're seeing real progress. We're going to be following the data very carefully, but if, as some of the experts suggest, if we are nearing the peak of the coronavirus and if Americans continue to do what they've been doing now for weeks across the country… we believe we'd be in a very different place come the end of April and we'll be able to bring forward recommendations."

Pence also addressed the initial lag in testing due to bureaucratic red tape, stating that the administration is now working closely with the private sector to improve testing capabilities. He highlighted the new 15-minute test developed by Abbott Laboratories, which is being made available across the country.

Regarding religious services, Pence acknowledged that most places of worship have complied with social distancing guidelines, with doors remaining closed. He encouraged continued financial support for religious institutions during this critical time.

On the economic front, Pence praised the bipartisan cooperation in Congress, stating that relief is on the way. He mentioned direct payments to families and the paycheck protection program for small businesses as key components of the relief efforts.

When asked about the ongoing debate over nationwide mail-in balloting, Pence did not reveal the administration's game plan, stating, "Our objective right now is to put the coronavirus in the past."

As the leader of the Coronavirus Task Force, Pence expressed optimism about the future, stating, "I believe there will indeed be light at the end of this very dark and tumultuous tunnel."

Title: Alaska Legislature Averts Obamacare Collapse with $55 Million Insurance Fund

Article:

Alaska, one of the most Republican-leaning states in the U.S., is taking steps to prevent the collapse of its Obamacare insurance marketplace. A bill, passed by the heavily GOP state Legislature and awaiting the signature of Governor Bill Walker, sets up a $55 million fund to subsidize enrollees' costs as the state grapples with Obamacare price spikes and the departure of all but one insurance company.

The legislation, originally proposed by Walker, redirects an existing tax on all insurance companies to finance the fund. The bill aims to ensure that the 23,000 Alaskans enrolled in exchange plans will not lose their insurance. Moda Health, the sole remaining company planning to sell coverage next year, announced last month that it would pull out of the Alaska exchange.

The $55 million fund will help cover medical expenses for high-cost enrollees. However, the money currently goes into Alaska's general fund, and redirecting it to bolster Obamacare has sparked criticism due to the state's massive budget deficit.

Republican state lawmakers, who have sued Walker for expanding Medicaid under the health law, maintain their opposition to Obamacare. However, they argue that they are taking necessary action to prevent health insurance premiums from skyrocketing and leaving thousands of people without coverage.

State Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-Alaska) stated, "What I'm getting — and I guarantee what the Alaska Legislature's getting — is constituents pleading with them for help." He added, "There's been no state in the union more negatively impacted by Obamacare than Alaska."

The Medicaid expansion lawsuit, meanwhile, was dismissed by one court earlier this year, and lawmakers are considering whether to appeal. The state's efforts to prevent Obamacare's collapse are unique among states, as no other state is currently considering such a step to prop up its insurance marketplace.

Alaska's high health care costs, historically some of the highest in the country, are attributed to factors such as physicians and hospitals being paid more compared to those in nearby states and difficulty accessing facilities in the rural state. Just a few severely ill patients have put a strain on insurers, with nearly 500 enrollees with severe medical conditions costing Alaska insurers about $59 million in less than two years, according to state documents.

If approved by the governor, the insurance fund will go into effect on June 30. The legislation also authorizes Alaska to apply for an Obamacare waiver that allows states to change pieces of the federal law starting in 2017 as long as those reforms meet certain requirements. State Sen. Cathy Giessel said, "We're doing something to help Alaskans who need health care."

Title: Journalist Endorses Bernie Sanders for U.S. President

Article:

In a recent statement, a columnist has announced their endorsement of Sen. Bernie Sanders for the position of President of the United States. The columnist, who contributes to various outlets offering in-depth political coverage, sports analysis, entertainment reviews, and cultural commentary, has expressed their support for Sanders over his opponent, Joe Biden, in the Democratic Party nomination.

The columnist's endorsement of Sanders is based on the belief that it is crucial to vote out incumbent President Donald Trump in November. Polls indicate that Sanders leads Trump with a greater margin than other contenders, and Sanders currently holds the highest popular approval rating of any public official in America.

The columnist asserts that Sanders' integrity and credibility are essential attributes in challenging a president who is perceived as a constant liar, such as Donald Trump. Sanders' history, vision, and platform are considered well-suited to defeat Trump, with the ability to expose Trump's false populism, broken promises on trade, and continued support for wars.

Sanders' campaign platform focuses on addressing the fundamental challenges facing working people. Key aspects of his agenda include Medicare for All, a Green New Deal, tuition-free college, a $15 minimum wage, empowering workers and unions, comprehensive immigration reform, universal childcare, criminal justice reform, and more.

The columnist argues that Sanders will inspire young people to vote in large numbers, a crucial factor in defeating Trump. They also emphasize that Sanders has a proven track record of forging a coalition between the working class and the middle class, and of standing for diversity against division.

Comparing Sanders to Biden, the columnist notes that while Biden is a decent man, he has a different record on issues such as Clarence Thomas, the Crime Bill, the Iraq War, and affirmative action. The columnist suggests that Biden's record does little to address the pain of African Americans or working people in general, while Sanders' progressive policies are considered more effective in addressing these issues.

The columnist concludes by stating that Sanders represents the moral center, with policies such as health care for all, tuition-free college, and a Middle East policy recognizing both Israel and Palestine, being in line with this moral center. When asked for their endorsement, the columnist shared their concerns about pressing issues with Sanders, who confirmed his commitment to addressing these issues, among others.

Title: Pope Francis Apologizes for Church Abuse Scandals in Ireland, Faces Accusations of Ignoring Abuse Allegations

Article:

Pope Francis, during a two-day visit to Ireland, expressed his apologies for the sexual abuse scandal within the Irish church and other abuses committed by the church, including at its so-called "mother and baby" homes. The pope made these statements in front of 45,000 supporters at the rain-soaked Knock shrine in the west of Ireland and at a later Mass in Dublin's Phoenix Park.

However, the visit has been marred by accusations from a former Vatican official, Archbishop Carlo Maria Vigano, who claimed that Pope Francis personally ignored sexual abuse allegations against prominent US cardinal Theodore McCarrick, who was forced to resign last month. Vigano wrote in a letter published in the National Catholic Register that he had informed Francis of the allegations in 2013, but that the pope responded by lifting sanctions imposed on McCarrick by his predecessor, Pope Benedict.

The Vatican has not commented on Vigano's claims. Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar directly urged the pope to take action against abuses and ensure justice for victims worldwide. The pope met with eight abuse victims during his visit, including a woman who was assaulted by a priest when she was 13 and a man who was illegally adopted from a Church-run "mother and baby" home.

At a news conference in Dublin by the group Ending Clergy Abuse (ECA), victim Mark Vincent Healey criticized the pope's speech in Dublin as a "total missed opportunity." Healey stated, "We're still waiting. We're left with uncertain silence. When is he going to act? What is he going to do?"

The pope's visit is part of the 2018 World Meeting of Families, a global Catholic gathering that addressed issues including the treatment of gay people in the Church. This is the first papal visit to Ireland since John Paul II spoke in front of 1.5 million people during a visit in 1979. The Church's role and standing have been badly dented by the abuse scandals, and the Irish have shed traditional Catholic mores, voting earlier this year to legalize abortion after approving same-sex marriage in 2015.

In Tuam, a town in western Ireland not far from Knock, hundreds joined in a silent vigil on Sunday in solidarity with victims of the "mother and baby" homes, institutions accused of being punishment hostels for unwed pregnant women. Significant quantities of baby remains found in makeshift graves at the site of one such home in Tuam last year shocked the country.

Multiple probes in Ireland have found Church leaders protected hundreds of predatory priests, and former Irish president Mary McAleese revealed this month that the Vatican had sought to keep Church documents inaccessible to government investigators. The abuse scandals in Ireland are part of a worldwide crisis for the Vatican. A devastating report earlier this month accused more than 300 priests in the US state of Pennsylvania of abusing more than 1,000 children since the 1950s. The Pope is due to head back to Rome late Sunday.

Title: Obama and Congressional Leaders Pursue Alternative Tax Plan as Fiscal Cliff Deadline Approaches

Article:
