In the ongoing negotiations to avoid the fiscal cliff, President Barack Obama and Congressional leaders are reportedly considering a fallback measure to prevent tax increases for most Americans. This alternative plan may pass in the House with strong support from Democrats, as conservative Republicans have signaled their opposition to any legislation that raises tax rates for more than 1 percent of Americans.

The proposed plan involves extending the Bush tax rates permanently for income below $250,000, a position Obama has maintained for four years. In negotiations with House Speaker John Boehner, Obama had tentatively agreed to raise the threshold to $400,000, and Congressional Democrats have suggested they might go as high as $500,000 to secure a deal with Republicans.

However, the rejection of Boehner's bill by Republicans on Thursday indicates that such concessions may not sway the antitax absolutists within the Republican party. Boehner's so-called Plan B would have extended the Bush tax cuts for income up to $1 million, but this was still too much for many of his members.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell has not publicly indicated whether he would support this alternative plan. When asked before Obama's statement whether he would agree not to filibuster the stripped-down bill, McConnell responded with "Merry Christmas."

Boehner has not specified when or if he will call the House back into session, but a spokesman said late Friday that the speaker would return to Washington after the holiday "ready to find a solution that can pass both houses of Congress."

The likely measure, according to Democrats on Capitol Hill, would extend the Bush-era tax rates for income below $250,000, increase the tax rate for capital gains and dividend income to 20 percent from 15 percent, and extend some other tax breaks. It would also delay the sequester, across-the-board spending cuts in military and domestic programs, and extend federal unemployment benefits for the estimated two million Americans who have been out of a job for long enough to exhaust their initial state aid.

A spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid said in a statement: "As a fallback plan to protect the middle class, Republicans should support passing a bill that extends tax cuts for families up to $250,000, extends unemployment insurance, and delays the so-called sequester while we negotiate additional policies next year."

The new bill would not, according to Congressional Democrats, put efforts in motion to achieve additional deficit reduction through overhauls of the tax code and spending for fast-growing entitlement programs, chiefly Medicare.

The upshot is that, for a second year, Obama has been unable to reach agreement with Boehner on a debt-reduction framework that would stabilize the nation's debt, which is growing unsustainably as the population ages and medical costs rise. Nor would the measure extend the nation's borrowing limit, which the Treasury will hit early in 2013. Obama had hoped for a deal that would include a debt-limit increase to avert the showdown that damaged the economy and both parties' public approval ratings last year.

By resorting to the stripped-down legislative option, Obama demonstrated that his and his party's priority is to prevent the Bush tax cuts from expiring for most Americans. However, he may be forfeiting some leverage in the coming fiscal battles early next year over extending the debt limit. Many Republicans are threatening to withhold support for increasing that limit without Obama's agreement to deep reductions in spending for Medicare and Social Security. By both sides' reckoning, Obama would have a strong hand in the debt limit debate if it remained tied to the tax issue, given Republicans' zeal to avoid tax increases.

Title: U.S.-China Trade Deal Remains Unclear as Details Remain Vague and Verification Challenges Persist

Article:

The U.S.-China trade deal, referred to as "Phase One" or "preliminary," has raised doubts about its ability to serve American interests. The lack of an English-language version of the agreement and the vague terms have led to questions about the common understanding of key terms in both languages.

The most detailed description of the agreement so far comes from the U.S. Trade Representative's (USTR) office, which provides specifics about U.S. tariff reductions but lacks details about China's own pledges. The agreement does not specify the Chinese purchases from the United States, the timeframe for these purchases, or the specifics of China's structural reforms and changes to its economic and trade regime in areas such as intellectual property, technology transfer, agriculture, financial services, and currency and foreign exchange.

The Trump administration has acknowledged the challenges in addressing these issues, which lie at the heart of the U.S.-China technology and national security rivalries, as well as the purely economic rivalry. The administration has settled for a shorter-term, interim agreement due to the complexity of these issues.

The agreement also lacks details about a "strong dispute resolution system that ensures prompt implementation and enforcement." If the United States does not insist on being the sole judge, jury, and court of appeals when dealing with Chinese compliance, the agreement's effectiveness in benefiting U.S.-based producers may be limited.

The political implications of the U.S. announcement are also puzzling. China's economy has taken a greater trade war hit than the United States, and the Chinese government is struggling to contain unrest in Hong Kong. The new U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) will offset some of the China-related losses suffered by agriculture-heavy states crucial to President Trump's re-election hopes.

The U.S.-China trade deal's tentative and flimsy nature suggests it is likely to fall apart sooner rather than later. Additionally, U.S.-China decoupling will continue due to the unbridgeable technology and national security gulf between the two countries and the increased wariness of U.S.-owned companies about exposing themselves to China's lawless and unreliable government.

Title: Tension Between U.S. and Russia Over Edward Snowden Threatens Obama-Putin Meeting

 Article:

 The ongoing dispute between the United States and Russia over the fugitive security leaker Edward Snowden has led President Barack Obama to consider cancelling a scheduled meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin. As Snowden continues to reside at a Moscow airport while seeking asylum, Obama may forgo a meeting with Putin, which was scheduled for June, according to The New York Times.

 Tensions remain high between the two leaders as Obama seeks a return of Snowden, while Putin considers allowing the government security whistleblower to stay in Russia. This escalating situation has created a rift between the U.S. and Russia amid broader concerns over arms negotiations, a missile defense program, and strategies moving forward on Syria and Iran, as reported by The New York Times.

 Initially, Obama had planned on the Moscow stop as part of a trip to St. Petersburg for the Group of 20 (G-20) nations. White House spokesman Jay Carney, when asked about the proposed trip, stated, "I can say that the president intends to travel to Russia for the G-20 summit. I don’t have anything to add to what we’ve said in the past about that trip."

 Putin, who has criticized the U.S. amid the spying disclosures, said Wednesday he did not want to hinder dialogue, stating, "Bilateral relations, in my opinion, are far more important than squabbles about the activities of the secret services."

 Critics of the White House's handling of the Snowden affair have urged Obama to take a firmer stance in bringing him home, suggesting that the president should consider relocating the summit out of Russia altogether. Senator Lindsey Graham, speaking with CNN's Jake Tapper on Wednesday, encouraged Obama to be more assertive with Russia. He has also suggested that Obama should boycott the Olympic Games set for Sochi in 2014.

 "President Obama, should you go to St. Petersburg, Russia, for the G-20 summit if they give Snowden asylum and they don’t change their policy toward Syria and continue to help Iran?" Graham said on CNN. "Should you go? My advice to you is I wouldn’t go to St. Petersburg. I would ask for a change of venue."

Title: President Obama Announces Executive Order for Paid Sick Leave for Federal Contractors, Expands Worker Protections

Article:

President Barack Obama's Labor Day announcement of an executive order requiring paid sick leave for federal contractors is the latest step in a broader second-term push to expand worker protections. Speaking at a Greater Boston Labor Council breakfast, Mr. Obama stated that the new regulation would offer approximately 300,000 people working on federal contracts the ability to earn up to seven days of paid sick leave each year.

Currently, federal law requires employers to provide up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave. However, the White House notes that 44 million workers, or 40% of the total private-sector workforce, do not have access to paid leave. Workers could use the paid time off under the Obama administration proposal to care for themselves or a family member or to deal with absences resulting from domestic violence or sexual assault. The provision is set to take effect in 2017, after Obama leaves office.

In addition, the Labor Department this week will publish a final rule prohibiting federal contractors from discriminating against employees and job applicants who discuss their salaries. The goal is to provide "a critical tool to encourage pay transparency and make it easier for workers to recognize pay discrimination and seek appropriate remedies," according to a White House fact sheet.

The president's pro-labor actions have increased significantly since his reelection. In a December 2011 speech in Osawatomie, Kan., Obama stated, "This is a make-or-break moment for the middle class, and for all those who are fighting to get into the middle class."

Last month, a federal court upheld Labor Department regulations that extend minimum-wage and overtime pay rules to most home-health workers, who previously had not been covered by the standards. In June, the administration proposed to more than double the weekly salary threshold – to $970 – that determines who is eligible for overtime pay. The Labor Department estimates the step would make 5 million more workers entitled to overtime pay.

In 2014, a Labor Department rule became effective that banned discrimination on the bases of sexual orientation and gender identity in the federal contracting workforce. In 2014, President Obama also signed an executive order raising the minimum wage to $10.10 for all workers on federal construction and service contracts.

At least three motivating factors are apparent in the president's steps to aid workers. After his first term, Obama became convinced that the Republican-controlled Congress would not approve legislation he requested. So the president began using executive orders that help federal workers and lay the groundwork for wider adoption in the future.

In his 2014 State of the Union address, the president called for a "year of action" to build new ladders of economic opportunity. "Some require congressional action, and I'm eager to work with all of you," Obama said. "But America does not stand still – and neither will I. So wherever and whenever I can take steps without legislation to expand opportunity for more American families, that's what I'm going to do."

Steps to improve conditions for workers also help build a legacy for a president nearing the end of his term. Obama's early career was spent as a community organizer in Chicago with a special interest in helping those on the economic margins. So the labor issues have a special resonance for him.

The spate of pro-worker actions also comes in the context of the labor movement being an important Democratic Party constituency in the 2016 presidential election. It would clearly help protect Obama's legacy if a Democratic president followed him.

However, White House relations with labor could use some attention. Labor leaders are unhappy with the 12-nation Asia-Pacific trade deal, the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the White House has negotiated. AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka is sharply critical of the pace at which the White House has acted on workplace safety regulations. "We haven't seen the needed regulations to keep pace with the change in the environment of the workplace," he said. "We kill 150 workers a day in this country. Doesn't that bother any of you?"

At the recent breakfast, Trumka also criticized Hillary Clinton's strategy of not being specific about her views on the TPP trade deal. "Candidates that try to skirt the issues, not talking about where you are on TPP, hurt you when it comes to activating the membership and the general populous," he said. "They want to know where people are even if they disagree with you."

Title: President Obama Pressures Senate Republicans on Supreme Court Nominee as Democrats Shift Focus to Senate Control

Article:

President Barack Obama conducted a series of interviews with television stations from six states with incumbent Republican senators on Monday, aiming to pressure the Senate Republican leadership to schedule a confirmation hearing and vote on Judge Merrick Garland, his Supreme Court nominee. The interviews were held at the White House, and the states included Arizona, Iowa, Missouri, New Hampshire, Ohio, and Wisconsin.

Judge Garland, who has been waiting for seven weeks for action, is facing calls for the release of his office of professional responsibility records from his tenure at the Justice Department during the Clinton administration. A government watchdog group, the Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust, has asked Judge Garland to authorize the release of these records to allow citizens to evaluate his qualifications for the Supreme Court.

During the George W. Bush administration, Senate Democrats used a similar issue as justification for blocking the nomination of conservative lawyer Miguel Estrada to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit. Democrats insisted on withholding a final vote until the White House released Mr. Estrada's working papers from his time at the Clinton Justice Department. The Bush administration refused to release those memos, and Mr. Estrada was also on the legal team for Mr. Bush that fought the Florida recount in the contested 2000 presidential election.

Democrats point to polling that shows Republicans such as Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley of Iowa losing support in their home states for supporting the blockade of Judge Garland's nomination. In a survey, 44 percent of respondents said they are less likely to support Mr. Grassley in November because he is blocking the Garland nomination.

The polling, funded by the Constitutional Responsibility Project and the League of Conservation Voters, found that 60 percent of Iowa voters, including 63 percent of independents, agree with the conclusion that Mr. Grassley is allowing Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky to dictate the Senate Republican position on the nomination, rather than acting as a leader as chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid, Nevada Democrat, said he is "terribly disappointed" in Mr. Grassley. Mr. Grassley has defended his stance against the Garland nomination as a principled move that will give voters in November a voice in choosing the direction of the court. Only two of the 54 Senate Republicans say Judge Garland should receive a confirmation hearing.

Conservative activists have expressed skepticism about Democrats' push for Judge Garland, with Carrie Severino, chief counsel of the Judicial Crisis Network, stating, "A Supreme Court with Garland would roll back our Second Amendment right to keep and bear arms, harm small businesses by empowering unaccountable bureaucrats at agencies like the EPA and legalize partial-birth abortion." The Judicial Crisis Network is airing a $500,000 ad campaign over the Senate's recess in key states to call attention to Judge Garland's record.

President Obama nominated Judge Garland, 63, in March to fill the vacancy created by the death of conservative Justice Antonin Scalia. He is chief judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit and has received bipartisan praise for his qualifications. Conservatives worry that replacing the conservative justice with Judge Garland would shift the balance of power on the evenly divided court in favor of progressives for years to come.

Title: Study Suggests Fake News Impacted 2016 Presidential Election Outcome

Article:

A team of researchers at Ohio State University has concluded in a new study that "fake news" stories may have significantly impacted the 2016 presidential election, potentially influencing the final result. The study, first reported by The Washington Post on Tuesday, aimed to measure the degree to which false news stories dissuaded voters who cast ballots for President Obama in 2012 from voting for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton.

While the researchers emphasized that they could not definitively say that fake news "caused" Obama voters to defect from Clinton in 2016, they concluded that these stories had a "substantial impact" on voters that may have been sufficient to swing the election to Donald Trump.

"Our analysis leads us to the conclusion that fake news most likely did have a substantial impact on the voting decisions of a strategically important set of voters—those who voted for Barack Obama in 2012," the researchers wrote. They further stated that given the narrow margins of victory by Donald Trump in key battleground states, this impact may have been sufficient to deprive Hillary Clinton of a victory in the Electoral College.

The study, conducted by Richard Gunther, Paul A. Beck, and Erik C. Nisbet, involved a YouGov survey of 585 voters who supported Obama in 2012 out of a total sample of 1,600. The researchers asked these voters 281 questions that included fake news statements, two of which were negative about Clinton and one positive about Trump, and all of which were propagated by traditional and social media.

The researchers found a significant correlation between belief in the fake news statements and vote choice. Specifically, a much larger percentage of those Obama voters who did not believe any of the fake news statements voted for Hillary Clinton in 2016 (89%) than those who believed one of the statements (61%) and those who believed two or three of them (17%).

The study also took into account other factors that could have dissuaded Obama voters from casting ballots for Clinton, including age, race, political identification, and gender. Using multivariate regression analysis, they found that belief in the fake news statements still accounted for a significant portion of the defections when other factors were considered, including the extent to which voters disliked Clinton or liked Trump.

"Former Obama voters who believed one or more of these fake news stories were 3.9 times more likely to defect from the Democratic ticket in 2016 than those who did not believe any of the false claims, after taking into account all of these other factors," the researchers wrote.

However, the study emphasized that one cannot conclude from the survey that fake news caused Obama voters to defect from Clinton in 2016. It notes that it is possible a voter first decided not to vote for Clinton, and then in turn cited false stories in order to rationalize their vote.

"We can not prove that belief in fake news ‘caused’ these former Obama voters to defect from the Democratic candidate in 2016," the researchers wrote. "But if these estimates are even remotely accurate as measures of the impact of belief in fake news on defections from the Democratic candidate, it is highly likely that this pernicious pollution of our political discourse was sufficient to influence the outcome of what was a very close election."

The researchers said making a judgment about whether the fake stories determined the outcome of the election would have required a larger survey sample. The study has not been published in an academic journal yet, but likely will be in the coming months.

Title: High-Profile Feminism: A Look at the HeForShe Campaign and the Rebranding of Feminism

Article:

Emma Watson, the acclaimed actress known for her role as Hermione Granger in the Harry Potter series, has lent her name and influence to the cause of feminism at the United Nations. In a speech about gender equality that received a standing ovation and has since gone viral, Watson questioned the demonization of the term "feminism" and extended an invitation to men to join the movement.

Watson's speech, delivered during the launch of the HeForShe campaign, focused on the role of men and the rebranding of feminism. The campaign aims to engage men in stopping violence against women. Watson's speech has been shared by both "E!" and U.N. Women on their respective Twitter accounts, a rare occurrence for such speeches.

In her speech, Watson highlighted the importance of gender equality, stating, "I think it is right that I should make decisions about my own body. I think it is right that women be involved on my behalf in the policies and decisions that will affect my life." She also acknowledged the privileges she has experienced due to the gender equality ambassadors in her life, who have not limited her opportunities because of her gender.

The HeForShe campaign is part of a growing trend of high-profile figures lending their support to the feminist cause. Beyoncé, for example, has also publicly identified as a feminist and argued for equal pay and respect for women. In 2014, she wrote a piece for the Shriver Report, stating, "Equality will be achieved when men and women are granted equal pay and equal respect."

However, translating this high-profile support into tangible progress has been a challenge. In media, women are underrepresented, with fewer women appearing as sources or in authoritative roles in news stories. In entertainment, the Geena Davis Institute on Gender in Media found that there are 2.24 male characters for every female character in recently released films. Economically, the women's-to-men's earnings ratio has decreased after peaking in 2005 and 2006.

The challenge now is to turn the talk about gender equality into actionable change. The rebranding of feminism by cultural luminaries is commendable, but more progress is needed to achieve visible, on-the-ground gains in the lives of ordinary women and men. The HeForShe campaign, with its focus on engaging men in the movement, may be a step in the right direction. It will take a concerted effort from a village, boosted by high-wattage celebrities, to create a fairer world for everyone.

Title: U.S.-Iran Tensions Escalate: Analysis of Recent Events and Implications

Article:

The recent incidents of tanker attacks and nuclear activities in the Middle East have raised concerns about the escalating tensions between the United States and Iran. The damage to the tankers and Iran's alleged violations of the Iran nuclear pact have been described as measured provocations, with the U.S. and Iran seemingly engaging in a delicate dance that could potentially lead to escalation.

President Trump described the damage to the tankers as "very minor," and he appears to recognize the danger of further escalation. However, the U.S. has deployed an additional 2,500 troops to the region, and there have been calls for military action against Iran. If the U.S. were to strike Iran, it is expected that Iran would respond in kind.

Brett McGurk, a national security expert and former presidential envoy, warned that the administration's Iran policy may soon leave Trump with few options: either back down or resort to military action. The concern is that the U.S. administration's approach to Iran has been ineffective, and Trump may be "boxed in."

Furthermore, there are concerns that the U.S. is conflating Shiite Iran with the Sunni Taliban. Members of Congress fear that this is an attempt to provide Trump with legal cover to attack Iran under the 2001 authorization for the use of military force against Al Qaeda and its offshoots.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has offered a 12-point plan for Iran, which has been criticized as unrealistic and akin to a demand for Iran to surrender. The international community, including U.S. allies, has expressed growing distrust towards America due to the administration's incompetent bullying tactics in attempting to enforce Iran sanctions.

As the situation remains volatile, there are few good options available. Some experts suggest an international force to protect tankers might help, along with secret diplomacy to explore the possibility of reviving the nuclear deal in a manner acceptable to both sides. However, the prospects of such a resolution appear slim.

Title: Israeli Intelligence Minister Denies Knowledge of Trump's Alleged Assassination Order for Syrian President

Article:

Israel's Intelligence Minister Yisrael Katz has stated that he has no knowledge of U.S. President Donald Trump ever ordering the killing of Syria's President Bashar al-Assad, contradicting claims made in a new book by Watergate reporter Bob Woodward.

In his book, "Fear: Trump in the White House," Woodward alleges that Trump told his defense secretary he wanted to have Assad assassinated in response to a chemical attack on Syrian civilians in April 2017. The book claims that Defense Secretary James Mattis responded by saying he would "get right on it," but instead developed a plan for a limited air strike that did not threaten Assad personally.

Trump has since denied the quotes attributed to Mattis, calling them "made up frauds, a con on the public." Mattis dismissed the book as "a uniquely Washington brand of literature."

In response to these allegations, Katz told Tel Aviv radio station 103 FM, "I do not know of any such instruction. He (Trump) is also denying it."

Israel, while neutral on the 7-year Syrian civil war, has carried out numerous air strikes against suspected attempts by Assad's Iranian and Lebanese Hezbollah allies to establish permanent posts or advanced arms. Katz stated, "In any event, what can be said is that in the framework of the coordination between the United States and Israel... the subject of the Syrian regime is certainly part of the discussions. Israel did not take a decision to topple Assad."

Under decades of Assad family rule, Syria has maintained a Cold War-style hostility toward Israel. Katz added, "Of course his (Assad's) actions are terrible actions, and something that we abhor and condemn. Those opposing him, ISIS and others, are not a side that we think are better. We took care to preserve our interests."

Woodward gained national fame for his reporting on the Watergate scandal in the 1970s and has since written a number of books that provide behind-the-scenes glimpses of presidential administrations and other Washington institutions. For this book, Woodward spoke to top aides and other insiders with the understanding that he would not reveal how he got his information, according to The Washington Post, which published excerpts from the book on Tuesday.

Title: Israel Clarifies Airstrikes in Syria as Targeting Hezbollah, Not Assad Regime

Article:

Israel has sought to play down the recent airstrikes in Syria, emphasizing that the attacks were aimed at Hezbollah, not the Syrian regime. Following the airstrikes on Friday and Sunday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's confidante, Tzachi Hanegbi, stated that the aim was to avoid escalating tensions with Syria, clarifying that any activity is only against Hezbollah, not the Syrian regime.

Hezbollah, an Iran-backed militant group that seeks Israel's elimination, has historically relied on the Assad regime to transfer weapons from Iran into its own hands. The relationship between Damascus and Hezbollah appears to have grown closer as a result of Syria's civil war, with Hezbollah fighters battling the Syrian opposition from within the country.

Israel's government reportedly informed President Bashar al-Assad through diplomatic channels that the attacks were not intended to influence the outcome of Syria's civil war. Israeli officials did not immediately confirm the report, but one suggested that such indirect contacts were not necessary.

Netanyahu left for a diplomatic trip to China on Sunday, which was described as part of Israel's effort to send a calming message to Assad. Israel will continue to maintain official silence about the two air strikes, with a senior Israeli official stating that the goal is to make clear to Assad that Israel's sole interest is in preventing advanced weaponry from reaching Hezbollah.

The Sunday airstrike hit a military facility near the presidential palace in Damascus, resulting in the deaths of dozens of elite troops, according to a Syrian official. A military hospital doctor reported at least 100 deaths and scores more injuries. Although Israel did not comment on the attacks, Israeli analysts suggest that they were likely targeting weapons meant to be transferred from the Syrian military to Hezbollah.

Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad told CNN that the Israeli strikes were "a declaration of war" and that Syria would respond. However, neither Syria nor Israel seem to desire a fresh conflict, as the next encounter promises to be more destructive than the 2006 war. Israeli security analyst Reuven Pedhazur told the Monitor that Syria and Hezbollah are unlikely to be willing to retaliate, even symbolically, as Israel will respond in kind.

Title: Former U.S. State Department and Pentagon Officials Sign Statement Criticizing Trump's Decision to Revoke John Brennan's Security Clearance

Article:

More than 175 former U.S. State Department and Pentagon officials have added their names to a statement signed by former national security officials criticizing President Donald Trump's decision to cancel the security clearance of former CIA Director John Brennan. The new signatories to the statement, initially issued last week by 15 former directors and deputy chiefs of the Central Intelligence Agency and Office of Director of National Intelligence, include former political appointees and career civil servants who have worked under both Democratic and Republican presidents.

Among the most prominent individuals to sign a new version of the statement released on Monday by senior officials from the George W. Bush and Barack Obama administrations are former NATO Commander Admiral James Stavridis, former Deputy Secretaries of State Anthony Blinken and William Burns, and former Undersecretaries of State Nicholas Burns, Wendy Sherman, and Thomas Pickering.

While they may not agree with all Brennan's public attacks on Trump, the statement reads, they believe "the country will be weakened if there is a political litmus test applied" before former officials are allowed to voice their views.

Separately, U.S. Senator Mark Warner, the Democratic vice chairman of the Intelligence Committee, filed legislation on Monday that would limit the president's ability to revoke an individual's security clearance.

Trump said last week he was considering withdrawing clearances for other former high-ranking officials as well as Bruce Ohr, a current Justice Department official. Brennan, who has publicly characterized Trump's comments at a recent summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin as "treasonous," has said he might sue the Trump administration over the revocation of his clearance.

Representatives Elijah Cummings and Stephen Lynch, top Democrats on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, in a letter on Monday to White House Chief of Staff John Kelly, questioned the security clearance of John Bolton, Trump's national security adviser. Cummings and Lynch asked Kelly to turn over documents related to whether Bolton, in security clearance forms or "other White House vetting materials," reported that in 2013 he participated by video in a roundtable discussion on gun rights organized by Maria Butina.

Butina was arrested in July and accused of acting as a Russian agent while developing ties with U.S. citizens and infiltrating political groups. The Washington Post has reported that Bolton recorded the video promoting an expansion of gun rights in Russia used by Right to Bear Arms, a group Butina formed.

The White House National Security Council had no immediate comment on the letter. White House aides also declined to comment. Russia has denied any interference in the 2016 U.S. election. Trump has said there was no collusion with his campaign.

"Everybody wants to keep their Security Clearance, it's worth great prestige and big dollars, even board seats, and that is why certain people are coming forward to protect Brennan," Trump said in a series of posts on Twitter.

Title: Joe Biden Outlines Policy Proposals to Address Racial Inequality and Systemic Racism

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden, the presumptive 2020 Democratic presidential nominee, has outlined a series of policy proposals aimed at addressing racial inequalities and systemic racism in the United States.

In a speech, Biden stated, "We know the nation we want to be. Now we have to deliver on this moment to achieve fundamental changes that address racial inequalities and white supremacy in our country."

Biden criticized President Donald Trump's rhetoric, stating that it inflames racial divides in the country. He emphasized the need to root out systemic racism across laws and institutions and ensure black Americans have equal opportunities.

One of the proposals Biden supports is enhancing penalties for making false 911 calls based on race, gender, or religion. He also suggested prioritizing support for mission-driven lenders in low-income communities, expanding the New Markets Tax Credit Program, and expanding programs at the Small Business Administration that are effective in helping launch black-owned businesses.

Housing discrimination is another area of concern for Biden. He highlighted the gap between African American and white homeownership and proposed giving local officials the tools to combat gentrification, end discriminatory lending practices, and eliminate exclusionary zoning laws.

Biden also addressed education, advocating for improving teacher diversity, solving the student debt crisis, and investing in historically underfunded institutions like historically black colleges and universities.

In terms of police reform, Biden supports banning chokeholds, ensuring independent prosecutors in police-involved killings, collecting data regarding police use of force, and requiring training for officers regarding racial and religious bias and their duty to intervene if another officer is abusing power. He also proposed an additional $300 million for community policing.

Biden also emphasized the need for investments in mental health services, drug treatment, and services for people experiencing homelessness. He suggested that social service providers could respond to calls with police officers in some situations.

Biden concluded, "We do not need a campaign, we need Biden to be a shadow president. Nothing about this fight will be easy. It will take leadership at the highest levels of our government—and sustained grassroots pressure from communities who will no longer stand by silently when injustices are inflicted on people of color."

Title: Minnesota Senator Al Franken Remains Unopposed by Republicans in 2014 Re-election Bid

Article:

Minnesota Senator Al Franken, who won his seat in 2009 by a narrow margin of 312 votes, has yet to draw a Republican opponent for his 2014 re-election bid. The Republican Party, which initially targeted Franken as a top pickoff target, now faces a recruitment challenge in finding a strong candidate to challenge the incumbent Democrat.

The GOP's struggle to find top-tier candidates in several states, including Minnesota, speaks to the broader recruitment challenge Republicans face in 2014. To overcome the Democrats' 10-seat Senate advantage, the GOP needs to expand the map by putting seats like Franken's in play. However, the party has yet to find strong candidates in several states that should, at least on paper, be competitive.

Senators Mark Udall of Colorado and Tom Udall of New Mexico, who were elected in 2008, are considered safe. No top-tier GOP candidate has announced yet in Michigan, New Hampshire, or Iowa. Democrats are defending seats in seven red states carried by Mitt Romney last year, but it is highly unlikely that Republicans will run the table in those places.

Franken, the former "Saturday Night Live" star and liberal talk show host, has worked hard to position himself as a serious lawmaker. He has kept a low profile, largely avoided national press, and focused on populist issues like privacy and consumer protection. Franken has cultivated a reputation as a serious lawmaker and has amassed a formidable war chest.

Minnesota, which was genuinely purple a decade ago, has taken on a more bluish hue. The state Republican Party is reeling, debt-ridden, and seeking to find its way after its Ron Paul-affiliated Senate nominee lost to Sen. Amy Klobuchar by 34 points in November.

Polling released last week shows Franken's approval rating just above the 50 percent threshold, a key metric for an incumbent. The Democratic firm Public Policy Polling showed him starting with a double-digit lead over six potential Republican candidates.

University of Minnesota political scientist Larry Jacobs commented, "It's shocking to me that Franken is as safe as he is at this point."

Republicans hope national atmospherics, specifically the growing unpopularity of Obamacare and the scandals enveloping President Obama, will help put Minnesota in play. They believe 2014 will be a bad year for incumbents in general, and that while Franken is no doubt the favorite at the moment, the race is not lost for the GOP.

Knowing he would have a tough race, Franken hired a campaign manager early and started fundraising aggressively. He brought in $2 million in the first quarter and has about that much cash on hand. Franken's campaign manager, Matt Burgess, stated, "My mantra is to be prepared and ready for anything."

Title: Meg Whitman Suggests Possible Endorsement of Hillary Clinton Over Donald Trump

Article:

In a private meeting held in Park City, Utah, Hewlett Packard Enterprise CEO Meg Whitman reportedly expressed reservations about supporting Donald Trump's presidential bid, suggesting the possibility of endorsing Hillary Clinton instead. According to John Chachas, a GOP donor who attended the event, Whitman posed the question, "Is it not reasonable to support Hillary Clinton?" given Trump's controversial statements.

During the meeting, Whitman reportedly compared Trump to both Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini, according to anonymous attendees speaking to Politico. However, in subsequent interviews, Whitman did not fully endorse Clinton, stating that she had not made a decision yet and would wait to see who the vice presidential picks are before making a final decision.

Whitman, 59, served as CEO of eBay for a decade starting in 1998 before taking on the same role at HP in 2011. She unsuccessfully ran for governor of California against Democratic incumbent Jerry Brown in 2010, setting a record for the most money ever spent by a political candidate on a single election, according to the Los Angeles Times.

Whitman advised Mitt Romney during his 2012 campaign to prevent President Obama's re-election and supported New Jersey Governor Chris Christie before he dropped out of the GOP race earlier in the election season. As of last June, Forbes estimated Whitman's net worth to be approximately $2.1 billion.

In response to Whitman's potential endorsement, Trump reportedly stated, "I never met Meg Whitman, but the job she is doing at Hewlett-Packard is not a very good one." Trump added, "Based on the disastrous campaign she ran in California, and the tens of millions of dollars she wasted, I have learned a lot from her. I do not want her support."

A previous report erroneously stated that the meeting was held in Washington, D.C.

Title: Republican Presidential Debate Focuses on Donald Trump's Remarks on Islam

Article:

The latest Republican presidential debate, hosted by CNN, took place on Thursday, with a significant portion of the discussion centered on the comments made by Donald Trump regarding Islam and Muslims. The debate, which was criticized for its bombastic and condescending presentation, did not result in any significant changes to the current political landscape.

During the debate, Trump reiterated his controversial stance on Islam, stating, "I think Islam hates us. There's something there that—there's a tremendous hatred there. We have to get to the bottom of it." When given an opportunity to clarify his remarks, Trump refused to distinguish between radical and non-radical interpretations of Islam.

In response to Trump's comments, Marco Rubio offered a tepid critique, stating that presidents cannot say anything they want. Rubio added that he was not interested in being politically correct, but that there were pragmatic reasons not to dehumanize 1.6 billion people.

The Intercept's Murtaza Hussain noted that this exchange was significant because it was not just about Trump, but about the entire Republican Party and the millions of Americans who continue to support it. The debate, as observed by people worldwide, presents a perception of the United States that may influence the opinions of those who are not yet set in their views of the country.

Title: China's Economic Slowdown: A Period of Significant Change and Uncertainty

Article:

China's economic outlook is facing challenges, as stock prices have been declining since the spring due to investor concerns about a potential weakening economy, including the risk of a "hard landing" for China. This economic slowdown could have a ripple effect on the global economy, contributing to recent downturns in U.S. stock markets.

However, some economists argue that a severe economic downturn, or "hard landing," may not occur. Instead, they suggest that the Chinese economy is cooling rather than plummeting. The slowdown was, in part, necessary and inevitable, as China's growth had been rooted in unsustainable investment in factories, property, and other fixed assets.

Moreover, the popular view of China as an unstoppable economic giant was never entirely accurate. The market plunge may prompt people to take a more realistic view that incorporates China's weaknesses and the transition from its high-growth era to the likelihood of slower growth in the future.

The economic challenges in China also present potential risks for political unrest, with reported signs of tension within the ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP). President Xi Jinping is pursuing sweeping economic changes alongside an avowed crackdown on official corruption.

Despite the short-term turmoil, many China watchers argue that a successful outcome would be if the economic bumps become steps along Xi's route to an economy that emphasizes freer markets and more domestic consumption, rather than growth fueled by exports and government-led investment.

China's economic slowdown could also have implications for the rest of the world, particularly neighboring Asian nations. If China's economy is slowing more than expected, it could pull some wind out of the world economy.

Economists are not necessarily adopting "hard-landing" forecasts for China. Julian Jessop of the forecasting firm Capital Economics in London wrote in a Monday analysis that the recent economic data from China "are not weak enough to justify fears of a 'hard landing,' especially with the full impact of policy stimulus yet to come through."

China's policymakers have financial firepower at their disposal to do substantially more in the way of stimulus as needed. Kamel Mellahi, of Britain's Warwick Business School, expects China's economy to weather its current financial market storm. He believes that Xi's government is very focused on navigating the long-term reforms outlined by the CCP in the past few years.

These reforms range from an overhaul of banking rules to a new system of farm property rights, and other steps toward modern regulatory systems and better market-based allocation of resources. "China is trying to calm the stock market and at the same time address short-term domestic financial problems," says Mellahi. "But I don't think China is going to take major decisions that could jeopardize its long-term objectives."

The road ahead won't necessarily be smooth, and the current turbulence can be viewed as an early reminder of that. "The Chinese economy will not, and should not, grow as fast as it used to," Mellahi says. "The ultimate goal is to achieve a balanced, more sustained growth level."

Title: Trump and Kim Jong-un Exchange Insults Amidst Ongoing Nuclear Tensions

Article:

In the ongoing saga of North Korea's nuclear weapons program, a series of tweets exchanged between U.S. President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un have raised concerns about the potential escalation of tensions.

During his Asia trip, President Trump took to Twitter to respond to Kim Jong-un's characterization of him as "old" in a speech. Trump tweeted, "Why would Kim Jong-un insult me by calling me 'old,'" followed by, "When I would NEVER call him'short and fat?'"

Some commentators, such as Ben Shapiro, have speculated that such exchanges could potentially lead to a nuclear conflict, with Shapiro tweeting, "World War III began after a series of seemingly comic tweets escalated into a nuclear exchange."

However, it is important to note that Kim Jong-un did not directly call Trump "short and fat" in his speech, but rather referred to Trump as an "old lunatic." This mischaracterization was reported by The Guardian.

President Trump has been advocating for global pressure against North Korea's nuclear weapons program during his Asia trip. In a speech delivered in South Korea's National Assembly on Tuesday, he warned, "Do not underestimate us. And do not try us... The weapons you're acquiring are not making you safer, they are putting your regime in grave danger."

In response, North Korea's Foreign Ministry stated, "Reckless remarks by an old lunatic like Trump will never scare us or stop our advance. On the contrary, all this makes us more sure that our choice to promote economic construction at the same time as building up our nuclear force is all the more righteous, and it pushes us to speed up the effort to complete our nuclear force."

At a news conference in Vietnam on Sunday, Trump expressed a hope for friendship with Kim Jong-un, stating, "That might be a strange thing to happen but it's a possibility... If it did happen it could be a good thing, I can tell you, for North Korea, but it could also be good for a lot of other places and be good for the rest of the world."

Trump and Kim have a history of exchanging insults and threats amidst escalating tensions over Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programs. North Korea conducted its sixth and most powerful nuclear bomb test on September 3, prompting another round of UN sanctions.

As of now, it remains to be seen how these exchanges will unfold. It is crucial to approach such developments with a nuanced understanding, recognizing the complexities and potential dangers of the situation, but also avoiding speculation and fear-mongering.

Title: Senate Democrats Break from Obama on Key Issues

Article:

Senate Democrats have been publicly criticizing President Barack Obama on several key issues, deviating from their usual support of the president's legislative agenda. From trade to Iran sanctions, the Keystone XL pipeline, Obamacare, the National Security Agency, and energy policy, Senate Democrats have shown an unusual willingness to criticize the president, with minimal concerns about repercussions from the White House.

Last week, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada rejected a bill to fast-track trade deals that is strongly backed by the White House, working against Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus of Montana, who has been tapped to be the president's ambassador to China.

Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) commented on the discontent among Democrats, referring to their criticism as similar to that of the Senate GOP campaign arm's aggressive anti-Obama messaging. Discontented Democrats like Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia have criticized Obama's energy policies and his statements during his State of the Union speech.

The criticism from some lawmakers is predictable, with Democrats from energy-producing states criticizing the administration's energy policies and red-state Democrats up for reelection in 2014 concerned about Obamacare fallout. However, not all the criticism is coming from expected quarters, with liberal Democrats decrying NSA surveillance programs.

Sen. Martin Heinrich (D-N.M.), a persistent critic of the White House on NSA policy, stated, "I think the framers did an incredible job of finding the right balance, so, we've gotten away from that. And when we get back to that, my outspokenness will diminish."

The rifts between Senate Democrats and the White House might represent poor message coordination and a White House that does not keep Capitol Hill in the loop. President Barack Obama does not have close personal relationships with most Democratic lawmakers, and his legislative affairs shop was criticized until the recent addition of longtime Hill staffer Katie Beirne Fallon.

Sen. Mary Landrieu (D-La.) of Obama's outreach to Democratic senators commented, "This White House has been very, how shall I say, it's not their strong suit to give anybody a heads-up on anything." Landrieu was angered recently by a surprise Statement of Administration Policy ripping her flood insurance bill, which would ease rate increases that would disproportionately hit flood-prone Louisiana. Obama's aides indicated the bill is not sound fiscal policy, though they notably did not threaten a veto of her bill.

Landrieu stated, "I believe in many of the principles of the Democratic Party. But I stay focused on the issues that are important to Louisiana. And when the president is for Louisiana, I'm for the president. When he's not, I'm not."

Title: Media Bias in Identifying Party Affiliation of Scandal-Plagued Governors

Article:

In the wake of former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell's indictment on 14 charges, including conspiracy and fraud, the three major network morning shows, NBC, ABC, and CBS, immediately identified McDonnell as a Republican. This contrasts with the media's response to a similar scandal involving a Democratic governor, Elliot Spitzer of New York, in 2008.

In the McDonnell case, NBC's Today host Savannah Guthrie introduced the segment by stating, "And now to that bombshell indictment of the former governor of Virginia, Bob McDonnell, a one-time rising star in the Republican Party." ABC provided an on-screen graphic identifying McDonnell as a Republican, and CBS This Morning's Nancy Cordes noted that "McDonnell was once considered a possible presidential contender for the GOP."

In contrast, during the Spitzer scandal, ABC and NBC failed to label Spitzer as a Democrat for two straight days in their lead stories. In 2008, my colleague Brent Baker noted that neither ABC's World News nor the NBC Nightly News verbally identified Spitzer's political party. On ABC, the only hints as to Spitzer's party were a few seconds of video of Spitzer beside Hillary Clinton as they walked down some steps and a (D) on screen by Spitzer's name over part of one soundbite. NBC did not even do that.

In total, NBC and CBS referenced McDonnell's Republican affiliation three times by name, whereas it took ABC three days to identify Spitzer as a Democrat in 2008, and even longer for NBC to do so. In fact, in 2008, both ABC and NBC found time to "applaud his [Elliot Spitzer] reputation and effectiveness as the Empire State's Attorney General before becoming Governor." In contrast, both CBS and NBC noted how McDonnell is "the first Virginia governor ever to be charged with a crime and the charges he's facing carry the possibility of decades behind bars."

CBS's Nancy Cordes hyped how, "It was not that long ago that McDonnell was considered a rising Republican star and possible presidential candidate in 2016," and ABC's Josh Elliott said McDonnell was "once considered a possible presidential candidate." In contrast, in the first two days following the Spitzer scandal, NBC's Today ran seven Spitzer-related segments and one interview with then-candidate Barak Obama, without once mentioning Spitzer's Democratic affiliation.

While both governors were embroiled in highly politicized scandals, the networks have made a concerted effort to let their viewers know when a Republican is in trouble but punt when it comes to identifying a Democrat. This practice by ABC, NBC, and CBS is nothing new and they will likely continue to rush to identify Republicans plagued in scandal while giving Democrats a pass.

Title: Michigan Barber Compares Governor's Lockdown to Holocaust, Defies Shutdown Orders

Article:

Michigan barber Karl Manke, who has gained national attention for defying Democratic Governor Gretchen Whitmer's coronavirus shutdown orders and subsequently having his license suspended, compared Whitmer's lockdown to the Holocaust during a protest in Lansing on Wednesday.

During "Operation Haircut," a protest inspired by Manke that featured barbers and stylists giving free haircuts in defiance of Whitmer's social distancing requirements, Manke spoke to demonstrators on the steps of the state Capitol. State police cited a number of barbers and stylists for their actions, according to MLive.

In his speech, Manke referenced a novel he wrote about the Holocaust that included factual accounts of Jews being tricked by Nazis to enter cattle cars, which took them to death camps. Manke stated, "I refuse to get into a cattle car!" He added, "I will not stand down. I will continue my work with or without a license."

A Court of Appeals panel has ruled that a judge should hold a hearing on the state's motion to temporarily close Manke's barbershop in Owosso and decide on the request by the end of the day Thursday, according to the Detroit News. It is unclear if Manke was among those who received citations.

Governor Whitmer stated earlier this week that it is "unlikely" that barbers, salons, and personal care services would reopen when the stay-at-home order expires on May 28, according to MLive. Republican state Sen. Kevin Daley received a haircut from barber Suzanne Dodoro during the demonstration, stating, "We need to support the people making a living. We need to save life, but we need to save livelihood, too."

Title: Tight Race for Congress Control: Democrats and Republicans Face Fundraising Challenges

Article:

The race for control of the U.S. Congress is currently extremely close, with Democrats facing potential crushing defeats due to a wave of Republican funding, unless something changes before midnight. However, Republicans are also struggling to defend themselves against Democrats who are outraising them.

In the lead-up to Tuesday's federal elections, both parties are urging supporters to donate money to level the playing field with the other side's relentless funding from billionaire donors. This political environment, characterized by pessimism, has become a common theme in fundraising emails from both parties.

Historically, gloominess has been associated with the Democratic Party, but this time around, even Republican strategists like Karl Rove, who is known for his optimistic fundraising appeals, have adopted a more pessimistic tone. In an email to National Republican Senatorial Committee donors, Rove wrote that the midterm environment is toxic for Democrats, but there is a chance that Republicans may not take the Senate. He attributed this to the Democrats' significant fundraising advantage.

The desperation for funds is not limited to emails. Both parties are using data selectively to prove that they are losing the cash race. For instance, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has warned that billionaire donors like the Koch brothers are trying to buy the election, while the Kochs have insisted that super-rich liberals have a better political machine.

Republicans, despite forecasts showing they are likely to win major victories, are also resorting to desperate rhetoric. Mitt Romney, in a fundraising email for the National Republican Congressional Committee, stated that Republicans are being beaten up and cannot defend themselves due to the Democrats' outraising them.

The analysis of the most recent FEC reports by ███ shows that among the groups reporting the biggest political ad spending in 2014, the 15 top Democrat-aligned committees that disclose their donors have outraised the 15 top Republican ones $453 million to $289 million in the 2014 cycle. This contrasts with the recent Democratic Party fundraising emails that suggest the opposite.

In a Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee email last week, signed by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, it was stated that Democrats are facing opposition unlike anything they've seen, with right-wing billionaires going all out to buy the Republican election. The email further stated that the only way to withstand this barrage of corporate interest attacks is with supporters' donations. Two days later, a missive from the Democratic Governors Association lamented polls showing Democrats slipping, Republicans hammering them with brutal attacks, and a lack of funds to fight back.

Title: Three Police Officers Killed, Several Wounded in Baton Rouge Shooting

Article:

Three police officers were shot dead and several others wounded in Baton Rouge, Louisiana on Sunday, according to the city's mayor, Kip Holden. The incident occurred as the country remains on edge following recent police shootings of black men and the killings of five Dallas officers.

The Baton Rouge Police Department issued a brief statement, indicating that they do not believe the shooting was race-related. The officers were responding to a call of shots fired when they were ambushed by at least one gunman, Mayor Holden told NBC News.

One suspect is dead, and police are using a robot to check the shooting scene for potential explosives, Baton Rouge Police spokesman L'Jean Mckneely said. Authorities are seeking more than one suspect and have asked the public to be on the lookout for individuals dressed in black and carrying long guns.

Earlier, a spokesman for the East Baton Rouge Sheriff's Office stated that police and sheriff's deputies were involved in the shooting incident, which occurred around 9 a.m. local time. Multiple officers from both agencies sustained injuries and were transported to local hospitals, according to the spokesman, with no firm numbers available on the number of officers hurt or the extent of their injuries.

The scene of the shootings is still active, and police have warned residents to stay away from the area, near Airline Highway, which is a mile from the Baton Rouge Police Department headquarters, where dozens of protesters were arrested earlier this month. Two nearby hospitals were reportedly on lockdown, but efforts to confirm this report were not immediately successful.

It is unclear whether there is a link between Sunday's shootings and the recent unrest over police killings of black men in Baton Rouge and Minnesota. A wave of protests against police violence in Baton Rouge and other cities erupted after Alton Sterling, a 37-year-old African-American father of five, was shot and killed by law enforcement officers on July 5.

In Dallas, a gunman opened fire on white officers during a protest against Sterling's killing and a similar incident in Minnesota, resulting in the deaths of five officers. The Black Lives Matter civil rights movement has called for police to end racial profiling, bringing the issue to national attention ahead of the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election.

The Justice Department, which has opened a federal probe into Sterling's death, declined to comment on Sunday's shootings. President Barack Obama has been briefed on the shooting of police officers in Baton Rouge and will be updated throughout the day, according to a White House official. The official added that the White House has also been in contact with local officials and has offered assistance.

Social media posts from Baton Rouge Police Chief David O. Brown and CNN correspondent Sara Sidner indicate that the situation remains active and fluid. The Associated Press, TODAY, CNN International, Al Jazeera News, Breaking News, and other news outlets are providing updates as more information becomes available.

Title: Major Corporations Pledge Carbon Neutrality and More Ambitious Emissions Reduction Targets

Article:

A growing number of major corporations, including Delta Air Lines, BP, Microsoft, Ikea, and Blackrock, are making lofty climate promises, with some vowing to not only become carbon neutral but to actively reduce carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. This trend is not limited to a few headline-grabbing outliers, as more companies are disclosing their carbon emissions and setting emissions reduction targets, according to the global nonprofit CDP (formerly the Carbon Disclosure Project).

The intensity of these commitments is rising, according to Engie Impact, a sustainability company tied to a French energy group. Companies are promising faster action, with the average time horizon now just eight years away, compared to 25 years in the past. The number of Fortune 500 companies with concrete, ambitious carbon targets has quadrupled in the past four years, to 23%.

The increase in activity comes after decades of pressure from environmental advocates and despite a lack of action from the U.S. government. The effects of climate change are becoming clearer to companies as wildfires, rising sea levels, droughts, and other symptoms of the crisis make headlines and affect business operations.

Solar and wind energy have also become significantly cheaper, making it easier for some companies to commit to shifting away from fossil fuels. Pressure from investors, customers, and the general public is mounting, with investors increasingly asking companies about their climate policies, and public awareness and concern growing more intense.

Employees and children are also playing a role in pushing companies to take action. Workers at companies such as Amazon are pushing their bosses to change, and some other companies see this as a way to attract and retain talent. Kyum Kim, the co-founder of the app Blind, where tech workers discuss their workplaces, says that half his users say a company's climate policy affects whether they want to work there.

Microsoft's chief sustainability officer, Lucas Joppa, says it helps to frame climate action as an accounting problem, based on quantifying exactly how much companies emit and how much they'll need to cut. "That really is what I see flip executives' mindsets around, is to just talk about this in terms that they understand... a climate 'budget,'" Joppa says. "At the end of the day, what companies are really good at doing is making decisions based on numbers."

However, setting a carbon budget is one thing, sticking to it is another. Some climate announcements in the past, such as BP's previous rebranding as "Beyond Petroleum," have been more PR push than actual shift in strategy, and advocates agree that follow-through and accountability will be essential if these new ambitious targets are to have an impact.

Some experts also caution that relying on big corporations to drive the fight against climate change can be dangerous, as vulnerable and marginalized communities need to have input in how the world fights climate change and feel the benefits of a switch to green energy. Shalanda Baker, a professor at Northeastern University who studies the social justice dimensions of a transition away from fossil fuels, says that corporate action can be powerful but that government policy can make sure vulnerable populations are protected.

In conclusion, major corporations are making lofty climate promises and setting more ambitious emissions reduction targets. The increase in activity comes after decades of pressure from environmental advocates and despite a lack of action from the U.S. government. Solar and wind energy have become significantly cheaper, making it easier for some companies to commit to shifting away from fossil fuels. Pressure from investors, customers, and the general public is mounting, with employees and children also playing a role in pushing companies to take action. However, follow-through and accountability will be essential if these new ambitious targets are to have an impact, and experts caution that relying on big corporations to drive the fight against climate change can be dangerous, as vulnerable and marginalized communities need to have input in how the world fights climate change and feel the benefits of a switch to green energy.

Title: Supreme Court Tightens Election Rules in Multiple States, Sparks Controversy

Article:

The Supreme Court appears to be fine-tuning the rules for the 2014 election, with recent decisions affecting early voting, same-day voter registration, and voter ID laws in several states. The high court's actions have sparked debate among legal analysts and judges, with some suggesting that the Court is more concerned with preventing last-minute voter confusion rather than upholding broad voting rights principles.

Over the past three weeks, the Supreme Court has allowed Ohio to cut early voting by a week, let North Carolina end same-day voter registration, and blocked Wisconsin from implementing a new voter ID law. The Court could soon face another request to block a Texas voter ID law from being enforced in the upcoming elections.

In a statement, 5th U.S. Circuit Judge Edith Clement wrote, "The stayed decisions have both upheld and struck down state statutes and affirmed and reversed district court decisions, so the timing of the decisions rather than their merits seems to be the key."

The high court justices who join in the court's actions on such emergency stays typically do not explain the reasoning behind the moves. Ohio State University professor Dan Tokaji suggests that the justices are concerned about last-minute voter confusion.

The tightening of election laws in all the states in question was pursued by Republican-led legislatures and objected to by Democratic and civil rights groups, who argued that it would disenfranchise minorities.

In the Ohio case, the Supreme Court produced a clearly partisan split, with the five GOP appointees voting to allow the state to cut back early voting by a week and the four Democratic appointees preferring to leave in place an appeals court order barring the change.

The North Carolina case, focusing on same-day registration and out-of-precinct voting, resulted in seven justices overturning an appeals court's ban on eliminating those accommodations. Two Democratic appointees, Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Sonia Sotomayor, dissented, noting that the appeals court found that ending those two voting practices "risked significantly reducing opportunities for black voters to exercise the franchise."

On the Wisconsin voter ID case, the high court split 6-3, with the liberal justices restoring the district court's ban on enforcement of the new voter ID requirements in the coming election. The three justices who dissented expressed concern about the absence of notifications on some absentee ballots regarding the need for photo ID.

Title: Republican Party Faces Internal Strife Amidst Dominant Political Control

Article:

The Republican Party, currently holding the White House, Senate, House, 34 governorships, and controlling 26 state legislatures, is experiencing internal strife despite its dominant position across the United States. This is not the party's "golden age," as the New York Times reports, due to attacks from various factions within the party, voter discontent, and disillusioned donors.

Since 1980, the Republican Party has adopted a policy of "radicalism for the win," which has led to the party being overtaken by Reagan's supply-side economics, Newt Gingrich's constant attacks on the system, the Tea Party's war on compromise, and now Donald Trump's cult of hate. This has resulted in a party that seeks out the worst in its candidates and demands disunity.

Recent events have further highlighted the party's internal struggles. Last week, Senate Republicans lost one of their own when Roy S. Moore, the former state judge, defeated Senator Luther Strange in an Alabama Senate runoff. The retirement of Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee has sparked a potentially contentious fight for his seat, with Governor Bill Haslam, the establishment's preferred successor, declining to run. Additionally, a House Republican, Tim Murphy of Pennsylvania, was forced to resign this week following the public disclosure of a text from his mistress in which she mocked him for his staunch opposition to abortion while pressuring her to terminate a pregnancy.

While stories about "Democrats in disarray" have been common, the Republican Party is currently in disarray due to the proliferation of bomb-throwers within the party, with most members willing to attack other Republicans. This internal strife comes as Democrats are reportedly seeking unity in policy and are reluctant to line up under any leadership.

Title: Republican Viewership of Late-Night Talk Shows: Colbert Lags Behind Kimmel, Fallon

Article:

According to a new survey by The Hollywood Reporter, Stephen Colbert's CBS show, "The Late Show," has a viewership that more closely reflects his former Comedy Central audience, with Democrats, atheists, and men being more likely to tune in. In contrast, Republican viewers have largely abandoned Colbert, with only 17% of his viewers identifying as Republican, the smallest margin among the three major broadcast late-night shows.

ABC's "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" has a higher percentage of Republican viewers at 33%, creating a 16-point gap between Colbert and Kimmel. The ideological split between Colbert's viewership is more pronounced, with 47% of his viewers identifying as Democrats, the highest margin among the three. Kimmel's viewership, on the other hand, shows a virtually nonexistent ideological split, with 34% Democrats and 33% Republicans. NBC's "The Tonight Show" host, Jimmy Fallon, has a slightly larger percentage of Republican viewers at 36%, compared to 31% Democrats.

Pollster Jon Penn explained that Colbert's audience is predominantly made up of wealthy, socially liberal men who support legalizing marijuana and want Bernie Sanders to be president. He described Kimmel's viewers as "conservative-leaning," Colbert's viewers as "liberal-leaning," and Fallon's fan base as "swing." Interestingly, Fallon attracts the most female viewers, while 30% of Colbert's viewers describe themselves as atheist, the top "religion category" choice for "The Late Show" viewers.

In the overall poll, Fallon beats out both Colbert and Kimmel by a 2-to-1 margin when viewers were asked which of the hosts is an "unpredictable, cool dude you want to be friends with." However, Colbert's liberal appeal may be limiting his wider audience growth. According to Mediaite, over the first six weeks since launching, Colbert beat Kimmel by an impressive 40% in the demo, but by the first week of November, there was a dramatic 45% swing in Kimmel's favor.

Title: Federal Judge Rules NSA Bulk Collection of Phone Records Likely Unconstitutional

Article:

A U.S. District Court Judge, Richard Leon, has ruled that the National Security Agency's (NSA) bulk collection of phone records likely violates the Constitution, marking a significant setback for the controversial spy agency. The ruling was granted in a preliminary injunction sought by plaintiffs Larry Klayman and Charles Strange, but the decision has been stayed pending appeal.

In his 68-page opinion, Judge Leon concluded that the two men are likely to be able to show that their privacy interests outweigh the government's interest in collecting the data. He ruled that the massive collection program is an unreasonable search under the Constitution's Fourth Amendment, which typically requires a neutral and detached authority between the police and the public.

Judge Leon wrote, "I can not imagine a more 'indiscriminate' and 'arbitrary invasion' than this systematic and high-tech collection and retention of personal data on virtually every single citizen for purposes of querying and analyzing it without prior judicial approval." He added that such a program infringes on "that degree of privacy" enshrined in the Fourth Amendment.

The Obama administration has defended the program as a crucial tool against terrorism, but Judge Leon concluded that the government did not cite a single instance in which the program "actually stopped an imminent terrorist attack." He expressed doubts about the efficacy of the metadata collection program in conducting time-sensitive investigations in cases involving imminent threats of terrorism.

An order was entered to bar the government from collecting "any telephony metadata associated with their personal Verizon accounts" and requiring the government to "destroy any such metadata in its possession" collected through the program. The judge stayed his ruling pending appeal "in light of the significant national security interests at stake in this case and the novelty of the constitutional issues."

The Justice Department released a brief statement after the decision, stating, "We believe the program is constitutional as previous judges have found. We have no further comment at this time." Former NSA contractor Edward Snowden, who exposed secrets about the NSA's data collection over the summer, released a statement praising the decision.

Title: Bipartisan Bills Introduced to Strengthen U.S. Cybersecurity and Election Security

Article:

The United States is facing ongoing cyberattacks from foreign adversaries, including China, Iran, North Korea, and Russia, targeting its electoral processes. These attacks have involved hacking election systems, disseminating propaganda online, funneling money into elections through opaque groups, and hiring unregistered lobbyists.

In the 2016 election cycle, Russian-affiliated hackers attempted to access election systems in all 50 states. Since 2018, Twitter has removed at least 14,000 accounts tied to foreign influence operations by Venezuela, Russia, Iran, and others.

The attacks are a threat to the nation's security posture, and the government has yet to address them effectively due to political division in Washington. Even the largest social media platforms, such as Facebook, have admitted that they do not have all the tools to stop foreign actors.

Congress has passed piecemeal legislation to address these cyberattacks, but there are still significant gaps that need to be filled. To strengthen the country's cybersecurity armor, bipartisan bills have been introduced.

For instance, Sens. James Lankford (R-Okla.) and Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) have championed the Secure Elections Act, which aims to strengthen voting systems while clarifying each individual state's role in administering federal elections.

Another bill, the Defending Elections from Threats by Establishing Redlines (DETER) Act, has been proposed by Klobuchar and Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.). The DETER Act would impose sanctions on foreign countries that interfere in U.S. elections.

The Honest Ads Act, re-introduced by Klobuchar and Sens. Mark Warner (D-Va.) and Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), would subject online political ads to rules modeled on those in place for television and radio, in an attempt to safeguard U.S. politics from foreign disinformation campaigns.

While these bills represent a first step toward ensuring that foreign adversaries will no longer attempt to influence the elections that represent the very heart of our democracy, cybersecurity failures are also crippling the underlying infrastructure of the economy.

In 2021, aggressive strains of ransomware infiltrated Atlanta and Baltimore's digital infrastructure, causing complete stops in their online operations. Members of Congress have recognized this pervasive issue but have expressed concerns about the federal government's role in addressing it.

The need for a bold, comprehensive plan that both parties can get behind to protect the nation's citizens, companies, governments, and democracy is urgent. Millions of Americans saw disinformation during the 2016 election produced by Russian agents, and China hacked into the Federal Election Commission, crashing the databases that track how money is both raised and spent during elections.

The U.S. faces a national security emergency, and its greatest institutions are under siege. Overcoming partisan politics and working together to protect the nation and the integrity of its elections is crucial. This is a chance for the nation's leaders to take up the mantle and defend, honor, and protect America for all of us today and for future generations.

Title: Former President Jimmy Carter Calls for Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp's Resignation

Article:

Former President Jimmy Carter has urged Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp to resign from his position overseeing the state's elections in a personal plea. Carter's appeal was made in a letter dated last Monday and was first obtained by The Associated Press. The contents of the letter were confirmed to NPR by a spokesperson for the Carter Center, the former president's organization devoted partly to monitoring democratic elections across the world.

In his letter to Kemp, Carter cited his decades of experience assisting elections abroad as the reason for his intervention in the bitter dispute now roiling the Georgia gubernatorial race. Kemp has been under fire for deciding to purge tens of thousands of voters from the voter rolls, months after declaring his intent to run for governor.

Carter wrote, "In Georgia's upcoming gubernatorial election, popular confidence is threatened not only by the undeniable racial discrimination of the past and the serious questions that the federal courts have raised about the security of Georgia's voting machines, but also because you are now overseeing the election in which you are a candidate."

Carter further stated, "This runs counter to the most fundamental principle of democratic elections—that the electoral process be managed by an independent and impartial election authority."

Carter is not the only prominent figure to raise concerns about Kemp's role as both candidate and referee in next week's election, and last year's voter purge is not the only move that has gotten Kemp embroiled in controversy.
