An APM Reports investigation found that removals have spiked during Kemp's tenure overseeing Georgia's election process. More than 1.6 million names were removed from the state's rolls in the past decade, including his eight years in office.

Additionally, a half-dozen civil rights groups recently sued the secretary of state over the delay of some 53,000 voter registration applications, which his office has placed on hold citing questions about the applicants' citizenship status. According to the AP, nearly 70 percent of those pending registrations came from African-Americans.

Kemp's Democratic opponent, Stacey Abrams, is seeking to become the first black female governor in U.S. history. The civil rights groups suing Kemp allege that the protocol will have a discriminatory impact on African-American, Latino, and Asian-American applicants and will impose severe burdens on voting-eligible Georgians' fundamental right to vote that are not justified by any rational or compelling state interest.

Kemp has denied wrongdoing and has dismissed previous calls for him to step down as secretary of state. He says his office's actions are squarely in line with a state protocol known as "exact match," which requires that information supplied on voter registration forms line up precisely with the applicant's Social Security and driving records. Errors such as misspellings or the use of nicknames can result in delayed processing under the law passed last year.

In response to Carter's letter, a Kemp spokesman blamed Abrams for "trying to distract voters with another publicity stunt." Campaign Communications Director Ryan Mahoney said in a statement, "It's sad that she's using the former president to do her dirty work."

A federal district judge held an emergency hearing on the matter Monday. The civil rights groups suing want the judge to order more election workers eligible to check those documents so things run smoother, according to Johnny Kauffman of Atlanta member station WABE.

Carter did not get too deep into specifics in his personal appeal to Kemp. Rather, the former president laid out his argument as a broad plea to ensure the stability of Georgia's electoral process. "In order to foster voter confidence in the upcoming election, which will be especially important if the race ends up very close, I urge you to step aside and hand over to a neutral authority the responsibility of overseeing the governor's election," Carter said. "This would not address every concern, but it would be a sign that you recognize the importance of this key democratic principle and want to ensure the confidence of our citizens in the outcome."

Title: Acting Homeland Security Secretary Anticipates 25% Drop in Border Apprehensions in June

Article:

Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan announced on Friday that the government expects a significant drop in illegal immigrant border apprehensions by up to 25% in June compared to May. McAleenan attributed the decrease to a deal President Donald Trump struck with Mexico and a new policy that requires asylum seekers to wait in Mexico until their court hearings in the U.S.

"It's become clear that over the past three weeks, since the administration reached a new agreement with Mexico, we've seen a substantial increase in the number of interdictions on the Mexican southern border and a sincere effort to address the transportation networks coming through Mexico," McAleenan said at a news conference.

McAleenan explained that the 25% decrease in June is more significant than what has been observed in past years. In May, immigration authorities apprehended 144,000 illegal immigrants, the highest single-month number since 2006.

However, NBC News reported that the projected decrease in border apprehensions could be attributed to summer conditions, as it is typical for border crossings to decrease during the summer months. McAleenan rejected this claim, stating that this year's May to June decrease is more significant than previous years.

McAleenan cautioned that officials will not know until the end of July whether their efforts "are sustained and having a significant impact."

During the press conference, McAleenan also addressed allegations that migrant children are not being properly cared for at detainment centers. "Contrary to the reporting, children in CBP custody at the border are receiving access to key supplies, including toothbrushes, appropriate meals, blankets, showers as soon as they can be provided, and medical screening," he claimed.

Title: Election 2016: Anxiety, Anger, and the American Voter

Article:

This week, National Public Radio (NPR) and several of its member stations will be gauging the sentiments of voters across the country. Follow their coverage on Twitter at the provided links.

The mood of the electorate in the 2016 election year is characterized by anxiety, fear, and anger. Candidates from both major parties are attempting to demonstrate their understanding of these emotions.

On the Democratic side, Bernie Sanders' fiery critiques of Wall Street have resonated with voters (for more on this, see NPR's report by Brian Naylor). Hillary Clinton frequently discusses the fears and insecurities of average voters.

On the Republican side, no candidate has tapped into or fueled voter anger as effectively as Donald Trump. In the latest Republican debate, Trump declared, "I will gladly accept the mantle of anger."

There are several reasons for this widespread voter discontent. Here are some key factors:

1. Economic Growth: The absence of broad-based economic growth that enables the American dream is a significant concern. Bill Galston, a former Clinton White House aide, explained, "People have gone a long time without making a lot of progress. They know it, they're feeling it, and they're not very happy about it."

2. Terrorism: The December attack in San Bernardino, California, brought the war on terrorism to American soil, causing widespread fear.

3. Demographic Change: In 2014, the majority of American kindergarteners were minorities, according to Harvard political scientist Danielle Allen. This demographic shift is causing tension, particularly in discussions about immigration.

4. Immigration: Immigration has become a contentious issue, particularly in the Republican primaries. According to immigration expert Roberto Suro of the University of Southern California, it is not specific immigrants or immigration itself that voters are angry about, but rather it serves as a conduit for anxieties about jobs, terrorism, and government inefficiency.

5. Gridlocked Politics: The inability of the political system to address major issues is exacerbating voter anxiety.

6. Elite Dissatisfaction: Voters in both parties are angry at elites, but their targets differ. For Republicans, the focus is on government and professional experts, while for Democrats, and more left-leaning Democrats, the focus is on economic and financial elites.

The extent to which these angry anti-elitist sentiments will influence the primary elections remains to be seen. Elections serve as a mirror to society, reflecting the feelings and desires of the electorate. The 2016 elections are being defined by these feelings of anger and anxiety.

Title: Family of British Teen Killed in Car Crash Meets President Trump, Calls for Diplomat's Wife to Return to UK

Article:

The parents of Harry Dunn, a British teenager killed in a car crash with a US diplomat's wife, met with President Donald Trump at the White House on Tuesday. The meeting was arranged to push for the waiving of diplomatic immunity for the American woman, Anne Sacoolas, to seek justice for their son.

Harry Dunn was 19 when he was killed in an August accident. He was riding his motorcycle on the correct side of the road when the 42-year-old diplomat's wife, who has been widely named as Anne Sacoolas, drove out of the RAF Croughton US Air Force base onto the wrong side of the road and hit the teen head-on, according to Sky News.

Sacoolas claimed diplomatic immunity and fled the UK earlier this October, despite initially telling police she would cooperate with the investigation, police said. Many are now calling for Sacoolas to return to the UK so the investigation can continue.

In an interview with BBC, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed hope that Anne Sacoolas would return and engage with the UK's legal processes. Sacoolas has not yet spoken publicly about the incident and could not be immediately reached by the media.

Dunn's parents have been pleading for justice for their son, directly asking for Trump to send Sacoolas back to the UK. In an interview with Sky News, Charlotte Charles, Dunn's mother, said, "President Trump, please listen. We’re a family in ruin. We’re broken. We can’t grieve. Please, please, let her get back on a plane. Come back to the UK."

On Tuesday, the parents visited the White House to make that plea to Trump in person. They said they did not know Sacoolas was in the next room, waiting for Trump to introduce them. The White House press secretary, Stephanie Grisham, said the meeting between Trump and the Dunns was held "at the request of Prime Minister Boris Johnson."

Grisham added, "The President met with members of the Dunn family to personally offer his condolences for the loss of their son." According to Grisham, Trump's intent was to comfort the victims of the tragic accident.

Speaking to reporters outside the White House, Charles said, "The bombshell was dropped" by Trump that "Anne Sacoolas was in the building and was willing to meet with us." The Dunn family said they refused the meeting but said they "would still love to meet with her but it has to be on our terms and on UK soil."

On Wednesday, Trump confirmed to reporters that he had arranged the meeting, saying he had "offered to bring the person in question in, and they were not ready for it." Trump added that accidents like the one that killed Harry Dunn are common for visiting Americans because "the roads are opposite."

"That happens in Europe, you go to Europe and the roads are opposite. It's very tough if you're from the United States," Trump said. "That happens to a lot of people, by the way."

Title: California Files Lawsuit Against Trump Administration Over New Visa Rule Affecting International Students

Article:

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra announced on Thursday that the state had filed a lawsuit against the Trump administration over a new visa rule that requires international students to leave the United States if all their classes are online. The lawsuit, which is supported by the California State University system (CSU) and California Community Colleges officials, claims the rule unfairly harms international students and puts them, teachers, other students, and the community at large at risk of getting and spreading the coronavirus or being subject to deportation.

In a statement, Becerra said, "Shame on the Trump Administration for risking not only the education opportunities for students who earned the chance to go to college, but now their health and well-being as well." He added, "Not on our watch...Today's lawsuit rests on America's enduring principle that everyone who works hard and plays by the rules can earn a chance to get ahead. We'll see the Trump Administration in court."

Cal State schools plan to mainly hold online classes in the fall due to the virus, according to The Los Angeles Times. CSU Chancellor Timothy White called the policy "callous and inflexible," adding it places thousands of international students into an "extremely difficult position."

In a letter to Acting Homeland Security Secretary Chad Wolf, Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, called for the extension of an exemption adopted by ICE in March through the end of the 2020-2021 school year. The ICE exemption allowed international students with F-1 visas to attend classes online while retaining their visa status.

Under the new policy, F-1 and M-1 visa holders "must depart the country or take other measures, such as transferring to a school with in-person instruction to remain in lawful status," Immigration and Customs Enforcement said in a statement, according to NBC News. The rules would also hurt colleges already struggling financially amid the outbreak since many colleges rely on international student tuition. California has more students on international visas than any other state, NBC reported.

The lawsuit seeks an injunction to block the policy and separately, the University of California plans to seek a restraining order as well. Becerra said it is the 86th lawsuit he's filed against the administration.

Title: Georgia Governor Primary Runoff: Kemp and Cagle Battle for Trump's Conservative Endorsement

Article:

Georgia voters will choose between two Trump-backing candidates, Brian Kemp and Casey Cagle, in the Republican primary runoff for governor on Tuesday. The race has been marked by a series of secretly recorded tapes, eye-catching advertisements, and an unexpected endorsement from President Trump.

Brian Kemp, who has described himself as a "politically incorrect conservative," made headlines in May for running an advertisement that boasted about having a pick-up truck "in case I need to round up criminal illegals." Trump endorsed Kemp last week, surprising the candidate who was in a press conference at the time.

Kemp stated to a media outlet on Monday that Georgia is a solid-red state that needs an "unapologetic conservative." He described Trump's endorsement as "huge" and compared it to "pouring gasoline on a fire."

Lt. Gov. Casey Cagle's candidacy has been affected by the release of several furtively-recorded audio tapes, including one in which Cagle allegedly offered to help pay off former gubernatorial candidate Clay Tippins' $300,000 in campaign debt in exchange for an endorsement. Cagle denied the allegations, stating he never offered a bribe for any reason and expressed frustration with "antics" in the race.

In another secretly recorded tape, Cagle seemed to disparage some of his constituents, saying the race was about "who had the biggest gun, who had the biggest truck, and who would be the craziest."

Vice President Mike Pence made his presence felt in the race, headlining a rally for Kemp, whom he called "tough on crime" and "strong on borders." Pence's appearance in Georgia followed a stop earlier in the day in Tennessee, where Pence touted Republican tax cuts and campaigned with two GOP congresswomen waging tough campaigns for statewide offices.

The winner of Tuesday's Republican contest will face Democrat Stacey Abrams in the general election in November. Abrams is seeking to become the first black female governor in the U.S.

Title: Democrats Focus on Presidential Abuse of Power and Obstruction of Congress in Impeachment Articles

Article:

Democrats in the United States House of Representatives have reportedly decided to focus on a straightforward case of presidential abuse of power and obstruction of Congress in the articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump. The decision to keep the impeachment charges simple is an attempt to make the case easy to understand.

The alleged abuse of power involves President Trump using the foreign policy tools at his disposal for personal political gain, specifically in the Ukraine controversy. The obstruction of Congress charges stem from the president's denial of relevant documents and witness testimony during the investigation.

The Democrats argue that the security of the 2020 presidential election and the protection of congressional authority as a co-equal branch of government are at stake. The main script for the impeachment process appears to involve a quick vote in the Judiciary Committee, followed by a vote on the floor of the House of Representatives, leading to presidential impeachment and a Senate trial.

In the meantime, Congressional Democrats are expected to approve President Trump's renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement, a move that has caused consternation among some liberals. The impeachment process is currently surrounded by a fever of allegations and accusations, including claims of intelligence agency misconduct in the investigation of 2016 Trump-Russia ties, presidential Twitter barbs at the FBI director, and criminal investigations of the president's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani.

While the main script for the impeachment process may be clear, the underlying unpredictability is the only predictable result.

Title: Trump Doubles Down on Threat to Strike Iranian Cultural Sites

Article:

President Donald Trump has reiterated his threat to target Iranian cultural heritage sites, asserting that the U.S. has the right to do so. In comments to White House pool reporters, Trump dismissed criticism from human rights organizations, stating that such an action would not be considered a war crime under international law.

Trump's remarks follow tweets on Saturday threatening to attack sites "at a very high level & important to Iran & the Iranian culture" should Iranian-backed forces strike U.S. civilians or military targets in the Middle East in retaliation for the death of Gen. Qassem Soleimani, the head of Iran's Quds Force, in a U.S. airstrike.

Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif responded in his own tweet, warning that such strikes would violate international law. "Having committed grave breaches of int'l law in Friday's cowardly assassinations, @realDonaldTrump threatens to commit again new breaches of JUS COGENS," Zarif tweeted. "Targeting cultural sites is a WAR CRIME."

The president's remarks were also criticized by officials at Human Rights Watch, a leading international rights group, which warned that Trump was threatening "war crimes" by insinuating that cultural sites could be targeted. "President Trump should publicly reverse his threats against Iran’s cultural property and make clear that he will not authorize nor order war crimes," Andrea Prasow, acting Washington director at Human Rights Watch, said in a statement. “The US Defense Department should publicly reaffirm its commitment to abide by the laws of war and comply only with lawful military orders."

Title: Former Aides of Senator Max Baucus Assist in Fundraising for Re-election Campaign

Article:

Senator Max Baucus' political career in Montana is reportedly being supported by a number of his former aides, who assist in fundraising activities. These activities include weekend fundraising retreats in Big Sky, Montana, and intimate events in Washington, D.C., such as a gathering last month near the Capitol.

Among the top givers is Jeffrey A. Forbes, a former Finance Committee staff director for Senator Baucus, who has donated at least $25,000 to Senator Baucus, his political action committee, or the Montana Democratic Party. Forbes, who is a partner at a lobbying firm, has donated significantly more when contributions from his clients, including Verizon and Altria, are included.

Paul Wilkins, Senator Baucus' chief of staff, has reportedly emphasized the importance of these donations and fundraising efforts. He stated that the nearly $4.6 million expected in hand by the end of this month would rank Senator Baucus' campaign chest among the top 10 in the Senate.

At a private event, Wilkins thanked former Baucus aides turned lobbyists for their support, noting that the fundraising efforts are "the basis of everything that we do." A New York Times reporter was asked to leave this event.

When asked about his comments later, Wilkins stated, "There is no expectation that former staffers do anything related to the office. They are private individuals, if they want to donate, fine. If they don't want to donate, that is fine, too."

Senator Baucus' office notes that the former aides who now work as tax lobbyists are a small fraction of those who have worked for him over the years. However, several colleagues who have served more than two decades on the finance panel, including Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, have much smaller networks of former aides who are tax lobbyists, according to data collected by LegiStorm and the Center for Responsive Politics.

Title: Obama Accuses Congress of Political Obstruction in Delay of Attorney General Nominee Loretta Lynch

Article:

President Obama has accused Congress of playing politics with law enforcement and national security by delaying the confirmation of Loretta Lynch as Attorney General. In his weekly address to the nation on Sunday, Mr. Obama criticized Republicans for preventing the female federal prosecutor from New York from succeeding Attorney General Eric Holder.

The nomination of Ms. Lynch has been delayed by more than 130 days due to concerns surrounding President Obama's executive action on immigration, which would provide temporary legal status to millions of illegal immigrants and reprieve from deportation. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, is reportedly using the nomination as leverage to pass the Justice for Victims of Trafficking Act, a bill containing language that would prohibit the use of restitution funds for abortions.

President Obama tapped Ms. Lynch to replace Mr. Holder in November, and he has become more vocal about the roadblocks that Republicans have set up for his nominee in recent weeks. Republicans control both the House and the Senate.

"No one can claim she's unqualified," Mr. Obama said during his weekly address. "No one's saying she can't do the job. Senators from both parties say they support her. This is purely about politics."

The White House has previously criticized the delay of Ms. Lynch's confirmation vote, with White House press secretary Josh Earnest describing it as "an unconscionable delay" during a March 16 press briefing.

"There is not a single legitimate question that has been raised about her aptitude for this job," Mr. Earnest said. "Instead, all we've seen is a bunch of political obstruction from Republicans that, again, does not speak well of Republicans' efforts to run the Senate in an effective fashion and certainly not in a way that's in the best interest of the country."

President Obama reiterated this point during an interview with Huffington Post, stating that it was wrong for Congress to hold the attorney general nominee hostage "for other issues."

"Republicans promised that Congress would function smoothly with them in charge," Mr. Obama said during his weekend address. "Here's a small chance for them to prove it."

Title: House Judiciary Committee Intensifies Trump Investigation, Adopts Resolution for Impeachment Proceedings

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee has voted to intensify its investigation of President Donald Trump, adopting a resolution that allows it to designate hearings as impeachment proceedings. The 41-member panel's decision brings the committee closer to deciding whether to recommend Trump's impeachment.

The resolution permits the committee to subject witnesses to more aggressive questioning and quicken the pace of the investigation, which is expanding into areas that could prove politically explosive for both Trump and Congress. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler announced the new procedures after a 24-17 vote along party lines.

"With these new procedures, we will begin next week an aggressive series of hearings investigating allegations of corruption, obstruction, and abuse of power against the president," Nadler told reporters.

The more aggressive probe could increase pressure on House Democratic leaders, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who has resisted impeachment of Trump as a politically risky step for moderate Democratic freshmen from swing districts where ousting the president is an unpopular idea.

Trump responded to the vote with a statement on his Facebook page, stating, "If they go down the path of impeachment they will be dividing the nation! So ridiculous to even be talking about this subject when all of the crimes were committed by the other side."

Trump and his Republican allies argue that former U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe into Russian interference in the 2016 election and the Trump campaign's possible collusion stemmed from an earlier effort to sink his candidacy and later his presidency by former officials at the Justice Department.

Republican lawmakers rejected the notion that the panel was pursuing an impeachment inquiry and dismissed the resolution as a "fantasy" intended to distract from Democrats' unwillingness to have the full House authorize a formal impeachment inquiry, as occurred during the Watergate era and the impeachment of former President Bill Clinton.

Republicans said Democrats lacked the votes to obtain formal House authorization and denounced Thursday's action as a show intended to pander to Democratic voters who want Trump removed from office.

Committee Democrats plan to use the new tactics that allow an hour of questioning by committee lawyers of Corey Lewandowski, a close Trump confidant and one of his campaign managers in 2016. Lewandowski is due to appear before the panel next Tuesday for what may be a contentious hearing.

Democrats expect his testimony to help lay out a charge of obstruction of justice. However, they are also pursuing allegations of campaign finance violations, witness tampering, and unlawful self-enrichment through his business ventures.

Democrats aim to decide by the end of the year whether to recommend articles of impeachment against Trump to the full House. If approved by the chamber, the Republican-controlled Senate would be left to hold a trial and consider the president's ouster.

A head count shows that 135 House Democrats back an impeachment inquiry. While that is a majority of the caucus, the number is well short of the 218 votes needed to pass a resolution. Only two American presidents have been impeached by the House: Andrew Johnson in 1868 and Clinton in 1999. Neither was convicted by the Senate. Nixon resigned in 1974 after the House Judiciary Committee approved articles of impeachment against him, but before the full House voted on the matter.

Title: Federal Court Hears Challenge to Affordable Care Act Subsidy Rule

Article:

In a federal court on Tuesday, the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as ObamaCare, faced another legal challenge as a group of business owners and individuals contested an Internal Revenue Service (IRS) regulation. The plaintiffs argue that the regulation, which determines eligibility for subsidies in connection with health care coverage, is unlawful and potentially crippling.

The contested regulation, stemming from the ACA, defines which applicants are eligible for subsidies based on the state in which they apply. The plaintiffs in Halbig v. Sebelius claim that the plain text of the ACA limits subsidies to applicants in states that have set up their own exchanges.

Sam Kazman, general counsel for the Competitive Enterprise Institute, stated, "Congress figured because it was loading up the state exchanges with a lot of goodies that just about every state would make the choice to participate." However, he noted that dozens of states declined the offer, leading to the IRS and the administration's interpretation that extends attractive subsidies to all states, including those that opted out. This interpretation, according to Kazman, gives rise to both employer and individual mandates and penalties, which are critical to funding the ACA.

The government, which lost its bid to have the case dismissed, argues that the plaintiffs are misreading the statute. In its motion to dismiss filing, the Department of Justice stated, "The plaintiffs' reading of the act is wrong." The government argues that an exchange established by the federal government stands in the shoes of the exchange that a state chooses not to establish.

U.S. District Judge Paul Friedman posed tough questions for both sides during the hearing, including the extent and location of information needed to understand Congress's intent. The plaintiffs argue that the text of the law is sufficient, while the government argues that reading the provision literally and out of context would be nonsensical.

Judge Friedman pledged to deliver a quick ruling, but offered no timeline. The outcome of this case could have significant implications for the implementation and funding of the Affordable Care Act.

Title: The Federal Reserve: A Closer Look at Its Role and Impact on the Economy

Article:

The Federal Reserve, often considered a complex and obscure institution, has been a subject of debate among economists, politicians, and the general public. The Fed, created in 1913, has a significant impact on the economy, and its actions can affect individual savings and future prospects.

Alan Greenspan, a former Fed chairman, admitted to intentionally using ambiguous language, known as "Fedspeak," to avoid unsettling financial markets. Greenspan, who was once a disciple of libertarian Ayn Rand, was known for his clarity in his youth, but his language during his tenure as Fed chairman was far less transparent. His successors, Ben Bernanke and Janet Yellen, are also often criticized for their lack of clarity.

The Fed's balance sheet has grown to an unprecedented $4 trillion, a fact that has raised concerns among some, including Sen. Rand Paul's father, retired Texas Congressman Ron Paul. Paul has argued that the Fed should not have the authority to create money out of thin air. For three decades, Ron Paul was virtually alone in questioning the Fed's role, but in recent times, more voices have emerged to challenge the institution.

Jim Bruce's documentary "Money for Nothing" provides a beginner's guide to the Fed, highlighting how the last two chairmen, appointed by both Republicans and Democrats, have increased central planning of the economy. The documentary argues that the Fed's actions have led to government control of more of the economy than ever before, a situation that is not considered a positive development.

The Fed was initially created to prevent bank runs and provide stability. However, the Fed's low interest rates during the Roaring Twenties led to the Great Stock Market Crash, and its tight money policies worsened the Depression. Despite claims of learning from their mistakes, the Fed's actions have been criticized for creating economic bubbles rather than promoting stability.

The Fed is now tasked with two missions: preserving a stable currency and reducing unemployment. This dual mandate has led to increased pressure on the Fed to make timely decisions to avoid economic downturns and, some argue, to make current political officeholders look good. This focus on the Fed's decisions has led investors and Wall Street analysts to pay more attention to the Fed's actions rather than inventions, productivity, and real wealth-creation.

Critics argue that the Fed, created to support capitalism, has become an instrument of government economic management, similar to a socialist planning board. The Fed's main mission has evolved into continually stimulating economic activity through cash infusions to maintain the illusion of economic stability.

The Fed's actions during the post-recession recovery have been criticized as ineffective, with some comparing it to Japan's central bank, which has attempted the same stimulus strategies for the past 15 years without success. In contrast, Canada, which had no central bank during the Great Depression, fared better, with not a single bank failure during the 1930s.

The massive bank bailouts during the financial crisis are based on the assumption that the banks are "too big to fail." However, critics argue that these banks, along with the Federal Reserve, are too big and powerful, posing a risk to the entire economy if they fail. The concentration of power in a small group of individuals is a concern for many.

In conclusion, the Federal Reserve, created to prevent bank runs and provide stability, has become a subject of debate due to its role in the economy and its impact on individual savings and the future. Critics argue that the Fed's actions have led to economic bubbles rather than promoting stability, and that its dual mandate has led to increased focus on the Fed's decisions rather than real wealth-creation. The debate surrounding the Fed's role and impact on the economy is ongoing.

Title: House Democrats Plan to Invite Guests Affected by White House Policies for Trump's First Congressional Address

Article:

House Democrats are strategizing to make President Donald Trump's first speech to Congress as uncomfortable as possible by inviting guests they believe will be adversely affected by new White House policies. This tactic is a shift from some Democrats who skipped Trump's inauguration last month in protest.

The strategy involves inviting ethnic minorities, LGBT individuals, undocumented immigrants, the disabled, and others to the joint session on Feb. 28. The goal is to place Trump face-to-face with people who feel alienated or targeted by his controversial executive orders.

In a letter circulating on Capitol Hill, a group of liberal Democrats is urging their colleagues to bring guests who have made "a positive impact" on their communities despite discrimination or marginalization. The letter states, "It is our hope that their presence in the House Gallery will remind President Trump that he is not the arbiter of patriotism. This country belongs to all of us, and his rhetoric of intolerance will not stand."

The authors of the letter include Reps. Jim Langevin (D-RI), who was shot accidentally as a teen and became the first quadriplegic to serve in Congress; Michelle Lujan Grisham (D-NM), head of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus; Cedric Richmond (D-LA), chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus; Judy Chu (D-CA), head of the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus; and David Cicilline (D-RI) and Jared Polis (D-CO), the co-chairman of the LGBT Equality Caucus.

Some Democrats are also considering another form of protest during the speech: refusing to shake hands with Trump as he walks down the center aisle of the House chamber on his way to the dais. Representatives Luis Gutiérrez (D-IL) and Filemon Vela (D-TX) have expressed their intention to avoid this tradition.

Trump's campaign rhetoric has been combative from the start, and he has continued this approach in the White House. Most recently, he temporarily banned all refugees from entering the U.S., as well as immigrants from seven Muslim-majority countries. This move sparked an outcry from Democrats and human rights groups, and drew thousands of protestors to airports and streets across the country.

The Democrats aim to maintain this spirit of protest as Trump prepares for his speech to Congress. The Democrats' letter states, "Instead of celebrating the very diversity that makes our country a beacon of inclusion and equality, he has chosen to vilify, bully, and alienate women, immigrants, people of color, people with disabilities, and people of differing faiths." They further assert, "His rhetoric emboldens those who seek a scapegoat for the challenges this country faces."

Title: GOP Senators Urge Trump to Invoke U.N. Snapback Mechanism in Response to Iran's Nuclear Violations

Article:

Three Republican senators have urged President Trump to invoke the "snapback" mechanism in a United Nations resolution that endorsed the 2015 nuclear agreement, in response to Iran's violation of the deal. The senators, Ted Cruz (R-Texas), Tom Cotton (R-Ark.), and Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), wrote a letter on Tuesday, urging Trump to reject what they describe as Iran's "nuclear blackmail."

Iran has recently begun stockpiling low-enriched uranium beyond the agreed limits, in violation of the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). The senators argue that Iran is signaling an intent to creep towards a nuclear weapon while demanding concessions and promising to "reverse" their violations if their demands are met.

The senators' letter comes as Iran's threats to enrich uranium could soon test the process of bringing the snapback mechanism into effect. The mechanism, outlined in United Nations Security Council resolution 2231, would restore sanctions on Iran's uranium enrichment and missile development.

The senators argue that the U.S., as a participant in the resolution, should invoke the snapback mechanism to end civil-nuclear waivers that they claim allow Iran to maintain a nuclear status quo. The preferred mechanism for disputes in the JCPOA is a joint commission of eight members to decide if it goes to the Security Council. However, Tehran's threats to enrich uranium mean the process of bringing the snapback mechanism into effect will likely be tested sooner rather than later.

From 2006 onwards, the United Nations Security Council passed six resolutions that imposed severe sanctions on Iran in an attempt to halt its nuclear ambitions by banning Iran from conducting nuclear research and developing ballistic missiles.

It is unclear how such a move would be received by America's European allies at the Security Council, who opposed the U.S. departure from the deal and have fought to keep the compact intact. Behnam Ben Taleblu, a Senior Fellow at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies in Washington D.C., told Fox News that if the snapback mechanism is used and resolution 2231 is done away with, "it would also mean the Rouhani government's policy of playing both sides of the Atlantic against one another would have failed."

An indication of the interagency discussions came earlier in the week from Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, whose statement on Iran's violation called on the international community to restore its longstanding requirement of not allowing any uranium enrichment for the regime's nuclear program in light of Iran's latest violation. His statement pulled no punches as he noted that "no nuclear deal should ever allow the Iranian regime to enrich uranium at any level."

A senior GOP congressional staffer told Fox News that "snapback is quickly becoming the only game in town, now that Iran has violated the deal." The staffer added that, even though the U.S. left the deal, the administration still has every right per the resolution to put the snapback mechanism into play. "There's no technical reason the Trump administration can't just do it and quickly restore the international sanctions from before the deal," the staffer stated, adding that some officials wanted to hold off while the Europeans negotiated with Iran to stay in bounds. "Now that the Europeans have failed and the Iranians are engaged in nuclear blackmail, there's no reason left to hold off."

Title: Grand Jury Impaneled in Mueller Investigation Fueling Speculation of Widening Scope

Article:

The impaneling of a grand jury by special counsel Robert Mueller has stirred speculation in Washington, D.C., suggesting that the investigation into Russian election meddling is expanding in both scope and gravity. The Wall Street Journal first reported that Mueller, who has amassed a team of 16 prosecutors in recent weeks, now has a dedicated pool of 23 grand jurors tasked with examining subpoenaed documents, listening to witness testimony, and determining whether criminal charges are warranted.

However, a spokesman for the special counsel declined to confirm or deny the existence of the grand jury. Legal experts argue that the development is not unexpected, as a special investigator with broad authority from the Justice Department to probe allegations with proximity to the White House would typically convene a select grand jury.

The grand jury's location in Washington, D.C., is significant because Mueller reportedly already had a grand jury in Alexandria, Virginia, for an investigation into the business dealings and campaign contacts of Trump's former national security adviser, Michael Flynn. If Mueller's investigation were limited to Flynn, some legal experts argue, he would not have needed to impanel a new grand jury in the nation's capital.

The existence of a grand jury indicates that Mueller will be pursuing criminal charges, although the target and the channels of investigation remain unknown. Mueller has subpoena powers and can compel witnesses to testify before his grand jury, which would also vote on whether to indict any subjects of his investigations.

The top-level legal talent that Mueller continues to attract, such as Greg Andres of the New York law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell, who left his partnership to join the team, suggests that the special counsel is preparing for a prolonged investigation.

"This is going well into 2018, and whether it lasts beyond that is anyone's guess," said Robert Ray, the special counsel who investigated President Bill Clinton's Whitewater dealings. "This is an indication that it will not be wrapped up in 30, 60, or 90 days."

Experts caution against reading too much into the formation of a grand jury, which is an expected step for a seasoned prosecutor like Mueller. Additionally, grand juries do not always return indictments. For instance, Ray's Whitewater grand jury did not result in criminal charges against the president.

"If I'm in Trump World, I don't know that this rattles me because it's not a surprise, but it's certainly not good news for the president," said John Wood, a former U.S. attorney. "It's newsworthy because there was always the possibility the investigation would wrap up soon, and this is an indication it won't."

However, it does not necessarily mean that charges are imminent. Grand juries are used for both the investigation and charging phases, so there may be no charges. The grand jury and special counsel will operate largely in secrecy, and it will likely be some time before the targets of the investigation or the investigation's direction are known.

Former FBI Director James Comey, whom Trump fired, testified that the president was never the target of an investigation when he was in charge of the bureau, in contrast to media reports that suggested otherwise. "Comey said three times the president is not under investigation, and we have no reason to believe that has changed," said White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders.

Meanwhile, Trump has escalated his attacks against Mueller in recent weeks, labeling the investigation a "witch hunt" and drawing attention to alleged conflicts of interest with members of Mueller's team. Trump's allies have described Mueller and Comey as close friends and have drawn attention to Democratic donations from some of the lawyers on the special counsel.

There has long been speculation that the president would fire Mueller or seek to have him removed, but Trump attorney Jay Sekulow dismissed that speculation in an interview on Fox News' "Your World with Neil Cavuto."

"The president is not thinking about firing Robert Mueller, so the speculation that's out there is just incorrect," he said. Sekulow also downplayed the impaneling of the grand jury, saying it was expected. "This is not a surprise because the impaneling of a grand jury in situations like this, when you've got an investigation, is typically how you move forward," Sekulow said. "It is really much a standard operating procedure when you've got a situation like this, but with respect to the impaneling of the grand jury, we have no reason to believe that the president is under investigation here."

White House special counsel Ty Cobb said he only learned of the grand jury through media reports. "Grand jury matters are typically secret," Cobb said in a statement. "The White House favors anything that accelerates the conclusion of his work fairly. The White House is committed to fully cooperating with Mr. Mueller."

Title: Trump's Campaign Rally in Pensacola: A Case of Projection and Counter-Projection

Article:

In a campaign rally in Pensacola, Florida, on Friday night, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump appeared to employ a strategy of projection and counter-projection in his speech. This tactic involves attributing one's own traits, actions, or criticisms to one's political opponent.

During the rally, Trump criticized his opponent, Hillary Clinton, stating that she has only managed to stay out of trouble. This comment was a direct reference to the ongoing Department of Justice investigation into Clinton's private email server.

In response to chants of "lock her up" from the crowd, Trump seemed to deviate from his prepared speech. He said, "Because she is being so protected, she could walk into this arena right now and shoot somebody with 20,000 people watching right smack in the middle of the heart, and she wouldn't be prosecuted." This assertion mirrors a statement Trump made about himself nearly nine months ago, during a campaign event in Sioux Center, Iowa, where he said, "I could stand in the middle of Fifth Avenue and shoot somebody, and I wouldn't lose any voters."

Later in the speech, Trump echoed another criticism that has been aimed at him, turning it back onto Clinton. "She's trigger-happy," Trump said of Clinton. "Personally, I think she's an unstable person." Clinton has made similar arguments about Trump, stating that he is "temperamentally unfit" to be president and that his ideas are "dangerously incoherent."

This pattern of projection and counter-projection has been observed in Trump's campaign speeches recently. Last week, Trump criticized Clinton for not providing specific policy details, despite her releasing a 288-page book detailing her proposed policies the same day, according to NPR's Tamara Keith. Not providing concrete policy plans is a criticism Clinton often brings up about her opponent.

In late August, Trump tweeted that Clinton was "pandering to the worst instincts in our society." This tweet was in response to a speech Clinton gave that day, in which she made a similar criticism about Trump, saying he "built his campaign on prejudice and paranoia" and "is reinforcing harmful stereotypes and offering a dog whistle to his most hateful supporters."

For the rest of the night in Florida, Trump mostly stayed on his standard messages, both those in line with traditional conservative values and his own lines, such as his promise to build the wall (with Mexico paying) and the idea of being friendly with Russia. However, he did veer off course one other time, suggesting that he would shoot Iranians circling U.S. destroyers. "With Iran," Trump told the crowd, "when they circle our beautiful destroyers with their little boats and they make gestures at our people that they should not be allowed to make, they will be shot out of the water."

Bloomberg reporter Jennifer Jacobs tweeted that this remark, along with the earlier comment about Clinton shooting someone, were both instances when Trump went off teleprompter.

Title: Lack of Consistent Leadership and Scientific-Based Decision Making Exacerbates COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in over 500,000 deaths globally in the past four months, with many experts believing the actual numbers to be much higher. This rapid spread and high death toll are unprecedented, with the last time such a large number of people perished in such a short time being during the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.

The virus, like radiation, is invisible, potentially deadly, and can cause permanent damage to those exposed. This is a mass casualty event that requires a unified, scientific-based response. However, the lack of consistent leadership and politically driven messaging has left many citizens confused and directionless.

In the United States, the lack of clear, factual information and the politicization of protective measures such as mask-wearing has led to a divide among the populace. The act of wearing a mask has become a symbol of unity and common decency for some, while for others, it represents restricted rights and oppression.

The recent surge in COVID-19 hospitalizations in Texas, following the Lt. Governor's disregard for state and federal medical authorities' guidance, is a prime example of the consequences of political negligence. The people of Texas deserve better leadership that prioritizes the health and safety of its citizens over political goals.

The message "We have to learn to live with the pandemic" is covert messaging that implies accepting the high number of deaths as inevitable. As a physician, this is unacceptable. Instead of casting doubt upon science and the collective knowledge concerning this threat, leaders should promote truth and transparency.

The current lack of leadership has led to mass casualties among our own citizens. Systemic neglect and sadistic behaviors, such as those manifested by national leaders, are easier to apply when most of the potential victims are poor, brown, and black. COVID-19, however, does not discriminate and will affect many regardless of political affiliation or socio-economic standing.

The best thing our politicians can do is to stop disseminating information based on political expediency and listen to science. They should apply true leadership by taking a step back and allowing the experts to speak directly to the public. The mission, the battle, the war is what is most important.

Harry S. Truman once said, "It is amazing what you can accomplish if you do not care who gets the credit." Oh, for the leadership of a Truman, now! The past is there to remind us of things we may have forgotten. Let us not make it obvious to the world that we have learned nothing from history.

Eventually, this will affect every citizen. No bombs were ever dropped directly on the United States during World War II, yet as a nation, we all strove, sacrificed, and did our part to help save others. You may not know anyone who has contracted COVID or has died from it, but unless we work together in unity, you most undoubtedly will.

Title: Republican Veepstakes: The Delicate Balance Between Safe and Boring

Article:

The race for the vice-presidential nomination, often referred to as the Veepstakes, is approaching its final stages, with several low-drama options, including Rob Portman, Tim Pawlenty, and Bobby Jindal, being considered.

Senator Rob Portman from Ohio, known for his impressive chicken imitation and a 1900-mile kayak journey along the Rio Grande River, is believed to be a top contender for Mitt Romney's running mate. However, Portman has been facing criticism for being too dull for the ticket, with comedian Stephen Colbert referring to a potential Romney-Portman union as "the bland leading the bland."

The politics of boring can be delicate, as a 2012 veep hopeful should be solid, smart, and noncontroversial, but not so unexciting that they are perceived as uninteresting or prone to controversy. This is a challenge for Portman, as well as other charisma-challenged politicians on Romney's presumed shortlist, such as former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty and Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal.

Supporters of Portman argue that his wonkish demeanor hides a real character. Former New York congressman Rick Lazio, who shared a house with Portman in Washington, stated, "If you define exciting as a celebrity who invites controversy—he’s not that guy. But he’s an interesting and fun-loving guy."

Despite the recent buzz about placing the decidedly-not-dull concert pianist, figure skater, and fashion icon Condoleezza Rice on the ticket, the Republican party seems to favor a cautious approach this year. Republican strategist John Weaver stated, "Boring is the most logical choice for Romney. Given the way the base so hates this president, they are going to be motivated regardless of who the vice president nominee is. So it makes more sense for him to go with [the] safer choice."

Terry Holt, a Republican presidential campaign veteran and strategist, added, "Just because someone seems interesting or flashy, that doesn’t qualify them to be vice president. It’s common for activists to try to reach for the brass ring, to hope for someone who will somehow end up being the silver bullet to victory. Ultimately, for Romney, it’s his leadership attributes that will determine whether or not people vote for him—not who he picks for a running mate."

Title: Pence Tapped as Trump's 'Reassuring' Figure in 2020 Campaign

Article:

Mike Pence, the Vice President of the United States, is being positioned as a key figure in President Donald Trump's 2020 reelection campaign, with a focus on appealing to suburban voters and women who may have reservations about Trump's personality. This strategy is a response to the Republican Party's losses in higher-income suburban areas during the 2018 midterm elections.

According to a recent poll by Morning Consult, Trump's favorability among registered voters, suburban residents, and women is significantly lower than Pence's. The poll found that Trump's favorability is -15 among registered voters, -14 among suburban residents, and -25 among women, while Pence's favorability is -6, -7, -16, respectively, in these categories.

Pence's folksy Midwestern charm is seen as disarming suburban women who may be put off by Trump's behavior. He has also been effective in appealing to white evangelical Christians, a demographic that quickly coalesced behind Trump when he chose Pence as his running mate in 2016.

The strategy of using Pence as a counterbalance to Trump's more brash personality is not new, and it is being described as a "good cop, bad cop" approach. Pence is expected to focus on smaller, more intimate settings, while Trump will handle larger rallies and unscripted media appearances.

The Trump campaign's strategy is based on the understanding that Trump's personality may be a liability with the exact voters they need to win over. This has led to speculation about potential running mates like Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor and Trump Cabinet member, who could be more effective in courting women and suburban voters. However, Trump has denied any interest in swapping out his running mate.

Campaign officials say Trump recognizes that Pence can connect with suburban women and voters over kitchen-table issues that matter most to them, and that his calm demeanor allows him to foster those connections in a way that doesn't obscure the substance. This extends to rhetoric, with Pence taking a more measured approach compared to Trump's more bombastic style.

In other words, Pence is seen as the retail politician, while Trump is the star. Their alliance is both unusual and advantageous, but it is not unlike past presidential tickets where vice presidents were chosen because of their electoral potency, not because of the wisdom or policy chops they would bring to the White House.

Title: Presidential Debate Moderators Face Criticism for Bias in Second Debate

Article:

In the context of baseball, three strikes signify the end of a batter's turn at bat. In the presidential debates, however, three debates, including the second presidential debate and a vice-presidential debate held on October 4, mark the beginning of a prolonged series of discussions. The moderators for Sunday night's debate, Anderson Cooper from CNN and Martha Raddatz from ABC, were criticized for perceived bias during the event.

During the debate, both candidates discussed each other's treatment of women, with Hillary Clinton questioning Donald Trump's fitness to be president and Trump countering by naming the victims of Bill Clinton's sexual advances and stating that Clinton should be ashamed of herself regarding their treatment.

The debate was met with criticism from various media outlets, with some describing it as "brutal" and "depressing." CNN's senior media correspondent Brian Stelter compared the debate to professional wrestling, while CBS's Bob Schieffer referred to it as "WrestleMania."

The moderators were accused of interrupting and speaking for Clinton, with Anderson Cooper asking four follow-up questions aimed at skewering Trump on a recent video controversy regarding offensive comments he made on an open mic. Martha Raddatz also lost her composure during the debate, leading to an embarrassing exchange.

Twitter exploded with criticism of Raddatz, with Trump adviser and former House speaker Newt Gingrich stating, "Why is Raddatz debating Trump? Isn't that Hillary's job?"

During the debate, Trump promised to call for a special prosecutor for Clinton's email scandal and stated that she would be "in jail." CNN's Dana Bash later compared Trump to African dictators, Stalin, and Hitler for the comment.

Reaction to the debate was predictably polarized, with media research center president Brent Bozell criticizing the obvious debate bias when the issue of Russia trying to influence the election came up. Clinton foreign policy spokesman Jesse Lehrich used Twitter to tell Trump to "go f--k himself," while Politico reporter Louis Nelson took the pro-Raddatz media line.

Debate panels were mixed about the result, with pollster Frank Luntz giving the win to Trump, while CNN's poll showed a 57% to 34% lead for Clinton.

The debate involved questions from 40 "uncommitted" voters selected by Gallup. However, it is unclear how anyone could be considered uncommitted with just 30 days to go until November 8. The debate also featured four Clinton accusers in the front row as a testament to how they had been treated by both Bill and Hillary Clinton.

Title: Senate Immigration Bill Clears Key Hurdle, Awaits Final Vote

Article:

A Senate immigration proposal has garnered enough votes to clear a key hurdle, though some lawmakers continue to vote as of Monday evening. The measure, which is an amendment to the main bill, needs 60 votes to pass. As of Monday, supporters of the proposal have attracted at least 66 votes.

The measure being voted on Monday is a bipartisan compromise amendment that is considered a key test of whether the bill itself has enough support to pass the full chamber. The amendment, touted by supporters as a border security compromise, includes provisions for an unprecedented surge of security on the border, according to the sponsors behind the amendment.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid anticipates the bill will pass with between 68 and 71 votes. Tensions were high ahead of the vote, with some conservative Republicans acknowledging the bill is likely to pass the Senate but warning that the House is another matter.

President Obama is also hosting a meeting at the White House with business leaders to discuss immigration reform and push for support of the bill among the business community. The bill would provide a years-long path to citizenship for the roughly 11 million illegal immigrants currently living in the U.S.

Some conservative groups have been skeptical of the amendment, with the Heritage Foundation warning that it would allow illegal immigrants to "receive amnesty now" with the possibility of more border security "somewhere down the road."

The bill's future in the House remains uncertain, with House Speaker John Boehner facing pressure from both Republican and Democratic lawmakers and conservative groups. If the bill passes the Senate, Boehner will be faced with honoring the will of the majority of House Republicans who do not appear to want to pass the legislation or honoring the majority of the chamber that appears to want at least a full floor vote.

Sen. Mike Lee (R-Utah) and Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) have argued that Congress should take a more step-by-step approach, starting with further securing the U.S.-Mexico border. "It could take years to implement the border-security measures," Lee said.

The bill's sponsors are trying to gather 70 votes to show the bill has widespread bipartisan support in the Democrat-controlled chamber and to give it momentum as it heads into the Republican-controlled House. Last week, senators proposed the so-called Border Surge amendment, which included 70,000 additional U.S. border agents and 700 more miles of border fencing, to garner support from lawmakers who said the influx of illegal immigrants remains a problem.

Title: Facebook Removes 1.5 Million Videos of New Zealand Mosque Shooting, Police Response Time Clarified

Article:

Facebook has removed or blocked 1.5 million videos of the shooting rampage at two New Zealand mosques that resulted in the deaths of 50 people and injuries to dozens more. Mia Garlick, spokeswoman for Facebook New Zealand, stated that approximately 300,000 videos were removed within the first 24 hours of the terrorist attack on Friday. Over 1.2 million videos were blocked at upload, according to Garlick.

In a tweet, Garlick said, "Out of respect for the people affected by this tragedy and the concerns of local authorities, we're also removing all edited versions of the video that do not show graphic content." Facebook is using technology and personnel "around the clock" to remove content that violates its violence policy.

Minutes before the attack, the alleged shooter posted a 74-page manifesto on Twitter and sent it to numerous officials and media outlets in New Zealand. The gunman also livestreamed the rampage via helmet cam on Facebook and Twitter. Footage of the massacre circulated for hours after the shooting, despite efforts by Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, and Reddit to take it down as quickly as possible. Twitter and YouTube said they were continuously monitoring and removing any content depicting the tragedy.

YouTube tweeted within hours of the attack, "Our hearts are broken over today’s terrible tragedy in New Zealand. Please know we are working vigilantly to remove any violent footage." Twitter issued a statement citing its "rigorous processes and a dedicated team" that activates in such emergencies. The site also stressed that it cooperates with law enforcement investigations.

Church services and candlelight vigils were taking place across the nation of fewer than 5 million people on Sunday. Dozens of people wounded in the assault on the Al Noor and Linwood mosques remained hospitalized.

New Zealand Police on Sunday released some details of the initial response to the attack. New Zealand Police Commissioner Mike Bush said in a statement, "There has been some speculation around the Police response times to the first attack. To clarify, police received its first 111 call at 1.41pm. The first armed police unit was on scene at 1.47pm. That’s six minutes to respond."

The department's highly trained Armed Offenders Squad arrived with 10 minutes, and the 28-year-old suspect was in custody within 36 minutes, Bush said. "I am very proud of the police response to this terrible attack," he added.

Title: Court Rules Against Compensation for Homeowner Whose House Was Destroyed in Police Raid

Article:

A federal appeals court has ruled that a Colorado homeowner, Leo Lech, is not entitled to compensation for the destruction of his home during a police raid in 2015. The raid, which left Lech and his family homeless, was not related to any of the family members. The family was not home when an armed shoplifter broke into their house on South Alton Street in Greenwood Village.

The two-day operation, which involved the use of high-caliber rifles, chemical agents, flash-bang grenades, remote-controlled robots, armored vehicles, breaching rams, and an armored vehicle driving through the home's front door, left the house unlivable. Greenwood Village condemned the structure, forcing Lech to have it torn down, and the city offered a measly $5,000 to cover the damage.

Lech's lawsuit, which has been ongoing for several years, claimed the city was liable under the Constitution's takings clause, which forbids governments from taking private property for public use without "just compensation." A federal district court ruled in 2016 that the city was not liable, and the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals agreed in a ruling issued on Wednesday. The three judges stated that police cannot be held liable for damage caused while trying to apprehend a suspect.

Lech received a $345,000 payout from his homeowner's insurance, but this was not enough to cover the full value of the home, which was appraised for $580,000. The payout also did not cover the costs of demolition or the loss of other property inside the home. Lech ended up having to take out a $390,000 loan to cover the costs of rebuilding.

Lech and his attorneys told The Denver Post that they plan to appeal the decision to a full panel on the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals and could eventually take the case to the Supreme Court. The details of the appeal are not currently available.

Title: Gallery Owners Settle Discrimination Lawsuit Over Same-Sex Wedding

Article:

A dispute between a gallery owner and a same-sex couple who were denied service for their wedding ceremony in 2013 has been resolved through arbitration. The gallery, Görtz Haus, is owned by Mr. and Mrs. Odgaard, a long-established couple who have since closed their business.

The couple, Lee Stafford and Jared Ellars, had initially booked their wedding at Görtz Haus but found themselves in a predicament when their hotel went bankrupt two months before the event. They approached Görtz Haus for an alternative venue, and after a 45-minute meeting, the Odgaards declined their request, citing religious beliefs.

Mr. Ellars, 35, a database administrator, and Mr. Stafford, 43, a business systems analyst, claim that the Odgaards only revealed their reasons for denying service when they inquired about the nature of the wedding. According to the couple, Mr. Odgaard stated, "I can't take your money, and we don't do anything for free."

The couple, who have been together for 13 years, never intended for the Odgaards' business to suffer as a result of the incident. Instead, they hoped the gallery owners would cease discriminating against same-sex couples. The settlement required the Odgaards to pay $5,000 to Mr. Stafford and Mr. Ellars, which they donated to an anti-bullying program for gay students.

The wedding ceremony was held in a barn, officiated by a minister from the Disciples of Christ church, which Mr. Stafford attends. To this day, Mr. Stafford remains troubled by the ongoing debate over religious liberty, stating, "Their religious beliefs say they don't approve of gay marriage, but my religious beliefs say that we can. Why does their religion trump mine?"

Title: Progressive Split Among New Hampshire Democrats as Sanders Mulls 2020 Bid

Article:

In the spring of 2015, before Bernie Sanders had a campaign office in New Hampshire, Elizabeth Ropp, an acupuncturist, was making homemade signs for the Vermont senator. "Bernie inspired me because, as someone who's lived without health insurance for most of my adult life, I want there to be a single-payer health care system," she said.

Ropp was disappointed Sanders was not the nominee and is convinced that if he had been, Donald Trump would not be president. "I want to see Bernie run again in 2020," said Ropp. "We need Bernie to run even if the field is crowded."

The 77-year-old Vermont senator has not announced his plans, but he has sparked plenty of speculation. In 2016, Sanders created a powerful progressive movement in a thin primary field. The dilemma for him now is that nearly every other Democratic presidential contender is adopting his positions on issues like health care and minimum wage, which means progressive voters in 2020 have plenty of other choices.

Earlier this month, when Sanders reintroduced a bill to raise the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour, every Democrat in the Senate who's rumored to be considering a run for president co-sponsored his legislation: Sherrod Brown, Elizabeth Warren, Cory Booker, Kirsten Gillibrand, Kamala Harris, and Amy Klobuchar.

Arnie Arnesen, a radio show host and former New Hampshire politician who thinks of herself as Sanders' ideological twin, says she's grateful that he ran in 2016 because he helped "expose some of the rot" in her own party. Sanders has helped change the Democratic National Committee rules for selecting a nominee, curtailing the role of superdelegates and shaping the current Democratic economic message. However, Arnesen wonders whether he's the right candidate for the White House.

"My question is, does he provide added value in this campaign for 2020? Or are there a lot of people who sort of carry very similar messages?" asked Arnesen, before answering her own question. "Does it have to be him? I don't think it does, and I admire him. I admire him to pieces."

The clearest example of the change is Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, who resigned as vice chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee so she could endorse Sanders in the 2016 primary. Gabbard recently launched her own presidential bid.

Sanders' first decisive victory in 2016 came in the New Hampshire primary; he crushed Hillary Clinton there by 22 percentage points. And activists like Andru Volinsky were part of the reason he did so well. Volinsky, Sanders' New Hampshire campaign lawyer during the 2016 primary, said that if the Vermont senator were to run for president again, he would be his top choice.

However, it's unclear whether Volinsky personally wants Sanders to run. "I want a strong advocate for addressing issues like income inequality and health care access and climate action," said Volinsky. "Sen. Sanders could be that strong voice. There are some others that could as well."

Many voters who strongly backed Sanders in 2016 say they realize Sanders is not necessarily the only progressive option in 2020. For some, that's confusing, but for others, it's appealing.

Arnesen is excited by many of the candidates considering a run for the presidency; many of them, she believes, carry elements of Sanders' message. For example, Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown, she says, has a lot of the same "authenticity" as Sanders "without being 80 years old" when he's elected (Sanders turns 79 in 2020).

"I think it's time for us to start creating a new bench," said Arnesen. "And the new bench isn't old, it should not be white, and it probably should not be male."

Some Sanders supporters also say the political environment has changed since 2016, and they want a candidate who can win. "Electability has leaped to the forefront for me," said Ron Abramson, an immigration lawyer who served as a Sanders delegate to the DNC. "I am prepared to support anyone who can help restore some measure of sanity [and] humanity."

"We're looking for somebody right now who can stand up to the nasty, nasty campaign that our idiot-in-chief the president is going to run in 2020," said Bill Stelling, an activist who runs an art gallery in Manchester. Stelling is not convinced Sanders is the right person for that job.

Even though he was "hugely inspired" by Sanders' message in 2016 and donated to the Vermont senator's campaign, these days, he's impressed with California Sen. Kamala Harris; he thinks she's "fearless." He's also intrigued by Beto O'Rourke, the former Texas congressman who tried to unseat Republican Sen. Ted Cruz last year. This week, Stelling is going to a "Draft Beto" house party. He wanted to spread the word, so he posted a note about the meeting on Facebook, but was disheartened by the response.

"I immediately got some snarky comments from progressives," said Stelling. "It's so counterproductive."

But loyal Sanders supporters are unyielding in their devotion to the Vermont senator, because, they insist, he is the only one pushing the Democratic Party to the left. "The other candidates are trying to posture themselves based on the assumption that Bernie Sanders is going to run," said Tim Smith, a four-term state legislator in Manchester and early Sanders supporter in the 2016 primary. "They don't want to be seen as being members of the conservative wing of the party."

Title: Republican Divide on Abortion Laws: Trump, Romney, and McCarthy Disagree on Exceptions

Article:

WASHINGTON - Pro-life laws are gaining momentum across the United States, from Alabama to Missouri. However, a growing divide among Republicans is emerging over the extent to which these laws should go.

Recently, President Donald Trump took to Twitter to celebrate his pro-life victories. In a tweet, he stated, "I am strongly pro-life, with the three exceptions of rape, incest, and protecting the life of the mother - the same position taken by Ronald Reagan."

This statement has sparked debate, as Trump is not alone in questioning the recent pro-life laws. Senator Mitt Romney (R-UT) told CNN's State of the Union, "I do not support the Alabama law. I believe there ought to be exceptions. I am pro-life, but there ought to be exceptions."

Similarly, House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) stated, "In my whole political career, I also believed in (exceptions for) rape, incest, or life of the mother. There was exceptions, that's exactly what Republicans have voted on in this House."

For some pro-life advocates, the recent laws are seen as an opening battle for a potential Supreme Court fight. Kristan Hawkins of Students for Life of America stated, "Actually, for the future of our country, Roe is destined to become a historical footnote."

Alabama state Rep. Terri Collins added, "No law is constitutional until the Supreme Court actually revisits Roe v Wade."

The Trump administration has been vocal about its commitment to the pro-life cause, with Vice President Mike Pence recently telling graduates of Liberty University, "We stand without apology for the sanctity of human life."

Democratic presidential candidates are also engaging in the debate. Senators Cory Booker (D-NJ), Elizabeth Warren (D-MA), and Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY) hope to codify Roe v Wade into federal law. Gillibrand told CBS' Face the Nation, "President Trump has started a war on America's women. If it's a fight he wants to have, it's a fight he's going to have."

Senator Bernie Sanders (I-VT) vowed in an interview with NBC's Meet the Press, "If you are asking me would I ever appoint a Supreme Court justice who does not believe in defending Roe v Wade, who does not believe a woman has a right to control her own body, I will never do that."

This week, the justices will decide whether to hear a case out of Indiana requiring women to get an ultrasound 18 hours before an abortion.

Title: Bipartisan Senators Express Optimism for Immigration Reform Amidst Shifting Republican Stance

Article:

A bipartisan group of senators expressed confidence on Monday in their proposal for major immigration reform. However, after the last significant congressional push failed in 2007, many are questioning why it would work this time around.

During a press conference, Republican Sen. John McCain, when asked by CNN's Dana Bash about the optimism, responded, "Elections, elections." He further explained, "The Republican Party is losing the support of our Hispanic citizens, and we realize that there are many issues on which we think we are in agreement with our Hispanic citizens, but this is a preeminent issue with those citizens."

In the 2012 presidential election, President Obama received 71% of the Latino vote compared to Mitt Romney's 27%. The Latino vote for Republicans has also trended down over the last three presidential elections. In 2008, 31% supported McCain, while 44% of the voting bloc turned out for then-President George W. Bush in 2004.

Since Election Day, leading Republicans have taken a noticeably different tune on immigration, with many stating that the party needs to adjust its messaging on the issue to appeal to a broader base.

Speaking later in the day on CNN's "The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer," McCain argued that he's not sure "politics" is entirely behind the shift, but "if we continue to polarize the Latino/Hispanic vote, the demographics indicate that our chances for being in the majority are minimal."

Polls during the election indicated that the economy—not immigration—was the top issue for Latino voters. A CNN poll conducted a little more than a month before the election showed that 44% of Latino adults rated the economy as their top issue, while immigration policy came in a distant second at 14%. Asked to choose between the economy and immigration, nearly three-quarters of Latinos – 74% – said the economy was more important.

However, more than three-quarters of Latino voters in exit polls said that undocumented immigrants should be offered the chance to apply for legal status.

Along with elections, McCain acknowledged other reasons for the renewed drive on illegal immigration legislation—saying "we can't forever have 11 million people live in the shadows"—but he also predicted a bumpy road ahead.

"Let me emphasize, there will still be fights. There will still be battles," he said on CNN. "But I am more confident now that I have ever been that we can reach an agreement and have a bill signed by the president."

Title: Ilhan Omar's Controversial Remarks on Israel and the Jewish Lobby

Article:

Representative Ilhan Omar's recent comments regarding the influence of the Jewish lobby in U.S. politics have sparked a heated debate, with critics accusing her of promoting the ancient smear of wealthy Jews buying influence, while some defenders argue she is accurately describing the power of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC).

In a tweet, Omar responded to a comment by journalist Glenn Greenwald about House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy's threat to punish Omar and fellow Muslim representative Rashida Tlaib over their criticisms of Israel. This led to an exchange with a writer for The Forward, resulting in a firestorm of criticism from both parties.

In a recent article, the author defends Omar and Tlaib against McCarthy's attacks but criticizes Omar's use of the term "Jewish lobby" to describe pro-Israel attitudes in the U.S. The author argues that Omar's remarks play into stereotypes that aid Republican efforts to suggest that any criticism of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's policies is on a slippery slope that leads to passing around copies of the anti-Semitic text, "Protocols of the Elders of Zion."

The author explains that Americans' pro-Israel attitudes are largely due to acute and widespread awareness of the Holocaust and Jewish statelessness, as well as religious perspectives that make America more pro-Israel than similar but more secular countries. A particularly large and politically active group of conservative American Evangelical Christians, who identify with Jews and place the State of Israel at the center of their vision of global salvation, have become the single most important constituency in the Republican Party's base.

The author also notes that the idea that it's "Jewish money" or "the Jewish lobby" that is the main reason for the Republican Party's move towards Israel is a distraction from the real reasons and furthers the argument that one must choose between Netanyahu, settlements, and Greater Israel on the one hand, or anti-Semitism on the other. The author argues that if Omar understands this, she should make it clear before she inadvertently becomes a casualty in the war of anti-Muslim extremists against anyone seeking peace and justice in the Middle East.

The author also cites a 2018 piece from The Forward, which notes that Vice President Mike Pence's visit to Israel was part of a long-term strategy by conservative white Christian evangelicals driving American policy toward Israel and the Palestinians.
