These evangelicals believe that Jews, and only Jews, must rule over Jerusalem to herald the return of Jesus Christ, and their absolute fealty toward Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and their antipathy toward the Palestinians are reflected in the itinerary for Pence's trip. The article concludes that the idea that it's "Jewish money" or "the Jewish lobby" that is the main reason for the Republican Party's move towards Israel is an absolute distraction from the real reasons and furthers the argument that one must choose between Netanyahu, settlements, and Greater Israel on the one hand, or anti-Semitism on the other.

Title: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren Announces Exploratory Committee for 2020 Presidential Run

Article:

Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has formally announced the establishment of an exploratory committee, marking a significant step towards her potential candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the 2020 presidential election. In a video emailed to supporters on New Year's Eve, Warren made a populist political appeal, emphasizing her middle-class background and her work on consumer financial protections.

Warren argued that the middle class is "under attack" from corporations and the right, including President Trump, whom she vowed to defeat in 2020. She stated, "Billionaires and big corporations decided they wanted more of the pie. And they enlisted politicians to cut them a fatter slice."

Senator Warren's potential strengths in the anticipated crowded contest include her track record of addressing economic concerns and her willingness to confront President Trump. However, she is a polarizing figure who may face challenges in crafting her own narrative, as she has become a target for conservatives, who portray her as a liberal elitist due to her background as a Harvard law professor.

Prior to her 2012 election to the Senate, Warren had never held elected office. Since then, she has been a liberal icon, instrumental in the establishment of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and known for her outspoken criticism of the banking industry.

During her years as a senator, Warren is best recognized for her sharp questioning of financial executives. In 2016, she famously told the then-CEO of Wells Fargo to resign for overseeing the bank during a time when it created fake accounts.

Speculation about Warren running for president began shortly after her Senate election in 2012. In 2016, many progressive groups urged her to run for president, and her hometown newspaper, the Boston Globe, even ran an editorial arguing that "Democrats need Elizabeth Warren's voice in the 2016 presidential race."

Warren declined the opportunity in 2016, but four years later, she is now ready. However, she will face a larger field, including potential progressive favorites like Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders and several other senators expected to join the race. Approximately two dozen Democrats are expected to run for president this cycle, including a number of women and candidates of color.

In a statement, Charles Chamberlain, executive director of Democracy for America, said, "Senator Elizabeth Warren's formal entrance into the 2020 race for President today helps launch what we believe will be a vibrant discussion of bold, inclusive populist ideas in the Democratic Primary." In 2014 and 2015, DFA worked with Moveon.org to encourage Warren to run for president.

Warren's entry into the contest to challenge President Trump in 2020 is a development he is likely to relish. Trump has frequently mocked Warren, derisively calling her "Pocahontas," a reference to her 2012 campaign against Republican Scott Brown when he claimed she had misrepresented her family's Cherokee heritage for professional gain. In October 2018, Warren released the results of a DNA test showing that she did have Native American ancestry going back several generations. The Cherokee Nation, however, called the DNA testing "useless."

The incident was intended to quiet critics, but it quickly became a cultural faux pas of its own. Trump's taunting did not end, and even some Democrats accused Warren of misunderstanding the complexity of race and identity.

Warren appears to target voters of varied cultural, geographic, and economic backgrounds with an anti-corporate, pro-worker message in her initial campaign pitch. One of the biggest criticisms of Hillary Clinton's failed 2016 bid was a focus on appealing to specific demographic groups, which some argue alienated white, working-class voters who helped elect Trump. In her launch video, Warren touched on her working-class childhood in Oklahoma, discussing how her mother got a minimum wage job at Sears when her father got sick, in order to keep the family in their house.

Title: Obama Pushes for Global Climate Pact at Paris Summit, Faces Domestic Opposition

Article:

President Barack Obama has embarked on a mission to secure a global climate accord at the ongoing two-week conference in Paris, where over 150 world leaders are negotiating an agreement aimed at curbing an increase in global temperatures. In his opening remarks, Obama described the meeting as a potential "turning point" in the global fight against climate change.

In his address, Obama emphasized the urgency of the challenge and the potential for human action to address it. He stated, "What should give us hope that this is a turning point, that this is the moment we finally determined we would save our planet, is the fact that our nations share a sense of urgency about this challenge and a growing realization that it is within our power to do something about it."

The Paris summit takes place in the aftermath of the devastating terror attacks in the city, and some Republicans have criticized Obama for focusing too much on global warming and not enough on security. However, Obama, in his remarks, characterized the negotiations as an "act of defiance" towards the attackers.

Obama also met one-on-one with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, two of the world's largest carbon emitters, on the sidelines of the summit. In addition, he held discussions with Russian President Vladimir Putin to address security matters.

Domestically, Obama faces opposition from congressional Republicans and several states concerned that his proposals will result in job losses. The president has pledged that the U.S. will cut its overall emissions by 26 percent to 28 percent by 2030, with a focus on reducing emissions from U.S. power plants. However, half the states are suing to block the power plant rules, claiming Obama has exceeded his authority under the Clean Air Act.

Furthermore, Republicans in Congress are threatening to block U.S. dollars for the U.N. Green Climate Fund, a fund designed to aid poorer countries in combating climate change. The Paris conference aims to secure the most comprehensive deal ever to tackle global warming. The 1997 Kyoto Protocol, the last major agreement, required only rich countries to cut emissions, and the U.S. did not sign on.

Among the sticking points in the negotiations is the allocation of funds for climate change mitigation and adaptation, as well as the potential impact on traditional oil and gas producers. At least 19 governments and 28 leading world investors have announced billions of dollars in investments for clean energy technology research and development.

In addition to climate change discussions, Obama and Putin also addressed the Syrian civil war and the recent downing of a Russian jet by Turkey, with Obama expressing regret for the loss of Russian lives and reiterating U.S. support for de-escalation between Russia and Turkey. Obama also reiterated that Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad must leave power as part of any political transition.

Title: House Freedom Caucus Members Call for Removal of Rep. Adam Schiff as Impeachment Inquiry Leader

Article:

House Freedom Caucus members have demanded the removal of Rep. Adam B. Schiff, the California Democrat and chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, from leading the impeachment inquiry. In a letter, 19 Caucus members, including new Chairman Andy Biggs, stated that Mr. Schiff cannot be trusted to lead the investigation due to his interactions with the whistleblower who filed a complaint before the impeachment inquiry began.

The letter alleges that Mr. Schiff's interactions with the whistleblower make him a potential fact witness and unfit for the serious responsibility of leading the investigation. The New York Times reported that the whistleblower, who accused President Trump of trying to pressure Ukraine into investigating former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his son Hunter, first approached an intelligence committee staffer who then relayed some "vague" information to Mr. Schiff. The committee aide then directed the whistleblower, per standard protocol, to Michael Atkinson, the inspector-general for the intelligence community.

Mr. Schiff stated last month that his team has not spoken directly with the whistleblower. However, media reports this week contradict that account, with The New York Times and others reporting the whistleblower had reached out to a House Intelligence Committee aide before filing the complaint.

Rep. Biggs accused Mr. Schiff of using the Ukraine allegations as a "fairy tale" to impeach the president. "Mr. Schiff is hardly an unbiased arbiter of this unauthorized impeachment process, and we call for his immediate recusal," he said.

In the letter, the Republicans argue that Mr. Schiff should be questioned himself regarding his interactions with the whistleblower. They also argue that Democrats demanded Rep. Devin Nunes, California Republican and the previous head of the intelligence panel, recuse himself from the Russia investigation because of his private meetings with a source.

Last week, Mr. Schiff accused Republicans of merely trying to protect the president. "Republicans continued the president's strategy of deflection by making the absurd claim that because a whistleblower contacted the committee seeking guidance, the committee can not conduct an investigation into the complaint," Mr. Schiff said. "If that were true, no whistleblower could contact Congress and no committee could conduct an investigation," he continued. "What the Republicans fear most is the truth. To avoid the facts, they stage confusion, undermine the Constitution, and attack the person the President fears most, Adam Schiff."

Title: President Trump's Media Relationships Remain Complex Despite White House Efforts to Downplay Ties

Article:

President Donald Trump's media relationships have remained complex, with some of his old ties persisting despite White House efforts to downplay their significance. According to several news outlets, including Bloomberg News, Trump has allegedly sworn off watching MSNBC's "Morning Joe" and many of his favorite CNN programs. However, on the morning of his well-received speech to a joint session of Congress, Trump reportedly spent 15 minutes chatting with Joe Scarborough, the host of "Morning Joe," in the Oval Office. An MSNBC spokesperson confirmed the meeting.

The apparent disconnect between some aides' insistence that Trump is taking his feud with the media seriously enough to turn off the TV, and his tendency to grant access to hosts of his favorite shows, suggests that aides have not yet figured out how to curb their boss's habits.

Trump's relationship with Scarborough isn't the only one of the president's old ties that his aides have tried to downplay. Trump's aides and advisers have declared that New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie is not that close to the president and has lost clout since he was unceremoniously ousted from leading the transition team shortly after the Nov. 8 election. However, Trump frequently calls Christie to ask his opinion on the administration's performance and to kibbitz about New York or whatever is happening that day, according to several people close to Trump with knowledge of the conversations.

The president also sought to appoint Christie as labor secretary after Trump's first nominee, Andrew Puzder, dropped out, even though some of his top advisers disapproved of the move. Christie declined the offer.

Aides have also tried to de-emphasize the president's friendship with Chris Ruddy, the CEO of Newsmax Television, who, in a CNN appearance last month, criticized Chief of Staff Reince Priebus as ineffective. "Don't listen to Ruddy," one senior administration official said after Ruddy's appearance. "He's trying to get attention. Trying to be important."

Ruddy, who has known Trump for more than a decade, talks to the president frequently—including a 30-minute meeting in the Oval Office on Wednesday. And some of Trump's aides feared that Ruddy was speaking on the president's behalf when he criticized Priebus on television, because the two men had seen each other for 30 minutes the night before at Mar-a-Lago.

Ruddy told The New York Times that he was speaking only for himself, and that Priebus had called him after the interview to ask him to keep an “open mind.” A week later, Priebus and Steve Bannon had a long dinner with Ruddy, according to a person familiar with the event.

Some in the White House have balked at Anthony Scaramucci, the New York financier who is disliked by some of the president's aides. But Scaramucci has the president's cellphone number and continues to speak to him, according to people familiar with their calls.

Corey Lewandowski, Trump's first campaign manager, who was purged last summer, still occasionally talks to the president and came in for a meeting last week with Trump, several people familiar with the calls and the meeting say. Some people familiar with the meeting said Lewandowski's continued relationship with Trump is frustrating for West Wing aides. Lewandowski declined to comment.

One senior White House official disclaimed any knowledge of Trump's calls with Christie and Scaramucci, but did not deny that they occurred. Trump keeps his own cellphone and is often alone in the West Wing at night, where he answers calls and dials people. He will sometimes ask his secretary to set up a meeting or put him on the phone with someone after seeing that person on TV.

"He talks to people in New York that his aides in the White House have no clue who they even are," said a person who regularly talks to Trump. "They've never even met some of these people, but the president listens to them."

The White House official confirmed Trump often calls people after seeing them on television, either to thank them for their comments or to engage further about the topic of discussion. "That’s true, he’s done that for 40 years," the White House official said, adding that it’s "a great thing that he communicates with a lot of different people."

Title: Obama Signs Defense Bill, Issues Statements on Controversial Provisions

Article:

President Barack Obama has signed into law a $633.3 billion defense bill, which includes a statement indicating his intention to interpret the law as he sees fit on various issues, such as the transfer of terrorism detainees and the military's policy on gay service members.

In a "signing statement" released Wednesday, Mr. Obama agreed with the "vast majority" of provisions in the 680-page law but expressed disagreement with some sections. He had earlier threatened to veto the bill if certain objectionable provisions survived.

Notably, Mr. Obama objected to Section 1027, which renews the prohibition against transferring detainees from the Guantanamo Bay detention center in Cuba to the United States. He argued that this provision violates constitutional separation of powers principles and could lead to constitutional conflicts.

Another contentious issue addressed in the statement is the military's policy on homosexuality and the gay lifestyle. Mr. Obama stated that a provision giving service members and military chaplains the legal right to oppose homosexuality, as long as their opposition does not interfere with good order and discipline in the military, is "unnecessary and ill-advised."

The president also objected to a provision that blocks proposed increases in health insurance fees for service members, stating that it could result in deeper cuts to military personnel.

The bill also includes provisions tightening penalties on Iran and enhancing security at U.S. diplomatic posts, in response to the deadly attack in Benghazi, Libya, last September.

Despite his veto threat, Mr. Obama signed the law due to the critical defense authorities and funding it provides, which he deemed too important to ignore. The measure also contains defense spending cuts agreed upon by the president and congressional Republicans in August 2011.

Title: Lawmakers Debate Gun Control in Wake of Colorado Shooting

Article:

In the aftermath of the mass shooting in Colorado that left 12 people dead and 58 others injured, the debate over stricter gun-control laws has resurfaced. Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper, a Democrat, declined to comment on whether Colorado should revisit its gun laws, stating that the shooting suspect, James Holmes, would have found a way to create "horror" even if he hadn't been able to acquire guns.

White House press secretary Jay Carney confirmed that President Obama's views on gun-control laws have not changed. He stated that the president's focus is on keeping guns out of the hands of those who should not have them under existing law.

Gun-control advocates, such as Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), have pointed to the types of weapons allegedly used by Holmes, a 24-year-old doctoral student at the University of Colorado, in the shooting at an Aurora theater during a midnight showing of "The Dark Knight Rises." Holmes was armed with a 100-round rifle magazine, among other weapons.

Sen. Feinstein called for a "sane" debate about banning military-style assault weapons, citing the powerful weapon used in the shooting and the high number of casualties despite a quick police response. Rep. Carolyn McCarthy (D-NY), a leading gun-control advocate, stated that mass shooters have one thing in common: a gun that can be loaded with large amounts of ammunition.

However, some lawmakers, such as Sen. Ron Johnson (R-WI) and Colorado Governor Hickenlooper, argue that the issue is not about guns but about individuals who would find ways to commit acts of violence regardless of the tools available to them.

While the Colorado shooting has reignited the gun control debate, little is known about the suspect's motivations. Aurora Mayor Steve Hogan stated that Holmes had given no hint of the rampage he is suspected of embarking on. Hickenlooper described Holmes as "clearly deranged, twisted, demonic in some way," with a goal to create terror.

Title: Obama Orders Paid Sick Leave for Government Contractors, Criticizes Republican Candidates on Union Policies

Article:

U.S. President Barack Obama signed an executive order on Monday, mandating that government contractors offer their workers seven days of paid sick leave per year. The order, signed during a flight to Boston, will affect approximately 300,000 workers starting in 2017.

Workers on government contracts will earn a minimum of one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked. Contractors have the discretion to offer more generous amounts.

Speaking at a union event in Boston, Obama emphasized the benefits of such policies and advocated for additional worker-friendly measures, such as paid maternity leave. He joked about the U.S. being the only advanced nation on Earth that does not guarantee paid maternity leave.

Obama made indirect references to Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie for their anti-union remarks and policies without naming them. In response, Governor Walker stated, "It’s clear he stands with the big government union bosses while we stand with the people."

The executive order is part of a series of measures by the White House to expand access to paid leave. In January, Obama issued a presidential memorandum directing the government to advance up to six weeks of paid sick leave for the birth or adoption of a child, or for other sick leave-eligible uses.

Obama is also pressing Congress to pass legislation giving government employees six additional weeks of paid parental leave. Labor Secretary Thomas Perez could not provide an estimate of the cost of implementing the seven-day paid leave rule for contractors.

During the trip to Boston, Obama also renewed his call for Congress to pass the Healthy Families Act, which would require all businesses with 15 or more employees to offer up to seven paid sick days each year. According to the White House, an estimated 44 million private-sector workers, about 40 percent of the total private-sector workforce, do not have access to paid sick leave.

Title: IRS Targeting of Conservative Groups Extends Beyond Cincinnati Office, New Evidence Suggests

Article:

New evidence has emerged suggesting that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) targeting of conservative organizations extended beyond the agency's Cincinnati office, as previously claimed by senior IRS officials. NBC News reported that documents, including those signed by IRS Tax Exempt Organizations Director Lois Lerner, were sent to Tea Party groups, requesting additional information.

Attorneys representing some of the targeted groups have stated that the additional scrutiny did not solely originate in the Cincinnati office, with requests for information coming from other offices and bearing the signatures of higher-ups at the agency. At least one letter requesting information about one of the groups bears the signature of Lois Lerner, the suspended director of the IRS Exempt Organizations department in Washington.

Jay Sekulow, an attorney representing 27 conservative political advocacy organizations that applied to the Internal Revenue Service for tax-exempt status, provided some of the letters to NBC News. He stated that the groups' contacts with the IRS prove that the practices went beyond a few "front line" employees in the Cincinnati office, as the IRS has maintained.

Among the letters were several that bore return IRS addresses other than Cincinnati, including "Department of the Treasury / Internal Revenue Service / Washington, D.C.", and the signatures of IRS officials higher up the chain. Two letters with "Department of the Treasury / Internal Revenue Service / Washington, D.C." letterhead were signed by "Tax Law Specialist (s)" from Exempt Organizations Technical Group 1 and Technical Group 2. Lerner's signature, which appeared to be a stamp rather than an actual signature, appeared on a letter requesting additional information from the Ohio Liberty Council Corp.

Lerner has been placed on administrative leave after refusing to testify before the House Oversight Committee about the scandal last week. She continues to receive a $180,000 per year, taxpayer-funded paycheck. Lerner was the first to publicly admit IRS targeting of conservatives was in fact taking place.

Title: White House Announces Kathy Kraninger as Nominee for Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Head

Article:

WASHINGTON - The White House announced on Saturday that President Donald Trump has chosen Kathy Kraninger, an official from the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), to lead the U.S. consumer watchdog, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB). The decision is facing criticism from consumer advocates and dividing conservatives.

Kraninger, who will succeed interim CFPB head Mick Mulvaney, will need Senate approval to assume the role. If confirmed, she will succeed her current boss, Mick Mulvaney, who was appointed as the temporary head of the CFPB in November to replace Richard Cordray, an appointee of former President Barack Obama.

In a statement, White House Deputy Press Secretary Lindsay Walters stated, "She [Kraninger] will bring a fresh perspective and much-needed management experience to the [bureau], which has been plagued by excessive spending, dysfunctional operations, and politicized agendas."

Kraninger, who holds a law degree and has worked at the Department of Homeland Security and as a Congressional staffer, did not immediately respond to a LinkedIn message seeking comment on Saturday.

During his six-month tenure at the CFPB, Mulvaney, a former Republican Congressman, has overhauled the agency, restructuring departments, shelving new regulations, and dropping cases against payday lenders. At the OMB, Kraninger has worked on financial policy issues for the CFPB, Treasury, and other regulators, and has extensive experience managing large teams in government, according to one person with direct knowledge of her role.

Consumer groups and conservatives alike have criticized the announcement, with both sides questioning whether she is qualified and expressing concerns about her ability to gain Senate approval. Allied Progress, a left-leaning consumer group, stated that Kraninger's nomination was an attempt by Mulvaney to keep a grip on the agency, adding that she has "no relevant experience."

J.W. Verret, an associate professor at the George Mason University Antonin Scalia Law School and financial regulation expert, said in an email that Kraninger was regarded in conservative Republican circles as very "smart," but he also pointed to her lack of consumer finance experience. Other conservatives argued that Mulvaney had a strong track record of picking good managers, and said he would not have backed her if he doubted her capability.

"Whether you agree with Mulvaney politically, there is no doubt he has been a highly effective manager in government, and since he's worked closely with her, he must know she is qualified," said Dina Ellis Rochkind, a lawyer at Paul Hastings and former Congressional staffer who worked for Republican lawmakers. "But the big test will be how she performs in her Senate confirmation hearing."

Title: Education Department Cancels $150 Million in Student Loans, Affecting 15,000 Borrowers

Article:

The United States Department of Education announced on Thursday that it will cancel $150 million in federal student loan debt, despite Secretary Betsy DeVos' efforts to overhaul the Obama-era policy. The department will forgive loans for approximately 15,000 borrowers whose schools closed, preventing them from completing their programs.

Three months ago, a federal judge ruled that DeVos' attempts to rescind the 2016 regulations were illegal, as reported by Politico. The judge also rejected for-profit colleges' bid to stop the policy in October.

About half of the affected borrowers attended Corinthian Colleges, a for-profit educational chain that closed its campuses in 2015. These borrowers will account for $80 million of the automatically discharged loans, while borrowers whose schools closed between November 1, 2013, and December 4, 2018, will account for the other $70 million.

Affected borrowers will begin receiving email notifications from the department on Friday, according to the department's press release. However, loan discharges may take longer than 90 days to complete, and loan holders will inform borrowers about the specific loans that were forgiven.

Previously, DeVos argued that the debt forgiveness was too lenient, lacking sufficient borrower proof requirements. The department proposed changes that would reduce frivolous claims and allow colleges to respond to borrower allegations.

In a separate development, Citibank has been ordered to pay $6.5 million for allegedly harming borrowers with student loan servicing failures. The specifics of this case are not detailed in the provided text.

Title: House Democrats Initiate Investigation into Deaths of Two Guatemalan Children at U.S.-Mexico Border

Article:

House Democrats have ordered Homeland Security officials to preserve all relevant evidence related to the two deaths this month of Guatemalan children who crossed the U.S.-Mexico border with their parents. This move signals the beginning of an investigation, which is set to commence next year, following the Democrats' anticipated takeover of the House and subsequent acquisition of powers to oversee investigations.

The request for preservation includes medical records, surveillance videos, and logs of interactions between Border Patrol agents and the children. The order was signed by the top Democrats on the House Judiciary, Oversight, and Homeland Security committees.

In a joint statement, the lawmakers announced that after the new Congress begins next week, their committees in the House of Representatives will hold hearings and conduct oversight on the two deaths that occurred earlier this month, as well as the conditions under which thousands of children are being held in DHS custody.

An 8-year-old boy died on Christmas Eve after six days in Border Patrol custody. Felipe Gomez Alonzo had been treated for a cold and fever at a hospital and was released, only to be readmitted hours later and subsequently died. His mother, still in Guatemala, stated that the boy's father brought the youngster on the trip because they believed he would have an easier chance of navigating the American immigration system to gain an illegal foothold in the U.S.

Earlier this month, a 7-year-old Guatemalan girl fell ill hours after being arrested crossing the border illegally with her father. Border Patrol agents managed to revive her twice, but she later suffered a heart attack and liver and respiratory failure at a hospital and died. The specific details regarding the girl's family and the circumstances surrounding her death were not available in the provided text.

Title: Rand Paul's Strategy of Revisiting Clinton Scandals Garners Media Attention, Yet Questions Remain on Its Effectiveness

Article:

The strategy of Kentucky Senator and potential 2016 presidential candidate Rand Paul of revisiting decades-old Clinton scandals, particularly the Monica Lewinsky affair, has proven effective in maintaining media attention this winter. By indirectly referencing the Oval Office sex scandal, Paul has managed to spark panel discussions and media articles.

This week, Paul's attacks were bolstered by the revelation of personal, decades-old correspondences between Hillary Clinton and Diane Blair, a close friend and confidant to the former first lady. The newly uncovered archives, which addressed the Lewinsky scandal and other trials from Bill Clinton's two terms, were presented as significant political news.

For Clinton critics, there appears to be no downside to the strategy. The media has largely celebrated Paul's Lewinsky-centric approach, with CNN's Candy Crowley describing him as being "on a roll lately" and CNN political reporter Peter Hamby claiming Paul's attack on Clinton's personal life represents "a potent message for Republicans at the moment."

However, the strategy's effectiveness in boosting Paul's political aspirations is questionable. In a national poll released on Tuesday, a McClatchy-Marist survey of Republican voters found that just 9% of them considered Rand Paul their pick to be the GOP's nominee in 2016. Even some Republican leaders think the Paul strategy is an electoral loser.

Additionally, a recent Washington Post poll found Clinton to be historically popular for a potential candidate. Yet, pundits continue to discuss supposed hurdles her campaign will face, with terms like "predestined" and "train wreck" being used to describe her potential candidacy.

Despite the ongoing negative Clinton analysis, the rehashing of Clinton scandals has remained a popular topic in the media. The Beltway press has been eager to cover the story, with the New York Times and CNN characterizing the Blair letters as providing "fresh insight into the private history of the Clintons" and "bringing new insights into how Clinton dealt with White House setbacks," respectively.

Veteran columnist Joe Klein, who has written about the Clintons for 30 years, criticized the notion that the Blair letters were big news or that the previously adjudicated sex scandals still matter today. "If Hillary Clinton does run for President, she should be examined carefully-as a public servant, not as a demonic caricature," wrote Klein. "She's far better than that; I hope we are, too."

Title: FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe Steps Down Amidst Ongoing Political Pressure and Allegations of Conflict of Interest

Article:

WASHINGTON—FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe has stepped down from his post on Monday, following weeks of criticism from President Donald Trump and other Republicans, according to people familiar with the matter. McCabe will take the remainder of his vacation time until he is technically eligible to retire from the Federal Bureau of Investigation in March.

McCabe has faced a steady string of attacks over an alleged conflict of interest stemming from his wife's previous run for Virginia state Senate as a Democrat before he became deputy director. He has denied any conflict.

President Trump and other Republicans have cited the alleged conflict as part of a broader assertion of bias on the part of the FBI, the Justice Department, and the special counsel's office as they investigate Russian meddling in the 2016 election and any links between the Trump campaign and Moscow in that effort. Trump has specifically called for McCabe's ouster.

Democrats say these assertions are an attempt to distract from the investigations and discredit them.

In an email to employees, FBI Director Chris Wray addressed McCabe's departure, saying he "will not be swayed by political or other pressure" in making decisions, according to a person familiar with the message. Wray thanked McCabe for his service, adding that McCabe said he would take leave immediately following a conversation between the two.

The email was earlier reported by the New York Times.

In the message, Wray also said he wouldn't comment on a pending report from the Justice Department's inspector general, an in-house watchdog, which is expected to criticize the FBI's handling of an investigation into Hillary Clinton's email arrangement when she was secretary of state. The report is expected to prompt some personnel changes.

McCabe's decision Monday surprised many inside the FBI and Justice Department. Officials abruptly canceled a press conference to discuss an unrelated criminal operation as news of McCabe's resignation became public minutes before the conference was to begin.

McCabe, 49 years old, will be succeeded, at least temporarily, by the No. 3 official at the bureau, David Bowdich, one person said.

Special counsel Robert Mueller has publicly obtained two guilty pleas from Trump campaign aides. He has charged two other Trump campaign officials with tax-related and other offenses related to private work predating the campaign.

The U.S. intelligence community in January 2017 said it believed Russia had conducted an influence operation with the goal of hurting Hillary Clinton and helping Trump in the 2016 presidential election.

McCabe's abrupt departure is the latest event in a highly unusual back-and-forth between the Trump administration and a federal law-enforcement establishment that is both investigating him as it works for him, and cherishes its independence.

The dueling narratives about the Russia investigation have engulfed multiple senior law-enforcement officials and spilled into a fight in Congress. House Republicans produced a memo earlier this month describing what they say were abuses by U.S. intelligence agencies in the Russia probe. Democrats dismissed the memo as a partisan document.

A House panel voted Monday to make the memo public, a move the Justice Department has said would be "extraordinarily reckless" because its officials had not reviewed it.

McCabe's resignation comes as the FBI faces fallout from thousands of text messages between an FBI agent and lawyer who were involved in the Russia investigation, including some texts harshly critical of Trump. The lawyer worked for McCabe.

After reports circulated in December that McCabe might soon leave the bureau, Trump took to Twitter to criticize him for remaining in the job. "FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe is racing the clock to retire with full benefits," Trump wrote. "90 days to go?!!!"

The White House said Trump played no role in McCabe's decision to step down. White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said the president wasn't part of the "decision-making process" on McCabe's departure.

McCabe, a career official at the FBI who spent nearly 20 years with the agency, was the acting FBI director after Trump fired the previous director, James Comey, in May. Days later, Mueller was appointed to probe the Russian conduct.

McCabe first worked on organized crime cases in the FBI's New York field office, then advanced to a series of leadership positions, including in counterterrorism and at the Bureau's Washington field office.

Beyond McCabe, Trump has criticized, or raised questions about, a variety of figures related to the Russia investigation, from Attorney General Jeff Sessions to Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein to Comey, who hired McCabe as his deputy in January 2016.

Those close to McCabe expected him to leave the FBI around March when he was eligible to receive his full retirement benefits after 20 years of service. Many agents in such a position choose to retire and start second, generally more lucrative, careers outside of government.

McCabe first attracted notice from Republicans in 2016 as a result of his supervisory role in the FBI investigation into Hillary Clinton's email server. Republicans raised conflict-of-interest questions because his wife, Dr. Jill McCabe, ran for Virginia state senate in 2015 with financial support from the political organization of then-Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat and longtime ally of Bill and Hillary Clinton.

The FBI has said McCabe played no role in his wife's campaign, and McAuliffe has said it is typical for governors to support candidates of the same party. McCabe received clearance from the FBI's ethics office to oversee the Clinton investigation, but Republicans have argued he should have stepped aside.

Title: Mortgage-Interest Tax Deduction: A Controversial Policy in Washington

Article:

The mortgage-interest tax deduction, a long-standing policy in the United States, has come under scrutiny from some policy advisers who argue that it lacks merit from a policy perspective. This view is supported by a significant body of academic research, which suggests that the mortgage-interest tax deduction disproportionately benefits the wealthy and has minimal impact on home ownership.

One policy adviser, who wished to remain anonymous for fear of losing his job, stated, "The mortgage-interest deduction, from a purely policy perspective, makes no sense." This perspective is met with resistance in Washington, D.C., where the mortgage-interest tax deduction is considered a "sacred cow."

Jimmy Williams, a former lobbyist for the National Association of Realtors, is one of the powerful forces that have long defended the mortgage-interest tax deduction. Williams stated, "If I were at the Realtors right now, I'd declare war on anyone who tried to get rid of the deduction." He would employ tactics such as running ads, encouraging Realtors across the country to make phone calls, and donating to influential legislators to deter any attempts to abolish the deduction.

Jamie Gregory, who currently lobbies for the Realtors, argues that eliminating the deduction would lead to a nationwide drop in home prices, potentially destabilizing the economy. Furthermore, he contends that homeowners are the primary lobby in favor of the deduction. Gregory asserts, "For middle-class Americans, either doing away or limiting the mortgage-interest deduction is going to be a tax increase."

While phasing out the deduction over time for future homebuyers is a possibility, the fear of being ridiculed for proposing such a change remains a significant barrier in Washington, D.C. The future of the mortgage-interest tax deduction remains uncertain, as smart policy staffers in D.C. navigate the complexities of this contentious issue.

Title: Obama's 2012 Election Campaign and Campaign Finance Reform

Article:

In the 2012 election, President Barack Obama, who has long positioned himself as a champion against the influence of big money in politics, has faced criticism from campaign finance reformers. These reformers argue that the president, despite his past rhetoric, has neglected his reformist agenda and embraced elements of a new, laissez-faire election system he previously criticized.

The president granted his approval earlier this year to Priorities USA Action, a super PAC run by two of his former staffers, to raise and spend unlimited sums of money from corporations, unions, or individuals. This move has led to the president potentially becoming the first chief executive not to successfully appoint someone to the Federal Election Commission (FEC).

The White House considered, but ultimately declined, to issue an executive order restricting federal contractors that receive taxpayer dollars from "interfering" in elections. The administration also abandoned a full-time "ethics czar" position and did not respond to a plea to overhaul the FEC submitted in February by good-government types.

The president has not proposed replacing the nation's presidential public funding system, a system he effectively rendered obsolete four years ago by reneging on a promise to accept public campaign funds and then raising approximately $750 million, more than any other presidential candidate in U.S. history.

"We're seeing daily things get worse," said Robert Weissman, President of Public Citizen. "And his failure of action will result in things growing even more worse."

David Bossie, president of the conservative Citizens United organization, expressed satisfaction with Obama's lack of action on campaign finance issues. "Obama hasn't been addressing these issues in any way, shape or form. It's great for us," Bossie said.

The Obama administration defends the president, noting he signed an executive order on his first day in office strictly limiting lobbyists' access to the administration. The White House spokesman, Eric Schultz, stated that Obama's White House has "done more than any administration in history" to "reduce the impact of special interests in Washington."

However, the president does not collect money from special-interest PACs or lobbyists, and about 98% of his donations come from people contributing $250 or less. The campaign also voluntarily releases information on its top fundraising bundlers.

Title: Trumpism Remains Elusive 100 Days into President Trump's Administration

Article:

One hundred days into President Donald Trump's administration, the definition of 'Trumpism' remains unclear, as the President's approach to governance appears to be a blend of conventional Republican policies and his own impulses.

During the campaign, two main theories emerged about Trumpism: economic populism combined with social conservatism and isolationism, or a lack of a coherent ideology, with Trump making decisions based on his own impulses. As of now, it remains uncertain which interpretation is more accurate.

On foreign policy, Trump is adopting a more traditional Republican stance, earning praise from the foreign-policy establishment he once criticized. However, on domestic policy, Trump is distancing himself from his populist campaign rhetoric, appointing billionaires and CEOs to his Cabinet, and signing executive orders beneficial to big banks.

One challenge President Trump faces in translating his nationalist, populist, and anti-establishment instincts into a coherent governing agenda is the lack of a significant number of Trumpist congressmen. Trumpism was more of an attitude than a well-defined movement.

Despite this, Trump does have a base, primarily white, working-class voters who are closely watching his actions on trade and immigration, the issues that fueled his rise. Trump is moving forward aggressively on these issues, focusing on the same economic and cultural anxieties he stoked during the campaign.

Trump's message on immigration is already being felt, with a decrease in illegal border crossings, H1B1 visa applications, applications from foreign students to American universities, and tourism to the U.S.

Upcoming issues, such as tax overhaul, will test Trumpism further. Trump has vowed to announce his tax cut plan on Wednesday. Every tax bill has winners and losers, and Trump's tax bill will provide insight into the true nature of Trumpism. If the working-class voters feel they are being negatively impacted, Trump could lose support from his base.

So far, Trump's base has remained loyal to him, with his base voters expressing satisfaction with his performance. However, his approval ratings are at historic lows for a new president, and Trumpism remains a mystery. Whether Trumpism is a nativist version of a Mitt Romney administration or an evolving ideology awaiting the next impulsive decision of a flexible and unpredictable president remains to be seen.

Title: Job Growth Slows as Economy Adds Only 69,000 Jobs in May

Article:

The U.S. economy added only 69,000 jobs in May, marking a significant slowdown from the 275,000 jobs created in January. The Labor Department reported these figures, indicating a potential deceleration in job growth.

Meanwhile, despite the ongoing recession, numerous small business owners are persisting in their efforts to expand and hire more employees. Srinivas Konanki, who owns Pipette Calibration Services with his wife, is one such entrepreneur. The company, based outside Boston, specializes in calibrating laboratory equipment, specifically precise lab tools called pipettes.

A pipette resembles an oversized ballpoint pen, with a click button on top that dispenses liquid instead of ink. "The difference here is that you are actually measuring what you're squirting," Konanki explains, contrasting it with a regular squirt gun. "And so this [measures] very accurate volumes."

Konanki's expertise lies in the workings of pipettes. His wife, Manjula Konanki, jokes that he could talk about them for hours. However, when discussing their business, the Konankis adopt a more serious tone. "We, as a small business, have been very careful as to how we spend our money," Srinivas says.

Job growth, according to Konanki, is heavily dependent on business confidence. To hire new workers, an entrepreneur needs to be optimistic that business will continue to improve. The economic environment, with its ongoing turbulence in Europe and potential cutbacks in U.S. government spending, has given business owners plenty of cause for caution.

Srinivas is particularly concerned about the ongoing economic instability in Europe, as many European countries run research labs in the Boston area. "When they make cuts, they make cuts all over," he says. "And when that happens, we see our business cut down."

His other major concern is potential cutbacks in U.S. government spending, particularly potential cuts to the National Institutes of Health (NIH). The NIH could face an 8% funding cut at the end of the year as part of what's called "sequestration," if Congress fails to meet budget-cutting targets it imposed on itself through legislation last year.

Betsey Stevenson, a labor economist with the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, shares Srinivas' concerns. She agrees that Europe could be a headwind on hiring in the U.S., and many other businesses are worried about Congress' decisions later this year regarding the Bush-era tax cuts, unemployment benefits, and required spending cuts.

These decisions facing Congress at year's end have been collectively dubbed the "fiscal cliff." "Congress is saying, 'We're going to make this difficult,'" Stevenson says. "That sends a signal to all the actors in the economy that 'there is potential for real damage to our economy coming in the future, and you should prepare for it today.'"

Despite these uncertainties, the U.S. is still managing to add new jobs each month. David Kotok, chief economist at Cumberland Advisors, a Florida-based investment advisory firm, acknowledges that job growth has slowed since the start of the year. However, he also sees reasons to be optimistic.

"The manufacturing sector is growing in the United States," Kotok says. As it does, he continues, it creates higher-paying jobs. The energy sector is also doing well, he says, with rapid growth in natural gas exploration promising to create many more well-paid work opportunities.

"And the third piece," Kotok says, "is the gradual stabilization of housing. It's happening slowly—but it's happening." If this trend continues, it eventually means more jobs for carpenters, electricians, and many other people who work in related industries.

Kotok, the chief investment officer for a firm that manages billions of dollars, has to put his money where his mouth is when it comes to reading the economic tea leaves. And he says he's placing his chips on a slow but continued recovery for the U.S. economy and for employment.

Title: New York Primary: Clinton and Trump Lead in Polls, Aim for Victory to Secure Delegates

Article:

The New York primary is underway, with Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump leading in the polls. The Republican front-runner, Trump, has vowed to win enough delegates to clinch the Republican nomination and prevent a contested convention. However, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), Sen. Bernie Sanders (D-Vt.), and Ohio Gov. John Kasich are not conceding defeat yet.

A significant win in New York could tip the scales for both Clinton and Trump in this year's race for the White House. Both candidates have experienced losses in recent contests, shifting the momentum to their rivals. Sanders, in a recent address to supporters, stated, "We have won eight out of the last nine caucuses and primaries!"

Trump needs to capture more than 50 percent of the vote statewide to secure all of New York's 95 GOP delegates, moving him closer to avoiding a contested convention. Trump urged his supporters, "We've got to vote and you know Cruz is way, way down in the polls."

Sanders, on the other hand, is hoping for a close race in the Empire State. A loss by 10 points would mean he'll need to win 80 percent of the remaining delegates to clinch the nomination.

Despite a predicted loss in New York, Cruz has not lost momentum. He is aiming to secure more delegates this weekend while emphasizing his ability to win in November. Cruz told his supporters, "Because if I'm the nominee, we win the General Election. We're beating Hillary in the key swing states, we're beating Hillary with Independents, we're beating Hillary with young people."

For now, Cruz, Kasich, and Sanders have moved on from New York to other states. Trump and Clinton are the only two remaining in their home state to watch the results come in.

Title: Trump Administration's Allegations Against China's Role in COVID-19 Pandemic: A Look at the Facts

Article:

The Trump administration's assertion that China is responsible for the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic has been a recurring theme in recent months. This claim, as expressed in various commentaries, including one by Jeffrey D. Sachs, a professor and director of the Center for Sustainable Development at Columbia University, suggests that China's success is a result of cheating, rather than hard work and strategic planning.

The Trump administration and its allies have recently escalated these claims, suggesting that the COVID-19 pandemic was the result of an accidental release from a Chinese laboratory and a subsequent cover-up by China. However, these allegations have been met with skepticism, as they could potentially lead the world towards conflict, much like the Bush Administration's lies about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq led the U.S. into war in 2003.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, for instance, asserted on Sunday, "There is a significant amount of evidence that this came from that laboratory in Wuhan." Such charges, if proven false, could be reminiscent of the end of the McCarthy era, with Trump being compared to Senator Joseph McCarthy, who used lies and innuendos to scare Americans into submission.

The right-wing claims against China are illogical and lack supporting evidence. The virus was in circulation in Wuhan for weeks before the Chinese authorities organized a major New Year's event on January 18, which spread the virus. If China knew about and was covering up a laboratory release several weeks earlier, why would they organize such an event? The actual answer is that they were still in the midst of combating the new virus.

The biology and chronology do not support the laboratory-release story. The Wuhan lab did not have the Covid-19 virus under study. The virus is of a kind that originates in bats, but Covid-19 may have had an intermediate mammal host, perhaps one that was traded in the Wuhan live animal market implicated in a majority of the cases with onset before January 1, 2020. The Wuhan market was shut down on January 1 after the initial outbreak.

Furthermore, the administration and right-wing media also charge that China covered up the outbreak more generally for weeks. However, the record shows that doctors in Wuhan first noted unusual cases of viral pneumonia in mid-December. Wuhan health officials notified the World Health Organization office in China on December 31. The China health agency called the US CDC on January 3. The genome was fully sequenced and published online on January 11, and Wuhan was locked down on January 23.

Given the inevitable early confusion about a new disease that had never before been seen, that is a rapid timeline. There were mistakes, such as the delay in declaring definitively that the virus transmitted human to human, but the overall response was relatively swift.

Tragically, Dr. Li Wenliang, who first warned of the outbreak, was forced to sign a statement admitting to disturbing the public order and later succumbed to the disease in February. However, he was exonerated by a national investigation in March.

In conclusion, the Trump administration's allegations against China's role in the COVID-19 pandemic lack supporting evidence and could potentially lead the world towards conflict. The timeline of events shows that China acted relatively swiftly in response to the outbreak, and the laboratory-release story is not supported by biology or chronology. The U.S. should focus on cooperation and fact-finding, rather than blame and accusations, to combat the ongoing pandemic.

Title: Lobbying Activities and Collusion Allegations Surface in EPA-NRDC Relationship

Article:

In a recent development, members of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, including Rep. Darrell E. Issa of California and Sen. David Vitter of Louisiana, have requested documents and emails from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regarding its association with the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC). The legislators' concern stems from allegations that the NRDC's influence on EPA policy decisions may have allowed it to achieve its own agenda.

The Energy & Environment Legal Institute, in a report of its investigation, has uncovered a trail of emails revealing a potential revolving door between senior EPA officials and radical environmentalists. One batch of messages suggests that Sierra Club lobbyists provided biased research, which eager EPA officials accepted as justification to shut down coal plants.

To avoid scrutiny and evade the agency's visitors log, outside activists and government employees reportedly met at the J.W. Marriott Hotel, located across the street from EPA headquarters, to discuss regulatory actions and the planning of EPA hearings. Government officials allegedly provided advance notice of regulatory actions, giving the groups a head start on organizing the appearance of grass-roots support.

The emails describing the EPA's alleged shady business dealings were obtained after more than a year of wrangling and court battles. Former EPA administrator Lisa P. Jackson, who used the email pseudonym "Richard Windsor," was found to have concealed her participation in some emails. An example of this is an email congratulating Al Armendariz, a regional EPA administrator, on his new job at the Sierra Club.

Senator Vitter suggests that the orders come from a group of left-wing foundations that pull the strings of environmentalist groups, influencing Washington. The specific activities of these foundations and their financial backers remain unclear, but the classic rent-seeking model, where opposing projects like the Keystone XL Pipeline opens the way for competing projects, is a possible explanation.

The allegations of collusion between the EPA and the NRDC are currently under investigation, and the EPA has yet to release the requested documents and emails. The full extent of the relationship between the two parties and the potential influence it may have had on EPA policy decisions remains to be determined.

Title: "Margaret Thatcher's Legacy and the Search for a New Conservative Leader"

Article:

In a statement reported by The Times of London in 1992, former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher criticized a fellow party member who supported Britain's entry into the European Union, stating, "The trouble with you, John, is that your spine does not reach your brain."

Thatcher, known for her iron will and boundless energy, was a woman whose life was devoted to reform. Her impact on British politics and conservatism is still felt today, with American conservatives often looking to Ronald Reagan as a model.

Reagan, who brought conservatism into the mainstream and proved its principles electorally and practically effective, was a charismatic leader who defied the caricatures of conservatives as either radicals or indifferent to human suffering. However, it is important to note that projecting Reagan's views and actions onto contemporary issues or the modern political landscape is a futile exercise, as no politician can replicate his unique gifts and character.

The Republican Party, which has been grappling with a lack of top talent following two successive electoral defeats, is in search of new leaders who can embody the principles of conservatism and inspire the electorate. While there are rising stars within the party, the absence of a clear heir apparent and an ideological captain has led to a tumultuous political landscape.

In 1975, Thatcher took control of the Conservative Party in the United Kingdom when it was in a state of disarray. The party had suffered defeats and the advancement of socialism, leaving it open to new ideas. Thatcher, a woman of middle-class origin, was not a movie star or a seasoned politician, but she fought her way to the front of the line, emphasizing ideas and the need for new ones.

Today's American Republicans could benefit from a leader with Thatcher's force of will and personality. While there are many with big ideas, there seems to be a lack of individuals with Thatcher's consuming fire. It is possible that out of the current chaos on the right, a Thatcher or two may be rising, thoughtful, urgent, and eloquent individuals who defy conventional thinking about the party. If America is ready for change in 2016, one of these individuals may have the chance to do what Thatcher did and reset the trajectory of their nation.

Title: Carly Fiorina's Presidential Ambitions and the Perception of Female Candidates

Article:

The widespread speculation that Carly Fiorina is only running for the vice presidency has been a recurring topic among political insiders, donors, consultants, media, and grassroots activists. This notion, particularly when expressed by women who identify as feminists, has sparked debate and raised eyebrows.

While it is acknowledged that the author, who has worked with Fiorina in the past, holds a biased perspective, the central point remains: the assumption that Fiorina is only aiming for the vice presidency is not applied to male candidates in the same manner.

In contrast to the numerous male candidates in the Republican field, Fiorina is the only one consistently taking on Hillary Clinton, the expected Democratic nominee, in a direct and sustained manner. Despite facing fewer resources and less media attention, Fiorina's focus on Clinton demonstrates her determination and potential strength as a presidential candidate.

However, the author suggests that this focus on Fiorina may stem from several factors, including her business background, the polling data, and the historical skepticism towards female candidates in politics. As a result, Fiorina, the only female Republican woman running in 2016, may face unique challenges and perceptions that male candidates do not encounter.

The author concludes by questioning whether America is ready for a female president, given the historical rejection of high-profile female candidates in the past. Despite these challenges, Fiorina's presidential ambitions are clear, and she is running for the presidency, not the vice presidency.

Title: Democrats Criticize Trump Over Iran Strike, Republicans Respond

Article:

Following the White House strike on Iranian General Qassem Soleimani, a series of criticisms from Democrats have been directed towards President Trump, rather than Iran. The attack, which took place at Baghdad International Airport, has sparked debate among political parties, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi describing it as "provocative and disproportionate."

White House counsel Kellyanne Conway responded to the criticism by accusing congressional Democrats of ignoring the danger posed by Soleimani, who was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of U.S. soldiers in the Middle East. In a White House briefing, Conway stated, "They sound like they’re defending Soleimani and attacking this president, and that’s on them."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell also defended Trump, stating that some Democrats have "rushed to blame our own government before even knowing the facts" and have "rushed to downplay Soleimani’s evil while presenting our own president as the villain."

Former vice presidential nominee Joe Lieberman criticized his fellow Democrats for their "uniformly skeptical or negative reactions to Soleimani’s death," arguing that the decision deserves bipartisan support.

Democrats have accused Trump of putting the nation on the path for another Middle East war and have questioned the legality of the attack, insisting that he should have sought congressional authorization. House intelligence committee chairman Adam Schiff called for Congress to engage with hearings and constraints, blasting Trump’s "dangerous and provocative decision."

The leading presidential candidates have also been critical of Trump. Sen. Elizabeth Warren tweeted that the president was "dangerous," while Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont called for legislation that "reasserts Congress’s constitutional authority over war."

Conservatives have criticized the coverage from mainstream media outlets as more friendly towards Soleimani than Trump. Kyle Drennen, Media Research Center senior news analyst, stated, "Story after story is talking about how 'Soleimani was so revered, so respected, so beloved in Iran, he was a hero to them.' This is the kind of fawning coverage that this terrorist has gotten on the networks."

In a related development, Washington Post reporter Missy Ryan was criticized on social media for retweeting a photo comparing the crowds at Soleimani’s funeral to those at Trump’s 2016 inauguration. "The media is not interested in reporting accurately or fairly on Iran and Iraq. They just want to help the Democrats beat Trump," said Erick Erickson of the Resurgent.

Title: Biden's New York Visit Signals Potential Challenge to Clinton Among Progressive Democrats

Article:

Joe Biden's visit to New York on Thursday marks a significant step in his apparent pre-campaign exploration, as he delves into the political territory once represented by Hillary Clinton, the former Secretary of State and New York Senator. This visit, which includes events focused on women's issues, minimum wage, and an appearance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, is seen by many as a direct challenge to Clinton's standing among liberal Democrats.

Biden's itinerary includes a discussion on rape kit backlogs, an appearance with Attorney General Loretta Lynch, whose Justice Department is currently investigating Clinton's email server use, and a joint event with New York Governor Andrew Cuomo to support a $15 minimum wage for fast-food workers, a cause popular among progressives.

The vice president's office maintains that these events are official and unrelated to his potential presidential run. However, the growing consensus among political observers is that these actions are indicative of a burgeoning campaign, to the excitement of many of Clinton's former constituents.

Representative Hakeem Jeffries, a Brooklyn Democrat, expressed his support for Clinton but noted his intention to assess Biden's intentions before making an endorsement. Neal Kwatra, a New York-based consultant with deep ties to labor and progressives, highlighted Biden's long history with labor unions as a potential advantage in a city with the highest union membership in the state.

While many high-profile New York Democrats, including Cuomo, Senators Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand, state Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, and state Comptroller Tom DiNapoli, have already endorsed Clinton, the support of traditional power brokers may not carry as much weight in the dynamic world of New York politics.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who is yet to endorse a candidate, is reportedly holding out hope of using his progressive seal of approval to boost his national profile. His spokesperson was unavailable for comment regarding Biden and Clinton's progressive support.

Gustavo Rivera, a state senator who represents the Bronx and identifies as progressive, expressed his support for Clinton but acknowledged that he, like many others, is eager for Biden to enter the race. Rivera believes that a Biden candidacy would compel Clinton to address progressive issues more thoroughly and potentially shift her political stance further to the left.

Clinton's campaign declined to comment on Biden's visit or her standing with New York progressives. Meanwhile, Clinton will be campaigning and fundraising in Columbus, Ohio and Milwaukee on Thursday.

Biden is expected to expand on the economic fairness message he began in Pittsburgh on Monday, where he addressed a union crowd and criticized the current tax code as unfair. However, Dan Morris, a consultant for New York groups involved with the Fight for 15 and other progressive causes, expressed reservations about Biden's record on progressive issues, citing his support for a $12 federal minimum wage, his 1990s anti-crime legislation's disproportionate impact on African-Americans, and his questionable appeal to minority and female voters who would benefit most from raising the minimum wage.

Despite these concerns, Morris acknowledged that a Biden campaign could benefit the Democrats by forcing Clinton to engage more deeply with progressive issues and potentially making Senator Bernie Sanders (I-VT) a more significant factor in the race. Morris also suggested that Biden's progressive credentials are uncertain, describing him as more of a "question mark" than an "exclamation point."

Title: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Obama's Foreign Policy Strategy in Interview, Blames It for Rise of ISIS

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has criticized President Barack Obama's foreign policy strategy, stating that it contributed to the rise of the Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq. In an interview with The Atlantic's national correspondent, Jeffrey Goldberg, Clinton argued that Obama's refusal to "build up a credible fighting force" created conditions for jihadists to gain dominance in Iraq.

Clinton stated, "The failure to help build up a credible fighting force of the people who were the originators of the protests against [Syrian leader Bashar] Assad — there were Islamists, there were secularists, there was everything in the middle — the failure to do that left a big vacuum, which the jihadists have now filled."

The comments appear to be an attempt by Clinton to distance herself from Obama in anticipation of a potential 2016 presidential bid. Clinton also criticized Obama's broader approach to foreign policy, saying, "Great nations need organizing principles, and 'Don't do stupid stuff' is not an organizing principle."

The interview marks Clinton's first major criticism of the president's foreign policy since she stepped down from the administration last year. A source close to Clinton told Business Insider that her comments were more related to the thoughts she set out in her new book, "Hard Choices," and that she was "merely commenting on world events."

However, according to Politico, a source familiar with the interview said Clinton's staff gave the White House a heads-up that it had taken place.

Meanwhile, hostility towards a Clinton run seems to be building from the president's quarters. Veteran journalist and New York Times best-selling author, Ed Klein, whose latest book, "Blood Feud," focuses on the rift between the Obamas and the Clintons, has reported that Obama authorized senior adviser Valerie Jarrett to have secret meetings with Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren. The aim, he said, is to encourage Warren to mount a challenge to a Clinton 2016 White House bid.

Title: Governors' Stay-at-Home Orders and Religious Gatherings: A Contentious Debate

Article:

The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has led to stay-at-home orders in nearly all U.S. states, prompting difficult decisions for lawmakers regarding which establishments should be deemed essential and remain open. One of the most contentious debates revolves around the closure of places of worship, such as churches, mosques, and synagogues.

While more than a dozen governors have included exemptions in their orders for religious gatherings, some have imposed limitations on attendance and mandated social distancing. Some religious leaders have complied by holding small services or transitioning to online worship, but others have defied restrictions by continuing to hold regular services to large crowds.

In Florida, an evangelical Christian pastor was arrested for persisting in holding large services last week. The state's governor later issued a stay-at-home order that included an exemption for religious gatherings with no limitations on crowd size.

Advocates for closing all places of worship during the pandemic argue that public health takes precedence over First Amendment freedoms at this time. Large crowds, regardless of the gathering, should be prohibited, they say, but there is also evidence that religious gatherings can be particularly dangerous. Coronavirus clusters in several states, including Washington and California, have been traced back to religious gatherings.

Religious leaders counter that physical attendance is not necessary to practice one's faith, citing online services as a high-quality alternative. Legal analysts maintain that closing places of worship does not violate freedom of religion as outlined in the First Amendment during the specific case of the pandemic.

A group of faith leaders and congregants argue that religion is an essential part of their lives, and the freedom to practice as they see fit—even if it poses a risk—takes precedence over public health orders. Others support allowing small religious gatherings that adhere to social distancing, rather than complete bans. Places of worship serve an important role beyond religious services in many communities, some argue, and could provide critical support for people with health or economic needs if permitted to safely remain open.

Concerns have been raised that orders that force religious institutions to close completely may backfire, creating an adversarial relationship between religion and government that stokes fears of persecution.

"When our diocese and our church made the difficult decision to close our church building, we began living into a truth we have long proclaimed: the church is not a building. It is a community of people," said Rev. Leslie Hague of the South Florida Sun Sentinel.

"In this time of chaos, uncertainty, and gloom, faith and religious gatherings can provide peace, purpose, and fellowship. However, it is for these reasons that church, and religious gatherings in general, are among the highest risk venues, as otherwise isolated older adults come into close contact with socially active younger adults and children who may carry the coronavirus asymptomatically," wrote Eugenia C. South and M. Kit Delgado in the Philadelphia Inquirer.

"Even if we do practice stringent hygiene and social distancing, coming together as congregations in the face of this pandemic actually mars our witness. Rather than looking courageous and faithful, we come off looking callous and even foolish," said Daniel Harrell in Christianity Today.

Some argue that leaders who refuse to shut down should face legal consequences. "Good pastors protect their flocks. Pastors who willfully expose their congregations to this deadly virus do not deserve the title. Church leaders who insist on putting lives at risk should be jailed," stated an editorial in the Sacramento Bee.

Title: George Soros's Role in Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's Political Career

Article:

New details have emerged suggesting that financier George Soros played a role in the political career of Democratic socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. According to reports, Soros, through his funding of a network of far-left publications, provided support to Ocasio-Cortez's campaign, which aided her victory in the Democratic primary.

Ocasio-Cortez, a former organizer for Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign, was able to defeat her heavily-funded opponent, Joseph Crowley, in the primary on June 26, 2018. This victory was attributed to her strong online presence, which was bolstered by coverage from media outlets linked to Soros-funded digital media.

In an interview with progressive digital media outlet "The Young Turks," a member of a Soros-funded network of far-left publications, Ocasio-Cortez admitted that their coverage had helped her win. Cenk Uygur, a member of the Soros-funded media and founder of one of the political groups that asked Ocasio-Cortez to run, Justice Democrats, was eventually forced out of the organization due to past sexist comments.

Justice Democrats, along with another organization, Brand New Congress, aims to elect socialist politicians to Congress. Ocasio-Cortez's website, Ocasio2018.com, was first registered in May 2017 and redirected to her page on BrandNewCongress.Org, according to an Internet archive captured in June 2017.

In a June 2017 interview with Uygur on his YouTube channel "The Young Turks," Ocasio-Cortez thanked Uygur and other media platforms for covering her before the primaries, stating that their support "in no small part" helped her win. Ocasio-Cortez also acknowledged that Justice Democrats and Brand New Congress had asked her to run for office in the first place.

The Media Consortium, a network of far-left media publications that includes Mother Jones, Democracy Now!, and dozens of other outlets, is a part of Soros's media empire, reaching nearly 300 million people a month, according to the Media Research Center (MRC). The MRC report suggests that Soros funds nearly every major left-wing media source in the United States, with 45 of those being financed through his support of the Media Consortium. The report also details the progressive echo chamber Soros intentionally created with the Media Consortium with the intention of shaping public opinion.

Title: Obama Appoints Ron Klain as Ebola Response Coordinator

Article:

President Barack Obama has appointed Ron Klain as the Ebola Response Coordinator, according to knowledgeable sources, following his announcement on Thursday that he would consider having one individual to coordinate the federal response to any potential Ebola outbreak in the United States.

White House press secretary Josh Earnest stated that Klain's role will be an "important, high-level implementation role" and that it will be his responsibility to ensure that all government agencies responsible for aspects of the response coordinate their efforts effectively. He will also play a role in making decisions related to the response.

The administration has faced criticism for its response to Ebola incidents in the United States, particularly in terms of hospital preparedness for potential Ebola patients and the preparedness of healthcare workers regarding personal protective gear. Some lawmakers have called for a travel ban on individuals coming from West Africa, where the outbreak is most severe, but the administration has not yet endorsed this idea.

Klain is highly regarded at the White House for his management skills and relationships both within the administration and on Capitol Hill. He has no extensive background in healthcare, but the job is viewed as a managerial challenge rather than a healthcare one.

Klain will report to White House homeland security adviser Lisa Monaco and National Security Adviser Susan Rice, according to a White House official. A former chief of staff to Vice President Joe Biden and then-Vice President Al Gore, Klain is currently president of Case Holdings and general counsel of Revolution, an investment group.

Some Republicans have criticized the appointment, citing Klain's lack of a healthcare background as a disqualifier. House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Ed Royce stated that Obama should have chosen someone with medical experience, while Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida expressed concerns about the president's choice.

The term "Ebola czar" is not officially endorsed by the White House, with press secretary Josh Earnest stating, "As far as I'm concerned, you can call him anything you want. We call him the Ebola Response Coordinator."

Title: Illinois Governor Rauner's Executive Order Aims to Reduce Business Regulations and Occupational Licensing

Article:

Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner, in an attempt to attract businesses and stimulate job growth, has issued Executive Order 16-13, which aims to reduce business regulations and administrative burdens by 25% over the next two years. The order, effective as of October 17, 2015, seeks to save the state at least $250 million in government fees.

To achieve these goals, the order provides seven guidelines, including ensuring regulations are up-to-date, understandable, consistent, necessary, and not unduly burdensome. Each state agency must review its administrative rules to ensure they adhere to these guidelines, with regulations that fail to meet the new standards subject to repeal or reform.

The Illinois Competitiveness Council, chaired by U-Jung Choe and comprising representatives from the governor's office and several regulatory agencies, will oversee these efforts.
