One of the council's focuses will be the reform of occupational licensing, a practice that requires individuals to obtain government permission to work in certain professions.

Occupational licensing has been criticized for imposing significant time and financial burdens that act as disincentives to work. According to the Institute for Justice's comprehensive report on state licensing, Illinois ranked 30th in terms of overall requirements and burdens. Out of the 102 low- and middle-income occupations evaluated in IJ's report, 40 required a license in Illinois.

The number of licenses issued by the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulations has increased 184% over the last 20 years. This follows a national upward trend in licensing that has occurred since the 1950s. University of Minnesota economist Morris Kleiner estimates that 25% of Illinois workers now require government permission to work, compared to Indiana, which licenses only 15% of its overall workforce.

Many Illinois licenses do little to ensure public safety, as demonstrated by less-burdensome standards in other states. For example, Illinois is one of few states that licenses pharmacy technicians, mandating two years of training, while 39 states do not license the occupation at all. Similarly, California requires only 365 days of training and no tests to become a preschool teacher, compared to Illinois' five times more training (1,825 days) and three more tests to teach young children.

Illinois makes cosmetologists complete 350 days of education and training, while Emergency Medical Technicians need to complete only 26 days of training. The correlation between safety risks and licensing burdens is often tenuous, with cutting, styling, and dying hair warranting some level of government-approved competency but posing less of a safety risk than an occupation that literally requires professionals to hold lives in their hands.

Governor Rauner's program created a Red Tape Reduction Portal, allowing Illinoisans to flag state regulations that hinder their businesses. The goal is to restore sanity to licensing by ensuring government intervention only when necessary. The current licensing system in Illinois creates substantial time and financial barriers to work that often do little or nothing to ensure public safety.

While reducing regulation is never easy, there is reason to be optimistic about Illinois' reform efforts. Other states, such as Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Indiana, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Jersey, and Wisconsin, have recently reformed their business regulations. The most significant takeaway from Executive Order 16-13 is that governors can single-handedly follow through on their promises to open more work opportunities, even if state legislatures refuse to make necessary reforms.

Title: Lame-Duck Session in December Expected to be Minimal, Focused on Government Funding

Article:

December's lame-duck session in the U.S. Congress is expected to be the least productive in a long time, with Senate Democrats and House Republicans privately stating that the post-election work period will be uneventful. Unlike the past two lame-duck sessions, which resulted in major fiscal deals, this year's session is likely to focus solely on renewing government funding at the beginning of the month.

Significant issues such as immigration, tax, or entitlement reform are not expected to be addressed during the lame-duck session. Both parties are not pretending a big legislative push is in the offing. The most recent attempt to ensure a productive lame-duck session came Tuesday when House Republicans announced they will extend the Export-Import Bank's charter until 2015, avoiding a December fight over the controversial issue.

The lack of legislative activity during the lame-duck session is attributed to the uncertainty about the power structure in the next Congress. If Republicans take the Senate, they are unlikely to cooperate in December. If Democrats maintain control of the chamber, the political gridlock will remain frozen. The only deadline is at the beginning of the month. The incentives are not in place to make December big and bold.

Intricate political calculations are being made behind the scenes. For example, House Republicans are being careful not to place any legislative fights in the opening months of 2015, as they don't want Republicans to have a rocky start if they capture the Senate majority. There isn't much talk about the post-election period in closed House Republican Conference strategy sessions.

House Republicans, who know they will remain in power come January, are so bullish on their party controlling the Senate that most of their internal planning is predicated on Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) becoming the majority leader in January. There have even been private conversations about a closed-door Senate-House policy retreat to develop an agenda if the party grabs control from Harry Reid (D-Nev.). They are privately fretting that Reid will push through a number of nominations if he loses the Senate.

The lame-duck plans, or lack thereof, were laid out by several top-level sources in both parties, and preview a December very different than in 2012 and 2010. In 2010, after Republicans took control of the House, President Barack Obama and congressional leaders cut a deal to extend the Bush-era tax rates for all Americans. In 2012, shortly after Mitt Romney and Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) lost the presidency, Congress narrowly averted the so-called fiscal cliff of steep tax increases and a government shutdown. Republicans agreed to raise taxes on wealthy Americans just before midnight on New Year's Eve.

This year, there's one main item to take care of in December: averting another government shutdown. The government-funding bill, which the House is likely to pass this week, will run until Dec. 11. Congress will return to D.C. at some point in late November—the House will hold its leadership elections then. Senior aides see two options to extend government funding: Appropriations Chairman Hal Rogers (R-Ky.) and Senate Appropriations Chairman Barbara Mikulski (D-Md.) want to begin crafting a long-term omnibus spending bill, but some in GOP leadership think it's more likely Congress will pass another stop-gap spending measure.

House Republicans are eager to avoid another fiscal cliff scenario—piling a number of deadlines close to each other. The debt ceiling must be raised some time in March, April, or May 2015, and the GOP wants to try to avoid placing the government-funding deadline in that range.

There are a few wild cards, however. A prolonged military conflict could force Congress to pass a supplemental spending bill. Several targeted tax provisions—known on Capitol Hill as "extenders"—need to be renewed. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act expires at year's end—and Republicans want to squeeze that through. And there's fear that if Obama takes any executive action on immigration, they will use the post-election period to try to cut off the White House's authority.

Title: Obama Administration's Appointment of Women in Senior Roles

Article:

Criticism arose earlier this year regarding the appointment of women in key positions within the Obama administration, following the departures of prominent figures such as Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former Secretary of State, and Hilda L. Solis, the former Labor Secretary. Notably, positions at the Departments of State, Defense, and the Treasury, which some liberals had anticipated would be filled by female candidates, were instead filled by male appointees.

In response to the criticism, President Obama stated at a January news conference during his second term, "I would just suggest that everybody kind of wait until they've seen all my appointments, who is in the White House staff and who is in my cabinet, before they rush to judgment. Until you've seen what my overall team looks like, it's premature to assume that somehow we're going backwards. We're not going backwards, we're going forward."

Since those remarks, President Obama has appointed several women to top posts, including for Interior Secretary, Commerce Secretary, Budget Director, and Director of the Environmental Protection Agency. However, according to some administration officials, this imbalance has been a point of contention within the building, leading the White House to prioritize considering female candidates earlier this year.

As of June 2012, 43 percent of President Obama's appointees had been women, according to a New York Times analysis of federal employment data. This proportion is comparable to that of the Clinton administration and represents an increase from the roughly one-third appointed by George W. Bush.

The largest gains in the number of women in the executive branch occurred during the Clinton administration. In no administration before his did women hold more than 18 percent of cabinet-level jobs; in his second term, the share exceeded 40 percent. At that level, women held a substantially larger share of senior roles in the executive branch than they did in Congress or in corporate America. During President Clinton's presidency, no more than nine women were ever serving in the Senate, whereas 20 do today.

The share of women holding board seats on Fortune 500 companies has also risen over the last two decades, to 16.6 percent last year from 9.6 percent in 1995, according to Catalyst. The executive branch continues to have a larger share of women in senior roles than Congress or corporate America, but it has also changed less since the 1990s.

Title: President Trump Retweets Controversial Images Amidst Charlottesville Fallout

Article:

President Donald Trump started Tuesday morning by retweeting a series of controversial images and sources, ranging from a known conspiracy theorist to an image depicting violence against the media. The retweet storm came as critics questioned the timing of Trump's scripted statement denouncing white supremacists for their role in the violence in Charlottesville, which was issued 48 hours after his initial remarks chiding "many sides" were criticized as inadequate.

One of the retweets was from Jack Posobiec, an alt-right figure who has pushed the Pizzagate and Seth Rich conspiracy theories. Posobiec's tweet questioned why there was no similar outrage over the violence in Chicago, stating, "Meanwhile: 39 shootings in Chicago this weekend, 9 deaths. No national media outrage. Why is that?" The retweet remained on the president's account as of Tuesday morning.

Another retweet shared an image of a person holding a CNN sign being hit by a train, with the commentary, "Nothing can stop the # TrumpTrain!!" The picture was an altered version of an IndyStar editorial cartoon, which depicted a Democratic donkey trying to hold back the Trump train. The altered image was reminiscent of another controversial tweet, when the president posted a gif that depicted him body-slamming and punching CNN.

The retweet's timing was criticized by many social media users as in poor taste, just days after a 20-year-old alleged white nationalist drove a car into a crowd of people protesting the "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville – killing one and wounding 19 others in an incident Attorney General Jeff Sessions said appeared to fit the legal definition of domestic terrorism.

The retweet of the violent image was deleted Tuesday morning, though it's unclear why. The president has deleted tweets and retweets in the past.

In addition to the controversial retweets, Walter Shaub, the former head of the Office of Government Ethics, called on Congress to condemn the president given the recent violence in Charlottesville, Virginia. Trump also retweeted Mike Holden, who called the president a "fascist" in response to news that the president was "seriously considering" a pardon for former Arizona sheriff Joe Arpaio. Arpaio was found guilty of criminal contempt related to a racial profiling case – a controversial move in the immediate aftermath of Charlottesville.

Trump deleted his retweet of the accusation of fascism on Tuesday morning, but Holden's Twitter bio reads, "Officially Endorsed by the President of the United States. I wish that were a good thing."

Title: Marine Corps Delays Implementation of Pullup Test for Female Recruits

Article:

The United States Marine Corps has postponed the implementation of a new physical standard for female recruits, requiring them to perform three pullups, until next year. The decision was announced quietly through social media posts and an item on the Corps' own TV show, The Corps Report.

According to Lance Cpl. Ally Beiswanger, the delay is to gather more data and ensure all female Marines are given the best opportunity to succeed. The move comes as only 45% of female recruits tested at the end of boot camp were able to perform three pullups, while 99% of male recruits passed the test.

The three pullups is already the minimum requirement for all male Marines. The Corps states that upper body strength, demonstrated by the pullup test, is necessary for ground combat duties, such as pulling oneself out of a canal, climbing over mud walls, and carrying ammunition.

For years, female Marines have had to meet a different standard, an exercise called the "flexed arm hang." However, beginning in 2016, women in the Marine Corps and Army will be allowed to serve in infantry, armor, and artillery units.

Robert Maginnis, a retired Army lieutenant colonel, suggests that the delay indicates women are unable to meet the same standards. "Young women, in spite of all the training and all the best intentions, are not going to be the equal of young men in terms of upper body strength," Maginnis says. "You've got to have a lot of upper body strength to lift the stuff. Been there, done that."

Greg Jacob, a former Marine and advocate for military women, argues that women can build the strength they need for pullups. He has observed female Marines reaching the same standard as their male counterparts through consistent training.

The Marine Corps must do a better job of training women to reach the same standard as men, according to Jacob. A small number of female Marines have already demonstrated their ability to pass advanced combat training, including the pullup requirement.

Some Marine officers privately express concern that only a handful of female Marines will show interest in combat or be able to pass the course. Meanwhile, Lance Cpl. Ally Beiswanger, a Corps Report anchor, is working to improve her own pullup performance, aiming to complete 12 pullups. The larger goal of women in ground combat remains two years away.

Title: Supreme Court Clarifies Scope of Speedy Trial Clause in Criminal Proceedings

Article:

The Supreme Court of the United States has ruled that the "speedy" part of the Sixth Amendment's "right to a speedy and public trial" no longer applies once a defendant has been found guilty or pleads guilty to a crime. This decision was made in the case of Betterman v. Montana, where the Court upheld a Montana state court's ruling that sentencing is not part of the "speedy trial" period.

The case involved Brandon Thomas Betterman, who was sentenced to seven years in prison 14 months after pleading guilty to felony bail jumping in a Montana state court. The Court's opinion, delivered by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, stated that the Sixth Amendment's Speedy Trial Clause protects the accused from arrest or indictment through trial but does not apply once a defendant has been found guilty at trial or has pleaded guilty to criminal charges.

Criminal proceedings consist of three parts: an investigation prior to arrest, a charge and trial where the accused is assumed innocent until proven guilty, and finally, after a conviction, a sentencing. The Court's opinion noted that the language in all three of these stages - "accused," "convicted," "trial," and "sentencing" - have distinctly separate protections. The Court's opinion further clarified that the Sixth Amendment's Speedy Trial Clause applies only to the second period, from arrest or indictment through conviction.

The Court's decision means that the Sixth Amendment does not protect the accused during sentencing, but the Constitution may have other protections. The opinion noted that the Court may have not considered due process clause challenges in this case, leaving open the question of whether the Fifth and 14th Amendments might provide other protections during the sentencing phase.

Justice Sonia Sotomayor, in a concurring opinion, emphasized that the question of inordinately long sentencing times is an open one, and that Betterman's argument was valid but based on the wrong constitutional provision.

Title: Facebook CEO Zuckerberg Criticizes Twitter's Fact-Checking Policy, Rejects Role as "Arbiter of Truth"

Article:

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has criticized Twitter for attaching fact-check notices to President Trump's tweets, stating that privately-owned digital platforms should not act as the "arbiter of truth." In an interview with Fox News' Dana Perino, scheduled to air in full on Thursday, Zuckerberg expressed his disagreement with Twitter's policy.

"We have a different policy than, I think, Twitter on this," Zuckerberg said. "I just believe strongly that Facebook should not be the arbiter of truth of everything that people say online." He added, "Private companies probably should not be, especially these platform companies, should not be in the position of doing that."

Zuckerberg's comments come after President Trump warned social media giants that the federal government could "strongly regulate" or "close them down" if they continue to "silence conservative voices." In response, Zuckerberg stated, "I have to understand what they actually would intend to do. But in general, I think a government choosing to censor a platform because they're worried about censorship does not exactly strike me as the right reflex there."

Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey responded late Wednesday, stating, "We'll continue to point out incorrect or disputed information about elections globally. And we will admit to and own any mistakes we make." Dorsey further clarified, "This does not make us an 'arbiter of truth.' Our intention is to connect the dots of conflicting statements and show the information in dispute so people can judge for themselves."

On Tuesday, Twitter slapped a fact-check notification on one of Trump's tweets for the first time, cautioning users that despite the president's claims about mail-in voting, "fact checkers" say there is "no evidence" that mail-in voting would increase fraud risks and that "experts say mail-in ballots are very rarely linked to voter fraud."

Facebook has faced criticism in the past for failing to address controversial content on the platform, but it appears Zuckerberg has no plans to change the company's policy. Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg expressed a similar sentiment during a 2017 CNBC interview, asserting that the tech giant does not intend "to be the publisher and we definitely don't want to be the arbiter of the truth."

"We don't think that's appropriate for us," Sandberg said at the time.

Title: Secretary of State John Kerry Urges International Community to Increase Ebola Response Efforts

Article:

In a speech at the State Department on Friday, Secretary of State John Kerry called on world leaders to contribute more to the international Ebola response effort. Kerry warned that without a concerted effort by the international community, Ebola could become a long-term global health issue like HIV or polio.

Addressing a room of foreign ambassadors, Kerry emphasized the need for stronger commitments to combat the Ebola outbreak, which has been ongoing in Sierra Leone, Guinea, and Liberia for weeks and has spread to the United States and Europe.

"There is no country that is exempt from being able to do something to contribute to this effort and help make a difference," Kerry said. "And everything we do depends on how we coordinate our efforts as partners in how we contribute together."

Kerry praised a few countries for their contributions to the effort, including Cuba, a country that is historically a foe of the U.S. and often criticized by the State Department. Cuba, a country with a population of 11 million, has sent 165 health professionals, and plans to send nearly 300 more, Kerry noted.

The United Nations has called for $1 billion in funding for the Ebola response effort over the next six months. So far, only about a third of this need has been met, Kerry said.

"We live in a world of a lot of close calls, tough decisions on a daily basis -- difficult and contentious issues where you can have an honest disagreement about what the best course of action is, or about what the facts are, or the results of your decision may be," Kerry conceded. "Ebola is not one of them."

As of now, more than 4,000 people have died from the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. The World Health Organization estimates that there will be between 5,000 and 10,000 new Ebola cases per week in the region by the first week of December.

Title: Netanyahu and Erdogan Normalize Relations After Apology for Mavi Marmara Incident

Article:

In a significant development, Israeli Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan have agreed to normalize relations, marking an end to a six-year diplomatic rift. The conversation took place as United States President Barack Obama was concluding his visit to Israel.

The reconciliation occurred following Netanyahu's apology for the loss of life in the 2010 Mavi Marmara incident, in which nine Turkish activists were killed. The incident occurred when the Turkish-led flotilla, aiming to break Israel's blockade of Gaza, was intercepted by the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF).

The apology marked a break in a three-year deadlock, with both leaders agreeing to complete the agreement for compensation. According to a statement, Prime Minister Netanyahu expressed regret for any errors that may have led to the loss of life.

Erdogan's office reported that he accepted the apology and acknowledged the centuries-long strong friendship and cooperation between the Turkish and Jewish nations. The United Nations' report on the 2010 flotilla raid, which primarily sided with Israel, is noteworthy in this context.

The significance of this reconciliation may indicate growing concern among Syria's neighbors about potential spillover from the ongoing Syrian conflict. The exact cause of this concern remains unclear, but it may be related to recent claims of chemical weapons usage or other forms of escalation yet to be reported globally.

This development could potentially have implications for Iran, as it prefers its enemies in Tel Aviv and its enemies among anti-Assad Islamists to remain divided. The exact impact of this normalization of relations on the broader Middle Eastern political landscape remains to be seen.

Title: Federal Judge in Maryland Blocks Revised Travel Ban, Citing Religious Discrimination

Article:

A federal judge in Maryland has issued an injunction against President Trump's revised travel ban, citing religious discrimination. The ruling by Judge Theodore D. Chuang, an Obama appointee, came hours after a similar injunction was issued by another Obama-appointed judge in Hawaii.

Both judges have determined that the administration's attempt to restrict admission of visitors and would-be immigrants from Chad, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen is likely illegal. However, they have allowed restrictions to go into effect for North Korea and Venezuela, two non-Muslim countries.

Judge Chuang, like his Hawaii counterpart, had previously ruled that earlier versions of the travel ban were illegal. In his 91-page ruling, he stated that the current list of eight countries subject to severe restrictions is similar to the previous list of six, suggesting little has changed. The earlier ban applied to Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen. The new list, which was developed after months of study by the Homeland Security and State departments of nearly 200 countries' level of cooperation in information-sharing, drops Sudan and adds Chad, North Korea, and Venezuela.

Administration officials are already working on their appeal of the Hawaii ruling. The Supreme Court had been scheduled to hear arguments on the earlier version of the travel ban last week, but after Trump's revisions in September, they called off the hearing, stating that the lower courts needed to evaluate the new policy.

While Tuesday's ruling affects the country-specific travel ban, another part of the original executive order—a 120-day pause on refugee admissions—remains mostly in effect, with some court-ordered exceptions. The 120-day period expires at the end of this month, and analysts are waiting to see whether Trump tries to extend the pause. He has already reduced the overall refugee target from 110,000 people in 2017 to 45,000 in 2018.

Title: Immigrant Mother Seeks Contact with Separated Daughter; Fate of Separated Children Unknown

Article:

Lilian Merida-Galicia, a 23-year-old Guatemalan, and her 7-year-old daughter were separated by U.S. officials after crossing the U.S.-Mexico border in Arizona in mid-May. Since then, Merida-Galicia has been trying to learn her daughter's whereabouts, according to her attorney, Michael Avenatti.

In a note to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Merida-Galicia asked for a phone number to communicate with her daughter. An ICE officer replied, stating they did not have this information.

Merida-Galicia is one of many incarcerated immigrant mothers whose attorneys tell similar stories about chaotic situations in which the mothers don't know where their children have been taken or how to contact them. The mothers themselves could not be contacted due to difficulties in accessing detained immigrants.

President Donald Trump reversed course on Wednesday, abandoning his policy of separating children from parents who are apprehended for illegally crossing the U.S.-Mexico border. However, the fate of the more than 2,300 children already separated from their parents while Trump's policy was still in force remains unknown.

Avenatti, who has made headlines representing porn star Stormy Daniels in an unrelated lawsuit against Trump, said Merida-Galicia is among more than 60 immigrant parents he represents, and 80 percent of them do not know where their children are.

The federal government and Congress are scrambling to address the many unanswered questions raised by the hastily drafted executive order Trump issued on Wednesday.

Attorney Luis Cortes Romero in Kent, Washington, represents a Salvadoran woman who was separated in early May from her 11-year-old daughter with Down syndrome after the two crossed the U.S.-Mexico border in Texas. The woman is being held in Washington state and has decided she doesn't want to pursue asylum so that she can be deported and reunited with her daughter.

Trump suggested on Friday that some of the wrenching tales that have emerged from the border were fabricated by Democrats.

"We cannot allow our Country to be overrun by illegal immigrants as the Democrats tell their phony stories of sadness and grief, hoping it will help them in the elections," Trump tweeted.

Trump urged Republican lawmakers on Friday to drop their efforts to pass comprehensive immigration legislation until after the November congressional elections, flip-flopping on his appeal earlier in the week for Congress to act soon.

Trump has gone back and forth on ways to solve the country's immigration problems, which he blames on Democrats.

"Elect more Republicans in November and we will pass the finest, fairest and most comprehensive Immigration Bills anywhere in the world," Trump said on Twitter.

U.S. President Donald Trump speaks during an "Angel Families" meeting with victims of illegal immigration at the White House in Washington, U.S., June 22, 2018. (Photo by Kevin Lamarque)

All 435 House seats and a third of the 100-member Senate will be up for grabs in November. Democrats are hoping that discontent among voters with Trump's policies, including on immigration, will help the party make gains in Congress and flip control to Democrats in at least one chamber.

The House of Representatives on Thursday rejected a bill backed by conservatives that would have halted the practice of splitting up families and addressed other immigration issues. The House postponed until next week a vote on a more moderate bill after it failed to attract enough support for passage. But Trump's latest tweets could doom that effort.

"Game over," said Representative Mark Sanford, a Republican critic of Trump who came under withering attack from the president before losing his primary race this month.

"Without the president having legislators' backs, there's no way they're going to take the risks that would be inherent in a major reform bill," Sanford told CNN.

Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican who represents a majority Hispanic district in Florida and is not running for re-election, said Trump's tweets amounted to "schizoid policy making."

Even though the president has now ordered that families be kept together in detention during immigration proceedings, it remains unclear how and when those children already separated will be reunited with their parents, and where families will be held while the parents face criminal charges.

The U.S. Navy is drafting plans to house up to 25,000 immigrants on its bases and other facilities, at an estimated cost to taxpayers of about $233 million over six months, a U.S. official said on Friday. However, the Navy has not so far been asked to provide accommodation for migrants who have entered the United States illegally, and the official, who asked not to be named, stressed that the draft memo, which looks at setting up housing on Navy airfields in Alabama, was for planning purposes only.

The Department of Homeland Security on Friday filed a notice saying it may need up to 15,000 more beds to handle immigrant families. That would be a sharp increase from the 2,500 beds available for families in the last fiscal year.

Shares in private prison operators CoreCivic Inc and Geo Group rose on Friday as investors bet on increasing demand for their services after U.S. authorities asked about available capacity for the detention of immigrant families.

It was also unclear if the government would keep prosecuting cases against people caught crossing the border illegally. It was the administration's policy of zero tolerance - announced in April - that led to blanket prosecutions, including of adults traveling with children.

Title: U.S. President Donald Trump Faces Challenges Amidst Coronavirus Outbreak and Economic Downturn

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump is facing one of the gravest challenges of his political career as the coronavirus pandemic spreads, leaving fellow Republicans concerned that the White House's response and the impact on the economy could harm his re-election prospects.

U.S. stock market indexes, which Trump has touted throughout his term as evidence of his success, plunged into bear market territory on Thursday, a day after he tried to calm Americans' fears with an Oval Office address that promised economic stimulus and a 30-day travel ban for Europeans.

Some Republicans expressed concern that the measures were too little, too late for an administration that for several weeks minimized the risk of the COVID-19 respiratory disease caused by the virus that has killed at least 39 Americans.

"The president's early downplaying and politicizing of the virus hurt his credibility and will make people question the administration's readiness from now until the day this passes," said Mike DuHaime, a Republican strategist who ran Chris Christie's gubernatorial campaigns in New Jersey.

"The president's greatest strength has been the economy. If the stock markets continue to tank, and real people begin to hurt financially, it will hurt the president politically," DuHaime added.

Trump emerged triumphant last month after his Senate acquittal in a Democratic-led impeachment drive, ready to ride high on a strong economy as a crowded field of Democratic candidates bickered over who was best to take him on in November's general election.

The narrative quickly changed. Moderate Democrats in the past two weeks have consolidated their support behind former Vice President Joe Biden over liberal Senator Bernie Sanders. They are betting that Biden can draw support from across the party, as well as from suburban moderates and disaffected Republicans.

Biden seized the chance to offer a contrast to voters with his own coronavirus speech on Thursday. He lambasted the administration's handling of the crisis while seeking to portray himself as a steady, experienced hand in the face of a public health emergency.

"I'd rather be Joe Biden than Trump right now," said a Republican official close to the White House. "A month ago, Trump is looking at Bernie Sanders and a strong economy and rising favorability after impeachment. Coronavirus can not have a positive impact."

Trump's re-election campaign defended the president's actions and, in a statement, accused Biden of trying to "capitalize politically and stoke citizens' fears."

The growing threat from the coronavirus forced Trump on Thursday to reverse course and suspend his large campaign rallies.

"The safety, security, and health of the American People is President Trump's top priority right now," the Trump campaign said in a text.

Noting that Trump had called the disease a "foreign virus," Biden warned against "xenophobia" and said the coronavirus "does not discriminate based on national origin, race, gender, or ZIP code."

Biden laid out his own plan for dealing with the outbreak, including emergency paid sick leave for workers and widely available free testing for the virus, saying the number of tests should number in the "millions, not the thousands." The Trump administration has been criticized for failing to produce enough tests to meet demand.

"This virus laid bare the severe shortcomings of the current administration," the former vice president said in his 20-minute address from his home state of Delaware. "Public fears are being compounded by pervasive lack of trust in this president fueled by an adversarial relationship with the truth."

Sanders, who has vowed to remain in the race despite lengthening odds, also bashed Trump's handling of the crisis. He called for stronger action by government agencies to halt the spread of the virus and for measures such as paid sick leave and unemployment compensation for those affected.

"During a crisis, we must make sure that we care for the communities most vulnerable to health and economic pain," Sanders told reporters in his hometown of Burlington, Vermont.

A Trump supporter and fundraiser said the coronavirus outbreak had been politicized, like every issue in the United States.

"The battle lines are drawn," said Jim Worthington, a health club executive in Bucks County, Pennsylvania. "If you like Trump, you think he's done all the things right, like cutting off travel to China. If you're a Democrat, you think the opposite."

"I think he's been ahead of the issue, and the media has really overhyped it," Worthington said, adding that he thought the virus should be taken seriously.

The crisis has reshaped the contours of the presidential campaign. Democratic officials announced on Thursday that Sunday's televised debate between Biden and Sanders would be moved to Washington from Arizona.

Officials had already decided not to allow an audience into the debate hall, citing contagion concerns.

Biden, Sanders, and Trump have all canceled campaign events in recent days after warnings from public health officials about holding large-scale gatherings. Arizona, Florida, Illinois, and Ohio hold Democratic nominating contests on Tuesday.

Biden's campaign on Wednesday converted planned rallies in Florida and Illinois into "virtual" events and on Thursday said all staffers would begin to work from home beginning Saturday. Sanders' staffers will also work from home, reaching out to voters online instead of holding large events or door-to-door canvasses, his campaign said Thursday.

Late Thursday, Trump's campaign said its events would also all be conducted in a virtual setting, including moving training sessions online.

One Republican strategist said Trump's handling of the coronavirus was hurting him now but that it was too soon to gauge its impact on his long-term political prospects. Ipsos polling from March 9-10 showed 55% of Americans disapproved of Trump, while 40% approved, largely unchanged from the past year.

"A few weeks ago, the president's supporters were very dismissive of the virus. Today, they are being very silent," the Republican political operative said. "It's a supply chain issue, and he's the supply chain president. When he says we have test kits on the ground and we don't, that's a real problem."

Title: Ten Perspectives on President Trump's Alleged Use of Offensive Language Toward Haiti and African Countries

Article:

1. The use of derogatory language by President Donald Trump is a recurring theme in his public statements, a trait that serves as both a strength and a weakness. Columnist John T. Bennett argues that Trump's straightforwardness, though often politically incorrect, is a desirable quality, but regrets that it is not expressed in a more sophisticated manner.

2. The use of derogatory terms such as "s--thole" to describe countries is inappropriate for a U.S. president, according to Bennett. He suggests that if Trump had used terms like "dysfunctional" instead, it might have been a service to the people of these countries, as it would have acknowledged the corruption that is a significant problem in many African and Central American countries.

3. The connection between the moral state of an immigrant's country and their contribution to America is a contentious issue. Data from the Center for Immigration Studies indicates that 73% of households headed by Central American and Mexican immigrants use one or more welfare programs, compared to 32% of East Asian and 26% of European immigrants.

4. The labeling of President Trump as a racist, white supremacist, fascist, and anti-Semite by the media is a "Big Lie," according to Bennett. The most often provided "evidence" for Trump's racism is his alleged comments about the Charlottesville, Virginia, demonstrations, which the media misrepresents as him referring to neo-Nazis as "fine people."

5. The repeated descriptions of America as "systemically racist" by the left are not morally equivalent to the use of offensive language, according to Bennett. These descriptions are at least as offensive, less true, and not made in private or semi-private conversations but in the open, such as in college classes.

6. The validity of describing any countries as "s--tholes" is questioned by some, with columnist Ben Shapiro arguing that the argument against Trump's use of the term comes down to nicety, not truth.

7. Trump's openness to discussing issues with Democrats, despite their opposition to his presidency, is seen as a testament to his self-confidence and naivety.

8. Private speech, according to Bennett, should not be a concern or business of the public. He defends Hillary Clinton and former President Harry Truman against charges of anti-Semitism for allegedly making derogatory comments in private.

9. The Washington Post reports that President Trump also expressed a willingness to accept more immigrants from Asian countries, which could be interpreted as a counterargument to the racism charge.

10. The left's use of the term "racist" has lost credibility, according to Bennett. The University of California lists statements like "There is only one race, the human race" as a "microaggression," and the left labels anyone who opposes race-based quotas, all-black college dorms, or the Black Lives Matter movement as "racist." The left's use of the term "racist" has been overused, making it difficult to believe when real instances of racism occur.

Title: Trump Appoints Richard Grenell as Acting Director of National Intelligence

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced via a tweet that Richard Grenell, the current U.S. ambassador to Germany, will serve as the acting director of national intelligence (DNI). The role, which was vacated by Dan Coats in August 2019, is a position of significant responsibility, overseeing and integrating the U.S. intelligence community and advising the president and the National Security Council on intelligence matters concerning national security.

Grenell, a staunch supporter of Trump, has been vocal about his deep-seated suspicion and antipathy towards the intelligence community, which he has referred to as "Deep State" operatives who "hate Trump." In Grenell, Trump will have an unwavering loyalist overseeing the 17 U.S. intelligence agencies. Prior to his ambassadorship, Grenell spent much of the previous two decades as a political adviser to Republicans, as the longest-serving U.S. spokesperson to the United Nations, and as the founder of Capitol Media Partners—a media and public affairs consultancy. Grenell has never worked for an intelligence agency.

Grenell will also be the first openly gay Cabinet secretary. Before his confirmation as ambassador to Germany, Grenell spent much of the previous two decades as a political adviser to Republicans, as the longest-serving U.S. spokesperson to the United Nations, and as the founder of Capitol Media Partners—a media and public affairs consultancy. Grenell has never worked for an intelligence agency.

As ambassador to Germany, Grenell has been vocal in pursuing Trump's agenda, earning high praise from Trump and impassioned complaints from some German politicians. Grenell has already been Senate-confirmed as ambassador to Germany. It's not yet clear whether Trump will ultimately nominate him for the permanent DNI position, which would require another Senate confirmation. Trump has expressed a preference for "acting" positions, citing the flexibility they provide.

In his role as ambassador, Grenell has pressured German companies to cut business with Iran, urged Germany to increase its NATO contributions, and warned the Germans against participating in the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline with Russia. On Sunday, Grenell tweeted, "Any nation who chooses to use an untrustworthy 5G vendor will jeopardize our ability to share Intelligence and information at the highest level." Some German politicians objected to this Twitter diplomacy, but Grenell responded, "No one is threatening you. I could say you are threatening the US that we must continue as usual even when you make dangerous mistakes. We get to have our own policy too."

Trump and Grenell have had a contentious relationship with previous DNI Coats, with Trump blocking deputy DNI Sue Gordon from becoming acting director upon Coats' departure in August 2019.

Title: House Approves Stopgap Bill to Avert Government Shutdown, Boost Spending by $300 Billion Over Two Years

Article:

The United States House of Representatives approved a stopgap bill early on Friday to prevent a government shutdown and increase spending by approximately $300 billion over the next two years. The Senate had passed the bill hours earlier, ensuring a brief end to the government shutdown that commenced at midnight.

The House voted 240-186 in favor of keeping the government operational for another six weeks. This temporary measure allows lawmakers to begin drafting a comprehensive two-year deal that lifts spending caps on both defense and non-defense spending and suspends the debt ceiling for 13 months, enabling more borrowing.

President Trump announced his approval of the measure shortly before 9 a.m. on Friday, praising its support for the military and stating on Twitter that it would also benefit the economy.

Democrats applauded the significant increase in domestic spending, while Republicans celebrated a larger surge in defense funding. Speaker Paul D. Ryan commented, "First and foremost, this agreement accomplishes getting the resources that we need to rebuild our military." He also highlighted funding for items such as disaster relief and combating the opioid epidemic.

Individual lawmakers also pointed to various provisions in the bill that would benefit their home states, including tens of billions of dollars in disaster relief for Texas and special protections for dairy farmers that will aid Vermont.

However, some liberals criticized the lack of action to protect young illegal immigrant "Dreamers," with House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi reiterating her call for a free-ranging debate on the issue. "Why can't we extend the hand of friendship and protection to our Dreamers?" Mrs. Pelosi said.

Many House Democrats initially withheld their votes, but more than 70 eventually voted yes to help Republicans pass the bill. More than 60 Republicans still voted no, as some conservatives argued that the budget represented a retreat on the spending cuts the GOP had achieved over the past six years.

The bill passed the Senate with a 71-28 vote, with support coming relatively evenly from both parties. Sen. Rand Paul had temporarily halted the proceedings in the Capitol, causing the government shutdown—the second of the year. Mr. Paul, the Kentucky Republican who instigated the shutdown with his filibuster, expressed no remorse.

"Tonight, you could feel the frustration and embarrassment growing in Congress as we exposed the hypocrisy of Republicans who are joining in an unholy alliance and spending spree with Democrats at the expense of the American people and our party's supposed principles," Mr. Paul said. "Make no mistake, I will always stand up for fiscal responsibility, regardless of which party is in power, and I will continue to call the Republican Party home to the ideas that led Americans to trust us with government in the first place."

Title: Fatherless Upbringing and Mass Shootings: A Correlation Suggested in Analysis

Article:

A recent analysis suggests a correlation between mass shootings and the absence of a father figure in the perpetrator's upbringing. The piece, which has sparked debate, points out that many mass shooters have not lived full-time with their fathers, a trend that appears to be particularly prevalent among school shooters.

Expanding the definition of "mass shooter" to include drug and gang-related violence in urban areas, the fatherless connection becomes more apparent. For instance, in Baltimore, where violence is notoriously high, fewer than 20% of teenagers are being raised by married parents.

The author, who faced criticism from Media Matters for this observation, proposes a solution that does not involve legislative changes or government intervention. Instead, they suggest addressing the issue by "raising our own kids," emphasizing the importance of staying married, being present, and actively raising children.

The article acknowledges that this solution would not prevent all acts of violence, but it could have a broader and deeper impact than any legislative action. The negative consequences of fatherlessness are well-established, and the solution, on an individual level, is straightforward: stay married, be present, raise your kids, and love your kids.

The article argues that a boy growing up without a father will likely experience feelings of abandonment and confusion, which can evolve into deep, simmering anger. This anger, the author suggests, is often not fully understood by the boy, and it is compounded because fathers are best suited to teach their sons how to channel anger and aggression constructively.

Fathers, according to the article, also teach their sons how to take healthy risks, how to fight back and stand up to bullies, and how to respect women and protect the weak. While mothers can pass along these life lessons, the article suggests that something is lost in translation, and a mother can only tell a boy how to be a man, while a father can show a boy how to be a man.

The article concludes by stating that this correlation should not be used as an excuse for mass murderers, who are responsible for their actions regardless of their upbringing. However, it suggests that it is better for children not to have these disadvantages to begin with, and that parents, especially fathers, play a crucial role in this regard. The article encourages a focus on this aspect before worrying about passing new laws.

Title: Immigrant's Life Story Highlights the Human Element in U.S. Immigration Debate

Article:

The story of immigration in the United States is often lost amidst the political debates and polarizing rhetoric, as demonstrated in a poignant personal account by journalist and author Jon Meacham. The article, published in The New York Times, shares the life story of Meacham's father-in-law, Paul Gavora, an immigrant who escaped Communist Czechoslovakia and built a successful life in the United States.

Born in 1931 in the Slovakian village of Brezova pod Bradlom, Paul experienced the harsh realities of war and political upheaval at a young age. He was expelled from school for questioning Communist doctrine and, at the age of 13, swam the Danube to escape the Communists. After spending time in an Austrian refugee camp, he was sent to Germany to finish high school and eventually earned a scholarship to Colorado State University.

Paul's journey continued as he worked as a milkman, opened a grocery store, and eventually built a business empire in Fairbanks, Alaska. He had nine children and was active in his community. Meacham emphasizes that Paul's story is not about his wealth, but rather the opportunity the United States provided for him to carve out the life he wanted.

Meacham laments the current state of the immigration debate, which he believes has become toxic due to the identity politics of both the Left and the Right. Immigrants are often portrayed as either victims or villains, rather than human beings seeking to make the most of the American dream. Meacham argues that the immigration story in America is one of people leaving or fleeing their birthplaces for the freedom to try their best, a story that belongs to no political party but can be abandoned by either.

The article serves as a reminder of the human element in the immigration debate, emphasizing the need for empathy and understanding in the face of complex and contentious issues. Meacham's personal account humanizes the immigration issue, highlighting the stories of individuals like Paul Gavora who have contributed to and benefited from the United States.

Title: California Voters to Decide on Cage-Free Farm Animal Standards for Nationwide Producers

Article:

California voters will decide in November whether to implement stricter animal welfare standards for farm animals raised in cages. Proposition 12, a ballot measure, would require more spacious living conditions for pigs, veal calves, and egg-laying hens, not only for animals in California but also for those raised elsewhere and sold in the state.

The measure is a revised version of a 2008 law, which some farmers found difficult to interpret in practical terms. The Humane Society of the United States and other animal welfare organizations, such as the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the Sierra Club, the California Democratic Party, the United Farm Workers, and the Center for Food Safety, support Proposition 12.

The Yes on 12 campaign has raised $6.1 million as of Sept. 28, while the opponents, Stop the Rotten Egg Initiative, have raised about $566,000. The next financial reporting deadline is Oct. 25.

Dede Boies, a farmer who raises chickens, ducks, turkeys, and pigs on Root Down Farm in Pescadero, supports the measure. "The point for me is to raise animals in a way that they were intended to live," says Boies. "And to basically give them the best life possible."

Under Proposition 12, each farm animal will have a specific amount of floor space beginning in 2020: 43 square feet for a veal calf, 24 square feet for a breeding pig, and 1 square foot for an egg-laying hen. Cage-free conditions will be mandatory for hens by 2022.

The Association of California Egg Farmers and the National Pork Producers Council oppose Proposition 12 primarily because the measure applies to all veal, pork, and eggs sold in California, even when the animals are raised in other states.

Ken Maschhoff, a fifth-generation hog farmer based in Carlyle, Ill., who runs one of the largest pork operations in the U.S., opposes the measure. "I certainly have a bone to pick with those that try to force their agenda and those costs on to others that would just as soon not bear those," says Maschhoff.

When his pigs are pregnant, they are confined for about 100 days in a gestation crate that is 7 to 8 feet long and 24 to 30 inches wide. It does not allow the pigs to turn around. Maschhoff argues that confining pigs during pregnancy is both humane and cost-effective because it prevents fighting between the animals, allowing more piglets to survive in the womb.

Economists find it challenging to forecast exact pork price increases, but egg prices are easier to predict. Cage-free eggs are already available on store shelves and are usually priced at about 50 cents to a dollar more per dozen than conventional eggs.

University of California, Davis economist Dan Sumner estimates that egg prices will increase to $100 to $150 per year for consumers. Another factor that could affect egg prices is an uncertain future, as animal welfare groups such as People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals are opposed to the new ballot measure, stating that it does not go far enough to protect chickens, which can still be confined in barns if the proposal passes.

If voters approve Proposition 12 on Nov. 6, the battle over how much space farm animals need may not be over, as animal welfare groups such as PETA argue that the measure does not go far enough to protect chickens.

Title: Thousands Protest Across U.S. Over George Floyd's Death; Violence Erupts in Some Cities

Article:

Thousands of protesters took to the streets in various U.S. cities on Friday, demonstrating against the death of George Floyd, a Minneapolis black man who died after being pinned by a white police officer's knee. The protests, which have spread across the country, resulted in chaos and violence in some locations, including New York, Atlanta, and Detroit.

In New York, thousands of protesters gathered at Barclays Center, leading to numerous arrests and the shutdown of a major thoroughfare. In Atlanta, demonstrations turned chaotic, with fires burning in downtown Atlanta near the CNN Center, the network's headquarters. At least one police car was among several vehicles burnt, and windows were smashed at the CNN building, along with storefronts.

In Brooklyn, police made scores of arrests at Friday's massive demonstration, loading cuffed protesters onto city buses. In lower Manhattan, protesters were pressing for legislation outlawing the police "chokehold" used in the 2014 death of Eric Garner, another black man.

Bernice King, the youngest daughter of civil rights icon Martin Luther King Jr., implored people to go home after more than 1,000 protesters marched to the state capitol from the Centennial Olympic Park, blocking traffic and an interstate highway along the way.

In Atlanta, Bernice King delivered an impassioned speech, urging non-violence. "The only way we get what we really want is through non-violence," she said in her father's hometown. "Let's do this the non-violent way to deal with the evil of our time."

In other cities, protests remained peaceful. Hundreds marched peacefully through Detroit demanding justice for Floyd, while hundreds in the automotive capital joined a "March Against Police Brutality." In Denver, hundreds gathered at City Hall, spilling onto Interstate 45's entrance ramp, chanting "I can't breathe" and "No justice, no peace."

In Houston, Texas, protests over Floyd's death and the shooting death of a 19-year-old man during a protest on Friday night are ongoing. Police could not immediately be reached for comment regarding the shooting incident.

In Louisville, Kentucky, where Breonna Taylor was shot by police in her home in March, protests are expected to continue over her death and Floyd's.

The unrest follows the death of George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man who died after a white police officer knelt on his neck for nearly nine minutes during an arrest in Minneapolis on May 25. The officer, Derek Chauvin, has been charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter. Three other officers involved in the incident have not been charged.

Title: Supreme Court's 2014 Term Opens with Major Actions in Same-Sex Marriage, Voting Rights, and Abortion Cases

Article:

The Supreme Court commenced its 2014 term this month with significant actions on same-sex marriage, voting rights, and abortion cases, all decided in private without explanation or a breakdown of individual justices' votes. No oral arguments were held, and the two sides in each dispute submitted lengthy briefs outlining their arguments. However, when it came time to rule, the justices did not return the favor.

In just 17 words on Friday, the court cleared the way for same-sex marriages in Alaska. The justices also did not explain their actions or publicize their votes on the 11 new cases they decided to hear this winter or the more than 1,900 they turned down. They simply issued lists of grants and denials, leaving it to the lawyers and journalists who follow the court to speculate as to the reasons behind their decisions.

Eric Segall, a law professor at Georgia State University and co-author of the forthcoming book Supreme Secrecy, stated, "All of America wants to know what they're thinking, and they refuse to let us know." Segall added, "They want to stay mysterious. They want to stay aloof."

The new term's mystery began to emerge on its opening day. While the justices debated a case that hinged on a broken brake light, their decision not to consider any of the pending same-sex marriage cases was hidden inside an 81-page list of cases similarly denied their day in court.

In the two weeks since, the court has intervened in a series of cases on gay marriage, voting rights, and abortion to consider emergency appeals. It upheld, reversed, or altered lower court rulings without explanation; only the dissenters explained their votes.

This is normal operating procedure for the court, and the process has its defenders. If the justices announced their votes on every case they refused to hear, it could affect how future cases on the same topics are litigated and decided. And there simply is not time to write opinions for every emergency petition, which usually require rapid-fire rulings.

William Jay, an appellate lawyer at Goodwin Procter who argues frequently at the court, stated, "Whenever the Supreme Court writes something, those things can be quoted back at it. There is no such thing as a non-precedential Supreme Court opinion."

There have been instances in the past when the court saw fit to explain even emergency opinions. In 2009, it issued a three-paragraph explanation of its decision not to block the sale of Chrysler's assets during bankruptcy proceedings. And in a 2006 challenge to Arizona's voter ID law, the justices issued a complete ruling that has been cited frequently ever since.

However, these are the exceptions. More often, the court's orders read like the one clearing the way for same-sex marriages in Alaska: "The application for stay presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the court is denied."

Chief Justice John Roberts, now entering his 10th year on the court and seeking to solidify his central role in its administration and jurisprudence, appeared to be a key player in the past two weeks' somewhat furtive actions.

On same-sex marriage, he likely was among the justices who refused to grant any cases from Utah, Oklahoma, Virginia, Indiana, or Wisconsin. That cleared the way for gay and lesbian marriages in those states and others—the single biggest step yet taken toward a 50-state solution.

Roberts also appeared to be a decisive vote in the court's blocking of an anti-abortion law in Texas and a voter ID law in Wisconsin. He sided with the court's conservatives in approving lesser voting restrictions in Ohio.

Now that those decisions are in the history books, court-watchers are left to speculate about Roberts' actual role. Only the justices who dissented in those cases put their names to their actions. The two whose names never appeared—Roberts and Kennedy—assembled the majorities.

"Even lower courts seeking guidance for their own rulings have been left to guess why the justices issued certain rulings," says Nan Aron, president of the liberal Alliance for Justice. "All of this is harmful to democracy." Aron added, "In exchange for their lifetime appointments, the least that the justices owe the American people is clear explanations for their decisions and their conduct."

That's what the American people get in most instances, Roberts says. "We are the most transparent branch of government," he said in 2011. "Everything we do that has an impact is done in public…our decisions are out there."

However, the court has issued lengthy rulings in some blockbusters recently—upholding President Obama's health care law in 2012, striking down key sections of the Voting Rights Act and Defense of Marriage Act last year, and granting religious liberties to for-profit businesses and local governments this year.

But for the 7,500 or so cases that do not make it to the court's docket, the justices simply refuse to hear them without explanation, as they did in the recent gay marriage cases.

The court has "an enormous practical effect in society on people's lives by denying review," says Erwin Chemerinsky, founding dean of the University of California-Irvine School of Law and author of the recent book The Case Against the Supreme Court.

Chemerinsky notes that without offering explanations or vote counts, the justices in the last few weeks have affected the lives of thousands of voters in Ohio, Wisconsin, and North Carolina, thousands of women seeking abortions in Texas, and thousands of gay and lesbian couples in at least 11 states, from Virginia to Alaska.

"I can not think of any time when the Supreme Court was having such a practical effect through the preliminary orders they were issuing," he says. "The problem, when it's an order without an opinion, is it just seems arbitrary."

If the justices think they are avoiding controversy by issuing brief, unexplained orders, however, this fall's flurry of rulings may come back to haunt them. That's because the orders are temporary; lower courts still must hear the cases on the merits, and their rulings can be appealed back to the Supreme Court.

"The…decisions seem to be setting the court up to issue earth-shaking rulings on voting rights, abortion, and marriage equality in the heat of the next presidential election season," says Doug Kendall, president of the Constitutional Accountability Center. "In the name of prudence, the court is arranging to put itself at the center of the 2016 political maelstrom."

Title: Obama Acknowledges Fault in Healthcare.gov Debacle, Outlines Solutions

Article:

President Obama admitted on Monday that the launch of the federal healthcare enrollment website, Healthcare.gov, was "no excuse" for its botched opening, which threatens to undermine the ability to enroll seven million uninsured Americans in 2014. The administration, led by Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius, is responsible for the website's issues, which are attributed to both unexpectedly high demand and technical glitches.

The administration has yet to explain why they failed to anticipate the high demand or provide a clear account of the technical problems and the responsible parties. In response to the website's failures, the administration has implemented a two-part approach. They have enlisted information technology experts from both government and private sectors to work around the clock to resolve the technical issues. Additionally, they have expanded and publicized alternative methods for obtaining information and enrolling in health plans, such as increased call center staffing, in-person counselors (navigators), and downloadable applications for mail-in submission.

President Obama also made a commitment to those who encountered difficulties while applying through the federal website. He pledged that, in the coming weeks, they would personally contact those individuals to recommend completion of the application, shopping for coverage, and selecting a suitable plan.

Title: Apple, Urban Outfitters, Verizon, and T-Mobile Temporarily Close Retail Stores Worldwide Due to Coronavirus Outbreak

Article:

In response to the global coronavirus outbreak, Apple Inc (AAPL.O) has announced the temporary closure of all its retail stores, with the exception of those located in Greater China, for the next two weeks. This decision was followed by several other U.S. retailers over the weekend.

In a letter posted on the company's website late on Friday, Apple CEO Tim Cook wrote, "We will be closing all of our retail stores outside of Greater China until March 27."

Apparel retailer Urban Outfitters Inc (URBN.O), which owns brands including Anthropologie and Free People, announced on Saturday that it is closing all its consumer stores worldwide until at least March 28.

Verizon Communications Inc (VZ.N) has temporarily closed "a number of its stores" across the United States to expand its work-from-home policy to include some of its retail employees.

T-Mobile US Inc (TMUS.O) will temporarily close its stores located in shopping malls starting March 16.

Apple reopened all 42 of its branded stores in China on Friday as the number of new cases fell in the country where the coronavirus outbreak originated.

As of the latest count, over 153,000 people have been infected worldwide, and 5,788 have died.

Retailers are bracing for a potential blow to sales as virus-wary shoppers in Europe and the United States stay home. U.S. retailers including Macy’s Inc (M.N), Saks Fifth Avenue, and Gap Inc’s (GPS.N) Banana Republic have remained open to stem losses due to a steep drop in traffic.

Apple's hourly workers will continue to receive pay during this period, and online sales will continue as usual. Cook also stated, "In all of our offices, we are moving to flexible work arrangements worldwide outside of Greater China. That means team members should work remotely if their job allows."

Philadelphia-based Urban Outfitters also said it would continue to pay its store employees while stores are closed.

Title: Budget Deal Convenient for Congress, Criticized for Nation's Economic Impact

Article:

The recently agreed two-year budget deal between Sen. Patty Murray and Rep. Paul Ryan is being viewed as a convenient solution for members of Congress, but a less favorable outcome for the nation. The deal, which aims to forestall election year standoffs, has left out key provisions such as an unemployment extension, and includes measures that could potentially slow economic growth.

The convenience for Congress is primarily due to the fact that the agreement eliminates the possibility of major budget standoffs until at least 2015, thus avoiding the political drama and potential economic instability that has resulted from previous standoffs. However, the deal's impact on the nation is less positive.

One of the most significant omissions from the deal is the lack of an extension of unemployment benefits. As a result, more than 1 million laid-off workers will see their benefits cut off in 2014. According to the Congressional Budget Office, this will slow growth by 0.2 percentage points and reduce the number of jobs by around 300,000.

While Congress did reshuffle funds to make sequester cuts less painful, one item on the reshuffling list deserves special attention. The budget deal would require that federal employees increase their contributions to their retirement, effectively cutting their pay by another 1%. This cut comes on top of pay freezes that have effectively cut real wages by more than 5% over the last three years.

The biggest issue for most of the public is that this federal budget will continue to impose a drag on the economy by preventing the sort of growth that is needed to return to full employment. While the stimulus approved by Congress boosted growth and added between 2-3 million jobs, the steep deficit reduction of the last three years has slowed the economy, costing millions of jobs.

The economy still lacks a source of demand to replace the demand generated by the housing bubble. The budget deal negotiated by Murray and Ryan will do nothing to expand demand in the economy. The deal could have devoted funds to rebuilding infrastructure, retrofitting homes and businesses to make them more energy efficient, and improving healthcare and education. Instead, we see further cuts that will lead to deteriorating service and fewer jobs.

In the longer term, the nation can hope to replace the bubble-generated demand of the last decade with more net exports. This would come about through a lower-valued dollar that would make our goods more competitive internationally. However, a lower-valued dollar is not expected in the immediate future, meaning that as a simple matter of logic, the only way to replace the demand lost due to the collapse of the housing bubble is through the government.

In conclusion, the budget deal negotiated by Murray and Ryan is being criticized for its potential negative impact on economic growth and employment, particularly due to the lack of unemployment benefit extension and the increased retirement contributions for federal employees. The deal does not address key strategies for economic growth, such as infrastructure investment and energy efficiency projects.

Title: Grass-roots Opposition to Immigration Bill Lags Behind 2007 Levels

Article:

Grass-roots activists, who were instrumental in derailing the 2007 attempt by Congress to overhaul immigration laws, have yet to ignite a similar level of opposition this time around. Coordinated rallies last week to oppose the current bipartisan immigration legislation drew sparse crowds, with fewer than 10 people showing up for a protest in Dover, Del.

The current immigration bill, introduced by a group of senators known as the "Gang of Eight," would provide a pathway to citizenship to about 11 million people illegally in the U.S. and create new work visa programs. It would also require the Homeland Security Secretary to submit a border security plan before illegal immigrants gain provisional legal status, the first step in the legalization process. The plan does not have to be implemented for the process to begin, and a system for employment verification would come later.

Opponents of the bill say that, like the 2007 effort, it amounts to amnesty for lawbreakers and does not stem the flow of illegal immigration. Adding legalized immigrants to the workforce would disadvantage jobless Americans, they say.

This year's bill has not stirred as much opposition. It has more support from mainstream Republicans eager to improve the party's standing with the fast-growing Hispanic population, and from many evangelical Christian leaders. Also, a steep drop in illegal immigration in recent years has meant fewer television images of migrants sneaking into the country.

Protesters at the Phoenix offices of Sens. John McCain and Jeff Flake spoke last week against the immigration bill that the lawmakers helped write. However, prospects for the bill's passage appear mixed. The Senate legislation has not yet been tested in that chamber, and efforts by a bipartisan House group to write a similarly broad bill have not succeeded. The path-to-citizenship provision of the Senate bill could prove particularly troubling in the House.

Meanwhile, opponents promise to intensify their campaign. Rusty Childress, who leads "Remember 1986," a group named after the year of the last big immigration overhaul, said his group would start targeting a tea-party base that he said is "newly energized" since the IRS news broke.

A fierce backlash against the bill six years ago ultimately spelled its demise because it prompted lawmakers such as Georgia Republican Sens. Johnny Isakson and Saxby Chambliss, who helped draft sections of the measure, to withdraw support. "The backlash began as soon as an outline for a bill was announced, and it was relentless," said Joan Kirchner, a top aide to Mr. Isakson. Neither of the Georgia senators has taken a public position on this year's bill.

In recent weeks, Mr. Isakson's office has been receiving about 100 calls a day versus as many as 2,000 a day in 2007. The volume is expected to rise if a bill reaches the floor, Ms. Kirchner said, "but signs are it won't be as intense." Activists said they are planning a protest outside Mr. Isakson's Atlanta office in early June.

Michael Harrison, publisher of Talkers, a talk-radio trade magazine, said many influential hosts have "moved on" to discuss gun control, health care, and other "hit topics" because "the public's attitude is different on immigration."

Alan Ogushoff, who made protest calls to Mr. Chambliss's office in 2007, often several times a day, said he remains a foe of any legalization. But, the avid listener of conservative talk radio said, "I'm just going to let this happen and move on; I'm burned out fighting it."

Roy Beck, president of NumbersUSA, a group that channeled opposition to the 2007 bill into a barrage of calls and emails to lawmakers, agreed "there may be some fatigue" now. However, the group over the weekend said it unveiled TV and radio ads in 18 states opposing the bill. One radio script warning of the dangers of adding more potential workers says: "Jobs—20 million of our friends, family, and neighbors still can't find one."

Groups pressing for an immigration overhaul, such as businesses and undocumented youngsters, also have been more vocal. The Evangelical Immigration Table, made up of leaders of Christian groups, this week will launch a new round of national radio ads to promote the bill.

"This time, there is not as much emotion on our side," said Mr. Beck of NumbersUSA. But, "I do not know if that means there is less resolve."

Title: Record Number of People Sign Up for Health Insurance on HealthCare.gov Ahead of Deadline

Article:

President Barack Obama announced on Friday that more than 670,000 people signed up for health insurance on HealthCare.gov on Thursday, marking the highest number of enrollees since the launch of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) exchanges three years ago. This figure surpasses the 600,000 people who signed up last year on Dec. 15.

Despite technical issues that caused approximately 1 million people to leave their contact information as they were unable to access the site, the surge in signups prompted the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to extend the deadline for enrollment on the federal exchange until 11:59 PM PST on Dec. 19. HealthCare.gov handles enrollment for 38 states. Deadlines for state exchanges vary, but several allow enrollment for Jan. 1 coverage for a few more days.

Signups rose steadily this week, with more than 325,000 Americans selecting plans on HealthCare.gov on Monday and more than 380,000 Americans doing so on Tuesday, marking two of the biggest days in HealthCare.gov's history.

The administration has been actively promoting the law, as Republican members of Congress and President-elect Donald Trump have vowed to repeal it next month. Even with a repeal, individuals who do not have insurance through their jobs will still be required to buy it at least through 2017 and likely longer. A plan to replace the ACA could take several years.

Earlier this week, Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Burwell went on a four-city tour to Tampa, Orlando, New York, and East Newark, N.J., to meet with people who have benefited from the ACA and encourage Americans to get covered. In-person assistance is available at http://localhelp.healthcare.gov, and operators are available in English or Spanish 24 hours a day, seven days a week at 1-800-318-2596.

Title: Trump Suggests Rick Perry's Role in Ukraine Call, Amidst Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

President Donald Trump reportedly stated during a meeting that he did not initially want to make the call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, but did so at the request of Energy Secretary Rick Perry. This revelation comes as the president has maintained that his call with Zelensky was "perfect" and he did nothing wrong.

Three sources confirmed the president's comments, with one source recalling Trump saying, "Not a lot of people know this, but I didn't even want to make the call. The only reason I made the call was because Rick asked me to. Something about an LNG [liquefied natural gas] plant."

The president's remarks suggest he may be seeking to distance himself from responsibility or recast the pretext for the call. White House officials did not respond to requests for comment.

Another source on the call said Trump added that "more of this will be coming out in the next few days" — referring to Perry.

Text messages released this week between Trump administration officials and Andrey Yermak, a top aide to Zelensky, suggest that Trump's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, was a primary advocate for arranging the call. However, there is no mention in the text messages of Perry playing a role in making this call happen.

Perry, who is reportedly resigning by the end of this year, has become increasingly embroiled in congressional Democrats' impeachment inquiry. In May, Perry led a U.S. delegation to Ukraine for Zelensky’s inauguration in place of Vice President Mike Pence, and Democrats have begun to press Perry for more information about the trip and his conversations with Ukrainian leaders.

The House subpoena of Rudy Giuliani also seeks documents related to Perry's "involvement with Ukrainian leaders last spring." However, Perry told the Christian Broadcasting Network on Friday that, "as God is my witness," neither Joe or Hunter Biden's name ever came up.

Perry's spokeswoman, Shaylyn Hynes, told a news outlet, "Secretary Perry absolutely supported and encouraged the president to speak to the new president of Ukraine to discuss matters related to their energy security and economic development."

"He continues to believe that there is significant need for improved regional energy security—which is exactly why he is heading to Lithuania tonight to meet with nearly 2 dozen European energy leaders (including Ukraine) on these issues," Hynes added.

The White House acknowledged the conference call in a Friday readout that said participants included Minority Leader McCarthy, Whip Steve Scalise, Republican Conference Chair Liz Cheney, and GOP leaders on key House committees—and that they discussed Friday's jobs report, the economy, and concerns about Democrats' impeachment inquiry.
