Title: Trump Suggests Trump National Doral Resort as Venue for 2020 G7 Summit

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has proposed hosting the 2020 Group of Seven (G7) summit at his own Trump National Doral golf resort near Miami, Florida. The G7 countries traditionally take turns hosting the summit, often choosing locations that showcase areas of natural beauty.

During this year's G7 summit in Biarritz, France, Trump highlighted the resort's size and proximity to Miami International Airport as reasons for its suitability. He stated, "They love the location of the hotel, they also like the fact it's right next to the airport for convenience. And it is Miami, Doral, Miami, so it is a great area."

Trump added that a final decision has not been made yet, but noted that no other location has come close to competing with the resort, particularly in terms of location.

In a subsequent news conference, Trump asserted that he would not directly benefit financially from hosting the G7 at his resort, stating, "From my standpoint, I'm not going to make any money. In my opinion, I'm not going to make any money."

Trump has attended three G7 summits, in Italy, Canada, and France. In the past, the meetings have been held at locations far from airports that can accommodate Air Force One, requiring the president to be transported by helicopter or a smaller plane. Trump noted the convenience of the Doral resort's proximity to an airport.

Although Trump criticized the need to switch planes during the France summit, he praised the setup in Biarritz, citing the conference center's architecture and room design. However, Trump did not indicate any intention to invite unexpected guests, as France did by inviting Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif for talks on the sidelines of the gathering.

Title: Understanding the "Three R's" of Police Reform: Reduce, Reinvent, and Redeploy

Article:

As the debate over police funding gains momentum across the United States, many Americans are seeking clarity on the concept of "defunding the police." While some interpret it as a call for the complete abolition of law enforcement, others view it as a specific set of policy proposals aimed at reforming the police force.

One such proposal, as presented by Randal Mayer, a former Cato policy analyst and justice reform advocate, outlines the "three R's of police reform": Reduce, Reinvent, and Redeploy.

The "Reduce" component involves cutting expenditures on militarized equipment, over-policing minor violations, and militarized training. Instead, funds would be allocated towards clearing backlogs of rape kits and increasing the number of detectives for investigating serious and violent crimes, which are often left unsolved. Additionally, states would reduce officers with poor records, and implement subsidized malpractice insurance for police, making them more accountable for wrongdoing.

The "Reinvent" aspect focuses on transforming police departments into community-focused organizations that prioritize de-escalation training and culture. This includes changing military-style rankings, recruitment tactics, and the overall culture of police departments, as well as altering engagement rules to minimize potential harm to suspects. Furthermore, it involves redefining the concept of "calling the police" to prioritize help and non-fatal conflict resolution over a SWAT-style response to situations such as mental health check-ins.

Lastly, the "Redeploy" component entails deploying newly trained and cultured police in the community to maintain law and order, while holding police accountable for their conduct and actions.

Regardless of one's stance on the "defund the police" issue, these proposals raise questions worth considering, such as the role we want police to play in our communities and the culture we want our law enforcement to embody.

To stay updated on these and other issues, subscribe to The ███ newsletter here.

Title: Armed Protesters Occupy Oregon Wildlife Refuge, Demand Release of Local Ranchers

Article:

A group of armed protesters, now known as Citizens for Constitutional Freedom, have taken control of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon. The group, led by Ammon Bundy, son of Cliven Bundy who was involved in a similar standoff in 2014, is demanding an end to what they perceive as "abuses" against local ranchers Dwight and Steven Hammond.

The Hammonds were convicted of arson in 2012 for fires that occurred on federal land in 2001 and 2006. Despite serving their original sentences, an appellate judge ruled in October that the terms were too short under federal minimum sentencing laws. The Hammonds were ordered to serve four more years in prison, with Dwight and Steven arriving at the Terminal Island Federal Correctional Institution on Monday afternoon.

In a statement, the Hammonds' attorneys said, "Dwight and Steven Hammond respect the rule of law. They have litigated this matter within the federal courts for over five years and, in every instance, have followed the order of the court without incident or violation."

Ammon Bundy accused federal officials of launching an "attack" on the Hammonds for refusing to sell their land. The protesters took over the refuge on Saturday after participating in a peaceful rally.

Harney County Sheriff Dave Ward has criticized the protesters, stating, "These men came to Harney County claiming to be part of militia groups supporting local ranchers, when in reality these men had alternative motives to attempt to overthrow the county and federal government in hopes to spark a movement across the United States."

The FBI has called for a "peaceful resolution" to the standoff, but has not provided specific details about their response due to "safety considerations for both those inside the refuge as well as the law enforcement officers involved."

Ammon Bundy's brother, Ryan, stated that the protesters plan to remain at the refuge as long as necessary. If the situation becomes violent, he attributes it to the federal government's actions. "We're here to restore order, we're here to restore rights, and that can go peacefully and easily," Ryan Bundy said.

The Hammonds have claimed that they lit the fires in 2001 and 2006 to reduce the growth of invasive plants and protect their property from wildfires. However, prosecutors maintain that the fires were set to cover up poaching activities.

The ongoing dispute between the federal government and some Westerners over the use of public lands dates back to the 1970s and the "Sagebrush Rebellion," a movement by Western states like Nevada to increase local control over federal land. Critics of the push for more local control have argued that the federal government should administer the public lands for the widest possible uses, including environmental and recreational purposes.

Title: Trump Appoints Kellyanne Conway as Counselor, Establishing Three Power Centers in His Administration

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump has appointed Kellyanne Conway as his counselor, installing her as the highest-ranking woman in the White House. This move, along with the appointments of Sean Spicer as press secretary, Jason Miller as communications director, Hope Hicks as strategic communications director, and Dan Scavino as social media director, has established three competing power centers in the Trump administration.

In a statement, Trump praised Conway, stating, "Kellyanne Conway has been a trusted advisor and strategist who played a crucial role in my victory. She is a tireless and tenacious advocate of my agenda and has amazing insights on how to effectively communicate our message. I am pleased that she will be part of my senior team in the West Wing."

Conway, who joined Trump's campaign as it was mired in controversy over the summer and managed it to a surprise victory last month, had previously expressed hesitation about accepting a White House role due to the time it would take her away from her four young children. However, she ultimately accepted the position, citing Trump's persuasive nature.

In her new role, Conway will work with senior leadership to effectively message and execute the administration's legislative priorities and actions. She will also continue to play a role in communications, alongside Spicer, Hicks, Miller, and Scavino.

Conway's duties and responsibilities will not be modeled after any particular predecessor but will be specific to Trump's administration. She is expected to continue serving as a "discreet advisor" and support Trump in his effective connecting and communicating with America.

Conway's appointment follows weeks of rumors and jockeying for position among Trump's campaign veterans and supporters. Some longtime aides have expressed concern about being frozen out in favor of more recent hires like Conway and Miller and members of the GOP establishment like Spicer and incoming White House chief of staff Reince Priebus.

The flurry of announcements on Thursday ended with the appointment of Steve Bannon as chief strategist, setting up three competing power centers in the Trump administration: Priebus as chief of staff, Bannon as chief strategist, Conway as counselor, and Spicer as press secretary.

Title: Clarification on President Trump's Remarks at Press Conference

Article:

In a press conference on Friday, President Donald Trump discussed job numbers and the role of the National Guard in limiting damage caused by riots and looting. Several news outlets, including ABC News, Business Insider, the Independent, and the New York Daily News, reported that Trump said he hoped George Floyd, a Black man who died in police custody, was looking down from heaven and was happy about the improving job numbers.

However, a closer examination of the president's remarks reveals that Trump was not referring to the jobs numbers when he mentioned George Floyd. The comments in question came immediately after Trump discussed the role of the National Guard in limiting damage caused by riots and looting, contrasting places like Minnesota, where the National Guard was active, with New York.

Trump said:

"Equal justice under the law must mean that every American receives equal treatment in every encounter with law enforcement, regardless of race, color, gender, or creed. They have to receive fair treatment from law enforcement. They have to receive it. We all saw what happened last week. We can't let that happen. Hopefully George is looking down right now and saying, 'This is a great thing that's happening for our country.' This is a great day for him. This is a great day for everybody. This is a great day for everybody. This is a great, great day in terms of equality."

While there are reasonable arguments to be made that Trump's comments were tone-deaf, given that he mentioned "George" immediately after talking about "equal justice under the law" and "fair treatment from law enforcement," and then followed by calling it a "great day in terms of equality," it is clear that Trump was referring to equal justice under the law when he mentioned Floyd. He was not "imagining George Floyd's reaction to the jobs numbers."

Title: Political Polarization and Income Inequality: A Growing Connection

Article:

A new study published in the Journal of Elections, Public Opinion and Parties suggests that political polarization is a significant factor contributing to income inequality in the United States. The study, which focuses on the economic priorities of the two major American political parties, concludes that the partisan difference in policy reflects the redistributive impact of these policies on the core constituents of the Democratic and Republican parties.

According to the study, Democrats are primarily concerned with unemployment, while Republicans focus on inflation and wages. This seesawing of economic priorities, the study argues, leads to "another pathway by which inequality is transmitted."

Gillian B. White, writing for The Atlantic, notes that this mounting polarization in America may result in political leaders prioritizing their core supporters, potentially leaving others economically disadvantaged.

This finding is not unique to this study. A Princeton study, which looked at voter partisanship and income, found that from 1956 to 1996, partisanship has become more stratified by income. In recent years, party affiliation has reportedly become directly tied to one's tax bracket.

Another study, released last year by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, found a link between income inequality and political polarization. The study concludes that both income inequality and political polarization are endogenous (or internal) variables that feed back on each other.

While the idea that party polarization is negatively impacting the fight to curb income inequality is not new, it is important to remember that this wasn't always the case. Historically, both parties had a mixture of rich and poor constituents that voted their interests, maintaining an economic balance for much of the second half of the 20th century.

However, this is no longer the case, and such a change isn't doing the economy any favors. The studies suggest that the increase in political polarization and income inequality began in the 1970s.

Title: Former President George W. Bush Endorses Senate Incumbents in 2016 Election

Article:

Former President George W. Bush has announced his intention to support several Republican incumbent senators in the 2016 election, marking a shift from his previous political abstention since the end of his second term in 2008. The New York Times reports that Bush will be campaigning for Sens. Roy Blunt (R-MO), Ron Johnson (R-WI), and Rob Portman (R-OH) in the coming weeks.

Bush has also participated in fundraisers for Sens. Kelly Ayotte (R-NH) and John McCain (R-AZ). This decision to engage in the election cycle comes as his approval ratings seem to be on the rise, with 52 percent of Americans having a favorable impression of him in a 2015 CNN poll, up from around a third of the public approving of him in 2009.

The shift in Bush's political involvement may be due to the unfavorability of the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, Donald Trump. According to a new Washington Post/ABC News poll, Trump's disapproval rating has reached an all-time high at 70 percent. This has caused some senators in tight races to distance themselves from Trump, even retracting previous endorsements.

Sen. Kelly Ayotte (R-NH) has stated that she will "support, but not endorse" Trump. Sen. Ron Johnson (R-WI) echoed Ayotte's sentiment, saying, "To me, support versus endorse are two totally different things. I intend to support."

Last month, both George W. and George H.W. Bush stated they had no plans to endorse Trump as the presidential candidate or attend the Republican National Convention in Cleveland this summer. Now, the 43rd president hopes to use his influence to maintain the Republican-held Senate as a "check and balance" on the White House. The potential president he refers to was not specified.

Title: US Attorney General William Barr Refuses to Testify Before Democratic-led House Judiciary Committee on Russia Inquiry

Article:

U.S. Attorney General William Barr has declined to testify before the Democratic-led House Judiciary Committee regarding his handling of the Russia inquiry. The standoff between the committee and the Justice Department raises the possibility that Barr, the nation's top legal official, could be held in contempt of Congress.

The Justice Department also stated that it would not comply with a subpoena issued by House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler for an unredacted version of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report and files from the investigation.

On Wednesday, Barr was questioned by a Senate panel about his decision to clear President Donald Trump of obstruction of justice. His defense of his actions before the Republican-led Senate Judiciary Committee followed Mueller's expressed frustration over the report summary. Mueller is expected to testify to Congress later this month.

In a statement, the Department of Justice said that Nadler had imposed conditions on the House Judiciary Committee hearing that were "unprecedented and unnecessary." The department argued that the planned move to have attorneys question Barr was unnecessary because most of the committee members were lawyers.

However, Nadler told reporters that Barr was afraid to testify on Thursday, stating, "He is terrified of having to face a skilled attorney." He added, "We plan on subpoenaing him if he decides not to show up. He can run but he can't hide."

Barr testified for the first time on Wednesday since the release of Mueller's 448-page report. The special counsel did not establish any collusion between the Kremlin and the Trump campaign. However, the report did not exonerate the president of obstruction of justice. It concluded that the Republican president had repeatedly intervened with an inquiry that he feared would doom his presidency.

Barr, who was appointed by Trump, told the Senate Judiciary Committee he was "frankly surprised" Mueller did not reach a conclusion on whether the president had tried to obstruct justice. The attorney general added that he was "absolutely" confident in his own judgment that Trump did not unlawfully attempt to impede the investigation.

Barr's testimony came after a letter he had received from Mueller was made public. In the document, the special counsel stated that Barr's summary "did not fully capture the context, nature, and substance" of his report's findings, and caused "public confusion about critical aspects of the results of our investigation." The letter, dated March 27, expressed Mueller's frustration that Barr had not released the executive summaries prepared by the special counsel's team.

During the hearing, Barr said that Mueller was not concerned with the accuracy of the summary, but with how it was being reported by media. "My understanding was his concern was not the accuracy of the statement of the findings in my letter, but that he wanted more out there to provide additional context to explain his reasoning and why he did not reach a decision on obstruction," he said.

Barr argued that the objections to his summary should be nullified by the release of the report itself, calling the controversy surrounding the summary, and the consequent hearings, "mind-bendingly bizarre." "I made clear from the beginning that I was putting out the report, as much of the report as I could, and it was clear it was going to take three weeks or so, maybe four," Mr. Barr said.

Title: Trump Defends Business Dealings in Russia, Calls Them "Very Legal & Very Cool"

Article:

President Donald Trump defended his actions pursuing a business deal in Russia, stating that they were "very legal & very cool" as he began his day at the G-20 summit in Argentina on Friday.

In a series of tweets, Trump reiterated his defense from Thursday, saying he was doing nothing wrong in running his business during the 2016 presidential campaign. The controversy over Trump's pursuit of a Trump Tower in Russia resurfaced after his former personal attorney, Michael Cohen, pleaded guilty to making false statements about his involvement in pursuing the deal.

Trump tweeted, "I am a very good developer, happily living my life, when I see our Country going in the wrong direction (to put it mildly). Against all odds, I decide to run for President & continue to run my business-very legal & very cool, talked about it on the campaign trail... Lightly looked at doing a building somewhere in Russia... Put up zero money, zero guarantees and didn’t do the project. Witch Hunt!"

Trump called Cohen a "liar" and a "weak person" shortly after news broke earlier Thursday that Cohen had pleaded guilty to making false statements to Congress in a deal with special counsel Robert Mueller, a significant development in the investigation into whether the Trump campaign colluded with Russia during the 2016 election.

Cohen appeared in federal court in Manhattan Thursday where he entered a guilty plea to making misstatements to Congress in closed-door testimony last year about his contacts with Russians during the 2016 presidential campaign.

Trump's dealings with Cohen, while serving as a senior executive in Trump's global empire, include several projects thought to be of interest to Mueller's prosecutors, most notably the pursuit of a Trump Tower project in Moscow during the presidential campaign.

According to court documents, Cohen falsely told Congress the Moscow project ended in January 2016. He then continued to look into business plans on that deal, according to the court filing. Cohen made false statements "in hopes of limiting the ongoing Russia investigations," according to the filing signed by Mueller.

Trump insisted there would not have been anything wrong with continuing business dealings during the campaign. "Now, here's the thing, even if he was right, it does not matter, because I was allowed to do whatever I wanted during the campaign," Trump said. "There was a good chance that I would not have won, in which case I would have gotten back into the business, and why should I lose lots of opportunities?" Trump said.

Trump said he ultimately decided to pass on the project "for a lot of reasons," but primarily because he was focused on running for president. "It lasted a short period of time. I did not do the project. I decided not to do the project," Trump said. "This deal was a very public deal. Everybody knows about this deal. I was not trying to hide anything, okay?"

When asked why, if Cohen is "weak" and a "liar," the president kept a close relationship with him for over a decade, Trump gave a vague response. "Because a long time ago he did me a favor," Trump said.

Despite the plea deal, Trump said he's "not worried at all" about what Cohen might be telling Mueller. Cohen has spent over 70 hours in interviews with Mueller's team since coming to another plea deal in August with federal prosecutors in the Southern District of New York that in which Cohen implicated Trump in campaign finance felonies.

Speaking to reporters on Capitol Hill, Democratic Rep. Adam Schiff, the incoming chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, called Thursday's news a "very significant plea and statement."

"It means that when the president was representing during the campaign that he had no business interests in Russia, that that wasn’t true, and when Mr. Cohen testified before our committee, as well as the Senate, and made representations about when the business dealing with Russia stopped, that wasn’t true," Schiff said.

"This, I think, only underscores the importance of our bringing back Mr. Cohen before our committee, but also looking into this issue of whether the Russians possess financial leverage over the president of the United States," he said.

Trump, as he did Thursday, has previously denied that he has any business deals with Russia, tweeting shortly before he was inaugurated, "I HAVE NOTHING TO DO WITH RUSSIA -- NO DEALS, NO LOANS, NO NOTHING!"

Title: Saudi Court Sentences Five to Death, Three to Prison in Jamal Khashoggi Murder Case

Article:

Saudi Arabia's criminal court has sentenced five individuals to death and three to prison over the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, but a United Nations (U.N.) investigator has accused the kingdom of making a "mockery" of justice by allowing the masterminds of the killing to go free.

A Saudi court, in a ruling that contradicts the findings of a U.N.-led investigation, rejected the premeditated nature of the killing, stating it was carried out "at the spur of the moment." Saudi Deputy Public Prosecutor and spokesman Shalaan al-Shalaan said the court dismissed charges against three of the 11 people tried, finding them not guilty.

The U.S., a critic of Saudi Arabia's handling of the killing, called the verdicts "an important step" in holding those responsible accountable. The U.S. will continue to press for full accountability, according to another senior U.S. official. Khashoggi, a U.S. resident and critic of Saudi Arabia's de facto ruler Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (MbS), was last seen at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on Oct. 2, 2018, and his body has not been found.

A source familiar with U.S. intelligence assessments said key U.S. government agencies rejected the validity of the court proceedings, and CIA experts still believe the crown prince personally ordered, or at least approved of, the killing. The five men condemned to death were essentially foot soldiers in the killing, while two senior security officials acquitted played a more significant role.

A Saudi prosecutor said there was no evidence connecting one of those senior officials, Saud al-Qahtani, to the killing, and the court dismissed charges against Ahmed al-Asiri, a former deputy intelligence chief.

The U.N.-led inquiry, published in February, reported that the evidence pointed to "a brutal and premeditated killing, planned and perpetrated" by Saudi officials. The publisher of the Washington Post, a newspaper for which Khashoggi wrote a column, said the lack of transparency and the Saudi government's refusal to cooperate with independent investigators suggested "a sham trial."

Human rights group Amnesty International said the verdict was a "whitewash" that failed to address the Saudi authorities' involvement or the location of Khashoggi's remains. However, one of Khashoggi's sons said the verdicts had been fair to his children.

Last November, the Saudi prosecutor said Qahtani, a former high-profile Saudi royal adviser, had discussed Khashoggi's activities before he entered the Saudi consulate with the team that went on to kill him. Both Qahtani and Asiri were dismissed from their positions, but while Asiri was tried, Qahtani was not. On Monday, Shalaan said Asiri has been tried and released due to insufficient evidence, and Qahtani had been investigated but was not charged and had been released.

The trial proceedings were held in secretive sessions in the capital Riyadh, and none of the names of the defendants was immediately released. Agnes Callamard, the U.N. special rapporteur for extrajudicial summary or arbitrary executions, said the trial verdict was a "mockery" of justice. "The hit-men are guilty, sentenced to death. The masterminds not only walk free, they have barely been touched by the investigation and the trial," she said on Twitter.

Title: US Repatriates Hundreds of Citizens from Coronavirus-Stricken Cruise Ship in Japan; China Reports Increase in Cases

Article:

Two planes carrying approximately 400 US citizens, who were on board the Diamond Princess cruise ship in Japan, have arrived in the United States. One plane landed at a US Air Force base in California, and the other in Texas. The passengers will be isolated at military facilities for a 14-day quarantine period.

The Diamond Princess, with around 3,700 passengers and crew, has been in quarantine since February 3. The ship was placed in quarantine in Japan's port of Yokohama after a man who disembarked in Hong Kong was found to have the virus.

Meanwhile, China has reported 2,051 new cases in the past 24 hours, with 94% of the new cases originating from Hubei province, the epicenter of the outbreak. As of the latest reports, more than 70,600 people across China have been infected by the virus, with 1,771 deaths. Most new cases and deaths have been reported in Wuhan, Hubei's largest city.

In Japan, a public gathering to celebrate the birthday of new Emperor Naruhito later this week has been cancelled due to concerns over the spread of the virus. Additionally, organisers of the Tokyo marathon due to take place on March 1 have cancelled the amateur part of the race, affecting some 38,000 runners, after cases of the virus were confirmed in the city. Only elite runners will be allowed to take part.

China's National People's Congress standing committee is scheduled to meet next week to discuss a possible delay of this year's Congress, the Communist Party's most important annual gathering, due to the outbreak.

At the weekend, an American woman tested positive for the virus in Malaysia after leaving a cruise ship docked off the coast of Cambodia. There are concerns for other passengers on the cruise, who are now dispersed around the world.

A Russian woman who was ordered to go back to a quarantine facility by a St Petersburg court has returned to hospital. Last week, Alla Ilyina escaped from the facility after testing negative three times for the virus, but was told to remain quarantined for two weeks.

More than 300 passengers were repatriated voluntarily, according to the US State Department. Fourteen of them were reported during transit to have tested positive for the virus and were being kept separate from the other passengers. They will all undergo a 14-day quarantine, on top of the time they have already spent confined on the ship.

US officials later said 13 of the passengers thought to be "high risk" were sent on to a special facility at the University of Nebraska in Omaha. At least 40 US citizens who were already showing symptoms prior to the evacuation were not allowed on the planes and would be treated in Japan.

Some Americans have declined to be evacuated, preferring to wait until the ship quarantine comes to an end on February 19. Passenger Matt Smith, a lawyer, said he would not want to travel on a bus to the plane with possibly infected people.

According to official figures for February 16, 100 people died from the virus in Hubei, down from 139 on Saturday. The Chinese authorities are tightening curbs on movement to combat the outbreak. People in Hubei province, which has 60 million people, have been ordered to stay at home, though they will be allowed to leave in an emergency.

In addition, a single person from each household will be allowed to leave the building or compound they live in every three days to buy food and essential items. On housing estates, one entrance will be kept open, guarded to ensure that only residents can enter or leave.

All businesses will stay closed, except chemists, hotels, food shops, and medical services. There will be a ban on the use of private cars, but vehicles used for the delivery of essential goods are exempt.

In the Chinese capital, Beijing, authorities have ordered everyone returning to the city to go into quarantine for 14 days or risk punishment. China's central bank will also disinfect and store used banknotes before recirculating them in a bid to stop the virus spreading.

New cases spiked last week after a change in the way they were counted, but have been falling since. National Health Commission spokesman Mi Feng said the figures showed China was managing to curb the outbreak.

Taiwan has reported a death from the illness - a taxi driver, 61, who had not travelled abroad recently but had diabetes and hepatitis B, Health Minister Chen Shih-chung said. The minister said many of his passengers had come from China.

Outside China, there have been more than 600 cases in nearly 30 countries. Four others have died outside mainland China - in France, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Japan. The virus is a new strain of coronavirus and causes an acute respiratory disease, which has been named Covid-19.

For further information or to speak to a BBC journalist, please contact us via the following methods: [contact information].

Title: Hong Kong Protests: Global Support for Demonstrators and Calls for U.S. Action

Article:

Hong Kong experienced a lockdown on Tuesday, with barricades in the city center, shuttered stores, and a heavy riot police presence, as authorities attempted to prevent protests from overshadowing China's National Day festivities in Beijing. The former British colony has been experiencing nearly four months of street clashes and demonstrations.

The protests have garnered worldwide attention, with protesters using a DIY approach to reach a global audience. Celebrity supporters testify in high-profile settings, crowdfunded media campaigns aim to keep the issue in the spotlight, and viral videos, catchy slogans, and a movement anthem and flag help magnify the message on social media.

The protests are a response to concerns that Beijing and its selected local government are violating the 1984 Sino-British Joint Declaration, which guaranteed Hong Kong's autonomy. Residents fear they are losing the political system they inherited from Britain, a system they know and trust.

The people of Hong Kong are sending a clear message to the Chinese government: they do not want the political system Beijing is offering; they want freedom and democracy. The United States is being called upon to answer this call with moral and diplomatic support and to work diligently to ensure democracy and human rights in Hong Kong.

The opportunity to turn the tide against tyranny is one that is not to be squandered. Over the last year, millions of people have risked their lives to challenge tyrannical regimes around the world, including in Venezuela, Sudan, and Algeria. The protestors in Hong Kong understand the history of tyranny and still choose to stand in the street and fight for their future.

The United States is being urged to immediately pass the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act of 2019. This legislation would proactively enshrine American support for Hong Kong's democracy and autonomy into law and send a powerful symbolic message to the people of Hong Kong that American support for Hong Kong is more than just empty words. The bill would require the State Department to annually certify and report to Congress whether Hong Kong's status of autonomy and the government's adherence to protecting civil liberties and upholding the rule of law justify its continued special status. The Commerce Department would also submit an annual report to Congress that determines if China is exploiting Hong Kong to circumvent U.S. sanctions and export controls. This important bill would also ensure that violators of human rights in the region are held accountable by applying sanctions and banning entry to the U.S.

Leaders in Congress on both sides of the aisle have made strong statements condemning the Chinese and Hong Kong governments' actions, but now is the time to attach action to words. The passage of the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act would not only be a momentous symbolic statement that the world still cares about the people of Hong Kong, but it would help incentivize the Hong Kong government to respect people's freedoms. It is time for the act to be passed.

Title: Three Dead in Fatal Shooting Outside Oklahoma Walmart

Article:

DUNCAN, Oklahoma (AP) — A shooting incident occurred outside a Walmart store in southwestern Oklahoma on Monday, November 18, 2019, resulting in the deaths of two men and a woman. The shooter is among the deceased, authorities confirmed.

According to Police Chief Danny Ford, the victims were shot in a car parked outside the store in Duncan before 10 a.m. The shooter is believed to have shot the male and female victims and then turned the gun on himself, as per Ford's statement to The ███.

Stephens County District Attorney Jason Hicks stated during a news conference Monday afternoon that there was no active shooter inside the store, and he described the shooting as an isolated incident. Hicks did not provide further details.

Two bodies, covered with sheets, were visible in the parking lot Monday afternoon. One body was in the driver's seat of a red, two-door car, while the other body was lying on the ground next to the vehicle. Bullet holes were visible in the car's windshield, and police reported finding a handgun at the scene.

Authorities have not released the identities of those killed, but they confirmed that the shooter was among the dead. Ford stated that all three knew each other but declined to describe their relationships or other identifying information pending notification of immediate family. He also confirmed that all three were dead when police arrived just minutes after the shooting.

Walmart spokeswoman LeMia Jenkins initially stated that no staff were involved. Jenkins later released a statement offering thoughts and prayers for the family of the woman killed in the shooting, who she said had been with the company for less than two months. Jenkins stated that the woman was at the Walmart during her free time and was not scheduled to work that day.

Duncan is a city of more than 22,000 residents located about 80 miles (130 kilometers) south of Oklahoma City. The Walmart is in a commercial center that includes a sporting goods store and a dollar store along U.S. Highway 81, the main road that passes through Duncan heading south toward Texas.

Aaron Helton, of Duncan, said he was parking outside the Walmart where he planned to buy groceries when he heard about nine gunshots. Helton was one of many nearby witnesses who fortunately was not hit by gunfire. The closest person was in a vehicle three parking spaces away from where the victims sat, Ford said.

"We got radio of a lot of people dodging and running," Ford said. "There were people in the vicinity, for sure."

There were more than 100 vehicles in the parking lot about two hours after the shooting, plus a steady stream of customers coming and going from Walmart, which remained open for business.

This shooting marks at least the third incident at a Walmart in the U.S. this year. A Walmart store in El Paso, Texas, reopened Thursday after being closed since August, when a gunman opened fire in the busy store, killing 22. Just days before, two Walmart employees in Mississippi were killed by a man authorities described as a disgruntled Walmart worker.

The killings in Oklahoma come amid a spate of high-profile shootings across the U.S. A 16-year-old student at a high school in the city of Santa Clarita outside Los Angeles shot and killed two classmates and wounded three other teens Thursday before shooting himself in the head. He died the next day.

In New Jersey, players and spectators ran for cover Friday night when a gunman opened fire at a high school football game, wounding two people. And on Sunday, four people were killed and six wounded in Fresno, California, where police say two shooters sneaked into a backyard party and shot into a group of Hmong family and friends.

Title: Senate Election Outlook: Democrats Face Uphill Battle for Control

Article:

As Election Day approaches, polls indicate that Democrats face an uphill battle in their quest to regain control of the Senate. The party is defending more seats than the Republicans, including many in conservative states. However, several key races remain close, and Democrats have paths to retake the chamber, albeit difficult ones.

Democrats are defending 26 seats, while Republicans are defending nine. The latest RealClearPolitics polling averages for key Democratic-held seats are as follows:

- In Missouri, Indiana, Florida, Montana, and West Virginia, Democrats lead by 2 to 11 points.
- In North Dakota, the race is very close, with zero to 2 points separating the candidates.

For the four main Republican-held seats Democrats are targeting, the RealClearPolitics averages currently show:

- In Nevada and Arizona, the races are very close, with zero to 2 points separating the candidates.
- In Texas and Tennessee, Republicans lead by 5 to 6 points.

A "jungle primary" is taking place in Mississippi today, which will likely advance one Republican and one Democratic candidate to a runoff election, scheduled for the end of the month.

Democrats need to gain two GOP-held seats for a majority. However, they also have more imperiled incumbents, and for each one who loses, they'd have to pick off another GOP-held seat to keep their hopes of Senate control alive. These polls are why every pundit and forecaster agrees that Republicans are the favorite to hold the majority.

While Republicans are playing whack-a-mole against Democratic challengers in the House, it's Democrats who are faced with that difficult task in the Senate. The challenge is that for each Democratic incumbent who loses, the number of Republicans who have to be defeated goes up—and that, very quickly, Democrats run out of targets.

If Democrats win every Senate race where there's a difference of 5 points or fewer between the candidates right now, as well as all the other races they currently lead by larger margins, they would deliver them two pickups of GOP-held seats, in Nevada and Arizona, in addition to getting almost every Democratic incumbent reelected. This would get them within one seat of a majority—because of the expected loss of Sen. Heidi Heitkamp (D-ND), the sole Democratic incumbent who has fallen behind her Republican challenger substantially in RealClearPolitics' average (she trails by 11 points).

If Heitkamp does lose, Democrats need to find another pickup somewhere for a majority. They'd likely have to pin their hopes on either Phil Bredesen from Tennessee or Beto O'Rourke (D-TX), hoping one of them pulls off an impressive upset (both currently trail by 5 to 6 points, per RealClearPolitics).

If another Democratic incumbent were to lose as well (say, Missouri's Claire McCaskill or Indiana's Joe Donnelly, who are both in races that polls show are about tied), the party would probably have to make up for it with both Bredesen and O'Rourke winning. If three Democratic incumbents lose, that ends the party's hopes for a majority, barring some total stunner elsewhere (such as in that Mississippi runoff that will likely be held at the end of November).

It's worth noting that the median outcome in FiveThirtyEight's classic forecast is for a 51-49 Senate controlled by Republicans, but their model does give Democrats about a one-in-five chance of taking over the chamber. This is largely because it's not uncommon for polls to be off by 5 or 6 points in Senate races. In recent years, there have been substantial polling errors in several Senate races. For example, in 2012, Democratic Senate candidates outperformed their polls by 6 points or more in North Dakota, Connecticut, Florida, and Missouri. In 2014, Republicans did so in Kansas, West Virginia, Arkansas, Virginia, Kentucky, and Iowa. In 2016, Republicans did so in Wisconsin and Indiana.

Democrats do, then, have something to hope for. However, one potential fear is that these polling errors could go in either direction. If it were to be Republicans who substantially outperform their polls, things could look very grim for Democrats indeed. The GOP would hold on to all their seats and would have a strong chance of defeating six Democratic incumbents—perhaps even more. We'll find out soon enough.

Title: Trump Campaign Chairman Paul Manafort Resigns Amidst Controversy, Shakeup in Trump Campaign Leadership

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Donald Trump's campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, has resigned from his position. This development comes as the Republican nominee's campaign faces a series of challenges, including poor polling numbers and self-inflicted controversies.

Manafort's resignation follows a string of unconventional moves by Trump, who, in a tightly scripted speech at a rally in North Carolina, admitted regretting some of his intemperate remarks made during the campaign. The resignation also coincides with the appointment of Steve Bannon, formerly of Breitbart, as the new campaign leadership.

The news of Manafort's resignation reportedly took some within the campaign by surprise, following a series of denials that a shakeup was underway. Sources familiar with the campaign have stated that Manafort had difficulty communicating with Trump in the same way that his predecessor, Corey Lewandowski, did.

Trump's son, Eric, suggested in an interview with Fox News that the controversy over Manafort's ties to Russia and a report this week that he potentially evaded the reporting requirements of the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA) led to his departure.

Manafort, a veteran political strategist, has been under scrutiny due to his role in advising foreign politicians, including Ukrainian strongman Viktor Yanukovych. His close connections to Russia, at a time when Trump is trying to criticize Clinton for taking money from foreign donors for her family foundation, have been a growing problem.

Manafort joined the campaign as an unpaid adviser in March, after Trump had been repeatedly outmaneuvered in the delegation selection process by rival Ted Cruz. He soon used that foothold to expand his mandate, eventually replacing Lewandowski, who was disdained by many within the party establishment as well as the Trump family.

In a statement issued on Friday, Trump suggested Manafort's role had peaked as an adviser during the Republican national convention in Cleveland. However, the resignation, which contradicts claims Manafort would stay on earlier in the week, is the second time Trump has exercised his famous slogan "you're fired" – following the ousting of Lewandowski in June.

Lewandowski is now thought likely to make a comeback within the constantly shifting Trump inner circle, as he favors the same approach of "letting Trump be Trump" as Bannon is believed to.

The Trump campaign's shakeup and the apologetic address on Thursday night have been met with skepticism by Democrats, who have rejected the notion of a new-look Trump. Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon stated, "In case you thought for a split second Trump was genuine about feeling regret, he is back to demonizing immigrants again in his new ad today."

Title: Liberal Perception of Donald Trump and His Supporters: A Focus on Racism, Islamophobia, and Xenophobia

Article:

A recent article by Zack Beauchamp in Vox suggests that the electoral success of right-wing movements, including the rise of Donald Trump and the outcome of the Brexit referendum, is not primarily driven by economic anxiety but rather by "racism, Islamophobia, and xenophobia." This perspective, according to the article, is shared by a significant number of liberals.

Beauchamp's article, which cites several academic studies, argues that the rise of right-wing nationalism cannot be explained solely in economic terms. However, the validity of this assertion, and the complete absence of economic factors in the rise of right-wing movements, is a matter of debate.

The article, and similar perspectives among liberals, have been criticized for displaying contempt for "particularistic instincts" that are not considered beyond the pale. These instincts, which include national, linguistic, religious, territorial, or ethnic attachments, are seen as natural to human beings and even coeval with political life.

The liberal view, as presented in the article, portrays supporters of right-wing movements as motivated by bigotry, fear, and selfishness, with a disregard for the rights and well-being of others. This perspective, critics argue, overlooks the legitimate concerns of these individuals, such as immigration, cultural preservation, and national sovereignty.

The article also suggests that this liberal denigration of the new nationalism is rooted in a desire to delegitimize any particularistic attachment or form of solidarity. This perspective, according to the article, presumes that all particularistic forms of solidarity must be superseded by a love of humanity in general, and that these particularistic attachments will be superseded by humanitarianism before long, as part of the inevitable unfolding of human progress.

However, critics argue that this perspective overlooks the historical and cultural context of these particularistic attachments, and the role they play in shaping individual and collective identities. They also argue that the humanitarian ideal, while laudable, may not be universally applicable or desirable, and that it is important to respect and understand the diverse perspectives and attachments that exist within society.

In conclusion, the article by Zack Beauchamp in Vox, and the broader perspective it represents, suggests that supporters of right-wing movements are primarily motivated by racism, Islamophobia, and xenophobia. This perspective, while based on academic studies, has been criticized for displaying contempt for particularistic instincts and for oversimplifying the complex motivations of individuals who support right-wing movements. The debate over the causes of the rise of right-wing movements, and the appropriate response to them, is ongoing.

Title: Liberty University President Jerry Falwell Jr. Demands Arrest of Reporters Over COVID-19 Coverage

Article:

Jerry Falwell Jr., president of Liberty University, has long advocated for free expression and intellectual diversity on college campuses. In a statement last June, Falwell emphasized the importance of open political discourse and encouraged colleges to promote such discourse on their campuses, as they do at Liberty University.

However, Falwell is now demanding the arrest of two reporters he accuses of portraying his school in a negative light during the COVID-19 pandemic. In an interview with radio host Todd Starnes, Falwell criticized articles by The New York Times and ProPublica for their coverage of his decision to partially reopen Liberty University amid the outbreak.

Falwell specifically took issue with a piece by New York Times journalist Elizabeth Williamson, who wrote about a conversation with local physician Thomas W. Eppes, Jr. Williamson reported that Eppes told her "nearly a dozen Liberty students were sick with symptoms that suggested Covid-19." Falwell claimed that the number of presumptive cases never reached 12, characterizing the report as "sensational click-bait."

As a result, Falwell secured arrest warrants for Times photographer Julia Rendleman and ProPublica reporter Alec MacGillis for trespassing, a Class 1 misdemeanor punishable by up to a year in jail. Falwell also stated that an additional warrant is coming against someone affiliated with another "big time liberal news organization." However, there is no warrant against Williamson because she did not take any photographs, so there is no physical proof that she was on campus. Falwell also threatened to sue The New York Times if a retraction or Liberty-friendly correction is not issued regarding the contagion numbers.

Ari Cohn, a free speech lawyer and former director at the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education (FIRE), commented on the situation, stating, "It is clear that Falwell is engaged in a campaign of petty retribution against journalists who write articles critical of the university." Cohn added, "But that's actually completely in line with Liberty University's faux concern for freedom of expression. Falwell's idea of freedom of expression on campus includes only expression that he approves of."

The trespassing charges are unlikely to hold up in court, as the reporters were photographing a student who invited them to campus for an interview. However, the alleged trespassing is not the main concern here, according to Cohn. Instead, the concern is Falwell's attempt to intimidate people who criticize his school.

Calum Best, the student interviewed by both The New York Times and ProPublica, described an angry phone call he received from Scott Lamb, the college's senior vice president for university communications, after he wrote a Facebook post arguing for tuition refunds amid COVID-19. Best wrote on Medium that he thought he was in trouble for a professional failure, but as the call went on, he realized his work-study boss had no need to be on the call and had no connection to the matter at hand.

This heavy-handedness tracks with how Falwell and his associates oversee Liberty University's student paper, Champion. Will E. Young, the former editor-in-chief, wrote last year that Falwell actively interfered with Trump-critical coverage, at one point removing a student op-ed lamenting Trump's Access Hollywood tape. The author of that op-ed, Joel Schmieg, took to Facebook to air the grievance and was promptly contacted by a faculty adviser, who reprimanded him for doing so. Schmieg then resigned.

As a private institution, Liberty University can set its own rules of conduct. However, it is the height of hypocrisy to muzzle student speech while making a show of opposing censorship. Furthermore, the university president is not just dealing with a newspaper on its own turf; with these warrants, Falwell is leveraging state power to try to stop speech by private actors whose only connection to his school is to write about it. It is a bad approach for anyone to take, but especially someone who claims to support free expression and intellectual diversity.

Title: Biden Campaign Intensifies Outreach to Latino Voters Ahead of 2020 Election

Article:

In an effort to bolster support among Latino voters, the Biden campaign has launched a significant outreach initiative, hiring a number of Hispanic operatives, spending over $1 million on Spanish-language outreach, and signing one of the nation's top pollsters in the field, Latino Decisions.

Recent general election polls show Biden with a lead nationwide and in many battleground states. He is already leading among Hispanic voters. If Biden can match Hillary Clinton's 2016 support and turnout levels among Latinos while continuing to perform well among black and white voters, he would effectively secure the crucial battlegrounds of Florida and Arizona, denying President Trump a second term.

Matt Barreto, Latino Decisions co-founder and pollster who also worked for Clinton's campaign, stated, "There's a huge opportunity." He added that Clinton's campaign "did an okay job" with Latino turnout and support levels.

Trump's record on immigration, Puerto Rico, healthcare, coronavirus response, and foreign policy, as well as Democrats' lessons learned from Florida's last election, where failing to aggressively reach out to Latino voters cost them the governor's office and a U.S. Senate seat, are factors driving the increased focus on Latino voters.

Biden's campaign plans to capitalize on the "incredible anger" among Puerto Rican voters in Florida over Trump's handling of Hurricane Maria in 2017 and increase support levels in border-state Arizona, where Latinos have been influenced by the immigrant rights movement, particularly younger Latinos, which is bad news for Donald Trump. Already, 2018 demonstrated that heightened Latino turnout can flip the state, and with continued investment in Latino outreach, 2020 could follow the same path as 2018.

The Biden campaign has already begun this outreach through Spanish-language TV ads running in Florida and Arizona since last month. The ads feature narrators with different accents to cater to the diverse Latino community in these states.

Jennifer Molina, Biden's Latino Media, stated, "The Latino vote is critically important, which is why we're bringing on Latino Decisions to help us with our messaging and outreach in order to engage with Latino voters on why Joe Biden is the best choice for President."

The Trump campaign, in response, stated that the president's values are shared by Hispanic voters who are motivated by jobs, education, family, faith, and community values.

Biden advisers and campaign insiders acknowledge that Biden has ground to make up with Hispanic voters if he wants to secure the election, but they attribute the heightened focus on Latinos to common-sense campaign strategy and improved campaign finances. The Biden campaign's continued embrace of digital campaigning amid the pandemic could have a beneficial effect when it comes to outreach, as Latino voters are disproportionately young and digitally connected.

However, a recent Trump ad focusing on crime and underfunded police departments made an impression on Spanish-speaking voters in South Florida, according to a source familiar with a focus group conducted by Democrats. A Democrat familiar with the Biden campaign's research also noted that the campaign has some problem areas to address, especially in Miami-Dade County, Florida's largest county with the largest proportion of Hispanic voters, where Biden is lagging Clinton's 2016 totals.

The Biden campaign's Latino outreach will extend to other battlegrounds, where a Latino Decisions poll released Friday shows problems for Trump. Barreto stated, "Beyond Arizona and Florida, North Carolina and Pennsylvania have large and growing Latino populations that could ultimately decide a very close election. Our research in these two states suggests over 70% of Latinos oppose Trump's divisive rhetoric and see Biden as fighting for Latinos."

Title: U.S. and China Agree on Framework for Trade Talks, Tariffs on Hold

Article:

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced on Sunday that the U.S. will hold off from imposing tariffs on Chinese goods as both nations attempt to negotiate trade agreements. The administration had previously threatened tariffs of $50 billion to $150 billion on Chinese goods to deter intellectual property theft and forced technology transfers. China countered with threats of tariffs on $50 billion worth of U.S. farm, chemical, and other exports.

During high-level talks on Thursday and Friday, the U.S. and China agreed on a framework for reducing the U.S. trade deficit with China and addressing technology trade issues. Mnuchin stated that the two sides have agreed to put tariffs on hold while they work to execute the framework.

The U.S. trade deficit with China totaled a record $375 billion in 2017, and the Trump administration had asked China to commit to reducing it by $200 billion by 2020. A joint U.S.-China statement released Saturday stated that "China will significantly increase purchases of United States goods and services," but did not specify the amount or timeline of the increased purchases.

Mnuchin expects major purchases this year, particularly of U.S. agriculture and energy products. He stated that Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross will visit China with "very hard commitments" in agriculture, where the U.S. expects to see a "very big increase — 35-40 percent increases — in agriculture this year alone." In energy, Mnuchin expects doubling the energy purchases, with potential annual energy purchases of $50 to $60 billion over the next three to five years.

Mnuchin declined to confirm whether China had agreed to a specific commitment to reduce the U.S. trade deficit with the country by $200 billion. He stated that the specific targets are not publicly disclosed and go industry by industry.

President Donald Trump has repeatedly stated that China has taken advantage of trade deals, and on the campaign trail, he said tariffs would be necessary in some cases to show that the U.S. is not playing games anymore. Economist Steve Moore, who is close to the Trump administration, stated that the teeter-totter nature of the China talks is quintessential Trump, offering that the latest turn is part of his negotiating tactics.

U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, one of the driving forces behind the intellectual property theft investigation that led Trump to threaten tariffs on $50 billion to $150 billion worth of Chinese goods, stated that the two sides have "agreed on a framework to address the very serious issues raised" in that probe. That includes putting the tariffs on hold, but keeping them in reserve if needed.

Lighthizer also downplayed the importance of China reducing trade barriers and increasing purchases of U.S. goods compared to ending practices that threaten the United States' ability to maintain its technological edge. "Getting China to open its market to more U.S. exports is significant, but the far more important issues revolve around forced technology transfers, cyber theft, and the protection of our innovation," Lighthizer said.

The tech industry welcomes the trade war cease-fire as a good step that will shield consumers from higher costs, but China still needs to make changes to level the playing field for American firms, according to Dean Garfield, president and CEO of the Information Technology Industry Council, a lobby group for Amazon, Google, and others.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer stated that it is up to Trump's team not to "blow it" with China. "There is nothing wrong with these talks, but the proof of the pudding is in the eating," Schumer said. "If President Xi is going to escape meaningful punishment for ZTE and fail to take strong actions on intellectual property, cyber theft, and American companies having free access to sell goods in China, and instead simply provide a promise to buy goods for the next few years, we will have lost."

Schumer was referring to the Chinese technology company ZTE, which faces stiff penalties for violating U.S. sanctions against North Korea and Iran. Trump stated last week that he would look into helping the company escape some of its harshest penalties. After talking with Chinese President Xi Jinping, Trump wrote on Twitter that he and Xi were working together to get ZTE back in business "fast."

On Sunday, Larry Kudlow, director of the White House National Economic Council, stated that ZTE would not get off "scot-free." Kudlow also stated that Trump has not completely abandoned the possibility of imposing tariffs on Chinese goods if Beijing does not address U.S. concerns about intellectual property theft and forced technology transfers. "Look, I don't think we're at that stage yet... Our view is China must open up. They must become fair traders," Kudlow said.

Title: Mayors of "Sanctuary Cities" Vow to Maintain Status, Potentially Clashing with Trump's Immigration Enforcement Push

Article:

Democratic mayors in cities across the United States, including Los Angeles, New York, Seattle, Boston, San Francisco, and Chicago, have reaffirmed their "sanctuary" status, potentially setting up a conflict with President-elect Donald Trump's immigration enforcement push. Trump's election has prompted city officials to affirm their commitment to providing safe havens for undocumented immigrants, defying Trump's campaign promises to penalize sanctuary cities by withholding federal funding.

Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago stated during a press conference, "Chicago will always be a sanctuary city." New York Mayor Bill de Blasio has gone as far as to say he would destroy a database of undocumented immigrants with city identification cards before handing it over to the Trump administration.

In sanctuary cities, local law enforcement officials are not required to contact U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) about the immigration status of individuals they encounter. This can mean that they do not notify the federal authorities when an undocumented immigrant is about to be released from custody, or when crime victims and witnesses might be less likely to cooperate with investigators if they are worried about being deported.

Trump has stated his intention to deport 2 million to 3 million undocumented immigrants with a criminal history. He has also suggested creating a special deportation task force within ICE, but sanctuary city resistance could complicate their efforts.

Critics of sanctuary cities argue that these policies harbor criminals and endanger public welfare. However, Los Angeles Police Chief Charlie Beck calls Trump's plan to deport illegal immigrants misguided and impractical. "For a local law enforcement agency to take on [the] role of immigration enforcement tears that fabric apart," Beck said.

Because states and cities cannot be required to enforce federal law, and there is no U.S. requirement that police ask about a person's immigration status, one of the only options Trump and the Republican-controlled Congress have is to pull federal funding. During a September campaign stop in Phoenix, Trump stated, "Cities that refuse to cooperate with federal authorities will not receive taxpayer dollars."

The Supreme Court has held that for Congress to impose conditions on the receipt of federal money by the states, the conditions must be reasonably related to the purpose of the money. It remains unclear what specific funding Trump might actually pull from the cities.

Title: Biden Supporters Urged to Take Tara Reade's Allegations Seriously Amidst Criticism of Trump's Handling of the Coronavirus Crisis

Article:

The political landscape in the United States is currently divided over the handling of the coronavirus crisis by President Donald Trump and the response to the sexual assault allegations against former Vice President Joe Biden.

Critics of Trump argue that his approach to the crisis varies depending on geographical locations with high and low coronavirus infection rates, with the latter often being areas that voted for him. Some believe that, given the country's historical tendency to rally around the leader during national crises, Trump's approval ratings should be higher than the current range of 45% to 50%.

The president's handling of the pandemic has been criticized for downplaying the severity of the pandemic, promoting dubious cures, and delaying testing and resource mobilization. These actions, which some experts consider the worst intelligence failure in U.S. history, have cost the opportunity to contain the pandemic.

In contrast, supporters of Biden argue that his long experience in government and his temperament would make him better equipped to handle an unprecedented crisis. However, the details of Biden's proposed response to the pandemic are not yet clear. His campaign has called for student loan forgiveness, a boost to Social Security benefits, fiscal transfers to state and local governments, more comprehensive action on paid sick leave, and additional checks to households beyond the $1,200 per person already enacted by Congress.

Regarding the sexual assault allegation against Biden, both conservatives and liberals have been criticized for their responses. Conservatives have weaponized the allegations against Biden, while some liberals have been accused of turning a blind eye to the serious nature of the accusations.

During the Brett Kavanaugh hearings, Biden publicly supported Christine Blasey Ford, emphasizing the importance of taking women's allegations seriously. He stated, "For a woman to come forward in the glaring lights of focus, nationally, you've got to start off with the presumption that at least the essence of what she's talking about is real." This same presumption, some argue, should apply when the accused is a Democrat running for president.

In conclusion, the political landscape in the United States is currently marked by criticism of Trump's handling of the coronavirus crisis and the serious sexual assault allegations against Biden. The response to these issues remains a topic of intense debate among Americans.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Joins GOP in Supporting 20-Week Abortion Ban

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, has announced his support for a ban on abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, also known as the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act. This stance places him in alignment with other potential Republican nominees for the 2016 presidential race.

In a statement, Mr. Christie emphasized the bipartisan appeal of the proposed legislation, which aims to protect unborn children from 20 weeks, or five months, of pregnancy, based on their ability to feel pain. He stated, "America is one of just seven countries that permit elective abortions past this point. We can do far better than this. I urge Congress to take swift action on this important issue."

Joining Governor Christie in supporting the ban are several other likely Republican presidential candidates, including Texas Senator Ted Cruz, Kentucky Senator Rand Paul, Florida Senator Marco Rubio, South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham, Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, Indiana Governor Mike Pence, former Pennsylvania Senator Rick Santorum, ex-Texas Governor Rick Perry, ex-Florida Governor Jeb Bush, ex-Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, former neurosurgeon Ben Carson, and former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina.

Marjorie Dannenfelser, president of Susan B. Anthony List, commented on the Republican unity around the push for the 20-week abortion ban. "There is complete unity on the Republican side around this push," she said in a statement.

In contrast, the national Democratic Party and its leaders have consistently emphasized the role of the abortion lobby in their policy and politics, according to Ms. Dannenfelser. She expects this clear difference to be a significant focus of the general election debate.

Title: White House Press Corps Skeptical of President Obama's Sequester-Related Warnings

Article:

President Barack Obama's apocalyptic predictions of the economic and personal consequences of the sequester spending cuts, set to take effect on March 1, are facing growing skepticism among an unexpected group: the White House press corps.

Over the past week, Mr. Obama has issued a series of dire warnings about the potential impacts of allowing the so-called sequester to occur. However, reporters are increasingly questioning the motivation behind the President's messaging and are doubting whether the White House is orchestrating the Pentagon and other agencies to highlight potential cuts to boost public anxiety and pressure congressional Republicans to compromise.

The skepticism peaked on Friday when outgoing Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood announced that the Transportation Department was planning on furloughing air-traffic controllers across the country, a move that would result in travel delays of up to 90 minutes at U.S. airports. Mr. LaHood faced sharp questioning over whether there weren't other, less disruptive cuts to be made.

"You've got a big budget. Can't you find some other way to cut that without telling air traffic controllers to stay home?" ABC News' Jonathan Karl asked Mr. LaHood.

Mr. LaHood insisted agency officials were searching "every contract" to find the right places to cut, even as he emphasized the difficulty in dealing with angry travelers. "Republicans need to step up here... This is not rocket science," he predicted.

In recent days, Mr. Obama has held public events highlighting potential painful cuts to emergency first-responders, and the Pentagon has warned of 800,000 civilian layoffs due to the sequester. The President will visit a shipbuilding yard in Newport News, Virginia on Tuesday to underscore more potential job losses and their impact on the local economy of the defense-heavy region.

Title: Texas High School Shooting Leaves Ten Dead, 10 Injured

Article:

A shooting at Santa Fe High School in Texas has resulted in the deaths of ten individuals and left ten others injured, according to Texas Governor Greg Abbott. The attacker, identified as 17-year-old Dimitrios Pagourtzis, is a pupil at the school and has been charged with murder.

Authorities found various kinds of explosive devices at the school, including a CO2 device and a Molotov cocktail, according to Governor Abbott. Pagourtzis allegedly used a shotgun and a revolver taken from his father, who legally owned the weapons.

Police found information on the suspect's diary, computer, and mobile phone suggesting that he planned the attack and intended to kill himself afterwards. However, Governor Abbott stated that the teenager "gave himself up" because "he did not have the courage to commit the suicide."

Santa Fe Police Chief Jeff Powell advised residents to be aware of any suspicious objects they find. "Do not touch any items that look out of place," he said. Santa Fe school police officer John Barnes has been named among the injured and is in a critical condition undergoing surgery, local media reported.

The shooting occurred on Friday, and one woman died and another was injured in a shooting outside a high school graduation ceremony in Atlanta the same day. So far this year, more than 5,000 people have died in shooting incidents in the United States, according to monitoring group the Gun Violence Archive.

Students reported that the shooter entered an art class and opened fire shortly before 08:00 (13:00 GMT). One witness told KTRK-TV, "There was someone that walked in with a shotgun and started shooting," and "this girl got shot in the leg."

A teacher who realized what was happening activated a fire alarm to evacuate the building, and students ran outside when the alarms went off. President Donald Trump described the attack as "absolutely horrific" and ordered flags to be flown at half-mast at the White House and all public and military buildings.

The Texas attack is the deadliest school shooting since a student opened fire in February at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, killing 17 people. That assault spawned a nationwide youth-led campaign for gun control, and a litany of proposed changes.

Authorities said journals kept by Pagourtzis showed that he planned to carry out the attack and intended to kill himself afterwards. However, unlike several previous mass shootings, authorities had not been alerted to Pagourtzis before the attack on Friday.

Title: Koch's Legacy Under Scrutiny: Climate Change Resistance and Philanthropic Efforts

Article:

Billionaire libertarian David Koch, who passed away this week following a battle with prostate cancer, has faced criticism for his resistance to action on climate change. As the Arctic rapidly melted and the Amazon rainforest burned, the Earth experienced its hottest month in recorded history. This coincided with the warnings scientists issued 30 years ago about climate change, warnings that Koch worked to ensure the American public ignored.

Throughout his career, Koch worked to remove from office any moderate Republicans who proposed regulating greenhouse gases. In 2009, for instance, Representative Bob Inglis of South Carolina proposed a carbon tax bill. Koch Industries, the company owned by the Koch brothers, stopped funding Inglis' campaign, donated heavily to a primary opponent named Trey Gowdy, and organized teams of Tea Party activists who protested against Inglis at town hall meetings.

Koch Industries is considered one of the country's most highly polluting companies, behind only ExxonMobil and American Electric Power. In the 20 years to 2017, the Kochs donated approximately $127 million to 92 groups that opposed climate crisis solutions, according to Greenpeace.

Recent months have seen a public spat between the Koch brothers and President Trump, with the Kochs criticizing Trump's trade tariffs and Trump labeling the billionaires as a "total joke." However, Trump has adopted many of the right-wing positions the Kochs have long advocated, with the exception of trade policy, which is contrary to the free-market views of the Kochs.

Koch's legacy is complex and filled with contradictions. He was a significant stakeholder in the second-largest privately held company in the country and had a net worth of around $50 billion. Despite his wealth, Koch was known for his philanthropic efforts, donating over $1 billion to causes such as the Smithsonian, Lincoln Center, and cancer research.

Koch supported same-sex marriage and abortion rights, free trade, and humane immigration policies. He was an advocate for criminal justice and prison reform, and his philanthropy extended to various cultural and educational institutions in New York City.

The circumstances surrounding Koch's political activities and philanthropy are now under scrutiny, with some arguing that there is enough evidence to support impeachment. The absence of an explicit quid pro quo over restarting aid does not necessarily weaken the case, as circumstantial evidence can be used to prove a criminal exchange. The focus of the investigation will be on the context and circumstances surrounding Koch's actions. Whether this evidence is enough to convince Republicans and lead to removal remains to be seen.

Title: Retired St. Louis Police Captain David Dorn Killed During Violent Protests

Article:

ST. LOUIS, Mo. (AP) — A retired police captain who died during a night of violent protests was trying to protect his friend's pawn shop, his widow said. David Dorn, a 77-year-old retired St. Louis police officer who served 38 years on the force, was shot and killed by looters at Lee's Pawn & Jewelry early Tuesday, June 2, 2020, police said. His body was found on the sidewalk at about 2:30 a.m.

Dorn's death came on a violent night in St. Louis, where four officers were shot, officers were pelted with rocks and fireworks, and 55 businesses were burglarized or damaged, including a convenience store that burned. Police also shot and gravely injured a burglary suspect who they say shot at officers.

Cities across the U.S. have seen protests and violence since George Floyd died May 25 after a white Minneapolis officer pressed his knee into Floyd's neck for several minutes even after the handcuffed black man stopped moving and pleading for air.

Dorn was a friend of the pawn shop's owner and frequently checked on the business when alarms went off, his wife, St. Louis police Sgt. Ann Marie Dorn, told the St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

David Dorn served 38 years on the St. Louis police force before retiring in October 2007. He then became chief of Moline Acres, a small town in St. Louis County.

Former St. Louis County police Chief Tim Fitch knew Dorn for 30 years and said they became close friends when Dorn and his wife were leading the St. Louis police department's Explorers program for young people interested in law enforcement careers, while Fitch was leading the county's program.

"He was very dedicated to youth, especially disadvantaged youth," said Fitch, who led the St. Louis County Police Department from 2009 to 2014. "He wanted to see them succeed. He wanted to be a role model for those young men and women to go into law enforcement."

Dorn's personality was "bigger than life," Fitch said. "He was a fun guy, a happy guy. You never had to wonder what he was thinking when somebody did something incredibly stupid like a crime because he would just say it as he saw it."

When he took over as chief in Moline Acres, Dorn made it clear that his officers would be held to the strictest of standards, Fitch said.

"He wanted them to do the right thing all the time," Fitch said.

The Ethical Society of Police, which represents black officers in St. Louis, said in a news release that Dorn was "the type of brother that would've given his life to save them if he had to."

St. Louis police Chief John Hayden called Dorn a "fine captain."

"Many of us, the other officers, looked up to him," Hayden said. "Was very well-liked, very pleasant. And his wife still works here. So a very sad time for our agency. We will honor him."

Title: U.S. Lawmakers Pursue Systemic Racism Reforms Across Multiple States

Article:

In the aftermath of nationwide protests against racial injustice, U.S. lawmakers are taking steps to address systemic racism in various aspects of public life. These efforts extend beyond policing reforms, prompting discussions that some believe the country has not previously engaged in due to discomfort.

Sydney Kamlager, a member of the Legislative Black Caucus in the California state Assembly, stated, "If you're just talking about police and you're not looking at the rest of the spectrum, then you're really not focused on change."
