The success of these reforms has been mixed. While California has celebrated recent legislative victories, lawmakers in New Hampshire refused to make an exception to their rules for a Democratic lawmaker who sought to introduce a bill examining racial bias and discrimination in the state's corrections, judicial, and police systems.

In California, a number of bills that have struggled to pass for years are suddenly gaining traction. Last week, the state Assembly overwhelmingly approved a bill that would allow voters to decide whether to overturn the state's 1996 ban on affirmative action in government and public colleges and universities. On Thursday, the state Senate passed a bill to make ethnic studies a graduation requirement in the California State University system, the country's largest four-year public university.

In other states, lawmakers are also addressing racial bias. In Pennsylvania, Democratic lawmakers are trying to capitalize on the moment to address racial bias in the judicial system. In Massachusetts, a Democratic lawmaker wants to overhaul state education spending to funnel more money to schools with high numbers of minority students. And in Ohio, separate resolutions would declare racism a public health crisis.

California is considering studying how the state could offer reparations for slavery. A bill would establish an eight-member task force to study the effects of slavery and its "legacy of structural discrimination." The committee would recommend how the state could compensate black people, which doesn't necessarily mean cash.

Other states are coupling their coronavirus relief efforts with racial justice issues. In Pennsylvania, Democratic lawmakers have fused a police reform and racial justice agenda with a pandemic recovery platform under the banner of a "just recovery." In Massachusetts, a priority will be finding an extra $1 billion over the next few years for struggling school systems, primarily in cities with high minority populations.

Ohio could go further by declaring racism a public health crisis. The Ohio Legislative Black Caucus has introduced resolutions in the House and Senate that would officially acknowledge racism in Ohio for the first time. They call for increased spending to address the effects of racism in education, housing, criminal justice, and health care. However, the House resolution, which is cosponsored entirely by Democrats, has yet to have a hearing in the Republican-controlled chamber.

Title: Majority of Republicans and GOP-leaning Independents Urge Cruz and Kasich to Withdraw from Presidential Race

Article:

A new CNN/ORC poll indicates that a majority of Republicans and GOP-leaning independents believe Sen. Ted Cruz and Ohio Gov. John Kasich should withdraw from the presidential race, as neither candidate can mathematically secure a majority of GOP delegates through the primary and caucus process alone.

The poll, released Monday, shows that 52% of respondents think Sen. Cruz should drop out, while 63% believe Gov. Kasich should exit the race. The questions were preceded by statements indicating that neither candidate can win a majority of delegates through the primary and caucus process at this point and could potentially win the nomination if no candidate reaches a majority.

Both Cruz and Kasich have argued that no candidate will win the 1,237 majority of delegates before the GOP convention in July, although Republican front-runner Donald Trump still has a viable path to that threshold.

The latest delegate tally, reported by The Associated Press, shows Trump with 996 delegates, Cruz with 565, and Kasich with 153. In terms of delegates, Kasich is also still behind Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, who left the race a month and a half ago. A separate poll released this week found that 58% of GOP voters in Ohio think Gov. Kasich should end his White House run.

The poll also revealed that a greater percentage of Republicans and leaners believe the party will still be divided in November, compared to March. Forty-nine percent of respondents said the party will still be divided in November, 41% said the party is divided now but will be united, and 7% said the party is currently united. In March, 46% said they thought the GOP would be divided in November, 45% said they thought the party is divided but will be united for the general election, and 8% said they thought the party was already united.

Title: Poll Shows Slight Lead for Marco Rubio Over Jeb Bush in Florida Presidential Race

Article:

A new poll conducted in Florida indicates that Senator Marco Rubio has a slight, statistically insignificant lead over his potential Republican presidential rival, Jeb Bush, in their home state. The Mason-Dixon Polling & Research survey, shared exclusively with POLITICO, was conducted among 400 registered Republican voters from Tuesday to Thursday.

Rubio received 31 percent support from Republicans, essentially tying Bush's 30 percent. Other likely and announced presidential candidates polled in the single digits, and 17 percent were undecided.

The poll's results are statistically insignificant due to the margin of error. However, the poll provides insight into the current state of the Republican primary race in Florida.

One of the primary concerns for Rubio before announcing his presidential bid was securing enough donors and supporters to secure his home state, given the presence of establishment figure Jeb Bush. The poll suggests that Rubio may have successfully addressed this concern.

Upon announcing his presidential bid, Rubio stated, "I've heard some suggest that I should step aside and wait my turn. But I can not. Because I believe our very identity as an exceptional nation is at stake, and I can make a difference as president."

The poll's results may indicate that the state of Florida is up for grabs in the Republican primary race. The poll's findings might be surprising to Bush's campaign team and other observers of the race.

Title: New York Times' 'The Interpreter' Blog and Newsletter Focuses More on Far-Right Politics and Movements

The New York Times' 'The Interpreter' blog and newsletter, which explores the ideas and context behind major world events, has a higher likelihood of reporting on far-right politicians and movements compared to far-left ones, according to an analysis. The blog is penned by Max Fisher and Amanda Taub, who are alumni of the left-leaning explainer site Vox.

The analysis, which examined more than 50 stories mentioning the political "right" or "left" around the globe written by Fisher and Taub for the blog since its inception in 2016, found a stark emphasis on coverage of the political right. The articles made 136 mentions of the "far right" but just one mention of the "far left," and 60 mentions of "right-wing" politicians or movements compared to 10 mentions of "left-wing" politicians or movements.

Thirty-two of their stories overall mentioned the "far right" and 31 mentioned "right-wing" movements or politicians, while one story mentioned the "far left" and seven mentioned "left-wing" movements or politicians. In a lengthy article headlined "How YouTube Radicalized Brazil," which appeared on Tuesday's front page, Fisher and Taub used the phrases "far right" and "right-wing" 15 times. It described President Jair Bolsonaro as a "star in YouTube's far-right community" before becoming president last year.

A piece by Taub headlined "Why Democracy Feels Like a Dangerous Game" on Dec. 1, 2017, mentioned the "far right" 12 times alone. The analysis, however, noted that the reporting is not always consistent in its political labeling. For instance, a report on corruption scandals embroiling former left-wing presidents Dilma Rousseff of Brazil and Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina did not provide a label for either of them, while this 2017 Interpreter story mentioned Rousseff's "left-wing party."

Furthermore, stories about Venezuela omitted the "far left" label to describe the failed socialist government there under Nicolas Maduro. A 2017 article on the rise of authoritarianism referred to Maduro's predecessor Hugo Chavez as championing "leftist populism." Another Interpreter story later that year mentioned the government's socialist bent but also omitted any "left" label.

A May 14, 2017, piece specifically analyzing Venezuela's economic collapse did not use the word "socialism" or "socialist" once. It did report on the "leftist" Chavez's rise to power, increased nationalization of the economy, and cronyism that eventually crippled the nation.

The New York Times overall is more likely to use the labels "far-right" and "right-wing" than "far-left" and "left-wing" in its reporting, a search shows. A search of the Times archives showed far fewer stories involving the terms "far-left" (5,259) and "left-wing" (40,972) than "far right" (11,868) and "right-wing" (51,168). The same also goes for the terms "hard left" (1,332) versus "hard right" (3,389) and "extreme left" (5,829) versus "extreme right" (6,902). The terms "conservative" and "liberal" can often be employed in nonpolitical contexts, so they were omitted.

Title: Congress Faces Potential Government Shutdown, but Avoidance Likely, Says GOP Leaders

Article:

The United States federal government is facing the possibility of a shutdown next week, with the government having previously experienced shutdowns in 1995 and 1996. However, recent statements from Republican leaders on Capitol Hill suggest that a shutdown may not occur, at least not next week.

Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) told CNN that he is not willing to risk a shutdown and have Republicans take the blame for it. Many Republicans fear they will be blamed for a shutdown, just months before a significant congressional election year. A CNN/ORC poll in mid-September showed that 51% of people would hold Republicans in Congress responsible for a shutdown, versus 40% for President Barack Obama.

House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) might already be in this camp. He initially proposed a spending bill that would have avoided a standoff, but conservatives forced him to go to war with a different version fully defunding Obamacare. Boehner's opening move was an important signal that he wants to sidestep a shutdown.

Sen. John McCain (R-Arizona) also expressed concern about the potential consequences of a shutdown, referring to the sting Republicans felt after the shutdowns in 1995 and 1996.

Congress operates on political currency, and multiple House GOP aides told CNN that the majority of Republicans in their conference fear a shutdown would cost them with voters.

Republicans are divided over how far to take the Obamacare battle at the moment. GOP leaders are also preparing a second Obamacare fight during the upcoming debt ceiling debate. They have the option of dropping the anti-Obamacare push from the shutdown debate now and instead including it in the debt ceiling fight coming up.

At the same time, Democrats are eager to move past the shutdown debate and on to the debt ceiling and budget cuts slated to hit in January at the latest.

Facebook users mentioned "Obamacare" 300,000 times in the U.S. and 360,000 times globally, according to data from the site.

If a shutdown does occur, it will likely happen in the day or two before the potential shutdown, as political pressure against a shutdown builds. Workers may be sent home without pay, troops' paychecks may be delayed, families may cancel vacations, and incredible political pressure against a shutdown will build.

The government does not necessarily have to shut down at the end of the day on September 30. If lawmakers are close to a deal, the president can order agencies to keep running for a few hours or perhaps even a day or two for Congress to pass the legislation.

In conclusion, the shutdown deadline is not as firm as people might think, and Congress operates best on deadlines. However, the swirling, unpredictable dynamics in Congress at the moment and Republicans' gut-level objections to Obamacare make it unclear whether a shutdown will occur. If a shutdown does happen, it will likely be the result of a late game of chicken between the House, Senate, and president.

Title: Media Panel Discusses Allegations Against Joe Biden and Comparisons to Brett Kavanaugh

Article:

In a segment of NBC's Meet the Press, political analysts discussed the calls for an investigation into Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden regarding an allegation of rape. The discussion, led by NBC political director Chuck Todd, featured Cook Political Report's Amy Walter and NBC Capitol Hill correspondent Kasie Hunt.

Todd read a portion of a column written by The New York Times editorial board, expressing dissatisfaction with Biden's denials made on MSNBC's Morning Joe late last week. The Times suggested that any investigation should be limited to information about the accuser and conducted by an unbiased, apolitical panel put together by the Democratic National Committee (DNC).

Todd questioned the extent of the Democratic Party's willingness to conduct such an investigation, as if it were a serious proposition. Hunt expressed concern that Republicans were focusing on the handling of Brett Kavanaugh's allegations and the media's coverage of him, rather than Donald Trump.

Hunt noted the discrepancy in the media's coverage of sexual misconduct allegations, particularly in favor of Democrats. She argued that the debate about Biden's alleged conduct had become "very muddled and devolved into lobbing charges back and forth."

Hunt attributed the lack of appetite for investigating Biden to fears of a 2016 repeat, referring to the email controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton. On the other hand, Walter criticized The Times' suggestion of the DNC putting together an unbiased panel to investigate Biden, stating that it was "stretching it."

Walter also discussed the perceived hypocrisy in the coverage of Biden and Brett Kavanaugh, with many people believing there was a partisan bias in the media's handling of the allegations. The segment ended with the panelists acknowledging the complexity and sensitivity of the issue, with Todd stating that "every social media debate devolves into, is some sort of whataboutism on those two gentlemen."

Title: Kerry's Remark on Syrian Chemical Weapons Sparks Possible Diplomatic Solution

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, a seemingly offhand suggestion by U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry that Syria could avert an American attack by relinquishing its chemical weapons has received widespread support from Syria, Russia, the United Nations, key American allies, and some Republicans. This proposal, initially perceived as a gaffe, is being considered as a potential solution to the Syria crisis.

During a news conference in London, Kerry suggested that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad could avoid a U.S.-led strike by turning over all his chemical weapons to the international community within a week. However, the State Department later clarified Kerry's remarks as "rhetorical" and made it clear that the administration's desire to strike could be tempered by a Syrian offer.

The State Department spokeswoman, Jen Psaki, explained that Kerry's point was that Assad, with a history of playing fast and loose with facts, cannot be trusted to turn over chemical weapons. A State Department spokesman also described Kerry's remark as "hypothetical," dismissing Russia's eagerness over the proposal as a "stalling tactic."

The potential outcome of this proposal would involve the confiscation of dangerous weapons from the Syrian regime, the U.S. claiming that its "pressure" led to this concession, avoiding an unwanted intervention, and resolving the "red line" conundrum. With the Senate debating an authorization of force resolution and widespread public opposition to a Syria intervention, the administration may be seizing this opportunity to extricate President Obama from his self-inflicted "red line" predicament.

However, White House Press Secretary Jay Carney stated that Congress should still vote to authorize a military strike on Syria, claiming that the only reason this proposal is on the table is because of the threat of military action. The White House's stance on the matter remains unclear, with the president scheduled to attend a Senate GOP lunch on Tuesday.

In the midst of this evolving situation, it appears that the administration is still committed to having these votes, and the president's advisers fear that Syria threatens to undercut his standing with the public and erode his political capital on other matters. The White House's response to this proposal and its impact on the Syria crisis continues to develop.

Title: Obama Adopts Aggressive Strategy in Second Presidential Debate

Article:

In the second presidential debate, President Barack Obama employed a strategy he has used effectively on the campaign trail, known as the "power of nope." The phrase "not true" was a frequent response from the president as he refuted numerous claims made by Mitt Romney. This approach, which was not used in the first debate, was signaled by the campaign as a more aggressive stance for Obama.

The 90-minute debate saw both candidates pacing, engaging, and frequently interrupting the moderator to finish their points. At one point, Obama sought the moderator's support after she corrected Romney's statement regarding the president's characterization of the Libya consulate attack.

Mitt Romney responded in kind, engaging in debates with the moderator and Obama about the ground rules and challenging the president on facts. However, Romney's demeanor was similar to that of the first debate, while Obama's was more assertive, aiming to revive his poll numbers following their initial debate.

The candidates frequently interrupted each other, leading to a more heated exchange compared to the first round. One notable moment occurred when Romney questioned Obama's pension, to which Obama quipped, "I don't look at my pension. It's not as big as yours."

The debate also revisited familiar topics such as taxes and the budget, with both candidates reiterating their respective positions. Romney proposed lowering tax rates across the board while ensuring the top 5 percent do not pay less than they currently do. Obama countered that Romney's tax cut plan would either increase the deficit or lead to a middle-class tax hike.

The town-hall-style format allowed for a discussion on a range of foreign and domestic issues, with the final presidential debate scheduled for October 22 in Boca Raton, Florida, focusing on foreign policy. The vice presidential debate last week saw Vice President Biden taking a more aggressive approach, similar to Obama's in the second presidential debate. However, Biden also faced criticism for his demeanor, laughing at and interrupting Republican opponent Paul Ryan throughout the debate.

Title: Supreme Court Rules Against Compulsory Union Dues for Public Sector Employees

Article:

In a 5-4 decision on Wednesday, the Supreme Court ruled that public sector unions do not have the constitutional right to collect compulsory dues from employees. The ruling, in the case of Janus v. AFSCME, means that employees will now have to give explicit consent before any money from their paychecks goes to support a public-sector union. This ruling does not apply to unions at private companies.

Mark Janus, a child support specialist at the Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services, was a non-member of the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) union, yet he was still required to pay "fair share" dues to the union. Janus argued that being forced to pay dues to a politically active union, in return for employment, violates his First Amendment rights.

Federal law prevents unions from requiring employees to join a union as a condition of their employment. However, unions argue that since their collective bargaining benefits all employees, all employees should be required to pay into the union. These "fair share" fees or "agency fees" are intended to cover only collective bargaining and contract negotiation, and not political activism. Unions claim that these fees also help pay for representation if a worker is being mistreated by an employer.

Unions argue that removing these fees or making them voluntary would substantially weaken their ability to perform even basic functions. However, Janus argued that having to donate any money to a politically active union violates his rights.

In the opinion of the court, Justice Samuel Alito stated that the justices had concluded that the act of taking union dues from employees who chose not to join a union "violates the free speech rights of nonmembers by compelling them to subsidize private speech on matters of substantial public concern."

Justice Alito's opinion was joined by Chief Justice Roberts, Justice Anthony Kennedy, Justice Clarence Thomas, and Justice Neil Ginsburg. The dissent was written by Justices Sonia Sotomayor, Elena Kagan, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and Stephen Breyer. The vote took place largely along ideological lines, with Justice Kennedy, often considered the swing vote, siding with the more conservative justices.

Title: Uninsured Rate Among U.S. Adults Hits Lowest Point Since 2008, According to Gallup Poll

Article:

A recent poll by Gallup indicates that nearly nine out of ten Americans now have health insurance, marking a significant improvement from two years ago before the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The uninsured rate among U.S. adults declined to 11.9% in the first quarter of 2015, down one percentage point from the end of 2014 and a notable improvement from the 18% without insurance in the fall of 2013, when Americans were first able to sign up for coverage at state and federal exchanges.

This is the lowest percentage of Americans without coverage since Gallup began tracking the figure in 2008. In 2008, the uninsured rate was just under 15%. The law requiring most Americans to have coverage or pay a penalty took effect at the start of 2014.

According to the Gallup report, an improving economy and a falling unemployment rate may have contributed to the steep drop in the percentage of uninsured over the past year. However, the uninsured rate is significantly lower than it was in early 2008, before the depths of the economic recession, suggesting that the recent decline is due to more than just an improving economy.

Those making less than $36,000 a year have seen the most significant rate of improvement. Though 22% of this income group still do not have coverage, that's down from 30.7% at the end of 2013.

Those aged 26 to 34 have also seen the most improvement of any age group, but more than 20% still lack coverage. About 98% of those aged 65 and older have coverage, a figure that remains unchanged from two years ago, as almost all of them qualify for Medicare.

Furthermore, far more minority adults still are without coverage, as about 13% of blacks and 30% of Hispanics do not have coverage. However, they have seen greater improvement in their rates of coverage than have whites.

Title: FDA Voluntary Guidelines on Antibiotic Use in Farm Animals Met with Skepticism

Article:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported in October that antibiotic-resistant bacteria, known as "superbugs," cause at least two million infections and 23,000 deaths in the United States annually. The cost to the U.S. health care system has been estimated at $17 billion to $26 billion per year.

In response, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued voluntary guidelines aimed at curbing the misuse of antibiotics in animals. However, these guidelines have been met with skepticism due to their voluntary nature and the potential for loopholes.

The FDA's guidelines ask industry not to use antibiotics for growth promotion but permit use of antibiotics for routine disease prevention with a veterinary prescription. This leaves producers with a loophole to continue using antibiotics for growth promotion by simply calling it another name. The guidelines also provide a disincentive to clean up their facilities, as the industry can use the simplest, cheapest, and most dangerous method to keep livestock healthy: antibiotics.

The FDA's guidelines have been criticized for not going far enough in restricting antibiotic use in farm animals. The agency argues that veterinarians will ensure responsible use, but most livestock and poultry are overseen by veterinarians employed by companies that have spent years fighting regulation.

The FDA's guidelines have been met with opposition from the drug industry, which stands to lose millions of dollars in sales if antibiotics are no longer used routinely for disease prevention. The chief executive of the largest animal drug company stated that the guidelines "will not have a significant impact on our revenues."

The Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act (PAMTA), a bill that would save eight classes of antibiotics for use on humans and sick animals, has been the subject of frequent industry attacks. Out of 225 lobbying reports filed in the 112th Congress on PAMTA, 195 reports (87.5%) were submitted on behalf of entities hostile to the legislation. Medical and consumer advocacy groups filed only 30 of the 225 reports (12.5%).

With millions of infections and thousands of deaths linked to antibiotic resistance, it is clear that meaningful action is needed. The World Health Organization has warned that antibiotic resistance could mean "an end to modern medicine as we know it." It is time for Congress to take meaningful action to regulate the use of antibiotics in farm animals and step up to the plate.

Title: Trump Replaces Campaign Manager as He Trails Biden in Polls

Article:

President Donald Trump has demoted his longtime campaign manager, Brad Parscale, and replaced him with Bill Stepien, according to a Facebook post by Trump. The move comes as Trump trails Democratic candidate Joe Biden in opinion polls less than four months before the November 3 vote.

As of Thursday night, Biden is ahead of Trump nationally by an average of 8.6%, according to RealClearPolitics. Many political analysts agree that Biden is a stronger opponent than Hillary Clinton was in 2016.

In 2016, more voters trusted Trump, with just 37% of those polled by Quinnipiac saying they believed Clinton to be more honest. Today, Biden leads Trump by 15 points on the question of whether voters believe the candidates to be honest.

Trump was on pace for a close reelection just five months ago, but a massive factor in his poor performance is beyond his control. Voters' loathing of Clinton played an enormous role in 2016. However, Biden does not inspire the same level of negative reaction.

Polls consistently show that Trump's supporters are more excited to vote for him than Biden's supporters are to vote for him. While Biden voters may not be all that excited about voting for Biden, they are very enthusiastic about voting against Trump. This gives Biden a strong edge, as Trump supporters do not despise Biden the way they despised Clinton in 2016.

Registered voters with negative opinions of both Trump and Biden preferred Biden to Trump by a whopping 23-point margin in the polling Nationscape conducted in June. They also rated Biden less negatively overall, with only 33% of this group saying they had a very unfavorable opinion of Biden compared to 62% who said the same of Trump.

These results, especially when combined with recent political science research on the power of negative partisanship, suggest that the public's stronger dislike of Trump is probably the more consequential enthusiasm gap in 2020.

Title: Federal Aid and State Budgets: A Look at the Fiscal Impact of COVID-19

Article:

As Congress considers further coronavirus aid, concerns have been raised that states may use federal funds to address pre-pandemic budgetary issues. In late April, President Donald Trump tweeted, "Why should the people and taxpayers of America be bailing out poorly run states (like Illinois, for example) and cities, in all cases Democrat run and managed, when most of the other states are not looking for bailout help? I am open to discussing anything, but just asking?"

However, Christopher Mooney, a professor of state politics at the University of Illinois at Chicago, argues that this characterization does not necessarily equate to "blue state bailouts." The response to COVID-19 has created a genuine fiscal emergency, and while many states with deep pension debts lean left, this does not automatically imply that additional aid would primarily benefit Democratic states.

Data from the Rockefeller Institute of Government in New York shows that Democratic states such as New Jersey, Massachusetts, and Connecticut pay the federal government far more than they receive each year. Conversely, some deep-red states like Alabama and Mississippi receive much more than they contribute. These imbalances are largely due to demographics, as America's progressive tax system means that residents in wealthy states (often heavily urban and Democratic-controlled) pay higher federal taxes than those in other states. Urban-oriented states usually have high demands for public services, leading to relatively high spending by state and local governments, according to Professor Mooney.

In essence, ideology may guide decisions, but demographics are the primary factor. When it comes to how states are managed, Professor Mooney notes that this is often a matter of opinion. He states, "When you start throwing out words like 'well run' or 'poorly run,' unless you have very specific criteria in mind... it's subjective by definition."

In conclusion, the ongoing debate surrounding federal aid and state budgets is complex and multifaceted. While ideological leanings may influence the discussion, demographic factors play a significant role in determining the fiscal health of states and their reliance on federal aid. The management of states and cities is a matter of opinion, and specific criteria are necessary to objectively evaluate their performance.

Title: Challenges Facing Jeb Bush and Hillary Clinton in Upcoming Presidential Election

Article:

The upcoming 2016 presidential election is anticipated to feature a match-up between former Florida Governor Jeb Bush and former First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton. Both candidates are well-known, well-funded, and have a wide network of supporters. However, their entry into the race has sparked questions from some about the viability of other candidates.

Jeb Bush and Hillary Clinton share similar strengths and weaknesses. Both have been able to raise significant funds, have the support of their party's establishment, and have been favorably portrayed by the media. They were expected to secure their party's nomination early, but grass-roots voters from both parties have expressed a desire for new faces and new ideas.

Both candidates also carry significant baggage. Their long political careers have led to perceptions of being part of political dynasties, which is not appealing to many voters. Both have faced subtle snubs from their parties' previous nominees. For instance, Hillary Clinton served as President Obama's Secretary of State, but Obama and his associates have been less than complimentary in their references to her. It has been reported that Obama confidant Valerie Jarrett may have leaked news of Clinton's private email accounts to the media. Similarly, Jeb Bush's fundraisers faced resistance from 2012 GOP nominee Mitt Romney, who hinted at running himself.

Hillary Clinton's image as an establishment, slightly left-of-center Democratic moderate has hurt her as the base of her party has shifted to the left. Her attempts to emulate populism have been met with skepticism. Jeb Bush, on the other hand, has faced criticism for emphasizing issues that are seen as suspect by the current GOP base. His response has been as ham-handed as Hillary's among Democrats.

While the "common wisdom" of the moment may suggest a Clinton-Bush match-up, it is not guaranteed. Both candidates face challenges in winning over their respective bases and may not live up to the expectations set by the "common wisdom."

Title: Navigating Political Conversations During Holiday Gatherings: NPR Readers Share Their Experiences

Article:

As the holiday season approaches, families across the United States are preparing for gatherings that may include heated political discussions. National Public Radio (NPR) asked its listeners for their best and worst experiences talking politics over Thanksgiving dinner.

Many of the stories received were not heartwarming, with incidents ranging from religious disagreements to racist epithets. However, some respondents reported that discussing politics could help clear the air and improve family dynamics.

Aaron Harmon shared his experience of his father-in-law insisting that he, an atheist, say grace at the table, which led to a heated argument about his religious beliefs and eventual shouting match between family members.

Stephanie Brown recounted a Thanksgiving dinner that started as a discussion about missing church, escalated into a political debate, and ended in a series of emotional attacks. However, the incident led to a family conversation about unresolved anger and the realization that the fight was not about the 2012 election results but rather long-standing family issues.

Jeremy Brown shared a particularly distressing experience of racist remarks and derogatory language during a Thanksgiving dinner, which led him to decide never to return for another holiday gathering.

To avoid political discussions, some families have implemented creative solutions, such as Sally Carleton's "duck quacker" that interrupts conversations about politics and religion. NPR's Sarah McCammon suggests focusing on food, children, and pets as topics of conversation to keep the peace.

Luke Aldridge emphasizes the importance of humility and respect in political discussions, while Danielle Kurtzleben suggests making controversial food choices to spark conversation and distract from political disagreements.

NPR's Brad Heil shared his mother's rule of sitting on the back porch during political discussions if one is unable to respect other parties' opinions. Finally, NPR offers its own solution to informed political discussions through its Politics section and new podcast.

In conclusion, while political discussions can be a source of tension during holiday gatherings, there are various strategies to navigate these conversations and maintain family harmony.

Title: Rare Defeat of a Republican Incumbent Senator: A Look at Historical Precedents

Article:

Liz Cheney, the daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, has officially ended her challenge to veteran Sen. Mike Enzi in the Wyoming Republican Senate primary. Cheney cited family illness as the primary reason for her decision. However, historically, Republicans do not typically oust their incumbent U.S. senators.

Since World War II, approximately 11 Republican senators have lost their party primaries, while Democratic senators have been defeated by their own party more than three times that number. These defeats often involve southern Democrats who lost in primaries that were effectively elections, as well as Democrats who did not align with the increasingly left-of-center leanings of party activists.

Examples of defeated Republican incumbents include Wisconsin's Sen. Robert La Follette Jr., who lost renomination in 1946 to a young Marine Corps veteran named Joe McCarthy. McCarthy ran as an internationalist and backer of the United Nations, criticizing La Follette's isolationist record. In contrast, McCarthy's reputation as a fervent and controversial anti-Communist would come later.

In 1968, California's Max Rafferty, a swashbuckling Superintendent of Public Instruction, defeated Senate GOP Whip and moderate Tom Kuchel. Rafferty, who went on to lose against Democrat Alan Cranston, ran as a conservative in contrast with a more moderate incumbent.

New York's Alfonse D'Amato beat veteran GOP Sen. Jacob Javits in New York's primary in 1980 and won in November, two years after conservative activist Jeff Bell defeated moderate Sen. Clifford Case in New Jersey. Bell, however, lost in November.

In 2010, constitutional lawyer and stalwart conservative Mike Lee won a convention battle over three-term Republican Sen. Bob Bennett of Utah, and serves in the Senate today. That same year, conservative Joe Miller ousted the more moderate Sen. Lisa Murkowski in Alaska's Republican primary, but she came back to be re-elected as a write-in candidate.

Despite the successes of D'Amato and Lee, there are numerous examples of conservative challengers who could not make a strong enough case to unseat an incumbent senator. In Connecticut, Prescott Bush Jr., brother of then-Vice President George Bush, quit a 1982 challenge to Sen. Lowell P. Weicker, an outspoken liberal Republican. Two years later, conservative Rep. Tom Corcoran lost in the Illinois Republican primary to moderate Sen. Charles Percy. In 2010, former Rep. J.D. Hayworth could not make a case to Arizona Republicans that Sen. John McCain was not conservative enough. McCain won handily.

Most state and national Republican leaders are expected to breathe a sigh of relief at the news about the Wyoming race. Despite Dick Cheney's revered status in Wyoming, most of his fellow GOP activists ignored his daughter and sided with three-termer Enzi. They saw no difference between the two conservatives on any issue other than Liz Cheney wanted to be a senator.

Liz Cheney clearly had problems going into the race, notably her long-time residence in Northern Virginia before becoming a candidate. She has personal reasons for ending her candidacy on Monday. However, she also had history against her.

Title: Analysis of Hillary Clinton's Potential 2016 Presidential Campaign

Article:

The article discusses the potential 2016 presidential campaign of Hillary Clinton, former First Lady, Senator, and Secretary of State. The piece suggests that while Clinton is a well-known figure in American politics, her candidacy is not universally supported, with some Democrats viewing her as their only viable option, while Republicans see her as a formidable opponent.

The article highlights Clinton's political experience, her ability to discuss policy, and her status as a woman, which could potentially help her with female voters. However, it also mentions that she has carried baggage from her husband's presidency and may face criticism for her role in President Barack Obama's administration.

The article also touches upon Clinton's public speaking style, which is described as stiff and wooden, and her perceived lack of political instinct. The piece suggests that Clinton's ambition, while strong, may not be matched by the "fire in the belly" that drives successful politicians.

The article further discusses the challenges Clinton might face in a 2016 campaign, such as increased scrutiny from the press and the need to defend her record. It also mentions the potential financial implications of a campaign, comparing the lifestyle of a candidate to that of a wealthy, retired individual.

The article concludes by suggesting that Clinton's ambition may be driving her towards a 2016 campaign, but she may face significant challenges, including a lack of enthusiasm from some voters and financial difficulties once the campaign begins. The piece also implies that the Clinton's focus on their own interests may lead to difficulties for others involved in their political endeavors.

The article does not provide a clear conclusion about Clinton's chances in a 2016 presidential campaign, instead presenting a balanced analysis of her strengths and weaknesses.

Title: Uncertainty for 4 Million Unauthorized Immigrants as Deferred Action Program Remains Suspended

Article:

Around four million unauthorized immigrants are currently in legal limbo more than two weeks after a federal judge in Texas suspended President Obama's move to temporarily protect them from deportation. Many of these parents of U.S. citizens and green-card holders are worried that the government will now force them to leave the U.S. The lack of legal clarity also means some of them are being treated inconsistently by government officials.

Wilfredis Ayala, a construction worker from El Salvador, would have been helped by President Obama's deferred action program for parents staying in the U.S. illegally. Ayala, 30, has been dodging deportation orders for the past 10 years after crossing the U.S.-Mexico border illegally by car. Now living on Long Island, N.Y., with his U.S.-born, 5-year-old son, Justin, Ayala says he's never had trouble with the police—until he was arrested last January for trespassing on private property while taking a shortcut through his neighborhood. That put him in the sights of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), which was ready to finally deport him before his lawyer got him released from the detention center.

"I cried tears of joy to be with my son again, to be able to hug him and kiss him and play with him," Ayala says in Spanish. "The whole time I was locked up I longed to be with him."

Ayala's lawyer, Bryan Johnson, argued that his client was eligible for Obama's deferred action program for parents, which temporarily protected Ayala from deportation until the Texas court ruling put the program on hold. Now, Johnson says he's not sure what will happen during their next appointment with immigration officials.

"I'm going to tell ICE that we're waiting for deferred action, and then from there, we'll see what happens," says Johnson, a partner at the immigration law firm Amoachi & Johnson. "But I mean he's not safe because there is no deferred action to apply for."

In a statement, an ICE spokesman says the agency is still focusing on deporting criminals and those who recently crossed the border illegally first—priorities that the president emphasized during a recent town hall meeting televised by MSNBC and Telemundo.

"If you've been here for a long time and if you qualify, generally, then during this period, even with legal uncertainty, they should be in a good place," Obama told the audience in Miami.

However, Marty Rosenbluth, who teaches immigration law at Elon University, says that some local immigration offices have been applying the policy inconsistently and detaining parents who would have been left alone before the Texas court ruling.

"It's created a huge amount of fear, and people who were preparing to apply now don't know what to do," he says.

Rosenbluth adds this could have a long-term impact on Obama's deferred action programs if the courts allow them to take effect. (The government is still accepting applications for the original deferred action program for young immigrants who came before turning 16 and have lived in the U.S. since 2007.)

"Convincing people that it's safe is going to be a lot tougher even if this temporary injunction is overturned," he says.

It could be months before the legal battle over the president's deferred action programs is finished in the courts. A judge is still reviewing the Obama administration's request for the programs to go ahead while the lawsuit continues. However, Ayala is facing a much shorter timeline; he's due back in front of immigration officials next Wednesday.

"The truth is," he says in Spanish, "I don't know what is going to happen that day."

Title: New York Attorney General's Office Alleges $1 Billion in Wire Transfers by Sackler Family Amid Opioid Crisis Litigation

Article:

The New York Attorney General's Office has reportedly uncovered approximately $1 billion in wire transfers by the Sackler family, the owners of Purdue Pharma, which could suggest an attempt to hide their wealth as they face litigation over their role in the opioid crisis. The transfers include some done through Swiss bank accounts, according to The New York Times.

State Attorney General Letitia James (D) reportedly issued subpoenas last month to 33 financial institutions and investment advisers in an attempt to fully discover the family's wealth. While the Sacklers continue to negotiate settlements with victims, James stated, "We refuse to allow the family to misuse the courts in an effort to shield their financial misconduct."

Records from one financial institution alone have shown approximately $1 billion in wire transfers between the Sacklers, entities they control, and different financial institutions, including those that have funneled funds into Swiss bank accounts. Court documents filed by James's office on Friday reportedly show initial findings from one unnamed financial institution. The filing reportedly shows a series of transfers by former Purdue board member Mortimer D.A. Sackler.

"Already, these records have allowed the state to identify previously unknown shell companies that one of the Sackler defendants used to shift Purdue money through accounts around the world and then conceal it in at least two separate multimillion-dollar real estate investments back here in New York, sanitized [until now] of any readily detectable connections to the Sackler family," wrote lawyer David E. Nachman from James's office in a letter to the court, according to the Times.

Purdue Pharma declined to comment, while a spokesperson for Mortimer D.A. Sackler dismissed allegations surrounding the wire transfers. "There is nothing newsworthy about these decade-old transfers, which were perfectly legal and appropriate in every respect. This is a cynical attempt by a hostile AG's office to generate defamatory headlines to try to torpedo a mutually beneficial settlement that is supported by so many other states and would result in billions of dollars going to communities and individuals across the country that need help," the spokesperson told ███.

The revelations come as Purdue Pharma has reached a multibillion-dollar tentative settlement with state and local governments over its alleged role in the opioid crisis. The exact details of the settlement have not been disclosed.

Title: North Carolina Emerges as Evenly Divided Presidential Battleground

Article:

North Carolina, historically known for its contradictory political leanings, is currently experiencing a shift in its demographics, making it difficult to predict the state's tilt in the upcoming November elections. The state, which has elected figures like racial hard-liner Jesse Helms and New South Democrats like Terry Sanford and Jim Hunt, is now more evenly divided in presidential elections than ever.

The two largest population centers, Charlotte and the Research Triangle of Raleigh, Durham, and Chapel Hill, have undergone significant transformation due to an influx of political centrists from other states. The fastest-growing party registration preference is not Republican nor Democrat, but unaffiliated. The rural white "Jessecrats," conservative Democrats who traditionally voted for Mr. Helms, are dwindling. The state's elections are now won in fast-growing edge towns like Cary, outside Raleigh, often jokingly referred to as Containment Area for Relocated Yankees.

Neither Donald Trump, with his hard-edge nationalism, nor Hillary Clinton, with a swirl of scandal surrounding her, appears to be a natural fit for a state that yearns for political moderation but is increasingly disenchanted with the political class. Carter Wrenn, a veteran Republican strategist in the state, stated, "They don't like either party and they don't like either candidate. It will just depend on which one they dislike less on Election Day."

Polls indicate that Trump and Clinton begin the general election close in North Carolina. The most telling sign of a toss-up: Democrats believe Trump starts with a narrow advantage, while Republicans believe Clinton does. What they agree on is that, as at the national level, Republicans are largely coalescing around Trump, and ruling out the possibility that Clinton could run away with the state.

However, Trump's difficulties among Hispanic voters could push typical swing states such as Colorado, Nevada, and Florida toward the Democrats. This could potentially force Trump to carry the combined 28 electoral votes from North Carolina and Virginia to capture the White House.

Title: Tight Races and Uncertain Outcomes: A Look at the 2014 Midterm Elections

Article:

The 2014 midterm elections are expected to be a close contest, with many congressional and gubernatorial races remaining undecided as voters head to the polls. The battle for the Senate is largely a referendum on President Obama's final two years in office, with the outcome potentially hinging on approximately 10 toss-up or battleground races. At the state level, nearly a dozen governors are at risk of losing their seats, a volatile landscape not seen in decades.

In the Senate, three races are considered locked down for the Republican Party: Montana, South Dakota, and West Virginia. However, Republicans remain in competitive races in a number of other states, including those that President Obama lost in 2012 and where he continues to have low approval ratings. This includes Alaska, Arkansas, Louisiana, and North Carolina. Arkansas is increasingly seen as a likely flip to Republican hands, with GOP Rep. Tom Cotton expected by many analysts to defeat Democratic Sen. Mark Pryor.

In the states Obama won in 2012, Republicans are competing. Topping this list are Iowa and Colorado, but Republican Scott Brown is also putting up a fight in his race against Democratic Sen. Jeanne Shaheen in New Hampshire. Republicans are battling to retain control of three seats: in Georgia, Kansas, and Kentucky.

The House of Representatives also sees tight races, with all 435 seats on the ballot. Of them, 233 are held by Republicans and 199 held by Democrats. Democrats would need 17 seats to take the majority, an unlikely possibility. Rather, Republicans are expected to pick up at least five more seats. Among the most compelling races are ones in Arizona and New York.

In Arizona, Republican Martha McSally, the first female Air Force pilot to fly in combat, is trying to take a House seat from Democrats. In New York, 30-year-old Republican Elise Stefanik would be the youngest female House member if she wins Tuesday. McSally is running in one of the few remaining moderate districts, for the seat once held by Democratic Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, who retired from Congress in 2012 after being shot in the head during a mass shooting. McSally again faces Democratic Rep. Ron Barber, the former Giffords staffer who narrowly defeated McSally in 2012. The nonpartisan RealClearPolitics.com lists the race as a tossup.

In New York, Stefanik, a former Bush White House aide, has positioned herself as a first-time candidate eager to bring "new ideas" and "new leadership" to the upstate 21st District. She faces Democratic nominee and film producer Aaron Woolf and third-party candidate Matt Funiciello for the open seat of retiring Democratic Rep. Bill Owens.

Gubernatorial seats in 36 states are on the ballot, and nearly a dozen U.S. governors are considered in political peril on Election Day, making it one of the toughest years for incumbent governors in decades. One survey, by Governing magazine, puts the number of toss-up races at 18 when including eight "competitive" races. The incumbents in Governing's 10 tossup races are a mix of seven Republicans and three Democrats and include such high-profile state leaders as Florida GOP Gov. Rick Scott, Wisconsin GOP Gov. Scott Walker, and Illinois Democratic Gov. Pat Quinn.

Title: Trump's Travel Ban: A Closer Look at the Six Countries and the Rationale Behind the Policy

Article:

In response to the recent terrorist attack in London, President Donald Trump tweeted that "we need to be smart, vigilant, and tough," "stop being politically correct," and "get down to the business of security for our people." The only concrete policy he mentioned was his temporary ban on visitors from six Muslim-majority countries, a measure that is unlikely to reduce the already tiny risk of dying in a terrorist attack.

The executive order, which covers six countries (down from seven in the original version), includes Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen. Since 1975, no one in the United States has died in an attack by a terrorist from any of those countries, although there have been less serious incidents, including two nonfatal knife attacks last year by people with Somali backgrounds, both of whom were killed in the midst of their assaults. From 1975 through 2015, according to a count by Cato Institute immigration analyst Alex Nowrasteh, six Iranians, six Sudanese, two Somalis, and one Yemini were "convicted of attempting or carrying out terrorist attacks on U.S. soil."

Trump's order mentions just one of those cases, involving "a native of Somalia who had been brought to the United States as a child refugee and later became a naturalized United States citizen." As the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit noted when it upheld the injunction against the travel ban, the order "does not include any examples of individuals from Iran, Libya, Sudan, Syria, or Yemen committing terrorism-related offenses in the United States." However, Nowrasteh found at least 13 such cases involving people from Iran, Sudan, and Yemen.

Even if Trump had included all the relevant examples, the case for targeting these six countries would be weak, since citizens of other countries account for a much larger share of terrorist plots, attacks, and casualties in the United States. From 1975 through 2015, Nowrasteh found, 19 foreign-born terrorists came from Saudi Arabia, 14 came from Pakistan, 11 came from Egypt, and 11 more came from Cuba. Their combined death toll was 2,537. During the same period, six foreign-born terrorists came from Iran, six from Sudan, two from Somalia, and one from Yemen. Zero came from Libya or Syria. The combined death toll for terrorists from those six countries was zero.

Nor is it clear how Trump's plan, which calls for the development of improved vetting procedures during the three months when citizens of the six countries would be forbidden to enter the United States, can reasonably be expected to catch the tiny percentage prone to terrorism. As an internal Department of Homeland Security report prepared last March notes, "most foreign-born, US-based violent extremists likely radicalized several years after their entry to the United States, limiting the ability of screening and vetting officials to prevent their entry because of national security concerns." In the one relevant case cited by Trump's executive order, better vetting would have made no difference, since the offender entered the country as a child.

In a declaration cited by the 4th Circuit, 10 former national security, foreign policy, and intelligence officials (mostly from Democratic administrations) said "there is no national security purpose for a total bar on entry for aliens" from the seven countries named in the original travel ban (the current six plus Iraq). "Since September 11, 2001," they said, "not a single terrorist attack in the United States has been perpetrated by aliens from the countries named in the Order." As noted above, that is not quite accurate. But it is fair to say that Trump's selection of countries seems arbitrary given the backgrounds of terrorists who have carried out attacks in the United States, very few of whom came from any of those countries.

The same is true if you look at people convicted in connection with planned domestic attacks that never came to fruition. Nowrasteh identified four such cases involving people from the targeted countries (two from Iran and two from Somalia) since 9/11.

Trump's travel ban may indeed be tough (at least as far as its impact on foreign nationals and their American relatives goes) and it may be (and probably is) constitutional. But that does not make it smart.

Addendum: In a follow-up tweet this morning, Trump says, "The Justice Dept. should have stayed with the original Travel Ban, not the watered down, politically correct version they submitted to S.C." That remark is weird for a couple of reasons: 1) It was Trump, not the Justice Department, who ultimately decided to issue a revised executive order rather than continue to defend the original version, and 2) excluding lawful permanent residents and current visa holders from the ban made the order harder to challenge.

Trump compounds the weirdness in a subsequent tweet: "The Justice Dept. should ask for an expedited hearing of the watered down Travel Ban before the Supreme Court— & seek much tougher version!" Reverting to the original order after successfully defending the revised one would only prolong the legal battle, and here again Trump makes it seem as if he is not really in charge of his own administration, that the Justice Department decides which executive orders to issue.

Title: Republican Party Gains Lead on Generic Congressional Ballot, Trump Approval Rating Equals Disapproval in New Poll

Article:

In a recent poll conducted by ███/Morning Consult, the Republican Party has taken the lead on the generic congressional ballot for the first time since April. The poll also shows President Donald Trump's approval rating matching the percentage of voters who disapprove of his job performance.

According to the poll, 39% of registered voters would support the GOP candidate for Congress in their district, while 38% would back the Democratic candidate. Nearly a quarter of voters, 23%, are undecided.

The poll reveals a split among voters along party lines. Democratic voters favor their party by a significant margin, 85% to 5%, while Republicans similarly favor the GOP, 84% to 8%. Among independent voters, 26% would vote for the Democrat, 25% for the Republican, and nearly half, 49%, are undecided.

The Republican Party's 1-point advantage comes after three months of tracking during which Democrats maintained a lead ranging between 2 and 10 points on the generic ballot. The most recent RealClearPolitics average shows Democrats ahead by 7 points on the generic ballot, though that's down from a high of 13 points late last year.

The new year has also produced a Trump polling bump. In the new poll, 47% of voters approve of the job Trump is doing as president, while the same percentage disapprove. Among Democrats, 16% approve of Trump's job performance and 80% disapprove. The numbers are almost exactly inverted among Republicans: 82% approve, while 16% disapprove. Trump is still underwater among independents: 39% approve and 49% disapprove.

Like with the generic ballot, other public polling is less rosy for Trump—but there is a distinct improvement over the past two months. The president's average approval rating as of late Tuesday was 41%, up from a low-water mark of 37% in mid-December.

The poll shows that voters' perceptions of Republicans have recovered from the lows of late last year, including on a number of key issues. "Not only have Republicans increased support on the generic congressional ballot, they are now trusted more to handle the most important issue when voters head to the polls: the economy," said Kyle Dropp, Morning Consult's co-founder and chief research officer. "In mid-December, 39% of voters said they trusted Democrats more to handle the economy, compared to 38% who said Republicans. Today, 43% say Republicans and 32% say Democrats."

Congressional Republicans also have a 9-point advantage on handling jobs, a 6-point lead on dealing with immigration, and a 19-point lead on handling national security. The Democratic advantage on health care has dwindled to just 4 percentage points, down from double digits last year.

The poll was conducted Feb. 8-12, surveying 1,985 registered voters. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus 2 percentage points. Morning Consult is a nonpartisan media and technology company that provides data-driven research and insights on politics, policy, and business strategy. More details on the poll and its methodology can be found in these two documents: Toplines (http://politi.co/2ErFkOI) and Crosstabs (http://politi.co/2F3WHSI).

Title: Republican Senators Distance Themselves from Trump Amid Widening Clinton Leads in Key States

Article:

In the ongoing 2016 presidential race, several House Republicans and Senate incumbents are distancing themselves from the Republican nominee, Donald Trump. Representative Mike Coffman of Colorado recently ran a commercial stating, "Honestly, I don't care for him much," and vowed that if Trump were elected, "I'll stand up to him. Plain and simple."

Kristen Soltis Anderson, a Republican pollster, notes that differentiating congressional candidates from the nominee may not be challenging. "One great thing for many Republican candidates is that Donald Trump is unusual—he's not a generic Republican," she said. "In a state like Ohio, voters will be able to distinguish between Trump and Rob Portman." Senator Portman is currently locked in a tight race.

Some endangered Senate incumbents, such as Mark Kirk of Illinois, have flatly declared they will not vote for Trump. Most others, however, are trying to avoid offending Trump's fervent followers while not alienating more independent-minded centrists. Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire stated she is supporting Trump but isn't endorsing him. If he comes to her state, she will be absent.

Senator Ayotte's supporters want her to distance herself further, especially since Trump called her "weak" last week. Few Republicans are suffering as much as Senator John McCain of Arizona. Privately, he has contempt for Trump, but the senator faces a right-wing primary challenge this month, in which many Trump supporters will turn out. Even when Trump took a shot at him last week, McCain held his fire and reiterated that he always supports the party nominee.

Recent polls suggest that this delicate facade may be cracking. Hillary Clinton has opened up significant leads in New Hampshire and Pennsylvania, with signs that Trump is dragging down incumbent senators. Republican strategists say a five-point Clinton victory in these states is survivable for down-ballot candidates. Anything more, particularly if her margin hits double digits, might mean curtains.

Democrats today are more optimistic that these wider margins are possible, noting that in this polarized environment, ticket-splitting is less prevalent. And waves, as Gaylord Nelson discovered in 1980, usually break late.

Title: Jonathan Gruber's Remarks on Affordable Care Act Spark Controversy

Article:

In a series of videos released over the past few days, economist Jonathan Gruber, one of the architects of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), has been caught making controversial remarks about the American public and the passage of the healthcare legislation.

In one video from 2010, Gruber stated that the American public "doesn't actually care that much about the uninsured." In another video from 2012, he claimed that the Obama administration successfully relied on an electorate that didn't fully understand the legislation.

Gruber also said in a speech at the University of Pennsylvania in 2013 that the very function of the law, doing what it was designed to do, was unpalatable to voters. He stated, "If you had a law which said healthy people are going to pay in -- if you made it explicit that healthy people pay in and sick people get money, it would not have passed."

Gruber also admitted that the sales pitch for the law was a cover-up operation, stating, "Lack of transparency is a huge advantage. And basically, you know, call it the stupidity of the American voter or whatever. But basically, that was really, really critical to getting the thing to pass."

These videos have sparked controversy, with critics arguing that Gruber's remarks demonstrate a lack of respect for the American public and a belief that the administration hoodwinked the American people to pass the legislation.

However, it is important to note that Gruber's remarks were made in public lectures, not in private meetings with liberal donors. Additionally, the Affordable Care Act's reliance on healthy people paying in to cover sick people was not a secret, and the administration spent millions on a marketing campaign to convince young, healthy people to invest in health insurance.

Furthermore, opponents of the legislation were vocal about the potential problems with the law, and numerous advocacy groups, impartial economists, and media outlets were fact-checking the President's rosy predictions about the law.

Despite Gruber's claims, the American people never voted on Obamacare, and the law has never enjoyed a majority of public support since its passage. According to Kaiser Family tracking polls, the law has never cracked a 51% favorability rating and has at times plummeted to the low 30s.

In conclusion, while Jonathan Gruber's remarks may be seen as arrogant and offensive, it is important to consider the context in which they were made and the public's awareness of the Affordable Care Act's reliance on healthy people paying in to cover sick people. The controversy surrounding Gruber's remarks is likely to continue as the Affordable Care Act's implementation and impact are debated in the coming years.

Title: Senate Passes Bipartisan Budget Deal, Averting Government Shutdown

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — A bipartisan budget and debt deal, which would permit the government to resume borrowing to pay all its bills and avoid a potential government shutdown in October, was passed by the Senate on Thursday in a 67-28 vote. The legislation, which President Donald Trump has promised to sign, would set an overall $1.37 trillion limit on agency budgets approved by Congress annually.

The deal, which was powered by President Trump's endorsement and a bipartisan drive to cement recent spending increases for the Pentagon and domestic agencies, marked a drama-free solution to a worrisome set of looming Washington deadlines. The measure does nothing to stem the government's spiraling debt and the return of $1 trillion-plus deficits but it also takes away the prospect of a government shutdown in October or the threat of deep automatic spending cuts.

The administration and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., played strong hands in the talks that sealed the agreement last week, producing a pragmatic measure that had much for lawmakers to dislike. Trump did step back from a possible fight over spending increases sought by liberals, and he achieved his priorities on Pentagon budgets and the stock market-soothing borrowing limit.

"Budget Deal is phenomenal for our Great Military, our Vets, and Jobs, Jobs, Jobs!" Trump tweeted before the vote. "Two year deal gets us past the Election. Go for it Republicans, there is always plenty of time to CUT!"

The bill was an epitaph to the 2011 Budget Control Act, which came about due to a tea party-fueled battle over debt limit legislation during the run-up to President Barack Obama's re-election. That law promised more than $2 trillion in deficit cuts through 2021, including automatic spending cuts that were put in place after the failure of a so-called deficit supercommittee.

The bill would lift the debt limit for two years, into either a second Trump term or the administration of a Democratic successor. It would reverse scheduled 10 percent cuts to defense and nondefense programs next year, at a two-year cost of more than $200 billion. An additional $100 billion over two years would add to recent gains for military readiness, combating opioids, and other domestic initiatives, and would keep pace with rising costs for veterans' health care.

Those increases alone, assuming they are repeated year after year, promise to add $2 trillion or more to the government's $22 trillion debt over the coming decade. The bill was powered by a coalition of GOP defense hawks, Democrats seeking to preserve gains in domestic accounts, and the leaders of the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. Democrats voted for the bill by a wide margin, and it won a healthy majority of Senate Republicans.

"Providing sufficient funding for our military and eliminating the threat of sequestration for good are absolutely necessary for our military to have the budgetary stability and predictability they so desperately need," said the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sen. James Inhofe, R-Okla.

It was also a long-sought victory for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., who initiated the negotiations and was deeply invested in bringing order and relative predictability to the budget and debt deadlines. Losers included more conservative elements of the White House. Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, a former tea party congressman from South Carolina, and acting budget director Russell Vought were rebuffed in attempts to add spending cuts to defray the bill's cost.

Title: White House Defends Obama's Legacy, Trump Criticizes Black Progress under Administration

Article:

In a recent statement, Donald Trump claimed that black Americans have not made progress under President Barack Obama, a claim that has sparked controversy and debate. The White House, however, has maintained that blacks have made progress under the first black president, and that Trump's policies would reverse these gains.

According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the black unemployment rate in July was 8.4 percent, compared to 12.6 percent when President Obama took office in January 2009. However, the jobless rate for whites, currently at 4.3 percent, has fallen slightly more than it has for blacks over the past eight years, decreasing by 37 percent for whites and 33 percent for blacks.

On a range of other government data, blacks are faring worse under President Obama. The black labor force participation rate has fallen from 63.2 percent in 2009 to 61.2 percent last month. Black homeownership last month was 41.7 percent, down from 46.1 percent in 2009 – a drop of nearly one-tenth. The percentage of black Americans living below the poverty line has risen from 25.8 percent in 2009 to 26.2 percent in 2014, according to the most recent Census Bureau data. The number of black food-stamp participants increased 58 percent, from 7.3 million to 11.7 million.

In response to these statistics, the White House has emphasized the importance of electing Hillary Clinton as president to build on President Obama's legacy. White House press secretary Josh Earnest stated, "The president’s never made the case that the work is finished, that the job is done. The point is, President Obama’s interested in being succeeded in office by someone who is committed to building on the progress we’ve made thus far as opposed to tearing it down."

Black leaders have criticized Trump's claim that he will improve conditions for black Americans. Ben Jealous, former president of the NAACP, stated, "Donald Trump is dancing around on race and immigration, because his racism and xenophobia is threatening to trump the GOP’s chances to hold on to the Senate let alone take back the White House."

Despite little evidence that Trump's plea to black voters is changing minds, dissatisfaction among blacks with the lack of progress under President Obama has been no secret. Tavis Smiley, broadcaster, stated earlier this year, "Sadly – and it pains me to say this – over the last decade, black folk, in the era of Obama, have lost ground in every major economic category."

The Urban League's National Equality Index has found blacks losing ground, from 57.4 percent equality with whites in 2009 to 56.2 percent this year. This year's rating represented a slight improvement from 55.8 percent in 2015. The report lamented "an all-too-familiar story of persistent racial disparities in American life, making clear that the historic Obama presidency has not been a panacea for America’s long-standing race problem."

The White House is arguing that, with President Obama having lowered jobless rates dramatically for whites and blacks, Hillary Clinton has better proposals than Trump to benefit all workers. White House press secretary Josh Earnest stated, "The kinds of proposals that have been put forward by the other side would have the effect of eroding our progress, primarily because they would have a devastating impact fiscally and economically doling out significant tax cuts to those at the top of the income scale and leaving the rest of us to pay the tab."

Mrs. Clinton moved more aggressively Thursday, using a campaign ad and a speech, to link Trump to white supremacists such as former KKK figure David Duke. She said Trump is "helping a radical fringe take over the Republican Party." Trump responded by accusing Clinton of "race baiting."

Title: President Trump Delivers Remarks at National Prayer Breakfast Amid Impeachment Acquittal

Article:

Washington, D.C. – President Donald Trump delivered remarks at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday, a day after his Senate acquittal in the impeachment trial. Trump used the event to criticize those who supported the impeachment drive, stating, "My family, our great country, and your president have been put through a terrible ordeal by some very dishonest and corrupt people."

Trump entered the venue waving copies of newspapers with headlines such as "ACQUITTED" and "Trump Acquitted." House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., commented before the president spoke, stating, "The Lord works in mysterious ways. I do not believe he could’ve picked a better day to bring us all together."

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., who led the impeachment drive, was also present at the event. Trump and Pelosi did not interact personally, with Trump commenting, "I do not like people who say 'I pray for you,' when they know that is not so." In December, Pelosi stated, "I pray for the president all the time."

After the event, Pelosi described Trump's comments as "completely inappropriate," stating, "Especially at a prayer breakfast." Several speakers at the event addressed political polarization and prayed for the nation to overcome it.

Trump recounted his actions supporting school prayer and international efforts to prevent the persecution of Christians. The National Prayer Breakfast, a Washington tradition since 1953, was established by President Dwight Eisenhower at the suggestion of evangelist Billy Graham.

Utah Sen. Mitt Romney, the GOP's nominee for president in 2012, was the only senator to vote to convict Trump on the charge of abuse of power. Romney cited the evidence and his Mormon faith in his decision, calling Trump's conduct "grievously wrong." Trump responded with a midnight tweet about Romney's 2012 loss, stating, "If the candidate had devoted the same energy and anger to defeating a faltering Barack Obama as he sanctimoniously does to me, he could have won the election."

Historian Kevin Kruse of Princeton University, who has studied the National Prayer Breakfast, told a news outlet, "I can't say how bizarre it is for a president to use the moment – traditionally one devoted to bipartisanship and unity – to strike such a vindictive tone." Trump concluded his remarks by stating, "When they impeach you for nothing, then you're supposed to like them, it's not easy, folks. I do my best."

Title: Grand Princess Cruise Ship Halted Off California Coast After First Known COVID-19 Death in State

Article:

The Grand Princess cruise ship is currently stationary off the California coast following the state's first known death from COVID-19. Health workers are set to test some of the current passengers to determine the presence of the respiratory virus.

Governor Gavin Newsom announced at a news conference on Wednesday that they will be sending testing kits to the ship, with results expected in a few hours. Eleven passengers and ten crew members are reportedly showing symptoms of COVID-19, with the number potentially understating the virus's presence on the ship.

Governor Newsom declared a state of emergency in California on Wednesday to help the state cope with its first COVID-19 death and over 50 confirmed cases overall. The passenger who died was an elderly man who, health officials believe, was exposed to the novel coronavirus during a trip from San Francisco to Mexico in mid-February.

Another California resident who was on the same trip has also tested positive for the virus. The man was on the ship from February 11-21 and had underlying health conditions before being hospitalized in California's Placer County on February 27.

The Grand Princess is carrying approximately 2,500 passengers and 1,150 crew members. Only a small fraction of these individuals will be tested, with the remainder of the people on board being asked to monitor themselves for any possible symptoms of COVID-19.

To carry out the tests, the California National Guard plans to use a helicopter to deliver kits to the Grand Princess on Thursday morning. The onboard medical team will then collect samples, which will be flown back to shore to be analyzed at a lab in Richmond, Calif.

In a letter sent to current passengers who were also on the earlier trip, Princess Cruises informed them that they must remain in their staterooms until cleared by the medical staff. The exact date and time for the ship's arrival are yet to be determined.

After the Grand Princess completed its Mexico trip, the ship left California for a cruise to Hawaii. It is now returning from that voyage, and operator Princess Cruises has canceled the ship's scheduled call in Ensenada, Mexico, to bring it off the coast near San Francisco on Thursday.

San Francisco announced its first two COVID-19 cases on Thursday: a man in his 90s hospitalized in serious condition and a woman in her 40s hospitalized in fair condition. Both were tested by the state department of public health on March 4.

The Grand Princess is the second Princess Cruises ship to be identified with a potential cluster of coronavirus cases. Last month, the Diamond Princess was held in quarantine for weeks at the port in Yokohama, Japan.

Princess Cruises has canceled the Grand Princess's next planned Hawaii cruise, which was to depart on Saturday. About half of the people who were on the cruise to Mexico are California residents, and authorities are working to contact them and urge them to monitor themselves for potential COVID-19 symptoms.

California health agencies are currently monitoring at least 9,400 people in 49 counties who were potentially exposed to the coronavirus through air travel. In addition to heightening the state's response to the coronavirus outbreak, the governor's emergency declaration forbids price gouging on products that are important in fighting viruses, such as hand sanitizer.

The U.S. now has at least 99 domestic cases of coronavirus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. This figure does not include the 49 cases in which Americans were repatriated to the U.S. on evacuation flights from Japan and from Wuhan, China, where the novel coronavirus was first detected.

Title: Record 3.7 Million Gun Background Checks in March, Suggested by COVID-19 Outbreak

Article:
