The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) processed a record 3.7 million gun background checks in March, surpassing any previously reported monthly total, according to the agency's latest data. This surge in gun sales appears to be, at least in part, linked to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

The Trump administration this week designated gun shops as "essential" businesses, enabling them to continue selling firearms to both existing and new customers, while other retail outlets have closed their doors. Five of the top ten days with the highest number of background checks occurred in March, since the inception of the National Instant Criminal Background Check System in 1998.

March ranks as the second-busiest month ever for gun sales, trailing only January 2013, which followed President Obama's re-election and the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, according to the New York Times.

David Yamane, a sociology professor at Wake Forest who has studied gun culture, attributes the increase in gun buying to mass social uncertainty. He stated, "In times of crisis, people tend to buy guns."

Reports of increased firearm and ammunition purchases, as well as an influx of first-time gun buyers, have already been documented in areas heavily impacted by COVID-19, such as Washington state, California, and New York. Yamane noted, "In addition to the usual suspects who are adding to what they already own, there has been a sort of different profile of people coming in [to gun shops]. In this instance, people who are first-time gun owners or do not fit the traditional demographic of older, white male."

The latest installment of the ███-Ipsos Coronavirus Index also indicated rises in purchases of guns and ammunition, although the sample size was relatively small.

In a video tweeted by the National Rifle Association (NRA) on March 21, an activist warned, "You might be stockpiling up on food right now, but if you aren't preparing to defend your property when everything goes wrong, you're really just stockpiling for somebody else."

Title: Supreme Court to Decide Fate of Gay Marriage and Voting Rights Act

Article:

The Supreme Court is set to deliver major rulings on two significant cases this week. One case challenges California's voter-enacted ban on same-sex marriage, while the other concerns the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) provision that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman.

In the California case, the Supreme Court is expected to rule on the constitutionality of Proposition 8, a voter-approved amendment to the state constitution that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman. Potential outcomes include nationwide invalidation of bans on gay marriage, legalization of gay marriage only in California and six other states with similar legal structures, or resumption of same-sex marriages in California alone. The justices may also uphold Prop 8.

The court heard oral arguments in the four-year-old case in March, with several justices expressing doubts about the case's validity. Justice Anthony Kennedy, who is often considered the potentially decisive vote on a closely divided court, suggested that the court could dismiss the case with no ruling at all. Such an outcome would allow gay marriages to resume in California but have no impact elsewhere.

In the DOMA case, the justices are considering the constitutionality of a provision that affects a range of benefits available to married couples, including tax breaks, survivor benefits, and health insurance for spouses of federal employees. The Obama administration abandoned its defense of the law in 2011 but continues to enforce it.

The justices chose the case of Edith Windsor, an 83-year-old New York resident, who sued to challenge a $363,000 federal estate tax bill after her partner of 44 years died in 2009. During the March hearing, Justice Kennedy expressed concerns about the law's intrusion on the power of states that recognize same-sex marriages. Other justices described the law as creating two classes of marriage: full marriage and "skim-milk marriage."

If the Supreme Court finds that it does not have the authority to hear the case, Windsor would likely still receive her refund, as she won in the lower courts. However, there would be no definitive decision about the law from the nation's highest court, and it would remain on the books.

In a separate ruling on Tuesday, the Supreme Court voted 5-4 to strike down the requirement in the Voting Rights Act that all or parts of 15 states with a history of discrimination in voting, mainly in the South, get Washington's approval before changing the way they hold elections. The court ruled that the formula determining which states are affected was unconstitutional.

The ruling potentially opens the door for certain states to implement voter ID laws and other efforts that had been held up because of the Voting Rights Act. Attorney General Greg Abbott, a Republican, stated that Texas' voter ID law, which a panel of federal judges blocked as discriminatory, would be allowed to take effect following Tuesday's ruling.

Attorney General Eric Holder warned states against going too far, stating that the Justice Department would not hesitate to take "swift" action against states looking to "take advantage" of the ruling. He, like President Obama, expressed disappointment in the decision, stating that discriminatory practices still exist and need to be addressed.

The high court is currently engaged in a broad re-examination of the ongoing necessity of laws and programs aimed at giving racial minorities access to major areas of American life from which they once were excluded. The justices issued a modest ruling on Monday that preserved affirmative action in higher education and will take on cases dealing with anti-discrimination sections of a federal housing law and another affirmative action case from Michigan next term.

Title: The Unattainability of Revolutionary Change: A Critique of Bernie Sanders' Campaign Strategy

Article:

In the aftermath of the Democratic primary, a critical analysis of Bernie Sanders' campaign strategy has emerged, suggesting that the senator's call for a "revolution" in the United States is unrealistic and potentially detrimental to the progressive cause.

The argument posits that the economic conditions necessary for a revolution, such as high unemployment, stagnant wages, and widespread dissatisfaction with the system, are not present in the current U.S. economy. Unemployment remains at 5%, wages have been stagnant since the turn of the century but still average close to $70,000, and 90% of the country has health insurance coverage.

The critique asserts that, given these economic conditions, a revolution is unlikely to occur. Instead, the author suggests that meaningful change must be achieved through the "slow boring of hard wood," a metaphor for the slow, incremental process of political change.

The author's concern lies in the potential consequences of promising a revolution that may never materialize. If the revolution fails, the author fears that Sanders' impressionable young followers may become disillusioned with politics and abandon their pursuit of change. This could lead to a net increase in political cynicism and potentially discourage talented future leaders from engaging in politics.

The author acknowledges that their argument and those of Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama may not be as inspiring as Sanders' promises, but argues that the goals must be attainable to prevent disillusionment among followers. By offering a "chimera" instead, the author contends, Sanders has done the progressive movement no favors.

In conclusion, this critique of Bernie Sanders' campaign strategy argues that the call for a revolution is unrealistic given the current economic conditions in the United States. Instead, the author advocates for a more pragmatic, incremental approach to political change to avoid disillusioning potential future leaders and increasing political cynicism.

Title: House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff Threatens Legal Action Over Whistleblower Complaint

Article:

House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff has vowed to take legal action against the Trump administration over a dispute regarding a whistleblower complaint to the intelligence community's inspector general, Michael Atkinson. The dispute centers around a complaint from an unidentified individual within the intelligence community concerning activity involving a high-ranking individual, which Schiff suggests is likely President Trump or someone close to him.

During a closed-door meeting with Atkinson, Schiff stated that the Justice Department has opined that the material is privileged and can be withheld from lawmakers. However, Schiff argues that the law and practice are clear: Congress oversees the intelligence agencies, and in this case, it must see the materials at issue.

Schiff told NPR on Thursday that if the administration is able to withhold the information, the whistleblower statute would not function, and it would discourage people from coming forward. He added that if they have to go to court to obtain the complaint, they will have a strong case.

President Trump has denied making any inappropriate comments to a foreign leader, stating in a series of tweets that "Virtually anytime I speak on the phone to a foreign leader, I understand that there may be many people listening from various U.S. agencies, not to mention those from the other country itself." Trump also questioned the credibility of the reports, stating, "Is anybody dumb enough to believe that I would say something inappropriate with a foreign leader while on such a potentially 'heavily populated' call?"

Schiff stated earlier that the intelligence community's inspector general determined that the complaint is both credible and urgent and should be transmitted to Congress under the law. Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire is set to testify in an open session before the panel next week.

The committee has released letters it received from the inspector general and a letter from Schiff to acting DNI Maguire. The Washington Post reported that the as-yet-unknown intelligence official filed a formal complaint to the IG on Aug. 12, and records show the president had "conversations or interactions" with five foreign leaders in the preceding weeks, including a phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin and two letters from North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

Other members of Congress, such as Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas), who sits on the Senate intelligence committee, are waiting to learn more about the complaint. Cornyn stated, "I'm anxious to hear more about it, but I expect we will in due course."

The dispute over the IG complaint is the latest political battle between Schiff and Trump, who have clashed frequently during the height of the Russia imbroglio. Schiff was among Democrats who said there was evidence that Trump's campaign colluded with the Russian attack on the 2016 election, citing the meeting that Donald Trump Jr. and other top aides took with a delegation from Moscow at Trump Tower. However, Schiff also alluded to evidence that was not public, including questions about whether Trump Jr.'s phone records from before the Trump Tower meeting might suggest that he had spoken with his father as it was being arranged. As it turned out, they did not, and Trump Jr. and the president have made Schiff a target of mockery and one of the faces of what Trump says is baseless hounding. The president revived that leitmotif on Thursday with another post on Twitter that complained about "Presidential Harassment!"

Title: Mueller's Testimony Leaves Political Landscape Unchanged, According to Sources

Article:

In a seemingly unchanged political landscape, former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's testimony did not appear to shift Speaker Nancy Pelosi's calculation regarding impeachment proceedings. The Senate Republicans' continued opposition to conviction in a potential Senate trial, which requires a two-thirds vote to remove President Donald Trump from office, has maintained the status quo.

Jeff Flake, the former Arizona senator who is one of the few prominent Republicans to openly defy Mr. Trump, commented, "It will certainly ratchet up pressure on the Dems to initiate impeachment proceedings, but I don't think it changes the fundamentals much." Flake added, "It's still a bad move in terms of 2020, and the speaker knows it."

At the White House, President Trump watched Mueller's testimony on television from the residence, spending most of the day there. Afterward, he met briefly with a few members of his staff and issued claims of vindication via Twitter and a press statement. However, privately, Trump reportedly complained that Mueller had always been out to get him and was frustrated that more people were not defending him on television, according to sources informed about his day.

Aides within the West Wing described a dominant feeling of outrage towards Mueller, but they also concluded that the special counsel had not altered the overall dynamics. No new facts emerged, and no smoking gun that had not already been known was presented. Mueller made clear that he would not go beyond his report even if he was called before a congressional committee.

One White House aide described the situation as stirring things up, similar to shaking a snow globe. Rarely has a high-profile special prosecutor left Washington so flummoxed, as former Watergate Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski left no doubt about his conclusions regarding President Richard M. Nixon, persuading a grand jury to name him an unindicted co-conspirator before his resignation.

Title: Senate Debates Proposed Immigration Overhaul, Boston Bombing Overshadows Discussion on Agriculture Workers' Legal Status

Article:

Senate Democrats and Republicans are currently debating a proposed immigration overhaul, with a focus on the eligibility of agricultural workers for a new "blue card" that would grant them permanent residence after five years. The debate, held at the second hearing since the bill's introduction, has been marked by disagreements over whether illegal immigrants working on U.S. farms should be eligible for the blue card.

Non-farmer workers in the United States illegally would have to wait about twice as long to achieve this status. However, the Senate Judiciary Committee debate has been overshadowed by the Boston Marathon bombings and the legal status of the two Russian-born suspects.

New York Democratic Sen. Chuck Schumer stated that the tragedy should not be used as an "excuse" for delaying the passage of immigration reform legislation. The debate was emotionally charged, with Iowa Sen. Chuck Grassley, the top Republican on the committee, expressing frustration. On Friday, Grassley stated that the circumstances related to the tragic bombings underscore the "gaps and loopholes" in the country's immigration system.

Committee Chairman Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., began the hearing by stating, "Late last week opponents of comprehensive immigration reform began to exploit the Boston Marathon bombing... Let no one be so cruel as to try to use the heinous acts of two young men last week to derail the dreams and futures of millions of hardworking people."

A bipartisan group of eight senators has been working on immigration reform legislation since January, an effort in part by both parties to reach out to Hispanics, the fastest-growing part of the U.S. population. The legislation was officially introduced last week, and five Senate hearings on the overall issue have been held so far this year. Chamber leaders expect to start submitting amendments in May with a vote this summer.

There are an estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in the U.S., and as many as 70% of U.S. agricultural workers are in the country illegally. Roughly 700,000 to 1.1 million illegal agricultural workers would be eligible for the blue card, provided they have at least a two-year work history and pass a criminal background check, pay fines, and taxes.

Supporters argue the change is needed in large part because of the high percentage of illegal workers in the industry and Americans' reluctance to perform the work. Alabama Republican Sen. Jeff Sessions argued that the guidelines for the proposal were crafted as part of a deal between big business and organized labor that benefits the United States the most. He also took issue with the argument about "jobs Americans won't do."

Republican Sens. John Cornyn, Texas, and Lindsey Graham, South Carolina, also raised concerns about how well the overall legislation will improve the tracking of immigrants who overstay their visas. Graham repeated his argument that the 19 hijackers involved in the 9/11 terror attacks were all students who overstayed their visas.

Title: California Attorney General Charges Undercover Journalists, Ignores Alleged Fetal Harvesting Confession

Article:

In a series of undercover videos released by the Center for Medical Progress, one video stands out for its graphic depiction of a Planned Parenthood employee's account of fetal tissue harvesting. Holly O' Donnell, a former StemExpress technician, described an incident at Planned Parenthood Mar Monte's Alameda Clinic in San Jose, California, where she was asked to "harvest" a fetus's brain.

O' Donnell's account, if accurate, could be considered a confession of murder under California law. The California Penal Code defines murder as the "unlawful killing of a human being, or a fetus, with malice aforethought." Planned Parenthood is alleged to have refused to render care to a born-alive infant, as required by California law, and to have acted affirmatively to cause the child's death.

Despite this revelation, major newspapers, mainstream websites, and nightly news outlets reportedly ignored the story. Now, California Attorney General Xavier Becerra has filed 15 felony charges against the undercover journalists, David Daleiden and Sandra Merritt, on the grounds that their recordings of business-related conversations without every participant's consent violated California eavesdropping laws.

Becerra, a Democrat, has received financial support from Planned Parenthood and has a 100% legislative rating from pro-abortion groups. In the past, his office has investigated claims of animal cruelty on chicken farms, but not homicide at abortion clinics.

The Center for Medical Progress's undercover videos have revealed Planned Parenthood's trade in fetal parts and its apparent disregard for the law. The videos have also exposed the moral rot within the abortion industry, with conversations about crushing babies to death and joking about the physical demands of dismembering a fetus.

On Wednesday, the Center for Medical Progress released a new video, in which Daleiden discusses abortion procedures with Dr. DeShawn Taylor, former medical director of Planned Parenthood Arizona, and the founder of her own abortion clinic in Phoenix. Taylor notes that, in Arizona, if a fetus shows signs of life, it is supposed to be transported to a hospital. Asked about a standard procedure for "verifying life," she replies, "The thing is, you need to pay attention to who's in the room, right?"

The Center for Medical Progress's work has prompted debate about the ethical boundaries of undercover journalism and the role of the media in exposing controversial practices. The organization's founder, David Daleiden, has been compared to whistleblowers who expose corruption and wrongdoing in various industries. The ongoing legal battle between Daleiden, Merritt, and the California Department of Justice is a testament to the power of undercover journalism and the importance of transparency in the medical field.

Title: Obama Pays Tribute to Fallen Heroes on Memorial Day

Article:

In his weekly address on Saturday, U.S. President Barack Obama commemorated Memorial Day by honoring the men and women who have sacrificed their lives in service to the country. The president urged all Americans to recognize and honor the nation's fallen heroes and stand with its veterans and military families this weekend.

In his address, Obama highlighted the importance of remembering the sacrifices made by these heroes, stating, "They are heroes, each and every one. They gave America the most precious thing they had -- 'the last full measure of devotion.'"

The president emphasized the quiet and unassuming nature of those who serve in the military, noting that their service and sacrifice are not always apparent due to their skill and the fact that they do not seek recognition or admiration. He also acknowledged the ideals of liberty and justice that these individuals have fought and died for, making America a beacon of hope for the world.

Obama also emphasized the importance of supporting the families of those currently serving and ensuring that veterans receive the care and benefits they have earned, as well as the jobs and opportunities they deserve. He concluded by urging Americans to remember the fallen heroes in their hearts and to work together to preserve the freedoms their sacrifices have secured.

The full transcript of Obama's address can be found on the White House website, and video of the address can be found on the White House's YouTube channel.

Title: Christian Business Leaders to Connect with Israeli Innovation at ARISE Conference

Article:

More than 600 business leaders from over 50 countries will gather in Israel for the second-annual ARISE conference on December 4, aiming to connect with and invest in Israeli business leaders. The theme of the conference, "Israeli Innovation for Humanity," will highlight Israeli companies in the medical, agricultural, transportation, and other fields whose products contribute to humanity.

ARISE Founder and President Adv. Calev Myers stated that the summit serves as a countermeasure against the global anti-Israel Boycotts, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement. Myers explained, "The best way to fight BDS is by bringing more business to Israel."

The ARISE team will facilitate hundreds of face-to-face meetings between Christian business leaders and Israeli companies to establish long-term investment relationships. The goal is to generate millions of dollars worth of transactions that strengthen Christian businesses and Israel's economy.

Myers emphasized that the conference offers Christians an entry point to Israel's economy through business matchmaking. He explained, "When you connect your business with a for-profit relationship, you're going to be coming to Israel more, you're going to be looking over your investments and your business, you're going to be reading Israeli headlines. It connects you on a deeper level."

Those unable to attend the event in Rishon Lezion can still participate online through ARISE's digital platform, where business owners can upload their profiles and chat with attendees. The conference will also feature a "Shark Tank"-style competition for Israeli companies and businesses to present their best products to the conference attendees. The winning business will receive a $10,000 grant from ARISE.

Myers also announced plans for a global trade center in Jerusalem, set to launch in 2022. He stated, "I can't think of a better way to humiliate BDS than by opening up a fully-functioning global trade center in Jerusalem." The trade center will be a partnership between faith-based business networks worldwide, aiming to streamline the process of bringing Israeli innovation to the nations.

Myers encourages Christians worldwide to participate in next week's conference.

Title: Obama's Shift in Approach to U.S. Capabilities and International Crises

Article:

In a statement, Jeremy Shapiro, a former Obama State Department official now at the Brookings Institution, suggested that U.S. presidents, including President Obama, have been reluctant to discuss deficiencies in capability due to the expectation of omnipotence and the associated sense of power. Shapiro added that Obama has been attempting to change this perception in the last year, recognizing that the demands of omnipotence have become disproportionate to what can be achieved.

However, the risk exists that the president may appear to be merely justifying his own actions or inactions, as noted by Daniel L. Byman, a former member of the Sept. 11 commission staff now teaching at Georgetown University. Byman expressed concern that Obama does not differentiate between issues he can influence and those beyond his control.

The criticisms leveled against President Obama are numerous. According to his detractors, he failed to curb the growth of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria by rejecting proposals to arm moderate elements of the Syrian resistance. Additionally, he left a power vacuum in Iraq by not taking steps to maintain a residual force after the withdrawal of American troops in 2011. Furthermore, his actions are perceived as signaling weakness to Russian President Vladimir V. Putin, encouraging the Kremlin to intervene in Ukraine without fear of significant consequences.

William C. Inboden, a former national security aide to President George W. Bush and executive director of the William P. Clements Jr. Center on History, Strategy and Statecraft at the University of Texas, offered a more nuanced perspective. Inboden acknowledged that President Obama is not solely responsible for the various international crises that have occurred during his tenure. However, he is accountable for actions and attitudes that have contributed to some of those crises, as well as for his responses or lack thereof.

Title: EPA Chief Scott Pruitt Resigns Amid Ethics Controversies, Andrew Wheeler to Serve as Acting Administrator

Article:

WASHINGTON - Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) chief Scott Pruitt resigned on Thursday, stepping down under heavy fire for a series of ethics-related controversies. Pruitt, who had been lauded by President Donald Trump for his aggressive efforts to roll back environmental regulations, was one of Trump's most polarizing Cabinet members.

Pruitt, during his tenure as EPA administrator, slashed regulations on the energy and manufacturing industries, including a move to repeal President Barack Obama's signature program to cut carbon emissions from power plants, known as the Clean Power Plan. He was also instrumental in lobbying Trump to withdraw the United States from the global 2015 Paris climate accord to combat global warming.

However, Pruitt lost favor with Trump's inner circle after a string of controversies, including first-class travel at taxpayer expense, lavish spending on security, the installation of a $43,000 soundproof phone booth in his office, and accusations that he used his position to receive favors, such as a discounted rental on a high-end condo from an energy lobbyist's wife.

In his resignation letter, Pruitt stated, "The unrelenting attacks on me personally, my family, are unprecedented and have taken a sizable toll on all of us." EPA Deputy Administrator Andrew Wheeler, a former mining industry lobbyist, will become the regulatory agency's acting chief on Monday. Wheeler is widely expected to continue Pruitt's efforts to roll back and streamline regulation, something that Trump had promised in his presidential campaign.

Democrats and environmental advocacy groups celebrated the departure of Pruitt, a close ally of the fossil fuel industry who has often questioned mainstream climate change science. Republican Senator Chuck Grassley of Iowa said Trump made the "right decision."

Pruitt, as Oklahoma's attorney general before heading up the EPA, had sued the federal agency more than a dozen times on behalf of his oil-drilling state. Pruitt also rankled some Republican lawmakers, including in Midwest corn-producing states, with his efforts to overhaul a U.S. policy requiring biofuels like corn-based ethanol in gasoline.

Pruitt's interim replacement, Wheeler, was formerly a lobbyist for Murray Energy, the country's largest underground coal mining company, and also worked for Senator Jim Inhofe, a self-described climate skeptic, on efforts to combat climate legislation.

Pruitt was facing around a dozen investigations into his tenure, including his frequent use of first-class flights and his spending on security – which the agency has defended as necessary to defend him against unprecedented threats. Travel records showed the U.S. government spent $17,000 in taxpayer money on a December trip to Morocco to promote U.S. exports of liquefied natural gas, which is not part of the EPA's jurisdiction. The Washington Post reported that a longtime Pruitt friend and lobbyist helped arrange the trip and later registered as a foreign agent representing Morocco.

In one of the investigations, the U.S. Government Accountability Office concluded that the EPA violated two laws by installing the $43,000 phone booth for Pruitt's office without telling lawmakers first. Pruitt said his staff never told him the cost. Some of the ethics accusations against Pruitt also involved jobs for his wife. Emails obtained by the Sierra Club environmental group showed Pruitt had an aide contact the chief executive of a fast-food chain about his wife becoming a franchise owner.

The Washington Post reported Pruitt had aides also try to get his wife a job at the Republican Attorneys General Association with a salary topping $200,000. Pruitt also had an employee carry out his personal errands, including researching the purchase of an old mattress from the Trump International Hotel, according to an interview transcript released by congressional Democrats last month. A source close to Trump said the controversy over the search for a used Trump International Hotel mattress was the last straw for Trump with Pruitt because it involved the Trump Organization.

Title: California Governor Gavin Newsom Signs Controversial Bill Requiring Presidential Tax Returns for Primary Ballot

Article:

California Governor Gavin Newsom has reportedly signed a bill that requires presidential candidates to publish their tax returns in order to appear on the state's primary ballot. The bill, SB 27, is primarily aimed at President Donald Trump, who has not published his tax returns.

The bill, which passed both houses of the California state legislature earlier this month, awaits Newsom's signature by the Tuesday deadline. Analysts describe it as a political "freebie" for Newsom, but it could be declared unconstitutional, and it could jeopardize the few areas in which Trump has cooperated with Newsom's administration.

The move is likely to face legal challenges, and it could strain California's already precarious relationship with the Trump administration. Jay Sekulow, a personal attorney for President Trump, suggested legal action will be taken in response to the move by Newsom. "The state of California's attempt to circumvent the Constitution will be answered in court," Sekulow stated.

Though the Golden State has often sued the Trump administration over its policies, California is also dependent on federal aid in several areas. Earlier this year, Trump canceled nearly $1 billion of funds for California's now-defunct high-speed rail project, which Newsom had still hoped to use despite canceling the project.

Newsom shared his own tax returns during the 2018 race for governor. The bill will largely be symbolic, as it will not matter if Trump does not appear on the California primary ballot, as he will still appear on the ballot in the general election. California exempts the presidential primary from its usual "jungle primary" process, in which only the top two candidates advance to the general election, regardless of party.

The bill could, however, inspire other Democrat-governed states to do the same. It will likely boost Newsom's national profile as well. Joel B. Pollak, Senior Editor-at-Large at ███, notes that Newsom's predecessor, Jerry Brown, did not publish his tax returns. The bill's impact on the 2024 presidential race remains to be seen.

Title: U.S. Job Growth Slows in July, but Economy Adds 1.5 Million Jobs Over Past Six Months

Article:

The U.S. economy added 209,000 jobs in July, according to a report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Friday. This figure is a slight decrease from the 298,000 jobs added in June, but the broader trend remains "respectable," economists said.

Over the past six months, the economy has added 1.5 million jobs, marking the strongest six-month hiring period since 2006. Heidi Shierholz, economist for the Economic Policy Institute, commented, "We're not losing ground. We're still in a recovery, but we're not seeing a big acceleration in job growth, either. We're back to the solid, but not stellar growth."

The unemployment rate ticked up to 6.2% in July from 6.1% in June as more workers joined the labor force. Since the 2008 financial crisis, about 8.7 million American jobs were wiped out, but the economy has regained them all earlier this year.

Blue-collar industries like manufacturing and construction were the hardest-hit sectors in the recession, and those jobs have started to return. Manufacturers have added 99,000 jobs over the past six months, while construction firms have added 114,000 jobs since January. Meanwhile, government jobs are starting to come back slowly as well.

However, stronger hiring has yet to translate into bigger paychecks for most workers. The average American wage edged up only 1 cent in July to $24.45 an hour. Over the past 12 months, wages rose 2%, but that's not enough to surpass inflation.

Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen has stated that she wants to see wages rise faster than inflation so American households will have more buying power. That has yet to happen, but the Fed is quickly nearing its other goals for a lower unemployment rate and stable prices. The central bank is gradually winding down its stimulative policies, and investors have become increasingly focused on trying to gauge when the Fed will eventually hike interest rates.

Friday's jobs report does not significantly impact the Fed's decision-making, and stocks were flat in morning trading. Many Americans still think the economy is not fully recovered. According to a CNN/ORC International poll released Friday, 41% of people surveyed rate the economy as "good," while 58% rate the economy as "poor."

These perceptions about the economy will be a key factor in November's midterm elections, as more than a third of the Senate and the entire House are up for grabs. Both sides of the aisle are blaming each other for holding back the recovery.

Secretary of Labor Tom Perez stated, "There are a lot of things that can be done on a bipartisan basis." He points to the Obama administration's push to raise the minimum wage, pass an immigration reform bill, and approve funding for infrastructure. Meanwhile, the GOP points fingers at the Democratic-controlled Senate for blocking their job-creation bills, including legislation that would build the Keystone Pipeline.

Both sides agree on one thing: "When I look at this report, I think one thing: we can do better," House Speaker John Boehner said.

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Reinstate Pennsylvania's Gerrymandered Congressional Maps

Article:

The Supreme Court of the United States has declined to reinstate Pennsylvania's gerrymandered congressional maps, marking the first time the high court has turned away such a case since the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh, who solidified a Republican majority on the court.

In January, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court struck down the state's congressional maps due to their violation of the state constitution. The unconstitutional maps, which were so aggressively gerrymandered that Republicans won 13 of the state's 18 congressional districts in 2012 despite Democrats winning a majority of the popular vote, should have been the final word on the case.

However, Pennsylvania Republicans took the case to the U.S. Supreme Court with a legal theory that argues the state supreme court's decision was unconstitutional because a court is not a legislature. The Constitution states that "the times, places and manner of holding elections for Senators and Representatives, shall be prescribed in each state by the legislature thereof."

The U.S. Supreme Court has previously rejected this reading of the word "legislature." In its 2015 decision in Arizona State Legislature v. Arizona Independent Redistricting Commission, the court held that redistricting can be determined by a referendum and that the governor may veto state redistricting legislation, even though the governor is not a member of a state's legislative branch.

Taken together, these cases establish that when the Constitution assigns the power to draw districts to the "legislature," it refers to the state's valid lawmaking process, not necessarily to the body of lawmakers elected by the people.

Nevertheless, Arizona State Legislature was a 5-4 decision, with four Republicans arguing that the word "legislature" can only refer to a state's legislative branch. The Court's fifth Republican, Justice Anthony Kennedy, crossed over to vote with the court's four Democrats in Arizona State Legislature. However, Kennedy is no longer on the court, and his replacement, Brett Kavanaugh, is a hardline conservative who appeared to call for revenge against Democrats during his confirmation hearing.

At the very least, however, Kavanaugh will not be able to take his revenge in this particular case. The Court's decision not to hear Turzai suggests that, at the very least, Republicans don't have the votes to reinstate one of the nation's most egregious gerrymanders.

Title: House of Representatives Approves Coronavirus Response Package in Bipartisan Vote

Article:

In a 363-40 vote early Saturday, the U.S. House of Representatives approved a coronavirus response package negotiated by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. All House Democrats supported the plan, while 40 Republicans opposed it. Independent Representative Justin Amash from Michigan, a former Republican, voted "present."

The bill, known as the Families First Coronavirus Response Act, includes provisions for free coronavirus testing for all who need it, paid sick leave, and expanded unemployment insurance. The bill also includes nutrition security initiatives, increased federal funds for Medicaid, and support for local, state, tribal, and territorial governments and health systems.

The apparent problems caught Democrats by surprise, with House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, D-Md., saying "we thought we had an agreement." However, the deal was not finalized until shortly before 10 p.m. ET on Friday, when Pelosi informed her Democratic caucus that the "process has taken some time."

President Trump declared a national emergency over the coronavirus outbreak on Friday and announced partnerships with major U.S. companies to expand testing capabilities. Trump tweeted his support for the bill on Friday night, encouraging all Republicans and Democrats to vote "yes."

The Senate is expected to take up the measure next week if it passes the House with an overwhelming majority. The revisions to the Democratic bill happened after the GOP flagged "major" concerns about the sick leave legislation on Thursday. House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., criticized the initial legislation for creating a paid sick leave program through the Social Security Administration that he said would take six months to set up and hamper the agency's normal functioning of disbursing checks to senior citizens.

McCarthy also objected to forcing permanent paid sick leave "for all businesses without exemptions and no sunsets." Late Friday, McCarthy told reporters the bill "had some things which needed to be cleaned up."

The bill is the first major piece of legislation in response to the coronavirus outbreak in the United States. The bill's passage in the House marks a bipartisan effort to address the growing public health and economic crisis caused by the virus. The bill now moves to the Senate for further action.

Title: Grassley Meets with Merrick Garland: A Breakfast Discussion on Supreme Court Nomination

Article:

Senator Chuck Grassley, a Republican from Iowa, met with Merrick Garland, President Obama's nominee for the Supreme Court, for breakfast in the Senate Dining Room on Tuesday. The meeting followed a series of town halls in Iowa where Grassley faced criticism from constituents over his refusal to hold confirmation hearings for Garland.

During the meeting, Grassley reportedly explained his reasons for not holding hearings for Garland, citing the Senate's role in the confirmation process and the upcoming presidential election. The New York Times reported that Grassley ordered oatmeal while Garland had eggs and toast.

The meeting, which was described as pleasant by some media outlets, was seen as a rare instance of bipartisan dialogue in a contentious political climate. However, some critics have questioned the purpose of the meeting, given that the Republican-led Senate has maintained a stance of not considering any Supreme Court nominee during an election year.

The meeting comes as the GOP faces pressure from both within and outside the party. Some Republicans, including Grassley, have faced criticism for their stance on the Supreme Court nomination, with some polls suggesting that the public disapproves of the obstructionism. The GOP also faces a challenging midterm election cycle, with several vulnerable seats up for re-election in purple and blue states.

Grassley's meeting with Garland can be seen as a compromise, allowing the nominee a face-to-face discussion while maintaining the Senate's position of not holding confirmation hearings. It remains to be seen whether this approach will be enough to appease both the GOP base and the general public. As of now, Grassley's poll numbers in Iowa have not significantly dropped, and he was re-elected to the Senate in 2016. However, the situation is evolving, and the outcome of the midterm elections will provide further insight into the public's opinion on the Supreme Court nomination and the GOP's stance on the issue.

Title: NASCAR Bans Confederate Flag, Faces Enforcement Challenges and Celebrity Support

Article:

NASCAR's decision to ban the Confederate flag from its races and venues has garnered praise from celebrities such as Reese Witherspoon and New Orleans Saints running back Alvin Kamara. The stock car series, known for its Southern roots, is now faced with the challenge of enforcing the ban at its tracks as fans return.

Approximately 1,000 members of the military will be allowed into Sunday's race near Miami, marking the first fans at a NASCAR event since the pandemic shut down sports in March. Enforcement of the ban is expected to be a significant challenge, especially at the Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama, where up to 5,000 fans are expected to be allowed in. Flags are a common sight at the superspeedway.

NASCAR executive vice president Steve O' Donnell stated that the series will work to develop protocols around enforcement, though the extent of the ban remains unclear. It is not known whether security will be tasked with policing every Rebel flag string bikini or scraping off all bumper stickers.

Bubba Wallace, NASCAR's lone black driver, is credited for pushing for the ban. Wallace, who finished 11th at Martinsville on Wednesday night, driving a Black Lives Matter paint scheme, has been praised for his efforts.

Joey Logano, the 2018 NASCAR champion, commended Wallace, stating, "He should be proud of the movement he’s made for the African-American community in our sport." Brad Daugherty, the lone black Cup Series team owner, expressed his support for the ban, stating, "This is a big step in the right direction and now is the time to envision the future."

There have been fans who are furious at the decision, with some taking to social media to express their displeasure. NASCAR helmet artist Jason Beam, who designs helmets for Jimmie Johnson, Kyle Busch, and other star drivers, has expressed opposition to the ban. Wallace and several drivers, including Johnson, have cut ties with Beam Designs as a result.

NASCAR has been one of the only live U.S. sports on television during the pandemic, and ratings are up slightly in this most unusual of seasons. Through the first 11 races, Cup Series racing on FOX/FS1 is averaging a 2.38 share, up 1% over last year's average of 2.35 out of 44 market averages. Martinsville scored 1,711,000 viewers for a weeknight race on FS1. The surge of celebrities engaged with NASCAR could signal a revival for the series.

Title: New NBC News/Wall Street Journal Poll Reveals Slight Increase in Approval Rating for President Obama, Mixed Views on Economy and Health Care

Article:

According to a recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, 44% of Americans approve of President Barack Obama's job performance, while 50% disapprove. This represents a slight uptick from his all-time low 41% approval rating in the poll last month.

The poll indicates that majorities of Americans do not approve of how President Obama is handling the economy (52%) and foreign policy (53%). However, for the first time since early October, more people have a positive view of the president (44%) than a negative one (41%).

The poll also reveals that a majority of registered voters (55%) believe the economy is stacked against people like them, and a majority of Americans (54%) say that because of a widening income gap, America is no longer a country where, regardless of their background, people have an opportunity to improve their standard of living.

Regarding the economy, a plurality of respondents (47% to 39%) say the current economic conditions are something President Obama inherited as opposed to something his policies are mostly responsible for. Forty-one percent believe that the economy has improved during his presidency, with 17% saying the economy has improved but do not give him much credit, and 42% saying the economy has not really improved.

In terms of health care, 36% of voters say President Obama's health care law was a good idea, while 46% say it was a bad idea. However, just about one-fifth of voters (20%) say the law should be completely repealed. Two-thirds of voters (66%) say it needs a major overhaul or minor modifications to improve it, and 8% think it's working well the way it is.

As for the midterm elections, 45% of registered voters prefer a Republican-controlled Congress, and 45% prefer a Democratic-controlled one. Forty-two percent of those polled identified with the Democratic party in some form, 34% identified with the Republican party, and 17% said they were independent.

The poll of 1,000 adults taken from April 23-27 has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

Title: Conservative Parties Grapple with Economic Inequality and Social Disintegration

Article:

The political landscape in several industrialized nations is undergoing a significant shift, with conservative parties attempting to navigate the challenges of economic inequality and social disintegration. The recent electoral setbacks for right-leaning parties, such as the failure of Theresa May's post-Brexit election gamble and the re-election of Angela Merkel, have led some to question the effectiveness of the conservative approach.

In the United States, the election of Donald Trump has not resulted in the revolution some of his supporters anticipated. Instead, his administration has been marked by political incompetence and a lack of a clear plan for addressing economic issues. In the United Kingdom, the Brexit process is stalling due to incompetent and convictionless politicians who have failed to negotiate effectively, potentially leading to a "no deal" exit from the European Union.

One potential savior for the Conservative Party in the United Kingdom is Ruth Davidson, the leader of Scotland's Conservative and Unionist party. Davidson, who is openly lesbian, has been credited with resurrecting her party from the grave following May's loss of the Tories' working majority. However, Davidson's recent political essay suggests that she may not be the answer to Mayism, as she calls for a reboot of capitalism to address the economic and social issues that have led to the rise of right-wing parties.

In her essay, Davidson argues that capitalism must be a moral enterprise that reaches out to those who have been left behind by the economy. She cites Adam Smith's contention that capitalism can provide the means for public services and praises "intervention, market restraints, and decisions made at a macro-level by governments to ensure basic fairness for the little guy." Davidson acknowledges the same problems that have been cited by May, Trump, and other right-wing dissidents, including the difficulty of finding work and the sense of helplessness felt by those who can no longer afford homeownership.

The challenges facing conservative parties and thinkers are not unique to any one nation. In many industrialized countries, the middle class is slipping away, and traditional social supports such as family, community, union, and church are disintegrating or becoming irrelevant. To these people, capitalism does not look like an opportunity; it looks like an opportunity to be fleeced.

While May and Trump may fail, it is likely that conservative parties and conservative thinkers will continue to grapple with these issues for the foreseeable future. The solutions may not be clear yet, but the problems do not appear to be going away anytime soon.

Title: Anonymous Op-Ed Author Denied by Vice President and Other Administration Officials

Article:

Washington, D.C. - As President Donald Trump faces criticism from within his administration, an anonymous op-ed published in The New York Times has caused a stir, with Vice President Mike Pence and other officials denying authorship.

Jarrod Agen, communications director for Pence, tweeted, "The Vice President puts his name on his Op-Eds. The @nytimes should be ashamed and so should the person who wrote the false, illogical, and gutless op-ed. Our office is above such amateur acts."

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, during a trip to India, told reporters, "It's not mine," and denounced The New York Times for publishing the anonymous article that suggests Trump may be facing a potential revolt within his own administration.

The op-ed, titled "I Am Part of the Resistance Inside the Trump Administration," was written by an anonymous senior Trump official who stated that staff members are working to block what they perceive as bad decisions by the president, on issues ranging from free trade to military policy.

The author describes Trump as unprincipled and "amoral," stating that meetings with him often veer off topic and result in half-baked, ill-informed, and occasionally reckless decisions that have to be walked back. The piece compares Trump unfavorably to the late Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., described as a "lodestar for restoring honor to public life and our national dialogue."

Trump has questioned the legitimacy of the anonymous author, tweeting, "Does the so-called 'Senior Administration Official' really exist, or is it just the Failing New York Times with another phony source? If the GUTLESS anonymous person does indeed exist, the Times must, for National Security purposes, turn him/her over to government at once!"

White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stated, "The coward who wrote the piece should step forward and resign, saying he is not putting country first, but putting himself and his ego ahead of the will of the American people."

Title: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos Issues Final Rules on Sexual Misconduct Allegations in Schools

Article:

Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has issued final rules on how schools will address allegations of sexual misconduct, securing new protections for students and faculty accused of misconduct. The new rules, which take effect in August, modify Title IX, a 1972 law prohibiting discrimination based on sex in education programs or activities that receive Federal financial assistance.

The new regulations narrow the definition of sexual harassment and require schools to challenge evidence and cross-examine students via a live hearing, among other things detailed in the more than 2,000-page rule. The new regulations will only find schools in violation of Title IX if they are determined to be "deliberately indifferent" to accusations of sexual assault that occurred in their programs and activities.

President Trump described the new regulations as "even-handed justice" with "a transparent grievance process that treats the accused as innocent until proven guilty." In a statement, DeVos said, "Too many students have lost access to their education because their school inadequately responded when a student filed a complaint of sexual harassment or sexual assault."

Victim advocacy groups, such as Know Your IX, have criticized the new rules, claiming they roll back the rights of student survivors and shield schools from liability for sexual misconduct that takes place in their facilities. The National Women's Law Center plans to contest the new rules in court, according to The New York Times.

Sen. Lamar Alexander, chairman of the Senate Education Committee, praised the new rules, stating, "Under the previous administration, a single official in the U.S. Department of Education was issuing edicts, without the proper public input, to 6,000 colleges and universities about how to handle the complex and sensitive problem of sexual assault on college campuses."

Title: High School Shooter in Maryland Killed by Police Officer After Attack

Article:

A 17-year-old gunman, identified as Austin Wyatt Rollins, shot and injured two teenage students at Great Mills High School in St. Mary's County, Maryland, before being shot dead in a gunfight with a police officer. The incident occurred on Tuesday morning before the start of lessons.

Rollins shot a 16-year-old girl, who is currently in critical condition, and a 14-year-old boy. The attack took place in a hallway at the school, according to Sheriff Tim Cameron.

Cameron stated that Rollins had a prior relationship with the girl. The school shooting occurred a month after a high school shooter killed 17 in Parkland, Florida.

St. Mary's County Sheriff's Deputy Blaine Gaskill, who was assigned to the school as a resource officer, exchanged gunfire with the attacker. It is unclear if the gunman was hit by Gaskill's gunfire or if he shot himself during the exchange.

The female student is in critical condition in the hospital. Some 1,600 students attend the school in the community of Great Mills near the Chesapeake Bay and were evacuated to a nearby school after the event.

Federal agents from the FBI and the bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, along with local police, are at the school investigating the incident. One Twitter user, who appears to be a student at the school, posted about the shootings.

Maryland Governor Larry Hogan has expressed concern, stating, "Today's horrible events should not be an excuse to pause our conversation about school safety." New York Governor Andrew Cuomo also commented, calling the attack "another tragic and exasperating reminder of the enduring threat of gun violence" and urging "our so-called leaders in Washington" to take action to stem gun attacks.

The shooting occurs four days before the March for Our Lives rally for student safety, inspired by the 14 February massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in southern Florida.

Title: Treasury Department Delays Employer Mandate in Affordable Care Act by One Year

Article:

The Treasury Department announced on Tuesday that the requirement for businesses to provide health insurance to their employees or face fines, a key provision of President Barack Obama's Affordable Care Act (ACA), will be delayed by one year. The delay comes in response to concerns expressed by business owners about the complexity of the law's reporting requirements.

Under the ACA, businesses employing 50 or more full-time workers that do not provide health insurance will be penalized. Mark J. Mazur, assistant secretary for tax policy, wrote in a post on the Treasury Department's website that the extra year before the requirement goes into effect will allow the government time to simplify the reporting process for businesses. Penalties for firms not providing health coverage to employees will now begin in 2015, after next year's congressional elections.

The new delay will not affect other aspects of the health law, including the establishment of exchanges in states for low-income Americans to obtain health insurance.

Supporters of the employer mandate argue that most firms already provide health insurance to full-time workers, and downplay the effect the requirement would have on small businesses, citing figures showing the vast majority of small businesses employ fewer than 50 workers.

However, opponents claim the employer mandate is a potential job killer, stating that businesses near the 50-worker cutoff will be unlikely to ramp up hiring if it means they are required to provide employees health insurance.

The Obama administration has previously expressed openness to making the health care law easier to implement, and has already shortened applications for health insurance on government-run exchanges from 21 pages to three.

On Tuesday, Obama's senior adviser Valerie Jarrett, who acts as the White House's liaison to big business, wrote the new delay was indicative of the administration's determination to implement the health care law effectively and fairly, and that it wouldn't affect other aspects of Obamacare.

However, many Republicans, and even some Democrats, have continued to express serious concerns about the roll-out of Obamacare. On Tuesday, GOP lawmakers said the delay of the employer mandate didn't go far enough.

"This announcement means even the Obama administration knows the 'train wreck' will only get worse," House Speaker John Boehner wrote. "Obamacare costs too much and it isn't working the way the administration promised," Sen. Mitch McConnell, the Senate Minority Leader, wrote in response to the decision, adding, "The fact remains that Obamacare needs to be repealed and replaced with common-sense reforms that actually lower costs for Americans."

Rep. Eric Cantor, the House Majority Leader, was more succinct. "The best delay for Obamacare is a permanent one," he wrote on Twitter.

Many allies of Obama, including major labor unions, did not immediately weigh in on the delay. A spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid said in response to the decision, "Flexibility is a good thing."

"Both the administration and Senate Democrats have shown – and continue to show – a willingness to be flexible and work with all interested parties to make sure that implementation of the Affordable Care Act is as beneficial as possible to all involved. It is better to do this right than fast," Adam Jentleson continued.

Even some Democrats have voiced concern about the roll-out of the health law – Sen. Max Baucus, a key Democrat who helped craft the legislation, expressed serious anxiety in April about its implementation.

"The administration's public information campaign on the benefits of the Affordable Care Act deserves a failing grade. You need to fix this," Baucus told Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius at a hearing.

"I just see a huge train wreck coming down," he added later.

Title: President Trump Fires FBI Director James Comey

Article:

President Donald Trump terminated FBI Director James Comey on Tuesday, citing a need for new leadership to restore public trust and confidence in the law enforcement agency. The decision was based on the recommendations of Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.

In a letter to Comey, Trump stated that the FBI director could not "effectively lead" the bureau. The White House Press Secretary, Sean Spicer, confirmed that the president's decision was based on the "clear recommendations" of Sessions and Rosenstein.

The search for a new permanent FBI director will begin immediately, with Andrew McCabe, the bureau's deputy director, assuming the position of acting director. The White House made the announcement shortly after the FBI corrected a sentence in Comey's sworn testimony on Capitol Hill last week.

The FBI clarified that only a small number of the thousands of emails found on the laptop of Huma Abedin, a top aide to then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, had been forwarded there, while most had simply been backed up from electronic devices. This error was apparently unrelated to the Comey firing.

Comey, who was nominated by President Barack Obama for the FBI post in 2013 to a 10-year term, first ran into problems during the 2016 presidential race when he tried to conclude his investigation into Clinton’s use of a private server system for emails while at the State Department. He concluded that Clinton, then the Democratic presidential nominee, had not acted criminally with classified emails but said she had been “extremely careless.”

He then announced a revived probe regarding the emails and Abedin’s handling of them in the closing days of the race. Clinton has said that this largely contributed to her loss to Trump, while Comey has defended his actions.

The FBI and other members of the U.S. intelligence community, as well as Congress, are now investigating the extent to which Russia was involved in stealing and making public emails from Clinton’s presidential campaign.

Senate Judiciary Chairman Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, said Comey had lost the "public trust and confidence." He also said Comey's decisions on controversial matters, including the Clinton email matter, "have prompted concern from across the political spectrum" and from career law enforcement experts.

Democrats are further insisting on an independent prosecutor to investigate possible links between the Trump campaign and Russia, following the firing. Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., said, "The only way the American people can have faith in this investigation is for it to be led by a fearless special prosecutor."

Title: Mail-In Voting: A Divisive Issue Amidst National Election

Article:

President Donald Trump's tweets expressing opposition towards mail-in voting have sparked a partisan divide on the issue at a national level. However, most local election officials, regardless of party affiliation, acknowledge the necessity of increased mail-in voting, despite the associated challenges. According to recent surveys, most voters agree with the need to reduce voter density on Election Day and during early voting, with an expansion of mail balloting considered essential for this purpose.

Despite the growing acceptance of mail-in voting, Americans value safe polling places in November. Voter behavior is resistant to change, with many Americans having voted in person throughout their adult lives. Some view in-person voting as an expression of civic pride and duty, while others distrust the postal system to deliver their ballot or have been influenced by Trump's criticism and choose not to vote by mail. Individuals with disabilities or those requiring language assistance may find in-person voting more convenient.

In a survey of registered voters in Pennsylvania, approximately half indicated they would vote in person in the fall. Even among primary voters who cast a mail ballot, 20% said they were likely to vote in person during the general election. Most of those who did not vote in the primary but plan to vote in November intend to do so in person.

For new or infrequent voters, certain aspects of absentee voting may be unfamiliar. They may encounter difficulties navigating websites to request a ballot or be surprised by the requirement to sign the outside envelope for verification purposes. In recent New Jersey elections, for example, as many as 10% of ballots were not counted due to lateness or technical deficiencies. Mail-in voting procedures can trip up some groups more than others. An analysis of data from Florida revealed that African Americans, young people, and first-time voters were less likely to have their mail ballots counted due to lateness or noncompliance with technical requirements.

Election Day polling places serve as an indispensable fail-safe for voters who do not receive their mail ballots on time. During the primary season, jurisdictions with limited experience in voting by mail have been overwhelmed by the number of mail ballots that need to be processed. In Wisconsin earlier this year, for example, more than 10,000 voters requested absentee ballots that they never received. A local federal judge extended the deadline for casting these ballots, but his decision was overturned the day before the election by a narrow majority of the United States Supreme Court. This left voters without mail ballots in a precarious position, as those who never received mail ballots now had to wait in long lines in places such as Milwaukee, which opened only five polling locations.

Title: Supreme Court Case Challenges Internet Sales Tax Exemption for Out-of-State Companies

Article:

A Supreme Court case, South Dakota v. Wayfair Inc., is currently under review, addressing the issue of state and local governments' ability to collect sales taxes from out-of-state companies. The case aims to overturn a 1992 Supreme Court decision, Quill Corp. v. North Dakota, which established that a business must have a significant presence in a state before that state can require it to collect sales taxes.

Under the current ruling, a small-scale online seller, such as an individual selling handcrafted goods on Etsy, does not have to collect sales taxes from consumers unless they are physically located in the same state. However, large companies like Amazon collect sales taxes from customers in all 45 states with a statewide sales tax due to their extensive distribution networks.

Many state lawmakers are advocating for the overturning of Quill, which would allow them to force out-of-state companies to collect sales taxes on their behalf. If the states were to win, they would be able to impose taxes on the small-scale online seller, even if they reside in a different state, have not elected the state's officials, and have not agreed to the state's tax laws.

The potential overturning of Quill could also lead to the loss of tax competition among states. Under the new regime, online consumers, regardless of their location or purchases, would lose the ability to shop around for a more favorable tax system. This competitive pressure, which limits state tax-grabbing abilities, is what lawmakers resent and want the Supreme Court to eliminate.

Some lawmakers may hope that increased revenue would alleviate their financial issues. However, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, 33 states faced shortfalls in fiscal 2017 and/or fiscal 2018, despite revenue collection growth in most states. This is because the more states collect in revenue, the more they spend.

Furthermore, states may be overestimating the revenue they would receive from taxes on internet sales. Online sales represent less than 10% of retail sales, according to a 2017 report by the Government Accountability Office. Additionally, the 100 largest online retailers already tax approximately 90% of their sales. Desperate lawmakers should not expect to collect more than 2-4% of total state and local government tax revenues this way, according to the GAO, if Quill were to be reversed.

A reversal of Quill could also impose significant compliance costs on small online retailers, which typically have thin profit margins. Compliance with the nation's 12,000 tax-collecting jurisdictions could be costly, and tax software may not be precise enough to handle the complexity of taxation on a case-by-case basis.

Republican state senator Deb Peters of South Dakota, in an interview with NPR on the morning of the South Dakota v. Wayfair hearing, dismissed concerns about compliance costs. According to Peters, free software provided by most desperate states would make the cost zero. However, this is questionable, as noted by an eBay representative on NPR, who pointed out that tax laws vary significantly between states, and compliance would still require extensive effort.

The Wayfair case has much at stake. If Quill were to be overturned, compliance costs could skyrocket for many retailers, and good principles of taxation could be discarded. Healthy tax competition is at risk. Let's hope the Supreme Court makes the right decision.

Title: Biden Honors U.S. Veterans as "Heart and Soul" and "Spine of the Nation" on Veterans Day

Article:

U.S. Vice President Joe Biden paid tribute to American veterans on Veterans Day, referring to them as the "heart and soul" and "very spine of this nation." The remarks were made during a wreath-laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery.

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was scheduled to deliver remarks at the Vietnam War memorial in Washington D.C. The United States began celebrating Veterans Day in 1954, replacing Armistice Day to honor all U.S. veterans. Since 2001, more than two million Americans have served overseas in the Afghanistan and Iraq wars.

In his speech, Biden acknowledged the significant burden placed on the U.S. all-volunteer force over an extended period. He addressed a crowd of veterans and their families, praising them as "the most trusted among us and the most tested of all Americans."

The past year has seen controversy at the Department of Veterans Affairs, with the secretary stepping down amid a scandal involving delayed care and falsified records at the agency's hospitals, which provide care to U.S. military veterans.

In Ohio, the occasion served as a reminder for Iraq war veterans from the state that they had limited time to collect a bonus authorized by the state in 2009. A group representing gay and lesbian veterans made their first appearance in Boston's Veterans Day parade.

A star-studded concert, featuring artists such as Bruce Springsteen, Rihanna, and Carrie Underwood, is planned for the National Mall in Washington D.C. in honor of veterans.

Title: House Democrats Announce Articles of Impeachment Against President Trump and USMCA Agreement

Article:

On Tuesday, House Democrats unveiled two articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump and announced they had reached an agreement with the White House on a replacement for the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), known as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA).

The impeachment charges, which accuse the president of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, were announced solemnly, but the mood shifted an hour later when Speaker Nancy Pelosi praised the USMCA, which she said Democrats took "great pride in." The deal, which includes various environmental and labor regulations, is expected to be signed by Mexico and Canada in the coming days.

President Trump took a break from his impeachment-related tweets to promote the deal, stating, "Looking like very good Democrat support for USMCA. That would be great for our Country!"

Speaker Pelosi told reporters that the timing of both developments was not under the control of Democrats. The impeachment hearings concluded on Monday, making it logical to unveil the articles of impeachment on Tuesday, she said. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, who has led the USMCA negotiations, wanted to finalize the NAFTA replacement before Congress goes on recess and while Democrats and Republicans remain on the same page.

Behind closed doors, Pelosi insisted that Democrats had the upper hand in the trade deal and outmaneuvered the GOP. "We ate their lunch," Pelosi reportedly said in a caucus meeting.

Supporters of Pelosi and more moderate Democrats praised the one-two punch of impeachment and the trade deal, arguing that Democrats needed to demonstrate their ability to "walk and chew gum at the same time." However, many progressives criticized the strategy, arguing that the USMCA undermined the party's case for impeachment.

Adam Serwer, a writer for The Atlantic, stated, "Either the Republic is in danger and impeachment is necessary, or it's not that big a deal and congress can do business as usual." Will Stancil, a researcher at the University of Minnesota Law School, called Pelosi's strategy "insane."

Some critics argued that Democrats were fulfilling the "Dems in disarray" stereotype and mistakenly trying to appease voters in swing states. Chris Hayes, the progressive MSNBC host, tweeted, "Nothing more perfectly embodies the Democratic party than announcing articles of impeachment and a huge deal with the President on his single biggest priority on the same day."

Brian Beutler, the editor-in-chief of the progressive media outlet Crooked Media, called Pelosi's strategy "a stunning betrayal." Beutler tweeted, "If you kill the deal, you can say it was a shitty deal, like everything else Trump has done and that you'll do better. If you pass the deal, you tell voters yeah, president deals actually did a good deal just like he promised."

Title: Romney's Favorability Rating Surpasses 50% Following Debate Performances

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, has surpassed a significant milestone in his favorability rating, according to the Real Clear Politics average of polls. As of early this week, Romney's favorability rating briefly exceeded 50%, marking the first time he has led President Obama in this measure.

The debates, particularly the first one, have reportedly dismantled President Obama's strategy of portraying Romney as an unacceptable choice for voters. According to Republican pollster Mike McKenna, the debates "destroyed the Obama campaign's strategy of disqualification."

Prior to the debates, Romney's favorability rating was 44.5%. By Monday, when he and Obama faced off for the third and final time, Romney's rating had risen to 50.5%. Tom Jensen, director of Public Policy Polling, a Democratic firm, described the surge in Romney's favorability as "remarkable."

As of Tuesday, Romney's favorability rating had dipped below 50% again, but he still leads Obama in net favorability, a calculation of favorable rating minus unfavorable rating. Obama's favorability averaged 49.7%, or 4.5 points more than his unfavorable rating, while Romney's favorability was 49.3%, or 6.5 points more than his unfavorable rating.

During the foreign policy-focused debate on Tuesday, Romney maintained a measured performance, although pundits criticized him for not presenting clear differences with Obama on world hot spots. However, Republicans argued that Romney succeeded in presenting himself as a palatable alternative to Obama.

In the final two weeks of the campaign, the election has once again become a referendum on President Obama. Obama, in his closing remarks during Monday's debate, emphasized his administration's progress in addressing economic and foreign policy challenges, while criticizing Romney's proposed policies.

The debates' impact on Romney's favorability rating is a significant development in the race, according to pollster John Zogby. "Voters got to see an option. Now that there is an option, Romney is viewed as favorably as Obama as a person," he said. However, Romney still faces challenges in terms of relatability, as indicated by a recent poll showing Obama nearly doubling Romney's likability rating.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 113,000 Jobs in January, Unemployment Rate at 6.6%

Article:

The U.S. economy added 113,000 jobs in January, according to the government, marking a slight improvement from the previous month but falling short of economists' expectations. The addition of jobs was far weaker than anticipated, with experts predicting an increase of 178,000 jobs.

Economists described the report as "disappointing" and "weak," but characterized the broader economic growth as "steady-as-she-goes." Julia Coronado, chief economist, North America for BNP Paribas, stated, "The U.S. economy is very stable. 2014 might not be a breakout year, but it's not a disaster either."

Many economists had hoped that December's weak job gains would be significantly revised higher, as many experts considered the December report a fluke. However, the number was revised higher, but only by 1,000 jobs to 75,000.

The unemployment rate was 6.6% in January, with 10 million Americans counted as unemployed. The unemployment rate has improved substantially since it peaked at 10% in 2009 and is now at its lowest level in more than five years.

However, much of the decline in unemployment is due to Americans dropping out of the labor force. As of January, only 63% of Americans over age 16 participated in the labor market, meaning they either had a job or looked for one. Although there was a slight improvement in January, participation is still hovering around its lowest level since 1978.

While some of the decline is partly due to baby boomers retiring, economists are also concerned about the long-term unemployed, who may be giving up on the job market altogether. Following the report, one of President Obama's top economic advisers, Jason Furman, called the unemployment rate "unacceptably high."

About 3.6 million Americans have been unemployed for six months or more. Those who were relying on extended government benefits lost that lifeline in December.

"These figures provide a stark reminder that despite the progress that has been made, the after-effects of the recession still linger and are creating hardship for many families," Furman wrote in a White House blog post.

The Federal Reserve has been stressing that its stimulus policies depend on the economic data. While it has been aiming for an unemployment rate of 6.5%, it's expected to distance itself from using that number as its main measure of the job market.

"Using the narrow, widely reported unemployment rate alone could suggest a misleadingly optimistic state of affairs," Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren said in a prepared speech Thursday, ahead of the jobs report.

Recently appointed Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is scheduled to testify before two Congressional committees next week.

Surprisingly, more than half of January's job gains came from traditional blue-collar sectors. Goods-producing industries added more jobs than the services sector for the first time since 2005. Construction firms added 48,000 jobs, manufacturers added 21,000 jobs, and the mining industry added 7,200 jobs.

However, that was one of few bright spots in the report. The health care sector cut 400 jobs—the first month of job losses since 2003. Health care had been an industry with strong job growth throughout the recession. Professional and business services added 36,000 jobs, but a large part of those jobs were through staffing agencies. About 15,000 jobs were added at restaurants and bars. Sporting goods, hobby, book, and music stores cut 22,000 jobs.
