Overall, the U.S. economy lost 8.7 million jobs in the financial crisis. As of January, 7.8 million jobs have come back, but once economists also account for population growth, they expect that it will still take years to get back to a pre-recession job market.

Title: Donald Trump Reverses Pledge to Support GOP Nominee: A Look at the Reasons Behind the Change

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has reversed his pledge to support the eventual GOP nominee, a promise he made during the party's primary debates in August. In a recent interview with CNN, Trump stated, "No, I do not anymore."

During the debates, all Republican candidates, including Trump, had pledged to support the nominee, even if it was not themselves. However, Trump was the only candidate who refused to make this pledge, citing leverage and the need to maintain control over the nomination process.

After meeting with Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus, Trump signed a pledge to support the GOP nominee. However, on Tuesday, Trump changed his stance once again, citing unfair treatment from the Republican National Committee and the "Republican Party establishment."

The change in Trump's stance comes as the finish line for the Republican primary race is in sight. With the active "stop-Trump" or #NeverTrump effort aiming to prevent Trump from reaching the 1,237 delegates needed to become the GOP nominee, Trump believes this effort is not fair, as he currently leads in the delegate count.

The rules of the Republican primary process state that the candidate with a majority of delegates, which is 50% plus one of the total number of voting delegates to the Republican National Convention (2,472), will be the nominee. Trump has criticized the number 1,237 as "very random" but it is, in fact, the majority required to secure the nomination.

Trump's strong and devoted following among a significant chunk of GOP primary voters is his biggest piece of leverage. In the past, Trump has threatened to run as a third-party candidate when he felt unfairly treated, and this threat has been effective in the past. Now, as the "stop-Trump" effort gains traction, Trump is using this leverage to pressure the party to back off.

The implications of Trump's decision to reverse his pledge to support the GOP nominee remain unclear, but it is certain that this decision will have a significant impact on the Republican primary race and the party's chances in the general election.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Indicates Willingness to Recuse Himself from Russia Investigation

Article:

Attorney General Jeff Sessions has stated that he would recuse himself from any investigation involving Russian involvement in President Trump's campaign if it is "appropriate." In an exclusive interview with NBC News, Sessions said, "I have said whenever it's appropriate, I will recuse myself."

Reports emerged Wednesday that Sessions spoke twice with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak during the 2016 presidential race. During his confirmation hearings for attorney general, Sessions testified under oath that he "did not have communications with the Russians."

In his comments with NBC News, Sessions defended himself, stating, "I have not met with any Russians at any time to discuss any political campaigns." He added, "Those remarks are unbelievable to me and are false. I don’t have anything else to say about that."

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) suggested Thursday that Sessions recusing himself from any Russia-related investigations would be "easier." McCarthy said, "I do not have all the information in front of me, I do not want to pre-judge, but I just think for any investigation going forward, you want to make sure everybody trusts the investigation."

The FBI is reportedly investigating contact between Russian officials and members of the Trump campaign, though there have yet to be any formal charges brought. Committees in the House and Senate are also pursuing their own investigations.

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) said Wednesday that if the FBI finds any criminal activity related to campaign aides' alleged contact with Russian officials, then a special prosecutor will likely be needed. Rep. Sean Duffy (R-Wis.) said he wished Sessions had been "more clear" during the confirmation process about his meetings.

Sessions, a former Republican senator from Alabama, reportedly spoke with Kislyak during a July event at the Republican National Convention and in a September phone call. The conversations took place during a time when U.S. intelligence officials assert that Russia was interfering in the 2016 race through a hacking and influence campaign.

Democrats have seized on the news about Sessions speaking with Kislyak, arguing that Sessions must recuse himself from any federal investigation into contact between Russia and Trump's team. Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) called for Sessions to resign following the news, while House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) also called for Sessions' resignation, stating that he is "not fit to serve as the top law enforcement officer of our country."

Trump has repeatedly dismissed the reports of Russia contacts as "fake news" and suggested the real issue is leaks of information from the intelligence community. Yet scrutiny of the issue continues to build, particularly after Michael Flynn resigned last month as national security adviser for misleading Vice President Pence about his own phone conversations with Kislyak after the election.

Title: Study Suggests Democratic Party's Leftward Shift Outpaces Republican Rightward Shift in Political Polarization

Article:

A new study by political scientists from Princeton, Georgetown, and the University of Oregon suggests that the Democratic Party's leftward shift may be more pronounced than the Republican Party's rightward shift in political polarization, particularly at the state level. The study, published in August, argues that income inequality has contributed to political polarization at the state level since the 1990s.

The authors of the study found that political polarization at the state level has increased due to the movement of state Democratic parties to the left rather than the movement of state Republican parties to the right. The Democratic Party's loss of power at the state level over the past 15 years has led to the shedding of its moderate wing, with centrist Democrats losing seats to Republicans, resulting in a more liberal Democratic party overall. The authors note that the ideological median of Republican legislators has shifted less.

While the study does not prove a thesis, it aligns with the trends observed in recent years. The findings challenge the conventional wisdom that the Republican Party has been moving farther and farther to the right, causing political polarization and gridlock in Washington, while the Democratic Party has become more moderate and centrist.

The study's findings are in contrast to the claims made by some Democrats, including President Obama and Hillary Clinton, who have often given the impression that their party is moderate and in line with public opinion, while Republicans have undergone a sudden jolt to the right. However, the study suggests that the narrative of Democratic moderation and Republican extremism may not be entirely accurate.

The study's findings add to the ongoing debate about political polarization in the United States and the role of income inequality in shaping political ideologies. While the study focuses on the state level, its findings may have implications for the national political landscape as well. The study's authors argue that understanding the causes of political polarization is essential for addressing the issue and promoting a more equitable and functional political system.

Title: Trump Offers Immigration Concessions, Democrats Reject; Shutdown Continues

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has criticized Democrats for rejecting his proposals aimed at ending the longest government shutdown in U.S. history. In a series of tweets, Trump claimed that his offers had been dismissed before he even presented them. The President proposed compromises in exchange for funding for his proposed security wall along the Mexican border, the primary cause of the shutdown.

Democrats labeled the proposals as "unacceptable," "a non-starter," and "hostage taking." In an address on Saturday, Trump proposed a three-year extension for approximately 700,000 Dreamers, individuals who entered the U.S. illegally as children with their parents, and for 300,000 people holding visas under Temporary Protection Status (TPS), individuals who have fled countries affected by war or disasters.

Trump tweeted that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other Democrats had "turned down my offer yesterday before I even got up to speak." He accused his opponents of not seeing crime and drugs, but rather focusing on the 2020 election, which they are not expected to win.

In a subsequent tweet, Trump addressed concerns from the conservative right that his immigration offer would amount to an amnesty. He clarified that "Amnesty is not part of my offer." He explained that he was only discussing a three-year extension, with amnesty being a potential part of a larger deal, either on immigration or another issue.

Trump also stated that he was not planning a "big push to remove 11 million plus people" in the U.S. illegally, but warned Pelosi to "be careful" on that matter. The target of Trump's anger was a statement released by Pelosi anticipating and rejecting the concessions before they were made.

Senator Chuck Schumer stated that Trump had previously "single-handedly" taken away Dreamer and TPS protections, and offering some protections back was "not a compromise but more hostage taking." The Democrats maintain that they will not negotiate until the government is reopened.

With the Democrats now in control of the House, while Trump's Republicans still have a majority in the Senate, the federal budget funding must be agreed upon by both parties. Opinion polls suggest most Americans blame Trump more than the Democrats for the shutdown.

As the shutdown enters its fifth week, some of the 800,000 federal employees who have been going unpaid since 22 December are in increasingly dire straits. More than 1,500 appeals have been set up by them on crowdfunding site GoFundMe, seeking financial assistance to pay rent or feed and clothe their children.

Title: Trump Administration to Allow Additional 30,000 Seasonal Workers through H-2B Visas

Article:

The Trump administration has cleared a rule to issue an additional 30,000 H-2B visas for foreign workers this summer, a higher-than-expected number that reflects internal tensions within the White House regarding legal immigration. The administration had earlier indicated it was considering only an additional 15,000 such visas.

The H-2B program allows employers to hire foreign workers for seasonal, non-agricultural jobs that they claim they cannot fill with American workers. The annual cap for these visas is 66,000, with 33,000 allocated for summer and 33,000 for winter. Demand for these visas often exceeds the supply.

In 2017, half of all H-2B visas were granted to agricultural and horticultural industries, according to the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services data on approvals. Building and construction, forestry and logging, food services and handlers, helpers and laborers accounted for most of the remaining visas.

The rule comes amid an ongoing immigration debate within the administration. While some officials, such as Stephen Miller, are pushing for stricter immigration policies, others, including Jared Kushner, are advocating for relaxed rules to facilitate growth in a tight job market. Kushner is reportedly finalizing a legislative proposal to overhaul immigration, which may result in offering a larger number of H-1B visas for high-skilled workers with fewer restrictions.

The administration has also been investigating companies seen as discriminating against American workers in favor of temporary workers through the Protecting U.S. Workers Initiative. The initiative has reached settlements with several companies for failing to comply with the H-2B program's requirements.

The debate over low-skilled and high-skilled foreign labor is a contentious issue in Congress, with some lawmakers expressing concerns about the impact of the H-2B visa program on both immigrant and American workers. The future of the H-2B visa program remains uncertain, with some members of Congress advocating for a higher number of visas, while others are calling for a reconsideration of the increase.

Title: Columbia Journalism Review Criticizes Media's Approach to Reporting on President Trump's Truthfulness

Article:

The Columbia Journalism Review has criticized the media's approach to reporting on President Donald Trump's truthfulness, arguing that efforts to label him a liar without explicitly doing so undermines journalistic standards and deepens national disarray.

The Review, a well-known publication that focuses on media analysis, questions the distinction most media institutions have made in referring to Trump as a liar without using the term. The Review highlights the New York Times' approach, such as its headline "Trump Falsely Says Times Made Up Source in Report on Korea Summit Meeting."

The Review points to White House Reporter Maggie Haberman's tweet, in which she stated that Trump told two demonstrable falsehoods, as an example of journalistic efforts to downplay the President's commitment to truth. The Review also mentions the Times' charge that "He Uses Conspiracy Theories to Erode Trust."

The Review argues that the media's approach to reporting on Trump's truthfulness is problematic, as it involves telling people what to think rather than presenting facts and allowing the public to make up their own minds. The Review suggests that journalists should present asserations and facts that undermine the Trumpian account, but without indignation or contempt, and allow the White House to answer those sources.

The Review also questions the media's role in society, stating that they are our eyes and ears, but not our brains. The Review argues that the media's attempts to lead viewers and readers by the nose is a non-fruitful mode of argumentation and discussion.

The Review concludes by stating that the media's fury at President Trump is sowing worrisome consequences for the future. The Review suggests that the media's angry judgmentalism, its love of crying "Liar!", is making things far angrier and more divisive than they are now. The Review also questions the long-term impact of the media's approach to reporting on Trump, suggesting that it may undermine public trust in the media and make it difficult for the media to regain that trust in the future.

Title: Christine Hallquist Becomes First Transgender Candidate to Win Major Party's Nomination for Governor

Article:

Christine Hallquist, a 62-year-old Democrat, has made history by becoming the first transgender candidate to win a major political party's nomination for governor in the state of Vermont. Hallquist defeated three other Democratic contenders in Tuesday's primary.

Hallquist, who is backed by The Victory Fund, a political action committee that supports LGBTQ candidates nationwide, emphasizes her platform, which includes higher wages for state workers, improved healthcare for families, and better education for children.

"Vermonters are going to elect me on my platform," Hallquist said. "They are not going to elect me because of the fact that I'm transgender—that's the reality." She added, "Obviously, nationwide it's significant, the first transgender governor. It is pioneering."

Elliot Imse, communications director for The Victory Fund, commented, "Because she is open and authentic about the fact that she is transgender, that immediately takes away all the questions, all the whispers, and instead allows people to focus on her personality and what she wants to do." Imse continued, "People are liking what they're hearing, and that's what's really cool about Christine."

Hallquist moved to Vermont in 1976 and worked for the Vermont Electric Co-operative, eventually becoming CEO in 2005. She was open about her 2015 transition and allowed news organizations to document the change. Hallquist stepped down from her position at the co-op earlier this year to run for office, citing Governor Phil Scott's alleged disregard for the interests of rural Vermonters.

In the primary, Hallquist defeated environmental activist James Ehlers, dance festival organizer Brenda Siegel, and 14-year-old Ethan Sonneborn, who made it onto the ticket due to a loophole in the state law that does not require candidates to be of voting age. If Hallquist wins in November, she would become the nation's first transgender governor.

Approximately 200 LGBT candidates are expected to be on the November ballot across the country for state and federal office, according to The Victory Fund. This represents the most LGBT candidates ever, with notable candidates including Alexandra Chandler, Massachusetts' first openly transgender candidate for Congress, and Kim Coco Iwamoto, who could become Hawaii's first transgender lieutenant governor if elected. Like Hallquist, both Chandler and Iwamoto are Democrats.

Title: U.S. Natural Gas Exporter Excelerate Energy Negotiates Long-Term Contracts for Overseas Shipments

Article:

Excelerate Energy, a natural gas exporter based in the United States, is in negotiations with several foreign companies to secure long-term contracts for shipping natural gas abroad. The company, which is half-owned by billionaire George B. Kaiser, expects to finalize these agreements by early next year, with the first shipments departing from the Texas coast by 2017.

Rob Bryngelson, the 44-year-old chief executive of Excelerate Energy, stated, "There's so much potential for the U.S. to take advantage of high prices in global markets. We've got to capitalize while we can."

With 15 other export projects currently under review by the Energy Department, the United States could soon become the world's second-largest natural gas exporter, trailing only Russia, the largest seller due to its long-term contracts with energy buyers across Europe and beyond.

According to the International Energy Agency, demand for natural gas is expected to increase by 50 percent over the next 20 years, with most growth coming from emerging markets like India and China, which are heavily reliant on energy imports to support their economies.

However, obstacles remain. Large American consumers of natural gas, such as the petrochemicals industry, are concerned that record-low domestic gas prices could rise if energy companies are allowed to export natural gas. Politicians also express concerns about the impact of exports on the country's energy security.

Roger Ihne, a principal in the energy practice of the consultancy Deloitte in Houston, commented, "People are struggling to decide what to do with this energy gift."

The glut places the United States at the center of the increasingly globalized natural gas market. Unlike the oil industry, which relies on a few global benchmark prices, the natural gas sector was a regional business until recently. Prices still vary wildly among continents, and most producers depend on vast pipeline networks to supply local customers like energy utilities and industrial companies.

Technology is changing how business is done, including how natural gas is extracted from the earth—via a technique called hydraulic fracturing, or fracking—and how the fuel is transported over long distances. By converting their product to liquefied natural gas (L.N.G.), natural gas suppliers can ship overseas in large tankers rather than relying on decades-old pipelines, which often run through politically unstable countries.

With the potential to ship anywhere in the world, energy companies are connecting regional natural gas markets to a greater extent than ever before. Analysts say producers can hunt for the highest price across different continents before deciding where to ship the gas.

For example, Qatar, the world's largest L.N.G. exporter, has shifted supplies from its European customers to new clients in Asia due to Europe's economic problems reducing demand there. In Asia, political decisions, such as Japan's move to close its remaining nuclear power plants after the disaster at the country's Fukushima reactor, have increased demand for L.N.G. imports. This year, Cheniere Energy, a Houston energy firm, signed a 20-year deal with the Korea Gas Corporation to ship natural gas to South Korea beginning in 2017. Cheniere, which plans to export from Louisiana, also has a long-term contract with GAIL India, the country's largest natural gas distributor.

Teri Viswanath, a commodity strategist at the French bank BNP Paribas in New York, stated, "Asian companies are out in front in signing natural gas contracts. For countries like China, the tremendous domestic demand ensures it will always be an importer."

Stronger ties within the natural gas industry are also bringing international energy companies to America. By acquiring stakes in American energy projects, analysts say, foreign firms are seeking access to the country's vast untapped resources.

In early October, Golden Pass Products, a venture whose majority owner is the state-owned Qatar Petroleum International, was granted a license to export liquefied natural gas from a proposed site in Texas. The British energy company BG Group, which owns shale gas deposits from Texas to New York, also plans to ship American natural gas from its operations in Louisiana.

Despite the multibillion-dollar investments, changes are not expected to happen overnight. Building L.N.G. terminals, for example, can take years. And many utilities, particularly in Europe and Asia, are locked into contracts with existing natural gas producers that could limit the opportunities for new entrants like American companies.

Yet the expansion of the natural gas industry in the United States and elsewhere, including in East Africa and South America, is expected to transform the sector over the next 20 years.

Joseph A. Stanislaw, a founder of the consultancy Cambridge Energy Research Associates, commented, "We still have regional markets, but they are becoming more tied together with each successive year."

Title: Decrease in National Security Advocacy Organizations Since 2008

Article:

Since 2008, many advocacy organizations have shifted their focus from national security, leaving a political vacuum for members of Congress when considering military action, such as the potential strikes on Syria's regime over the alleged use of chemical weapons. The public's opposition to military action and the lack of infrastructure to change public opinion have created a daunting political reality for lawmakers.

In the past, during the height of the national debate over the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, there was a robust network of groups on both the left and right advocating on issues of war and peace. However, since President Barack Obama's election and the 2008 financial meltdown, many of the most assertive advocacy organizations have either withered away or shifted their focus to topics other than national security.

This atrophy is particularly noticeable on the right, where once-prominent groups set up to support interventionist politicians have all but disappeared. Freedom's Watch, a Republican group that spent tens of millions of dollars in the 2008 campaign marshaling support for the Iraq war, disbanded after Obama's election. The conservative veterans' advocacy organization Vets for Freedom has gone dormant, with the last video posted on its website being a 2010 clip from MSNBC's "Hardball." Keep America Safe, a hawkish group founded in 2009 by Liz Cheney and others, closed up shop ahead of Cheney's decision to run for Senate in Wyoming.

Ari Fleischer, former Bush White House press secretary and one of the founders of Freedom's Watch, stated that there is no standing entity dedicated to supporting aggressive foreign and military policy. Fleischer, who supports military action in Syria, said, "I don't know that there's ever been such a group, really, especially since the collapse of the Soviet Union." Freedom's Watch, he recalled, was intended to continue its work, but ultimately became an organization with a "one-time mission" focused on Iraq.

Pete Hegseth, the former head of Vets for Freedom, said the Syria issue doesn't lend itself to sharp partisan battle lines. He supports "limited action that shows red lines matter" in Syria but doesn't expect substantial pro-intervention advocacy from outside groups. Hegseth now helms the nonprofit group Concerned Veterans for America, which didn't advertise in the 2012 elections and has no plans at present to do so in 2014.

"Iraq was such a galvanizing issue for so many people," said Hegseth. "I certainly wouldn't start a Syria intervention organization right now."

The anti-war side of the advocacy world has also slowed down. Some Democratic-leaning groups that ran TV ads defending opposition to the Iraq war have turned their attention more recently to domestic issues. The liberal Americans United for Change, which aired ads back in the 2008 cycle pressuring Republican lawmakers to break ranks on Iraq (and accusing then-Minnesota Sen. Norm Coleman of wanting "permanent war" there), says Syria isn't on the top of its agenda. AUC president Brad Woodhouse said there are "no current plans" to dive into that debate.

"We're busy on Obamacare and gearing up for the budget fight," said Woodhouse, formerly a top strategist at Obama's Democratic National Committee.

Title: Lawmakers Propose Firearm and Ammunition Taxes as Part of Broader Gun Control Measures

Article:

Lawmakers at both the state and federal levels are introducing new taxes on firearms and ammunition as part of a broader effort to regulate firearms in response to mass shootings such as the Newtown school shooting. The proposed taxes range from a 5 percent tax on firearms in New Jersey to a 50 percent tax on ammunition in Maryland.

The taxes, similar to so-called "sin taxes" on items like cigarettes, aim to deter buyers and generate revenue for favored programs such as mental health services, police training, and victims' treatment. However, firearms groups argue that a "sin tax" on firearms unfairly penalizes law-abiding gun owners.

Lawrence Keane, senior vice president and general counsel for the National Shooting Sports Foundation, stated, "If anything, gun owners ought to be getting a tax rebate for helping reduce crime." He added that the taxes are intended to "frustrate and limit the exercise of the Second Amendment."

While some revenue from these taxes and fees would go to victims' services, Keane argued that those paying the tax are not typically responsible for gun crime. "We're obviously extremely opposed to trying to tax the lawful exercise of the Second Amendment rights by law-abiding Americans," he said.

At the federal level, Rep. Linda Sanchez (D-Calif.) has proposed a bill that would impose a 10 percent tax on "any concealable" firearm, with the revenue used to fund a national gun buyback program. The bill is still in committee.

In California, state Rep. Roger Dickinson recently introduced a bill to impose a 5-cent tax on every bullet. Massachusetts state Rep. David Linsky is pushing a 25 percent sales tax on ammunition and firearms, while Maryland state Rep. Jon Cardin has introduced a bill imposing a 50 percent tax on ammunition and an annual $25 gun registration fee.

According to the Las Vegas Review Journal, Assembly Majority Leader William Horne is pushing a draft bill that would include a $25 per gun sales tax, in addition to a 2-cent tax for every round of ammunition.

The tax proposals are part of a broader campaign by pro-gun control lawmakers to regulate firearms. While some states, such as Colorado, have moved forward with new gun regulations, the movement on Capitol Hill has been more restrained. President Obama, who has been quiet on the gun control issue since initiating gun legislation, is expected to discuss the topic during a speech to supporters and donors in Washington on Wednesday.

Title: Trump Defends Soleimani Strike, Cites Iranian Influence in Iraq

Article:

President Donald Trump has defended the U.S. airstrike that killed Iran's top military commander, Qassem Soleimani, on Friday, stating that Soleimani "should have been taken out many years ago" and was "directly and indirectly responsible for the death of millions of people."

In a series of tweets, Trump addressed the decision to launch air strikes that killed Iran's top military commander, marking his first public comments on authorizing the action.

"General Qassem Soleimani has killed or badly wounded thousands of Americans over an extended period of time, and was plotting to kill many more... but got caught! He was directly and indirectly responsible for the death of millions of people, including the recent large number of PROTESTERS killed in Iran itself," Trump tweeted Friday morning.

The president also stated that Soleimani was "both hated and feared within the country" and that the people of Iraq "don't want to be dominated & controlled by Iran." Trump added that the U.S. has paid Iraq billions of dollars over the years and that Iran has gained more and more control over Iraq, causing instability in the region.

Soleimani is believed to be responsible for the deaths of hundreds of U.S. soldiers over the years, and the airstrike at Baghdad's airport received applause from Republicans. However, the strike has left much of the world on edge, and Iran has vowed revenge.

The State Department on Friday urged U.S. citizens to leave Iraq immediately and said that American citizens "should not approach" the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. The Pentagon confirmed that the president had ordered a strike against Soleimani, the head of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps' elite Quds Force.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that the move "saved American lives." Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader of Iran, called Soleimani's death "bitter" but vowed that life would be "more bitter for the murderers and criminals." Foreign Minister Javad Zarif called the strike against Soleimani an "act of international terrorism" and a "foolish escalation."

The move marked a significant escalation in Trump's widening confrontation with Iran and stoked fears about the potential for destabilizing consequences in the region. In a sign of the immediate ramifications, the U.S. Embassy in Iraq urged Americans to immediately leave the country.

Democrats have criticized Trump for not giving Congress proper notification of the strike and warned of the potential for significant and debilitating consequences. The White House and Trump, who is at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Fla., had been relatively quiet about the decision until Friday. Late Thursday, shortly before the Pentagon statement was issued, the president tweeted an image of an American flag without any text. Earlier Friday, Trump also retweeted a number of accounts referencing the strike and wrote cryptically that Iran "never won a war, but never lost a negotiation."

Title: Katie Couric Accused of Deceptive Editing in Second Documentary

Article:

Katie Couric, who recently admitted to deceptive editing in an interview with pro-gun activists, is facing new accusations of manipulating another film, "Fed Up," to embarrass interviewees. According to the Washington Free Beacon, Couric, the producer of the film, allegedly edited the documentary to discredit individuals who were interviewed.

"Fed Up" examines the issue of obesity and the food industry. The Free Beacon reported that the film includes two interviews with figures who hold viewpoints counter to the narrative of the film, and sources say both interviews include at least one misleading or deceptive edit intended to embarrass the interviewee.

Dr. David Allison, director of the Nutrition Obesity Research Center and an expert interviewed in "Fed Up," told the paper that Couric's actions were "antithetical to not only just human decency and civility but is antithetical to the spirit of science and democratic dialogue."

Allison said he had a brief discussion with Couric about whether sugary drinks exacerbate America's obesity problem more than other foods. Couric reportedly questioned Allison about the science behind his claims, and he asked for a moment to "get his thoughts together" because she had specifically requested that all his answers be in layman terms. Allison said Couric told him before filming that he could take a moment to collect his thoughts at any point.

In a clip of the interview, Couric responds to Allison's on-camera request with, "OK." However, the cameras continued rolling, and Allison can be seen sitting silently for nearly 10 seconds before the documentary cuts to the next interviewee. After those seven seconds passed, Allison says he answered Couric's question.

"I had what I thought was a very cogent answer," he said. "Of course, I gave an answer. I gave an answer to every question she asked me in a 90-minute interview, and out of a 90-minute interview, she chose to show the approximately 10 seconds when I paused and said, 'Let me collect my thoughts.'"

In another example, Stephanie Soechtig, director of "Fed Up," is accused of deceptively editing an interview with Lisa Gable, a spokeswoman for the Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation. Sources told the Free Beacon that Soechtig's voice was edited to embarrass Gable.

Soechtig and Gable talked about whether stores would consider removing food products from shelves. At one point, Soechtig can be heard saying Gable is avoiding the question, and Gable is seen sitting silently for around three seconds.

"She is badgered about companies' willingness to reformulate their products, to which the producer answers, 'It feels like you're avoiding the question,'" an industry source told the Free Beacon. "That response from the producer didn't actually follow that particular exchange and was edited to make it look like that was how their conversation actually went."

Watch the "Fed Up" clip of the interview with Lisa Gable.

Another source told the paper, "It was apparent in the 'Fed Up' documentary that all interviewees were not treated equally."

The new accusations surface only one week after Couric accepted blame for deceptively editing the "Under the Gun" documentary. Couric wrote on the website of "Under the Gun" about the edit:

"I take responsibility for a decision that misrepresented an exchange I had with members of the Virginia Citizens Defense League (VCDL). My question to the VCDL regarding the ability of convicted felons and those on the terror watch list to legally obtain a gun, was followed by an extended pause, making the participants appear to be speechless. When I screened an early version of the film with the director, Stephanie Soechtig, I questioned her and the editor about the pause and was told that a 'beat' was added for, as she described it, 'dramatic effect,' to give the audience a moment to consider the question. When VCDL members recently pointed out that they had in fact immediately answered this question, I went back and reviewed it and agree that those eight seconds do not accurately represent their response."

She also expressed some remorse for the edit, saying, "I regret that those eight seconds were misleading and that I did not raise my initial concerns more vigorously."

Upon hearing news of the "Under the Gun" edit, radio host Rush Limbaugh came down harshly on Couric, whom he described as "not a nice person."

"It was a totally fake and phony edit, and she's now taking responsibility for it because the pressure obviously got to be so intense," Limbaugh said.

"I bet you there will not be a single story on how many sponsors she's lost because of this. Not a single one. Nor will there be any stories on how many sponsors lost here and wanted to come back and we said 'no' to. There won't be any coverage like that at all, cause that's not the point of the coverage."

"So they're gonna try to cover it up for Katie and limit the damage to her as much possible. That's why she feels confident going out there and taking the hit cause she knows it's gonna all be over by the next day. And no harm, no foul, and she'll still be doing what she's doing the same way she's doing it. In other words, getting away with it – except when she's caught."

Soechtig, the film's director, released a statement trying to explain why she inserted the long pause of nothingness: "There are a wide range of views expressed in the film. My intention was to provide a pause for the viewer to have a moment to consider this important question before presenting the facts on Americans' opinions on background checks. I never intended to make anyone look bad and I apologize if anyone felt that way."

Although the documentary cut out the responses, the film's website is now providing the transcript, showing the responses were immediate and substantive.

Title: U.S. and China Exchange Tariff Threats, Escalating Trade Tensions

Article:

The United States and China have exchanged tariff threats this week, with the potential for a full-blown trade war looming. On Wednesday, China released a list of $50 billion worth of U.S. products targeted with tariffs, in response to the Trump administration's threat to increase taxes on $1,300 billion of China's high-tech imports. This is not yet a declared trade war, but economists are describing it as a preliminary stage, with both sides testing each other's limits without engaging in full-blown action.

China's new tariffs list targets U.S. industries that are significant in China and areas that are politically influential for President Trump, such as agriculture and other industries that do substantial business in China. The list includes soybeans, pork, cranberries, whiskey, automobiles, airplanes, and plastic, among other products.

President Trump has made good on a campaign promise to address China's trade abuses with these tariffs and other trade policies. The tariffs and other measures are aimed at China's intellectual property theft, a long-standing issue for U.S. companies.

President Trump tweeted, "We are not in a trade war with China, that war was lost many years ago by the foolish, or incompetent, people who represented the U.S. Now we have a Trade Deficit of $500 Billion a year, with Intellectual Property Theft of another $300 Billion. We can not let this continue!"

The risks of an escalating exchange of tariffs with America's largest trading partner are substantial, with potential higher prices for U.S. consumers and lost jobs in affected industries. However, Denise Bode, a tax and trade analyst at a Washington law firm, believes a full-blown trade war is possible but more likely that President Trump will make a deal.

In issuing its hit list, China blamed the U.S. for picking a fight. China's deputy commerce minister, Wang Shouwen, said, "It must be said, we have been forced into taking this action." The value of the U.S. products on China's list is virtually identical to the $50 billion in Chinese high-tech products identified for tariffs on a list the Trump administration released late Tuesday.

Neither list will go into immediate effect. The U.S. tariffs require a monthslong comment and review process, and China said it, too, is moving slowly. Larry Kudlow, director of the president's National Economic Council, tried to tamp down concerns about a trade war, saying a negotiated resolution is more likely.

Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) expressed concern about the impact on U.S. agriculture, stating, "Farmers and ranchers shouldn't be expected to bear the brunt of retaliation for the entire country. It's not fair, and it doesn't make economic sense." Grassley vowed to push the issue in the Senate.

The 1,300 Chinese products on the U.S. tariff list include aerospace, pharmaceuticals, and electronics. China had previously threatened to retaliate when President Trump announced pending tariffs last month. China responded with a list of more than 120 U.S. items worth about $3 billion to hit with an import tax after the Trump administration imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum from all countries, though exemptions were later offered to Mexico, Canada, South Korea, and other major importers of those metals.

Title: President Trump Calls for Potential Government Shutdown in September to Address Legislative Impasse

Article:

President Donald Trump has called for a potential government shutdown in September, citing the need to address the current legislative impasse in Congress. In a series of tweets on Tuesday, Trump expressed frustration with the filibuster rule in the Senate, which requires 60 votes for most legislation, and suggested that either more Republican senators need to be elected in 2018 or the rules need to be changed to a simple majority of 51 percent.

Trump's comments appear to reflect his dissatisfaction with the spending deal Congress is poised to approve this week, which would fund the government through September and represents the first major bipartisan legislation of Trump's presidency. Democrats have argued that they won most of the battles surrounding the bill, and several media accounts have suggested that Trump and the White House were losers in the negotiations.

The measure will spare the president a damaging government shutdown, but it leaves out many of his biggest policy requests, such as funding for his proposed wall along the U.S.-Mexico border and language stripping federal money from so-called sanctuary cities. The White House also backed off a threat to withhold ObamaCare subsidy payments to insurance companies.

Trump did secure increased military spending in the 2017 budget deal, breaking with longstanding practice that a boost in Pentagon spending be accompanied by a dollar-for-dollar spike in domestic spending. White House budget director Mick Mulvaney defended the president's threat of a shutdown in the fall, stating, "The president’s tweet was that we might need a shutdown at some point to drive home that this place — that Washington needs to be fixed."

Mulvaney argued the current deal running through September was a White House victory because Democrats were determined to cause a shutdown that would hurt Trump. "They wanted a shutdown. They wanted to try and make this president look like he could not govern," he said. "And he beat them on that at the very, very highest level."

Trump's comments are likely to irk top Republican lawmakers, who have been frustrated by Trump's repeated attempts to intervene in the legislative process. Senator John Cornyn did not mention the president or his tweets, but his remarks about the importance of avoiding a shutdown and the strength of the filibuster were notable coming shortly after Trump's tweets. "We were elected to govern. Yes, governing is hard. It's hard by design," he said. "But that's the way our founding fathers designed our constitutional system."

If GOP lawmakers are frustrated with Trump, however, the feeling may be mutual. The businessman-turned-president has vented frustration with the slow pace of work on Capitol Hill. "I'm disappointed that it doesn't go quicker," Trump told Fox News last week when asked about the Republican effort to repeal and replace ObamaCare.

Title: CIA Assessment Suggests Saudi Crown Prince Ordered Khashoggi Killing, Trump Maintains No Role for Now

Article:

The Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) has intelligence that substantiates an assessment that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, according to a U.S. official familiar with the intelligence. However, the official declined to characterize the confidence level of the CIA's assessment. A separate U.S. official told a news outlet on Friday that U.S. intelligence has "high confidence" in its assessment that bin Salman ordered the killing, an assessment based on an understanding of how Saudi Arabia operates.

Neither official indicated that there is direct evidence linking bin Salman to the killing on the day of the incident. On Saturday, President Donald Trump called CIA Director Gina Haspel and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo from Air Force One as he flew to California to view wildfire damage. President Trump has confidence in the CIA, according to press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, but she provided no additional details.

Before leaving the White House, President Trump stated that, regarding the crown prince, "as of this moment we were told that he did not play a role." He added, "We're going to have to find out what they have to say."

In his remarks, the president spoke of Saudi Arabia as "a truly spectacular ally in terms of jobs and economic development." He also mentioned that he has to take a lot of things into consideration when deciding what measures to take against the kingdom.

The intelligence agencies' conclusion will bolster efforts in Congress to further punish the close U.S. ally for the killing. The Trump administration this past week penalized 17 Saudi officials for their alleged role in the killing, but American lawmakers have called on the administration to curtail arms sales to Saudi Arabia or take other harsher punitive measures.

Saudi Arabia's top diplomat has said the crown prince had "absolutely" nothing to do with the killing. Vice President Mike Pence, when asked about the matter, declined to comment on "classified information." He stated Saturday that the murder of Jamal Khashoggi was an atrocity and an affront to a free and independent press.

Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi who lived in the United States, was a columnist for The Washington Post and often criticized the royal family. He was killed on October 2 at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul while seeking marriage documents. Turkish and Saudi authorities have said he was killed inside the consulate by a team from the kingdom.

This past week, U.S. intelligence officials briefed members of the Senate and House intelligence committees, and the Treasury Department announced economic sanctions on 17 Saudi officials suspected of being responsible for or complicit in the killing. Also this past week, the top prosecutor in Saudi Arabia announced he will seek the death penalty against five men suspected in the killing.

President Trump has called the killing a botched operation that was carried out very poorly and has said "the cover-up was one of the worst cover-ups in the history of cover-ups." However, he has resisted calls to cut off arms sales to the kingdom and has been reluctant to antagonize the Saudi rulers. President Trump considers the Saudis vital allies in his Mideast agenda.

Title: Trump Administration Rescinds DAPA Program, Leaves DACA Intact

Article:

WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has rescinded a 2014 memo that allowed certain undocumented immigrants to remain in the United States, but has left intact the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, created in 2012. The DAPA program, which was never implemented due to court challenges, protected undocumented immigrants who have a child who is a U.S. citizen or lawful resident.

Homeland Security Secretary John F. Kelly announced the decision late Thursday, stating that there is "no credible path forward" to litigate the policy. The move fulfills part of President Trump's campaign promise to overturn two of former President Barack Obama's memos on illegal immigration.

However, the terms of the DACA program, which grants reprieves from deportation to nearly 800,000 undocumented immigrants who arrived in the United States as children, will not change. The rescinded program provided expanded work authorization for DACA recipients.

Advocates for undocumented immigrants have expressed concern that while the DACA program remains in place for now, it is vulnerable to future changes. Greisa Martinez Rosas, advocacy director for United We Dream, stated, "The DACA program still stands, but it’s vulnerable."

Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) praised the decision to rescind the DAPA program, calling it "a deeply irresponsible policy from the start." Rep. Don Beyer (D-Va.) criticized the move, noting that it came as Democrats and Republicans had put aside partisanship to gather for the Congressional Baseball Game following the shooting of House Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) during a practice session earlier in the week.

Title: Romney Breaks with GOP on Minimum Wage, Expresses Support for Increase

Article:

Former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, expressed his support for an increase in the minimum wage during a Thursday morning interview on "Morning Joe." Romney's stance on the issue contrasts with many Republicans who have historically opposed minimum wage hikes.

"I, for instance, as you know, part company with many of the conservatives in my party on the issue of the minimum wage," Romney said. "I think we ought to raise it." He added, "Our party is all about more jobs and better pay."

Romney's comments come after Senate Republicans rejected a vote on a Senate bill that would have increased the minimum wage to $10.10. In recent times, former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty and former Pennsylvania Senator Rick Santorum, both of whom also ran for the Republican nomination in 2012, have also expressed support for some increase in the minimum wage.

During the wide-ranging interview, Romney reiterated that he is not running for president in 2016. He mentioned several potential Republican presidential candidates, including his 2012 running mate, Representative Paul Ryan (R-Wis.), New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, among others.

Romney also criticized Hillary Clinton, who is expected to be the presumptive front-runner for the Democrats if she chooses to run in 2016. When asked about her time as Secretary of State, Romney said, "That's going to be an enormous liability for her... If you look around the world... this was not a good time for America." He added that Clinton's record as Secretary of State is "going to raise a lot of questions about her capacity to actually accomplish things of significance, particularly on foreign soil."

Romney also appeared to condone fundraising efforts by the National Republican Congressional Committee and National Republican Senatorial Committee that invoked the September 2012 attacks in Benghazi. When asked about fundraising off the issue, Romney responded by saying, "Without a GOP majority in the House, there would have been no investigations into Benghazi or the IRS." The specifics of these fundraising efforts and Romney's exact stance on them were not detailed in the provided text.

Title: Tribute in Light, Moments of Silence, and Commemoration Mark 18th Anniversary of 9/11 Attacks

Article:

Two parallel beams of light illuminated the New York City sky on Wednesday, marking the annual Tribute in Light public art installation, commemorating the 18th anniversary of the September 11th terror attacks. Simultaneously, bells tolled across New York City, President Donald Trump spoke at the Pentagon, and moments of silence were observed in Shanksville, Pennsylvania, and across the nation.

In New York, the names of the nearly 3,000 people who lost their lives were solemnly read at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum. Intermittent moments of silence marked the impact times of the Ground Zero planes, the time when each tower collapsed, and the moment when planes struck the Pentagon and a field in Shanksville.

Mary Ann Marino, who read some of the names, including that of her son, firefighter Kenneth Marino, stated, "Eighteen years have not lessened our loss."

The first moment of silence was observed at 8:46 a.m. EDT to mark the time when American Airlines Flight 11, en route to Los Angeles from Boston when it was hijacked, slammed into the north face of the World Trade Center's North Tower. At 9:03 a.m., United Airlines Flight 175, also bound for Los Angeles from Boston, when it crashed into the south face of the World Trade Center's South Tower. At 9:37 a.m., American Airlines Flight 77, scheduled to fly from Washington to Los Angeles when it hit the Pentagon. At 10:03 a.m., Flight 93, flying from Newark, New Jersey, to San Francisco when it slammed into a western Pennsylvania field.

The World Trade Center's South Tower collapsed at 9:59 a.m.; the North Tower fell 29 minutes later. The New York ceremony was open only to family members, but the event was streamed live. The memorial will open to the public later in the day.

Nicholas Haros Jr., whose mother, Frances, died in the World Trade Center, challenged a statement this summer from Rep. Ilhan Omar, D-Minn., that "some people did something" and that "all of us were starting to lose access" to civil liberties. Haros wore a black T-shirt with the words "Some people did something" as he read the names of the dead.

In Shanksville, Vice President Mike Pence lauded the heroes from United Airlines Flight 93. The Memorial Plaza is near the site where Flight 93 crashed into a field after passengers fought with hijackers intent on crashing into the U.S. Capitol.

The memory of those who died is "carved into the hearts and memories of the American people," Pence said. The names of the 40 passengers and crew were read, and the Bells of Remembrance were rung. A wreath was placed at the Wall of Names at the site.

Trump led a brief remembrance on the South Lawn of the White House, joined by hundreds of guests, including 9/11 survivors and family members and current and former law enforcement personnel. He then spoke at a ceremony at the Pentagon, where 184 people were killed 18 years ago.

"Today the nation honors and mourns nearly 3,000 lives that were stolen from us," Trump said. He recounted going to Ground Zero after the planes hit.

"We are united with you in grief," he said. "We offer you all that we have: our unwavering loyalty, our undying devotion, our eternal pledge that your loved ones will never, ever be forgotten."

Trump blamed the Taliban for the cancellation of peace talks to try to end the war that started in Afghanistan shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks. He said U.S. forces have "hit them" harder than ever.

"And if for any reason they ever come back to our country, we will go wherever they are and use power the likes of which the U.S. has never used before," Trump said.

Cities and towns across the nation marked the anniversary. In Michigan, an anti-Muslim event was canceled amid condemnation from politicians and organizations. Bloomfield Hills Baptist Church announced in a one-sentence email Monday evening that it canceled a two-day event called "9/11 forgotten? Is Michigan surrendering to Islam?" that had been scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday. The event was set to host two speakers addressing topics such as "How the interfaith movement is sabotaging America and the church" and "How Islam is destroying America from within."

Title: Indiana Governor Mike Pence Defends "Religious Freedom" Law, Faces Intense Backlash

Article:

Indiana Governor Mike Pence has defended his state's new "Religious Freedom Restoration Act" (RFRA), stating that the controversy surrounding the law is due to "a tremendous amount of misinformation and misunderstanding." However, Pence declined to answer several questions about whether the measure could be used to discriminate against LGBT individuals.

During an appearance on ABC's "This Week," Pence refused to confirm or deny that the RFRA legalizes discrimination against gays and lesbians. He also stated that he would not support legislation adding protections based on sexual orientation to Indiana's anti-discrimination laws.

The RFRA, signed into law last week, allows Indiana businesses to cite their religious beliefs as a legal defense. The law has sparked intense backlash, with tech companies, mayors, sports organizations, and celebrities criticizing the measure.

White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest called Pence "in damage control mode" during the same segment on ABC's "This Week." Apple CEO Tim Cook and Salesforce.com head Marc Benioff have both expressed their disapproval of the law, with Apple threatening to halt its expansion in Indiana and Salesforce.com encouraging employees to leave the state.

Mayors of San Francisco and Seattle have announced bans on public funds being spent on employee travel to Indiana, with San Francisco making exceptions for travel "essential to the public health and safety." Seattle will inspect city contracts to see if any are with businesses located in Indiana.

Indianapolis' mayor, Greg Ballard, condemned the new law, stating, "We are a diverse city, and I want everyone who visits and lives in Indy to feel comfortable here. RFRA sends the wrong signal." The NCAA, which is headquartered in Indianapolis and is set to host its men's basketball Final Four in the city this week, has expressed concerns that the law could lead it to move events elsewhere in future years.

Popular culture figures, such as Miley Cyrus and M.C. Hammer, have also weighed in, with Cyrus calling Pence an "a--hole" on Instagram and Hammer describing the law as "barbaric and inhumane."

Pence maintained that the law is about protecting religious liberty and not about discriminating against LGBT individuals. He noted that President Bill Clinton signed a similar law nationally, and then-state Sen. Barack Obama supported one in Illinois.

However, when asked about comments made by Eric Miller, the head of Advance America and a powerful lobbyist on socially conservative causes in Indiana, Pence refused to answer several times whether Miller's claims, such as refusing to participate in a homosexual marriage or allowing a man to use the women's restroom, were accurate.

Local businesses have also expressed concerns, with the chief executive of Angie's List, who was also the campaign manager for Pence's Republican predecessor, former Gov. Mitch Daniels, stating that his company is halting its plans for a major expansion in Indianapolis.

Pence is open to legislative efforts to clarify the "religious freedom" law, though the state's Republican-dominated legislature has already rejected Democrats' push to amend it to protect gays and lesbians from discrimination. Pence stated, "This is not about disputes between individuals, it's about government overreach, and I'm proud that Indiana stepped forward."

Title: Presidential Candidates Court African American Voters Amidst Ongoing Structural Inequalities

Article:

As the Democratic presidential primaries progress, candidates are focusing on courting African American voters in states such as Nevada, South Carolina, and those participating in Super Tuesday. However, many candidates' rhetoric contrasts with their records, as their promises often conflict with their past performances.

Donald Trump, in an attempt to appeal to black voters, has highlighted the economy, the initial steps towards reducing mass incarceration, and the so-called "opportunity zones." Despite this, his history, which includes the racially charged "birther" movement, embracing white supremacists at Charlottesville, a focus on erasing Obama's legacy, and a political strategy that relies on race-baiting politics, contradicts his current efforts.

Pete Buttigieg, who is often praised for his oratory skills, faces criticism from African American leaders in his hometown regarding his record on race and policing as mayor. Amy Klobuchar, who positions herself as a moderate, has a controversial record as a prosecutor that limits her appeal. Mike Bloomberg, who has the financial resources to dominate the campaign trail, struggles to explain his harsh and racially biased stop-and-frisk policies as mayor of New York and his embrace of right-wing conspiracy theories.

Joe Biden is also on an apparent apology tour, joining Bloomberg. African American voters are not easily swayed, as they are acutely aware of the structural inequalities they face, including higher unemployment rates, lower wages, inadequate healthcare, and a biased criminal justice system.

Notably absent from the debate is a leader who is prepared to address the challenges facing African Americans with the same boldness and seriousness as the Kerner Commission, established in the aftermath of the urban riots of the late 1960s. The commission, chaired by Illinois Governor Otto Kerner, issued a stark warning: "Our nation is moving toward two societies, one black, one white—separate and unequal."

The Kerner Report, as it became known, offered a comprehensive agenda to address the structural inequalities, including new jobs, integrated schools, daycare for children, higher wages, greater services, and more diverse and sensitive police forces. The report did not shy away from the significant costs associated with implementing these recommendations, suggesting that the cost of inaction would be far greater.

Unfortunately, the costs of the Vietnam War, both in terms of money, lives, and political upheaval, overshadowed any serious effort to address domestic issues during that time. The Kerner Report, along with Johnson's War on Poverty, was lost in the jungles of Vietnam.

Fifty-two years later, much has changed, yet many issues remain unresolved. Affirmative action has provided opportunities for some people of color, but structural racism still permeates our society, particularly in the criminal justice system. As the politicians campaign for African American votes, they will receive a hearing. We appreciate the attention and gestures, but the Kerner Report set the standard for what a serious leader would champion. We'll see who comes close—if anyone does—to accepting that challenge.

Title: Unresolved Budget Impasse Could Lead to Slower Job Growth in 2013, Economists Warn

Article:

Economists are expressing concern that job creation could slow significantly if President Obama and Congressional Republicans fail to reach an agreement on deficit reduction by the end of the year, leading to more than $600 billion in government spending cuts and automatic tax increases in 2013. The Congressional Budget Office, along with many private economists, warn that this path could lead to a recession in the first half of 2013 and push unemployment rates higher.

Ethan Harris, co-head of global economics at Bank of America Merrill Lynch, stated that while businesses seem to be hiring despite the uncertainty in Washington, this could change quickly. "If the budget impasse can't be resolved this month, it's likely that jobs growth will weaken early next year," he said.

Even if both sides in Washington come up with a short-term solution on the budget, the pace of job growth remains well below what is needed to push wages substantially higher or to significantly reduce the broadest measure of unemployment anytime soon. In November, the broad unemployment gauge dipped to 14.4 percent from 14.6 percent in October.

Average hourly earnings rose 0.2 percent in November, and are up about 1.7 percent from a year earlier—about half the annual rate of growth seen in 2007 before the recession hit, when unemployment was below 5 percent. The size of the labor force, according to a household survey separate from the one showing how many jobs were added by businesses and government, shrank by 350,000 in November.

The labor participation rate, which represents the portion of the adult population that is either employed or actively looking for work, remains low by historical standards. At 63.6 percent in November, it is near the low point in this economic cycle, said Nigel Gault, chief United States economist for IHS Global Insight.

"We're not at the point in which the jobs market is strong enough to pull discouraged workers back into the labor market," he said. Although job growth in November exceeded expectations, the Labor Department revised downward its figures for the preceding months. For September, the Labor Department said the economy created 132,000 jobs, down from an earlier estimate of 148,000, and the figure for October was lowered to 138,000 from 171,000.

Highlighting just how vulnerable the economy remains, a widely followed measure of how likely consumers were to make purchases showed a marked drop. The Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan index of consumer confidence for early December, released on Friday, fell to 74.5, down from 82.7 in November.

One notable point of weakness in the latest jobs report was the manufacturing sector, which lost 7,000 jobs in November. Demand for goods from Europe and other overseas markets has softened recently, and some manufacturing companies have held up spending amid the standoff in Washington.

Employment in the construction sector fell by 20,000 last month—one hint of Hurricane Sandy's impact, economists said. However, construction employment could pick up in December as homeowners rebuild in the Northeast and as the housing sector continues to regain ground nationwide.

Retailers added 53,000 jobs last month, more than triple the typical monthly rate in the last year. Much of that increase was to accommodate holiday shoppers, and Julia Coronado, chief North American economist at BNP Paribas, suggested the early start of sales promotions and an early Thanksgiving may have encouraged stores to hire workers more quickly than usual in November.

"We may see less of a gain in retail in December," she said. "This was a very, very strong number that probably won't persist."

Among the unemployed, the percentage of people who have been out of a job for more than 27 weeks remains high but came down slightly in November, falling to 40.1 percent from 40.6 percent a month before.

Younger workers, who have had significantly higher rates of unemployment than older workers since the recession, also seem to have done a bit better in November. According to seasonally adjusted figures in the household survey, unemployment among workers aged 20 to 24 fell to 12.7 percent in November from 13.2 percent in October, and among 25- to 34-year-olds it fell to 7.9 percent from 8.3 percent.

While substantially lower, the unemployment rate among workers 55 and older held steady at 5.8 percent.

Title: Trump Confirms Obama's U.S. Birth, Denies Role in Birther Movement

Article:

In a campaign event at the Trump International Hotel in Washington D.C. on Friday, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump confirmed that President Barack Obama was born in the United States. However, Trump's statement contradicts the claim that his campaign had previously made about his role in the so-called "birther movement."

Trump's statement came after five years of questioning Obama's citizenship on various media platforms. Despite his campaign manager and spokesperson stating that Trump believes Obama was born in the United States, Trump had not explicitly acknowledged this fact until Friday.

During the event, Trump stated, "Hillary Clinton and her campaign of 2008 started the birther controversy," which is a claim that has been widely discredited. Trump added, "I finished it. I finished it, you know what I mean."

The event, billed as a campaign event, was held in the gilded ballroom of the $212 million hotel at 1100 Pennsylvania Ave., which remains federal property. The hotel, which is still under construction, is partially open for business, with rooms available for $895 a night.

Trump's opening remarks were an advertisement for the hotel, and he claimed the hotel was finished under budget and ahead of schedule, a claim that is not true. He then turned his attention to the people onstage, praising the generals and Medal of Honor winners present.

When he returned to the lectern, the crowd erupted in chants of "USA!" Trump talked in a sleepy tone, delivering platitudes about improving the country and mistruths about the state of the country. He then made the statement, "Now, I just want to tell you all, President Barack Obama was born in the United States, period."

Trump took no questions and offered no explanation for why he had changed his stance after Obama released his long-form birth certificate in 2011. For years, Trump had questioned Obama's citizenship, fueling the birther movement, but on Friday, he stated, "I finished it."

The birther movement, which questioned Obama's citizenship and eligibility to be president, gained traction in 2008, with claims that Obama's mother was unable to fly in the late months of her pregnancy, and so he was born in Kenya. These claims were largely discredited, and Hillary Clinton, during her 2008 campaign, did not push the rumors.

Trump's announcement comes as the polls are narrowing, and his campaign strategists' advice to act more diplomatically has proven effective. However, a few words on the subject cannot erase years of questioning Obama's citizenship, which has been widely criticized as racist. After Trump exited the ballroom, the blue curtain collapsed onto the stage, taking down the American flags with it.

Title: House Armed Services Committee Releases Report on Benghazi Attack, Finds White House Failed to Comprehend Security Situation

Article:

The House Armed Services Committee, led by Republicans, has released a report today, concluding that the White House failed to comprehend or ignored the deteriorating security situation in Libya prior to the attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi on September 11, 2012. The report also states that U.S. personnel in Benghazi were "woefully vulnerable" and that the Defense Department believed the violence was a terrorist attack "nearly from the outset."

The 31-page report, authored by Chairman Buck McKeon (R-Calif.), Vice Chairman Mac Thornberry (R-Texas), and Rep. Martha Roby (R-Ala.), found that the administration did not direct a change in military force posture, there was no intelligence of a specific "imminent" threat in Libya, and the Department of State, which has primary responsibility for diplomatic security, "favored a reduction" of Department of Defense security personnel in Libya before the attack.

The report also agrees with the administration that during the attack, military assets were not positioned to make a difference in the response, and there was no stand-down order issued by the administration to forces in Tripoli preparing to respond. However, it states that "there was no'stand down' order issued to U.S. military personnel in Tripoli who sought to join the fight in Benghazi."

Democrats on the committee, including ranking Democrat Adam Smith (D-Wash.) and Rep. Niki Tsongas, the top Democrat on the committee's investigative subcommittee, believe the Republican report ends the controversy that there was any corruption in the aftermath of the attack. They wrote in a statement, "It is time to move forward, take the real conclusions we have arrived at and establish how to best protect our citizens around the globe."

The report comes after Republicans on the committee had previously accused the Obama administration of preventing a rescue attempt by the U.S. military. The attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi killed four Americans, including Ambassador Christopher Stevens. It triggered a firestorm of criticism accusing the Obama administration of covering up its response to the attack.

Title: House Republicans, President Obama Still Far Apart on Budget Priorities After Meeting

Article:

In a bid to bridge the partisan divide between the White House and House Republicans, President Barack Obama met with GOP leaders on Wednesday, but the meeting yielded little progress on budget priorities. The meeting, part of the White House's "charm offensive" on Capitol Hill, was followed by a news conference where House Speaker John Boehner thanked the president for coming but noted the challenges remaining on a host of issues, particularly those related to reducing the deficit.

Republicans' top priority, tackling federal spending and reining in record deficits, came up early in the Republican conference meeting. Oklahoma Rep. Jim Lankford asked the first question, pressing the president to explain why he would not join House Republicans in their effort to balance the budget in a decade. According to several Republicans, Obama explained that he did not share that priority, an answer that many emphasized as they left the meeting.

Georgia Rep. Paul Broun, a conservative who is running for the Senate, mentioned that exchange as he left, telling reporters, "basically his whole talk was just a bunch of platitudes and no substance to it."

Rep. Tom Cotton, R-Arkansas, said afterward, "He thought what was more important was that deficits fall below growth as a percentage of GDP -- certainly a laudable goal, but I think the federal government, like any business or any family, needs to work towards a balanced budget."

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor gave a blunt assessment about the divide on fiscal issues, suggesting it could carry over to other issues. "If the president wants to let our unwillingness to raise taxes get in the way, then we're not going to be able to set differences aside and focus on what we agree on," Cantor told reporters at the GOP leaders' news conference.

When Lankford raised fiscal issues during the meeting, he also pointed out that the president's other meeting on Wednesday was with his political arm, Organizing for Action. This rankled many GOP members who suggested Obama was more concerned with political goals than working across the aisle.

"We know the president is going to speak before Organizing for Action tonight," Rep. Greg Walden, R-Oregon, who leads the House Republicans' campaign arm, told reporters as he left the meeting. "We know he's made it clear that taking out the House is his big priority, and we know he's been on the never-ending campaign tour up to this point, so there's a trust factor."

Mindful of the House GOP undercurrent that Obama is chiefly focused on scoring political points, one source inside the meeting said the president addressed those concerns directly at the end of the meeting. This source told CNN that the president told GOP members that if he were only focused on the midterms, he would not be pushing immigration reform because that's not necessarily helpful for some members of his party. He said he would not push for entitlement reform because a lot of Democrats do not agree and are nervous about tackling such a politically explosive issue.

He told them that he runs the country, that he wants it to succeed, and that he looks around the room and sees other people who love their country. Obama said they have a moment and should seize it, according to this source.

Walden did say the session helped build some trust, and it was a good opportunity to raise a wide spectrum of issues. He mentioned Israel as one area where both parties found some common ground.

Exiting the conference, House Budget Committee Chairman and former Republican vice presidential nominee Paul Ryan (R-Wisconsin) said of the president, "He did himself some good."

Several members in the meeting said it helped open a dialogue but lamented that the session was only the second time the president had traveled up Pennsylvania Avenue to talk to House Republicans since he was elected.

"The president does not spend a lot of time working with members of Congress. He does not have to -- he's president of the United States -- but I think it's made his job a lot more difficult, and it's made our task a lot more difficult because there's very little communication," Florida Rep. Mario Diaz-Balart said after the meeting.

Cotton described the president's demeanor in the meeting as "affable" and said the various members who asked questions were "very cordial and respectful."

According to multiple GOP sources, conference Chairwoman Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington screened questions in advance and called on members after the president made opening remarks.

Rep. Michael Grimm of New York said the event had been peppered with occasional lighter moments such as speculation after word got around the room that the new pope was about to be announced.

"Anyone who thinks this president is anything but affable and pleasant when he's speaking with a group is just simply wrong. They haven't met him," said Grimm. But he added he was waiting to see if the president would follow up his outreach with some bipartisan action.

Obama fielded some tense questions during the meeting. Michigan Rep. Candice Miller told reporters she was not satisfied with the president's response to her complaint that the White House had suspended public tours after forced spending cuts went into effect. Republicans have charged that the closures were politically motivated, but Obama said Wednesday the decision had been made by the Secret Service.

Title: "Congress Introduces Over 90 'Jobs' Bills in Response to Unemployment Concerns"

Article:

In the past 18 months, the United States Congress has introduced approximately 90 bills, collectively labeled as "jobs" bills, with the aim of creating or preserving jobs. This is a significant increase compared to the previous two-year congressional cycle and the Congress before that. The Labor Department reported on Friday that employers nationwide added only 80,000 jobs in June, maintaining an unemployment rate of 8.2 percent.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, stated on Friday that the Senate will move toward votes on a series of "common-sense jobs bills." These bills include a small-business tax cut designed to incentivize hiring and promote payroll growth.

However, job-creation policies, like many issues on Capitol Hill, are often subject to partisan and political spin. The definition of a "jobs bill" can vary, with Republicans characterizing the employment report as evidence that the jobs agenda of the Obama administration and the Democrat-controlled Congress has been ineffective.

House Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, stated that the jobs agenda of the Obama administration and the Democrat-controlled Congress has failed, citing the June employment report. He called on the president to work with Republicans to remove government obstacles to job creation.

The House GOP leaders plan to introduce legislation this summer to "rein in job-crushing red tape," including a measure to continue tax cuts instituted during the administration of President George W. Bush that are set to expire at the end of the year.

Some of the so-called "jobs" bills seem to stretch the definition of job creation. For example, the National Strategic and Critical Minerals Production Act, which does not specifically mention jobs, aims to more efficiently develop domestic sources of strategically important minerals. House Natural Resources Committee Chairman Doc Hastings, a Washington Republican, claims the measure will streamline government red tape in mining and related industries, fostering job growth.

The Farm Dust Regulation Prevention Act, which the House passed but is indefinitely stalled in the Senate, is also labeled as a jobs bill by House GOP leadership.
