The bill aims to exempt "farm dust" from falling under Clean Air Act regulations, a move that the bill's backers claim will protect American farm jobs.

A massive bill that cleared Congress last month to fund federal transportation projects was a rare example of legislation claimed by both parties to boost job growth. The bill promises to save or create almost 3 million jobs. However, the "highway bill" almost stalled due to a dispute over a proposed Keystone XL pipeline provision.

The debate over job-creation bills often revolves around the number of jobs that would be preserved or created. GOP backers often put the number in the tens of thousands, a figure dismissed by opponents as excessively optimistic.

Lawmakers also label measures they dislike as job killers. The Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare, is a frequent target. Republicans argue that the law will force employers to lay off workers or close up shop altogether. Representative Michele Bachmann, a Minnesota Republican and former presidential candidate, stated in late June that the "No. 1 reason [small businesses] aren't hiring is because of Obamacare."

President Obama has stated that the health care law, most of which was upheld by the Supreme Court last month, will lay a foundation for a stronger economy that will create jobs.

Title: Trump Signals Desire for Eased Coronavirus Restrictions by Easter, Contradicting Public Health Experts

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed a desire to ease up on coronavirus-related restrictions in the United States within the next three weeks, a timeline that contradicts the advice of top public health experts. During a Fox News town-hall event at the White House on Tuesday, Trump stated, "I would love to have the country opened up and just raring to go by Easter," referring to April 12.

The Fox News host Bill Hemmer responded, "That would be a great American resurrection." Easter is a significant religious holiday for many Americans, and Trump added, "Wouldn't it be great to have all the churches full?"

This call to reopen the US economy goes against the advice of his own experts, including Dr. Anthony Fauci, the US's top expert on infectious diseases. On Friday, Fauci stated, "I can't see that all of a sudden, next week or two weeks from now, it's going to be over. I don't think there's a chance of that."

Fauci added, "I think we should do everything we possibly can do. I mean, in all sectors, because obviously, as I've said so many times, when you think you're maybe overreacting, you probably are not acting as forcefully as you should. So as we've always said, we've got to try very much to stay ahead of the curve."

Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York, who is on the front lines of the pandemic, also implored Trump not to risk endangering lives by rushing to reopen the economy. The World Health Organization has warned that the US could become the new epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic, citing a "very large acceleration" in infections.

The US had fewer than 100 confirmed coronavirus cases on March 1, but by Tuesday afternoon, it had nearly 50,000. The White House announced new guidelines on March 16 aimed at slowing the spread of the virus, including avoiding gatherings of 10 or more people, canceling nonessential travel, and not going out to bars and restaurants. These guidelines were intended to be in place for 15 days and then reassessed.

President Trump has since signaled growing impatience with the stringent measures to fight the pandemic that have essentially shut down major US cities and dealt a huge blow to the economy. On Tuesday, Trump suggested that more people could die by suicide because of stress and anxiety about the economy than would die from COVID-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus.

However, Trump's power to reopen the economy is limited due to the 10th amendment, meaning these decisions will largely occur at the state level and be made by governors, not the president.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 280,000 Jobs in May, Unemployment Rate Increases Slightly

Article:

The U.S. economy added 280,000 new jobs in May, surpassing economists' expectations of 226,000, according to the latest report from the U.S. Department of Labor. The unemployment rate, however, ticked up to 5.5 percent, despite economists' predictions that it would remain steady at 5.4 percent.

The leisure and hospitality sector experienced a significant growth with 57,000 new jobs, while the arts, entertainment, and recreation sector saw an increase of 29,000 jobs. Retail added 31,000 jobs, and the construction sector saw 17,000 new positions.

The civilian labor force saw an increase of 397,000 people, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, but the labor participation rate remained virtually unchanged at 62.9 percent.

The latest figures follow a report on Thursday that unemployment claims had dropped, indicating that employers were confident in retaining workers. The Labor Department reported that claims had decreased by 8,000 to a seasonally adjusted 276,000.

The manufacturing workweek remained unchanged at 40.7 hours, and wages for private, nonfarm payrolls rose by 8 cents to $24.96.

The Associated Press notes that May's strong job growth "suggests that employers remained confident enough to keep hiring even after the economy shrank during the first three months of the year." The government also revised up its estimate of job growth in March and April by a combined net 32,000.

Valuewalk.com points out that some investors have been watching the three-month average of 191,000 on the low end, and note that any print under this level would be a negative sign for the U.S. economy. To reassure economic observers, yield curve traders suggest that the upside job gains would need to move well past the 255,000 six-month moving average for nonfarm payrolls and show a print above 300,000.

Title: Carolina Panthers Quarterback Cam Newton Stresses Accountability and Justice in Response to Charlotte Protests

Article:

Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton emphasized the importance of accountability during a press conference on Wednesday, addressing the recent police shooting of an armed black man in Charlotte, North Carolina, which led to violent protests in the city this week.

"My big thing is always holding people accountable, no matter what the race is, no matter what the gender is, no matter what the age is. We all have to hold each other accountable," Mr. Newton stated, according to a local NBC News affiliate.

He further expressed, "I'm a firm believer of justice. I'm a firm believer of doing the right thing."

Mr. Newton acknowledged his understanding of the frustrations in the black community due to what he referred to as "this state of oppression." However, he added, "We also, as black people, have to do right by ourselves. We can't be hypocrites."

Regarding the death of 43-year-old Keith Lamont Scott, who was fatally shot by police on Tuesday at an apartment complex in Charlotte, and the subsequent rioting, Mr. Newton stated, "My heart mourns for the family, but I just don't know enough info now."

Police reported that Mr. Scott had a gun in his possession at the time of his death, contradicting claims by his family that he was holding a book.

Mr. Newton remained mostly neutral during his comments, expressing concern over the number of police shootings in the U.S., which he described as "embarrassing." He also lamented the potential consequences of speaking out on race relations, stating that he could be critiqued for doing so or accused of being insincere if he remained silent.

Coach Ron Rivera supported Mr. Newton's comments, stating, "I think he's very thoughtful when he talks about this city and his feelings. He thinks before he speaks." Rivera added, "The best way to change things is to vote,'maybe instead of tearing up our city.'"

The article does not provide further details about the specific circumstances surrounding the police shooting or the protests that followed.

Title: Trump Accuses Clinton of Causing "Tremendous Death" in Middle East

Article:

Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump has introduced a new attack line against Hillary Clinton, stating that her decisions as Secretary of State during President Obama's first term led to unnecessary deaths in the Middle East. In an interview on CBS's "Face the Nation" on Sunday, Trump argued that Clinton's policies were responsible for the rise of the Islamic State and the subsequent "tremendous death and destruction" in the region.

Trump claimed that the removal of Saddam Hussein in Iraq, a policy initiated by President George W. Bush, has led to the rise of the Islamic State. He asserted that Clinton, as a key figure during Obama's term, shares responsibility for the current state of the Middle East.

In addition, Trump has been criticized for his call for a ban on Muslim immigration to the United States, with the terrorist group al-Shabaab using a clip of Trump in their call for Muslims to join jihad or leave the U.S. Trump defended his statements, stating, "What I have to say? There's a problem. We have to find out what is the problem. And we have to solve that problem."

In the interview, Trump also disagreed with President Obama on the need for more gun control, particularly if Obama were to move the issue by executive action rather than working with a recalcitrant Congress. Trump argued that mental health, not guns, is the root of the problem and suggested building institutions for the mentally ill.

Despite leading in national polls, Trump plans to spend approximately $2 million per week on advertising in the lead-up to the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. He commented, "I think I'm probably wasting the money, but I'm $35 million under budget... I almost feel guilty."

Title: House Approves Senate Compromise Bill to Avert Fiscal Cliff

Article:

The United States House of Representatives voted Tuesday night to approve a Senate bill aimed at averting a feared fiscal cliff. The measure, which maintains tax cuts for most Americans while increasing rates on the wealthy, passed the Democratic-led Senate overwhelmingly earlier in the day.

The legislation, which would raise approximately $600 billion in new revenues over a decade, according to various estimates, was subject to an up-or-down vote in the House, with no amendments added.

Representative Tom Cole (R-Oklahoma) told CNN before the House vote, "I'd say let's take the Senate deal, fight another day." He predicted the House would pass the bill with a "pretty strong bipartisan majority."

Representative Nan Hayworth, an outgoing Republican representative from New York, said, "This is the best we can do given the Senate and the White House sentiment at this point in time, and it is at least a partial victory for the American people." She added, "I'll take that at this point."

The timing of the vote was crucial, as a new Congress is set to be sworn in on Thursday. The legislation averted much of the fiscal cliff's negative near-term economic impact by extending the Bush-era tax cuts for the majority of Americans. It also extends long-term unemployment benefits that were set to expire.

Had the House not acted, and the tax cuts enacted last decade expired fully, broad tax increases would have kicked in, as would $110 billion in automatic cuts to domestic and military spending.

Title: Opinion Piece Highlights Concerns Over Illegal Immigration and its Impact on U.S. Safety

Article:

In an opinion piece published on ███.com, columnist Mollie Ziegler Hemingway expresses concerns over the impact of illegal immigration on American safety. The article, which does not represent the views of ███.com, argues that the Democratic Party is the "party of No Borders, Abolish ICE, and of murdered Americans."

The article references the murder of Mollie Tibbetts, an American college student, by an illegal immigrant, and suggests that this incident is indicative of a broader issue. The piece asserts that the Democratic Party's stance on immigration contributes to a body count of Americans due to uncontrolled illegal immigration.

The article argues that the Democratic Party's open borders policies enable illegal immigration, leading to increased crime and the loss of American lives. The piece also criticizes the Democratic Party for prioritizing uncontrolled immigration over the safety of American citizens.

The article concludes by urging readers to demand a change in the midterm elections, stating that a Democratic majority would continue the "bloodbath" of American lives lost to illegal immigration. The piece also calls for the construction of a wall to keep people and drugs out of the country.

It is important to note that the opinions expressed in this article are those of the columnist and do not represent the views of ███.com. The article does not provide any data or statistics to support its claims, and it is up to the reader to evaluate the validity of the arguments presented.

Title: Journalistic Integrity Under Scrutiny: Fact-Checking and the Consequences of Inaccurate Reporting

Article:

In the realm of modern journalism, the credibility of news stories is under scrutiny as several high-profile incidents of inaccurate reporting have come to light. One such instance is the Rolling Stone's story about an alleged rape at the University of Virginia, which has since been debunked due to a lack of evidence to substantiate the claim. The university has since imposed sanctions on the entire Greek system, including sororities, despite the absence of concrete evidence.

Another example of questionable reporting can be found in New York magazine, where a high school student from Queens claimed to have made $72 million trading stocks during his lunch breaks. The student, Mohammad Islam, admitted to fabricating the story, and the magazine is currently investigating the matter further.

A third instance of inaccurate reporting involves a story published in The New York Times, which claimed Pope Francis had stated that heaven is open to pets. The story was based on a misinterpretation of the pope's general audience at the Vatican and was later debunked as false.

R. Emmett Tyrrell Jr., founder and editor-in-chief of The American Spectator, has highlighted these incidents as examples of the importance of fact-checking in journalism. He emphasizes that double-checking is a fundamental rule in journalism, and its absence can lead to the publication of inaccurate and misleading stories.

These incidents serve as a reminder of the importance of fact-checking and the potential consequences of inaccurate reporting. As the public continues to rely on news sources for information, the need for journalistic integrity remains paramount.

Title: Obama Launches Gun Control Tour as Bloomberg Spends Millions on Ad Campaign

Article:

New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg is investing millions of dollars in a nationwide advertising campaign, while President Barack Obama is preparing for a tour focused on gun control, despite the failure of Senator Dianne Feinstein's latest gun control legislation last week. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has offered to present Feinstein's legislation as an amendment, but has no plans to bring the legislation as part of a larger gun control package to the Senate floor for a vote.

Bloomberg's pro-gun control group, Mayors Against Illegal Guns, is launching the campaign in states where senators may be undecided about a package of firearms proposals being considered by the Senate. As the push for that legislation seems to falter, President Obama plans to soon tour the country to discuss the need to reduce gun violence, a senior administration official confirmed to Fox News. Bloomberg also confirmed on Sunday that he plans to spend $12 million on ads in at least 10 states, suggesting there could be a political price to pay for opposing the measures.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) and its CEO, Wayne LaPierre, have responded to Bloomberg's campaign. LaPierre challenged Bloomberg's plan to spend $12 million on ads aimed at pressuring senators into supporting strict new gun control measures, stating, "He can't buy America."

Bloomberg, in response, made clear his intention to counter the NRA's influence, stating, "I want to make sure the powerful gun lobby is not the only voice in this debate." If he can achieve this, Bloomberg said, "then I think my money would be well spent."

LaPierre reiterated his stance on NBC's "Meet the Press," saying, "He can't spend enough of his $27 billion to try to impose his will on the American public." "He can't buy America," LaPierre added.

Meanwhile, the NRA reported its best fundraising totals in a decade. The specific details of the fundraising amounts are unavailable in the provided source text.

Title: Elite Writers and Academics Denounce Perceived Constriction of Speech, Sparking Controversy

Article:

A letter signed by several high-profile writers and academics, including figures from The New Yorker, The New York Times, Vox, The Washington Post, and this magazine, among others, has sparked controversy over allegations of silencing, particularly in relation to institutional racism. The letter, which has since seen at least two signatories distance themselves, and a counter-letter published by another group, expresses concern over the narrowing of free speech boundaries.

The signatories, who include well-known figures such as J.K. Rowling, Salman Rushdie, and Wynton Marsalis, as well as educators affiliated with universities like Harvard, Yale, Stanford, and Columbia, have been criticized for their perceived hypocrisy. The letter's focus on perceived censorship in the U.S., while journalists and intellectuals worldwide face more severe challenges, has been a point of contention.

The Committee to Protect Journalists estimates that at least 250 journalists were imprisoned worldwide last year for their reporting. In the U.S., the Trump administration continues to threaten reporters' safety and undermine the belief in the value of journalism in a democracy. The country is also experiencing an economic recession, impacting industries including journalism and academia.

The signatories' job losses, referenced in the letter, are not attributed to the pandemic or government pressure, but to actions criticized as potentially harming marginalized groups. This small group includes James Bennet, the former editor of the New York Times editorial page, who resigned after the op-ed page he supervised published an article by Arkansas Senator Tom Cotton that endorsed state violence.

Title: Wall Street Journal Staffers Accuse Editor of Suppressing Story Due to Political Bias

Article:

An anonymous email circulated by Wall Street Journal staffers on Thursday accused a senior editor, later identified as editor-in-chief Gerry Baker, of suppressing a story and accompanying graphics because they were too liberal. The story, published on Tuesday, examined the country's recovery from the 2008 financial crisis and included information on how economic inequality had increased.

The email urged staffers to begin tweeting the graphics-heavy story at noon, which many did. A Journal spokesman denied that the editor had suppressed the story, stating that the piece was first published on Tuesday and had been online ever since, with additional reporting and analysis to be added.

One person familiar with the matter told the media outlet that there was a miscommunication, and that Baker had not seen the final version of the story and graphics before they were published. The person disputed the idea that Baker wanted to suppress the story, saying that he wanted to "put it to the side" and then resurface it in a more prominent position on the Journal's website once more information was added.

Baker reportedly wanted something "more exhaustive," with more "macro-economic context," according to the source, including "a lot more on the markets." Without that information, he felt that the piece was "tilting in one direction" and making it too liberal. A second Wall Street Journal newsroom employee confirmed that Baker was unhappy with the initial version and requested the additional information so that the piece could later be re-launched.

Baker has faced criticism in the past for softening coverage of President Donald Trump. He has denied the criticisms, but claimed that other outlets had been too one-sided in their coverage of the 2016 election. The financial crisis piece published on Thursday, which was reported by Cezary Podkul, examines what has and hasn't changed over the past decade through text, graphs, and images.

The accusations regarding the proposed changes were made in an anonymously written email sent to colleagues under the name "Barney Kilgore," a reference to the late Journal managing editor who helped transform the paper more than a half-century ago. The email stated, "This week a senior editor at the Wall Street Journal attempted to take a graphic offline because the facts it contained were not politically palatable." The anonymous author proposed "resurfacing" the graphics piece on social media, including blasting it out at noon on Twitter.

Title: House Democrats Launch "Chaos" Campaign Aimed at GOP Over Budget Impasse

Article:

House Democrats are pursuing a campaign strategy centered around the theme of "chaos" in an attempt to sway voters' opinions in the 2014 midterm elections, according to The Hill. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) aims to portray the Republican Party as more focused on ideological disputes than on avoiding a government shutdown and safeguarding the nation's credit.

DCCC Chairman Steve Israel told The Hill, "Americans are fed up with House Republicans' gridlock and obstruction — but most importantly, they're frustrated with the lack of progress on issues that matter, like working together to create good jobs, protecting Medicare, and reducing our deficit in a balanced way."

The party's primary focus is on the stance of some conservatives who are pushing for a government shutdown over their call to defund the Affordable Care Act, particularly in the House where approximately 80 GOP members seem determined to defy their leadership and obstruct the implementation of the Affordable Care Act. Israel stated, "House Republicans are threatening shutdowns and economic crises if they do not get their way in partisan ideological battles — and that will be their downfall in 2014."

Republicans, however, believe the strategy will be ineffective, arguing that the public holds all lawmakers accountable for the gridlock in Washington. They also contend that a similar narrative failed in 2011 during the debt ceiling debate. National Republican Congressional Committee spokesman Dan Scarpinato told The Hill, "It sounds to me [what] House Democrats are saying more and more is they're actually rooting for a government shutdown so they can score political points. That's the lowest of the low."

Scarpinato added, "The longer House Democrats refuse to be part of the solution to stopping Obamacare and reducing our debt, the more voters are going to reject putting [California Rep. Nancy] Pelosi back in the speaker's chair."

To regain the majority in 2014, Democrats would need to pick up 17 seats, a challenging goal for a midterm election, according to The Hill.

Title: Alabama Senate Passes Near-Total Abortion Ban, Sending Bill to Governor's Desk

Article:

Alabama's Senate passed a bill on Tuesday night that could impose life imprisonment on doctors who perform abortions, marking one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the United States. The legislation, known as HB 314, amounts to a near-total ban on abortion in the state and is aimed at overturning the landmark Supreme Court case, Roe v. Wade, which legalized abortion.

The Republican-led Senate voted 25-6 to pass the bill, which would penalize doctors with up to 99 years in prison for performing an abortion. The Alabama House passed the bill earlier this month. The law only allows exceptions to avoid a serious health risk to the unborn child's mother, for ectopic pregnancy, and if the "unborn child has a lethal anomaly."

Democrats attempted to amend the bill to exempt rape and incest victims, but the motion failed on an 11-21 vote. The bill's consideration made frequent reference to the chamber's dramatic vote last week to drop an amendment that would have made exemptions to abortions performed for instances of rape or incest.

Republican Governor Kay Ivey, who has previously aligned herself as anti-abortion, has not publicly taken a stance on the bill but has six days to sign the legislation. If signed, the bill would not take effect until six months after becoming law. The American Civil Rights Union of Alabama, the national ACLU, Planned Parenthood, and Planned Parenthood of Southeast have announced their intention to challenge the bill in court should it become law.

The bill's sponsor, Republican State Sen. Clyde Chambliss, emphasized that the bill impacts women who are "known to be pregnant" and provides "every female that's pregnant or thinks they're pregnant, and the male who was involved, it gives them that window of time -- this bill does not change that window of time." The bill outlaws surgical abortions as soon as a pregnancy can be medically determined.

In a news release, Chambliss stated that his bill outlaws surgical abortions as soon as a pregnancy can be medically determined. Speaking on the Senate floor, Chambliss repeatedly referred to a "window" of time between conception and when a woman knows for certain that she's pregnant. The state senator said he believed that time was between about seven and 10 days.

The bill's consideration sparked heated debates, with Democratic state Sen. Rodger Smitherman questioning what would happen under the bill to a young girl who was a victim of incest and found out she was pregnant. Chambliss responded by stating that he hoped the bill would result in young women learning to seek help quickly if they are abused.

For more on reproductive rights, tune in to "United Shades of America" on Sunday at 10 p.m. ET/PT, where W. Kamau Bell explores the divisive world of reproductive rights and reproductive justice in Jackson, Mississippi.

Title: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Renames Eskimo Pie, Joins Brands Reevaluating Racially Charged Logos

Article:

In a statement, the owner of the century-old Eskimo Pie ice cream bar, Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream, announced changes to the brand's name and marketing. The decision comes as part of a larger review to ensure the company's brands align with their values on racial equality.

The Eskimo Pie treat was patented by Christian Kent Nelson and Russell C. Stover in 1922, according to Smithsonian Magazine. The brand is the latest to reconsider its marketing in response to the Black Lives Matter protests following the death of George Floyd.

Quaker Oats announced earlier this week that it will retire the Aunt Jemima brand, acknowledging the character's origins as a racial stereotype. Other companies are also reviewing their names or logos, including Geechie Boy Mill, which is considering changes to its branding. Mars Inc. and B&G Foods Inc. are reviewing their Uncle Ben's rice brand and Cream of Wheat packaging, respectively.

Chicago-based Conagra Brands, which makes Mrs. Butterworth's syrup, stated that its bottles, which are shaped like a matronly woman, are intended to evoke a "loving grandmother." However, the company acknowledged that the packaging could be misinterpreted, with critics claiming the bottle's design is rooted in the "mammy" stereotype.

The reevaluation of these brands' names and logos reflects a growing awareness and commitment to racial equality in marketing practices. The specific changes to be made by each company are yet to be announced.

Title: Trump Suggests Rogue Killers, Not Saudi Officials, in Khashoggi Disappearance

Article:

President Donald Trump has suggested that rogue killers, not Saudi officials, may be responsible for the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, a U.S.-based journalist whose disappearance has sparked an international outcry.

During a press briefing at the White House on Monday, Trump stated, "Rogue killers," and not Saudi officials, may have been involved in Khashoggi's disappearance. The president cited no specific evidence, but noted he had just spoken with Saudi King Salman, who denied that Riyadh was involved.

"I don’t want to get into his mind, but it sounded to me like maybe these could have been rogue killers. Who knows?" Trump said.

The president said King Salman's denial "was very, very strong" and it did not seem as if "there was a question" in the king's mind about his claim that Saudi Arabia was not involved.

"We’re going to try to get to the bottom of it very soon, but his was a flat denial," said Trump.

Turkish officials have stated they believe Khashoggi was killed and dismembered inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on orders from the Saudi government. The journalist, who wrote for The Washington Post and resided in Virginia, visited the consulate on Oct. 2 to get paperwork necessary for his marriage and has not been seen since.

There have been reports of 15 Saudi agents entering Turkey before Khashoggi arrived at the consulate and leaving the country following the journalist's disappearance.

Trump's comments could spur further controversy surrounding the journalist's apparent death. The incident has sparked a major diplomatic crisis between the U.S. and Saudi Arabia, with lawmakers pressuring Trump to take swift action to punish Riyadh.

Trump on Monday dispatched Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to meet with King Salman. The president has previously threatened to impose penalties on Saudi Arabia if it is found to have been responsible for Khashoggi's disappearance, but he said on Monday that he did not raise the issue with King Salman.

"We didn’t talk about that. We didn’t talk about that. I did say this is very important. The world is watching, the world is talking. This is very important to get to the bottom of it. I think he understands that very well," Trump said.

There was speculation before Trump spoke that Saudi Arabia, which has faced growing pressure over Khashoggi's disappearance, might seek to blame rogue agents, a sign the president could have been repeating something King Salman said.

Trump earlier this year repeated Russian President Vladimir Putin's denials that Moscow interfered in the 2016 presidential election. "I have great confidence in my intelligence people, but I will tell you that President Putin was extremely strong and powerful in his denial today," Trump said during a press conference with the Russian leader after their July meeting in Helsinki.

Trump has also suggested that others might have been responsible for hacking the Democratic National Committee during the campaign, an attack the U.S. intelligence community has unanimously blamed on Russia. Trump appeared to have arrived at that conclusion on his own and not from a conversation with Putin.

"I don't think anybody knows it was Russia that broke into the DNC," he said during a September 2016 debate with his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. "It could be Russia, but it could also be China. Could also be lots of other people. It could also be somebody sitting on their bed who weighs 400 pounds, OK?"

Title: Trump Administration Seeks Supreme Court's Approval for Revised Travel Ban

Article:

The Trump administration has requested the Supreme Court to allow the implementation of the revised travel ban, which was previously blocked by two lower court rulings. The administration filed two emergency applications with the nine justices, challenging the decision made by the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia.

In the filing, the Justice Department argued that the appeals court in Richmond made several errors in ruling against President Trump's travel order. Sarah Isgur Flores, a Justice Department spokeswoman, stated that the ban is lawful. The Justice Department believes that President Trump's executive order is within his lawful authority to ensure national security and protect the United States from terrorism.

The order, issued in March, bars entry for people from six Muslim majority nations, including Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen, for 90 days while the U.S. implements stricter visa screenings. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals had previously called the national security concerns an after-the-fact justification for a policy that was "intended to bar Muslims from this country."

Rights groups fighting the policy in the courts have expressed opposition to the travel and refugee bans taking effect. Karen Tumlin, legal director of the National Immigration Law Center, stated, "Again and again, our nation's courts have found that President Trump's Muslim ban is unconstitutional. We will continue to defend our plaintiffs' right to live free from fear of discriminatory treatment by the federal government."

Trump signed his first executive order on travel a week after he took office in January. It applied to travelers from the six countries, as well as Iraq, and took effect immediately, causing chaos and panic at airports as the Homeland Security Department struggled to determine who the order covered and how it was to be implemented. A federal judge blocked it eight days later, an order that was upheld by a 9th Circuit panel. Rather than pursue an appeal, the administration chose to revise the policy.

Title: Senate Proposes Comprehensive Immigration Bill with Merit-Based Green Card Program and Guest Worker Programs

Article:

A bipartisan group of senators has introduced a comprehensive immigration bill that, if passed, will introduce a merit-based program for awarding green cards to legal permanent residents. The merit system, set to take effect five years after the bill's passage, will allow at least 120,000 foreign-born individuals annually to obtain green cards based on their skills, education, family ties, and length of residence in the United States.

Over a decade, the bill aims to gradually shift the immigration system's focus from the current 75% of visas allocated to family members of immigrants already residing in the U.S. The proposed legislation anticipates that approximately 50% of visas will be distributed based on family ties, while the remaining half will be allocated based on job skills.

The bill includes border security measures, such as requiring all employers to verify the legal status of new hires using a federal photo-matching system within five years. Additionally, the federal government will be mandated to establish an electronic system within ten years for checking foreigners as they depart through airports and seaports.

The bill also introduces two new guest-worker programs, one for farmworkers and another for low-wage laborers. Furthermore, it provides employers in technology and science fields with tens of thousands of new temporary and permanent resident visas annually for computer engineers and foreign graduates with advanced degrees from American universities. The current annual caps on temporary high-skilled visas (H-1B) will increase from 65,000 to 110,000, with an additional 5,000 visas for foreign graduates. The cap will gradually rise to 180,000.

The bill also allows young illegal immigrants who arrived in the U.S. as children, often referred to as Dreamers, to become citizens after five years.

The senators behind the bill hope it will address enough longstanding issues to garner support from a diverse range of groups, including Latinos, religious groups, labor unions, big technology companies, agricultural growers, and immigrant families seeking faster reunification with legal family members.

Title: Skepticism Surrounding Jussie Smollett's Alleged Hate Crime Incident

Article:

The alleged hate crime incident involving actor Jussie Smollett, best known for his role in the television show 'Empire,' has been met with skepticism by many outsiders, as the details surrounding the incident have raised questions about its authenticity.

On January 29, the New York Times reported that Smollett was attacked in Chicago by two assailants who hurled racial and homophobic slurs. The tone of the report, and many others like it, conveyed an absolute certainty about an unconfirmed claim. News outlets such as ABC News, Los Angeles Times, and GQ, among others, reported on the incident with similar certainty.

However, the strange circumstances surrounding Smollett's claims have led some to question the veracity of the attack. Chicago's ABC7 News reported this week that "multiple sources," presumably within the Chicago Police Department, had labeled the alleged attack as "staged" by Smollett and two accomplices. CBS2 News and the Chicago Tribune made similar reports. A spokesman for the CPD quickly stated that the sources cited were "uninformed and inaccurate."

The certainty with which the initial reports were made stands in stark contrast to the Times' usual cautious approach to publishing unconfirmed information. The Times would have been on firmer ground if it had simply added six letters - "says he" - between the words "Empire" and "was attacked."

The incident has sparked strong reactions from politicians, with Cory Booker, Joe Biden, and Kamala Harris, among others, expressing their support for Smollett and condemning the alleged attack. However, some on the political left have expressed doubt about the incident, with some arguing that the publicity surrounding the case may overshadow other, more significant instances of hate crimes.

The case of Matthew Shepard, a 21-year-old student who was tortured and killed in Laramie, Wyoming, is often cited as an example of rampant hate crimes against the LGBTQ+ community. However, Shepard's case occurred 21 years ago, and some question whether he was killed because of his sexuality. The FBI has logged 7,000 hate crimes in the entire country in the supposed nightmare first year of the Trump administration, with an incidence rate of 0.00002 percent.

Some have suggested that all self-reported hate crimes should be presumed hoaxes, while others argue that reported hate crimes with a "perfectly crafted narrative" should be regarded with skepticism until proven true. The media tend to lose interest in hate-crime hoaxes once they are unmasked, but there are many instances of such hoaxes, as can be seen on fakehatecrimes.org.

Journalists and politicians whose priors align with those of activists should be especially cautious about taking at face value claims that seem wobbly, for the good of their own reputations. But it's not just as a journalist that I doubted Smollett's version of events. I doubted it as an American. I decline to look at Chicago (or Kentucky, or Oklahoma, or anywhere else) and put much credence in the idea that vicious Trump-supporting attackers are roaming around looking for minorities to assault.

Title: Trump's Remarks on Sweden Spark Controversy and Fact-Checking by Librarian Emma Johansson

Article:

In a recent rally in Florida, former President Donald Trump discussed his controversial immigration ban, which was halted by federal judges, as well as terror attacks in Europe. The speech, which was lengthy, drew attention for Trump's comments on terrorism in Brussels, Nice, and Paris, cities that have experienced terror attacks in recent months. However, it was his remarks about terrorism in Sweden that caused confusion.

Trump stated, "You look at what's happening in Germany, you look at what's happening last night in Sweden – Sweden – who would believe this? Sweden? They took in large numbers, they're having problems like they never thought possible."

In response to Trump's comments, hundreds of messages were sent to the Sweden Twitter account, currently managed by Swede Emma Johansson, also known as 'kseenaa.' Johansson, who is participating in the project Curators of Sweden, a 2011 initiative from the Swedish Institute and Visit Sweden, was tasked with correcting the US president's misinformation.

Contrary to Trump's claims, all the news in Sweden has been about a music competition, and there have been no terror attacks to speak of. Johansson's fact-checking efforts have since gone viral, with many praising her for her role in setting the record straight.

It is unclear what specific information Trump was referring to, as the White House has yet to issue a clarifying statement. Some speculate that Trump may have been referring to a Tucker Carlson segment about Sweden on Fox News.

Interestingly, the woman who is gaining attention for fact-checking the US president is a librarian.

Title: Call to Address China's Economic and Intellectual Property Abuses in the Global Trade Arena

Article:

The United States has called for action against the People's Republic of China's economic and intellectual property abuses, citing decades of exploitation of American enterprise and the current global health crisis as evidence of China's relentless and pernicious economic adversarialism.

The article highlights China's delayed response to the COVID-19 outbreak, with the World Health Organization (WHO) failing to publish information about the human-to-human transmission risk of the virus until December 31, despite intelligence services briefing the U.S. president on the threat on January 3 and multiple subsequent briefings throughout January and February.

The article also points to China's control of critical products and components in America's supply chains, accounting for 95% of ibuprofen, 91% of hydrocortisone, and 80% of all antibiotics. This dependence on Chinese medicine has reportedly crippled the U.S.'s ability to fight COVID-19 and various illnesses.

Furthermore, the article discusses China's exploitation of intellectual property, leading to the introduction of the SHEET Act to prevent countries such as China from stealing technology and intelligence from educational foreign-exchange programs.

The article argues that China has been abusive towards American companies since joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2001, causing supply-chain disruptions for three-quarters of American companies. China's manipulation extends beyond supply-chains, as seen in incidents where companies such as Marriott and Delta changed their maps to appease China's authoritarian regime.

To counter China's outsized influence, the article suggests creating new supply chains and reinforcing existing ones with U.S. allies in Asia, the Western Hemisphere, and Europe. Policymakers should create new incentives for businesses to reorient supply chains away from China and disincentives for companies to invest there, such as a "sovereignty tax" on American investment in China.

As the pandemic abates, the U.S. and its allies should openly call out China's abuses and work towards ending China's exploitation through a partnership with American, European, and Asian businesses and governments. The article argues that incurring higher costs to be strategically secure is worthwhile.

Title: Jon Stewart Urges Mitch McConnell to Expedite 9/11 Victims Compensation Fund Reauthorization

Article:

Jon Stewart, the former host of the "Daily Show," has called on Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) to expedite the reauthorization of the 9/11 Victims Compensation Fund. The fund, established after the September 11 terrorist attacks to aid victims and their families with medical and economic losses, is running out of money and requires reauthorization to continue its operations.

During a segment on "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert" on Monday, Stewart criticized McConnell's comments made in a Fox News interview, where McConnell stated, "Many things in Congress happen at the last minute... we will address it again. I don't know why he's all bent out of shape." McConnell's comment was in response to Stewart's advocacy for the fund's reauthorization.

In the segment, Stewart addressed McConnell directly, stating, "Senator, you're not good at this argument thing. Basically, we're saying you love the 9/11 community when they serve your political purposes, but when they're in urgent need, you slow-walk, you dither. You used it as a political pawn to get other things you want, and you don't get the job done completely, and your answer to that charge is, 'Yeah, duh, we're Congress. That's how we do.'"

Stewart urged McConnell to meet with the 9/11 community "tomorrow as soon as possible," stating, "You can pass this thing as a standalone bill tomorrow. Meet with them. I'm begging you." The reauthorization bill, which currently has 320 bipartisan House cosponsors, is expected to pass the House. However, it is unclear if it will pass the Republican-controlled Senate. Previous renewal attempts faced opposition from Senate Republicans who objected to the price tag of reauthorization legislation.

The House Judiciary Committee passed the bill on June 12, and it now goes to consideration by the full House. The bill's progress in the Senate remains uncertain.

Title: Cokie Roberts on Norquist: "The Emperor Has No Clothes"

Article:

In a recent discussion, journalist Cokie Roberts addressed the political implications of adhering to the anti-tax pledge of Grover Norquist, a conservative political activist.

Roberts stated that the association of Republicans with Norquist's pledge could potentially harm their political standing, particularly in the context of tax rate increases. She suggested that if Republicans were heavily involved in a deal that resulted in increased spending and taxes, it could negatively impact a potential re-election bid, as it did for former President George H.W. Bush in 1992.

However, Roberts noted that if Republicans cooperate with the president to make 80% of the Bush tax cuts permanent for 98% of the American people, they could still engage in further discussions about higher rates and revenue generation. She considered this a superior position politically and a more advantageous way to shape the discussion.

Roberts also mentioned the concern among some Republicans about the potential political fallout if the fiscal cliff is crossed, a situation they believe would result in blame being placed on them. She also referenced a point made by Tom, suggesting that it is politically smart to cut the ground out from under Norquist, who is seen as a powerful figure in conservative politics.

Roberts further commented on the notion that Democrats, who have recently elected a democratic president, would need to make the vast majority of Bush's tax cuts permanent. She found it surprising that these tax cuts, which were not just rate cuts but cuts across the board, could be made permanent, given their demonization by the Democrats.

Roberts concluded by questioning whether Republicans should take a victory lap for achieving the permanence of most of the Bush tax cuts, even though she expressed skepticism about the political wisdom of raising taxes. She also suggested that undermining Norquist, who is seen as having no political clothes, could be a politically smart move.

Title: Paul Ryan Affirms Plans for Another Term as Speaker of the House, Expresses Support for Donald Trump

Article:

In a recent interview on Green Bay, Wisconsin's WTAQ-AM, Speaker of the House Paul Ryan confirmed his intention to seek another term as speaker, despite speculation that he may step down after the upcoming elections. The speculation, reported in The Hill, suggested that Ryan faces a challenging path to secure the 218 votes necessary for a full two-year term as House GOP leader.

During the interview, host Jerry Bader asked Ryan, "Can you say with 100 percent certainly you seek another term as speaker?" Ryan, who was calling in from a bus tour of Wisconsin, responded, "Yes, I can. This is the typical chatter you have every two years that they call 'palace intrigue' in the Hill rags. I am going to seek staying on as speaker."

Ryan expressed pride in his "Better Way" agenda and stated his intention to execute this agenda in the next session of Congress. "There is a lot of unfinished work to do. I think I can do a lot to help our cause, our party," he said.

Ryan also revealed plans to be on a bus tour with Sen. Ron Johnson throughout the state and to rally with Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, the GOP nominee for vice president, in Mukwonago, Wisconsin, on Saturday.

Regarding the upcoming elections, Ryan expressed his support for the Republican ticket, stating, "Just imagine the scandal baggage Hillary Clinton brings in–if she were to get elected–on top of the liberal-Obama agenda she wants to prosecute." He also expressed regret that young people do not remember the challenges the Clinton administration posed in the 1990s, stating, "This is what life with the Clinton's looks like–there is always a scandal around the corner–then, there is some kind of investigation–you never know what's coming next."

Ryan further commented on the Clinton family, stating, "They play the system to enrich themselves through what everyone calls: 'Clinton Incorporated.'"

Title: Trump Announces Executive Action on Police Reform, Aims to Leverage Federal Funds for Training and Certification

Article:

Administration officials have revealed that President Trump's approach to police reform will involve utilizing federal grant money to incentivize local departments to enhance training and certification around a set of national "best practices." Departments that prioritize such goals will be given priority for grant funding, with one senior administration official stating, "You don't necessarily have to demonize them or withdraw funds."

At the White House on Monday, Trump emphasized the need for "law and order" and "justice," stating, "It's about law and order, but it's about justice also." The executive action is the result of months of deliberation by a policing commission established by Trump in late December, before the death of George Floyd, which sparked nationwide protests.

Trump intends to call on Congress to pass legislative reforms on Tuesday, but feels compelled to act to "turn the anger in the country now into action and hopefully bring some unification and some healing." However, Trump's rhetoric in the aftermath of Floyd's death has contributed to deep divisions in the nation, with his emphasis on "law and order" and portrayal of many protesters as violent.

On Monday, Trump called the death of Rayshard Brooks, who was shot and killed by police in Atlanta, "very disturbing" and a "terrible situation." Brooks' killing has led to new protests in Atlanta. Trump has criticized Seattle Mayor Jenny Durkan and Washington Governor Jay Inslee for their handling of protests in Seattle, where protesters have taken over several city blocks.

Trump has discussed the situation with Attorney General William P. Barr, but declined to specify any potential steps his administration might take. The pending executive action will be announced at a news conference, where Trump is expected to be joined by law enforcement officials and family members of people killed by police.

Republican congressional leaders signaled on Monday that legislative reforms to overhaul police practices could slip beyond this month. The Senate GOP package, being primarily drafted by Sen. Tim Scott (R-S.C.), is expected to be released later this week. The package is expected to discourage the use of chokeholds by withholding federal funds to police agencies that allow them, but is not expected to explicitly ban the practice.

Sen. Scott, the Senate's lone black Republican, said it would be a "bad decision" to wait until next month to deliberate on a legislative package. The House Democrats' plan also includes establishing a national database to track police misconduct and prohibiting certain no-knock warrants. The House Judiciary Committee will meet Wednesday to work on the bill.

Trump aides emphasized that the president remains opposed to any legislation that would end qualified immunity for police officers. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) stated Monday afternoon on the Senate floor that the Senate GOP is developing a "serious proposal to reform law enforcement in smart ways without lashing out needlessly and counterproductively at the first responders who are a credit to their communities."

The Senate Judiciary Committee has scheduled a hearing Tuesday afternoon with law enforcement, legal experts, and government officials. Administration officials did not specify how much federal money could be tied to police training reforms, and they suggested it could be up to Congress to provide additional funding to help create new programs that Trump will outline on Tuesday. Among these programs is a "co-responder program" that would pair local police with mental health experts to respond more holistically to reports of crime in communities and in dealing with suspects.

When asked how the president envisioned getting around potential objections from police unions, the first administration official acknowledged the executive action would hinge on cooperation from mayors and other local officials. "The federal government can only do so much," the official said.

In a statement, the National Fraternal Order of Police said it had reviewed a draft of Trump's executive action and found that it "strikes a great balance between the vital need for public and officer safety, and the equally vital need for lasting, meaningful, and enforceable police reform."

Title: Trump, Xi Discuss North Korea Nuclear Threat and Trade at G20 Summit

Article:

In a significant meeting on Saturday at the G20 summit in Hamburg, Germany, President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping discussed the growing North Korea nuclear threat and trade relations between the two nations. The meeting, which was one of several high-level discussions Trump and his administration had with world leaders, was considered critical due to China's role as North Korea's largest trading partner.

Trump referred to China as a "great trading partner" and stated that resolving the North Korea nuclear missile threat may take longer than desired but will ultimately be successful "one way or the other." Xi also spoke briefly, but his comments were not immediately translated and made available.

The meeting focused on trade and North Korea's nuclear missile testing. Trump expressed concerns about trade imbalances between the United States and China, stating, "Many things have happened that have created trade imbalances, but we’re going to turn that around."

The meeting was attended by about a dozen top administration officials, including Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and adviser Jared Kushner. The meeting followed a long-range missile test launch by North Korea on Tuesday, which a Pentagon spokesman described as a type not previously seen by U.S. analysts.

Following the missile launch, Trump expressed frustration with China over its expanding trade with North Korea. He tweeted, "Trade between China and North Korea grew almost 40% in the first quarter. So much for China working with us - but we had to give it a try!"

China has historically resisted intensifying economic pressure on North Korea due to concerns about instability and potential influx of North Korean refugees. Tillerson, on Tuesday, vowed "stronger measures" to hold North Korea accountable and stated that any country aiding North Korea militarily, economically, or taking in its guest workers is "aid[ing] and abet[ing] a dangerous regime." Tillerson also emphasized the need for global action to address the North Korea threat.

Title: Understanding the President's Daily Brief and Its Importance

Article:

The President's Daily Brief (PDB) is a concise, daily intelligence briefing presented to the U.S. President and a select group of top officials. This briefing has been a tradition at the White House for over 50 years, with the winner of the presidential election receiving the same briefing during their transition period to prepare for the challenges they will face in office.

However, the current President, Donald Trump, has deviated from this tradition by declining to receive the PDB most days, making it more of a weekly occurrence rather than a daily one. Trump's reasons for not receiving the briefing were stated in a recent interview, where he expressed that he does not need to be told the same information daily and that he is a "smart person."

The PDB, also known as the President and White House staff as the PIC, is considered the most tightly controlled daily document in the world. It originated during the early days of John F. Kennedy's presidency, when the Central Intelligence Agency felt the need for a more organized way to keep the president updated on potential crises and hot spots around the globe.

The PDB's content is carefully controlled, and the president determines who gets to see it. The circle of individuals who receive the briefing varies between administrations, but it remains a highly exclusive group. The briefing is presented in either a personal or briefing-book format, depending on the president's preference.

U.S. intelligence veteran Barry Pavel, who served in the past two administrations, emphasized the critical nature of the PDB. He stated that the briefing is a "critical start to their day, where they have this exchange on these critical issues" and that it "gets them thinking about what's going to happen that day, that month, or that year."

Pavel expressed concern about Trump's decision to skip the briefing, stating that a new briefer or approach may be necessary to present the information in a way that works for Trump. He also highlighted the importance of these regular sessions during the presidential transition period, as it helps the president-elect get up to speed on the state of the world and establish a good relationship and rapport with intelligence officials.

In conclusion, the President's Daily Brief is a critical document that provides the U.S. President with a daily update on potential crises and hot spots around the globe. The briefing is a tradition that has been in place for over 50 years, and while the current President, Donald Trump, has chosen to deviate from this tradition, the importance of the briefing during the presidential transition period and in the White House remains significant.

Title: FCC Shuts Down Austin's Liberty Radio, Known for Alex Jones Broadcasts, Faces $15,000 Fine

Article:

The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has taken action against pirate radio station Liberty Radio, known for its broadcasts of conspiracy theorist Alex Jones. According to The Austin American-Statesman, the station was fined $15,000 and temporarily removed from the airwaves due to unlicensed broadcasts since at least 2013.

The newspaper reported that the lawsuit, filed in federal court in Austin, alleged that Liberty Radio, also known as LRN.FM, was transmitting from a tower at an Austin apartment complex without a license. The station stopped airing on the radio in December but continues to stream online.

The FCC is charging that the station was also illegally broadcasting on an FM wavelength. The Associated Press reported that Walter Olenick and M. Rae Nadler-Olenick were named as the defendants in the lawsuit, and the apartment complex from which the station was transmitting is linked to them.

The Olenicks reportedly told the FCC that they would not pay the fine and would consider any agency representatives as trespassers. Media reports, including the local Statesman, described the station as Jones's "flagship" outlet; NPR reported Thursday that it had picked up the nickname "Alex Jones Radio" over the years. The station does air rebroadcasts of "The Alex Jones Show."

However, station host Danny Sessom wrote in a Facebook post late Wednesday that media reports describing the station as Jones's "flagship" are "actual fake news," noting that Jones did not broadcast from the station.

Jones, a conspiracy theorist who founded the site Infowars, has recently been banned by several platforms, including Facebook and YouTube, for allegedly violating their terms of service. Infowars and Jones's content have also been pulled from Spotify and Vimeo, and Twitter placed restrictions on their accounts. Jones has been forcefully criticized for some of the conspiracy theories he promotes. The parents of children killed in the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting have sued him for saying the massacre was staged and a cover-up was orchestrated by the parents of the children.

Title: Lawmakers Race Against Time to Avert Fiscal Crisis as Deadline Looms

Article:

The United States Congress is under pressure to avert more than $600 billion in tax hikes and spending cuts, which are set to take effect in less than a week. The predicament is a result of lawmakers' failure to act sooner.

As the New Year approaches, all sides are expressing hope that the impending January 1 deadline will finally yield an agreement on the looming fiscal crisis. President Obama is expected to return to Washington from his Hawaii vacation on Thursday.

Officials have reported a "unanimous desire" on Capitol Hill, with a few exceptions, to avert the potential catastrophe of income tax hikes, investment tax hikes, defense cuts, and a halt in long-term unemployment aid all at once. However, few are providing specific details on how this might be achieved.

Over the long holiday weekend, there seemed to be little activity on the fiscal crisis front. House Speaker John Boehner's spokesperson confirmed that the president and the speaker did not speak over the weekend. Representatives for the Republican and Democratic Senate leaders also reported "nothing" on Monday.

Given the short timeframe, it is challenging to write and pass a comprehensive budget bill, let alone do so without a clear roadmap.

The options for averting the crisis diminished last week when Boehner abruptly withdrew his "Plan B" proposal from the floor, citing a lack of Republican support. This bill, though fiercely opposed by Democrats, would have extended current tax rates for all but those earning over $1 million.

The move also effectively halted negotiations between Boehner and Obama toward a broader compromise agreement.

Obama's aides and lawmakers are now discussing a scaled-down package as the most likely solution, something that could at least prevent most of the scheduled tax hikes and possibly extend jobless aid. Lawmakers could then resume the debate early next year over the most contentious issues of entitlement cuts and tax reform.

Democrats and Republicans still need to decide who, if anyone, would see a tax hike next year. Lawmakers also need a bill to work from. The administration official suggested there was more contact in recent days between White House staff and Senate Democratic leadership staff, indicating that new legislation, if proposed, could come from the Senate side.

Boehner, in announcing late last week that he did not have the votes to pass Plan B, called on the Senate to take action. "At some point, the United States Senate has to do something," Boehner said. "What we were trying to do this week was to basically jumpstart and try to kick into gear some action by the Senate to avert these tax increases going into effect January 1."

Congress has been in the position of having to craft an 11th-hour deal on numerous occasions, most recently over the vote to raise the debt ceiling but also on countless budget bills and tax cut extension packages.

The senior administration official stated that the mounting pressure this week should "animate" all sides to come together on a deal.

If Washington fails to act, however, Americans are facing a historic blow. The rollback of the Bush-era tax rates is estimated to cost the typical middle-income family over $2,000 a year. Another expiring tax provision could cost thousands more. Investment taxes and the estate tax are also scheduled to rise. The automatic budget cuts could impact defense contractors and other businesses that rely on government spending.

The Congressional Budget Office has predicted a double-dip recession if the stalemate persists well into 2013.

Title: White House Faces Controversy as Leaked Conversations with Foreign Leaders Emerge

Article:

A series of leaked conversations between President Donald Trump and foreign leaders have caused a stir, with the information being provided to The Washington Post and The Associated Press in an apparent attempt to embarrass the president. The leaks, which involve the closely guarded secrets of government, have raised questions about the president's ability to maintain confidential conversations with world leaders.

The leaks, which have been described as an attempt by the bureaucracy to damage Trump, portray him as a disruptive force on the international stage. The specifics of the leaked conversations, including tone and context, are not fully known.

The leaks have been met with criticism from both sides of the political spectrum, with some arguing that the leaks are an attempt to undermine the president, while others see them as a means of shedding light on the president's diplomatic dealings.

One of the leaked conversations involved a call between Trump and Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, during which Trump reportedly criticized a refugee agreement and accused Australia of seeking to export potential terrorists. The call was abruptly ended after 25 minutes.

Another leaked conversation involved a call between Trump and Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, during which Trump reportedly threatened to send U.S. troops to Mexico unless the Mexican military took action to control "bad hombres."

The leaks have sparked a flurry of activity from White House officials, who have attempted to provide context for the conversations. For example, one source told CNN that Trump was fatigued during the call with Turnbull, while the AP quoted a White House official as saying Trump's remarks about sending troops to Mexico were "lighthearted."

The leaks have also raised questions about the president's diplomatic style, with some arguing that Trump's blunt and confrontational approach is not conducive to effective diplomacy.

In addition to the leaks, the White House has also faced criticism over its handling of the raid in Yemen, which resulted in the death of a Navy SEAL. U.S. military officials have reportedly criticized the decision to approve the raid without sufficient intelligence, ground support, or backup preparations.

The leaks and the Yemen raid have raised concerns about the level of hostility within the government towards the new president, and the challenges that the White House may face in maintaining loyalty among its troops. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis will likely play a key role in instilling a sense of loyalty among their respective departments.

Title: Pilgrims and Puritans: Founding of Plymouth and Massachusetts Bay Colonies

Article:

On November 21, 1620, a group of English settlers, known as the Pilgrims, landed on Cape Cod, Massachusetts, in a vessel named the Mayflower. The journey from Europe had been arduous, with the ship being a wine carrier poorly converted for passenger use, and the 102 passengers and crew enduring 66 days of harsh conditions.

The Pilgrims, who were religious separatists, faced challenges not only from the harsh New World environment but also from the other passengers, who were primarily motivated by the pursuit of wealth. This group, later derisively referred to as "the Saints," had established a rudimentary form of government during the voyage, but there was discord over the details.

Upon reaching their destination, which they named Plymouth, the Pilgrims gave thanks for their arrival, a year before the formal observance of Thanksgiving. The ensuing weeks, months, and years saw the initial adversity of living on the Mayflower and in caves and shoddy wooden shacks evolve into a religious community fortified by a strong private enterprise economy.

Two leaders who played significant roles in this transformation were governors William Bradford of Plymouth and John Winthrop of the Massachusetts Bay colony, founded in 1630. Bradford, who became governor at 31, was a maverick who deserted his family's church for a separatist faith and became a master weaver in Holland before moving to America. As governor, Bradford implemented private enterprise principles into the colony, repudiating a communal property requirement and paying off loans with high-interest rates.

John Winthrop, like Bradford, was a Puritan who had studied law and moved to higher legal positions in London. He, too, found solace in his religious creed, which emphasized man's quest for perfection and the belief that good people could build a model society through continual religious devotion and hard work.

Both the Plymouth and Massachusetts Bay colonies thrived, with few settlers choosing to return to the Old World. The Pilgrims, who lost half their population in the first year due to disease and starvation, expressed their determination to stay, stating, "It is not as with other men, whom small things could discourage or small discontents cause to wish themselves home again."

John Winthrop, like the Pilgrims, celebrated his first Thanksgiving in one of his first letters to his wife, expressing his contentment in America: "I thank God. I like so well to be here, as I do not repent my coming: and if I were to come again, I would not have altered my course, though I had foreseen all these Afflictions: I have never fared better in my life, never slept better, never had more content of mind."

Thomas V. DiBacco, professor emeritus at American University, is the author of this article.

Title: "Winter Storm Octavia Hits Eastern U.S., Brings Snow, Cold, and Travel Disruptions"

Article:

The latest winter storm, dubbed Winter Storm Octavia, has caused disruptions across several states in the Eastern United States. The Weather Channel's Jim Cantore and his crew captured the weather phenomenon of thundersnow during the storm.

Boston, which received 16.5 inches of snow over the weekend, was expected to receive a few more inches on Tuesday, but the city will avoid the brunt of the storm compared to less well-equipped areas such as Kentucky, Tennessee, Virginia, and Maryland. Washington, D.C., is bracing for between 4 and 8 inches of snow, with most of it falling early Tuesday and tapering off during the morning commute. Gov. Terry McAuliffe of Virginia declared a statewide emergency due to the potential for up to a foot of snow in some areas.

Non-essential travel is discouraged, and thousands of students throughout the region will have an additional day off due to the storm. Bitter cold temperatures are adding to the region's woes, with Washington's high temperature forecast to reach 25 degrees, about 20 degrees below average for the date.

New England experienced frigid temperatures on Monday, with Mount Washington, N.H., recording a low of -34 degrees with a wind-chill factor of -87. A hiker who activated her emergency personal locator beacon in the state's Presidential Range amid minus-30 temperatures and 100-mph winds was found dead on Monday.

In Kentucky, a section of Interstate 71 near Louisville closed Monday shortly after the snow started. Parts of the state could see more than a foot of snow, according to the National Weather Service. "For Louisville, it could be one of the worst (snowstorms) in 10 years," said meteorologist Joe Sullivan.

Waterford, Ky., reported 7.5 inches of snow at midday Monday. In Nashville, homeless shelter volunteer coordinator Robb McCluskey expressed concern that a few inches of slush, ice, and snow would keep drivers from bringing people to the shelter and keep church congregations from delivering dinner.

Jacksboro, Tenn., reported a midday total of a half inch of ice on the ground. The Weather Channel reported that "snow, sleet, and freezing rain will make travel difficult, and winter storm warnings have already been posted for almost 47 million people."

Atlanta forecasters cautioned about possible black ice for the morning commute after a day of cold rain and overnight temperatures dipping below freezing. Frigid temperatures were reported all across the northeastern United States on Monday, with Erie, Pa., dropping to -18 degrees, tying the city's all-time record low temperature, according to the National Weather Service.

Airlines have canceled more than 1,000 flights nationwide on Monday and more than 300 for Tuesday due to the cold and snow. Monday's cancellations were scattered across airports from New England to the Deep South as lingering disruptions from the weekend's blizzard mixed with the latest winter storm.

In Boston, the 58.5 inches of snow so far this month make February 2015 the city's snowiest month on record, according to the National Weather Service. The city's 2014-15 winter is the third-snowiest on record, with more than 95 inches recorded so far. The city is only 12 inches away from its snowiest winter ever, based on records dating to the 1870s.

"It's certainly not a record that we want," Mayor Marty Walsh told the Boston Herald. "It looks like a record we can get."

Title: Clinton and Sanders Debate in New Hampshire, Highlighting Harmony and Dissonance

Article:

The fifth debate between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, held in New Hampshire on Thursday, marked their first joint appearance as Democratic presidential nomination contenders. With Martin O'Malley having suspended his campaign earlier in the week, the two remaining candidates met on stage for nearly two hours.

During the debate, Clinton and Sanders agreed on several issues of current foreign policy and government priorities. Sanders declined to criticize Clinton for her use of a private email server to handle State Department emails, while Clinton demurred when asked to comment on certain tactics of the Sanders campaign.

However, the debate also featured moments of conflict, as both candidates highlighted their differences. Sanders, the self-proclaimed populist and visionary, described change as coming when Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell "looks out the window and sees a whole lot of people saying: 'Mitch, stop representing the billionaire class; start listening to working families.'" Clinton, on the other hand, presented herself as the nation's pragmatic mechanic, stating, "I'm interested in making what we have work better."

Sanders continued to bear in on Clinton's campaign donations and speaking fees from Wall Street and other big business entities. He described the "business model of Wall Street as fraud," facilitated by government officials who had been its beneficiaries. Clinton denounced what she called "an artful smear" and challenged Sanders to identify a single vote she had cast or changed to pay off a donor.

On her six-figure paid speeches, Clinton stated that she had spoken to these groups only about her knowledge of world politics. When asked whether she would release transcripts of those speeches, Clinton replied, "I do not know the status, but I'll certainly look into it."

Sanders also came under scrutiny for an ad that featured praise from an Iowa newspaper that had actually endorsed Clinton. Sanders stated the ad never claimed he had received the endorsement, but MSNBC moderator Rachel Maddow noted the ad was titled "Endorsement."

On foreign policy, Clinton demonstrated fluency and mastery of the field, while Sanders seemed to be in first gear. However, Sanders offered his oft-repeated point: "She may have the experience, but I had the judgment to vote against the Iraq War."

In terms of the polls, Sanders had opened a 20-point lead on Clinton in two polls publicized just before the debate began. Sanders has traditionally enjoyed a boost in New Hampshire due to his next-door-neighbor status and his long-standing presence in regional politics.

Clinton, however, presented a supreme confidence and sunny demeanor, suggesting she saw brighter days ahead, perhaps in voting venues well to the south and west. The campaign moves to South Carolina and Nevada later this month, with a dozen states voting on March 1, most of which are in the nation's Southeast. On March 15, Florida holds a primary that could be make or break for the candidate trailing at that point.

Before then, there will be at least two more debates between Clinton and Sanders.

Title: Louisiana's Economic Recovery Struggles Spark Debate Over Fiscal Policy

Article:

Louisiana's economic recovery, while not unique, has sparked a debate among political figures regarding the state's fiscal policy. The criticism of the current policy is directed towards the incumbent governor, Bobby Jindal, who is barred from seeking a third term due to term limits.

One of the policy's critics is United States Senator David Vitter, a Republican and the current favorite in the governor's race. Vitter expressed concerns about the state's generous and expanding tax incentives and its increasing reliance on one-time sources of revenue to balance the budget.

Vitter stated, "In many ways the economy's doing pretty good, but there's a disconnect because of this broken fiscal policy." He further criticized Jindal's approach, saying, "I don't agree with his general approach."

In response, Governor Jindal defended his record, attributing the state's budget shortfall primarily to the downturn in oil prices. He emphasized that the intention was to shrink the state government, not as an unfortunate side effect, but as part of a deliberate policy decision.

"We made an explicit decision and commitment that we were going to cut the government, the public sector economy, as opposed to the private sector economy," Jindal said, adding that per capita income in the state is at its highest. He further explained, "We made the intentional policy decision we think it'd be better to shrink government and cut taxes. That's unusual for Louisiana."

A movement to reassess tax credits and exemptions, which total more than $1 billion annually, has been gaining momentum in the Republican-controlled Legislature. However, Jindal has expressed firm opposition to any changes that would result in net new revenue. Last year, he vetoed a bill that would have required the state to tally up the costs of those tax credits and rebates, citing potential uncertainty about the state's commitment to job creation and economic development.

Title: Obama Campaign Pre-emptively Criticizes Romney's Foreign Policy Stance Ahead of Speech

Article:

In anticipation of Mitt Romney's planned foreign policy address, President Obama's re-election campaign has launched a pre-emptive critique, alleging that Mr. Romney has failed the commander-in-chief test on the global stage. The Obama campaign released a new television advertisement and issued a memo on Monday, criticizing Mr. Romney's overseas trip this summer and his response to the attacks on the U.S. diplomatic post in Libya.

The Obama campaign's memo, authored by two former top Obama national security advisers, Michele Flournoy and Colin Kahl, asserts that Mr. Romney's foreign policy positions are outside the mainstream and often to the right of former President George W. Bush.
