They suggest that this is not surprising, given that Mr. Romney has surrounded himself with advisers who supported the "with-us-or-against-us approach" that led to "some of the worst foreign policy failures in American history, including the Iraq War."

The Obama campaign also challenges Mr. Romney to provide specifics on how his foreign policy approach would differ from the current administration. The memo states, "Governor Romney still can’t say what he’d do differently on Iran other than taking us to war, he continues to criticize the president’s time line in Afghanistan even while saying he’d pursue it as president, his position on Libya has no credibility since he’s been both for and against our Libya policy, and he offers no way forward on Syria other than suggesting that the United States should get more deeply involved in the conflict without defining a strategy."

In the memo, the Obama campaign also highlights Mr. Romney's stumbling performance during his July trip to Britain, Israel, and Poland. The campaign also cites the criticism of Anthony Cordesman, a national security adviser to GOP Sen. John McCain's 2008 presidential campaign, who described Mr. Romney's stance on Libya as "the worst possible reaction."

Mr. Romney is set to deliver a broad-scale attack on Mr. Obama's handling of foreign policy and national security issues in a speech at the Virginia Military Institute. According to excerpts of the speech, Mr. Romney will touch on some of the topics mentioned in the Obama campaign's memo, arguing that the United States must have a more robust presence in world affairs. He will also warn that the attacks on U.S. diplomatic posts last month are part of a broader struggle that is playing out across the Middle East and represent an effort by Islamic extremists to "wage perpetual war on the West."

The Obama campaign, in the memo, argues that their president has had a strong national security record, citing achievements such as decimating al Qaeda's leadership, taking out Osama bin Laden, ending the war in Iraq, providing unparalleled support to Israel, producing unprecedented pressure on Iran, strengthening alliances, and restoring the U.S.'s standing in the world.

However, the Romney campaign has pushed back, arguing that Mr. Obama has weakened America's standing abroad in the past four years. Romney spokeswoman Amanda Henneberg stated, "In every region of the world—and particularly in the Middle East—American influence has been weakened by President Obama’s failed foreign policy. American security and the cause of freedom can not afford four more years like the last four years, and Mitt Romney will restore the bipartisan tradition of American leadership abroad that President Obama has not lived up to."

In the new ad released Monday, the Obama campaign highlights critical news reports of Mr. Romney's stumbling performance during his July trip and the biting commentary of Anthony Cordesman, who described Mr. Romney's response to the attack on the U.S. Consulate in Libya as "the worst possible reaction." The ad concludes with the narrator stating, "If this is how he handles the world now, just think what Mitt Romney might do as president."

Title: Israel, Syria, and Iran Tensions Escalate: Israeli F-16 Shot Down by Syrian Missiles

Article:

Over the past few hours, actions by Israel, Syria, and Iran have increased the chances of a conflagration. At around 4:30 am on Saturday, an Iranian drone entered Israeli territory from Syria. One of the Israeli military's helicopters intercepted the drone; an Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) spokesperson added that the drone "was on a mission."

In response, Israel sent eight fighter jets that morning to strike the area from where the drone supposedly launched, near the city of Palmyra. Middle East security experts, like the Royal United Services Institute's Shashank Joshi, noted this Israeli aerial attack was quite big compared to previous ones.

Syria didn't take kindly to that, however, and it launched anti-aircraft missiles into the sky—an Israeli official confirmed that the munitions hit one of Israel's F-16s. Both of the Israeli pilots in the plane are safe, but one is severely injured due to "an emergency evacuation," according to the Israeli military. Later on Saturday, the Washington Post reported that the Israeli military launched a "large scale attack" after one of its jets "crashed under Syrian antiaircraft fire."

On Saturday night, the White House put out a statement condemning Syrian hostility and affirming its support for Israel: "Israel is a staunch ally of the United States, and we support its right to defend itself from the Iranian-backed Syrian and militia forces in southern Syria. We call on Iran and its allies to cease provocative actions and work toward regional peace."

It's the first time in years, perhaps since the 1980s, that enemy weaponry brought down an Israeli jet. IDF spokesperson Jonathan Conricus told CNN that other Israeli planes made it back to base. That might make Israel rethink its flights into Syria in order to drop bombs.

"The Israeli enemy entity early morning at dawn conducted a new aggression against one of the military bases in the central region," the Syrian state news agency SANA said, adding that it hit more than one plane. (Syria has a history of falsely claiming that it downed Israeli aircraft.)

That led Israel to respond with even greater force: Also on Saturday, it struck at least 12 targets in Syria, including four Iranian military targets in the country. If true, it would be Israel's first direct military confrontation with Iran across the Golan Heights, a demilitarized zone between Israel and Syria.

Israeli officials say this situation started because of Iran. "Iran is dragging the region into an adventure in which it doesn't know how it will end," Brig. Gen. Ronen Manelis, Israel's chief military spokesperson, said in a statement. "Whoever is responsible for this incident is the one who will pay the price."

But Israel faults Syria too. "The Syrians are playing with fire that they are allowing the Iranians to attack Israel from their soil," Conricus told the Washington Post. "The IDF is ready and capable to inflict a heavy price on anyone that attacks us." Israel now says it has the drone and claims it is Iranian.

What makes this situation even scarier: Israel says it is "fully prepared for further action," which means things could get worse.

Tehran has spent the past seven years fighting to keep Syrian President Bashar al-Assad in power while using the Syrian civil war's chaos to gain more control in the region. Israel, on the other hand, uses military force to curb Iran's influence.

"Iran is busy turning Syria into a base of military entrenchment," Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said at a news conference last September. "It wants to use Syria and Lebanon as war fronts against its declared goal to eradicate Israel."

On February 7, Israel fired missiles at a Syrian ammunition depot in Jamraya. That's the location of a suspected Syrian facility that produces chemical weapons.

We've seen something like this before. Last September, Israeli jets attacked a Syrian military installation near the city of Masyaf that also allegedly produced chemical weapons and advanced missiles. The Syrian Army said two soldiers died. (The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a UK-based monitoring organization that supports anti-government forces in the civil war, claimed there were at least seven casualties.)

In a statement after the attack, the Syrian military said there could be "serious repercussions of such acts of aggression on the security and stability of the region."

The Israeli government didn't comment on that operation. But it became pretty clear that it hit Syria to prevent Iranian ally Hezbollah—a Lebanese militant group that considers Israel an enemy—from acquiring precision-guided missiles to use against Israel.

Israel has launched around 100 strikes inside Syria over the past five years, according to Amir Eshel, a former chief of the Israeli Air Force. Usual targets include convoys of Syrian military or Hezbollah members.

Israel is particularly worried about Hezbollah because they have fought before. In 2006, the two battled in a month-long war where the militant group fired more than 4,000 rockets into Israel; in response, Israeli forces fired around 7,000 bombs and missiles into Lebanon.

Around 160 Israelis troops and civilians died, according to the Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and about 1,100 Lebanese—most of them civilians—perished, per Human Rights Watch, a US-based advocacy organization. The organization also reports about 4,400 Lebanese were injured, and around 1 million people were displaced.

Today, Israel believes Hezbollah has around 150,000 rockets at its disposal, although those weapons aren't as advanced as the precision weapons made at the facility Israel struck in September 2017.

That said, what happened last September is nothing like Saturday's events. This most recent flare-up could escalate simmering tensions between Israel, Syria, and Iran even further—something an already roiling Middle East can't afford.

Update: This post has been updated to confirm that Syria shot down an Israeli F-16 and to add a statement from the White House.

Title: Puerto Rico, Whitefish Energy, and Power Grid Restoration Efforts Under Scrutiny

Article:

Puerto Rico and Whitefish Energy Holdings are defending a $300 million contract awarded to the small Montana company to repair the U.S. territory's hurricane-damaged power grid, following criticism from U.S. lawmakers. The controversy arises as Puerto Rico continues to struggle to restore power to over 80% of the island, a month after Hurricane Maria made landfall.

Whitefish signed a deal with Puerto Rico's quasi-public power utility, PREPA, to help rebuild a grid that was severely damaged by Maria, the strongest storm to hit Puerto Rico in 90 years. The deal was awarded without a competitive bidding process, and despite the fact that Whitefish had only two full-time employees and was established just two years ago. This has led to criticism from legislators who suggest cheaper options may have been available.

Governor Ricardo Rossello stated that his administration would review PREPA's contracting practices and forward findings to the island's comptroller. Rossello defended the deal, stating that it was necessary to ensure Puerto Rico would have workers in place quickly.

Rossello commented, "Of those (contractors) who met the requirements and aggressive schedules to bring brigades, one was asking for a substantial amount of money - which PREPA had no liquidity for - and another did not require it. That other one is Whitefish."

Puerto Rico was already in financial straits before the storm, with a $72 billion debt. As the island works to recover, power restoration is a key challenge, and one of keen interest to contractors and lawmakers alike. Maria left all of Puerto Rico without power when it made landfall on Sept. 20. As of Monday, only 18% had been restored, according to U.S. Department of Energy data.

Rossello's comments followed criticism from lawmakers like Democrat Raul Grijalva, the ranking member of the U.S. House Committee on Natural Resources, who stated, "Congress needs to understand why the Whitefish contract was awarded and whether other, more cost-effective options were available."

Whitefish spokesman Ken Luce called the criticism unfounded, stating, "Washington's got it backwards." Luce added that the firm has been working in Puerto Rico since Oct. 2 and has hired dozens of workers, largely through subcontracts, as it ramps up operations in Puerto Rico.

Meanwhile, the Department of Defense announced that the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers has awarded a similar power grid repair contract to a subsidiary of Fluor Corp. Greenville, South Carolina-based Fluor Enterprises Inc beat out another undisclosed bidder for a $240 million construction contract set to run through next April, the DOD stated.

Other companies working on power restoration include JEA, a Jacksonville, Florida-based utility, and representatives from the New York Power Authority. Fixing Puerto Rico's power grid is an enormous task, as Maria would have severely damaged a healthy grid, but Puerto Rico's was in a fragile state after years without maintenance. PREPA has struggled with heavy management turnover and a $9 billion debt load, which led it to declare bankruptcy in July.

PREPA has set aggressive goals for repairs, aiming to restore 95% of power by mid-December, a schedule viewed as ambitious. (Reporting by Nick Brown; additional reporting by David Gaffen)

Title: North Korea Fires Short-Range Ballistic Missile, Third Test Since New South Korean President Took Office

Article:

North Korea launched at least one short-range ballistic missile on Monday, marking the third test since South Korea's liberal President Moon Jae-in took office on May 10. The missile, believed to be a Scud-class ballistic missile, flew about 450 km (280 miles) before landing in the sea off North Korea's east coast, according to South Korean officials.

The missile test follows two successful medium-to-long-range missile tests by North Korea in the past two weeks. The country has been conducting these tests at an unprecedented pace in an effort to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) capable of hitting the mainland United States.

South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff spokesman Roh Jae-cheon stated that the missile reached an altitude of 120 km (75 miles). Roh also noted that the assessment is that there was at least one missile, but the number of missiles is still being analyzed.

North Korea, which has conducted dozens of missile tests and tested two nuclear bombs since the beginning of 2016, says the program is necessary to counter U.S. aggression. The White House stated that President Donald Trump had been briefed about the launch, and the U.S. Pacific Command tracked the missile for six minutes and assessed it did not pose a threat to North America.

The United States has said it is looking at discussing with China a new U.N. Security Council resolution and that Beijing, North Korea's main diplomatic ally and neighbor, realizes time is limited to rein in its weapons program through negotiations. The situation on the Korean peninsula is complex and sensitive, and China has urged all relevant sides to maintain calm and exercise restraint.

Japan lodged a protest against the test missile, which appeared to have landed in its exclusive economic zone. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe vowed action along with other nations to deter Pyongyang's repeated provocations. The issue of North Korea is a top priority for the international community, Abe stated, and working with the United States, they will take specific action to deter North Korea.

South Korea's Moon called a meeting of the National Security Council in response to the test launch. North Korea last test-fired a ballistic missile on May 21 and said on Sunday it had tested a new anti-aircraft weapon supervised by leader Kim Jong Un. Experts suggest that North Korea may be testing new capabilities that may be fed into its efforts to build an ICBM. The United States will test an existing missile defense system to try to intercept an ICBM on Tuesday, officials stated last week.

Title: Christie's Political Future in Question Following Bridgegate Scandal

Article:

The political future of former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie is uncertain following the "Bridgegate" scandal, as questions about his involvement and knowledge of the traffic jam conspiracy continue to mount. The scandal, which involved the closure of lanes on the George Washington Bridge in 2013, has led to speculation about Christie's leadership and potential dishonesty.

On Thursday, Christie announced that he had fired his deputy chief of staff Bridget Kelly, one of the officials at the center of the traffic jam conspiracy, and prospectively fired another confidant from future political jobs. He claimed to have been "blindsided" by Wednesday's revelations and insisted that he never detected a whiff of impropriety until the now infamous "Time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee" emails became public.

Christie stated, "I am not a micromanager. I delegate enormous amounts of authority." If this is true, then he still faces the problem of reconciling his delegatory style with the revelation that he allowed multiple individuals to act with impunity within his inner circle.

If it is discovered that Christie was not completely unaware of or involved in the scandal, it could be detrimental to his political career. Over the course of two hours, Christie provided several new avenues for inquiry during his press conference.

Conservatives who are inclined to defend Christie have resorted to tu quoque defenses, comparing Bridgegate to the Benghazi controversy or the IRS targeting of political nonprofits. However, these comparisons have been met with criticism, as the IRS actions have far graver implications than creating traffic on the George Washington Bridge, and the bad actors in this case were Christie's closest, most trusted aides, not low-level officials in a far-off bureaucracy.

The authentic, gruff earnestness that Christie exudes and his allies in the national press corps may have helped him escape an at-times incoherent press conference without revealing conspicuous malice. However, the problem for Christie, politically, probatively, and legally, is that the story will eventually settle around one of two conclusions: either he is no better prepared to serve as a politician after two decades in politics and four years as the New Jersey governor, or he is one of the most audacious liars in 21st-century American politics.

There is little gray area in which Christie might redeem his judgment and managerial skill without admitting that he lied about his knowledge of or involvement in the scandal. The future prospects of Christie's political career have been badly damaged, regardless of the eventual outcome of the investigation.

Title: FBI Modifies Decision, to Release More Details on Clinton Email Investigation

Article:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has announced a change in its decision regarding the release of details from its obstruction of justice probe into former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's email case. The Justice Department confirmed the new position in a letter on Thursday to Ty Clevenger, a lawyer who had filed an open records request for the information.

Initially, the FBI stated there was not enough public interest to outweigh Clinton's privacy concerns. However, after Clevenger appealed to the Justice Department, they have concluded that the records in question are part of the Clinton email investigation file, which is already being made public in installments.

Justice Department official Sean R. O' Neill stated that the records are being posted at the FBI's "vault," a section of the bureau's website, under the heading "Hillary R. Clinton." The FBI will continue to process and post subsequent releases of responsive records until the entire investigative file is complete.

Clevenger interpreted this as the Justice Department overruling the FBI and reversing its earlier decision. Earlier this week, Clevenger won a ruling from a state judge in Maryland who overruled the state bar counsel's office and ordered an investigation into whether Clinton's lawyers should face discipline for their handling of Clinton's emails.

Clevenger alleges that by deleting emails that the government later determined were official records and should have been returned to the State Department—and were subject to preservation requests—the lawyers engaged in destruction of evidence.

Title: Virginia Governor's Race: McAuliffe Wins by Narrow Margin, Cuccinelli Campaign Highlights Impact of Obamacare

Article:

Democrat Terry McAuliffe won the Virginia governorship on Tuesday, narrowly defeating Republican Kenneth T. Cuccinelli in a race that was far closer than polls had suggested just days ago. The results of the Virginia gubernatorial election, along with the re-election of New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, will be closely studied by candidates heading into the next two federal elections.

In the two biggest elections of the night - the New Jersey and Virginia governor's races - neither Democratic candidate topped 50 percent. Between purple-state Virginia and deep-blue New Jersey, the Republican candidates combined for 2.2 million votes, or 400,000 more than the Democratic candidates.

The final results in Virginia were far closer than polls suggested just days ago. At the end of the government shutdown, Mr. McAuliffe held leads of as much as 17 percentage points. However, with the shutdown over, Mr. Cuccinelli and national Republican figures argued that Virginia's election was a referendum on Obamacare - and the polls began to tighten, ending with Mr. McAuliffe's narrow 2 percentage-point victory on Tuesday.

Exit polling showed 41 percent of Virginians "strongly oppose" the health care law, while only 27 percent "strongly support" the law. Of voters who said health care was the most important issue in their vote, Mr. Cuccinelli topped Mr. McAuliffe, 49 percent to 45 percent.

Mr. Cuccinelli's big stumble came on social issues, with a large chunk of voters saying abortion was their chief concern, and Mr. McAuliffe overwhelmingly winning those voters, 59 percent to 34 percent.

In New Jersey, the polling on Obamacare was a little closer, with 34 percent strongly opposed and 23 percent strongly supporting it.

Liberal groups said they welcomed viewing the election night as a referendum on Obamacare, since Virginia did end up going Democratic in both the governor's race and the lieutenant governor's race.

"Advantage: Obamacare," said Americans United for Change, a group run by the former spokesman for the national Democratic Party.

Current Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz said in a statement that the Virginia victories showed just how badly the government shutdown hurt Republicans.

"Tonight in Virginia, we saw voters reject the extreme tea party politics that caused our government to shut down and drove our economy to the brink of collapse," she said.

While there's little doubt Mr. Cuccinelli turned off voters, so did Mr. McAuliffe. Exit polling showed just 52 percent said they strongly backed the man they voted for, while 17 percent said they voted for their choice because they disliked the others. Mr. McAuliffe won half of those voters, signaling his margin of victory came not because voters were eager to see him in office, but because they were wary of Mr. Cuccinelli.

A Libertarian candidate, Robert C. Sarvis, won 6.6 percent of the vote, which was well more than the slim margin of victory for Mr. McAuliffe. Mr. Sarvis won almost all of his support from voters who simply disliked the two major-party offerings.

Title: Supreme Court to Decide on 2020 Census Citizenship Question

Article:

The Supreme Court will review a lower court ruling that blocked the Trump administration from including a question about citizenship in the 2020 census. The high court will hear arguments for the case in late April, with a decision expected by late June.

Initially, justices were scheduled to hear the case on Feb. 19, but oral arguments were suspended last month. The justices put the matter on hold after a federal district court judge ruled the government could not proceed with its plans.

In his court opinion, the federal judge stated that the inclusion of a citizenship question would likely reduce the response rate and congressional representation of non-citizens. The judge also ruled that the addition of the question was arbitrary and did not follow proper procedure. The judge cited a law requiring a three-year notice for any plan to add a question about citizenship to the census.

The Trump administration, however, announced last month that it would appeal the federal court judge's ruling and seek a Supreme Court review. The Commerce Department, which designs the census, had failed to properly analyze the effect the question would have on immigrant households, according to a case brought by a dozen states or big cities and immigrants' rights groups.

The Commerce Department stated last May that the citizenship question would be added to the 2020 census count in response to a request made by the Justice Department in December 2017. The department argued that the citizenship question was necessary to provide complete and accurate census block level data.

The census count is required by the Constitution, and its results are used to determine federal spending, as well as the number of congressional seats allocated to each state for the next decade, and the number of electoral votes available from each state.

The inclusion of the citizenship question has been a contentious issue, with Republicans largely supporting the additional question as a logical step, while Democrats argue that the inclusion amounts to an effort to intimidate immigrant communities and siphon money and electoral power away from them.

The Commerce Department has pointed out that almost every decennial census between 1820 and 1950 " asked a question about citizenship in some form." The department also stated that the citizenship question would be the same as the one that it asked on the yearly American Community Service (ACS), which is sent to a much smaller percentage of American homes than the actual census.

"The citizenship data provided to the [Department of Justice] will be more accurate with the question than without it," Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said last May. "Which is of greater importance than any adverse effect that may result from people violating their legal duty to respond."

Title: The Role of Spouses in Political Campaigns: A Gender Perspective

Article:

In the political arena, the role of spouses, particularly those of female candidates, has been a subject of scrutiny and debate. According to Kelly Dittmar, a professor at Rutgers University who specializes in women in American politics, the presence of a husband can raise questions about the candidate's autonomy.

Jennifer Granholm, the first female governor of Michigan in 2003, experienced this dynamic with her husband, Dan Mulhern. In an interview, Mulhern discussed dealing with sexist undertones and implicit bias, including the perception that he was calling the shots, which he emphasized was untrue.

As the 2020 primary elections approach, Democratic campaign operatives view this as a relatively safe space to begin addressing these questions. However, the focus remains on managing the public's perception of the candidates before delving into the role of their husbands.

Jen Palmieri, a former communications director for Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama's presidential campaigns, noted that voters have not often seen men in supportive roles in campaigns, especially in executive positions. Only 3% of governors in American history have been women, according to an analysis by Dittmar.

In the case of the 2020 presidential race, some spouses, such as Jill Biden and Jane Sanders, are already playing significant roles in their husbands' campaigns, as they did in their past campaigns. This presents a challenge in determining how voters want to see these spouses and the role they want them to play. As Palmieri stated, "There's no playbook for it."

The general election, however, may present a different story, with voters' reactions and President Donald Trump's approach to societal hot buttons being a significant factor. The role and presentation of these spouses during the general election could become a more complex question to navigate.

Title: "House Represents Ron Paul's "Audit the Fed" Legislation for Vote Amidst Pre-Election Bills"

Article:

The House of Representatives is set to vote on the "Audit the Fed" bill this week, a piece of legislation that was a key cause of former Representative Ron Paul. The bill, which aims to audit the Federal Reserve, is one of a series of pre-election bills designed to highlight lawmakers' stances before they return to their constituencies.

First introduced by Paul in 2012, the bill garnered significant bipartisan support, passing with a vote of 327-98. However, the bill faced opposition from Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, who initially supported an audit of the Federal Reserve but later reversed his stance.

Paul, who retired from the House after the last Congress, is no longer in office, but the current House version of the legislation is sponsored by Rep. Paul Broun, a Georgia Republican. Broun's version of the bill cleared the House Oversight Committee in July, suggesting continued bipartisan support.

The bill, if passed, would order the Government Accountability Office (GAO), Congress's chief investigative arm, to review the Fed's decision-making, particularly on monetary policy. The Federal Reserve, established nearly a century ago, acts as a lender of last resort to the country's banking system and is charged with fighting inflation and promoting economic growth and employment.

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates the bill would cost about $5 million for the staff required to conduct the audit, with the Federal Reserve spending additional money complying with the review, resulting in approximately $3 million in lower revenue from the Fed over the next decade.

Previous Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke opposed the audit, stating it could lead to politicians second-guessing the secretive board's decisions. When Paul's bill came up for a vote in 2012, Bernanke called it a "nightmare scenario."

Paul's son, Senator Rand Paul (Kentucky Republican), has a companion bill in the Senate, but it has not seen any action due to Democrats controlling the chamber. Despite Democratic leaders' opposition, a number of rank-and-file Democrats support the legislation.

Nineteen Democrats in the House are co-sponsors of Broun's bill, and in the Senate, Senator Mark Begich (Alaska Democrat) is a co-sponsor. Begich has even publicly supported the legislation during a recent Senate campaign debate.

Title: President Obama and Congressional Leaders at Odds Over Student Loan Interest Rate Hike

Article:

In a renewed effort to address the impending increase in student loan interest rates, President Obama criticized congressional Republicans for inaction on the issue during a White House event on Thursday. The interest rates on federal Stafford student loans are scheduled to double on July 1 if Congress takes no action.

President Obama stated, "We've been stuck watching Congress play 'chicken' with another deadline." He emphasized that there are still 10 days for Congress to take action and avoid the rate hike. The average student would face approximately $1,000 in additional interest payments due to the rate increase, according to the White House.

Republican leaders, however, accused the White House of ignoring their proposed solutions to the stalemate. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, stated, "We proposed multiple good-faith solutions to this problem before it's too late." He added that the administration has yet to respond to these proposals.

White House press secretary Jay Carney stated that the administration has been working "broadly" with lawmakers but declined to name any specific Republicans with whom they have been in contact. Carney emphasized that the administration has made every effort to resolve the matter.

The issue of student loan interest rates has become a point of contention, with Republicans accusing President Obama of exploiting the issue for political gain during his reelection campaign. President Obama, in response, stated that Congress has largely ignored his entreaties and that the issue should have been resolved weeks ago.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, expressed optimism that an agreement could still be reached before the deadline, stating that discussions over the past two days have been productive. However, he acknowledged that Congress is not yet at an agreement.

The debate over the cost of subsidizing the student loans has been a contentious issue, with both parties offering proposals. The House of Representatives passed a student-loan bill that would take money from a preventative health care fund, but the fund is not specifically designated for women's health care programs. The White House has proposed cutting the same program.

In the midst of this debate, President Obama repeated a claim that has been debunked, stating that House Republicans want to pay for student loans by cutting funding for women's health care programs. This claim has been disputed, as the preventative health care fund is not specifically designated for women's health care programs.

As the deadline approaches, both parties continue to negotiate a solution to the student loan interest rate issue. The potential impact on millions of students hangs in the balance.

Title: Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring Admits to Blackface Incident, Adding to Virginia Governor's Scandal

Article:

Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring, the third in line to the governorship following the recent scandals involving Governor Ralph Northam and Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax, admitted to a blackface incident from 1980 on Wednesday. In a statement, Herring explained that he and his friends attended a party dressed as rappers, wearing wigs and brown makeup.

Herring expressed profound apologies for his actions, calling them "inexcusable" and insensitive but not reflective of his current self. Ordinarily, this admission might have ended Herring's career, but the current political climate in Virginia's Democratic Party is unpredictable due to the multi-layered race and sex scandals.

The crisis began last week when a photo of Governor Northam's med-school yearbook page, showing a man in blackface next to a man dressed as a Klansman, was unearthed. Northam initially admitted he was one of the men in the photo, but later backtracked during a press conference, suggesting he wasn't either man and resisting calls to resign.

Lieutenant Governor Fairfax's role in the current leadership crisis is significant due to the sexual assault allegation against him. If the top three Democrats in Virginia become untenable, the fourth in line to the governorship would be House Speaker Kirk Cox, a Republican.

Both Northam and Fairfax have responded defensively. Northam is reportedly hiring a private investigator to investigate the origin of the yearbook photo, while Fairfax has accused his political enemies of orchestrating a smear campaign. Fairfax's future was further complicated on Wednesday when Dr. Vanessa Tyson, a professor at Scripps College in California, detailed an alleged sexual assault incident involving Fairfax in 2004.

According to Tyson, she and Fairfax interacted as colleagues during the Democratic National Convention in 2004. When they went to Fairfax's hotel room to retrieve documents, Tyson alleged Fairfax kissed her, and though she was receptive, she did not intend to engage in sexual activity. However, she alleged Fairfax forced her to perform oral sex, despite her "obvious distress." Tyson stated she "suffered from both deep humiliation and shame" for years afterward.

Fairfax has not yet responded to the allegations publicly. The future of Virginia's political leadership remains uncertain as the events unfold.

Title: Obama's Future Relevance: A Look at the President's Remaining Influence

Article:

In a press conference following the midterm elections, President Barack Obama expressed optimism and a cooperative tone towards the newly elected Republican majority in Congress. He stated, "I told them both that I look forward to finishing up this Congress's business and then working together for the next two years to advance America's business."

The president's optimistic tone is likely a strategic move to maintain relevance in the face of a significant Republican victory. The question arises as to whether Obama is still relevant, given the historic scale of the Republican victory.

While a president's relevance is not easily diminished due to the power of the office, history offers a notable example in former President Ronald Reagan. In 1986, Reagan's party also lost the Senate and the House, yet his final two years were marked by significant achievements, such as the INF Treaty with Mikhail Gorbachev and the 1986 Tax Reform Act.

However, it is unlikely that Republicans will seek to replicate the Iran-Contra hearings in an attempt to make Obama politically irrelevant. Such an attempt would be met with strong opposition, potentially labeled as politically counter-productive and divisive.

In foreign policy, Obama's ability to lead has been questioned, with few significant achievements to his name. Domestically, his signature policy, Obamacare, is likely to face opposition, and the president's inability to reach across the aisle over the past six years has limited his ability to pass legislation.

In the coming years, Obama's main source of impact may come from unilateral overtures, such as executive orders, and shaping the courts through appointments and judicial decisions. The long-term impact on issues like religious freedom could be significant, particularly if Obama is able to replace Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg with a leftist in the mold of Elena Kagan.

In conclusion, while President Barack Obama remains relevant, his ability to implement his agenda is likely to be limited, with his main source of impact coming from unilateral actions and shaping the courts. The question of his relevance is complex, with his own ideology and psychology playing a significant role in shaping his ability to lead and achieve bipartisan success.

Title: Thousands of Pro-Democracy Protesters in Hong Kong Call for U.S. Intervention, Citing Support from Defense Secretary Mark Esper

Article:

Thousands of pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong, wearing black shirts and masks, marched to the U.S. Consulate on Sunday, chanting the U.S. national anthem and calling on President Donald Trump to "liberate" the Chinese-ruled city. The protesters, who also waved American flags and carried posters reading "President Trump, please liberate Hong Kong," were met by riot police and their demonstration turned violent later in the day.

The protesters' actions come after U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper counseled Beijing to use "restraint" in its dealing with Hong Kong, a British colony that was returned to Chinese rule in 1997. Esper stated at a press conference in Paris on Saturday that the U.S. would urge "restraint and not to act, and to sit down and talk with the protesters and resolve the differences."

The Sunday protests began peacefully but later turned violent when police fired tear gas to disperse the crowds that converged on the city's Central District, where banks, jewelry stores, and high-end clothing shops are located. The demonstrators smashed windows, vandalized a subway station, ignited fires in the street, and put up barricades.

The city has been in a state of turmoil throughout the summer, prompted by an extradition bill that would have allowed suspects in semi-autonomous Hong Kong to be sent to mainland China to face trial in courts controlled by the Communist Party. Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam last week said she was formally withdrawing the bill, but it did little to discourage the protests that have since turned into calls for more democratic reforms.

Panzer Chan, one of the organizers of the march, told the Associated Press that Hong Kong is "at the forefront of the battle against the totalitarian regime of China." Chan urged President Trump to "support us in our fight." The exact nature of the support being sought by the protesters is unclear.

Title: Paul Ryan Emerges as Key Figure in Washington's Budget Standoff

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Republican Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin has emerged as a key figure in the ongoing budget standoff in Washington, D.C. After keeping a low profile, Ryan has successfully appeased House Republicans and engaged President Barack Obama in as little as 48 hours, a feat that is near impossible in the current climate of extreme partisanship.

Ryan, who was the Republican vice presidential candidate in 2012, has managed to move demands by tea party-aligned House Republicans on government funding and debt away from Obamacare, enabling House Republicans to propose an approach on the fiscal impasse that has not yet met President Obama's chief requirements but has not halted negotiations.

During a meeting at the White House, Ryan stepped in and changed the tone of the meeting. The two sides had seemed to be talking past each other, but Ryan's intervention resulted in a more cooperative atmosphere. Ryan conceded that his side would not get all it wanted, while Obama asked how he could make something happen.

Republicans left the meeting expressing optimism, motivated to get to work. The White House admitted progress. However, it remains to be seen if Ryan can push a deal over the finish line.

Ryan's role in the negotiations is significant, as House Speaker John Boehner has been unable or unwilling to reach a deal with the President amid the shutdown. Boehner and Obama have a fractured history of bitter negotiations.

In contrast, Ryan and Obama have a different relationship. While they were fierce competitors during the presidential election, they remain political foes. Despite their public criticisms and derogatory remarks during the campaign, they seem to have maintained a professional relationship.

The last time they worked together was six months ago during the last budget battle in March. Obama invited Ryan and his Democratic counterpart, Rep. Chris Van Hollen, D-Maryland, to lunch. It was the first time Obama and Ryan had sat down together since the presidential race.

Van Hollen said at the time that "their relationship is developing." One of their first public encounters, however, was mixed. When Obama invited himself to a Republican retreat in Baltimore in 2010, he took questions from the members while the television cameras rolled.

Ryan introduced himself as "a ranking member of the Budget Committee," indicating he was unsure if the president knew who he was. After a back-and-forth about the budget, the president abruptly cut Ryan off, ending the discussion.

Obama later complimented Ryan, saying, "I think Paul Ryan is a pretty sincere guy and has a beautiful family." Obama joked, "And by the way, in case he's going to get a Republican challenge, I did not mean it. Do not want to hurt you, man."

Fast forward to today. While they have been on different sides of nearly every debate, their relationship is not broken. In today's Washington, that's saying a lot.

Title: Romney's Shift in Stances: A Look at the Presidential Candidate's Evolving Positions

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, is set to participate in the third and final presidential debate on Monday, an opportunity to further showcase his evolving political positions. The debates, with their large television audiences, have provided Romney with a platform to adjust some stances, soften others, and present himself as a more moderate candidate compared to his primary contest image.

In March, Romney spokesman Eric Fehrnstrom famously foreshadowed these changes when he told CNN, "Well, I think you hit a reset button for the fall campaign. Everything changes. It's almost like an Etch A Sketch. You can kind of shake it up and restart all of over again."

Some of Romney's "Etch A Sketch" moments include his call for boosting Pell Grant funding, a reversal of his criticism of President Obama's increases. Additionally, Romney now supports keeping parts of the national health care law and has indicated more flexibility on legalizing young illegal immigrants and abortion.

President Obama, on the campaign trail, has poked fun at Romney's perceived shift, referring to him as "Moderate Mitt." Obama diagnosed the "condition" as "Romnesia," warning college students in Virginia that Romney will say anything to get elected and cannot be trusted, repeating the "flip-flopper" charge that has dogged Romney, thanks to his support of an individual health care mandate in Massachusetts and his evolution on abortion and gun rights.

Despite the criticism, Romney's move towards the political center seems to be paying off, as polls show him even or ahead of the president. Larry J. Sabato, director of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, stated, "Romney has more flexibility to maneuver than almost any presidential nominee I can think of. He'd be crazy not to take advantage of this fact. And he's not crazy."

Republican strategist Ford O'Connell agreed, stating that Romney is trying to woo single-issue voters and to narrow Obama's lead among the coalition of voters—women, Hispanic, and young voters—that propelled the Democrat to victory four years ago.

Romney has vowed to "keep our Pell Grant program growing" and to keep the most popular provisions of the Affordable Care Act, such as covering pre-existing conditions and allowing young people to stay on their family plan. He has also promised not to "reduce the share that's being paid by the highest-income taxpayers."

In terms of immigration, Romney has softened his stance before the first debate, telling The Denver Post that he would not immediately deport the illegal immigrants granted temporary legal status under Obama's nondeportation directive. He also told The Des Moines Register's editorial board that he has no legislation in mind regarding abortion that would become part of his agenda, a direct appeal to female voters in swing states.

Romney's vagueness on some issues, such as the National Defense Authorization Act and immigration, has irritated some people. Michael F. Cannon, director of health policy studies at the libertarian-leaning Cato Institute, stated, "He won't be nailed down; he wants ambiguity. And even if you did, his word is a poor predictor of his thoughts and future actions because he's Mitt Romney."

Frank Sharry, executive director of America's Voice, which advocates for immigrant rights, said that when it comes to immigration, Romney is "trying to put lipstick on the pig."

"The pig, his policies, amount to this: All but young undocumented immigrants who serve in the military should be forced out of the country. His rhetoric is this: I want permanent solutions on a bipartisan basis," Sharry said. "He's got the fog machine on in hopes that Latino immigrants will think he's actually going to do something for them. But they get this issue better than the Boston brain trust. They get he actually wants to do something to them."
